text:
Surprising good bagels from this unassuming shop on the north end of Lambertville. 
Very friendly owner.  Decent coffee.  
Definitely a keeper.

Returned today for lunch at 12:30.  

The small dining area was crowded, but I found a deuce in the corner nearest the work area and settled in after ordering their Apple Sausage Special.  

It arrived about 10 minutes later, a small, but tasty Apple Pork Sausage with Maple Chipotle BBQ Sauce, Grilled Onions, and a boatload of fries.  While it was a very good lunch, a couple of observations need be made.  First, the roll of a potato hot dog roll, which was not as good as a crusty French or Italian alternative would have been.  Second, there were a lot more fries than sausage.  They were good fries, but made the sandwich seem even smaller by comparison. 

Still, I liked the ambiance, service, and overall brightness of the place, and did not mind that they made some presentation decisions that detracted from what could have been an exceptional lunch.  

Certainly worth many returns.

Rolling in from Westmoreland County on the Pa Pike, my stomach started growling after almost four hours on the road.  I was near exit 312.  I pulled out my trusty sidekick Mobile Yelp and dialed in "Thai Restaurant."  It came back with two choices in the vicinity, so I opted for the one nearer my location.

Thai Place has an unassuming name, but under its self deprecating identity lurks a very fine Thai kitchen and comfortable dining space turning out very good authentic grub. Where many other restos of this genre approach the atmospherics with dark wood and musty scents, this shop is bright, light, and airy.  The owner works the front of the house enthusiastically, while the single server on the floor managed a warm smile and genuine concern for all the patrons. 

I ordered the Tom Yum Soup (Vegetables) and Drunken Noodles (Chicken).  Both were excellent.  They asked my preferred spice level between 1 and 3, and I asked for max spice.  That's the way I got it, right at the point where my sinuses start to run. Love it!  There were plenty of Veggies and Tofu in the soup, and even more in the Drunken Noodles.  There was enough for dinner the next night.  

The only reason Thai Place did not reach the apex was that my Jasmine Tea arrived in a lovely lime green mug with a teabag, rather than a pot of brewing boiling water and loose tea leaves.  That is the best way to achieve full bodied flavor, and requires fewer return visits to refill the mug with hot water.  I get that good tea is expensive and often unappreciated, but for me it sets apart the very good from the superlative.

Mandarin Garden in Willow Grove, Pa., is a throwback type of Chinese restaurant, the kind I went to with family as a kid in New York. Larger space.  Silk wall hangings. Jade sculptures.  Large menu covering most things from Cantonese through Hunan and Szechuan delicacies.  Seniors taking advantage of the Early Bird specials.  My nostalgia surprised me. 

Most important, the food was very good.  We were celebrating a first birthday in the USA (Chinese national), and were hoping for something a little extraordinary.  Judging from the approving smiles as each dish was devoured, we got what we came for.  

Hot Green Tea arrived immediately along with the dry crisp noodles duck sauce and hot mustard so ubiquitous in Chinese/American houses.  I don't indulge in this table snack, but my friends did in large quantities.  I was selected to do all the ordering, and came up with the following choices: DanDan Noodles (Spicy), Gunpowder Chicken (moderate spice), Jumbo Walnut Shrimp (mild spicy), Crispy Beef with House Made Toffee Cashews (mild spice), Cumin Lamb (spicy), and Tsingtao Beer for all the birthday toasts throughout dinner.  

Realizing that management was Fuzhounese, we did not have high expectations in the spice department.  Their cuisine tends toward sweetness, but there was no harm in asking for some heat.  The kitchen handled each dish in their own fashion.  

The DanDan Noodles were topped with ground pork and a chili sauce mix that was warm, but not what I was hoping for.  Still, our server anticipated this and had given the table a small dish of chili sauce to upgrade the burn.  I used some of it, but my guests did not.  They were content with what was presented, and not as accustomed to heavy spice as me (Good to know).  

The Gunpowder Chicken was also on the mildly sweet side, with a trace of chili on the bird breading, but with the sauce sweetened by an apple.  Unusual, and enjoyable, even if not packing heat.  

The Cumin Lamb was the strongest dish, with plenty of tender meat and cumin, that brought a light sweat to the upper lip.  Not the killer dose of cumin piled on lamb chops in some shops, but strong enough to know they were trying to appease us.  

The Crispy Beef with Toffee Cashews, was also tending toward sweetness, but they had candied the nuts very well, and when eaten with the copious slices of lightly crisped beef, was fun to eat.  

Finally, the Jumbo Shrimp with Walnuts reinforced the theme that the house interpretation of spice and heat began from the perspective that food from this part of China was always degrees of sweetness or sourness, but not really chili pepper fire breathing dragons.  

Again, my friends were fine with all of this and genuinely enjoyed their meals.  It was my own blinders about Szechuan flames that was the issue, not the kitchen attempt to move their dial in my direction.  Once I realized that I was making myself too critical of the platters because I wanted my friends to be happy; and that they were already there and praising me for finding such a nice place to celebrate, that I was able to let go, and just roll with the food, and accept that it was really very good.  

Good lesson to learn.  Better to let the house do what it does well, than to ask them to conform to my unrealistic expectations.

As a facility to hold a large luncheon meeting for about 150 lawyers, this Wyndham Garden Hotel in the heart of Trenton, NJ, is reasonably decent. Walking distance from the courthouses, and parking deck next door, it is easily accessible for most who want to attend to get a good meal while listening to a quality presentation on the latest issues in internet discovery requirements and security. These Bench Bar lunches are always a good place to catch up with friends and hobnob with the judges in this vicinage. 

The banquet room was large enough to commodate all of us, had an adequate sound system that everyone could hear clearly, and a catering kitchen that put out a Cornish hen plate that was tasty and attractive. The carrot cake dessert was a bit over the top, but no one was complaining about the buttercream icing. 

Service was unabtrusive, but kept the meal moving and the water glasses full. 

Can't speak to the rooms above, but this operation handled our bar association meeting quite well.

Despite the hour long wait on Friday night, J.B. Dawson's in the Flowers Mill Shopping Center was worth the wait.  Normally, I would see the waiting room crowd and listen to the hostess's lament of the wait time, and walk out immediately. For some reason, my intuition counseled patience, so I took the radio buzzer they handed me, and found three seats to settle in.  

The  bar was packed with Friday Happy Hour folk getting their zip on, and the two HDTVs in the waiting area were soundlessly tuned to Disney Channel and ESPN.  No one seemed to be paying attention, and the peeps around me were all conversing or buried in their smartphones. The time passed quickly, and we were eventually led to a corner booth in the barroom.  Our server introduced herself, took drink orders and came back promptly to take our order.  We wanted to share the Baby Back Rib and Chicken Tender plate, while young man went with his standard Cheeseburger and Fries.  

Dinner took a little while due to the packed house, but not so long as to become an issue.  When it arrived in the hands of a different server, we beheld a half rack of Baby Backs nicely browned and caramelized on top, and a larger pile of Tempura coated white meat Chicken, plus sides of Garlic Mashed Potatoes and Spiced Apples.  I began to salivate involuntarily as the aroma of the BBQ sauce hit me.  I hoped the first bite would be as seductive.  

It was more than that.   

The meat easily pulled from the bone.  The taste was very good, and the texture just chewy and tender enough to be completely satisfying.  Although there was very little meat left on the bones, I found myself sucking on them to capture every last bit of BBQ taste.  If anything, the Chicken Tenders were even better and a much bigger surprise.  They were big strips of never frozen chicken, breaded in a Tempura style, that were juicy, lightly crunchy and delicious.  The small mound of Mashed Taters were a nice complement to the more exciting pig and bird, but did a great job absorbing whatever sauce was stuck to the plate.  The Spiced Apple was yet another change of directly with its tartness and heat.  

I did not see a smoker on the premises, nor smell it at work, but regardless of how the meal was prepared, the execution was high end and the experience very solidly worth a return visit.

Just returned to Keystone to buy 4 new tires. They recommended Continentals, and I agreed with their assessment of their quality and ride. 

On the way home, one of them blew out!  What?!  True.

I called and returned the next day for a replacement (They had to order it).  They apologized for the experience, although it was clearly a manufacturer's defect, and discounted it down to the cost of mounting and balancing (normally part of the quoted price). They handled the paperwork. 

While this was not a fun time, but Keystone stood behind the product and satisfied me of their integrity. I did not have to ask for some consideration. They offered it straight up. 

I did not mind the small cost of mounting the new tire in light of how well they handled the situation. 

5 Stars if they had taken care of all of it.

When you're down in Bensalem around Neshaminy Mall, finding a good Chinese/Sushi restaurant can be a challenge.  The AMC 24 is a nice place to watch a movie, but the "dinner and" part of that is limited in the immediate vicinity unless you like highway-style fast/casual food.  

Then there is Misto Diner, which I found courtesy of Yelp. As other reviewers said, the location on this site is off by about a mile.  It is further down Neshaminy Blvd after passing Bristol Road if coming from the rear of NM, in a small strip mall anchored by 7-11.  Keep going.  You will get there. It is worth the search, as the quality of the room and cuisine are considerably above the standard Chinese American shop.  

White table clothes and red cloth napkins are a nice touch suggesting a bit of quality control in the product.  The owner family is present and in charge.  They bring care and pride to the effort.  Although I did not ask, our server seemed to be the father.  He had a Jackie Chan appearance; friendly, engaged, and humorous.  His bifocals tried to hide his bemused visage as we asked questions about the menu and the history of the joint.  

We settled on Hot and Sour Soup, Chicken Broccoli in Garlic Sauce, and Shredded Pork Mei Fun.  The soup was a rich, thick, spicy mix.  We added a spoonful of Chili Oil to bring out more of the hot richness.  It was a nice improvement to an already good bowl of soup.  The Chicken dish was off menu as we asked for garlic sauce as opposed to the Hunan style base.  The meat was tender and very tasty.  The broccoli cut into small enough sprigs and excellently cooked.  The mei fun was also good, but not at the same level as the other dishes.

To be clear, Misto Diner is still a traditional Chinese American restaurant found in most suburban areas, but it is a very good one.  It should not be mistaken for an authentic Chinese restaurant found in more heavily Chinese populated parts of the region. But, if you find yourself in this neck of the woods this is a very good choice.  Too, they have no problem giving you an extra pot of tea if you want to wait there for your movie time.

It's a bit surprising to find a decent BBQ joint in a back room of the Best Western Motel on Street Road, Bensalem, Pa.  The place has almost zero atmosphere, no aroma of smoking meat, no beer spillage on the floor, and no one in boots nor large apron cutting the brisket.  There is only Julie, the matron of the house and jack of all serving trades, handling just about everything.  She bartends, takes food orders, serves everything that comes out of the kitchen, and then collects payment at the end of the night.  She makes it personal by asking everyone's first name, and remembering them throughout. 

Don't let the environment deter you from coming in.  The grub is very good.  First, there are several beers on tap or bottles, although on this Sunday night they seemed to be out of most of the good crafties.  Still, my End of The World draft was pleasantly cold and refreshing at $4 for 10oz. Friends seemed to be downing Yards brew as quickly as it was poured.  

My crew of three ordered Half BBQ Chicken (3 sides, corn bread, fries); Coffee Rubbed Brisket (3 sides, hush puppies, fries); and a third rack of St. Louis style Ribs (4 bones, 2 sides, fries).  There was a ton and a half of food.  And, it was all very good to amazing.  The Half Chicken came our golden skinned without a crack in the covering.  It was uber-moist and had a wonderful flavor.  It needed no accompanying sauce to kick it up a notch, as it was really an apex bird.  The Ribs were very good, but not the meatiest I have encountered.  The dry rub was very solid, but I found it needed a little liquid zing to get to my preferred taste level.  The table had 2 unmarked bottle rockets, one based in vinegar, the other, tomato.  Both okay, but not the strength of the cuisine.  

The unexpected star of the show was the Brisket.  This cut of beef in normally dry in my experience, but this was not the case at Ben's.  Whether the coffee rub, or the time in the smoker, this thin sliced pound of nearly black carne was just so moist, tender and delicious.  The taste of brisket was very present, but the secret sauce brought out undertones and texture that truly opened our eyes.  Even the normal stringiness of the cut was an asset on the platter.  It made for more surface area to hold the smoke and rub.  Can't say that I actually tasted coffee, but that wasn't needed to find this dish remarkable.  

There are a few downsides to eating at Ben's.  First, service was slow by definition.  Only one person doing everything.  She made a few mistakes on our orders, but nothing so egregious as to require markdowns.  Then, we were given plastic utensils to negotiate the load of food.  They simply were not up to the task of dealing with the meat and sides.  Broken fork prongs, snapped knives were a part of the night.  How much better to invest in real steel blades and spikes to control the contest.  As mentioned above, they seemed to be out of many of their listed brews. 

Prices are fair for the menu and (lack of) atmosphere.  

Put the smokers out in the parking lot for all to see, maintain your beer inventory, and provide customers with the tools to subdue the wild animals on our plates, and Ben (Franklin)'s could become a great BBQ mainstay in this area.

I found myself here for lunch and dinner one day last week due to a long court appearance.  I have no complaints about the kitchen, nor the service of Spice Thai Cuisine. 

The space is all cool dark wood and deep red texture that took me far away from the courthouse for a peaceful interlude.  The young server was gracious, engaging and had a high watt smile that made ordering a pleasure.  I asked if this was truly a Thai house, and she assured me the owner and chef were legit.  

For lunch I had the Hot Jungle Special at heat level 4 (out of 7).  The plate arrived loaded with fresh veggies and a mildly pepper/curry sauce that brought everything together nicely, but wasn't quite the inferno I was looking for.  Still, it was totally enjoyable, and I used it as a measure should I chose to return for another round.  That I returned for dinner was totally unexpected, unless you consider leaving a briefcase behind as an act of kismet.  I had to return that evening to get it, and while there decided to sit for dinner. 

I supped on Pad Thai with Calamari and heat level 5. This was more like it!  The meal arrived in a large ceramic plate with a built in pedestal.  It looked beautiful.  The spice level was excellent, and the Calamari was fresh and scored in a crosshatch pattern to expose max surface area.  It was soft and pliant.  The overall experience was delicious. I took enough home for another dinner.

Spice Thai Cuisine is a very good restaurant, if not quite at the level of Aroi Thai or some of the other specialty houses in the area.  No doubt, it could reach that apex with a little more time and imagination.

Wandered in after court one morning, needing coffee and something, having skipped breakfast to get out the door early.  Lily's was sitting there, cute windows suggesting something different inside. Wooden floors, large chalk board menus, dessert displayed right where they can do the most damage to good intentions.  And, bagels that looked more like they were from a ring toss game with sesame seeds and onion flakes.  Had to have it!
Fresh, chewy and flavorful.  Good coffee. Yes, and lemon bars that squeeze the salivaries into submission with a crunchy smooth sweet tartness. 
I walked out thinking this was a cool place; well worth another try, and wishing Lily's was in Newtown.

Great Harvest Bread Company sits in the same large Village of Newtown Shopping Center where McCaffery's now is. On impulse I went in this morning to see what was available for breakfast.  The friendly assistant bakery/counter person told me the muffins were still in the oven, but they had very fresh Blueberry Cream Cheese Scones available.  She pointed to them and allowed me to come around the counter to have a closer look (and take a photo).  

I don't know much about scones, except for eating them a few years ago when in England.  I remembered a hard, cookie-like outside and a textured chew.  These were quite different. They were the shape of scones, and soft through and through. No crunch. Much like a muffin in the shape of a scone. I liked it, the same as I would have enjoyed the muffin. Perhaps they were less sweet than their cousins. 

The loaves of bread were tempting, and I will try some of them over time.  The coffee was good, the beans roasted locally.  

Their wall menu suggests that their sandwiches are worth trying, as does the video attached to this Yelp listing.  

I look forward to future visits and sampling more of what appears to be high end healthy bread and all things that can be created out of it.  

Very happy to have them in Newtown.

I found Kriscroix while cruising Yelp for a change of pace meal in the area. Yesterday, I finally had the time to go there for an early lunch after dropping son off at the mall for a Magic tournament (that's another story). 

On first approach it is easy to miss this place on the end of a small strip on the south side of a particularly ugly stretch of Rt. 1 in Fairless Hills. The signage is small, and first glance is of a store that looks like a beer distributor, with many brew signs on the windows.  Don't be deterred.  Walk in, turn left, and you are in a 1970's dining room with comfortable blue leatherette booths, brass fitting, and wall to wall maritime memorabilia.  Very seaworthy!

I was fortunate to have Tracy as my server.  She was friendly, funny, and took time and pride to show me through the menu and make useful suggestions.  From the reviews I knew I was going to have good choices, but decided to go with the standard Fish and Chips for my first taste.  It was a nice size Cod Fillet, batter dipped in a light English style coating, and fried enough to slightly harden the batter into a shell that left the fish soft and tender.  No oily taste nor texture.  The French Fries were not house made, but still crispy and fresh tasting. It came with Tartar Sauce or Cocktail Sauce.  I did not ask for Malt Vinegar, but I suspect it was back in the kitchen.  A tin of Old Bay was also placed on the table for the fries. A side of Cole Slaw came along for the ride. It was mayo based, but also fresh and enjoyable.  All the while Tracy was refilling my coffee mug, and telling me more about the restaurant. The only thing missing was having the Fish and Chips served in a newspaper cone as done in England. 

I don't normally do dessert, but Tracy asked if I wanted to hear what was available.  Ok. I was game to listen. She said a few options, and then got to the Fried Oreos and Fried Twinkies. What?!  I went for it. 

A few minutes later out came a large white shallow bowl with four halves of Twinkies, apparently wrapped in a crepe-like blanket, covered in powdered sugar, and drizzled with raspberry sauce.  The Twinkie Cream was slightly oozing out and mixing with the white and red.  

How did it taste?  Well, imagine the first time you ate a Twinkie as a kid; that soft, sweet, creamy surprise...Now, imagine it hot, with extra sugar, and a hint of raspberry stirring your palate... Taste it? 

It was a fun dessert.  

Kriscroix Restaurant. Highly Recommended for fish and fun.

Slate Bleu (Blue Slate) Restaurant is part of a very attractive adaptive reuse of an old brick 19th Century building in Doylestown.  For that alone, the structure is worth a close look. The architect gets 5 Stars for adaptation and execution. 

The restaurant is Au Provence French style look and feel.  Dark wood tones, center floor bar, and a quiet sensibility with white tablecloths, benches along the walls, and simple chairs.  The bartender (owner?) serves as hostess and maître d., serving drinks to the tables after she makes them. A nice touch.  Our waitress was friendly, knowledgeable and unobtrusive. 

The dinner menu is not extensive, but covers all the food groups.  The chef is creative and makes the effort to bring his best to his work.  We had the Green Salad, Bronzino with a Fruit Salsa Sauce, and for dessert shared a Pistachio Souffle.

 The salad was basically a fresh spring mix, but with a dressing that tasted weak in combination with the greens.  The Bronzino (Mediterranean Sea Bass) was very well presented, light tasting with a tasty Mexican-esque fruit salsa combination piled high on the fillet. It was very enjoyable. It was a daily special @ $28 per. Finally, the Souffle was made from scratch and came with a gravy boat full of hot chocolate for pouring into its center.  While very light, fluffy and yummy, the $15. plus price was a chill to the digestion. (I knew in advance and decided to bite the silver bullet in favor of making my companion happy. You know how that is.) 

So, although Slate Bleu is an attractively appointed French/Country space, and the cuisine is very good for the most part, there is a sticker shock that accompanies the experience.  While I would return, it will only be when I have a very special occasion. When a dinner for two comes in over the century mark without drinks, reservations about reservations are appropriate.

This is an excellent and honest auto repair shop. 
Too bad Yelp thinks it is in Clifton Heights, when it is in fact in Newtown, Bucks County.
Check the website to get the right information.
Once you do, you will find a place you can absolutely trust with your car. 
Five stars is not far off.

I have been buying my tires here for several years.  Great service and prices, and helpful suggestions for safety where the rubber meets the road. Call ahead for an appointment, or drive over, and they take care of you and your car.

"I saw a werewolf with a Chinese menu in his hand,
Walking through the streets of SoHo in the rain.
He was looking for a place called Lee How Fook's. 
Gonna get a big dish of beef chow mein.

Aaooooooo
Werewolves of London. 
Aaooooooo.

Aaooooooo.
Werewolves of London.
Aaooooooo."

The historic truth is that the werewolf wasn't from SoHo, London, but Chinatown, Philadelphia.  Poetic license for a largely underappreciated songwriter and rock performer, Warren Zevon. He spent a lot of time in the city, especially in the early 1980s, when he was living with, and ultimately married to a well know radio DJ here. They lived on Rittenhouse Square for several years, before divorce drove him back to California.  If you were very fortunate, you saw his concert at the TLA on South Street, and had your musical life changed.

 He really visited the small Cantonese restaurant on the corner of 11th and Spring Streets and used it for inspiration for the song, "Werewolves of London." Even the kitchen door in an alley off Spring Street, found its way into the lyrics, as the door you must not open unless you sought the fate of the, "Little old lady, got mutilated late last night..." It remains a scary place even today with decades of thick, black grease caked to the walls and pavement. Who knows what evil lurks in those sewer drains?! 

So, I was there the other day after a haircut across the street. I had been singing his songs as I drove to Philly, and wanted to pay homage to the man and have some good Cantonese food. 

The dining room was small, with no more than eight tables. It was well preserved in dark mahogany stained panels.  It was fairly clean and tidy for a joint in C.Town. We were the only customers on arrival, and took liberties to walk around a bit and take a few photos. Amazingly, not a thing memorializing Zevon. Maybe this third generation Asian kitchen doesn't know from American rock and roll. Warren would no doubt get a laugh out of that. 

We ordered Salt Baked Squid, Orange Beef and Fish Hot Pot; more than enough for two of us, but plenty to bring home for the sons. They were all very good, if not best of breed. The squid was tender and mildly salty as expected.  The beef was plentiful with a good dark red amber sauce and sliced onion and green pepper. The fish arrived in a covered casserole still bubbling from the fire in the kitchen. Soft, moist and delicious. Each dish was $11.95. Credit cards accepted. 

This was one of the better Cantonese meals eaten in C.Town, made more desirable by the ability to think about Warren Zevon sitting at the table in back, chowing down and noodling about a song that we are still singing long after his death. 

Aaoooooooo!

It would seem that this supermarket is now part of the 1st Oriental Supermarket group that has a huge facility down at 6th and Washington in South Philly. Looks and feels the same. I think I also recognized some of the clerks and cashiers. 

Anywho, this store carries almost everything you needed for a well stocked Asian kitchen. From butcher to fishmonger, soy sauce and vinegar, noodles from around the world, and even those secret ingredients needed for great dumplings, are right at hand. Vietnam, Thailand, Korea, Cambodia and China are all well represented. The green grocer department has fruit and veggies that often can only be found where they are grown in Asia. They even had a box of super fat green frogs for exotic eating or taking home as pets. 

It was a pleasure to grab a grocery cart after a good dim sum brunch right next door and walk it off up and down the aisles.  The free parking replicates what they have down the city, but it sure makes life easier not to have to hunt and pay for a space for wheels.

Papillon Cafe in Goodnoe Corner, Newtown, PA, was a first for me. A French Kosher Organic Cafe in the heart of this 325 year old ville. It is a sign of the growing diversity in my home town, and it may actually make it, with something tasty for everyone. Even plenty for gluten frees.

This Sunday afternoon, only the owner was running the show. He had a perfect friendly personality, making me feel immediately welcome. His middle eastern accent with French lilt suggested the nature of the house. The shelf full of great looking pastries was one direction, the long list of crepes, another; and Paninis and onion soup, yet other possibilities. The weather frigid, I went for a hot tuna melt panini and coffee washdown. 

The plate was served by the Le Monsieur, sporting the split sandwich on crisp and crumbly pressed baguette, and a pile of thin sliced pan fried potatoes with a garlicky white sauce drip. They were fine, if not inspired. Certainly, a solid contribution for lunch. The pomme frite were interesting - served cold. Rather than being the expected French fries, it became a very good cool potato salad side dish. Like it, even if unintended.

The java was also surprising. Although equipped for expresso drinks, all I wanted was something hot and strongly caffeinated. What I received was a corrugated paper cup that required no heat shielding cuff (clever). For the milk stir-in, I was handed the large stainless frothing pitcher full of cow juice, heated with the steam wand. I poured and stirred like a rookie barista. Great touch, and the Groundwork beans showed their strong roasted roots. Impressive.

I really liked Papillon, but it could use a little TLC. With only one person doing the entire operation, the details  got away from him. Someone bussing tables and sweeping up would eliminate crumbs on tables and floor and make the experience an unqualified pleasure.

3.5 STARS

Our very personable waitperson described Jones as serving, "American Comfort Food."  Even before seeing the menu my mind was wandering about what that would mean to my Chinese friends experiencing local cuisine for just about the first time.  For me, a brownie and a glass of milk is comfort food, but for anyone lacking a database of experience, they might have some fairly wild ideas.  

Turns out, they didn't have a clue and relied on me to order for them.  Okay. I was up for the challenge.  How about a good burger for the 19 year old, and a turkey club for his mother?  Handled.  I've been curious about the chicken & waffles craze, so when I saw it on the menu, I stopped reading.  

We were all satisfied with our lunches.  The burger was a big hit with the young guy.  He believes burgers are the height of American culture.  He could be right.  Turkey is not well known in China, but the combination with bacon, lettuce, spicy mayo and tomato seemed to captivate my friend.  I moved quickly to remove the long wooden picks used to hold each quarter together, as she was unaccustomed to this shiv and nearly poked her eye out.  

The fried chicken arrived as a breast/thigh combo with golden brown crispy coat.  It was good, but perhaps a little too salty.  The waffle was the better companion, done well on an iron and still steamy soft within with a hint of sweetness to counterbalance the NaCl on the bird.  As a lover of Southern Fried Chicken, I did not truly appreciate the passionate embrace of these two carb loads on one plate.  Call me old fashioned, but I will stick with waffles for breakfast and fried chicken for other meals; although I might be convinced to change my mind if someone poured pure maple syrup over both and allowed me this sticky indulgence. 

Jones is a very nice facility with high ceilings, which make the brown sandstone columns around the house quite attractive and draw eyes upward, giving the sense of a mountain lodge in Red Rock, Sedona.  

Made the saying of "Grace" seem totally appropriate.

Shing Kee is one of the few Chinese houses on Washington Avenue.  It serves of Hong Kong/ Cantonese style dishes that are fairly authentic, very tasty, and at good prices.  It came highly recommended by my friends who work in the area, and rightly so.

Service was above average in that promptness and smiles were part of the interaction with the servers.  My only nit was that there were two large HDTVs on the walls that were both tuned to the same channel that no one was watching, although the Eagles preseason game was available.  They just couldn't manage to change over to the game despite saying they would.  I just decided to finish quickly, and catch the game on the car radio.  

The dinner was good aside from that annoyance. Scallion Pancakes were two deep and as wide as a large dinner plate.  Not too greasy, and enough green onion flavor.  The Pork Cutlets were large, well fried and very tasty is a good Garlic Sauce.  There was some bone left, but it was easy to pick them up and work the meat off.  I appreciated that they were a large size and non-oily.  The ubiquitous Broccoli Florets were ho-hum. 

Shing Kee is a definite keeper, especially in light of the absence of many legit alternatives in the area.  It also is a good driving destination as they are in a shopping center with a decent parking lot.  While there, there are a couple of markets for grabbing your Asian ingredients for your adventures in Asian cooking.

This stretch of Bustleton Avenue in Northeast Philadelphia is lined with one strip mall after another, and it is hard to tell them apart. Each has a few restaurants in them, but unless you know what you are looking for you are likely to become numb from their sameness and just keep driving. Taj India could unfortunately suffer than ignominious fate, but luckily is located right next door to the new Georgian Breads, and a street before the new Super Wawa.  It is worth finding. 

This is a vegetarian house.  Their menu consists of six pages of mostly Kerala delights, with a little other North and South India thrown in to keep it interesting and popular. It was a perfect place to settle down after excellent foot massage right up the road at Lavendar Spa.  

We shared these dishes: Sweet Corn Soup, Chili Pakoda, Kaju Curry, Vegetable Jalfrezi and Garlic Naan.  All were good to near excellent, except for the Masala Tea which was tasteless and disappointing. I love most forms of corn soup, and this was fairly standard. Sweet kernels with a light dusting of curry. Not sure if it came from a fresh ear of corn or a can, but it was still good.  The Chili Pakora was a nice surprise - Jalapeno peppers stuffed with mashed potato and spices, dipped in a heavy pakora breading and deep fried.  Very spicy and a strong nod to Indo-Mex cuisine.  The Kaju (cashew) Curry was a cool play on nuttiness in a mild, almost sweet pale orange curry.  Terrific. Perfect for sopping up with the Garlic Naan, which was more lightly tandoored than most I have eaten.  The texture was not heavy with oil nor garlic, despite its strong taste.  Very well done. Finally, the Veggie Jalfrezi provided a mix of mostly standard local green is a pleasant moderately heated curry.  We went with Level 5 on all dishes, except the Chili, and found it adequate for our tastes.  Regardless, some were hotter than others, but quite satisfactory across the board.  

Service was friendly and efficient, and prices on the pleasant side of reasonable. $44 for all the above four dishes, naan and tea.

There are several decent Indian kitchens in this area, and Taj should be on your list when in the neighborhood and in the mood for quality vegetarian meals.

Rediscovering Bordentown, I stopped into Angie's Family Restaurant for breakfast last week to check it out. 

True, there is something of a time vortex effect within its shop.  The colorful hand painted murals, lazy tables basking in the sun along the front windows, and the small counter with maybe a half dozen spinners, all combined to catch me off guard and drop me into somewhere in my youth, perhaps 1972 in Boulder, Colorado.  

It may have played tricks with my mind, but it did not impact my taste buds.  My French Toast, Orange Juice and Coffee Special was fresh and tasty. The FT nicely cauterized by the hot grill to provide the light crunch I crave. My server wasn't Angie (I asked), but she and her mother had worked with Ms. A for many years and knew her to be a lovely person.  

In fact, this joint is so square it's hip.  It suits its neighborhood in this transforming river town.  If Bonaparte was still here, he would be a regular.  

Those fortunate enough to come often must call this place, "Angie's," as there is no need for the rest of the name.  

Angie speaks for herself.

APRIL 2, 2015 UPDATE - Went with the Breakfast Special today; Kielbasi, Onion and Jalapeno Omelet @ $8.95, a bit pricey compared to the rest of the menu, but I liked the concept.  It included Home Fries, Toast and Coffee.  The Omelet was not as I imagined it.  Rather than chunks of fresh Kielbasi from the Polish deli, it was a thin sliced pink colored processed meat-food that had no resemblance in look, nor taste to the Polish Sausage.  Too, the Jalapenos were the pickled and sliced version, rather than fresh pepper cut and sautéed before being thrown into the mix.  Overall, a disappointment.  Stick with the tried and true regular menu options going forward.

Dos Amores (Two Loves) Mexican Cuisine is a strictly take out stall in the Village of Newtown Farmers Market. Along with the rest of the shops it is only open Thursday through Saturday, so there is only a small window for getting in/out with a good sampling of their south of the border offerings. Most are of the self contained variety, like enchiladas, quesadillas, empanadas and chile rellenos, that can be prepared in advance, kept cool and then heated at home in the microwave or oven. You can also eat in the market within the common dining area at the back of the store. 

That is what I did. I ordered beef and chicken empanadas, and asked them to be heated for consumption in the market. That took all of 3 minutes. They were handed to me in a paper boat with small containers of salsa and sour cream. Other sides were available, but as it was my first dive into their delectables, I opted to forego any additions. 

Both empanadas were very good. The dough was crisp and strong enough to stay together as I bit through them. The chicken and ground beef were both nicely spiced, and I was also able to pour more salsa inside through the bite hole, and keep it contained until next munch. The beef was cooked with more chili powder, and had a warmer profile than the chicken. Still, I enjoyed them both for their freshness and authenticity. Like everything else in this market, prices are high. You pay the same as if you were dining in a full service restaurant. 

The atmosphere of the farmers market is entertaining with all the Amish/Mennonite vendors dressed in their traditional garb and speaking colloquially. That is certainly worth the premium paid, as it is the only place in town where there is a real cultural exchange. Admittedly, Dos Amores lacks the Pennsylvania Dutch accent, but their Spanish makes up for that. 

I really should come here more often just to step away from modern times for a little while and enjoy all the interesting grub.

This Big Bear Natural Foods in Langhorne, Pa., is one of five shops in the Bucks/Mercer area providing a huge array of vitamins, minerals, supplements and organic/vegan foods to a grossly underserved segment of our community.  Family owned since 1971, it has deep roots and a loyal following.  While some question their choice of locations (both stores on Lincoln Highway - Rt. 1 - feel sketchy, there is little doubt that there was considerable savings in these spots as opposed to more upscale commercial zones.  So, if you want those healthful things that can't be found in supermarkets, and don't want to pay Whole Foods or GNC prices, then The Bear is the place to shop.

I am a semi-regular customer in the to Bucks stores.  My own focus is on quality vitamins and supplements like, Grape Seed Extract, Saw Palmetto, Ginseng, Co Q 10, and Vitamin B combos.  Over the past 20 + years I like to think they have helped keep me healthy and slowed the aging process.  

There are only a few natural food stores within a 20 minute drive from home, and the majority of them are Big Bear outlets.  Luckily, they have everything I use in multiple brands and strengths.  The staff is knowledgeable and usually friendly.  I am comfortable with the treatment and satisfied with the results of my visits.  I have never sampled their juice bar, nor eaten their prepared food.  I prefer making my own fresh smoothies, and I live/work too far from their spots to make it for breakfast or lunch.  

It's very good to have Big Bear around all this time.  Hope it has been worth it for them, too.

There may have been changes in ownership and management, but Italian Peoples Bakery on Butler Street in Trenton, NJ, continues to turn out great bread, pastries, cakes and deli sandwiches like they were partying in 1999.  

I recently rediscovered this small shop on one-way Butler Street, where double and triple parking is a way of life.  Still found a spot for the wheels and walked into a doughy time machine.  The high glass display counters. Back shelves filled with donuts, loaves of many types, and great guttural Trentonese dialect, sent me back in time to when there were several awesome Italian bakeries in the Burg, and they competed with each other for quality dominance.  The last baker standing is the latest incarnation of IPB, for whatever might be missing, their bread remains classic and museum worthy.  

The deli in back still offers wonderful sandwiches with the star of the show always the bread in which it is captured.  On two recent visits I found that the Home Roasted Turkey, Swiss, Lettuce and Mayo on Onion Roll, and the follow up Chicken Salad on small Torpedo Roll, to be delicious and priced for smiles.  Zaftig sandwiches like these for under $5, are too good to be true, unless the kitchen and ovens are trapped in the prior century.  Each creation was really two meals.  The wall of drink coolers provided substantial choice, and there was always budgetary room for one of their large cookies, cannoli, or even deep double fudge brownies.  

Yes. You do have to navigate into the inner recesses of Chambersburg, and deal with all the one way streets, and the sudden loss of GPS signals.  But, once you're there and exploring this historic haven, you are in for a mighty treat.

Richman's Ice Cream on Bristol Emile Road in Levittown, Pa., is a local burger joint that emphasizes its ice cream, but does a bang up job on their beef pucks.  It has a 1960's feel to it, with indoor/outdoor dining and order/pickup windows. You order and the receipt has a number that will be called when your meal is ready.  

We stopped in after shopping in the area for a late lunch.  We ordered their Original Burger (Double with cheese, onion, lettuce, tomato, mayo and a spicy chipotle-type sauce, on a bun), and a Southwest Burger (avocado, lettuce, tomato, cheese and extra spicy sauce).  The combo provides an ample load of fries and a large drink, so we ordered one combo to share those extras. At $14, it was a good deal.

The burgers were hand packed and loose enough to grill up well and retain that special grease that makes good burgers, great. They reminded of 5 Guys, but better in that they were not crushed in wrapping, and the sauces were nicely complimentary.  Liked them a lot.  Only negative was the quality of the roll, which was not strong enough to hold together after a few bites.  It became necessary to find the plastic forks so as to avoid having to pick up the pieces falling out of the sandwich with sticky fingers. A better roll (potato or Kaiser) would offer longer support for the weighty innards. The fries were well done (the way I like them), and the lemonade tart enough to quench two dry whistles. 

We didn't get a chance to try the ice cream, as although we sat outside under blue sunny skies at first, by the time we were halfway through the meal, the skies had darkened, and it was raining pretty hard, forcing us inside, where it was crowded and difficult to move around.  Will try their 'scream next time. 

All in all, a pleasant burgerlicious experience.

What is it about bridges?

Since childhood on the upper west side of Manhattan when I played underneath the George Washington Bridge, they have held a special fascination for me.  From ground level, the soaring towers and thick cables looked like a magical castle drawbridge. Even now I get an excited sensation every time I walk or drive over even the most modest crossing over a creek.  

It is hard to believe that before 1926 when the Ben was opened there was only ferry service carrying people and commerce across the Delaware. Too, it is passing strange that it was not until 1956 that Big Ben Blue received its current name, and that it was the largest suspension bridge in the world for a while.  

Yes. It can be maddening to deal with the traffic during rush hours, and the cost makes us wish for the return of ferries.  Still, when it lights up at night, or we cross it on a weekend and can look upstream or down, the sense of flight and the required leap of faith that the roadway will hold us on our passage to the other side, blend into a metaphor for life.   

Someone once said, "Great cities have great bridges..."  I am sure Ben would agree.

When I finally got around to dealing with curtains for the French doors leading to the back porch, I had to admit I had no idea how to deal with them.  Way above my pay grade!  

So, breaking it down into the elements I thought involved, I went first to a fabric store to find material for drapes.  Twenty overwhelming and mind numbing minutes later, I was defeated by the aisle upon aisle of material that could be used to make curtains.  No wonder it had taken so long for me to address this project.  

Serendipity plays funny games, and if not for my tortured look as I approached a saleswoman at the measuring/cutting counter in the rear of this megastore, I might have never known of Marburn Curtains.  I asked this saintly person how I should approach buying fabric for curtains, and how find someone to actually measure and make them.  She looked at me as if I was not the first clueless guy to ask this dumb question.  It was like; "If you gotta ask, then you really don't want to know..."  

She was right.  I was going about it entirely the wrong way.  

Then, she told me a secret that lifted the dark clouds and pointed the way.   "Go to Marburn Curtains in Bensalem.  They have premade curtains in all styles and sizes.  They can help you out."  

Thirty minutes later I walked into this throwback 20th Century warehouse/store that had more curtains hanging in the aisles than I could look at.  The shop was staffed by a crew of ladies whose life was curtains.  One took my hand and led me to the back of the store where the kind of curtains I described were displayed.  We were down to less than a hundred now, and the task seemed manageable.  I finally selected the two packs of 60 X 84 beautiful beige lined silk-like pieces, complete with grommet holes and the necessary hardware for installation.   

All this and immense piece of mind for under $70.  What had been so daunting was reduced to a simple transaction.  

Next step - installation. 

(To be continued)

Located in the White House Building on South State Street, in the same location as Duck Sauce, Snacks by the Pound is the latest tenant to occupy the other corner space.  We wish them great success there!  I mention its neighbor because that is the way I first noticed this shop set back from the street.  I came out of Duck Sauce and walking on the covered front porch I noticed the new store and went in to have a look.  

I didn't know that homemade chocolate would taste so good after a good spicy Asian meal, but it did!  In fact, I suggest that these owners talk to each other and start to cross market their goods.  A little chocolate delivered with the lunch or dinner bill would be a great touch (and better than the Andes Mints).  A discount coupon for a quality Chinese or Thai repast with the purchase of $10. worth of candy, would also be a hot commodity.  Maybe they are already doing that, but I did not see it. Come talk to me.

S/P is a veritable wonderland of sweets set in a well appointed comfortable setting. Made to look "country," it succeeds in taking you away from the world outside and dropping you into a childhood daydream.  Hard not to smile and salivate when looking at the enormity of the collection here, and reminiscing about those candies you craved as a kid.  

Yes. It is a little decadent, but it is so innocent that no one will turn you in to the diet police.

Heng Fa Market on 10th Street in Chinatown is a relatively small shop specializing as a green grocer, butcher and fish monger. No canned goods here. Everything looked fresh and well maintained. Prices were better than the Asia basement store, and the crowded aisles we're ample proof. 

There are only handheld baskets as there is no room for shopping carts. That limits how much you can buy in one visit unless you come with a team to help carry your take. There is constant bumping into folks, and the floor around the seafood department is always damp, so some caution is required. But, the jostling is worthwhile to secure the quality goods offered here. Just be sure to secure your wallet because there is more than one type of fishing going on. 

We picked up meat, veggies and eggs ($3.50 for 3 doz. XLs!), paying much less than in the aforementioned dungeon. The cashier line runs up the vegetable aisle, so you can imagine the low level confusion going on. 

Still, if you enjoy interacting with humanity the experience was almost enjoyable. Just glad we weren't running for a bus.

While I will always prefer the real French pastries found on every corner in even the smallest ville in France, at least this particular Paris Baguette has the touch and feel of a real old fashioned Boulanger. Wooden floors and display shelves, mural of the Tour Eifel, and decent cakes, breads, tarts and coffee, make this a pleasant stop and relaxation spot.

This is the third PB I have visited, and it is by far the most comfortable on a human scale.  The others have either been too big and cold (Edison), or too small and subterranean (Elkins Park).  This one does it well. 

Glad they got it right this time.

I liked my breakfast at Hampton House Waffles & Eatery. 

The dining room was nicer than expected, and service was outspokenly friendly and accommodating. I sat at the short counter where I was attended to by several people.  Coffee arrived promptly, and my order was taken with interest.  The server wanted to be sure that I knew what I was getting with the Gus' Special Omelet. He described in detail that it was a pancake type egg dish, with the home fries, as well as the feta, onions and green peppers inside the egg shell.  No problem. That was exactly what I wanted. 

It arrived about ten minutes later, filling the entire plate from rim to rim.  The rye toast arrived a few moments later, lathered in butter. A few shakes of the pepper shaker and I was good to go. 

It was a solid, filling meal.  Plenty of ingredients to load it up, with each element identifiable on the tongue. Maybe, a little more feta would have been helpful. The toast was also worthy of special recognition, as it was very hot from the toaster, and had a great crunch. 

Next time, have to try the namesake waffles.

Ashni Kumar Guru is the master chef and personality behind Guru Indian Cuisine on Cambridge Lane in Newtown, Pa.  It is housed in the former Mexican/Guatemalan restaurant, Mamita's, and retains the colors and Latin feel.  It reminds of the Indo-Mex restaurants I ran into in Montreal; full blown spice assault with a Tequila chaser. 

Chef Guru has a great feel for the elements of Indian cooking; mixing taste, texture and color with fresh ingredients to produce an array of very good to excellent plates that are as appealing to the eye, as to the tongue.  He makes a point of coming out to meet his customers to be sure they are satisfied and inquire about anything they might desire.  His visage tucked under a Philly's cap was a personal touch that is so often lacking in other restaurants.  

We came in for Saturday buffet around 1:00.  The joint was empty but for us.  Surprising given the popularity of the place, but maybe not given it being the day after Christmas.  The spread was attractive, but fairly limited in options, with only a handful of offerings from all food groups.  It was enough to get an idea about the quality of the food, but not enough to really sample a broad cross section of the menu.  I am neglectful to record what we were eating, but the two chicken dishes were very good with wonderful creamy spiced tawny sauces, and the vegetable choices were tasty.  Fresh Naan brought hot to the table was a great approach to balancing the more mass produced buffet table with something prepared just for us.  As always, the Naan was a wonderful pinch and sponge to grab all the delicious sauces on the plate.  Contrarily, the Mango Lassi was watery and tasted of coming from a mix, rather than any approximation of fresh fruit. 

I want to return to order off the menu to experience main courses prepared only for us, as something is always lost with a buffet.  After experiencing Guru's apex efforts I will be in a better position to fully appreciate the magic of his kitchen.

JANUARY 21, 2016 - The Bucks County Department of Health just cited Guru for 13 health code violations dealing with hand washing, proper cooling. All correctable, but stay informed about this by visiting the County website where the reports and follow up inspections are found.

FEBRUARY 23, 2016 -  Updated Inspection Report. Many violations corrected.

Maybe it's because I have visited China Café often enough over the past few years to be its Duke, or maybe it's the way the owner of this twenty plus year establishment smiles at me when she sees me walk in, but the food here seems to be getting better.  

The joint still looks every day of its longevity in Lalor Plaza, and sorely needs a makeover that brightens it up and takes the storage out of the dining room, and it wouldn't be the worse thing in the world if Mr. Café trimmed his Confucian beard.  Nonetheless, some kind of magic is happening in the kitchen that is creating more distinct and enjoyable dishes from the lunch menu.  

Today, the Hot & Sour Soup took me by surprise.  I told the Mrs. that I did not want MSG in it, and she assured me there would be none.  Sure enough, the small bowl arrived without the telltale sheen on the surface that denotes the presence of the food enhancer to which I am allergic. It was loaded with tofu, sprouts and other veggies, and had a great taste.  Next up was the Roast Pork Egg Foo Young.  It came out as two pancake omelets full of sliced pork, veggies, and covered in the ubiquitous brown sauce.  The eggs were not particularly oily and the sauce was hot without the aftertaste of sitting around too long.  Liked it a lot. 

No one will mistake China Café for fine dining, but it seems to have found its equilibrium at a higher point than most other local wok shops.  The ingredients seemed fresher, and the attention to detail and timing of the elements more rigorous.  Given that I rarely give such houses more than an Okay grade, the upmark for this place is significant.  

Whatever the reason, China Café has my appreciation, with sincere hope that it continues on this path.

Very glad I went alone to check out Texas Roadhouse on Street Road, Bensalem, PA. The wait for a table would have been at least an hour given the size of the SRO crowd in the entranceway and milling by the front door. Solo I was able to find the solitary empty bar stool and jump right on without putting my name on a waiting list. This was a first experience with this outfit and I was amazed by the full house and amplitude of the noise. 

What was going on here to make it so popular? I soon found out.

No fewer than 3 bartenders stopped by to introduce themselves within the first ten minutes, with the first taking my order for a Sam's Winter Ale pint and a Smokehouse Burger. They all called me by name and seemed genuinely interested in my satisfaction. Despite the full house, and arrival of a few couples now standing around the small square bar hoping for a double vacancy, I never felt rushed nor put upon for ordering a sandwich rather than a large slab of grilled beef and dinner. 

And, the medium finish burger was exactly what I got. Half pounder. Hot pink core. Cheddar/American cheese blend. Tomato. Red onion. Mushroom. BBQ sauce. Sesame seed roll. Squirt of Heinz red and I was ready to dive in. 

It was excellent. Juicy and textured with luscious profile as I cleaved through it exposing a cross section of the large sandwich. Its 5 inch height was too much for my jaw to expand around, so I ended up using knife and fork to get the job done. Definitely fair value at $12 and change. The tag along fries were not as good, and I left most of them behind. 

Folks on either side of me were into their steaks, and seemed as content as me in their choices. Must admit that the aroma from all that sizzling meat was intoxicating. 

Leaving the house about an hour later it was even more crowded and louder than when I arrived. I wend my way through the peeps into the open air. So many families waiting to be fed; content to wait as long as it took to partake of the kitchen fare. Now I understood why. For meat lovers this was paradise on a budget. A place they could afford to take their families, have a filling tasty meal, and not break the bank. 

Del Frisco's it wasn't. Nor did anyone want it to be.

After visiting Parx Casino for the first time I wanted to grab a bite on site to satisfy my skipped dinner hunger and check out one of its food options. I saw Liberty Bell Gastropub right off the casino floor and walked in to see what was going on. 

The bar was a large rectangle with plenty of open seats. I grabbed one after the hostess said I was free to do so. The space is attractively appointed with very high wood planked ceiling and large HDTVs all around. The bartenders were friendly and efficient. I asked for a menu and then saw the Happy Hour card standing on the bar near me. I realized that HH was from 9 to 11, and that I was right in the middle of it. It had more or less what I wanted (burger & beer) and nice discounts. I went with their Smokehouse Burger (gouda, bacon, BBQ sauce on brioche bun), side of mashed rather than fries, and a Victory Prime Pilsner. $7 savings made for a great and tasty deal. 

The burger was the perfect medium finish requested, and the garlicy mashed potatoes a pleasant alternative to overworked fries. The Philly brewed Victory beer was a cold refreshing washdown. Also nice to have linen napkin and heavy grade flatware on hand. 

All in all, Liberty Bell Gastropub could easily stand on its own as a high quality roadside stop. Of course, the gambling operation no doubt subsidizes the cost in order to keep people near the gaming tables. Still, it was a job well done.

Unable to reach my regular dentist after several calls, it was time to find someone who was actually available for treatment. After Yelp search and word of mouth inquiries, I chose Smile Culture Dental in Levittown for necessary and emergent dental care. 

Their facility on Oxford Valley Road was bigger than expected, especially after being accustomed to a one man office prior to this visit. The waiting area was attractive, with comfortable seating, and a self serve coffee station for all visitors. The sign in process had a few pages to read and sign, but that was simple and the folks behind the counter were pleasant and efficient. After about a 15 minute wait, we were called into the working area, and walked down a long half-walled hallway with dental chairs on both sides. I think I saw five work stations for the three dentists in the practice. Dr. Patel introduced himself in his aquamarine scrubs. He was friendly and had no problem with answering questions and explaining what he was seeing and what he intended to do about it. 

He worked with a dental assistant who knew her stuff and had a warm and empathetic personality. When we heard the diagnosis of a broken molar that required extraction, and that he was going to remove the tooth immediately with consent, he gave his patient time to absorb what was going to happen, ask questions, and think about it before seeking approval.  When that was forthcoming, an office/billing person came over with surgical consent form and billing information for signing. It was professionally done. Not high pressure in any way. 

Dr. Patel had a steady hand and explained the procedure from anesthesia through means of extraction and post op expectations. He was patient and had an easy, yet knowledgeable manner. He described what he was seeing and doing in a play by play narrative that was simple and understandable. Twenty minutes later the offending tooth was in the grip of his extractor (pliers), and he was packing the vacated space with artificial bone to maintain spacing and have a base for future implant. 

He provided prescriptions for antibiotic and pain management (if needed), and explained proper home care and next visit. The cost was fair, especially compared with dental offices closer to home (upscale communities have upscale dentists). They seem to have some flexibility in pricing and a program for regular visits and maintenance if desired. We deferred that decision pending the outcome of this experience. 

For the moment, I am quite satisfied with how we were treated at Smile Culture Dental. Should anything change, I will be sure to let you know.

There have been a stream of Indian restaurants at this location on Krewstown Road, just off Grant, but none of them have stuck until now. Me thinks the Mayura may break that trend and hang around for a long while. The dining room is colorful, the service is friendly, if not quite polished, and the menu is South Indian with an interesting list of vegetarian and non-vegetarian choices. 

We went with appetizers of Veggies Samosas, Onion Bajhi; large bowls of Vegetable Korma and Chicken Masala, and a smaller plate of Indo Chinese Chili Chicken. A basket of Garlic Ginger Naan and supply of Basmati Rice completed the table. Of course, we ordered way too much, but after tasting everything, we were happy to bring the leftovers home. 

The Samosas were golden fried and filled with mashed potatoes and green peas. Very good. The Onion Bajhi were basically dipped and deep fried in a light flour batter, made to be complemented by an excellent sweet/tart tamarind sauce. The Korma was a load of soft veggies in a dark tan cashew mild curry reduction. The Masala was darker and spicier, while the Chili Chicken was a decent rendition of the interaction between Chinese and Indian notions of inbred meals, not as crisp as found in Tibet, but leaning on Szechuan red chili with tumeric bite from south of the border. Each was a carousel of flavor and texture that deserved a trek in the high mountains between the two nations where life is hard , yet a grand adventure. We enjoyed it all. Oh, and the Naan was great with that hint of ginger mixed with garlic. 

The only downside was the Mango Lassi, which was from a mix that was so thick that it could not be pulled through a straw, and required major dilution with water in order to get it down the gullet. 

Otherwise, Mayura was all around a strong showing with only slight fraying around the edges.

Came down to The Pines Tavern on Radcliffe Street in old Bristol Borough to celebrate mi cumpleanos the other night.  Yelp reviews were very positive, and it had been a while since I had anything more than a cup of great coffee (Calm Waters Coffee Roasters) in this old river city. 

The bar/dining room is small, with square bar and perhaps ten to fifteen stools and equal number of tables.  The room is dark with several HDTVs for sport enthusiasts. The crowd was a mix of octogenarians  and middle aged folks, who all seemed to get along smashingly.  Drinks were very reasonably priced, and the custom beer list, while limited, had enough for us to be satisfied. Service was prompt and friendly with black T-shirted smiling servers always available to bring what you needed.  

The kitchen feels mostly homegrown talent.  They know what they are doing, especially in the realm of American or ethno-American cuisine.  The plates are full to overflowing, while still being dusted with herb and sauce for that new-American high end look.  I came for the Meatloaf and was lucky enough to discover it was "Meatloaf Night."  Saved a buck or two.  The meal was very good, with Garlic Mashed and fresh Steamed String Beans.  Liked it a lot!  
My companions ordered Lobster Mac and Cheese, which came in a low baking dish, topped with Bread Crumbs and melted Cheese.  It was tasty, but to my tongue, the cheese was too strong for the Lobster and hid much of its flavor.  The third entre, a Chicken/Shrimp Thai Curry with Brown Rice, was weaker, as we knew Thai food too well to find this imitation close enough to experience and expectations.  The curry was a little off as if they might not have had all the ingredients needed for authenticity.  Plenty of bird and shellfish. 

We also ordered the Buffalo Cheesesteak & Fries app.  It was huge and plenty hot between the Buffalo Red Sauce and semi-melted Blue Cheese.  Our twenty year old inhaled most of this.  It was a big hit. 

All in all, we enjoyed our evening at The Pines.  This is far more than your average neighborhood tavern.  A real effort has been made to polish the kitchen and bring in people who want more than just bar food.  In this they have succeeded, even if not perfectly. 

We applaud the effort and love the atmosphere. 

We will be back.

Keystone is still the reliable discount tire house on Street Road, Bensalem, Pa. They offer a broad inventory of competitive tires, and provide honest assessments of which is best for your car and driving style.  

Just came down to replace two all season touring hard rubbers, and had several to choose from, and others that could be on site within 24 hours.  They suggested which would most likely suit my needs, and it was on the low end of the price range.  65,000 miles rode wear guarantee.  They also showed me where my existing tires were worn unevenly, and strongly recommended an alignment at my earliest opportunity.  They didn't push.  They just pointed out the problems I had been having and would continue to experience if this was not addressed. 

I drove away with a new set of shoes and a far smoother ride.

Whoomzie's is named for an owner's mother's nickname, according to the counter person who made my onion bagel, butter & Swiss sandwich this morning. In all respects but the new name, this bagel house is unchanged from its days as Jersey Girl Cafe. There is a small lounge area with TV, table and loveseat, as well as a sunny dining area with seven tables. Orders are taken toward the rear of the shop. 

My morning repast was good, although I found the bagel denser than I prefer. Still a good taste with fresh butter and cheese. It was a very decent chew. Having I Love Lucy reruns playing in the background made for a relaxing and reminiscing moment. Those gags never get old. 

Oh, I just realized that something else has changed. They reversed the entry/exit doors to improve traffic flow within the store. Too, the door latch hardware still sticks without paying proper attention to turning the knob.

Bai Wei is the successor to Sakura Mandarin at the corner of 11th & Race in Chinatown, Philadelphia. Same ownership. Renovated and expanded dining room. Where the focus was formerly on excellent xiao long bao and other Shanghai delights, it has now expanded to include a strong taste of Szechuan and Hunan pepper and black bean hot dishes. I quite liked the old house, and returned late last week to see what the newly imagined kitchen held in store.

From our exploration of the two dishes we ordered, it would appear Bai Wei (many tastes) has it going on.  Their takes on crispy spicy chicken and cumin lamb dry pot were excellent. The chicken was loaded with red Szechuan peppers and small morsels of deep fried chicken. Enough to give our tongues a sincere capcesin workout and loosen our sinuses; stopping just short of bringing on tears. Completely addictive. The lamb, tender in a mix of chopped onion and more peppers and overwhelmed with a dusting of coarse cumin seed. Delicious. About as good as the best Szechuanese bowls I've found in the USA.

The only downside was the continuing attempt by the staff at up selling our order. We were repeatedly asked about appetizers, drinks and rice - even after we declined multiple times. Sure, they want more money per customer, but it became excessive and annoying. 

But for that weird dynamic, we thoroughly enjoyed the meal. Just train your servers to accept the customer's wishes and you have a winner.

Not only does Khmer Kitchen do Cambodian cuisine well, but the entire experience is so authentic that by the time you finish eating and pay the very reasonable bill, you may believe that stepping into this corner shop has transported you to the steamy streets of Penom Penh.

The house has only space for six tables with six chairs, but they can be separated for smaller groups like was done for us. This is a family operation from chef to cashier, and it runs efficiently. The front of the house belongs to Tony, who has been the sole (soul) server, busser, furniture mover for the past five years, and he has it down to a graceful science. Impressive.

The kitchen isn't fast, sending out one dish at a time as it is finished rather than bringing everything at once, but that is the style in most of Asia. Yet, once they arrive at the table they demand attention. They are beautiful to behold and distinctively delicious. 

We apped on fried calamari. Big pieces, deep fried but not oily, with a nice spicy red amber dipping sauce. Very good. The lemongrass chicken was a huge plate with celery, onion, green pepper and a hot curry lemongrass sauce. Excellent! Finally, we got to work on a pumpkin papaya vegetarian soup that offset the heat with a mild sweetness. Next time I promise to remember the Cambodian names of these wonderful dishes. 

The cooking here is a close cousin to Thai and Viet style, but with a few other spices indigenous to that part of Southeast Asia, and a tip of the hat to India and Burma as well. 

On this hot day the air conditioning was inadequate, and with the door open to help circulation the flies came in to enjoy their own meals. They were the only reason Khmer Kitchen did not make 5 Stars on this visit, although their buzzing did add to the authenticity.

I'm here to check out the new Wendy's breakfast menu that recently came online. They appear to be in direct competition with the morning offerings from McDonald's, Burger King and Chik Fil-A, at least in this neck of the Northeastern woods. 

As an aside I will note that the facility looks recently refurbished, because the old complaints about a run down enterprise is no longer true. The place looks modern and clean (w the exception of the men's room, which is another story). 

I went with a sausage, egg & cheese biscuit combo, which included roasted potato wedges and fresh brewed coffee. It was immediately noticed that their sausage and biscuit retain the signature square shape, but appear smaller than their opposite numbers at the other joints. Regardless, the taste and texture of the sandwich were on target, with flakey, buttery biscuit and good flavored patty. The taters were a solid contributor with pleasant crispness and seasoning. The coffee was brewed for me and it was good and strong. At under $6 for the meal, it was a decent value. 

How does the sammy compare? Glad you asked. 

To my tastebuds and eyesight, it was palpably smaller than Mickey's, but perhaps providing a better biscuit and sausage flavor. Not by much, but still winning by a nose. It is definitely a superior product to that sold by B. K, but fell short of the excellent sandwich prepared by Chik Fil-A. Those guys really have the right stuff from top to bottom when it comes to stuffed biscuits. They are both larger and far more enjoyable. 

So, there you have it. If absolute dominance is what you strive for, Chik Fil-A is your go to. However, if you can't find one nearby, choose Wendy's, McD's or B.B. King in that order if you want to sing the Breakfast Blues.

The amazing thing about Take A Taste Café is its unexpected presence in the Team Toyota Service Center of Lincoln Highway (old Rt. 1), in Langhorne.  I saw the reviews and could not visualize what the joint was all about - perhaps, a little space between the Parts Department and the Waiting Area? 

Wrong!

It is a fairly large, totally café-like experience in the back of the service building; right next to the large and comfortable waiting zone, and sharing wall space with the "Theater," (another surprising variant in this auto complex).  The refrigerated display has a load of deli materials, and the walls were large format black & white ceramic tiles.  The Dude running the show was all hatted-up and super friendly.  He must be accustomed to people wandering in and needing a short explanation about what was going on.  He gave me the nickel tour, and I ordered a Sausage, Egg & Cheese Sandwich on Croissant.  

No sweat.  He called my name a few minutes later and I went to pick up his handiwork.  It was an excellent sandwich on a fresh decent French airy, flakey crescent roll.  Darn good! And, the coffee was free to all who eat there or simply wait patiently for their chariots to be ready.  

Fresh ingredients all around. Scratch preparation.  Home baked bagels and other loaves.  

I may never drive a Toyota or Scion, but I was impressed with the marketing savvy and foresight of the folks who put this place together.  Take A Taste is worth the search and discovery.  

Who knows, offer a test drive along with breakfast, and they might move their floor plan up the scale. 

How about a vape shop next to the theater?

232 Corner Café (formerly Hogeland's) is a pleasant surprise. 

When the former luncheonette closed last year due to the landlord's expectation that this space would be taken over by a medical provider outpatient clinic at substantially higher rents, those of us who knew and loved the old gal were sad and disappointed.  It appeared to be the end of an iconic local institution that had been around, while changing hands, for nearly half a century.  Progress to some.  Loss of culture to others. 

The "best laid plans...sometimes go astray...", and when the plans for the medical facility shrunk to a smaller piece of the strip mall, this corner was not included.  All the fixtures remained intact, and a new business bloomed out of the ashes of the old. Ron now runs the operation, and at first blush, the new order of things feels much like the former enterprise.  The counter and tables are the same.  The grill and coffee brew where they sat before.  The menu has been updated, but the kitchen still puts out very good breakfasts (and lunches).  

My French Toast was done right.  The standard two slices were dipped in an egg/vanilla/cinnamon mix, and grilled expertly with caramelized edges.  The taste was what I wanted, and I appreciated that the "small stack" was now the main size for the plate.  A melt of butter; and splash of syrup, and I was a happy man.  The New England Roast Bunn drip java was hot, fresh and repeatedly refilled by Ron as he entertained the troops.  

232 Corner Café is a victory for the community.  Come on down and join in the celebration.

Classic German American bakery in Bensalem, Bucks County.  This two store chain produces some of the best sweet dough around.  Their Cinnamon
Rolls are big, light and covered in excellent icing.  Eat 'em while they're hot for maximum load mind blowing experience. They react well out of the microwave, too.  Butter Cake is more dense, moist and uber sweet for those of us who love a mouth full of Domino delight. Heat it up and it becomes sweet butter soup.
The large cookie, brownie, cannoli trays looked great, but will await another day. 

This shop is well lit, allowing we gawkers to have close up looks at all the amazing goodies.  The staff is friendly and seems to enjoy all the customers drooling over their wares.  

The coffee isn't bad, either.

The status of Duke must mean that I like the place enough to return more often than any other Yelper.  It has sought of snuck up on me that I have become Newtown Bagel Company royalty, but it does reflect reality.  

I have grown accustomed to their bagels, and more particularly the warm friendly way they greet me and know what I want before I order it.  Yes. They are making a safe assumption for someone who is a creature of habit when it comes to bagels.  

They informed me that they have a punch card and since acquiring it I have scored a couple of free cups of coffee.  Nice touch. 

I have become a fan based on the above, and it is time for my reviews to reflect this.

Who'da thunk that the simple grilled cheese sandwich could morph into a 21 Century restaurant chain centered on this basic food group? Bread and cheese becomes delicious fast casual cuisine. Born in New York, the brainchild of a twenty something selling hot sammies from a window operation, it now extends as far west as Minnesota. The Newtown store is the second in PA; the first in King of Prussia Mall. 

I caught it on its first day. It seemed the entire staff was on hand to help out. They wore black T's with the Melt Shop logo on the back, and ball caps similarly adorned. The place was crowded with assorted families and kids just out of Council Rock North's last week of school. The music system played on a rock loop that made for a very noisy atmosphere that was unnecessary given that it just interfered with conversation and made ordering a shouting contest. 

Just turn off the sound system, please! 

The food was very good. I went with the Maple Bacon Grilled Cheese (maple cured thick bacon, cheddar/American slices) within decent bread slices, and Shop Tots (tater tots sprinkled with grated cheese and mild spices). Plenty of chewy flavor inside the hot grilled pain, and well deep fried crisped tots. Liked them both alot. Drank a bottle of their signature water from GIVN, an outfit that brings clean H2O to communities in need. 

Prices add up quickly, so if you want a shake with that, lunch reaches $15 in a hurry. 

Melt Shop also does variations with fried chicken and burgers, both of which looked good on other tables. Will make it back to check them out. I'll give them a while to figure things out first.

Shout out to Davide, one of the managers, with whom I had an informative discussion about the store.

We weren't sure where to go for a good haircut/shaping for her thick black Chinese hair, but waiting longer for a visit home was finally off the table. She decided to walk around Chinatown and check out a few salons and talk with the cutters to see what they recommended. Our third stop was Famous Hair Salon on Cherry Street between 10th & 11th. Not sure how the decision was made, but she took a seat in front of the mirror and the manager/stylist went to work. I sat on a bench and nodded out.

She looked great and seemed very pleased with the result. Happy she. Happy me! 

The prices were reasonable, although it is a cash only shop.
