I didn't expect to find a decent Chinese restaurant in a Street Road strip center in Bensalem, PA, but there it was. Hong Kong Star Noodle House is a traditional looking Asian dining room with mahogany stained furniture and considerable menu primarily of Cantonese cuisine, and a tip of the cap to Szechuan and Thai tastes. But, it calls itself a noodle house and that was what I was there for. I really like chow fun, and they say on their Yelp page that it is done very well in their kitchen. A bowl of Hot & Sour Soup was my introduction on this cool windy afternoon, to be followed by Beef Chow Fun. 

First positive was the presentation of the soup. Rather than being served in a standard round bowl, it arrived in an oblong dish carried atop a white plate. It made it look voluminous with a rich ochre luster. It was full of mushrooms, strips of soft tofu and sprouts. The flavor was perfectly balanced between the vinegar and sesame oil. The textures mixed well between the crunchy sprouts, medium dense mushrooms and silky tofu. It was delectible. 

Next came the semi broad noodles and brown sauce of the chow fun. The thin sliced beef was very tender and had been grilled expertly. The noodles, onion and sprouts were in good proportion and the brown sauce both mildly spicy as requested, yet still subtly sweet as per the original recipe. Liked it very much, but it was too much to finish, and I took the rest home for the family. 

Service was prompt and friendly. My tea mug and water glass were refilled as needed by the woman who appeared to be a manager/owner of the establishment. 

Hong Kong Star Noodle House impressed me with its close proximation of a old school Chinese restaurant and the quality of its kitchen. It was several rungs above what is normally found outside of Chinatown.

Core Creek Park is part of the Bucks County Parks system, and it is the largest county park in lower Bucks County.  

It is a great place for families, joggers, dog owners, casual boaters, fisherpeople, and folks who just want a place to mellow-out in a pretty, natural setting.  It is very well landscaped, with trails, and a nice manmade lake from the flow of Core Creek.  There is even a leash-less dog park. You can rent a canoe or paddleboat by the hour or half day, or bring your own small craft (no motors) and buy a launch permit for a few bucks. Be forewarned that if you are over 6' you will have a problem fitting into the paddle boat and working the bicycle-like leg churners that power the craft. 

In good weather, the park fills with large family gatherings for picnics.  There are acres of areas with large trees and green lawns for your selection. 

While much smaller and more tame than Tyler State Park a few miles away, Core Creek Park is a very good facility for bringing people close to nature.  The more you visit and find your favorite spot away from others, the more you will return and make the park your back yard.

No doubt, NJ Weedman and his Joint have a long and interesting story to tell, but that is best left for historians and devotees of the man.  

Me?  I was just looking for a cup of coffee after exiting Trenton City Hall across the street.  And, I was successful.  The small shop with the brightly painted van out front was empty when I entered, but I heard rustling in the back, and soon enough Weedy's son came to see me to inquire of my desire.  When all I wished for was hot coffee, he easily obliged by pointing me to the coffee corner where self service was the order of the day.  What's more, he asked if I was a government worker. No. I'm in private practice, but thanks for asking.  

Never mind, then.  You can have a free cup, too.  His father believed in hospitality and graciousness to all, and he was continuing that generous tradition.  

Felt a little guilt not ordering anything else to put some gelt in his cashbox, but I didn't see anything within sight.  

The coffee was very good (Jamaican Blue?), and stayed hot all day in my coach given our steaming weather.  

My curiosity has the better of me.  I want to go back and learn the Weedman's story.  Next time, over lunch.

Pho Nam Giang (village) is the new Vietnamese kid on the block in southern Bucks County. It sits on Franklin Mills Drive, one of the access roads around the now "Philadelphia Mills." The room is spacious and utilitarian; comfortable and attractive in a Spartan kind of way. 

I sat alone in the back corner to give myself and everyone else sufficient space to remove our masks and feel confident in this renewed COVID social environment. The room wasn't crowded, but there were enough customers to keep the staff busy. They were efficient and friendly. I ordered Chicken Lemongrass Dumpling Pho and the Roast Pork Banh Mi, and settled in and waited to be served, sipping a plastic glass of hot tea (orange pekoe?).

PHO - I liked the variety of noodle soup offered on the menu. The choices were much broader than just traditional spicy beef base and thin cuts of steak, tendon, meatballs, etc. The Chicken Lemongrass Dumplings were plentiful and very good, even though the lemongrass flavor was not pronounced. The complexity of the stock could have been more subtle as well, but with the addition of jalapeno slices, Thai basil and squeezed lime wedges, it was a solid enjoyable slurp. The nest of thin rice noodles beneath the surface were tender and held the broth well as I sucked them up through whistled lips.

BANH MI - Excellent sandwich on very good french demi baguette, stuffed with lots of roast pork, cucumber, carrot and daikon strips with sprigs of cilantro across the top. It was a solid bite and chew, made better with a light touch of combined sriracha and hoisin for extra punch and smooth smokey sweetness. Definitely, one of the better banh mi's I've enjoyed in the past few years in Philly. 

Pho Nam Giang has a real chance to succeed if it maintains its standards and spends a little more time enriching its base beef and chicken stock. It uses quality ingredients and keeps its facility clean. There isn't much competition nearby, so with effort and good fortune their road is clear ahead.

Taranovas Pizza & Pasta sits in the same commercial strip as the PennDot Service Center, which is how I first noticed it as I waited for a new driver's license. Its dining room is a good size, as is the breadth of the menu, which covers all three daily meals. 

I stopped in for an early dinner before an evening meeting, and was greeted by a friendly server who also vibed as a possible manager. The broad glass windows face directly west into the setting sun, casting a bronze glow over everything, as beautiful as it was blinding. Even lowering the thin verticals did little to reduce the glare. I ordered the standards - chicken parmagiana, linguini aglio olio and small side salad (balsamic). 

There was plenty on the plate when I dug in. There were one and a half breasts, lightly breaded and pan fried in olive oil, covered in rich red gravy. It was crisp edged and a real palate pleaser. The pasta was a special request to change from more marinara. While plentiful in a large bowl of its own, the kitchen used pre-minced garlic rather than fresh sliced and sautéed bulb, making it nearly invisible and translucent, rather than the golden browned garlic I love in pasta. A bit of a disappointment. The small salad was fine, but using only one cherry tomato seemed rather retentive. 

Overall, it was a satisfactory meal that would have scored better had there been a stronger effort on the linguini sauce and more generosity with the salad. Still, the chicken warmed the heart and I walked away with leftovers, so the negatives are muted. 

3.5 STARS

Don Panchito's sits in a former banquet facility at the corner of Grant and Academy in Northeast Philadelphia. The dining room is fairly large with minimalist decor, especially in response to required Covid Protocol. So, the atmosphere feels more utilitarian, than ethnic, but that does not distract from the quality of the food put out by the kitchen. 

I went with two appetizers; Esquites and Chicken Flautas. The first, a fresh sweet corn dish mixed with chipotle mayo, spices and crema. The kernals were plump and firm, making for an engaging cool salad-like dish that showed me a new way to enjoy corn off the cob. The Flautas were three homemade tortillas stuffed with excellent ground chicken, spices and cheese, cut in half and served in a star pattern, topped with crema and guacamole. This way, it became finger food, holding shape and contents from presentation to mouth. They were hot, crisp and delicious. 

An interesting aspect of Don Panchito's is that it has a halal kitchen. Before going, I really couldn't imagine how that looked in reality. Turned out that many of the other customers there were in a party that was partially Muslim. They had a Call to Prayer in a corner of the dining room while I was there, complete with carpet for kneeling. I was impressed with the dedication to their faith and the obvious comfort they felt in observing their customs in that setting. Definitely unique for a Mexican grill! 

And, I have to mention Sophia, my friendly server who was covering the whole floor alone. She never lost her cool despite handling both the solo me, and the twenty or so partiers who were only minutes ahead of me ordering their food. The kitchen was slammed, but everything kept moving smoothly, due in large part in Sophia's verve and grace.

Frank's Spaghetti House is an old time Italian restaurant on Castor Avenue in the Rhawnhurst section of Northeast Philly. You know you're there when you see the dark red painted storefront and large white/red sign inviting you to dine in or take out. They have been there so long that the prices seem of another age when paper money was backed by gold. It is a bit dated with Formica tables and stained wood benches for the wall booths, and a tight fit bar in the front corner. 

Yes. It reminds of the set of an old Martin Scorcese movie. It's all part of the charm. 

We were there for our Valentine's dinner and chose Frank's because we thought it might not be crowded. It wasn't, but had a bustle to it that kept the joint lively. We had a booth immediately on entering without reservation. 

Our server was friendly, but not informal with us. She took our drink order (half carafe Chianti) and handed us menus. She returned with our hearty red vino, two glasses and basket of bread. Nice start with good crusty Italian loaf and aromatic wine with strong paisano flavor. We ordered Veal Scallopini and Chicken Marsala, with soup and veggie sides, and listened to a romantic serenade of Italian crooners. 

The entrees were quite good, with special mention of the marsala which although thick cutlets, were tender with delicious white wine/butter/lemon/garlic reduction, and plenty of fresh mushrooms on top of penne. The Scallopini was thin, tender with rich savory red gravy. The sides were pedestrian with lifeless stringbeans and cool french fries. My cup of Chicken Noodle Soup was a pot bottom bowl of too salty bouillon. We weren't there for those little plates anyway. We did enjoy the Caprese Salad appetizer, with soft Buffalo mozza, basil and decent off season tomatoes. 

With the wine and tip, we still walked out for under $60. So while a little inconsistent in execution, we were still very satisfied with the experience. It was the romantic and memorable celebration we hoped for. 

3.5 STARS

The Newtown area has an embarrassment of riches when it comes to fresh, homemade ice cream.  At last count, there are at least four shops making their own cold creamies, and each has something special going for it. With February weather reaching 80 last week, climate change now makes ice cream an all year delight. 

Uncle Dave's is located in the main store on Shady Brook Farm off Stony Brook Road and the Newtown Bypass. They offer an interesting selection of their ice cream with the ability to accessorize with sprinkles, fudge, caramel, etc. Prices are about right for the competition. Under $4 for the "Kids" size; $5 for the "Medium," and $7 for the "Large." In my experience, that Kids size with three scoops of up to three of your favorite flavors was enough. Don't let the description of "Kids" deter you from getting only what you can lick in one serving. 

I went with two scoops of butter pecan and one scoop of the seasonal pumpkin. They were both creamy and tasted as they should. Not too sweet, not under-flavored. Both were pretty much what I expected. My friends and their young kids opted for more varieties, including cappuccino, strawberry and peanut butter with a side of peanut butter sauce.  They were all happy with their choices. 

Was it the best ice cream in greater Newtown? That's a matter of personal preference.  But, given all the alternatives, it represented Dave's well.  Their offerings were more standard that some other parlors, so if exotic and romantic taste is your thing, you might find this place a little uninspired.  For you folks, OhWowCow in Wrightstown is the only way to go. Of course, it also costs more for premium. 

Lick on!

Found myself in Columbus, NJ, after a court appearance in Mt. Holly, the county seat of Burlington County.  This building is right in the center of town and looks to have been a bank in the past.  It is mostly takeout, but there are a few tables (mostly taken up by the owners' kids) for the brave souls who prefer to eat while the food is hot.  

The Sesame Chicken was above average.  Although the amount was somewhat less than given in most other Chinois houses, the breading was not overly thick, and the sauce was actually pretty good.  The Fried Rice was full of pork, peas and a few other veggie pieces.  I liked the dish. 

Most appreciated was the curtsy to hospitality provided by the real plate on which the meal sat.  It was a pleasant touch to get away from serving in-house customers as if they were taking lunch with them.  I don't like eating out of Styrofoam when seated in the restaurant.  The small extra cost of washing a few dishes is nothing compared to the sense that the other places really don't want you around.  The front of the house woman was friendly and engaging as she watched over her kids and the shop.  

While Hong Kong Restaurant is still a Sino/American house with standard menu, their effort to provide a welcoming touch to their operation goes a long way.

One of the largest grocery store chains in the region, Giant competes well with Acme for the merchandising middle ground between quality and price, but not in the same class as Wegman's, nor Whole Foods. Yet, it may have found the sweet spot that allows it to survive in hard times and modestly prosper in good. This outlet on DeKalb Pike in Blue Bell, PA, can stock your pantry, fridge and medicine cabinet with almost everything you need, even if not everything you yearn for. 

We stopped in recently while in the area for hair styling, hoping to pick up a few things there rather than drive the 30 minutes back home and then stop at our local Giant, when we were hungrier and didn't feel like making that detour closer to dinner. Actually newer than our regular shop, and a touch larger, we discovered that its layout was different than we were used to, and thus slower to cruise through as we searched for our needs. 

The space was clean, with special attention given to their extensive salad bar and back of the shop deli/bakery and the organic section of their their produce department. 

Found what we needed in the personal care aisle and bakery, and slid through checkout in a minute. Considered grabbing a roast chicken, but there were not available at the moment. Will probably get that on the next visit to Costco.

Even on Saturday morning, Rt. 73 in Marlton is a pain in the butt to drive, but at least it now has Bhan Thai as a worthy destination, making the traffic and crazies causing it, tolerable. 

I hadn't eaten a good Thai meal in many months, and decided a few days before to get up early this weekend and cruise across the Burlington Bristol Bridge and down 295 to this well reviewed Vietnamese kitchen. Arriving just as it opened at 11:30, I walked into an empty dining room and was greeted by a friendly Asian woman who welcomed me and confirmed I could dine outside on their umbrellaed patio. Seemed like the safer way to go in this renewed age of raging Delta Covid. 

I went with faves, Tom Kha Soup and Drunken Noodles (veggie), 'Thai Spicy'. They threw in a sushi orange ginger dressing salad, which was a surprise. The Tom Kha was excellent, with plenty of fresh mushrooms, sliced chicken, carrots, onion, coconut milk and lemongrass for kicks. Loved each and every slurp. The Drunken was a large plate with extra wide noodles and lots of colorful veggies.

 It also came with plenty of cubed tofu pan sauteed to a near burnt finish. The heat was there, although not the conflagration desired. The taste of the overdone tofu while subtle, was enough to through the flavor of the dish slightly off. So, while it was still recognizable, it could have been much better with a more deft hand holding the pan. 

Bhan Thai is a reasonable facsimile of a genuine attractive Thai restaurant, but candor requires referencing that better can be found in and around Philly, Central Jersey, and closer to home. 

3.75 STARS.

Thai Orchid of Blue Bell is a beautifully appointed Siamese restaurant on DeKalb Pike in the wonderfully named town of Blue Bell, PA. It is one of those places where the environment is so rich in southeast Asian colors, textures and artistry, that it is possible to eat the atmosphere. From woodcuts to tapestry the space is relaxed and mellow enough to have you believing you've stepped into a palace in Chiangmai. 

I was there for late lunch after a meeting in Norristown. The shop sits in a strip center, the last door on the far right. Don't be put off by that or you'll miss all the magic. There was only one other customer dining when I arrived and was taken to a table on a raised platform that held most of the tables. The menu was full of Thai delights, and lunch combo specials that included soup, appetizer and main entree, for around $10 and change. That seemed the way to go to sample a few things and get more bang for the buck. I went with the Thai Ravioli Soup (wonton), Veggie Roll and Drunken Noodles. 

Believe me, it was a huge amount of food. The soup was vegetable based broth with fancy goldfish wonton filled with ground shrimp and chicken. It had a mild sesame oil flavor and tasted fresh and pleasing. The roll was deep fried with a filling of mixed vegetables, glass noodles and a small dish of sweet & sour dipping sauce. It was good, but a tad over fried.

 The drunken noodle was a large plate full of medium width noodles (not jumbo), loaded with chunky onions, bell peppers, green beans, fresh basil, thin sliced beef and moderately hot Thai spices. I asked for it to be very chilified, but it was still pretty tame. It seems that regardless of what you ask for on the heat scale, it is interpreted as only moderately spicy. How you actually get the "Very spicy yet Bearable," fire level is beyond me. Here, it cost them a star for failing to honor my clear direction. 

Aside from the width of the noodles and the lack of burn, this was a very satisfying meal, and enough to keep me sated for the rest of the day. The decor and food together make Thai Orchid of Blue Bell a worthy stop for quality exotic cuisine. It would be even better if they paid closer attention to what was being requested.

I seem to be going through a mini tuna obsession lately. For the past few weeks I have found myself searching for deli or sandwich shop that does chopped tuna the way I like it - with mayo, celery, light black pepper and finished with hot and sweet pickled peppers. I can go for years without even thinking of it, but every once in a while I just gotta have some.

Slack's Hoagie Shack is a regional chain in these parts. They have a large menu of everything that can be stuffed into a torpedo roll and eaten. They happen to do tuna particularly well. They seem to grind it, more than chop it, making for a smooth, plyably, dense consistency, that hangs together well in a sandwich, and accepts additional condiments easily. It is not overly moist, so it is not given to slipping out the back door, and keeps it's shape until bitten. 

One hoagie is enough for two meals for me, as the standard length is about 12 inches. Their bread is pretty good, but mine may have been past its prime, as it seemed ein bissel dry. In the Trenton area, with so many Italian bakeries, this is almost inexcusable. Fix this, and 5 Stars await.

Service was excellent, with easy ordering by phone, and smiling takeout once at the shop. Facility was also immaculate.

Very glad to report that nothing much has changed at Bagel Delight since my last report.
Still baking very good Bagels, providing friendly service & above average Java. The regulars appear to be the same, too. Understandable. If I lived in Lambertville I would be one of them.

I am not a lover of 20th Century Malls (dinosaurs), nor most particularly their anchor tenants (dead men walking).  Yet, I found myself in JC Penny in the Oxford Valley Mall recently to exchange shoes that had been purchased online, but arrived the wrong size.  While that might warrant a negative review on its own, the way the folks in the store handled the problem was worthy of praise. 

We came to the shoe department hoping to find the exact shoe we wanted, but their inventory was rather limited.  When we explained to the manager who happened to be at the register what was going on, she promptly accepted our explanation and the shoes and was able to credit our card immediately.  Beyond that, she ordered the shoes we wanted directly at the register, for free delivery within three days.  

Sure enough, UPS dropped off the right shoes to our front porch three days later.  They made us happy to have dealt with them.  Even though it would have been better had the right shoes arrived the first time, the way the fix was dealt with was friendly, apologetic and efficient.  And, they threw in an extra $5 discount for our troubles. 

I may be the victim of low expectations, but I was pleased by the overall experience. Mistakes can be made by anyone.  It is how they are remedied that tells the tale. 

This experience made me a fan of JC Penny.

Serious Chinese-style massage going on here. 

The residuals of two herniated discs in my lumbar spine occasionally require hands on attention to release the pent up tension and pain that comes from living a regular life.  Lizhi Health Spa is operated in the Chinese tradition, with lots of heavy hands, forearms, elbows, and back walking if a "strong" massage is what you want.  

I did, and they did.  I found myself breathing in unison with my masseuse's work, because the pressure was so intense at times, that inhaling was not an option.  Joints and tense muscles began to pop and relax as the effort continued.  Even my left shoulder, injured thirty years ago, began to unwind as a sharp elbow found its target.  After torso and limbs addressed this way, she returned to my arms and legs and began to stretch them beyond their normal range to increase their motion and reduce restrictions.  My legs were torqued as she leaned her body weight into it.  My lower back begrudgingly responded, and for the first time in years, the sense of tingling in my feet stopped for the rest of the day.  

All in all, an impressive display of Tui-Na.  I ended up on the table for two hours, and each minute was intensely worth it.  At $100 for 120 minutes, the price was fair for all the heavy lifting this diminutive woman undertook.  She had surprising strength and excellent technique.  My tip was commensurate with her quality work.

Will certainly return as needed.  

Cash Only.

Returned to Aldo's for dinner for the first time in more than a decade. At one time it had been a regular stop in my rotation when I lived right across Buck Road in Holland, PA. It was good to be back. 

The menu offered a broad swatch of Italian cuisine, mostly of the red sauce variety, but with enough variation to keep it interesting. We went with the Calamari appetizer, and entrees of Veal Parmesan and Chicken Francais, both with sides of pasta, minestrone soup and side salad. We were quite happy with our meals. 

They started off on an off note with a luke warm minestrone that had not been sufficiently reheated, nor tested. The early salad was satisfactory, if less than imaginative. Things improved from there. The Calamari was perfectly prepared with tender squid wrapped in a tasty bread crumb dredge and a thick marinara dipping sauce. The veal was delicious with two thin filets, breaded and pan fried in extra virgin just right to maximize its delicate texture and finished with melted mozza and more chunky red gravy. The three Francaised chicken breast medallions were pan sauteed in butter, lemon and white wine. They were fork cuttable and the interplay of the lemon and wine played tartly and smartly on the tongue. We used the crusty bread to sop up as much of the reduction as possible. My request for the pasta side bowl to be penne aglio olio rather than more tomato sauce was a good call because I loved the well browned garlic and black pepper mix. 

Aldo still does a solid traditional Italian American dinner in an attractive dining room. It was nice to know that for the most part they hadn't lost their touch.

In between all the smoker shops and other degradation along Bridge Street in Morrisville, Pa., stands a pizza shop that belies its surroundings, while well disguised within it.  

Anthony's IV Pizza & Pasta is sentry at its corner with Washington Street, and after decades of inattention to its own condition, still puts out good pizza and better Italian-styled sandwiches for those lucky enough to know it is there.  You may find the house a bit dirty in the corners, and in need of some love and care, but the kitchen knows what it is doing.  

When I walked in the other night looking for a modest dinner, I was met with a warm smile and greeting from the woman behind the high cashier's counter.  I asked if they were still serving, and was advised I could sit anywhere and be served hot food until late into the night.  The menu was full of most of the usual suspects to be found in a Roman bistro, excepts perhaps for the first Specialty Pizza, the Mexican.  I asked about their Sausage, Pepper & Onion Sandwich and was told it was one of her favorites.  Good enough for me.

What seemed like 5 minutes later, out of the kitchen walked the chef holding a white ceramic plate with my dinner.  Fast!  First look was of a split Sweet Italian Sausage well grilled and a pile of Sautéed Onions and Green Peppers overflowing the rim of the torpedo roll.  They may have saved a few bucks on the bread, which was sort of non-descript, but the innards were hot, tasty and a very good representation of the genre.  No need for ketchup or other additional condiments.  This was a heavy hitter with strong accent.  I liked it a lot, although it would have been even better with Green Frying Peppers in place of the generic greens.  

And, at a cost of under $6 for this creation, it made little dent in my wallet.  

I will be back to try the pizza and other goodies at Anthony IV, as this place is close to the best pizza joint I have sampled in the Morrisville area.  Between the down/dirty ambiance, friendly service, and good food, it checks off most of my boxes.

So nice to be pleasantly surprised.

Barnes & Noble sits in a single building in the same shopping center as Home Depot, Dick's Sporting Goods and Petco. I think of it as a historic artifact from the days when paper and ink were required to publish and market books.  These days that is becoming much less so, and it will only be the public's love of books and the emotional connection with libraries and bookstores that will keep this cultural icon from becoming extinct.  

I enjoy the sensations of being surrounded by knowledge, scholarship and tons of information.  It reminds of the libraries of Alexandria, Athens, Rome, Xian, London, New York, and all the other great repositories of our wisdom.  It moves me in a way that the internet does not and cannot.  I, for one, will join libraries, and visit bookstores like B & N to contribute to their survival.  

Last night I attended a writers' group of about a dozen people who love written expression and are willing to read their work and accept criticism from other writers.  Very interesting experience. You just don't know what a person can create and write about.  Sometimes their appearance is completely opposite to what flows from their own hand. 

Barnes & Noble is to be applauded for making comfortable space available for such groups to explore the written word.  Whether any of us will ever find our tomes populating the shelves of this store remains to be dreamed of. 

Oh, yes...The Starbucks is much too small for the demand it generates, and the chairs, tables and other seating areas are insufficient for the volume of customers who come and like to hang out here for extended periods of time to socialize or dive into the stacks.

This review reflects only on the Xiao Long Bao, Beef Scallion Pancakes, Crispy Salted Chicken and Dam Dam (sic?) Noodles, all of which are on the Dim Sum Appetizers menu.  

We chose Shanghai 1 specifically for their reputation for good XLB as described by many Yelpers.  The shop is another of those long narrow houses with tables running along the north wall all the way to the restroom.  It is attractive enough with artificial flowers on each table and modern wall hangings.  The service is fast and friendly, especially if Mandarin is spoken in the exchange.  

We found the Soup Dumplings (XLB) to be very good.  The skin was thin, the soup hot and savory, and the ground pork filling, soft and tasty.  The table rocket with the dumpling vinegar was a great tool for squirting into the open pouch once the top knot was bitten off to suck out the broth.  We liked them so much, we ordered another bamboo steamer of 6 after finishing everything else.  

The Beef Scallion Pancake was likewise very enjoyable.  I did not find it overly oily given it was fried in that scalding fluid, and the beef within was tender and brought to sweet life with the Hoisin Sauce in which it had been prepared.  The Crispy Salted Chicken was their take on the fried chicken craze.  The chicken was tender, but the breading a might over-fried to a too-dark brown.  The pieces were very small and included many droplets of plain dough without any meat within.  While the taste was okay, the overall impression was underwhelming.   

Both the XLB and Pancakes were winners, while the Crispy Fried Chicken left something to be desired. I leave it to others to discuss the relative merits of the XLB created by the other shops known for this Shanghai delicacy, Dim Sum Garden and Sakura Mandarin.  If we had stopped with the first three dishes all would have been quite content.  Our son was still hungry and wanted some noodles.  He ordered the Dam Dam Noodles with Chili Sauce hoping to top off his meal with some spicy carbs.  At 19, he can afford to do that.  Unfortunately, he was disappointed with this dish.  He complained that it was tasteless and bland.  He left half of it in the bowl and declined to take the rest home. Perhaps, we should have known given the exotic spelling of the dish.  

We will stick with the Xiao Long Bao and Scallion Pancakes on future visits.

This warehouse of a shoe store is to feet what The Home Depot is to home improvement. It offers more than you could possibly need to do the job, but intoxicates with choices. Depending on your interest, you can wander around either one mesmerized by all the possibilities.

I needed a pair of dress browns to wear with business suits. The far left wall had at least 50. Wing tip, two tone, light, medium or dark umber. Contrasting laces, loafers. Traditional or light weight. American, English or Italian. Get the picture? 

Eenie, meenie, miinie, mo...

The psychology is to force abandonment of rational decisions and lead you to the conclusion that it makes sense to buy more than one pair to get you past indecisiveness. Don't worry. You are saving money, too. 

I fought off the urge to splurge and went with Aldo wingtips. Good fit. The cashier approved.  Will need to find the right color shoe cream to keep them looking spiffy. 

Very proud that I didn't succumb to the pressure to buy them all (Yet).

Le Viet is not your every day run of the mill traditional Vietnamese restaurant.  Its modern décor informs about the approach the kitchen takes to its menu.  It too, is modern and uniquely different from most of the other ethnic houses in this community.  If you want a break from Pho and Broken Rice (or even if you don't), but desire creativity and great distinctive flavor, this is your destination of choice.  

I had read the reviews, but was still very pleasantly surprised by the attention to comfort and privacy afforded here.  Booths with high back benches separating us from our dining neighbors.  Dark woody tones with high ceilings and subdued lighting. Glass vases, mirrors behind the bar, and extended front wall to let an image of the city enter, but keep us hidden within.  A place for a date. 

We ordered #s 9 and 70 - Pineapple Salad appetizer and Short Ribs roasted in a clay pot.  Both were exceptional.  The App came in a hollowed out half Pineapple, loaded with fresh Fruit, raw Calamari, spicy Shrimp, and assorted sidekick Veggies, all held together with a Lime and Pineapple Juice base with an assist from a good Fish Sauce. It was delicious. It wasn't Cerviche, but suggested that style.  When the solids were consumed, we asked for spoons so we could drink the sauce remaining in the bottom of the pineapple.  I could have had that for a cocktail if mixed with a little light rum. 

The Short Ribs had been torched to a dark burn, so that everything else in the clay pot had been caramelized into a thick glazy gravy that was hot with a hint of sweet.  The meat was easily liberated from the bone and also captured that intense taste.  We loved it.  

If there was a weakness it came from the bar that prepared the Mai Tai we requested.  I envisioned a Trader Vic's drink, full of orange, pineapple and lime juice, two rums, coconut liquor, and Grenadine.  Aside from a squirt of lime and a pour of Grenadine and Light Rum, the other ingredients were absent, making for a thin drink lacking its soul.  Next time, we skip the drinks. 

Otherwise, this was a top notch meal.  It was a great alternative to the usual stops on Philly-Saigon-Hanoi dinner train.

Is it the best diner in New Jersey, Land of Diner Enchantment?
Maybe not, but it certainly has history and local color going for it.
Oh, and a great breakfast if you fancy overflowing plates, unlimited coffee, and a Greek Omelet that is a wonder of the world.  
What is it about feta cheese and eggs that moves me so?  Don't know, but when mixed with sausage, potato, onion, peppers, all wrapped up in an fresh egg case, they become an amazing sensory explosion.  
Trenton may have seen better days (we have been waiting for its resurgence since it was "Americas Town" in the 60's), but Pat's carries on.
Diners are only partially about the food, and the rest about the concept, design, and lustful loyalty they inspire. 
Pat's is a worthy contender for the Urban Diner List on Yelp* (If there is one). 
Give it a try. 
Sit at the counter and watch professionals do their thing. Sit at a window and see a worldview that captures the past-its-prime city, the capital of the Garden State, remind you that... We Are Still Here.

The Big Easy used to be Maxine's back in the day.  In those wild and wooly days of yesteryear, I was bartending around the corner, and would sometimes stop in here on an off night or after hours for a few drinks and/or dances.  The layout looks the same - like the inside of a ship.  Two levels of seating in an oval dining room.  Large dance floor still holding down the main deck.  

I stopped in for breakfast earlier this week.  The door was propped open and I wasn't certain they were doing morning business.  They were. I was greeted by a warm smiling young woman who walked me into the smaller barroom, where I chose a table close by the front windows.  They were still setting/cleaning up, but made me feel quite welcome.  

This kitchen is Halal, so I ordered a Beef Bacon, Egg and Cheese on an Whole Wheat Roll.  As you can see from the photo, the sandwich was big and loaded.  I enjoyed every bite.  The coffee was fresh brewed after I asked for some, and it was very tasty. I think that was Chicory mixed in as a nod to Café du Monde in NOLA.  

This is a great place for an early morning meeting or just a quiet solitary breakfast.  It was fun to be back in the old joint, and to see it was being so well cared for.  

For downtown Trenton, this is a definite gem.

It took me two tries to find the front door of Mauceri Pizza.  It has combined two storefronts.  The one to the right lets you in, while the door on the left is permanently closed on the dining room side of the establishment.  It is not immediately apparent that this is now one operation, so take this tip to find your way.  It is worth your while to come inside. 

First glance, it still looks like an Italian pizza shop with a couple of pies on display, and large ovens toward the back.  It is rather hot in there on a humid Judy day, but the now-glass wall between the two rooms also insulates the strong air conditioning in the dining room.  As there was no one else eating when I arrived, I sought permission to enter and have lunch.  No problem.  Although a Salvadoran house, most there spoke English well enough to understand each other.  The room is rather large with ample tables for a nice dinner crowd.  

The menu is a cross between Italian and Salvadoran cuisine.  All the usual suspects on the Roman side, and substantial offerings in Spanish, as well.  One of their specialties was Chili Rellenos, one of my favorite Central American dishes, and I went for it.  What followed was a parade of plates from Chips and Salsa, to Pickled Peppers, Tortillas, and a huge platter with the Rellenos, Rice and Salad.  The stuffed chili pepper covered in egg and drowned in spicy red sauce, was about the best I had ever eaten.  The stuffing seemed to be a combination of ground meat, cheese, onion and more pepper.  It was filling and delicious. I will never know how they expected one man to eat that much.  I barely touched the tortillas and the rice.  My cold Jicaima Juice was a rich dark cranberry color, sweet and refreshing. 

The only question that arose was the actual price for my meal.  The hand out flyer listed the dish at $7., while the hard menu said it was $8.  I was charged $9. They should work on getting some consistency in pricing to avoid any chance someone might think they were trying to take advantage of a gringo.  Yet, even at the highest price, it was still a deal. I said nothing and let the confusion slide. 

This piece of Liberty Street is attempting to come back to life after a rough couple of decades.  There are now a few restaurants and shops on the street and a new CVS down the block.  With a little luck, they will all do well.

Once upon a time, there was a Jersey Diner on Olden Avenue called The Extension Diner.  It had good food, but was old and tired. A reviewer stopped in for breakfast once in a while on his way to court.  He loved the counter service, the humongous muffins displayed in front of him, and the bottomless cup of coffee from the Cecilware perk antique coffee maker.  When he semi-retired, and stopped visiting "The Ex," the diner was so sad, it decided to close its doors. 

Two guys named Peter came along.  They saw the bathetic eatery and its promise.  They decided to buy it, modernize it, and reopen with a fresh face, new menu, and the old Cecilware coffee maker.  

Eventually, the reviewer came out of retirement, strapped on his suit and long sword, and returned to slaying dragons.  Driving down Olden Avenue he beheld the new Two Peters Diner where the old Extension used to be, and stopped in to see what it was about.  Much to his amazement the new joint was beautiful.  Everything inside was new, spacious, bright and cheerful.  The maidens were just as friendly and courteous as he remembered; the Cecilware coffee just a wonderfully dark and rich.  

Half the long counter was gone, replaced by a large cake/pie display.  Still, he found a spinner and slid onto it.  As in past ages the muffins were directly in front of him as if time had not moved them from their appointed place.  They were still very large, with pillow tops and trim paper bases.  

Had to have one.  Cranberry it was. 

Toasted, it was still soft with a moistness that bespoke freshness.  The texture was dense, compressing pleasantly when chewed, and slowly releasing its sweetness, and mild acidic cranberry charm.  It crumbled slightly on the plate, but was easily captured with the tines of the fork. With Cecil coffee, it was an ample breakfast. 

Two Peters is a worthy successor to the old "Ex."  In many ways a vast improvement.  This knight errant will make it a regular stop on his quest to slay the firebreathers.

The reviews for The Firkin Tavern are like a blind man touching an elephant. Depending on what you touch you have a different impression. Is it a dive bar?  A sports bar? A college bar? An old man's bar? A beer bar?  A good happy hour bar?  A foodie bar?  The answers are simple. Yes. 

Any really good hangout bar is all things to all people.  That's what makes them fun and special.  Whoever you are; whatever you do; whatever you want; regardless of time; The Firkin delivers.  It allows you to feel at home, and make it your own.  I've only been here a couple of times, once for lunch and another for happy hour after work, and although the experience of each visit was different, the constant was an upbeat vibe with friendly attractive staff, and drinks, menu and activities that were entertaining, tasty and fairly priced.  Most important - the crowd mixes well together.  Labels are unnecessary and soon forgotten. Just have fun.  

The space is surprisingly large, and well placed mirrors make it seem even bigger.  The dark tones make it seem older than it is and adds to the atmospherics.  The bar is big enough for bellyups, and the bar menu is sufficiently diverse to make a few hours on a stool pass quickly.  Decent beer choices for the craft people, and those who are happy with their Buds.  The kitchen turns out interesting plates of nachos, flatbreads, sammys, burgers, soups, salads, and more.  Your tastebuds will be satisfied. 

I have sampled several of the above while sitting at the bar at happy hour, and been pleasantly surprised.  Cheesesteak Nachos!? Are you kidding me?  Fun comfort food at its best.  Stuffed Chicken Sammy on a fresh roll with a load of mushrooms, cheese and honey mustard sauce - very good.  Burgers; thick and way above average.  

Yeah! The Firkin Tavern is a sleeper and a keeper, regardless of what part of the elephant you touch.

So this is 21st Century bowling.  Amazing!

As a kid growing up in a big city, I first experienced bowling in a tiny, 8 lane facility on the second floor of an old factory that had been adaptively reused into a recreation zone.   There was a tire store downstairs, and a candy store on the corner.  Games were 3 for a buck, and shoe rental another two bits.  It was great fun for my buds and me.  

Brunswick Zone is a different animal entirely.  Bowling is not even mentioned in the name nor signage.  Yet, there are 48 lanes here, and the distant thunder of ball striking pin is buffered by the sounds of laser tag, pool, large bar/restaurant, and arcade with pinball wizards running up the score.  It has become full menu fun.  The cost is higher for all these options, but really still a decent value. 

I went down to Feasterville to pick up number one son from an afternoon/early evening of Brunswick Zone entertainment.  Walking through the sliding doors I felt like this was another Home Depot, Cabellas moment - a huge warehouse hanger of a building jammed with every group game imaginable.  Overwhelming sounds and lights. I was preparing to head for the large bar to wait until the young man emerged from laser tag or a final few frames of a bowling tournament, but found him quickly in front of the laser tag desk.  

I hope he has another invite to go there to play so I can check everything out in more detail.  If not, I will have to take him there myself.  

I hear my childhood calling.

A wholesome piece of Americana right on State Street, Doylestown.  It feels like a luncheonette with small booths, tables, and a very friendly "Coach" handling the orders and register.  High school banners on the walls and a HDTV tuned to ESPN. Local kids working the grills.  Feels familiar and timeless.

The menu is on a digital board (a bit incongruously).  As soon as I saw the juxtaposition of two of my favorite words, "burger and jalapenos," I knew where I was heading.  Rather than the quarter pound puck I expected, it arrived in a red plastic basket as two small sliders about 3" high, cheese melted over the bottom bun, and the sauteed onion and green 'pena holding up the roof. I smiled at the surprise. Still, it is the first bite experience that matters here, and it was great! I was thinking, "Fat White Castle," but after the jaw clenched and released, I felt my mouth fill with the combination of flavors and textures, and knew I had to savor the moment.  

Thank you for a pleasant surprise that makes a day. 

Coach's took me by ambush.  I wasn't anticipating anything special here, but came away with a memory and wish to return soon.

This GNC has been in the Village of Newtown for 15 years.  It is a good place to pick up nutritional supplements to assist your healthy lifestyle remain that way.  While diet is a key determinant of health, sometimes an assist from a quality vitamin, mineral, or herbal mix can enhance the constitution.  

For me, several health professionals, both traditional, allopathic and alternative have recommended Grape Seed Extract, Ginseng, Ginko Biloba and a good multi-vitamin be added on a daily basis. After more than 20 years of using them they seem to have made a difference.  Skeptics can doubt, but I am a believer.  

GNC offers high end products, and when I don't want to boil herbs to make health teas, I use their supplements based on confidence that they are high quality and subject to decent quality control.  Sometimes the higher price disturbs me when I find another good manufacturer at better price (I do shop around), but absent that, GNC has my loyalty.

Breakfasted here this week while waiting for my court appearance. The location is very convenient to the courthouses, and unlike the hilltop, there is no parking issue down here.  

The space is large and bright, and looks the same as most Paneras.  The service was fine, although the ordering and delivery take place at opposite ends of the long half wall that separates the work from dining areas.  There were plenty of free tables at 8:00 am and I was very comfortable occupying a booth by myself.  

I had a basic breakfast of Quinoa Steel Cut Oatmeal, which came with sliced Strawberries, Walnut and Brown Sugar.  It was thick and tasty.  Glad it was a small bowl.  The Toasted Everything Bagel was fresh and held the Veggie Spread well.  With coffee, the meal was under $10.  No problem there.  

I have visited enough Paneras around the country to know that while they all look the same, they do not all act the same.  The Doylestown facility did not seem to have any problem with attitude, nor accuracy, although other Yelpers seem to have had different experiences.  

Given the overall quality of the experience and the ease of parking, this Panera gets my vote for the optimal breakfast on a busy morning in the downtown area.

As the nearest watering hole to my Newtown office, Black Horse is a great place for an after work happy hour stop.  I just walk over for an hour, have a beer, martini or margarita and a nibble of pretty good bar food specials, and make my way home.  It is also perfect for pre/post meeting meetings to prep/rehash the issue of the moment.  I usually find my buds upstairs in a cluster, but we have been known to find a corner downstairs to stand around in as we strategize or just blow off steam.  

The alcohol is what swings this dark horse, but the kitchen does turn out some quality dishes.  The wings, dumplings, Mexi/Texi tapas, and even the burgers are done well, though their concepts may be different than you have experienced elsewhere.  

Too, you gotta like the overall atmosphere of the old place.  The renovations have not detracted from the historical marker that this tavern has been over many many years.  After one drink it is easy to imagine the Continental Army marching down State Street on its way to Washington Crossing.  After two drinks you realize that there are Tory sympathizers in the bar.  After three, the Sons of Liberty are ready to throw them out into the street.  

I have not actually sat down for a full dinner here.  No particular reason other than the circumstances of the day.  The prices are higher than my other favorite watering hole, The Clubhouse, but the differential can be explained by the ambiance and the targeted customers. 

 Depending on my mood, BHT can be exactly right, particularly if planning the next skirmish in the War of Independence.

My current addiction to fried chicken found me cruising around Morrisville looking for my fix.  Driving along Pennsylvania Avenue after crossing the river on the pay bridge, I spied US Fried Chicken in a strip behind La Villa Italian restaurant.  I pulled into the parking lot, and wove my way closer to their shop. 

Walking up to their door I looked again at their overhead sign.  Did it mean United States Fried Chicken, or We Fry Chicken? My curiosity became more intense when I saw that the enterprise was run by a Korean couple. They were friendly, courteous, and as I was the only customer in there when I arrived, willing to do what it took to please me.  

They didn't have much chicken in the heating bins, so I asked if they would be cooking up some more.  Yes. If I was willing to wait 15 minutes, they would put a load together for the deep fryer.  Are you kidding me? Only 15 for fresh fried chicken?  I would have waited 30 if need be.  So, I watched as they took the chicken from the refrigerator (not freezer), put in into a large aluminum bowl and poured in the flour/spice mix and stirred it up.  A small cloud of orange dust rose from the swirling.  I could smell the pepper and other secret ingredients when they reached me.  Hmmm...

Mister US brought the bowl over to the fryer and carefully lowered the breasts and wings into the gurgling oil one piece at a time, while Mrs. US put together the Fried Rice that came with my order.  Other folks came in while I waited, and each was taken care of in turn.  The operation was smooth and they worked very well together as a team.  

When the chicken was golden and tested for completion, my take away order was packaged and bagged.  It was heavy from the 2 breasts, 2 wings and the hefty load of rice.  Smelled great, and it remained hot until I started eating it at home.  

The Breast was plump, moist and almost entirely edible with little bone.  The coating was crisp, crunchy, and had a very satisfying spiciness that was a little hot from whatever chili essence might be in the mix.  The wings were similarly plump and delicious.  The Fried Rice was surprisingly good.  It did not taste stale from sitting around, but was still in its early stages of existence.  

For the moment, US Fried Chicken has caught my attention and appreciation.  My search for the Southern Fried Grail continues, but at least now I know where I can go to find a fine substitute for the ultimate Fried Chicken.

Canal Street Grille sits on the corner of Afton Avenue, and the narrow service road that runs behind Main Street in Yardley Borough.  The entrance is in the back of the building and is oriented toward the canal, which can easily be seen through the window wall of the restaurant.  

My first impression was that it was a busy place for lunch, and a very attractive dining room with all the glass bringing in natural light and a pleasant view - even when the world is snow covered.  The Greek/Mediterranean menu is diverse enough to satisfy most palates.  We ordered a Bowl of Chicken Orzo Soup, Chicken Gyro with Fries, and Spanakopita, while sitting at a deuce in the middle of the floor.  We did not feel crowded nor lacking privacy despite the nearly full house.  

The Chicken Orzo Soup was a bit pricy @ $5. for a cup, but the taste was right on with a lemony aroma and flavor and chunks of white meat chicken and creamy stock.  The Gyro wrapped a warm pita around roasted chicken, tahini sauce, lettuce, and red onion.  Very good mix of texture and flavor and a satisfying meal.  The fries were good, but nothing exceptional.  The Spanakopita for lunch was an approximate 5 inch square of properly backed, philo flakey, feta melty, spinach garlicy tartness.  All quality ingredients.  The overall meal was completely enjoyable, and made me wonder why I hadn't eaten here before. 

The price structure is such that it is hard to get out for less than about $12 per, so Canal Grille might not be your every day stop, yet it certainly presents itself as a classy mellow space to enjoy a special lunch with an important conversation.  

Well done!

UPDATE. JUNE 13, 2017 - Returned to Canal Grille a few weeks ago with officemates for lunch. The place looks the same, which is to say, attractive with its airy lightness and windows facing the canal.  Menu was about the same. Still predominantly Greek. Service professional. 
My Salate Trio, consisting of a sampling of Sesame Noodles, Pineapple Chicken Salad and  Greek Salad, was pretty on the plate, and tasty going down. Each unique in texture and flavor, and just enough to fill me without feeling stuffed.  The pita was also light and excellent at absorbing the nuances of each salad.  

Still a superior lunch in the heart of Yardley, Pa.

Perhaps I am showing my cultural blinders, but I never thought a successful business could be created out of the sale of olive oils and vinegars.  Seemed like a hobby more than an enterprise. Shows how much I know!

Still, I walked into Olive Oil Etcetera, perused the merchandise, and after stifling a disbelieving chuckle, allowed myself to find something to taste.  The little cubes of Italian bread made for a perfect sponge.  I tried a few olive oils infused with garlic and was impressed with the intensity of the herb and the smoothness of the oil base.  Finally, I went for something more wild and personally rewarding.  I found the Black Cherry Balsamic Vinegar...

As in the old standard, "Love Potion Number 9," "I held my nose; I closed my eyes; I took a drink..." 

It was truly an amazing sensation. Tart over sweet cherry flavors dominated.  The vinegar offered a plush background ooze in which to savor the coating of my tongue.  It was great!

Yes. I purchased a small bottle that fit easily in my hand. It looked to be a magic potion.

But, when I kissed my lady down at 34th and Vine, I knew that Black Cherry Balsamic  Vinegar was Love Potion #9.

Got to go back for more!!!

Pura Vida (Good Life) is a new Costa Rican casa y taberna on Cummings Avenue in old Chambersburg, Trenton, NJ.  A lot of effort has been put into refinishing the outside in stone, while retaining the mid-Twentieth Century dark wood tones of the long bar and dining areas.  The place feels cool and comforting, with HDTVs in every corner playing Latin music videos that most of the customers can sing along with.  

My server, Arlene, was smoothly bilingual as she welcomed me and brought me a menu. A picture of grace and beauty.  The food offerings were diverse, but focused primarily on the native cuisine of this Central American nation.  I ordered the "Sandwich Pura Vida" with Chicken, and a fresh Bastida Mora (Raspberry shake).  When it arrived, it was in the form of a Panini, with scorch marks top and bottom, and compressed down with lettuce and tomato showing from the edges.  

After squirting on a little mayo from the table rockets, I clamped down for a big bite.  The juicy contents were hot and flavorful, although the chicken was slightly overcooked and dry.  Still, the overall impression was of a zesty, filling torta, well worth the $7 tag.  The accompanying French Fries were crispy and nicely spiced.  The Raspberry frappe was cool, tart, delicious, and made from real berries (not a mix).  

I enjoyed my visit to Pura Vida, and it was obvious that the other clientele felt the same, as most were there engaged in conversation long after their meals were done.  This resto joins a growing community of casas Latinas taking root in the capital city; each distinct, yet providing a broad palette of color and exotic rhythms to the streets of Trenton.

Stopped in mid-afternoon last Saturday.

Really liked what they've done with the place.  The core bar and dining area remains untouched, but there is a large outdoor canvassed patio out back that really expands the possibilities.  This day, a band was tuning up for an early set while a cadre of heavy metal thunder Harleys chilled and waited. 

The people working the bar and floor were cool and sweet and handled everyone with grace and humor.  The food (Burger and Roast Pork Sandwiches) were very good.  My Yeungling Draft was cold and thirst quenching. 

Haven't met Ralphie yet, but the dude got something going on! 

Will be back pronto. Left something with our pleasing server that I really want back.

This Acme in the Village of Newtown Shopping Center recently underwent a makeover to bring it into the 21 Century.  The two main improvements were the new beer aisle and Starbucks, both very near the right side entrance to the supermarket, just beyond the bakery.  

These in house coffee shops are a version of the outlets found in airports around the world. A decent work area for the crew, with smaller units for pastries and light fare, and very limited displays for their branded coffee and accessories. 

The mermaid has been here about six months and they are efficient in their operation.  One early evening this week it was well staffed with a friendly crew ready to serve.  The barista kept her poise as she mixed my Chai Latte. Never missed a beat in our repartee. The others were cleaning up in anticipation of closing within the hour.  

Perhaps, because they see the same customers routinely, but this shop was far better in its customer service than the equivalent business in an airport.  They show that the opportunity to build relationships enhances the overall experience.  No doubt, for both parties. 

Even this Starbucks-phobe found this captive distribution point enjoyable.  It even made their drinks taste better somehow. 

Good job!

Getting back to basics, all I wanted was the original double patty Elevation Burger, straight up with ketchup, jalapenos, and hot pepper relish. No fries. No shake. No sweet drinks. 

That was exactly what was delivered to my high top several minutes later. It came neatly wrapped in a plain brown paper sleeve. Upon opening, there was copious grease dripping from the wrapper. The chef must have added that after grilling, because the burger itself was no overly wet. 

It tasted great. There must be something to that organic, hormone free, free range cattle from whence the beef puck comes. The texture was soft, and the flavor, excellent. Definitely a step above 5 Dudes, and on par with Shake Shack at a lower price point. Reminded of Burgatory, one of my faves in the Pittsburgh, PA area. Priced right at around $7 for the sandwich. 

Fries started at $3.50, and shakes, $5. Add those and pretty soon you have an expensive lunch on your hands. Without, the burger justifies itself every time.

We were looking for a solid Polish restaurant to satisfy our craving for pierogis.  Alexander's Café was the nearest to our location, although not exactly in the neighborhood. We found it after a twisted course mapped by my GPS.  It sits below the train tracks on Park Avenue in Elkins Park, in a nicely renovated early 20th Century building.  Walking in, the impression was of exposed red brick walls and highly polished dark wood floors.  

It didn't feel Polish, and after sitting at a white tableclothed table and perusing the menu, it clearly wasn't only that.  There were more Italian and American dishes offered, with only a small piece of the list for East European cuisine.  That the solitary server was Asian helped complete the comfortable, yet disjointed, gestalt of the house. 

Still, we ordered a mixed plate of pierogis along side the Chicken Parmesan Special, and a bowl of Cream of Broccoli Leek Soup.  We wanted to share everything, and we were provided separate bowls and plates of each dish.  It was a very strong touch of class and customer accommodation (See Photos). 

The Soup was silky smooth and steaming.  The leek announced itself dominant to the broccoli, which was the way I liked it.  Fresh toasted croutons floated on top.  They were well seasoned and lightly crunchy.  The Pierogis were potato/cheese, sauerkraut and beef in unusually soft dough dumpling shell.  Excellent with a sautéed onion and chive garnish. We had four apiece; just enough for a co-staring role with the Chicken.  The bird was fresh (never frozen), pan fried in olive oil and breaded lightly.  The red gravy was homemade with a mild spiciness. The mozza was very new, and melted easily, without covering the color and texture beneath.  Quite tasty.  

The shop was short a server that night, and our man was forced into hard labor to keep up.  He never lost his poise, but the time between courses and receiving our check was longer than necessary due to his need to be in overdrive all evening. Not on him at all, and we showed our appreciation.  Still, management has responsibility to assure service is impeccable if they are to receive highest rank.  

Alexander's Café is a good place for dinner on a cold night, as long as you understand that it is not completely a Polish house.

Street parking can be challenging.

Staples is a cornucopia of office supplies. 

Much like Home Depot for home repairs, or Cabella's for all things outdoors, this warehouse provides multiple alternatives for anything you need to run your office, prepare your kids for school, and even large colorful tins of Danish butter cookies for your office kitchen. 

While not always the most competitive in price compared to the catalogue and online outfits, when a shop like Staples is in your town, and you can eyeball and touch the things you need before you take them home or to the office, there is an obvious advantage to the consumer that makes the cost differential worthwhile.  It is the only place I buy my calendar for the new year, and I admit to being amazed and amused by the variety of paperclips available. 

If there is a shortcoming (and the basis for not shouting, "Woohoo!") it is that the staffing is meager and there are seldom enough workers on the floor to help out finding things.  

Still, I am very happy to have Staples in Newtown.

I rarely get to this part of Levittown, but I had a date with Levittown Printing just down Haines Road and decided to look for a breakfast place where I could hang out until they opened.  Yelp led me to Violetwood Café, yet another of those quiet gardens hidden from plain sight in a strip commercial center that has seen far better days.

The café is brightly painted and staffed by a cadre of black T- shirted servers who have a very positive attitude about their restaurant and seem to enjoy their jobs.  I sat down in a booth toward the back and had a mug of coffee in front of me within a minute. It was fine. The menu had both the popular usual suspects for breakfast, plus a few permanent house specials as well as a daily black board.  

My Sausage Scramble (I think that was it) was a large mountain of Egg, Italian Sweet Sausage, Onion, Peppers, topped with Provolone.  It was moist, and chunky and fun to eat.  The Rye Toast was a real loaf complete with Caraway Seeds.  

Violetwood Café is a 4 Star performer, and could easily move up.

Freddie's Tavern on Railroad Avenue, Ewing, NJ, is an old line Italian house within a mansion across from the West Trenton Railroad Station. It has a large square bar with tables on the edges, and a couple of large dining rooms. The space is carpeted with heavy curtains, and gives off the sense of at one time being a club to bring business associates or family for traditional boot dining and entertainment. New ownership took over fairly recently, but the place looks the same as before, with the exception of live music in the bar a few nights a week. 

We sat in the bar at a hightop, ordered two drafts (Sam Adams Winterbrew & Stella Artois), and pulled a large Nonna's Margharita Pie, Calamari and bowl of French Onion Soup from the thick menu. While there, the band started playing Eagles covers in the opposite corner of the room. They were pretty good for a Tuesday night, so we hung around longer than normal to catch a few extra tunes. 

The grub was good for bar food. The squid was a touch over deep fried, but still tasted good with their excellent dipping red sauce. It included tentacles, always a plus. The soup was sealed in melted gruyere, had a strong beef stock and a load of soft sweet onions and saturated bread within. Enjoyable. The pizza was a decent rendition of the Italian flag - red sauce, white mozzarella and green basil - on a thin crisp crust. It was good, but not in the pantheon of amazing bar pies found around the capital area.

All in all, we were quite satisfied with our night at Freddy's, and agreed we would def return to satisfy our  need for Roman cuisine or burgers. For me, it was nice to be back in the bar I spend much time in during my younger days. 

Felt just like old times with older people, including me.

Liberty Two Diner (Freedom to Dine) was a good place to stop for lunch on my way north on Rt. 130 in Bordentown, NJ.  It doesn't look like much at 50 mph, but at speeds slow enough to allow for a seat at the 10 spinner counter, it had everything necessary for a solid meal.  Friendly service, large menu, Cecilware coffee maker, and small bowl of soup with every sandwich.  

The Navy Bean potage was surprisingly good, loaded with white beans and well-stewed veggies in a mild tomato base.  Liked it a lot.  Followed on by a Chicken Salad Sandwich on Rye toast, which was tasty and filling.  Perhaps, not as chunky as I prefer, but still fresh, cool, and plentiful.  The side of French Fries was way over the top, but the few I sampled were hot and crisp.  Beware opening the ketchup bottle (It discharges on its own). 

All this, and change for $7., plus tip.  

I'll be back.

I really enjoy the adaptive reuse of old factories in the heart of the city. What Conshohocken Brewing @ Bridgeport (Norristown) has done with this old gal is impressive. In addition to a utilitarian black brick with exposed steel and large windows, these guys brew up some very tasty and interesting suds, and have a dynamite kitchen.  Three strikes and you win! 

So, we stopped in on a rainy afternoon to celebrate a significant milestone (securing a driver's license), and found a table on the first floor.  The space had a long wall divider separating the bar from the dining area. There was a metal grate stairway to a second floor retreat that might have been a cool place to hang on a crowded, hoppy night.  We ordered a flight of four drafts, and a lunch of their Brussel sprout app., Fiesta Tacos, and Harvest Salad.  The beers were: Puddlers Row ESB, Burn Everything Rye Porter, Glazing Saddles, and Viking Funeral.  They were 4 ounce samples of their extensive custom brew list.  All were distinctly different, some more appealing to my palate than others.  

The ESB had a strong hoppiness, while the Burn Everything, a dominant bitters flavor.  I enjoyed the Glazing Saddles (were there really local donuts in the fermentation?), and the Viking Funeral, which was extra dark with a honey chocolate taste.  Liked these last two a lot. 

The food surprised me on the up side.  The Brussels were roasted with parmigiana  cheese and pork bellies.  The were scorched and delicious.  I've been trying to make these at home, but never as good as these dudes.  The tacos were loaded with corn, beans, tomato, lettuce, and some other things wrapped in warm tortillas.  Very good.  The salad was full of dried cranberries, walnuts, romaine, gorganzolla and more leafy stuff in an excellent vinaigrette.  More than I could consume.  We took half the salad and a few remaining sprouts home in a neat black box. 

If I was more a beer man, this place although a distance from home, would be a regular stop on the pilsner trail. Make that bourbon and I could be convinced to ride the circuit and tempt the traffic demigods on the PA Pike between Bridgeport and Bucks frequently.

Still, I read that the burgers are exceptional, so at least one more visit is foreseeable.

Taqueria Aguila (Eagle) is really two places in one. 
First, it is La Mexicana grocery store, with a great bakery and other standard items for la cocina. Second, it is a taqueria, with hot kitchen on wheels in back grilling up excellent plates of pork, beef and chicken for a variety of menu items from tacos to tortas and full dinners. In fact, the whole operation is turned around, with entrance in the rear leading to the tienda, and a dozen or so tables in back (front) for dining in. There is table service, but most of the trade is cash and carry. 

I figured this out recently when I arrived looking for dinner, read the sign on the front (back) door leading me to the rear of the building, where the entrada was, right next to a shiny stainless steel trailer cooking away and scenting the air with all manner of delicious aromas. While they don't have everything listed on their printed menu, they do have the tacos, burritos, quesadillas and various specials available. I was happy to go with two Tacos Al Pastor and fresh Watermelon juice. At $2.99 per taco, and $3.00 for  large glass of refreshing red bebida, I thought the price right, if the meal was up to snuff.

And, it was. 

The double layered tortilla rolled taco had plenty of tasty pineapple infused grilled slivers of pork, onion, peppers and crema, with lime wedges and sliced radish as garnish. A little squirt of hot sauce, a dribble of red/green salsa, and I was good to go. They were excellent - hot, crisp and a glorious mouthful to chew with a smile. The watermelon (la sandia), was cool, sweet and so refreshing. Like eating right from the totally absorbed fruit and crushing it in my mouth. Hard not to smile and let some of that delight run down my chin. 

Yes. This joint is a little divey, but that adds to its authenticity. Mixed furniture thrown together over somewhat unswept floors, just adds to the impression that for the moment you have entered Juarez or Mexicali, and departed the USA without your passport. 

I felt great solidarity with our Mexican brethren last weekend. This was the fastest way to travel to their side and join them in common cause.

Bagel appreciation is very subjective.  

One person's phantasm is another persons disappointment. So, it is important to keep that in mind when evaluating a rounder experience. 

This became paramount when I stopped by Abington All Star Bagel on Rt. 611.  The shop was small and clean.  The staff, friendly and helpful.  The bagels in the display, real beauties.  I ordered my standard Onion Bagel with butter and Swiss, and took the bag to go.  

Upon opening the white sack, and unfolding its wrappings, I beheld a large, lovely, heavily onion flaked top, which still carried the aroma of its freshness.  First bite confirmed its recent vintage, and also that it was quite dense and firmly chewy.  Many like this texture in their bagels, but I prefer a crunchier skin and light, airy innards.  

This was not that, but I appreciated the quality of the product nonetheless.  While I would not seek out All Star for my frequent bagel fix, there are others who will find these dough tires the cat's meow. 

Freedom of Choice!

La Chapinita is a Guatemalan house on Chambers Street, Trenton, NJ.  The space was the famous home of Papa's Tomato Pies, and the look is the same now as then, with the exception of Spanish signs and futbol games on the HDTVs.  The booths that once bore great tomato pies, are now primarily for Guatemaltecans to enjoy the superior comidas that come out of the new kitchen.  

The place is clean, with Tiffany-style light fixtures descending from the ceiling, and a very friendly, bilingual staff ready to assist this first time customer.  The lunch menu is fairly comprehensive with variations of beef, chicken and pork used as primary ingredients in styles Asada, Empanizada, a la Mexicana and Encebollado. They also do the traditional Tostados, Quesadillas, Burritos, Tortillas and Tacos. I ordered the Pechuga Empanizada (Breaded Chicken Cutlet with Rice and Black Beans), and Jugos Naturales de Pina (Pineapple Juice). The plate came with Black Beans and White Rice.  

It was very big for a lunch.  There were two large, thin breaded chicken breasts, lightly browned, with a wedge of lime for seasoning.  A couple of raw onion rings, slices of radish, and a pile of lettuce completed the performance.  I cut everything with my fork and enjoyed every bite.  All was tasty, complementary, and filling (I did not finish the rice).  The Pineapple Juice was cool and refreshing with a nice bite of just juiced pulpy fruit.  

This was an excellent lunch in a comfortable setting.  At under $10 for everything (plus tip), I was very satisfied, and happy that another historic Italian house was now transformed into an equally qualified newcomer from Central America. 

Buena Suerte!

Café Ole in The Valley sits in the place where Brooklyn Bagels once resided just off Second Street Pike and Bustleton Pike in Southampton, PA. The space is fairly generic, with minimalist furniture, gray walls, pseudo wood floor and large colorful mural on the back wall. Their one refrigerated display has a lot of beautiful looking pastries, but I was there for breakfast. I found the register toward the rear, and the large wall menu behind the cashier/order taker. With fresh croissant available, I went for a brekkie sandwich of turkey sausage, egg and cheese, and a small mug of coffee. 

The java arrived first and immediately woke me from my morning malaise. It was hot, strong and had a nice bite. It was roasted locally by some guy named Jay, who knows about beans. It was so flavorful I had to ask about it. Just wish I knew whether refills were free, because I would have jumped at the chance. Alas, no one stopped by to pour more, and given that I had already paid upfront for my meal, I didn't feel like testing the question. Still, it was the best part of the meal. 

The sandwich came from the back kitchen, and due to lack of any odor or sound emanating from that area, I concluded that a microwave was used to meld together the sandwich. It was fine, but the croissant was somewhat flattened in preparation, and not as flaky as this roll should be. The flavors worked well together, but it was far from extraordinary. 

Service was okay, with a new POS system and tactile screen for adding a tip (before being served, nor even seeing what you were getting), and fingering a signature to complete the credit card process. That transaction point might be reconsidered by management, as being asked for a tip at ordering seemed awkward, and likely guaranteed to generate smaller gratuities then when dealt with at the close of the meal. 

That key lime pie looked tempting, so maybe a return visit is warranted. Wouldn't go back for the breakfast, except for the luscious coffee.

Noodle Eighty-Eight (Lucky Noodles), is a surprising hybrid house in Souderton, PA. Nicely renovated residence, the dining rooms are simple, but well appointed for comfort and utilitarian style. We were there for Sunday lunch, although there was no special menu. The main attraction were the Xiao Long Bao, the Shanghai soup dumpling specialty that I had been Jones-ing for. We added mushroom filled spring rolls as a second appetizer, and General Tso's Chicken and Short Ribs as entrees. 

In order of appearance the meal ran from excellent to ordinary. 

The XLB were very good, with steaming tasty pork truffle oil bouillon and filling. The gingered vinegar was a nice complement to pour into the pouch once the top knot was bitten off and the mixed contents sucked out. Such a tactile fun experience. 

The Spring Rolls were deep fried and stuffed with ground mushroom and sweet dipping sauce. They were crunchy, but the filling had little flavor nor interest. Wouldn't get this again.

The side greens salad was small, but had a pleasing sweet vinegar finish. It's unusual to get a salad in a Chinese house, and this was a tip of their chef's cap to their hybrid intentions. Far better than the ginger goop dressing on iceberg found in almost all sushi zones. 

General Tso was the weak soldier this day. The pieces were large requiring cutting to consume (thus, the need for western flatware). The breading was thick and not at all crisp, and the old man had spent too much time being woked. It was dry and lacked any verve. Disappointing.

Luckily, the day was saved by the Short Rib dish. More western than Asian in presentation and taste, it was tender, juicy and packed a tangy punch from the excellently reduced sauce. It pulled off the bone easily. But for the baby bok choy, this reminded of a good pot roast or sauerbraten. Regardless, it was nearly perfect.  

We made the drive from Newtown in 40 minutes on a rainy afternoon. Given the overall experience it is doubtful we would do it again. The dishes were inconsistent, but priced for perfection. Service was good, but without expected hot tea, nor rice. Also true about the parking situation. Not good unless you park across the road, around the corner or find one of the few that hug the building. 

3.5 STARS

Cleanest Friendly's I've ever visited. 

Like an oasis in the middle of Gloucester Premium Outlets, it provided shelter and sustenance when I had had enough shopping and just wanted to get off my feet and quell the emerging late afternoon hunger pangs from dodging lunch.  

Friendly service, and a reasonably priced patty melt with waffle fries were exactly what I needed.  The surprise free sundae put a creamy smile on my face. 

Sure. I've had better, but Being There was Everything this day!

The question of the decade is: When it comes to cheesesteak, is there a difference between using a traditional Italian long roll or stepping out with a round poppy seed kaiser? 

Donkey's Place on Haddon Avenue in Camden, NJ, has been an iconoclast for a generation, daring to shape shift and challenge all comers to demonstrate that their creation is in any way inferior to the classic torpedo.
