Now that I sat at the bar, watched the sliced beef being grilled and consumed a whole sandwich 'wit' soft, translucent sauteed onions, I have an opinion. 

And, it is that there IS a difference in taste and texture that is pronounced and obvious. First, the flavor of the bread is distinct in each. While the Italian roll has a sourdough light saltiness, the round boy is a bit sweet as white bread tends to be. Second, the meat/bread ratio is changed, with relatively more meat to roll at Donkey's. After all, there is less bread in the Kaiser than a foot long. Third, the thin sliced beef is never separated for grilling @ Donkey's, but allowed to cook in a thick pile and turned over so that only the top and bottom of the pack touch hot steel. The rest are heated through passage of the heat through the slices. In my case, it meant that the middle of the sandwich was tender and juicy, while the outer layers were mildly overcooked, tougher and chewier. Forth, the Donk adds spice to the pile of onions simmering on the stove, giving them a reddish orange tint and slight chili flavor. Never experienced that at my favorite joints in and around Philly. 

Don't get me wrong, I really liked the sandwich and the overall dive bar essence of this place. Service was pretty and efficient, and I was given a bumper sticker to commemorate the visit. Still, I would be less than honest if I said I liked it just as much as Steve's Prince of Steaks. No. It wasn't as instantly addicting and scrumptious as that. It was a half step down from that pinnacle of steakdom. 

Still, overall it was a very enjoyable lunch, with the atmosphere contributing mightily to the fun. I understand what Anthony Bourdain loved about it, but he didn't live cheesesteak his whole life. 

Doubtless, I will be back for more.

Cheeseboro's Kitchen is a stand alone building on Pennington Road that does soul food and other American classics.  It is primarily a take away house, with only a few tables along the front window for those who want to eat right there.  Ordering is done at the cash register, and each meal is prepared individually. The finished dishes come out on the other side of the room in front of the pizza ovens left over by the previous tenant.  

The good thing about this approach is that the meals are hot and fresh.  Only the side dishes were premade and chilled as they wait for you.  The down side of this "just in time" production is that when they get busy, the wait can be rather long for your meal to be completed and brought out of the kitchen.  While I was there, people were going outside to wait, or leaving all together to return when the food was ready.  Some customers call ahead, which while a good idea, just prolongs the wait for everyone. 

The people working here, including management, are friendly and appear to be working hard to get the food out.  My questions were answered with a smile, even when I was showing my cultural ignorance about how certain things would be presented.  For example, a "sandwich" is not something between two slices of bread, but instead is a load of whatever you want on top of three slices of white bread.  You can make a sandwich of it yourself, but there is way more meat, fish, etc., than can fit within the confines of a manageable sandwich. Easier just to eat the food and as much of the loaf as you desire. Me? I skipped it all together in order to consume as much fish as possible.  Happy to be enlightened. 

What about my whiting sandwich and side of macaroni salad (recommended)?  Six large fillets, light breading and flash deep fried, made for a delicious lunch.  I could only eat four of them. The macaroni side came in a plastic tub, mixed with copious mayo and bits of tuna.  Cool and great tasting. Again, more than this man could stuff down.  

The only drawback to Cheeseboro's is the wait for the food to be prepared, and secondarily to the unused space in the store that could be put to use with more tables or perhaps, displays.  The meal, with the side and bottle of iced tea, came to around $12.  Quite reasonable for the quantity and quality of the offerings.  Now that I have a better idea what is going on, I will be back to try the rib sandwich, and perhaps, even their burgers, and more of their side dishes.

This is a tough one to call. 

The premises of Three Monkeys Café is beautiful, both inside and out. A lot of thought and money was put into bringing the old saloon back to life. From tin-type ceiling tiles, through refinished wood floors, exceptional back bar, and zany monkey decorations throughout, the inner sanctum of this place is a pleasure to sit in and enjoy.  Great job!

The outer side patio/garden is likewise a wonderland.  Colorful, whimsical, tall treed, and full of monkey business.  On a spring, summer or autumn day or evening, it is no doubt an endearing space for a few drinks and semi-romantic meal.  Gotta love it!

The weak link is the kitchen. 

We were there for breakfast after visiting the USCIS facility nearby. It wasn't quite warm enough to dine al fresco, so we sat at a corner table in the barroom, and were served by a friendly management person.  We were introduced to Douwe Egbert Coffee, a Dutch brand in operation since 1753.  One of their spinoffs developed a novel approach to mass produced coffee that liquefies it in concentrate, and brews on site and when ordered, so every cup is fresh and strong.  Mine had a mild chicory flavor.  I really liked it, although I would need a lot more sampling and comparison to fresh ground beans to know if it was as good as what I grind/brew at home. Still, it was a pleasant cuppa Joe. 

The sausage, egg and cheese on seeded roll with side of home fries, were the main attractions.  They left me somewhat disappointed.  It was fine that they used cut up links rather than patties, and threw them in with a few scrambled eggs and slices of cheese.  It was very big, because the roll was from a cheesesteak sandwich; not a hard Kaiser.  But, it had not been grilled at all, and did not really work with the breakfast theme.  Too, the mix lacked spice, and would have benefited by being cooked with a pinch of salt, pepper, and maybe even a shake or two of Pecos Bill.  Finally, the potatoes looked great and greasy, but were completely cold.  

A little quality control at the grill, and perhaps retaining a real chef to handle the preparation or at least to train the staff, would make a world of difference.  Three Monkeys has a ton of potential. It just needs to polish the brass and sand the wood trim (culinary-wise) to become a completely enthralling experience.  

3.5 Stars

Redhouse Bagels sits underneath Johnny Apple's Restaurant on Buck Road, Holland, PA.  It is in what was the walkout basement.  Coming from the north, it is easy to miss as it is behind the massive building housing Johnny's.  Still, plenty of parking on the side near the creek.  It is worth finding. 

Bagels preferences are very subjective, but to my buds, Redhouse does a very good rounder. When fresh and hot from the oven, they are richly textural and flavorful.  They seem to do only one large batch in the early morning, so if you get there late like I did, there is the chance you won't get what you really want.  I'm an onion bagel maven, but as they were all depleted, I grabbed the last everything bagel in the house. Butter and Swiss is my standard order, so that the taste of the bagel complements, rather than being overwhelmed by a heavier load. They did not skimp on the toppings, and the overall experience was very positive. While I prefer a crisper skin and soft innards, this one was more pliant, but still had wonderful flavor to compensate.  The egg bagel was likewise a pleasure to eat according to my beautiful companion. 

The only downside aside from the lack of crunch, was that Redhouse is strictly takeout, with no place to sit and enjoy breakfast.  If I were them, I'd look into clearing some of the brush in the parking lot along the creek, and putting in a few tables and benches for people to enjoy watching the roiling water flow just off the nearby old mill race.  That would be a fantastic place to hang out with good bagel and cuppa joe.

Adrianne, the woman who runs Mommie Joe's told me that the tiny shop at the corner of South Broad and Division Streets in Trenton, NJ, had been slinging Haitian dishes for more than thirty years at that location.  How is it that I never saw it before last week after living and/or working in the TNJ for almost that long?  I guess I just wasn't ready for it. 

After the cover of each heated chaffing dish was lifted for me to see what was cooking, I had no problem selecting a plate of Black Rice, Oxtail Stew and a couple of golden fried Platanos. The Black Rice was a first for me, but I have learned it is possible to buy it in the right markets.  It acted like the paler version I was accustomed to, with the taste of salt, pepper, garlic, and maybe a touch of something like turmeric or coriander, that only required the spooning of the Oxtail bone and amazing tawny rich sauce to make it explode with a flavor combination that was savory, smoky, meaty and mysterious.  With only plastic utensils to handle the chunkiness of the beef, I really had no choice but to get manual.  It would have been great if lunch had been served on a plate rather than in styro take out containers, but I understand that sometimes low budget is the only way to survive.  

It became an unruly mess to pick up and gnaw at the tender ox still clinging to this matrix, but after a few seconds I forgot about the office I had to return to, and the white shirt and tie I was wearing, and just let such stolid convention go.  The only way to eat this was DIRTY.  

The Plantain was thin and nicely breaded before frying.  It was still starchy, but the flavor was compelling.  

Mommie Joe's certainly needs a clean up, and a better spacing of the tables that were all pushed together in front of the store, but there is no question of authenticity.  Adrianne even let me come behind the counter to have a better look at her dishes.  She was very confident that I would like what was on the menu.  

She was right.

The name on the sign out front is, "Mauceri's Steak House."  

While I didn't see any steak on the menu, this crossover Salvadoran/Italian shop seems to know what they are doing in the cocina.  On my first visit, I had the pleasure of sampling their Chili Rellenos from the Latin side of the menu.  They was very good.  This time, I went with the Italian Hot Dog because of my curiosity about how it would be different than all the others I have eaten around Trenton over the years.  Too, at $3.50, it was the best deal in the house.  

I was impressed.  The standard frankfurter arrived at the bottom of an excellent half torpedo roll, and buried alive with a load of sautéed onion, pepper and potato.  More French fries on the side.  There was ketchup on the table, but no mustard.  I decided to go with the flow and doctor my sandwich with what was available.  So, I squirted from the red table rocket, and poured in most of the salsa that came with the chips.  

The result: A hot and spicy creation that looked Italian, but tasted like the hybrid it really was.  The salsa gave it a real kick in the pants, and brought the best out of the sandwich.  I enjoyed every bite. 

The Licuados Tamarindo was cool and a bit sweeter than I prefer, perhaps because it seemed to come premade, rather than made fresh in a blender.  Still, @ $3., I wasn't complaining. 

Overall, a very happy face meal.

When many folks think about bars in Newtown they think pretentious crowds and overpriced drinks and meals. You know who you are, and what I am talking about. Truth is, you guys are not far off the mark.  "Those places" do have an attytood. 

Perhaps, the lone exception is the Clubhouse Bar and Grill on lower East State Street. It is the outrider that serves the rest of us who prefer to drink our beer and eat bar food or pizza with a jukebox playing in the background, and the sound of billiard balls slamming into each other, or hanging outback on nice evenings, watching the sunset to the sound of acoustic guitar and local talent entertainers. All this at such a decent price. You will get change from your Twenty for a couple of beers and a light meal. 

There are plenty of brew alternatives here, both bottle and draft, with 'make you' happy hour specials. The wings come out hot, spicy and delectable, and no one minds if the bones pile up high on the table. They also realize that your fingers are going to get a bit sticky and bring out a stack of heavy gauge napkins without being asked.  Ain't nothing dainty 'bout the Clubhouse.  I had the cheesesteak quesadilla app the other night, and I took a quarter of it home to feed my son. He was so pleased he wants to go with me next time. Ok, buster.  It was that good!

The Clubhouse is not perfect, but who cares? It is still the mellowest joint in Ntown, and the place everyone knows your name.

It's where you want to be.


February 2, 2014 - Went to their take out side today to pick up wings and beer for the Super Bowl. Called ahead. Everything ready in 30 minutes.  Quite an efficient operation.  Great wings. Enough beer choices to keep everyone happy. 

Definitely use Clubhouse again for home events.  The wings were large and tasty.  Blue Moon, Boddington and Redd's Apple Ale.  Everyone was happy, except the Broncos.

Villa Rosa was a regular stop in my early years in Bucks County, but as Newtown evolved into a community with many good restaurants, the need to travel to Lower Makefield (not Yardley), became an unnecessary time expense.  Last night I was driving back from a meeting and found myself hungry and very near Villa Rosa, and decided to stop in and have something light.  

I ordered an Eggplant Parm sandwich.  It arrived a few minutes later in the hands of a pleasant server.  Although the store was scheduled to close in 30 minutes I felt no pressure to eat quickly, and my server returned a few times to check on my satisfaction.  The meal itself was quite good.  The Eggplant was very thinly sliced and lightly sautéed in olive oil before placement in the Torpedo Roll for toasting in the oven.  It was not breaded and held up well with the Mozza and Red Gravy.  The Roll itself was crisped nicely before arrival.  I normally just eat the innards and have only a few bites of the bread, which is what I did this time.  It was as filling as I needed it to be.  

Overall, I was satisfied with my repast, and will have no hesitancy to return next time in the area.  Besides, there are a few other decent food outlets in this commercial center, not the least of which is Indian Garden, an excellent curry house.

Stopped in the other day for a late lunch.  This was a first visit since this pizza parlor changed hands, and it was immediately apparent that the entire shop had had a makeover. The kitchen was now in the back, and the dining room in front; a reversal of its original layout.  New walls and floors made the place feel more upscale than the old place. Nice use of stone, wood and paint. 

We opted for cheesesteak and eggplant parm sandwiches.  Both came with fries. The steak was a full load of chopped beef mixed with onions and mushrooms on a lightly crusted roll.  Very good.  The eggplant was thin sliced, breaded, sautéed in olive oil, and then grilled again in the oven, after which it was dosed with their homemade gravy and mozza.  Again, very good. The rolls were notable for their crunch and pleasant taste. The fries were really unnecessary, and were the weakest part of the repast, as frozen crinkle cuts.  

Reasonable prices.  Friendly service. 

Will definitely return for the pizza and more menu items when in an Italian mood.

Well, all right!

The new and improved Acme in The Village of Newtown requires a revisit to the old review. It is no longer the boring step sister box store of yesteryear. Now, not only has Starbucks taken up residence in the front of the store, but they have installed a beer and wine aisle and a small eating area near the deli department. Will the wonders never cease?!

Even service seems to have moved up a notch. More friendly faces and helpful hands. Better trained cashiers and help desk personnel. The salad bar is definitely cleaner and better stocked than before, too. 

Yes. It is still an Acme and not a Wegmans, so let's keep perspective. Yet, the new Acme is far better than the old, and they deserve an "A" for effort. Prices are still very competitive for the area. They are really working to hold on to their old customers and attract new ones. 

These days I find myself thinking of stopping in their Starbucks, or grabbing a six pack rather than making a separate run to the local beer outlet. Give them credit for opening my mind to their new possibilities.

Wandering around Northern Liberties gives the feeling of late 19th Century urban America, when each neighborhood had to be self contained to provide its residents with all the necessities of life. Somehow the benign neglect that has allowed a slow evolution of this cityscape has resulted in organic growth that is very appealing to those of us seeking a comfortable alternative to what is now high speed life hot wired into our existence. 

While a place like Soy Cafe would never have been dreamed of in those early days, the new urban pioneers create a new version of what a hood should have.  The retail space feels old and timeless, while the actual business is anything but.  If smoothies and light fare with a veggie bias is what you seek, then Soy Cafe is your siren song. 

Work your way through the multitude of fresh fruit and soy milk drinks, each more satisfying than the last.  If something solid is required, don't hesitate to try a wrap or sandwich or a noodle bowl.  Everything is fresh and prepared with love. Grab a table and watch the gentles and notso come and go. 

Zen Peach or Grill Eggplant Wrap are the yin-yang of a satisfying meal.  Always a house made sweet by the register for après dinez vous..

Better known as Anthony's IV Pizza & Pasta on Bridge Street in Morrisville, Pa., which has its own Yelp page and more reviews, this old line pizza joint may not look like much, but turns out pretty good Italian sandwiches and platters at last century prices. 

Only street parking available, but in the evening, the avenues of Morrisville are pretty much open and you can pull up right in front or on the side street (Washington).  Friendly faces and adequate booth and table seating.  

This is another of the Mexican/Italian deals, but don't let that deter you.  The food is good and you won't really notice any Spanish accent unless you order the Mexican Pizza.  My Sweet Sausage, Pepper & Onion Sandwich was as good as most you can get across the river in the capital of New Guernsey.

The third child of New Leaf Cuisine (Manayunk & Broomall being the elder siblings), Purple has replaced the ill fated Golden China at the Floral Vale location in Lower Makefield. While "Asian Fusion" is often just confusion, this house seems to actually know what it's doing when it comes to Sushi and Chinese food. 

Their menu is a complex of decent sushi, "Street Food," noodles and Chinese dishes, all well done with a touch of creativity and lots of flavor. Prices reflect the talent in the kitchen, so even the dim sum small plates add up fast. As a first timer, and suspecting that Mandarin was the primary language, we opted for that part of the menu to sample. 

Smart move.

Our four dishes were; Beef Chow Fun (traditional Cantonese broad noodles), Chicken with Dry Pepper (medium heat w jicama for cool crunch) from Chinese Kitchen - Entrees, Spicy Crispy Chicken (crunchy fried chicken Szechuan style) and Wok-fried Lemongrass Beef (hottest dish w Thai spice sensibilities). They were all very good, with tender sliced beef, white meat chicken and no skimping on the spices nor portions. Three of us supped to our hearts' content with leftovers for another day. Each made its own statement without redundancy. The kitchen was well trained in the mystic art of Asian sauces. 

If the sushi and other Japanese pieces are on par with the mainland portion of the menu, Purple Leaf could well be worthy of that fifth star. As it is, it is a giant leap forward for the local Asian restaurant scene.

TWO SLICE LUNCH REVIEW

Independence Plaza on South Broad Street, Hamilton, has been a difficult place to attract customers since its development thirty years ago. But, there is a new pizza joint down there now that provides reason for renewed optimism. 

LaLucci Pizza has been open a few months. I stopped in last week for a two slice and a soft drink (water) lunch. Like most pizza parlor these days, it has several prebaked pies on display for consideration and a grill for hot sandwiches. As a first timer, I wanted to try a basic slice and something higher end for comparison. There was a good looking Margherita sitting up front and a regular pie on the counter, both with a few triangles missing. I asked for one of each, and mentioned that I like my reheats well done.

The store manager brought them to me a few minutes later, steam still wafting off the Vulcan surface. They were a nice size. I sprinkled crushed hot pepper flakes on them and went to work. First bite brought a crunchy report from the firm undercarriage. Very nice! No droop. Slightly salty taste to the sauce and cheese. The regular slice was leaking oil onto the paper plate, but not enough to require a demerit. The red, white and green margherita had the same hard edge crust and the pleasant flavor of fresh basil enhancing the chunky tomato gravy. 

Both were better than the average reheat jobs for the area, and deserving recognition. 

Happy to oblige with 4 big ones!

Khmer Grill is one of the small shops in the new Chinatown Square food court in the middle of Race Street between 10th and 11th.  It prepares and serves up a limited menu of Cambodian style BBQ wings, beef skewers, sausage and chicken hearts on gizzards on sticks. There are also a few sides of rice and papaya salad.  Prices reflect that they are operating indoors in a newly renovated building with commensurate overhead. Thus, they cannot compete with the open air food carts at FDR nor Mifflin Parks in South Philly, where the vendors pay a yearly licensing fee, rent or buy their small stands, and are otherwise free of fixed costs.  If you don't want to wait for warmer weather for your Cambodian BBQ fix, Khmer Grill is presently your cold weather friend.  

The food is well marinaded and basted while on the fire.  The result is a pleasant tasting mildly tart/semi-sweet flavor on tender meats that retain their juices.  My sausage was plump and spurted with every firm bite.  The thin sliced beef was easily slipped from its impalement on the bamboo sticks.  Liked them both a lot. 

With any luck, both Khmer Grill and Chinatown Square will be successful and lead the way to other such food malls that have been so successful in the larger Asian population centers in Flushing, NY, L.A., San Fran., and Toronto.  In the space formerly reserved for one restaurant, you can now have a multitude of street food options from around the world. Right. Not the same as a standard sit down meal, but it has its place when interesting light bite snacks are more what you are looking for.  

For those fortunate enough to have sampled the real thing while travelling through Southeast Asia, Khmer Grill is authentic enough to bring back fond memories.

I am a fan of any new business that takes on the challenge of a major competitor with better goods, warmer environment and sincere service.  That Pretty Bird Coffee is about 50 yards from the green mermaid makes these folks heroic. That they are truly outclassing them is the stuff of legend. 

The space, although a small storefront, is well designed and cozy.  There are a few deuces, high communal tables and a counter for those desiring to maximize the experience by sipping in.  The staff is young and very friendly, with a few managers involved to keep everything flowing.  It was easy to engage in a pleasant conversation with them as I waited for my latte and strawberry donut (homemade). These guys are really making an effort to build their reputation and customer base.  

My latte was very good. No need for sugar or other adulterants, as it was strong and flavorful on its own.  The donuts were an indulgence, but they were sitting in the work area just staring at me. Impossible to resist.  When I took my first bite, I learned it was a cake donut with an interesting sugar/cinnamon/strawberry sprinkle topping.  Very good, but impossible to eat without a trail of crystals.  Slightly tart, too.  Liked it, but doesn't challenge Yum Yum or Mary's in the gooey goodness department.  

At $6.50 for the medium cup and the dunker, the price was okay. 

Pretty Bird is a nice place for meetups, and small conversations. 

Parking behind the building and in the adjacent lots.

Tommy is the new kid in town. 

He took over the old pizza joint named, "Gabriella's," renovated it into a bigger, more attractive kitchen specializing in burgers, hot dogs, chicken, ice cream and shakes. Indoor and outdoor seating available. Plenty of parking in back. It feels a bit like an escapee from New Hope just a few miles up River Road. 

I ordered a Cheeseburger Junior (4 oz., w cheddar, sauteed onions and ketchup), and standard Hot Dog (mustard, ketchup, sweet relish), and Vanilla Shake. The hot dog was very good with firm casing and nice garlic beef profile, in an excellent torpedo roll with capacity to hold everything without leakage or falling off the truck when tipped. Liked it alot. The burger was half consumed by family before I had a photo opportunity.

 My portion was decent for a quarter pounder, with juicy chew and flavor from the blend of shortrib, chuck and sirloin used for the puck, and the semisweet onion. The only weak link was the bun which was saturated by grease from the sandwich and did not survive the experience intact due to sogginess. The shake was cool and thick, but began separating before I could drink it all. It seemed to be made from soft-serve and milk rather than real ice cream. Not worth the $5.99 tag. 

The closest comparison among offerings in the fast casual burger universe is 5 Guys. Tommy's hot dogs are superior, their burgers very similar, but the shakes need work. Can't speak to the rest of the menu, but I wouldn't mind returning to find out.

Apparently, the Popeyes website had so much traffic recently as people went crazy looking for their new chicken sandwiches, that it broke down! What followed was the exhaustion of sandwich provisions nationally, resulting in millions of disappointed customers arriving at bright orange & red stores just to discover signs across the wall menu that said, 

" WE'LL BE BACK!" 

I was one of those people at their small shop in Levittown, PA. The line wasn't long, but the sense of delayed gratification was tangible. After all those YouTube vids of people sitting with stacks of regular and spicy mayo sammies wrapped in specially designed paper, and watching them munch them up, rolling their eyes in delight, and attempting to speak waxingly with mouths full, it was almost too much to bear. 

So, I grudgingly went home with a 3 piece dinner to share, knowing I would have a hard time convincing anyone that I didn't eat them on the way. 

Brilliant marketing, though! Always leave us wanting more.

Rice & Curry Asian Bistro is a Thai/Asian fusion house on Limekiln Pike in Maple Glen, PA. Although I ate outside at a table under the overhang, I did go in looking to let someone know I was there. The dining room was attractive, and in a post-Covid world I would definitely chose to dine inside. 

Their menu is divided between standard Thai dishes and Japanese sushi. There may be compromises with strict authenticity for the sake of broadening market appeal, but not so much that close familiarity is missing. In fact, my late lunch and the green curry takeout for family were quite good and definitely worthwhile. I, for one, understand the business decision to find a reasonable common denominator in ingredients and style, as long as the fundamental touch, feel and flavor of the food remains. 

This, Curry & Rice succeeded in doing. 

My Spicy Noodles (not "Drunken Noodles") were prepared with medium width rice pasta, rather than the traditional broader noodles, but the sauce was right on and plenty hot enough, with a strong variety of fresh veggies (carrot, string bean, onion, green/red pepper). So, while there was less surface area for the sauce to cling to, it wasn't really noticeable on the tongue, although there was less chew. They also decorated the bowl with an iceberg wedge, which seemed incongruous. Too, my Tom Kha Soup was excellent, with a pleasing hot/cool profile of lemongrass and coconut milk, with a large supply of shredded chicken and fresh mushrooms. I tipped the rim of the bowl to my lips to suck out every drop. My son liked his Green Curry takeout when he got to it hours later. 

I appreciated their lunch menu provided somewhat smaller plates at commensurate prices. I was able to push away from the table feeling satisfied without being overfull. 

That is always appreciated.

Devil's Acre Tavern is a very attractive reuse of an old roadhouse along Easton Road (Rt. 611), Plumsteadville, PA. It takes it name from the nearby Devil's Half Acre, originally a stone tavern built in the 18th Century close on the Delaware River that sold alcohol and other services to the river traffic navigating upstream and down in a time the the river was the primary means of transportation in this part of colonial America. In fact, they had no license to make nor sell alcohol, and the joint was a place where violence and shady characters abounded. Legend and history say there were many people killed there and buried in the backyard. 

Perhaps, to lessen the reliance on that unsavory history, the name was chosen without the word "Half," but the connection is not lost on those aware of these facts. Still, it appears often enough in the menu and on the walls of the establishment to hint at the local lore. 

Luckily, this house is totally legit. Ownership has created an attractive utilitarian space, German American in nature, with excellent cross section of Deutsch brews, quality cocktails, reasonable happy hour choices and a strong kitchen. We stopped in on Saturday afternoon at the start of HH, and thoroughly enjoyed the entire experience. After a little confusion with our new server about availability of happy hour and where to sit to capture those prices, everything was resolved quickly and we waited for delivery to our dining room table of Three Onion Soup, Dragon Wings and Pierogi of the Day apps/sides, and two DHA Burgers and a DHA Dog. 

Everything was very good to terrific. My stepson wouldn't share his potage, so it must have been great. We all sampled the wings @$.50 per. They were not too big, but were amply meaty with a good sweet/hot glaze with sesame seeds sprinkled on top. The pierogi were the weak link. The dough was thick, too chewy and dominated the flavor of the seasoned veggies within. Ate one and took the rest home. Maybe sour cream would have helped. 

The burgers were huge with double patties, bacon, lettuce, red onion, and their DHA sauce. Both were past the medium well finish requested, but there was still plenty of flavor and moisture. I loved the double dog with chopped red onion, dark mustard and well done bacon in a fresh crisp torpedo roll. Great taste and texture. @$5 HH price it was a star of the show. 

Devil's Acre Tavern is a 35 minute drive from home, but when in the mood for German beer and cuisine it is well worth the trip. Tuesday Burger Night sounds like a winner, too.

CURBSIDE SERVICE COVID-19 REVIEW -

Bualoy is a Lao restaurant in Devon, PA. It was fairly near Knox Covered Bridge in Valley Forge Historic Park, and the right place to pick up a late lunch to take home. 

We parked out front and were greeted by a friendly order taker who handed us a paper menu and made good suggestions in response to our inquiry about what they did best. The conversation led to ordering Homemade Laotian Sausage, Nam Khao Salad and spicy Drunken Noodles with Beef. Fifteen minutes later she returned with our neatly packed meal. 

Arriving home 50 minutes later, the sausage was still warm, the salad cool and the drunkens, hot. We liked all three dishes. The sausage had the interesting flavor of lemongrass, cilantro, onion and ground veggies mixed with pork. It came with a small side of mashed chilli sauce which added a kick. The Nam Khao was cool and hot with special mention to the crushed peanuts that were fried with a mild sweetener that added unusual interest to the dish. The Drunken Noodles were wide rice pasta loaded with green pepper, onion, carrot and sprouts in a three star hot scale brown gravy. Delicious. 

We can only imagine how much better our meal would have been had we been able to eat in restaurant when everything was right from the kitchen. Still, it was good enough to make a return visit when it is safe to enjoy a sit down right at the source.

The name on the Spring Menu breakfast was: "I Can't Believe They're Vegan Pancakes." 

Well, now I know that was just a bit of clever marketing, because after eating the nearly tasteless, dry, syrup sponges, I now fully believe they WERE vegan, and in a word, "boring."  My high hopes were dashed by reality. 

But, I forgive Turning Point for misleading me, because everything else about their new facility in the Village @ Newtown Shopping Center, is first class. The room is sun filled, bright and airy, with high fanned ceilings, white walls, and copious amounts of glass, letting customers be part of any sunny day outside while they sup within. A definite country cottage vibe throughout. Service is uber friendly without being unctuous, and the $2.50 house brewed java comes with a insulted pitcher of coffee, mug, and small glass carafe of milk (upon request). More than enough for me. 

I enjoyed sitting at the bar and watching the coffee operation in front of me, and the dining room activity through the backbar mirrors. The rest of the menu was appealing for both morning and afternoon meals, even if the prices reflected the cost of Newtown's newly discovered sophistication (falling into the category of be careful what you wish for). 

Turning Point, like its sibling nearby, Harvest, is the new order of things around here. Along with all the other restaurants already there, and those being planned (Chipotle, Iron Hill, Starbucks, Melt Shop, etc.), they will either become a sought after destination for fast casual dining, or a place to be avoided because of inadequate parking, and too much sameness. There is already talk of the center becoming a food court. 

It definitely feels like a gold rush around here, and it remains to be seen how deep and wide the rich vein goes. It will thrive for a while, but whether it becomes a permanent part of life or a ghost town, depends on changing tastes, the local economy and how well conceived the plans were at the start.

I stopped in at Namaste Indian Bistro in the Davisville Center in Warrington, PA, yesterday to chow down on their weekend lunch buffet. The shop is deep and quite narrow, obviously carved out of an adjoining store to create another retail space. Maybe a dozen tables in front, with the food spread out on a table right outside the kitchen. 

There was plenty to choose from made up of a mix of chicken, vegetarian and even a goat curry dish. Some were very freshly prepared, while others were past their prime from sitting out over a steam table, inevitable when dealing with buffets. Still everything I tasted was good to excellent, especially the veggie korma and custom made garlic naan. Appreciated all the beautiful yellows, reds and amber colors from all the sauces. 

I enjoyed my meal. At $11.99 for AYCE, I thought it a very good deal. 

Service was minimalist, but how much to expect when basically serving yourself? My water glass was refilled, the used plate removed from the table promptly and the naan brought out from the tandor oven when fully baked and steaming hot. 

What's not to like?!

Surprisingly strong fried chicken down on South Broad Street by Popeye's. 

The bright orange shop has been there for several years, but always seemed out of place as a drive through box in the middle of urbanity. My bad for not checking it out before now. Walked in on a very clean space staffed with friendlies and stocked with trays of golden brown clucker. 

Their two piece lunch deal came with one side and a biscuit. Under $5 for a filling and tasty treat. I ordered the spicy version. While it wasn't too spicy, it was certainly hot and crisp. The inner meat in the breast burnt my fingers as I ripped it apart. Soft and juicy. Really liked it. Actually gave me two wings along with the breast. Coke machine offered a large variety of their soft drinks. 

There is another excellent chicken shack further down Broad, so there is a choice of good stops to satisfy the bird lover in you.

While I am not an Applebee's regular customer, I do like this chain for consistently decent food (primarily salads and burgers), reasonably priced drinks and a well trained staff. This particular location on Street Road in Southampton, PA, does not deviate from the norm. It is a pleasant place to grab a beer and bite at the bar when traveling solo, or at a booth when with family. They don't take themselves too seriously. They recognize they are a roadhouse, provide sustenance without pretension and work to let customers have a good time, in a wholesome atmosphere. 

There was a wait for tables in the lobby when I arrived, but almost no one at the bar. I inquired of a passing server if I could belly up there immediately, and she said, "no problem." I was alone, and saw no point to occupying a table when a bar stool suited my needs. Bartender Kate approached quickly to take my drink order. I asked about pumpkins, and she told me that River Horse had just delivered their Hipp-O-Lantern pumpkin ale. Perfect! I was sipping from their signature hippo snifter a moment later. She also handed me a menu. I quickly decided on the whiskey bacon burger, pink. 

What I received was a half pounder with melted cheese, crisp bacon, lettuce, tomato and red onion. While beyond pink, it was still fresh and tasty with a sweetish bun. I needed knife and fork to disassemble the thick sandwich. The fries were nice and hot/crisp. 

At about $11, it was a value investment in a filling and enjoyable meal. We all have certainly paid more for much less in the current burger wars.

I'm not sure how the words, "authentic" and "style" can be used in the same phrase to describe the legitimacy of anything produced far from the original source, as done by Manhattan Bagels. "Style" suggests it has a similarity to the original, but really isn't from the creative source; while, "authentic," is defined as being from the original hands. So, it really can't be both - except in the world of Madison Avenue false advertising. 

Please excuse the discourse on meaning, but the truth is that regardless of name and slogans, these are decent bagels. While not quite as crisp as I like on the outside, the texture is lightly chewy with a pleasant mild maltiness within, and without skimping on the toasted onion flakes or veggie cream cheese. I would like them even if from Manhattan, Kansas. 

Service was friendly and quick, and the House Blend coffee provided the requisite morning kick in the pants. 

This franchise is well represented in these parts, so while not on my list of absolute favorite bagel houses, it is certainly worth a stop when the breakfast bird is hunting for its early worm. You shouldn't be disappointed.

Hospitals are never fun places to be. Even when just visiting a sense of dread overcomes us. 

Yet, Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, and all its component parts, makes the experience as positive as possible for most of us.  From the valet service drivers through the Chief of Medicine everyone approaches people with humanity and an understanding of what is involved in going there.  

I have been using TJUH for a long time for myself, my family, and friends.  I recommend it to everyone seeking world class medicine with a friendly face.  From Rothman, The Heart Institute, Cancer Center, and ER, the treatment is state of the art and first class. 

Unfortunately, I have seen my share of medical centers in New York, and for my health and for those I love, Jefferson is where I find the best combination of care and caring. 

Before you decide on anything serious it is wise to at least obtain a consultation with a Jeff doc.  You will be glad you did.

This is an old style Jersey diner before they started using steroids to make them bigger. The ambiance suits the architecture, and the staff is friendly and prompt.  

I stopped in for a late lunch last week.  I was greeted with a warm engaging smile by Christine, who led me to my table, handed me the menu, and went over the specials.  

I went with the Chicken Salad Wrap which came with a cup of Chicken Okra Soup and Fries.  The Soup was really good; making me wish I had a bowl of it.  Lots of chunky okra and chicken, with other veggies thrown in for good measure.  The Chicken Salad was wrapped tight with Lettuce, Tomato and Sweet Pepper.  I could only finish half, but it tasted freshly made.  Quite enjoyable, although I prefer my chicken salad chunkier.  

I was most taken by the atmosphere here.  It captured the feel of an old time diner, and while I ate I was able to temporarily depart this contemporary mortal coil, and spend a few moments in a bygone era.  Although the interior is of recent vintage, they did an excellent job in maintaining its simplicity. 

Will definitely return regularly.

After a dozen or more breakfast take out visits, I have become a fan of this Cosi in the Newtown Business Commons.  The staff now recognizes me, knows what I want, and meet me with my coffee poured. 

 I like the personal touch. 

The oatmeal, square bagel, and hot coffee is my routine, and I am sticking to it.

Definitely deserving of an upgrade. 

Thanks, Tina.
Go to the right place - Erwin's Country Kitchen - for the full lowdown on this venerable eatery.

California Tortilla has good, fresh grub in a Mexican/Tex-Mex style.  The store is large and clean, and the staff seems into its mission.  My Chicken Quesadilla was loaded with Beans, Corn, Lettuce, Fresh Jalapenos, Monterrey Jack and plenty of Doodle Do.   The Tortilla was thin and crisp from heating on the grill as its ingredients were gathered and mixed and then sealed with the melting of the cheese.  It was very nice.  

Their signature is the wall of hot sauces that you can select and pour into little plastic cups in any configuration and quantity you wish.  I went with the Bee Sting Honey/Habanero and Pineapple Pizzazz (I do love fruity salsas).  The Pineapple combo was deliciously hot and played well with the quesadilla.  The Bee Sting was exactly that.  Hot, piquant, and left me to drive home with semi-numb lips.  It was great! 

So, while I normally prefer my Southwestern cuisine in divey bars in Tucson or Nuevo Laredo, or even in the transformed taverns of Trenton that are now all Latin eateries, California Tortilla offers a very tasty and entertaining alternative, especially if you don't like adventure as part of your dining experience.

Ristorante Aida is located in the Mallard Creek Shopping Center in Richboro, Pa.  It is a small shop run by a young family.  The husband does the cooking, while the wife works the floor and assists in the kitchen. Bambino has a corner to himself to play and watch TV.  

If an earnest desire to please was paramount, Aida would be a 5 Star experience.  I have seldom seen a server express the sweet insecurity of both expressing how wonderful she believes the food to be, and at the same moment showing her deepest hope that the customer will agree with her. 

Those eyes.

The bathos was as rich as the creamy White Wine Lemon Butter Sauce on my Scaloppine Di Pollo (Francoise). It was a very good dish.  Luckily, the two home baked rolls were big enough for me to rip them apart throughout the meal and soak up both the Olive Oil and the zesty yet silky sauce.  The large plate also held the side House Salad of Lettuce, Tomato, Onion, Olive Oil and Vinegar.  

If I had had room, the house desserts looked very appealing sitting in the front display. Maybe next time. Aida is worth another look.

When a young and growing child runs through a pair of athletic shoes in a matter of months, the need for a fairly priced distribution point becomes a financial necessity.  

So it is that Dick's Sporting Goods a big box store very near the Oxford Valley Mall comes into play.  It is in the rear of that warehouse of a retail outlet that all varieties of foot gear are displayed and available for purchase.  Where some of the smaller shops have a few designs in a few colors from a few manufacturers, Dick's offers the most of all.  Too, if paying attention to the flyers in the mail or email advertisements, it is possible to save substantially.

Size 12 Nike Air basketball shoes listed for sale at $85, were actually secured for $20 less with the help of those coupons and cards.  The cashier was very helpful in making sure we got the best possible price.  

Knowing we will be back in about 90 days to replace the worn out Nikes with a new and likely larger pair, is a good incentive for both parties to maintain good relations.  

See you then, Dick.

The cheapest gas in this part of town and right on my way home at night. 

Yes. It is a busy station due to price and location (Route 29 Northbound), but I find the service to be prompt and friendly.  I never go into the store, so can't comment on the coffee, snacks nor social propositioning.  

If you're looking for quality gasoline and good prices, this is a good place to consider.

A breakfast meeting brought me to Cafe Chorba in the Morrisville Shopping Center, just across the Calhoun St. Bridge from Trenton, NJ. 
The cafe is a little hard to find, tucked into the east side of the center. Don't give up if you don't see it right away, as it is worth your while to find it, and chow down.
The environment is diner-like in terms of menu, but more like a luncheonette in ambiance. Very Americana, despite its Turkish name. 
I had the french toast.  It was among the best FT I have had.  A slight crunch on the outside, and soft and totally cooked on the inside.  Thick sliced fresh bread makes for a very nice meal with good coffee.  My meeting partner had eggs over and scrapple.  She said the "meat" was well above average. I admit to never having tried it. 
The cost for the 2 breakfasts with coffee, $12. 
Friendly staff, and decent traditional breakfast, lunch and dinner menu.  
I will definitely return when the opportunity presents itself.  
Suggestion: Offer real maple syrup for french toast and pancakes.  That would add to the overall value proposition here.  Even if charging extra for it, it would upgrade the experience beyond the little packages of industrial syrup provided now. 
Overall - Very pleased!

I knew something was up when I walked into Hogeland's Corner Grill and the counter was full but for the very last spinner.  Laughter and the strong hum of conversation was the tip off that this joint was the hang for an old crew.  The fact that a stranger had just entered did not change the pace of socializing.  I was just another friend they had never met before.  Welcome!

The space is small, with only 4 quads and a counter with room for 8. Cozy. An ancient 12" TV hung from the ceiling.  The Formica countertop, old wall signs, and attentive silverhairs bustling around, contributed to the sense of being in a 70's / 80's sitcom, Mel's Diner.  Happy to play my part.  Irma, Sherry, and Steve were right out of central casting, with white aprons, dual-fisted coffee pots, and very long spatulas. They were open and diligent, friendly and forthcoming about the history of what has been several incarnations of a coffee shop/luncheonette over the past 20-odd years.  You know that something special has happened when a former worker becomes an owner, and then after selling the business continues to work at the place she loves.  That speaks to the closeness of the people, and the magic that happens when they are together.  

All of that would be only a quaint tale if the food slung was not worth the price of admission to the theater.  It certainly was.  From my front row seat I watched everything.  After ordering Coffee and French Toast, I saw the bread bathed in egg and placed on the grill.  Steve lovingly pushed it around to be sure the surface was touching metal, and then cut the 3 slices with his spatula.  He asked if I wanted Powdered Sugar and Cinnamon on it, and I liked the idea.  He sprinkled it on after plating the toast, and walked over to lay it in front of me.  A little butter, a squirt of syrup, and I was ready to go.  

It was great!  I prefer my French Toast to possess a little crispy crunch from the hot grill caramelizing the egg/butter/bread intersection.  It had that, while remaining soft and fully egged within.  It has been a long time since I had that, and I was pleased.  
The Coffee was very good and was refilled before I had gotten half way through. I liked that I was asked if I wanted a refill before the pour, so I could decide how much was needed to maintain the right coffee/milk balance.  

All the while, I was drawn into various conversations with the other patrons at the counter, so by the time I was ready to pay the bill and go, people were asking when I would return to continue the banter.  Turns out, I knew one of the guys that came in after me, and after a short exchange of kindnesses, I said I would be back very soon.  

Richboro is not exactly in my home zone, but for an experience like this, I will certainly make the trip when my mornings allow.  Hogeland's is on the short list of exceptional breakfast emporiums.  Hear tell that lunches are good, too.
Two listings for this new smoothie shop. This one appears to be secondary. Try the other for tips and reviews.

Leave it to Yelp to uncover yet another gem in the rough.

In this case, the rough refers to the section of North Brunswick Avenue in Trenton where Pho Tan has staked its claim and hopes to mine Vietnamese gold out of its kitchen.  In the shadow of the former Helene Fuld Medical Center, this unassuming storefront houses an authentic menu that turns out very good VN cuisine.  The space shows signs of originally being a Mexican joint, but I have no problems with that.  

The staff is very friendly (and cute), and the owner/chef is checking with his customers to be sure they are satisfied and to tell his story of this 3 month old enterprise.  The room fills up in the evening with compatriots, some of whom are obviously family.  They fill the air with Vietnamese jokes and deference to the seniors among them.  Very nice to be part of this culture for the evening. 

I wanted to try the Banh Mi with Roast Pork, and a Small Bowl of Pho with Flank and Tendon.  At $4. the Baguette Sandwich was large and stuffed with the Pork, Cucumber, Cilantro, Carrot, and some kind of Mayo.  A squirt of Hoisin from the table rocket brought the combination to the right flavor quotient.  It was very good, although the Pork had some rough spots.  It was enjoyable.  

The Pho was accompanied by a full plate of Basil, Lime, Sprouts, & Jalapeno Slices that helped the simmering broth attain full taste.  The heat of the soup slowly cooked the once rare Beef to a nice medium.  The Noodles at the bottom of the bowl were hidden beneath the Beef and condiments, and had to be raised with my chopsticks and flat bottom spoon.  Once thoroughly mixed, the full mastery of this creation came to the fore.  It was a mighty fine bowl of Pho, full of subtle flavors and textures that were a pleasure to uncover a layer at a time.  I could not finish it, and was glad I had not asked for the larger portion.  

Pho Tan has great possibilities.  I need to try their Vietnamese Coffee and Summer Rolls to be sure it is as good as my first impressions.  It will not take long for me to return to sample those things and revisit my ranking.  

Pho Tan could be very special. 

Good luck to Mr. Tan and his family in this endeavor


SEPTEMBER 10, 2014 - Returned this evening for another run at Pho Tan, and went with the Pho Ga (Chicken) and Spring Rolls.  The Spring Rolls were deep fried and stuffed with ground spiced pork.  Aside from the oily skin, the app was tasty and filling.  The dipping sauce seemed a bit thin and less sweet/pungent than expected.  A little more potency and thickness would improve the final result.  

The Pho Ga only came in the LARGE size, and I could not finish it.  The broth was new in that it did not taste like it had been simmering for a long time to bring out the spicy flavors.  I added a shot of Sriracha to bring it up a notch.  However, the Chicken Breast slices were fresh, thick and plentiful.  It was the most chicken I had ever had in my pho.  I prepped a small dish with a mix of Hoisin and  Sriracha to dip the chicken in before eating.  Tasted great!  All the other fixings were on the table, and I put most of them into the bowl.  Good quantity of noodles lurking in the bottom of the bowl.

The Café sits in the Pine Watson Shopping Plaza on North Pine just before the intersection with Maple Street in Langhorne Borough.  It is the star of an otherwise undistinguished row of shops and restos. The interior is bright and homey with  nice counters, tables and booths. The servers are friendly, courteous and have time for a short chat with all the customers. 

The breakfast menu is traditional, and the coffee is Ellis through a Bunn-o-Matic. Strong, middle of the road brew.  I went with a short stack of French Toast along with the java.  It was made with Texas Toast and arrived nicely crusty with caramelized edges.  It would have been even better with real maple syrup, but then the price would have been much higher.  

There are a high percentage of regulars here which adds to the attraction.  The repartee with the high energy behind the counter ladies is warm and clever.  I imagine that if this was closer to home or on my way to work, I, too, would be a regular guest. 

As it is, I am a fan, and I will get here sporadically when I can.

Corner Bakery is brought to us by a company with HQ in Newtown, so I take pride in its roots, and wish them great success.  
The ambiance is high ceilings and dark wood, with tables and booths spaced well to avoid the feeling of being too crowded when eating. Yet, there is an issue with traffic flow between the front doors and the counter.  The coffee is right in the central area and can get a little congested.  A redesign might help.  
The food is all decent, if slightly more expensive than other places in the area. Sandwiches, soups, salads for lunch.  Oatmeal, bagels, muffins, omelets for breakfast.  
A community room adds to the neighborhood flavor.  There are always meetings going on of various sizes, and it is really nice that these activities were taken into consideration.  
Parking is an issue, as the undersized lot is shared with TD Bank.  Any time near lunch is an adventure in parking.  Be prepared to park and walk a couple of minutes. As Woody Allen might say after a poor parking performance, "It's all right.  We can take a taxi from here."

6.01.13 - Time for an upgrade to 4 Stars. This morning walked in for a meeting reserved for the Community Room. Apparently, whoever took down the info was NOT the manager, and they knew nothing about it. Grrr...But, the real manager and his staff jumped into action and prepared the catering we required for the 12 people and 2 hour meeting.  Everything else went smoothly. 

For stepping up when it would have been easier to just shrug and give empty apologies, they took care of us with professionalism and a smile. Time to move into a better neighborhood, CBC.  Thanks!

First the Big News!
 
Oishi is moving to another part of the Village of Newtown Shopping Center!  They will be taking over the space formerly occupied by Basil Leaf and Lee's Hoagie House in the portion of the Center that has McCaffery's Supermarket.  It will take several months for that to happen, but it received its conditional use approval from Newtown Township last week, so it will move forward.  The space where the restaurant currently resides will remain a restaurant under the same ownership, but with a different orientation.  You heard it here first. 

The current Japanese, Thai, Korean success story is about to write a new chapter.  But, the old story is still a very good one.  They still present some of the best sushi, sashimi, and true Asian fusion in Bucks County and the surrounding area. I returned there yesterday for lunch for the second time since joining Yelp.  The ambiance remains hushed dark wood and stone tones that are very comforting and warm.  The activity of the white hats behind the sushi bar continues to offer the sights and sounds of sharp steel knives on  cool granite as the Zen of fish slicing and rice molding into seaweed wraps captures our attention and imagination.  Quite a show!  When the orders are sufficient to keep the fish ultra fresh, the production is razor fast and the taste sensational.  Me? I love the Crunchy Tuna, but I am happy with whatever is put in front of me.  The Wasabi and Ginger are also fresh, so the mix into the light soy sauce complement each other perfectly.  

Yesterday, my companions and I were in the mood for soup and noodles.  Three had variations of soups with Udon, Tofu and Chicken.  All looked great in the asymmetric bowls (see photo), and my Pad Thai, while bathed in a slightly unusual peanut sauce, was still quite good, although I do prefer the versions offered by Duck Sauce and Aroi Thai. 

We were all happy with our meals. 

Why not 5 Stars?  The prices are a couple of bucks higher than the competition, and they did not bring tea to the table, nor inquire if we wanted any.  The staff was courteous, but not particularly friendly, nor forthcoming with answers to our questions, nor suggestions.  They seem to believe that they are working in the best place in Newtown for this cuisine, and perhaps there was a sniff of arrogance in their demeanor.  That attitude always starts at the top and is passed down to the staff.  Some carry it off well, but most do not.  

Oishi is well named, but there is more to being a great restaurant than just having "delicious" food.

A nice smallish 11th Street veggie joint with a comfortable vibe, friendly service, and an interesting menu.  

I stopped in after an appointment nearby for a late lunch.  I was the sole customer and had my pick of tables and all the attention of the lovely proprietress.  I went with a Scallion Pancake and the Soft Noodles with Peanut Sauce.  The Pancake was hot and the heat waves off it had the aroma of spring onion. Crispy and tasty.  Very nice.  The Noodles were a large plate (see photo), way more than I could eat, but with a wonderful creamy sauce topped with slivers of Red and Green Pepper, Sprouts and sprinkled with Sesame Seeds.  Delicious. 

I took half of it home, and my car smelled great the whole way. 

The prices seem an issue here.  The apps and noodle dishes seemed fairly marked, and the "Homestyle" offerings @ $10.50 across the board were alright.  I did not go for the "Main Courses," but at $15.95 for all items there, it seemed too much given the overall feel of the place.  Not sure I would be drawn to that part of the menu given all the other less expensive things ahead of it.  There is also a 24 count "Lunch Special" menu that is worth a look @ $6.50.  

Certainly a decent place for veggie lovers to fill up. 

Aptly named.

New kid in town...Smoothie King in the Village of Newtown South. Near Marcos and Wendy's. 
Huge selection of combo fruit drinks with nutritional additives of choice. Three sizes: large, larger and largest. 
I just tried something with Orange and Mango Juices, plus Banana and some secret ingredients.  First sip came on strong, and it continued to hold my attention all the way to the bottom.  

The owners of this new shop are good local folk excited to be opening a business in Newtown.  

We wish them every success.

On the corner of 13th & Snyder in South Philly, AmeriThai was a pleasant respite on a steamy late June afternoon. Although as colorful as a Thai temple with rusty orange hues and elephants abounding, sitting in a quiet corner with the air cooling only ourselves, it felt a chill oasis. 

The menu offered plenty of choices from soup to noodles, curry to bigger game like chicken, pork, beef and duck. We order Chu Chee Duck and Crazy Noodles, with appetizer of Curry Puffs. 

In reverse order; the Curry Puffs reminded of Indian Samosas -  Sweet and White Mashed Potato, Onion, Peas,  mixed in mild Curry powder, deep fried, with semi-sweet/spicy Chili Dipping Sauce in a small brass dish. Excellently golden. Crisp shell. Tasty innards. Tart sauce. Liked it a lot!

The Crazy (Drunken) Noodles with tender Sliced Beef was a load and a half with big Fat Noodles, Veggies, and hot spicies. Plenty of dry Chili Pepper flakes in the mix. So glad we had Thai Iced Tea to tamp down the flames. 

Chu Chee Duck had wonderfully crisp skin, moist delicious meat and a pale orange cream curry sauce. This became slightly sloppy finger food, as every morsel was too good to miss and required close examination and tongue probing to suck it all off the bone. 

There are many very good Thai houses in and around Philly, and AmeriThai is certainly one. It is a little frayed around the edges, but it fits well with the neighborhood. Others mentioned that the kitchen is inconsistent, but I don't know about that yet. What I know is that when they get it right, it is an excellent place for dinner.

Returned to Olive Garden with gift card in tow after an hiatus of almost 2 years.  The place is still crowded, and the wait for a table just as long on a weekday evening.  The menu looked to be about the same, with the exception of a Specials Menu that had been in place long enough to justify its own handout upon seating.  The prices appeared to be about the same as my last visit.

While I am not usually enamored of the chain ethnic shops, I admit that this most recent experience was of a higher quality than the last.  I didn't remember what I ordered last time, but it turned out I ordered it again.  I did not care for it according to my last review, but this time, the Garlic Rosemary Chicken on the "Lite" menu was actually pretty good.  The two breasts had been well-grilled, and the garlic clove sauce was not at all salty.  The mashed were very good.  

My companions were in their first exposure to Olive Garden, and were also quite happy with their Stuffed Chicken Marsala.  

Finally, the three-way split of the Apple Crustada dessert was also a good ending to a surprisingly decent Italian-esque meal. It was a very good version of apple pie a la modec complete with a drizzle of Caramel Sauce.  Given the improvement in quality, we would certainly welcome another gift card.  

Keep up the good work!

Corner Bakery Café is still a comfortable place for breakfast, lunch or dinner, and seems to have settled into its skin in the time it has been open in the Village of Newtown.  

I am partial to the Steel Cut Oatmeal breakfast, and the sandwiches available for lunch. The basic Tuna Salad Sandy is tasty and filling at a reasonable price.  The option between Carrot Sticks or Chips is a good one.  The Bakery choices are very good, if perhaps a little pricey for the size of each slice, muffin or bagel.  Coffee is above average. 

However, as the current Duke of this domain I am at a loss to understand why I was asked not to take a photo of the display case with all its goodies.  I thought free advertising was always a good thing.  Especially on Yelp!

Marty's Place sits at the corner of Hamilton and Johnston Avenues in Hamilton, NJ.  It has been a corner neighborhood watering hole for at least the last 80 years, under several owners and in various disguises.  

This most recent incarnation is a comfortable dive that it almost too cute for that distinction.  It is bright and airy for a small space, with lots of color, and well maintained barroom. The bartender working the afternoon shift when I stopped in for lunch was a lifelong local and took pride in his work.  The bar itself is the shape of a "Question Mark," with the open end toward Hamilton Avenue, and the tail toward the rear near the pool table.  It is in good shape given its age, although the stools could stand refurbishment.  

The menu covers breakfast, lunch and dinner, with special attention to oversized omelets, burgers and other hot sandwiches.  My large Burger with Cheddar, Fried Onions and Jalapeno Slices was better than expected, although it was obviously a prepackaged frozen disk.  It was closer to well done than the medium requested, but I don't mind cutting the kitchen some slack given that the result was still tasty and I had no expectations that it would be a gastronomic delight.  It was a satisfying chew, and came with choice of sides, for $6.75.  Very good deal.

The conversation was pleasant throughout, and the folks coming in and out all seemed to know the barkeep and all exchanged upbeat repartee.  

The suds were mostly American, with the usual suspects from abroad.  This is not a craft dispensary; nor should it be.  

Overall, Marty's Place feels like a winner for a quick lunch and conversation.  Evenings might be more lively, but I appreciated the relative quiet of a mid afternoon break.

The Tai Nam, Ve Don (Rare Steak & Crispy Flank) was a perfect counterpoint to the biting cold running rampant in the streets of Chinatown last night. 

The space on the corner of 10th and Arch is small, but well maintained. The service is efficient, if not overly friendly, nor chatty.  But, given that there was a large bowl of steaming funky pho placed before me about 2 minutes after ordering, they can afford to let their speed and excellent broth do the talking. I found it rich and subtle with plenty of time simmering in a huge pot in the kitchen.  The star anise played second violin to the beef stock's leading melody.  The noodles were submerged beneath the ample supply of thinly sliced rare and well done meats.  It was all I wanted.

Some nights are just a little strange, and it wasn't even a full moon.  On my walk over to Pho Cali I was stopped by a man who told a story so believable about having his tools and wallet lifted, that I gave him cab fare home.  On the way out of the café, I was stopped again.  This time by a woman who claimed to be an art student in Jersey. She just wanted to take photos of me while I made a crazy face.  I obliged, half thinking that I would find myself on Facebook looking like a madman.  The end of a promising career in public service. 

I just rolled with it all.  As long as the pho was superlative, I could tolerate almost anything.

Dark streets. Cold winds. Bizarre interactions. Take your best shot.

I am still a breakfast regular, and an occasional lunch person here. 
My Oatmeal, Squagel and Coffee still offer a good price for a good meal.  In fact, the cost seems to have gone down recently due to some combo they put into effect.  

It is a convenient stop on my way to the office.  They recently moved the coffee out from behind the service counter and it is now pour your own.  This makes for a small jam, but it is manageable. 

Every ten breakfasts/coffees gets a freebee if you have their card. 

Good deal.

Time warp pizza parlor with several HD TVs to remind everyone that their prices may be incredibly cheap (a la 1980), but they are still state of the art video-wise.  

The regular Pizza Slice has a strong firm crust that holds its point even when somewhat cooled (second slice).  There is a preference for cheese over tomato sauce, making this a pizza rather than a T. Pie.  The taste is good, but the dominance of the cheese makes it a heavier experience with a bit of oil drip, rather than the more subtle flavors that arise when the sauce takes priority with hints of plum tomato, basil, oregano, garlic and even sugar.  

Not a bad place for a quick lunch with a throwback flair.  Even the local constabulary has been known to drop in for lunch.  Two slices of regular pizza and a medium fountain drink (iced tea) comes in at $5.  Hard to beat!

You may not get the sensations of some of the more famous pizza houses in the area (you know who they are), but neither are you being asked to pay a premium for the privilege of manging on a pie with pedigree.  

Anthony's Pizza Palace is a fun dine down memory lane.  The large pies are at most $17., and the dinners top out at $12.95, complete with salad and bread.

There is a place in the world for decent cheap Italian grub.

What do you get when you mix a Vietnamese wife and chef, who spend many years in Cambodia, with a Chinese husband and entrepreneur? 
Neon Phnom Penh Restaurant on 7th and Wolf in deep South Philly, and some very good unintentional fusion dishes from that golden triangle of spicy cuisine. This small corner house with eight tables and booths has a cozy feel, from the wall art and houseplants, down to the Buddha shrine sitting on the floor with oranges in supplication. 

We ordered their spring rolls (3 for $5), beef with fat noodles, and beef lo mein. They were all good to very good, but the star of the show were the deep fried spring rolls that had a great rough texture and were filled with ground pork, veggies, sprouts and homemade sweet dipping sauce with peanuts chunks. They were nearly a meal by themselves. 

The fat noodles were also quite delicious with plenty of tender sliced beef, Chinese broccoli, string beans, onions, peppers, scallions and a tasty brown sauce that melded everything together.  Liked this a lot. The lo mein was also good, but not at the level of the former dishes. It had an interesting, indefinable almost smoky flavor, with plenty of meat and greens, but not as scrumptious as everything else. 

We ended up taking half of each of the mains home with us, and one of the rolls, for subsequent consumption by our son.  He devoured all this the same night, and claimed to like it all, while also questioning the ingredients of the lo mein and that somewhat odd taste. 

Still, a worthy stop in the heart of Cambodiatown. Plenty of atmosphere, and a friendly family team that spent more time that normal chatting with us about their lives in Asia and Philly. Good people with an interesting story to tell. 

Made for an entertaining and satisfying dining experience.

After a hiatus of a few years, I returned to Four Rivers for an early dinner late last week.  The first thing I noticed was how much cleaner the place looked, and the new furniture really helped the joint feel more respectable.  Nice job.

The servers were friendly and attentive; another plus.  The new (clean) menus had the traditional Szechuan style cuisine, plus a curtsy to the American palate with some of the usual neutered dishes to avoid mouth burn.  It was my good fortune to dine with a Chengdu friend and she went after the dishes with glee after questioning the waitperson for a few minutes about how the dishes were prepared.  Satisfied, she went to work: Duck & Seaweed Soup, Crystal Wonton in Hot Oil, Dan Dan Noodles with Minced Pork, Double Sautéed Pork Belly, Water Spinach & Garlic, and White Rice.  

The soup was a first for me.  I like Duck, but was not sure how I felt about mixing seaweed into the broth.  Fear not.  It was really delicious.  The large serving bowl overflowed with meaty chunks of tender Duck that was easily sucked off the bone.  The brackish flavor of the seaweed somehow complemented the bird's taste, enhancing them both.  I had several small bowls of it throughout the meal.  

The Dan Dan Noodles were served lukewarm in temperature, and insufficiently spicy for me.  I asked for a side dish of Hot Chili Oil, and once engaged with the pasta and Pork, it came alive.  My sidekick loved it.  The Crystal Wonton in Hot Oil presented a semi-diaphanous skin with a delicate tail in a rich red hot oily sauce.  It reminded me of the Butterfly Dumplings found in nighttime food carts that set up shop everywhere in Chengdu after sunset.  These little darlings were made by hand only minutes before boiling. 

The Pork Belly was tender with plenty of Red and Green Peppers in the mix.  Good, but I have had better in town.  Finally, the Water Spinach was done the traditional way with a load of fresh sliced Garlic thrown in with the thin leafed variety of this veggie. 

Prices were very good for the amount of food we had on the table.  About $50. including tip.  I would definitely return with little prompting, but would probably choose E Mei on Arch as my go to Szechuan/Chongqing style dinner in Chinatown.

Very sad to learn that Hogeland's has closed its doors for the last time. 
Its food, and the warm community atmosphere it created, will be sorely missed.

Piccolo Trattoria is a local success story, and it is well deserved.  Its growth to 3 shops is testament to the hard work and persistence of its creator.  While I have only frequented the Newtown location, I hear great things about Flowers Mill and Pennington.  

Take out pizza is an almost weekly order for us.  Friday or Saturday night would not be complete with a regular or Brooklyn Pie and a Spring Mix Salad.  The kitchen is a factory operation which you can watch as you wait at the register to pick up your food.  It is a beehive. 

The pizza is very good and the Brooklyn Pie an excellent version of Sicilian with semi-sweet sauce, basil leaves, and copious mozzarella.  The Spring Mix is loaded with Green Apple slices, Walnuts, Feta, and first class Balsamic. The times I have eaten in house, everything has been well presented, tasty, and in abundance.  Most of the menu is traditional Italian American fare, so if you have a more adventurous palate, you may want to try Vecchia Osteria., or travel a bit farther afield to Philly or NYC. 

Otherwise, you can't go wrong with Piccolo.

Mamma Flora's Trattoria sits at the end of the Shop Rite Shopping Center at the corner of North Olden Avenue and Parkway Avenue in Ewing, NJ.  It is surprisingly attractive inside with mirrored walls and large dining areas.  Service was excellent, with friendly repartee and suggestions for first timers like me.  

I chose the eggplant parm sandwich, which came with chips.  For two bucks more, I could have had a side salad.  Prices were right at $7.25 for this grinder.  I made a good selection, because the hot sammy arrived a few minutes later steaming from its visit to the oven to melt the cheese and crisp the good Italian torpedo roll.  

The eggplant had been sliced very thin and sautéed in olive oil before making its way to the roll where the chef put the remaining pieces together.  I appreciated that the nightshade was so thin that it was easy to heat and remained fully tender. No breading to add unwanted calories; just ripe melanzane. The homemade red sauce was slightly sweet with a nice basil undertone. The mozzarella was also quality and did not sweat from the oven's heat.  The roll was crunchy and good tasting (although I only ate half of it).  This was a very good rendition, although next time I would ask for extra sauce on the side as there wasn't quite enough to fully mix with the base ingredients below.  

Still, Momma Flora's was a pleasant surprise for a neighborhood osteria. I will definitely return to try the tomato pie and some of their dinner offerings.

Way down Rt.13 in Croydon, PA, lies a new casa Mexicana run by a young entrepreneurial college student. Although bare boned at present, the large dining room, with colorful mural and carved/painted tables & chairs, already has a kitchen turning out authentic south of the border cuisine. 

Last night I enjoyed an order of tacos dorado - chicken and cheese stuffed /rolled flautas (flutes), chips and salsa and tamarindo drink for less than $10. The roll ups were hot and crunchy with a top load of shredded lettuce, tomato and fresh crema dressing. I poured on the salsa from the table munchies to turn up the heat. Enjoyed it very much. The drink was tasty and sweet (perhaps, too much so), but refreshing and an effective counterpoint to the chili burn. 

Service was friendly, informative and provided by the owner of the enterprise. Her pride and smooth effort was visible and a pleasure to behold. 

Will be back to see what she does with the place.

A good bagel if you like the dense variety with plenty a texture and chew. 

Mine was certainly fresh that morning, with those super sized onion flakes sticking resolutely to its top, and big enough to retain some moisture within and provide more flavor than the smaller chips that crunch well but fall off too easily. This was my maiden voyage to Bagelocity/Soup King, although I had liked its name since driving by the store in a strip center on Bensalem Road a few years ago. 

I went with my favorite combination breakfast bagel sandwich with butter and swiss (love the interplay of nutty swiss cheese and those onion flakes on my tongue). With coffee the price was under $4, compared to a couple of bucks more for the same thing at my local place in Yardley. 

The shop has been around for a while, but is still comfortable and clean. The staff I dealt with were friendly and brought the bagel to my booth when ready. Although I prefer a lighter, more airy, less kneaded round, I would certainly return to Bagelocity, especially to check out their soups and try a few more bagels.

A & S Pizza & Pasta at the bottom of Edgely Road, just off Route 13, Levittown, PA, is a small parlor dealing pies, slices, pasta and Italian sandwiches. It has been in one family for decades. While not the best of neighborhoods, and a bit frayed around the edges,  they do prepare very good and filling dishes. 

We ordered standard cheesesteak and eggplant parmesan sandwiches to check out their basics. Both were very good, if not best of breed. They were loaded - one with a ton of chopped steak, onions and cheese, and the other with thin sliced, breaded and fried nightshade, red gravy and mozzarella, run through the oven to melt and crisp everything. They use excellent torpedo rolls that toast up well and had a good flavor. 

While straight up steak houses like Steve's in the Northeast/Langhorne and Dalessandro's in Roxborough, are the class of the field for steaks, these guys do a credible job for a corner neighborhood  place. Aside from a kitchen that works eggplant without breading and has faith in its sauce and olive oil to provide enough mass and taste on their own, A&S is as good as the best of them. 

It's good to have strong local choices at fair prices.

Le Pain Quotidien (The Daily Bread) is a Belgian bakery/cafe at the corner of 8th & Walnut in Center City, Philadelphia. If that sounds like a familiar location, that's because it is. Until recently this was the home of Robbins 8th & Walnut, the famous diamond dealer.
