So, if a Yelp review says that the boulangerie now there is a "hidden gem," they may not know how right they are! 

These folks have done a great job morphing that old jewelry store into a continental bistro. High ceiling, floor to ceiling windows overlooking the teeming street life of this hospital part of town, large communal table in the center floor, wood everywhere. The atmosphere is captivating. It was a perfect place to relax over good coffee and densely textured blueberry muffin while waiting for an appointment across the street at Penn Medicine. 

I took a deuce against the wall facing Walnut. My small order arrived within a minute. The java came in in a pot for pouring into a wide mouth cup, the muffin on a flat white personal size tray. Cool that something as common as coffee and a nosh were reimagined to present in an interesting alternative. If that was Brussels style, I was all for it! 

Service was fast and friendly. Those baguettes and demi-pain looked great and tempting enough to want to return for a sandwich to sample the crunchy crust of traditional French bread. 

On the way out I stepped on the old ceramic tile floor that had anchored Robbins for decades and was left in place by the new business. It neatly tied the past with the present, honoring history while adding ambiance to today.

El Negro De Oro (Black Gold) is a new Ecuadorian restaurant at the corner of Sewall and S. Broad in Hamilton, New Jersey.  It is easy to find because it is painted the colors of its name and stands out in an otherwise drab urbanscape.  Street parking is required, but the side streets around there offer plenty of space for a short stroll to the entrada. 

Walking in, the color combination grabs your attention immediately. Black and gold floors and walls.  The house has been open only three months and the atmosphere is clean and bright with a small counter near the kitchen entrance, and an area for entertainment off to the side.  They did a very good job turning a small grocery/deli into an attractive place to dine.  

Service was warm and informative and we had no trouble understanding each other though all accents (including mine) were thick as homemade salsa.  The menu is bilingual which is very helpful.  I ordered the Special Lunch of the Day, Catfish/Yam Soup and Quarter Roast Chicken with Red Beans and Rice.  A couple of dishes of salsa tagged along, one a traditional Green Sauce, and the other a more unusual thick Yellow Grainy Sauce, which had an unusual flavor that mixed well with the chicken and rice. Think Adobo.  

The Soup contained a tender chunk of Catfish, bone in and with skin.  It was very tasty.  The orange color of the soup base came from the Yams in which everything simmered for many hours.  There was some spice thrown in for good measure.  The sweetness of the tubers was the most obvious flavor, and cooking the fish in it was an excellent approach, as the mild white meat of the Catfish had nicely picked up the Yamminess from the stewing process.  

The Chicken was smaller than the typical clucker found in most restaurants, and had the look of a Cornish Hen, although the taste was not gamey.  I was able to pull it apart with knife, fork and fingers and suck the meat off the bones.  Liked it a lot.  The White Rice absorbed the juices from the bird and Red Beans and was a good companion to the rest of the plate.  

While eating, the owner/chef came out to check on my satisfaction.  I learned that his nickname was "Black Gold," and that he was also a trained Italian chef.  As if to prove this point, he came out with a piece of Tiramisu prepared in his kitchen.  While this is not my normal tea and crumpets, it was soft, rummy, creamy and sweet.  I suggest he consider adding a few of his best Italian dishes on the menu to broaden the appeal of his shop.  There are not many Ecuadorian/Italian places around here (or anywhere).  

El Negro De Oro is another of the first rate Latin kitchens sprouting up in Trenton and Hamilton.  It is a variation of what we know as Mexi/Guat/Salvador/Puerto Rican/Dominican/Cuban restos, and well worth a visit.  

The cuisine and the hospitality are the real deal.

The Terminal Restaurant sits at the crossroads of Moreland and Davisville Roads in Willow Grove, Pa. While the name originally referred to the railroad station that was once close by, that stop has moved into history, and the sense of the house now is that it is more the terminus of two old generational trails.  Although renovated, it has the feel of an older way station that still carries its legacy and kitchen skills very well.  

The customer base is interestingly diverse, but the common thread seems to be old time locals who know where to find good, cheap vittles, and who are loyal to their institutions.  Can't blame them.  There is something deep and authentic about this place; its cramped booths and tables, its classic servers, and its faithfulness to real American grub.  No brunch served here. No mimosas.  Just straight ahead, no apologies, grill'em-ups. 

The coffee flowed strong and free.  Not the best, but we were not here for La Colombe. All we wanted was caffeinated washdown, and got it. The Country Omelet was a 2 egger loaded with taters and 'yons, with grilled sausage added for taste and texture. Delicious, with a side of toasted rye.  The home fries had crisp edges, but could have used more flavor.  So be it. There was also the option for grits. Maybe next time. 

Really liked The Terminal Resto.  Next time I feel like taking a drive in the country and into the past, I might find myself terminating the excursion right here.

Spring Garden Restaurant at the corner of N. 4th and Spring Garden Street in Northern Liberties, Philly, is an old school urban diner. There is a dining area to one side and a ten stool counter overlooking the grill on the other. The menu is traditional Americana breakfast and lunch, with prices the remind of the earlier years of the century. Nice to have lower rents. 

On arrival it was a full house, but for a couple of spinners. When none of the earlier people waiting for tables wanted them, we accepted with gratitude. Not sure about the tables, but we felt lucky to be able to watch the show from our orchestra seats. 

Our black shirt server came over promptly for drink requests, and kept her poise and humor despite the beehive of activity around her. The Bunn-O-Matic java was average, but it did provide a buzz and washed down our meal, which we thoroughly enjoyed. My better half went with a beef sausage, egg and cheese on kaiser, while I asked for french toast and bacon. Both were very good. The sammy was a two egger on a fresh and tasty roll. The frenchie had a great vanilla/sugar/cinnamon egg mix that saturated the three bread slices to the core leading to strong texture and taste. The crisp caramelized edges were aces. Melted butter and Kraft syrup pour and I was a happy man. Maple syrup would have made this dish perfect. 

All the while we watched the chef (he was so much more than a short order cook) move through the orders without wasted motion. Grasping eggs with one hand, cracking them into a stainless bowl, and whipping them with a fork with the other; then pouring them onto the hot steel while shaping and flipping them with spatchula, before sliding the finished omelet or over easys, smoothly onto a plate. He then quickly scraped away the residue on the grill into the trough while he moved the plate to the counter to be retrieved for serving.  His efficiency was astonishing. He was intense and focused, and when a server expressed impatience waiting for her order despite his masterly effort, he reminded her with rich irony that he only had two hands. Two?!  It looked like four from where we sat. 

Can't ask for more than a solid breakfast and great floorshow. They should charge a premium for those counter seats.

Crestview Deli & Market has been under new ownership for about 10 months, so if you haven't been there lately, you might consider stopping in again to see if there are any changes.  The two women I met when I stopped in to pick up a sandwich for lunch were very pleasant and efficient in constructing a Boar's Head Turkey & Swiss on Rye.  They asked if I wanted anything more in the sandwich and happily added sweet peppers to the project.  

The "market" part of the operation offers limited provisions for those in need of a few small items.  It reminded of a small old fashioned grocery in a rural area, where larger supermarkets are not readily available.  There were also shelves of snacks and a back wall lined with refrigerated drinks, which reinforced the impression of somewhat stepping back in time.  I enjoyed the nostalgic break.  

Opening the foil wrapped sandwich at my desk, I beheld a nicely packed load of turkey and cheese with lettuce, mayo and the peppers.  The bread was fresh and had a nice rye and caraway taste.  I liked it.  

There is a small sitting area in a corner of this deli that could be a nice place to sit and enjoy morning coffee and a made to order breakfast sandwich.  

I intend to return to find out, and continue my conversation with the nice folks there.

Georgian Bread Cuisine on Bustleton Avenue in Northeast, Philly, is an excellent deli/restaurant specializing in the very interesting and tasty kitchen from this small nation in eastern Europe on the Black Sea. That these people thrived as a gateway to Asia for more than a thousand years is both an important historic fact and an exceptional cultural phenomenon that is a great benefit to everyone. After dinner there it was fascinating how their food captured elements of all the Silk Road traffic that brought the food from the far East and West through Tblisi and other ancient cities, leaving their diverse flavors and skills behind. 

Everything we sampled reminded of dishes eaten in other cooking styles. The eggplant with walnuts, with its mildly bitter nightshade base and soft sweetness from the ground walnut hummus-like spread, took me to Middle Eastern and Greek houses. The adjaruli bread boat with its tender hot dough split open on top to expose a lake of molten cheese and raw egg, came right from an oven that looked similar to a tandor Indian oven, and easily reminded of an Italian calzone, only more cheesily delicious. Finally, the khinkali soup dumplings were larger versions of Shanghai xiao long bao, complete with steaming beef/pork consume and flavorful filling, and eaten by hand. 

Whether it was Marco Polo or Ghengis Khan bringing these ideas on their travels or conquests, or anyone else along the way, this Georgian restaurant continues the culinary exchange between East and West, and is awesome food for both taste buds and anthropologists.

It was a cold, windy, city morn when we reached Washington Avenue, and I still hadn't had my first cup of java. I was trying to maintain my good mood, but it would be a losing battle without some caffeine soon. 

Desperate times called for desperate measures. 

I remembered there was this Bambu shop nearby, so I Yelped it and realized it was right across 6th Street from where we were. We walked over and found it in the inner corner of the shopping center. It was a small shop, with short red sofa, three cafe tables, and a few chairs along the window. The walls were covered in menus and photos of their signature Che fruity concoctions. 

Colorful, but I needed something stronger and hotter. Farther down the drinks list was the coffee. I asked for Vietnamese coffee, hot. I normally drink it in VN cafes or after meals, so this was my first takeout. 

It was exactly as expected. Strong, hot and sweetened by condensed milk. I missed the whole drip experience but it was great to be able to shop the market with java in hand.

Can't say that a woman's accessories boutique is a subject in my wheelhouse, but I know an attractive shop when I see one. More to the point, when they are having a sale on handbags and I can stock up for Valentine's Day on leather I think she will like, it is a very good day. 

Lou Lou Boutique has shelves of sacks and over the shoulder book pockets, not to mention, costume jewelry and a few clothing racks, that make browsing an enjoyable indulgence. 

With the half price stickers, buying two was easy, even with the cost of parking thrown in. The stop at Green Eggs Cafe may have been a little over the top, but added to the quality afternoon.

Battery Park sits along a stretch of the Delaware River shoreline, beginning at the bottom of Delaware Street in New Castle, and going southwestward for a little over a mile next to Gambacorta Marsh to where Army Creek enters the Delaware.  There are two dikes, one holding back the marsh and the other a former railroad spur line. There is little left of the original battery built to defend against French incursions before the Revolution, and later against the British. Too, the railroad that used to run from where the small white wooden ticket office now stands, all the way to Frenchtown, Maryland, is little more than an historic footnote.  

Yet, what remains is a beautiful place to walk or bike along the water's edge and witness some amazing sunsets. There are the remains of the small harbor sticking their waterlogged lumber above the surface of the river in spots, and a few ice piers placed to keep ice from clogging the shipping lanes.  

It is hard to imagine that New Castle is older than Philadelphia, and was the spot where William Penn first set foot in America to oversee his vast land grant from the king.  But, the harbor here is not very big, and Philadelphia soon became the major port for this region.  Commerce was not sufficient to sustain any significant long term economic growth, although for about 30 years the New Castle & Frenchtown Railroad (the first on the east coast), did help with transport between Philly and Baltimore, because going by boat between the two cities was difficult due to the topography of the Delmarva Peninsula.  Eventually, first canals, and later larger railroads and toll roads assumed the largest share of commercial transport, and New Castle became a literal backwater in time. 

Yet, without that, Battery Park would likely have been overrun by industrialization and extensive shipping, and not become the lovely green space that natives and visitors enjoy today.

If you are someone who loves good soft serve ice cream, give C & C Dairyland a try. 

It doesn't look like much out on Bustleton Avenue in the far Northeast, Philadelphia; in fact I was looking for it the other night and drove right by it and had to turn around. Which is to say, even though it is one of those mid-20th Century flat roofed  all white ice cream stores, it tends to blend into the background. Still, it is worth the effort to slow down and take a few minutes out of your day to sample their sweet creamies. 

They do vanilla soft serve the way it should be done - taking the time to be sure it is fully blended and chilled before dispensing through their antique equipment. The result is among the best softies I have had the pleasure to explore with my tongue. While Kohr's down the shore remains the gold standard, C & C is just a step behind. Their thing is to add toppings to every cone and dish going out the windows. In my case, it was smashed cherries, although the Jimmies and wet nuts also looked damn good. 

The only downside is the harsh environment surrounding the building. There are no trees, bushes, umbrellas, picnic tables, overhangs, etc., to shelter customers from the blazing sun nor Saharan heat. The choice is to stand around and melt with the ice cream, sit in your car with the air conditioner going full bore, or to drive away and hope when you arrive home your prize hasn't leaked onto the floor. Makes the consumption less than it could be if even a small effort was made to provide some seating in the shade. On a hot and steamy late Sunday afternoon it was quite oppressive.

I guess we could bring a beach umbrella and set it up on the grass behind the shop, but then I would need a sandy beach to make it feel right - and I might as well go down the shore for a Kohr's. 

3.5 Stars

This is the second OwowCow I have customered.   It is housed in a former industrial space and the reuse is attractive, if rather basic.  Small public space with a few tables, and the expectation that most people will take their ice cream and leave. 

Their flavors are exotic-sounding, and for the most part they succeed in producing the subtle tastes that are seldom found in ice cream parlors.  My "Regular" sized cup of Indonesian Vanilla and Banana Caramel was smooth, creamy and required some attention to appreciate the variations and their mixture on the tongue. 

The sizes are smaller than the competition, and the prices a bit higher, at $5. for two small scoops of whatever flavors you choose. That may be a good thing, as it does suggest slowing down to enjoy the moment over piling on luscious calories. 

The shop is across the parking lot from Big Bear Natural Foods, and people have been known to park there without hassle.

Now that I am spending more time at the USCIS building on 41st Street, and the immigration interviews and other proceedings start as early at 8:00 am, I need a place to cool my jets over coffee or breakfast while I wait to be heard. I learned long ago that it is better to arrive early and wait for court or other meetings, than to deal with heavier traffic later in the morning, and risk arriving late. Today, I asked one of the guards in the security area where to go for coffee until the public was allowed into the building at 7:30.  He was thoughtful and thorough, giving me a list of places within a few blocks.  When he mentioned the restaurant on Market Street that had a full breakfast menu, he showed more enthusiasm then for the others mentioned, so I took my clients there for morning repast.  

Turned out that Hamilton Restaurant is an old school luncheonette, with long counter with spinners on one side, and tables on the other.  Kitchen in back. The offerings were plentiful, with both breakfast and lunch available during open hours.  We opted for a couple of omelets (w/ home fries), turkey sage sausage, egg & cheese on Kaiser roll, and a grilled blueberry muffin.  Ten minutes later we were served by a very friendly and considerate woman, who seemed to anticipate our needs.  That was unexpected and exceptional. 

Our food was very good.  The omelets were stuffed to the gills with the cheesesteak and sausage fillings two of them wanted, while my sandwich was not overly large, but very tasty with the turkey sage sausage a surprise star of the show.  Very happy with that recommendation.  The muffin had a strong resemblance to Costco muffins, but there were no complaints. Coffee was strong and the request that one be half milk, well received and delivered. 

This location is beyond the spreading influence of UPenn and Drexel.  That means that it is still an original joint that has not been gentrified yet.  The cozy neighborhood atmosphere was palpable, and the prices reflective of that.  

Very happy to find a place where I can eat and be comfortable while waiting to go to work.

Online car shopping is only as good as the people on the other end and the principles of the organization they represent. Luckily for me the new owner of the Willow Grove Infiniti dealership is the Faulkner Group. They know how to put the customer in as much comfort as possible when shopping for a new/used car. The process is what is important to me, so even if we don't come to terms I feel appreciated as a valuable customer and know they want my business, if at all possible.  

They happened to have a mature Infiniti that suited me quite well. I found it through Car Gurus. The communication was prompt and unpressured when I inquired. We were able to arrange a visit to their dealership and a test drive for later in the week. I arrived. I was introduced. I test drove. We discussed the outlines of a deal. All cordial and relaxed. 

Life can interfere with even car buying. As Mick J sang, "You can't always get what you want...but ... you just might get you get what you need." Despite legit price reduction, I decided on a different direction for several reasons. 

Regardless, I felt good about Faulkner Infiniti of Willow Grove, and plan to return for service and when it is time to replace my aging M. Such a great car. They were right when they say theirs was a better vehicle than the other one I was interested in, but sometimes better isn't what's best under all the circumstances. This was so here. 

Someone's going to be fist bumping.  Someone's going to be frustrated. I'll get something that I can use well for several years, and save a few grand by being prudent. 

But, I'll be back soon for service on my M, and to keep an eye on what they have out on the lot.

Breakfast Nook is a small morning/afternoon luncheonette in the Borough of Riverton, NJ, right across Bannard Street from the Cinnaminson Light Rail Station very close by the Delaware River. It sits on the first floor of a warehouse-looking building, not normally a place I'd look for breakfast. Still, it is a bright and clean house with a dozen or so tables and counter service toward the rear. 

I plopped down on a stool and settled in as a server welcomed me, brought me coffee, milk and a menu. I appreciated the fresh milk availability in lieu of mini moo. The specials board caught my attention with its offer of a sausage, egg and cheese on grilled rye sandwich (with home fries, $7). 

It called my name.

It was a very good sammy. Crisp, grill toasted bread, with tasty patty, sharp cheddar and still lightly drippy fried egg. Just the way I like it. The home fries were copious, with dark nibs throughout, and just greasy enough for max flavor. Coffee wasn't memorable, but it was hot and bracing on a cool late November morn. 

While looking around I saw three wooden plates on the wall, each with the name of a restaurant owned by this team. Kelly's Kitchen in Bensalem, PA, Dredge Harbor Cafe in Riverton and Breakfast Nook. I had now eaten in all three, and wondered if there was a prize for this accomplishment. Probably not, but there ought to be at least a cupcake in recognition. 

Maybe they'll read this and let me know.

This was my first visit to Mexican Mariachi Grill and it won't be my last.  

Sitting in a nondescript mini shopping strip across from the old GM plant, this joint is a bright and pleasant spot for lunch, and probably dinner.  Once inside it is a long, narrow space with a wall of tables on one side, and the kitchen prep area on the other.  The menu is simple with the usual suspect tacos, burritos, quesadillas and the like, but as soon as I saw they had grilled pork Tortas, I zoned in on that.  

The Chips and Salsas are self-serve on top of the counter, with a choice of hot and hotter green/red dippers in small plastic containers.  The chips are extra thick and crunchy. The lunch special includes a drink, smooth Black Bean mash, and mildly spicy Rice with kernels of corn mixed in. Both, tasty and textural accompaniments.  The Torta arrived - an oversized fresh roll stuffed with Grilled Pork, Lettuce, Tomato, Melty Cheese, Hot Sauce, and Chipotle Mayo dressing, half-wrapped in foil to hold it together and allow for pick up without mess.  Under $7.

The chew was a robust mix of hot and cold, sweet and spicy, chewy and compliant; a very tasty and intriguing eat.  The only note of caution is when removing the foil to attack the rest of the sandwich, remember that the sauce inside can leak and drip, and even dampen the bread.  You don't want that causing a trip to the cleaners. 

Otherwise, a totally satisfying experience that I am very likely to repeat.

Yordana's Pizza & Pasta on Emilie Road, Levittown, PA., is a very good find for a well prepared Italian meal.  Although dressed up like a pizza parlor on the outside, there is a comfortable dining room within, with large wall murals of Venice, and a menu that covers most of the traditional Roman dishes, plus a few custom designed in house.  To my pleasant surprise, everything we ordered was first rate.  

We went with two chicken platters; Parmegano and Valentino, with side of pasta and nice sized green salad. Both consisted of three breast fillets. The Parmegano was olive oil pan sautéed bread crumb covered in thick chunky red sauce, with a mildly salty and basil flavor, covered with melted mozza. It was tender and filling. Our request that the pasta side be done Alfredo was granted, and after a shake or two of black pepper, it was excellent as a complement to the main course. Similarly, the Valentino was laid over with freshly cut mushrooms and steamed asparagus, and a light cream sauce. The veggies were still crisp, while the chicken cut easily with a fork. The white sauce was mellow and perfect for the combination of other flavors and textures. It was very different than the Alfredo sauce, showing the skill of the chef in preparing each separately as ordered. The aglio olio penne pasta in the side bowl was likewise delicious.  We were very impressed how each dish was so remarkably distinct and fun to eat. 

Service was friendly and prompt, but also not fawning nor overdone. This was still Levittown, after all. 

This is the second or third superior meal we have scored on Emilie Road, and it is unlikely to be the last.  It is so worth exploring this neighborhood, especially when it is obvious that there is no loss of quality along with the appreciated loss of expense. 

Yordana's is worth the trip.

While I'm not a Starbucks guy (too often burnt beans), this new drive thru sit down plant in the Village @ Newtown Shopping Center is very cool. Laid back, smaller footprint, friendly accommodating baristas, and decent breakfast profile, make for a pleasant interlude. Panoramic view of the ever expanding choices coming online in this primary commercial zone in Newtown. Can see Melt Shop, Factory Donuts, Naked Chocolate, Oishi, Nothing Bundt Cakes from my small deuce in the window. 

Here for a quick Saturday morning meeting, I enjoyed their oatmeal with blueberries, crannies, raisins and a touch of brown sugar (How come you dance so good?!). Perhaps, a little too much packaging for a health planet, but they do have choices. Even the Pike's Roast was more flavorful and less bitter than usual. 

Meeting went well, so this $$$bucks could become a strong house for getting together in private conversation. There is enough ambient noise from the polished concrete floor, high metal ceiling and sound system to mask any but the loudest voice.

Apparently the sibling of 1st Oriental Supermarket on 6th Street in South Philly, with similar layout and the same products from live fish through Vietnamese noodles and Thai sauces. Yeah, it has an odor of over ripe fruit and spilled frog water, but that goes with the territory. While some find it offensive, it reminds me of the outdoor markets throughout Asia where the smells are part of the experience. 

We had the good fortune of eating dim sum next door at China Gourmet before shopping. It was very good and a great opening act for the aisle cruising to come. Made for a complete excursion to the East.

Maryland Crab Seafood House is located in the former Extension Diner on Olden Avenue Extension, Ewing, NJ. It is the fish restaurant project undertaken by the proprietor of the Ewing Diner, a traditional Greek stainless palace nearby.

 The space is nicely renovated, but retains the familiarity of its beginnings with marble lunch counter and enormous slices of dessert cakes, pies and puddings. The service folk looked vaguely like the old staff at The Extension, but as it was many years since my last visit, I wasn't sure if we were all just older versions of our previous selves. They were well schooled in taking care of customers and made certain I had all the water and oven heated rolls I wanted.

I walked in after 3 and was hungry enough for dinner after skipping lunch and an early breakfast. I saw Flounder Francais on the Specials Menu, and stopped reading. As a Francais Fanatic there was nothing more to consider. Let's see what these guys could do with a favorite dish. 

The side Caesar Salad was big and fresh, but lacked anchovy based dressing. The small Dinner Rolls were excellent right from the oven with a tasty herb butter melting into them. The large plate with a bed of yellow rice under Flounder fillet dipped in egg and lightly sauteed in more butter, lemon and white wine was flakey and tender and seemed to have avoided freezer time.

 Its only shortcoming was caused by my expectation that it would be an Italian or French style finish with a pan sautee browning and thin lemon wine butter reduction. Rather, it was a much heavier bright yellow Greek gravy that was more a thick Avgolemono soup, than the delicate tart complement to the flounder. It wasn't bad, but just not what I envisioned.

That will remind me to live in the moment and leave expectations behind where they can't influence what's yet to come.

Before I was ready to write a review, I needed a refresher on the geography and history of Uzbekistan, the Central Asian nation surrounded by other "stans;" its cities of Tashkent, Samarkand and Bukara, some of the Pearls along the Silk Road from Istanbul to Xian, China, made famous by the epic journeys of Marco Polo.  I had visited Tashkent on business some years ago, and remembered it as very old and mysterious; full of mosques and museums - and especially, gem markets where trade in rare colored crystals and semi-precious stones, kept me excited, curious and negotiating for days at a time.  

And, the food was equally excellent.  So, when we decided on impulse to have dinner at Chaikhana on Bustleton Avenue last weekend, it was with a sense of remembered delicacies and dinners that went on for hours into the wee hours of the morning; with too much local alcohol and toasts to everything under the sun and moon.  This was one of those friction points between two cultures, where each was influenced by the other.  Here it meant people who looked Asian, but spoke Russian and various dialects.  A place where Buddha was said to have travelled, and Islam flourished.  

This shop is not typical Philly.  It announces itself loudly by occupying a large house fronting the busy Bustleton, and having a large enclosed patio in front, wrapped in plastic to maintain temperature, and lit by tiny white lights encased in miniature trees on each table.  No reservation was required this Sunday night, as we were seated on the end of a large table big enough for six.  This porch was occupied by a few large parties celebrating happiness, which naturally took a lot of attention to service well.  We still had enough of our gracious server's help to understand the menu with wise suggestions as to the dishes to mix without going overboard.  Her suggestions were right on, as each plate was loaded with enough for two people, and ordering as we would in another restaurant would have been overkill here.

We started with mushroom soup and bread.  One order was enough for both of us, and it was served in two bowls.  It had several fungal varieties in a rich and savor base stock.  Maybe a tad oily, but very flavorful and excellent.  The round loaf of bread was a very pleasant surprise.  It had a thick and chewy texture, and both a salty and sweet flavor.  It was amazing.  A smear of butter, or a sponging of the soup or gravies, made it the perfect complement for whatever was eaten.  

Two apps were also shared.  The Cheburek, a deep fried folded over dough filled with spicy ground beef, potato, onions and a few mysteries, was richly textured, smooth and delicious. The other escapes me at the moment, but it was round, plump and baked. Loved it.  Our main entre was a chicken and lamb kabob, both of which were cooked to their apex of tenderness and flavor, with onion slices on the side.  They were both wonderful, and again, enough for us to share.  We ate well while those around us celebrated to the max.  It was fun to watch and listen.  

We were full before dessert, although very tempted by the cherry Vareniki and honey cake.  

There was plenty left unexplored on this visit.  But, like Marco Polo, many more trips to this part of Uzbekistan are anticipated.

Just ordered a 16 piece fried chicken bucket from Chicken Holiday on Olden Avenue Extension in Ewing, NJ. After calling it in, I drove there on my way home, and arrived just as it was coming out of the pressure fryer. It looked dark bronze and the odor of the steam being released went right to my head, and made me feel a bit intoxicated. 

Nothing wrong with that!

I watched as the cook removed the chicken and transferred it to an aluminum tray for safe travel. I counted the pieces with him, and think my package carried 17 total. I appreciated the extra generosity. He then wrapped the tray in foil, and tore open the top dome to allow the condensation to escape. In turn, that was placed in a heavy gauge brown paper sack, and again split open at the top for additional moisture release. 

By the time I arrived home, I was nearly overcome by the aroma enveloping the car. I decided to sample a wing while still hot and wait for the family before consuming more. First bite encountered crisp skin, followed by warm white meat and a pleasant clean oil fried chicken flavor. I nibbled and sucked all the meat from them bones, and I selfishly considered grabbing a plump breast for a long moment. 

Nah! It would be more fun to indulge with the fam. So, I waited. 

An hour later we were sitting around the kitchen table with sides of homemade mashed potatoes and green salad as excellent complementary pieces to a very happy meal. 

A star is missing because truth be told, the chicken was a tad overdone. A lighter golden copper finish would have made it perfect. Turns out that as much as I love the color bronze, it is past prime when it comes to fried chicken excellence. Still very good texture and taste, but with a subtle aftertaste that missed the mark. 

In fried chicken, even a seconds can make a big difference.

I've had this Chase credit card since 1985.  When the new card arrived to replace the expiring one, I dutifully made the required call to activate it.  Little did I know I would be entering the Bizarro world of "Verification."

My call was transferred to a human being because their system did not recognize me.  I was told that they did not have my Social Security number, nor anything else in their records to identify me! 

What?!

Thirty years in the system and suddenly I did not exist.  They had issued the card originally with some required information. They no longer had it.  They had sent me the renewal, but had no way for me to use it.  I had become a digital phantom. 

My deduction was that my identity had been dumped or lost in a security breach, and now to be sure I was not one of the bad guys, I had to justify my existence.  How, you ask?  By going to a bricks and mortar bank branch and introducing myself to a bank officer with some backup credentials.  

The story has a happy (if time wasting) ending.  I went into this branch today and met with one of their suits.  He was very nice and sat me down in his cubicle to review the facts and call the Chase verification center.  A five minute conversation ensued with an exchange of information with HQ, which resulted in my identity being accepted, and the card useable.  

For the humorous professionalism demonstrated by SB (shall remain nameless), and his cutting through the BS and bringing my identity back online, I am a true fan of this gentleman and the bank branch he represents.

Thai Chef & Noodle Fusion is located on a dreary strip of Rt. 1 (Lincoln Highway) in Penndel.  The effort to bring new life is taking shape with a few new restaurants in a two block area.  This place is one of its anchors, and is a pioneer there over several years.  

The shop has a casual air, much more laid back and cozy than it appears from outside.  The tables on one side are separated by privacy screens made up of thin branches and curtains.  The outer wall has carved wooden folding screens that can be opened to extend for more separation.  Nice touch.  The staff is friendly, informative and prompt.  This is primarily a Thai house, although the name and menu offer alternatives in Japanese and Chinese cuisine.  I join the other reviewers in skepticism that "fusion" is a reality as opposed to a marketing gimmick.  I have only tried the Thai dishes as the owners and chef are Thai, and they come by this style honestly - they live it. 

I had a lunch special which is a combination of a choice of cup of soup, app, and entre.  I chose the Tum Yom Soup, Moon Dumplings, and Drunken Noodles with Chicken.  The soup had the strong taste of lemongrass and mild chili with ample slices of chicken and veggies.  I enjoyed it.  The Moon Dumplings were a pleasant surprise.  While small and lightly fried, they were loaded with ground mushrooms and possessed a nice earthy flavor, and absorbed the hot chili oil/sauce well.  The Drunken Noodles were very good, with the right ratio of broad noodles to veggies and chicken and a decent sauce.  It was a little bland so I asked for chili flakes to liven it up.  I was brought a shaker of finely ground orange pepper that was a perfect complement to the dish and brought it to the heat level I wanted.  Some joints don't have the right spice and offer only Sriracha, which, while hot, does not blend well and distribute evenly over most foods.  Thai Chef had what was needed.  

I can't comment on the "fusion" aspects, but I was very satisfied with my Thai lunch here.  I know that I look forward to more visits, and that makes me a fan.

August 10, 2014 - I have had dinner here a couple of times recently.  If anything, the dinners are superior to the lunch deals.  Last night I sampled their "Jungle King" and "Cashew".  The names themselves were unique. Both were nice portions of fresh veggies, tofu, chicken, with a nice mix of spices, including ginger and a sweetish curry, and large cashews on one.  An order of House Fried Rice rounded out the meal, while leaving enough to take home for today's lunch.  

The vibe continues to relax and encourage lingering.  The fact that the owners are Thai helps bring the authenticity home.

Folcroft Diner sits on Chester Pike (Rt. 13) in the northern panhandle of the borough by that name in Delaware County, PA. Before the interstate was completed, it and Rt.1 were the primary roads north and south between Philly and Baltimore. Driving it last Friday on the way back from UDel to Bucks County due to jammed traffic on Rt. I 95, was an historic tour of yesteryear America when roadside attractions were often the best part of a family car trip to the intended destination. 

Cruising north with son after school was declared closed for classes for the remainder of the spring semester, it was natural to reflect on the drive with my parents between New York and Washington when I was a student in D.C. Felt like an unfortunate right of passage to be experiencing this due to the curse of COVID-19. 

The diner was the perfect stage for a lunch stop to stretch and grab a quick bite of Americana. A cup of New England Clam Chowder and Petty Melt (medium, fries, slaw & pickle slices), were the way to go. Our booth was comfy, our server friendly and attentive, and the space around us sufficient to allow us to feel socially distanced. We considered whether restaurants would remain open for sit down business in the days and weeks ahead. If this was to be a last meal in the Age of COVID-19, then we would soberly celebrate the moment and pray our angels protected us. 

The chowder was thick creamy and loaded with diced clam. The cup was very filling and more than enough for a sample. The burger was a half pounder, finished as desired, bracketed by quality rye toast, melted Swiss and filled with sauteed onions and mushrooms. A long red squirt of Heinz Ketchup and I had a fun, satisfying meal. I could only down half, and took the rest home. Prices were surprisingly reasonable for the quality and quality of the plates served, almost like the menu was printed in the last century. 

Maybe it was.

Al's Airport Inn has come a long way from its dive bar existence in the last quarter of the 20th Century. What was once a place only lone drinkers and cheaters could love, it has moved more uptown into a comfortable local bar with a pretty good kitchen. Son and I dropped in last night for dinner, and were duly impressed. 

We ordered Al's wings and two burgers, along with draft Miller Lites (There isn't much in the way of crafties here). The wings were very good, and justify their reputation. Crisp, meaty, and spicy without being volcanic. At 10 for $10, reasonably priced. Happy hour provides a $2 discount. The burgers were freshly ground and shaped in house. Although we requested medium finish, they were both well done. That could be because the chef was doubling as a waiter and not attentive enough at the grill. Still, with a little more seasoning they could have been very good. Superior brioche style bun held together to the end. 

Al's accepts credit cards now, which is a big deal in opening their market to more of the public. It did appear that they didn't have much experience with them, as the original bill was not returned with the credit card invoice for signing, making it impossible to compare for accuracy. Better practice to do so. 

Overall, Al's is vastly improved over its past life. Haunted or not, it is no longer a dive bar, and is a nice place to hang out.

3.5 STARS

Sofra is a Turkish café on Bristol Pike in Levittown, Pa.  It doesn't look like much from the outside, with small stature in a rather unattractive part of Bucks County, but grab some courage and go inside.  Within, you will find a small dining room, with open floor space for entertainment.  Most important, the chef knows a thing or two about Istanbul cuisine.  

Our Saturday jaunt to a commercial area nearby resulted in us stopping in to check out what was going on here.  We were greeted by a gentlemen I took to be an owner, owing to his general lack of social grace. Why else would he be handling guests?  Still, we sat to one side and were brought menus and cold water.  I am no maven when it comes to Turkish kitchens, but Middle Eastern chow I know something about from time spent in the eastern Mediterranean.  

I was looking for lamb gyro as an introduction to the skill here, but it was not available for lunch.  So, I looked further and found Shepherd's Salad, Falafel and Grilled Lamb in Pita Sandwich as attractive alternatives.  All arrived about ten minutes later in the hands of our erstwhile host.  The Salad was a plentiful pile of Tomato, Cucumber, Black Olive, Red Onion and a nice Olive Oil based herbed dressing.  Very refreshing. The Falafel Plate was 5 nice sized balls of ground chickpea and herbs, deep fried to a medium brown finish, with a stainless bowl of Tahini Sauce in the middle.  Wedge Tomato and Lettuce garnish.  Liked it!  Finally, the Grilled Lamb wrapped tightly in pita and again in paper, was excellent, with a rich BBQ-like flavor and more lettuce, onion and a wonderful savory taste.  Star of the show. 

We weren't asked if we wanted dessert or Turkish coffee (we did), but were handed the check as soon as we finished eating our mains.  I guess we weren't on the guest list, even being the only customers in the house.  

Too bad, because Sofra has potential.

Eleven of us showed up at 10:30 for a Dim Sum experience in Philadelphia Chinatown last Saturday.  I had selected Ocean City Restaurant on the north end of 9th Street from Yelp reviews.  A little out of the way. A lot more available tables than other similar banquet halls closer to the center of CTown. 

We were met near the front door by the owner/manager, who at first thought there were only two of us.  He was gracious, even knowing we could not eat enough to make his day.  Then, we explained there were actually nine more right behind us.  His face registered the glint of happy surprise as he swiveled and pointed to the large round table in the front corner with exactly eleven chairs around it.  Now, he was very happy, and walked with us and set up the lazy Susan in the middle of the table as we all gathered 'round.  Maybe, we would help his bottom line.  

Indeed, we did.

As the cart ladies approached, the titular hostess of this feast arose and began to order for everyone.  Nothing random here.  She pointed and placed, requested and demanded, served and bussed, and made sure everyone had an equal amount of every dish desired.  Truly, an amazing display of taking charge, and improving the experience.  She has a future in the hosting business.  

If you check the photos, you will see that we sampled a large amount of what Ocean City had to offer.  Everything was good to exceptional for dim sum.  Special mention to the Minced Pork Congee, Tofu Skin with Veggies, and the Seafood Dumplings.  Tasty and fun.  We didn't try everything, but enjoyed what we had, with even the rookies fully engaged.  We left enough on the menu for another visit.  

It always surprises me how much food you get at a dim sum, and for what a fair price.  Eleven of us (9 adults), gorged for under $150, and even brought a few things home.  

Ocean City is a traditional seafood house that does a splendid Hong Kong style 'small plates'.  Can't speak to the regular menu, but they do dim sum the old fashioned way. Full floor show. Totally satisfied.

Keep it coming!

It may not have the shelf space of the large Asian Markets in Flushing, nor the mystique of my favorite subterranean shop in Philly, but H Mart is only ten minutes from home and provides me with most of the Asian specialties I would otherwise get stuck on the Verrazano Bridge to reach, or be forced to pay ten bucks to park in Center City.  

Returned last night to pick up Chinese Eggplant, Ginger Root, Assorted Frozen Dumplings, Hot Dumpling Sauce, Crispy Chili in Oil, and a big can of Wasabi Sweet Peas (Thailand), for meals and snacks over the next few weeks; while checking out the fresh fish, and other exotics, like an anthropologist enjoying a stroll through a museum.  

I have yet to take a seat in the little café to taste what's going on there, but until I do, the rest of the store suits my needs perfectly.

Smith's Ace Hardware is an extension of Yardville Supply, a serious regional provider of all home improvement merchandise, geared for the professional contractor set more than the general public. Their Ace ventures attempt to overcome that marketing disadvantage by fitting a niche between big box highway warehouses and mom & pop corner retail hardware shops. 

In Newtown, they compete with the historic Newtown Hardware on State Street in the Borough, which has been in business for over one hundred years. So, the disparity between shopping old and shopping new could not be greater. Ace is larger and has superior inventory as a result, but lacks the community roots and hands on experience of the museum-like NHH. They don't really compete on price, because they are both more expensive than the big boxes. 

So, whether you want to buy self piercing screws or replacement screens to patch the originals on your back porch, depends on your feeling about local vs. corporate enterprise. You wouldn't go to either if price was your primary focus, as Home Depot and Lowes are both cheaper. But, if keeping local businesses afloat is important to you, the choice is a closer call. This Ace is owned by a Jersey company and is limited to a small region in NJ and PA. It provides local jobs to help the economy. Yet, if you like a dose of true history when you are looking for small pieces to complete a home project, and love to rummage through old wooden drawers full of nails, screws, and electrical parts, Newtown Hardware has you covered. 

The choice is yours.

Riverfront Market is a glorified food court housed in a redeveloped brick and beam warehouse on the banks of the Christina River in Wilmington, DE. It was built under the auspices of the state funded Riverfront Development Corporation in the late 1990s. It is an interesting destination in a part of town that was weed filled lots and dilapidated buildings prior to the large investment of taxpayer funds. It is much better to reestablish a functional, economically viable commercial center than to leave it forgotten and abandoned. 

The mix of dining choices comes from all locally owned food outlets of varying ethnicity, including, Mexican, Thai, Italian, cheesesteak and Korean green grocer. New kitchens are taking the place of those that have not survived. With hours from 6 to 6, it is primarily a lunch choice, with only the Mexican place open for business when I arrived at 4 on a Friday. The rest were already locked down, or being cleaned and straighten in preparation for the next day. 

The building is historically attractive, a pleasant place to walk around or sit at the many tables around the retail space or the second story open balconies. I was the only customer in the house and had time to explore before and after eating my tacos carnitas. It was disappointing that they were unable to sustain their businesses the entire day, but the market has made it this far (with possible subsidies), and the city and state should assure that it can continue to attract people to this part of town.

Hate to admit that after many years of attending court in the same complex, that I never noticed Sal's Pizzeria before this week.  So, after an afternoon session, and hungry from skipping lunch, I drove around to the front of this oldish commercial strip center and spied this TPie shop.  

Upon entry, I was struck by the orange and yellow walls in the surprising large restaurant.  Although dated, it had a wholesome ambiance conducive to an Italian meal.  Given the hour, I went with a single slice of Traditional Pizza with Sweet Sausage, and a drink.  

Good choice, as the slice was larger than average.  I asked for it "well done," and that was what I received.  Upon lifting off the large attractively orange plate, I was immediately impressed that despite its size and extra weight from the topside, the point held firm and high with nary a quiver.  First bite was a full blown crunch through cheese, sauce and meat; all of which were received warmly with pleasure in my mouth.  It was a very good slice of pizza, despite being reheated.  

With this lunch coming in under $5. I was very satisfied with the experience, and will not be a stranger to Sal's.  The rest of the menu listed the usual suspects.  If done as well as their pies, I will become a regular customer when in Mt. Holly.

Just the fact that there is a local place that does Southern style cuisine in the area means Southern Comforts will be a success as long as they don't screw up this opportunity. Stick to traditional recipes, offer generous helpings and keep price within reason, and it will take off once Covid restrictions are in the rearview. 

If my first exposure to their kitchen is any indication, they are on their way. They need to open their dining room to customers, and the rest is baked in. We ordered their "Make Your Own" dinners of 1) Country Fried Steak, roasted carrots & baked beans, and 2) Crab Cakes, bread stuffing, gravy and candied yams; with slice of carrot cake as shared dessert. It was all pretty darned good, except for the carrot cake. Allow me to elaborate. 

The fried steak was a thin prefab ground patty, nicely fried and drowned in that white gravy. Nice texture and taste, with the gravy not too heavy on the tongue. The sides were a well made complement. Same with the crab cake. Crisp edges with crumbly crab with a little breading to bind them together, but with a dominant crustacean taste. We didn't use those little packages or tartar sauce, as there was enough flavor without them. The yams were sweet, but the bread stuffing was a bit dry and was not resuscitated by the gravy. Yet skipping the stuffing left a still very enjoyable meal. 

Word to the wise - Don't over sell a dessert that is past its prime. I was asked if I wanted dessert, and since it was brought to my attention, allowed myself to be upsold because I do love carrot cake as a general proposition. This wayward slice was the exception that proved the rule. It was smallish,  without much cake nor cream cheese icing. It was also noticeably dried out from too much shelf time. Definitely not the place to end a successful meal. It just wasn't worth the calories nor sugar kick. I don't mind being upsold when the product is worthwhile, but when it is a disappointment, it is self defeating. 

Almost lost me there, but decided the rest of the meal was good enough to warrant partially overlooking that mistake. 

3.5 STARS

Great pleasant surprise when I drove over to Penn Medicine's offices on Township Line Road in Lower Makefield, PA, for an x-ray and found Nick Roast Beef's food truck in their parking lot. It was already 1:30 and I hadn't had lunch. I knew I would be over as soon as I was finished with radiology. The fates continued to smile when the lab time put me back on the street in less than half an hour and Nick's was still there and open for business. 

I walked over to their window and was met by the lovely, friendly server, who smiled for a photo before taking my roast pork sandwich order. Her assistant worked the grill and constructed my lunch with a pile of hot pork on a kaiser roll. It was handed to me in a paper boat with small tubs of pickled jalapeno slices and white horseradish. Napkins and other necessities were on the side table to the left; drinks in two portable coolers on the ground to the right. 

I drove home and demolished the porker at my kitchen table. It was a thick, juicy mother. All pale tender thin moist sliced roaster, without a lick of fat nor dryness. It was awesome, although the roll was a few minutes past prime. The peppers and radish brought up the burn to a warm wet kiss all the way down. 

I hope this is a regular stop for Nick's truck, because I could become a faithful customer.

Barry's Buns is another small shop in the Markets at Wayfare on Germantown Avenue, Chestnut Hill. They do all manner of bakery sweets that go well with coffee for breakfast, or any other time of day when you desire a tasty sugar fix. 

When I was there on Saturday afternoon the market was packed with beer drinkers both inside and out. Perhaps because of that Barry's inventory was pretty much threadbare. All I saw were a few chunks of Crumb Cake, Jewish Apple Cake, and somethings that looked like fruit topped cupcakes. The woman working the counter was friendly and answered my questions about what was left and smoothly packed up my order of two Crumb Cakes into a white paper bag. 

My sense was that as soon as her meagre stock was gone, so was she. If she had been willing to sell that apple cake by the wedge, rather than requiring the whole kubboodle go at once, I would have been happy to grab a handful. I love Jewish Apple Cake, but I didn't want the temptation of bringing it home in my car. I couldn't trust myself not to dive in and fist large handfuls into my mouth like the 8 year old kid lurking within would do. 

I did more calmly sample a piece of the Crumb Cake on the way after stopping at Poppy's Cafe for hot coffee to wash it down. It was excellent - still moist, soft, sweet, with clumped brown sugar/cinnamon/butter embedded within like a happy toy in a Cracker Jack box. 

Clearly have to come here earlier in the day to have the most choice.

My son and I were looking for a light dinner and decided to try Greenstraw Smoothies on Sycamore Street, the main drag in Newtown, Bucks County.  It is a new place on the nicely redeveloped commercial district.  

The menu consists of a long list of healthy drinks with fresh fruits and veggies, along with nutritional supplements to suit your particular need - Maca, Hemp protein, Flax Seed, Chia, Spirulina, Wheatgrass Juice, etc.  The foundation of the smoothies are cow milk alternatives like Almond or Coconut Milk, Yogurt, and Fruit Juices.  The combinations are surprisingly refreshing and tasty.  

I ordered a Leo's Favorite, consisting of Almond Milk, Apple Juice, Banana, Peanut Butter, Strawberries, Raspberries, and Greens.  The resultant reddish blend was thick and smooth, but simply sucked through a straw (Yes. It was green). It was a pleasure to imbibe.  My son had The Mango Tree, with Coconut Milk, Mango Juice, Banana, Mango Pieces, Pineapple, and Greens.  The mix came out a ruddy greenish mash that was also quite good.  We both smiled on first drought, and sampled each others drinks.  

I was definitely satisfied with my liquid dinner and was not hungry again last night. Young man needed a bit more sustenance after finishing his homework.  

This is definitely a worthy spot for a healthy drink.  The prices are reasonable at $5.75 for the middle sized concoction, which was quite filling. 

There is also fair trade coffee available, but that will wait for another day. 

Good luck, Greenstraw.

We had a great La Villa Traditional Square Pizza here last week. I had forgotten how delicious their pies were. It was loaded with peppers, onions, mushrooms and sausage, and baked to a wonderful crispy crust(see photo). Service was also friendly and prompt. The black clad servers certainly kept a certain 21 year old family member entertained. 

However, the app special Crab Cake was drenched in a cheesy white sauce that overwhelmed the titular star of the show to such an extent that the crabbiness of the crustacean was lost.  The big Greek Salad while plentiful lacked imagination and an impressive dressing.  I would not ask for either of those again. 

But, in the end it is all about the pie.  La Villa's are vastly superior to any of its nearby competitors, and can stand their own with some of the best across the river in Jersey or Philly. 

Happily, it is much closer in Morrisville, in a nicely appointed renovated Pizza Hut structure in the middle of a strip mall parking field off Pennsylvania Avenue.

I can't speak to the authenticity of their German cuisine, because I was just there for breakfast, but I certainly enjoyed what I had for my morning meal. 

Sitting at the bar under the huge head of a taxidermy moose, with large steins high on a shelf, I was surprised by the extensive breakfast menu.  Tracy, the manager/server in the barroom, was cordial, but gave me time and space to decide what to eat, after bringing me a mug of coffee and side cordial glass of milk. Nice touch! 

I went with their, "Mini Vacation in Paris." You guessed it - a short stack of french toast with two extra plump pork sausages. After doctoring everything with butter and Smucker's syrup, I went to work. It was all pretty good, with good flavor packed into the two slices of white, and extra pleasant taste emanating from the bangers. It would have been even better with maple syrup, but at a price under $8 for everything, I am not complaining. 
 
Coffee was refilled without asking, and I was even given the TV remote to watch whatever I chose on the corner monitor. That was a first, and even though I preferred to catch up on my reading, I appreciated the generous offer. 

If I find myself out that way again, I would def stop in to discover more of the morning possibilities. I bet Tracy has some stories to tell.

On the dreary stretch of Rt. 1 (Lincoln Highway) in Fairless Hills, Pa., sits a solitary Colonel Sanders, aka, KFC. 

I have customered it a few times over the years.  Each time the parking lot was nearly empty, and the dining area bereft of fried chicken lovers.  Hitchcockian if pushed for a description, with an orange neon sign on the wall saying it was "Sunday dinner every night."  Yet, the actual meals were good, and the Honey BBQ wings way better than average due in part to their initial preparation as Buffalo Wings, then lathered with the thick sweet tang of the Honey BBQ recipe, giving the wings a hot sweet sallow flavor that can lead to compulsive eating disorders.  The Original Recipe Buckets are also quite good, especially for feeding teenage boys coming together for a party.

Thus, my reason for being there late last week, as I waited for the order to be packed and bagged.  I was surprised when the bucket of 20 pieces and box of 20 wings came in over $40., but nothing is too good for my now teenage son.  

My car smelled of greasy BBQ on the ride home, and it tortured my saliva glands so much that I nearly pulled over to put one of those rusty red chicken wings in my mouth.  I overcame that impulse and made it home in 20 minutes. As soon as I entered the house, my son, his friends, and a couple of parents became transfixed at the aroma, and silently rose to follow me into the dining room.  Shades of Night of the Living Dead. 

The entire batch was devoured in a half hour, and there were sated smiles all around. I am convinced that a chemical analysis of the chicken coating would turn up crack in the mix.  It was that good. 

Have to be careful as this stuff is quickly addictive, but so damn yummy.

Solstice, the nouveau cuisine restaurant recently opened in the Village @ Newtown Shopping Center, bring something attractive and creative to the fairly standard kitchens that are crowding into town recently. Its space is open and bright, with high ceilings and the feel of a summer home at the beach on a sunny summer day. Walking in for our reservation immediately shifted my attitude from just another dinner, to the possibility of something transformative. It was that beautiful and unexpected. 

The staff was equal to the environment, and took great care of us from seating to, "Thanks for coming. Hope to see you again soon." Likewise, the menu offerings were seasonal, with many vegetarian oriented appetizers and entrees. The summer listings were a cross between colorful blends of meat and leaf, pasta and creative takes on traditional dishes. We went with Lobster Risotto, Filet (medium well), Braised Waygu Short Rib & Mashed, and Sweet Corn Ricotta Gnocchi. I also sampled the Cantelope Gazpacho to broaden our exposure to their kitchen. 

The result was less than perfection, but strong enough to appreciate what the chef was trying to do to separate Solstice from the ragtag assortment of other houses in the neighborhood. Special merit to the Gazpacho, which was just a delicious cold soup on an extremely hot day. In fact, it was the best thing brought to our table. 

The Risotto was visually stunning with the yellow rice base and orange lobster, but not the most tasty rendition available for these ingredients. Liked it. Didn't love it. The Filet was mild pink throughout as described by our server, yet somewhat thinner than anticipated and less flavorful than hoped. Admittedly, my stepson may have been influenced by the same cut he ordered last week at Rocco's, which knocked his socks off. This slab was certainly less overwhelming, but still decent. It just suffered by comparison. 

The Short Rib was perfectly cooked and was again a stunning visual presentation. The sauce could have used more zip, as it had the texture/flavor of American roast beef, rather than accentuating the Waygu or the many Asian or citrus spices that could have made this dish sing. In the same way, the Gnocchi was tender and mixed very well with the veggies and shaved cheese, but had a excess of water at the bottom of the deep plate and was a bit salty. As you can tell, everything was good to excellent, but each left something to be desired. 

There will be a next time, but our approach will be to treat Solstice as a tapas house. We will order several appetizers, rather than entrees, and enjoy tasting many more of their creative dishes. The Gazpacho was the best we tried, and the hummus and other small plates seemed to have potential as we scanned the other tables for reactions to the food. I suspect, without knowing, that this may be the way to go.

Long Life Chinese Natural Herbs is a Chinese apothecary shop much like you will find in most Asian neighborhoods around the globe.  It has both packaged and loose herbs for most known (and many unknown to western culture) ailments.  The owner and employees are quite knowledgeable at understanding your symptoms and making informed suggestions for treatment.  

I observed as several customers described their physical problems, were questioned by the herbalists, and finally reached a thoughtful solution.  Then, the chief lay sheets of clean paper on the counter and began to place various herbs, roots, and barks onto each of them in approximately equal amounts before wrapping each carefully, and placing them in separate bags; one for each dosage - usually a strong tea.  Fascinating!

I was there for fresh, sliced American Ginseng to help stimulate my energy level, and an herbal patch for a friend with Plantar's Fasciitis.  Securing both after enjoying the cultural display rarely seen outside of the Chinatown's of the USA, I left with confidence in my new elixirs.

This place seems to move substantial volume, and it is a safe bet that their products are fresher than those sometimes found in stores that sell a multitude of other things.

Zara's Food Cart although on wheels and with a hitch for getting on the road, is a permanent fixture of the Riggins gas station on Street Road, Bensalem, PA. Its lime green paint job makes it easy to see on the southbound side. The menu is limited to gyros and over rice options in lamb, chicken or beef Afghani style faire. From what I saw and tasted, its popularity is well founded. 

My son turned me on to it on our way back from a day visiting Delaware, and just describing his experience there made us hungry to try it. So, we got off RT. 95 and cruised up Street Road a mile or so until we found it. About 4 parking spaces in proximity, but all we needed was one. The cart is tiny which explains the absence of room for refrigerated drinks. Only a small person could work in such tight conditions. Zara be that guy.

My lamb Gyro was excellent. A ton of well cut and grilled seasoned lamb, with lettuce, tomato, cucumber and garlicy white sauce, in a soft, thick pita, wrapped in sandwich paper and aluminum foil. It was still hot and delicious when we got home. My son's chicken and rice was similarly loaded. He couldn't wait and scarfed it down in the car. 

Had Zara had room for vertical grills, shaved the meat off the spit, and set up a few picnic tables to permit dining on site, this would have been a full five star adventure. As it was it was pretty darn close. 

This one is worth going back to.

The "New & Improved" Village @ Newtown is slowly getting up to speed and opening the many restaurants that suddenly find this community simply irresistibly. Chipotle Mexican Grill is the latest to have its grand opening in the new complex across from McCaffrey's Supermarket. 

Luckily the parking lot was completed on time, too, so there is plenty of parking available for it now, and hopefully when the other five kitchens are open for business at the same time. Walking in, the room is smaller than anticipated, with several high communal tables for people to eat & run. It wasn't so busy when I was there around 3:30. The assembly line concept seemed efficient, but I was causing a slowdown by asking too many questions. I'm generally not a fan of this approach to dining, so I needed instruction on some of the basics. In the end, a carne asada burrito was delivered to me at the end of the line - stuffed with brown rice, pinto beans, carne asada, queso, avocado and a few other things. It was stuffed to the gills with sour cream on the side. I took it home somewhat concerned the whole thing would explode, it was packed so tight! 

It was a tasty package with so many things going on that it all blended together in my mouth. Definitely a four napkin meal. I enjoyed it, although I could only finish half. As two meals the $11 tag seemed quite reasonable. 

I can see what people like about Chipotle. It uses fresh ingredients, is basically healthy with a little self control, and you can fit it into a lunch hour. But, if authenticity in Mexican cuisine is paramount for you, this burrito was no where near as delicious as can be found in any good Casa Mexicana elsewhere in Bucks and Montgomery Counties, or across the river in Trenton. 

I wish them success in Newtown.

This review addresses two subjects; the BK App and the new Ch'King Chicken Sandwich. While the first lacks intuitive feel and is frustratingly obtuse, the later is a damned good attempt to compete with all the other clucker on brioche buns coming to fast food franchises around the country. 

The app offers many benefits not available to walk-in/drive-in customers. There are free Whoppers with first Ch'King purchases, discounted sides and drinks as "points" are accumulated, and surprise gifts with purchase on a regular basis. Today, it was vanilla soft-serve in a cone or cup when buying something of $3 or more price. So, there are pleasant upsides if you like the BK menu and can navigate the app. 

Easier said then done.

I found that the special offers didn't always appear on the app from use to use. It wasn't obvious, therefore, which deals were present, and which expired. I found myself repeatedly returning to the opening page as I tried to work my way through the process. I ultimately got the ordering completed with what I wanted, but the time waste was a pain in the butt. If not for my curiosity and persistence, I would have deleted the app and driven to Popeye's instead. 

Yet, it turned out that the new Ch'King standard chicken sandwich was very good (I left the free Whopper for my son to devour). The breast was plump, juicy, well breaded/fried, and all quite tasty. The brioche roll was fresh and held together to the last bite. The special sauce was the flavor of mild mayo,tartar, perhaps a bit of Sriracha, and the pickle slices pleasantly sour and crisp. The Sammy was so thick that my jaws couldn't open wide enough to fit it in for my incisors to clamp down,without squeezing it together and shimmying it back and forth to slowly gain necessary placement between my dents. 

I chose onion rings over fries, and thought they were a decent alternative, although more calories. 

This Ch'king falls just shy of the Popeye's version, but ahead of Chik Fil-A, Wendy's and McDonald's iterations in terms of taste, texture, composition and fun. Too, it is competitive with the smaller chicken shops like Lovebird, at a better price. For someone who prefers chicken to burgers as a protein source, this is clearly a reasonable and satisfying way to go.

To be honest, bubble tea is lost on me. I have tried it several times when thirsty walking around one Chinatown or another, but never really found it all that good. Usually too sweet, and those tapioca balls on the bottom were an unpleasant semi firm gooey tooth sticky choking hazard. I never understood the attraction. 

So, when Hi Tea Bar opened on State Street in Newtown it was surprising, but not particularly interesting to me. Yet, I passed it every day and the urge to Yelp about it eventually drove my curiosity. Longer story short, I stopped in today to check it out. 

Walking in (the front door opens outwards), the shop was narrow and deep with service area behind high wall on the right, and tables Covid-spaced along the left. It was a bit incongruous seeing only local high school girls behind the counter when all prior experience had been a totally Asian tone. I had a brief conversation with the cashier/order taker and sat down at an open table at the front window waiting for the Popcorn Chicken and Peach Green Tea to arrive. This would be my lunch today. 

The tea got there first, followed by a handled plastic bag with the chicken inside with plastic fork and small container of spicy dipping sauce. Not exactly an environmentally neutral package. Similarly, the peach green tea was in plastic, but very tasty and refreshing. I think they mixed liquid fruit extract in with the green iced tea. I really liked it alot. The chicken was cut in small pieces, coated in breadcrumbs and deep fried. As I didn't smell anything cooking, I guessed it was premade and heated in a microwave. Not soft/crunchy like popcorn, but still texturally satisfying, with decent flavor  enhanced by the dipping sauce, I was enjoying an interesting snack. 

Overall, a pretty good light meal and drink that differed greatly from standard American fare. Worthwhile even without the bubbles. 

When Covid is over, Hi Tea Bar management will hopefully be less wasteful with materials, but continue to create enjoyable teas, smoothies and snacks that will have a permanent place in our local economy, right in the heart of town.

Yes. I've seen the Original Dominick's Pizza (Shoppe) in Richboro for many years, but never had the urge to stop in before the other night.  I regret my oversight. 

In fact, Old Dom's is a very good restaurant hiding in disguise in the strip commercial development in the heart of Richboro.  What looks like a typical pizza parlor designed primarily for take out, is in fact a comfortable and attractive dining experience.  Just walk past the counter into the rear dining room, and be transported to a curbside café in Napoli.  Red tile roof, stucco walls, trellis, red checkered tablecloths, the smell of garlic and tomatoes. Yes, it is Disneyesque, but I can easily suspend my disbelief to allow the atmosphere to positively impact my dinner.  

It was a quiet night and I had my choice of tables.  My server was attentive and did not mind answering my first timer questions.  I wanted pasta, and ordered Penne Aglio Olio with Sautéed Spinach.  It came with a side salad, but not just a small plate of iceberg and a few veggies.  A large bowl of fresh Romaine, Plum Tomatoes, Shaved Carrots, Red Onion, and Balsamic was placed in front of me.  It was almost enough to be a meal by itself.  It was very good, and I placed it to the side when the main course arrived, so I could enjoy them together.  

The Penne was another large deep plate well mixed with Extra Virgin and Chopped Garlic.  The Spinach was fresh and sautéed whole leaf and piled nicely mid-plate.  Really well done.  All this for under $10. 

I can see how Original Dominick's has expanded and thrived.  Good food and good value. 

A powerful combo. No need to become the New Dom's.

Visiting a take out Chinese shop for an eat-in lunch is always a bit of a gamble.  

You never know what you are going to confront the first time walking in.  Will it be a dive with your shoes sticking to the floor, and the food indigestible?  Or, will the place have a pleasant personality and tone with decent grub given its inherent limitations?  

Very happy to report that China Wok is the later.  

The small space is clean and bright, with the owners/operators equally so.  The menu is adequate for both lunch and dinner, but as I was here in the afternoon for a late lunch, I went with the lunch specials.  Orange Chicken, Fried Rice and a drink (water) for a very reasonable price. 

Yes, it was served in its take out container, but in an interesting way.  It came on a tray with the take out menu opened fully to act like a placemat.  Pleasant alternative to just having the various folding boxes placed in front of me.  Too, the smile that accompanied the service was an unexpected bonus.  Could have used a spoon along with the skinny plastic fork, but why quibble? 

The meal was on the high end for cheap Chinese walk away.  The Chicken was not heavily coated, and it appeared it had not been frozen for long, if at all.  It was soft and pliant without that freezer burn toughness so often present.  The sauce was properly piquant with slices of Orange Peel and Red Szechuan Chili throughout.  The Fried Rice was decent with small chunks of pork and veggies. 

All in all, a surprisingly good meal.  While it would never be confused with fine dining, it was certainly substantial enough without the obvious pitfalls of fast Chinese, that it is worth another visit.

This is another of those Yelp doubles, that have more than one entry for the same business.  The other, Original Dominick's Pizza Shoppe, has a few more reviews.  The confusion lies in the addresses.  The number on the front door is 1045, the address for the "Pizza Shoppe" page.  1067 is given as the address for ODP, but that number is not on the door.  

Until that is straightened out, just check out both pages for a full display of reviews, tips and photos. 

Mange bien!

When I walked in my first reaction was, "Wow! This looks way different than Cosi. Very colorful, light and airy, and lots of smiling faces behind the counter."  

I had the Chicken Salad Pita Sandwich with a side of Grilled White Beans, which was really a thick bean soup.  Everything was fresh, if not totally original or outstanding in composition and taste.  It was very satisfying, and warrants a return visit to check out more items on the menu.

The manager came over to chat with us.  She was warm and engaging, and explained that part of the Zoes corporate culture was to contribute to the community.  She asked us to think of them when we needed donations of food for a good cause.  It seemed that it was too busy a place for meetings in a quiet corner, but the offer was well received here. 

Zoes seems to be a very positive addition to Newtown's Sycamore Street core, and with the many alternative food outlets right there, it will help draw more people to the area when they are looking for a good meal in a great location. 

Good luck, Zoe.

Didn't start off heading for Perfetto's Pizza, but when Chester's Halal Fried Chicken was closed for prayer Friday afternoon, I ended up across Lalor Street at this outwardly dumpy looking pizza joint. 

I was wrong to judge a pizzeria by its cover.  Turns out that Perfetto's is bigger than it looks, with a dining room in back, counter service in front, and a comprehensive menu.  

I sat down in the dining area (where it was warmer), alongside some of Trenton's finest.  I didn't want pizza, so ordered the lunch sized Penne with Broccoli, Garlic and Oil.  I asked for the garlic to be very well done.  The lunch came with choice of soup or salad, and a basket of home baked bread.  

The platter arrived overflowing with Broccoli and Penne.  The Garlic was thin sliced, golden and ubiquitous. A little grated Romano and ground Pepper, and I was in business.  It tasted great!  The Salad with Balsamic was adequate, but not memorable, and the bread, while warm, was basically pizza dough shaped into a half loaf. It would have been better flat and covered with red gravy and cheese.  

The service was friendly, bilingual, and perhaps a bit slow due to the dining room being out of sight of the front cashier and kitchen door.  Still, at $7.50 for a full meal with take home extras, I was pleased with finding Perfetto's.

Perfetto's was not perfect, but had its moments of grandeur.

MARCH 3, 2015 UPDATE: Returned today and had Cavatelli Spinach and a Bowl of Chicken Veggie Soup.  The Soup was loaded with soft Chicken, Onions, Celery and Carrots, and the Cavatelli was a full platter of well sautéed spinach with plenty of golden garlic.  Impressive lunch for $7.95!
