UPDATE: MARCH 6, 3018 - Perfetto's is really making a statement now. The house was near capacity today @1:30. Far busier than last time I was here about two years ago. Still a better than average kitchen with a real bargain for lunch - almost a dinner size meal, now at $8.50. My penne aglio olio with broccoli was a heavy load, without skimp. Salad still needs an upgrade from iceberg, but otherwise, this joint is one of the best deals in town.

The New Madison Restaurant sits in an old strip of stores on Vets Highway in Levittown.  It is one of several around this part of Bucks County, developed to bring commercial opportunity and convenience to the new "suburbs" being created by Mr. Levitt.  As such it is living history.  

Madison sits in the middle of all this 70 year old Americana.  Its interior is in the luncheonette style food dispensary, which adds to its authenticity and comfort.  It feels like you could easily sit down with your parents and grandparents at one of the booths for a $.75 meal. 

Alone, I chose the old fashioned counter where I could alternate between eating, reading and chatting with the staff.  Here, that is a special pleasure because all the women were warm and attractive. Christine served me with a smile and friendly banter as sweet as the syrup on my French Toast.  Lori was equally engaging, and betrothed to Dean, the owner. I met him when he sat down at the counter to chat with another customer. Cool dude.

My breakfast was solid.  The coffee flowed freely, and the FT was made of "Texas Toast," well egged and grilled.  Even the Turkey Sausage was more than expected (4 links) and good tasting.  I asked for a drop of Vanilla in the egg mix, but there was none in the kitchen. Regardless, it still was very good.

Rumor has it that New Madison may have a sibling in Langhorne soon.  Stay tuned for an important announcement.  

I am saving the 5th Star for credit card convenience.

I've been to Tina's twice (not counting the visit to the bagel side of the building).  The first visit was to try their pizza.  I had a slice of Old Style Brooklyn Pie and one of Regular Pizza.  

While the Brooklyn effort was excellent, with robust sauce, fresh basil and a lively crunchy crust, the Regular slice was just average.  Part of the problem was the while the oven time was sufficient for the thinner crust Brooklyn to be completely reheated, the standard pie had a thicker crust and it did not heat up to the proper temp, leaving the bite soft and thick, rather than firm and cracker firm.  That is just a matter of the kitchen knowing what the oven can do and how long it takes to do it. 

My second visit last week went with the Italian Hot Dog on the recommendation of the server, (another Tina, I believe).  These creations were born in Trenton about a generation ago (the dearly departed Casino on Anderson St., and its sibling, Tony Goes).  This bambino was amazingly great!  It was loaded with Green Frying Peppers, and large, chunky Hash Brown Potatoes that were grilled to a nice brown firm edge.  Each bite sliced through the fresh Italian Torpedo, Crunchy Potato, Pepper, Red Pepper and finally the Frankfurter. Heinz Ketchup and French's Mustard were on the table.  It was so big, it could have been two meals. The lunch also came with a cup of soup (Chicken Noodle was homemade and tasty.) 

With very good bagels, too, Tina's is a good destination for breakfast or lunch. They bring an extra ingredient to their menu - imagination.

One of my regular stops while in Tucson for the gem and stone extravaganza in late January every year is Miss Saigon (Yes. I've seen the play). It is another of the North Campbell Avenue string of pearl restaurants that I found and stuck with over many years.  

The shop is comfortably designed with a relaxed Asian décor.  The staff is warm and usually prompt in that offhand attentive way we all know.  The menu is simple and everything I have tried has been solidly satisfying.  

My choices tend to be the same each year, as I obviously can't get there often.  An order of Spring Rolls (Shrimp, Pork, Greens, Noodles in translucent Rice Paper), Mixed Wok Veggies with Tofu in Ginger Sauce, and one of several great Pho alternatives. My young son, as always the genuine food critic, came to love their Chicken Wings, Orange Chicken, and eventually, the Pho Ga. All these dishes have been enjoyable and strong enough to induce some loyalty.  

Yes. I have eaten equally good Vietnamese cuisine elsewhere in the USA, but it is great to know I don't have to give anything away when I want some in Tucson.

On a warm Spring day there are few places that are better for sitting in the fresh air and watching the world go by than the veranda of Havana.  If it is approaching mid summer, it almost reminds of its namesake in Cuba.  

When we stopped in for lunch yesterday after concluding our business in nearby Lahaska, we all marveled at the perfection of the moment.  Havana contributed to the occasion by providing drink and victuals to our liking, with friendly efficient service.  I split a Panini Cubano and Side Salad, both of which were very good.  The grilled sandy contained BBQ Pork, and Mild Cheese between the fresh large format bread.  The Side Salad was full of lively greens, reds, purples and yellows in a variety of shapes and a pleasantly spiced dressing.  The accompanying Fries were the thicker crunchy type, and not really necessary given the rest of the meal.  

The other companions were also content, and we lingered a while, slowly finishing our drinks and conversations while we enjoyed the breeze created by the nearby Delaware River and the surrounding hills.  

While I cannot speak to the nightside of Havana nor New Hope here, it is a wonderful spot for a leisurely lunch on a warm Friday afternoon in late May.

Established in 1919, this family owned/operated German style bakery sits in a small strip center between Easton and Davisville Roads in Willow Grove, Pa.  The Vietnamese restaurant, Pho & Beyond is right next door, and a convenient neighbor to have if dessert apres noodle soup is your sweet desire.  

The space includes two storefronts, and is bright and cheery.  The staff dresses the part of bakers and assistants, with white coats and hats.  With all the goodies in displays, and glass walls permitting a look at the actual creation of the cookies, cakes, scones, petit fours, and cupcakes, Weinrich's is all about seduction and temptation.  In that it succeeds quite well.  It was next to impossible not to want to sample a little of everything in sight, especially when they offered me a petit four as a first timer.  That was small and delicious, and set everything that happened next into motion.  

Just had a get a half dozen cupcakes (Raspberry Cream, Caramel Cream, and Lemon Cream), and the same number of the freshly baked and glazed donuts.  A small bag of scones were thrown in for good measure.  

Everything was very good to excellent.  The cake bottoms were firm enough to hold the top load easily.  Each cupcake was injected with the cream of choice, right down to the bottom of the base. The icing was soft with subtle flavor, rather than the hard topping found in many shops.  The donuts were more the standard variety, with Red Velvet and Vanilla cake style, as well as traditional glazed and French Cruller alternatives.  All dipped in vanilla glaze icing, they were less enchanting as their texture, touch and taste were not so unique from the more mass produced options found elsewhere.  The scones were raisined, and had a mild sweetness.  

There was far more in this shop than could be sampled or purchased in one visit.  I am not a bakery cookie guy, preferring home baked to almost anything that can be made in quantity, yet given what I've just tried, Weinrich's is certainly worth several returns to get hands and tongue into the rest of this cookie jar.

Zook's BBQ Barn is in the corner of the Newtown Farmers' Market, and operated by Amish folks in full dress and accents.  The market is only open Thursday thru Saturday, so plan accordingly.

The BBQ is excellent across the board.  From pork, chicken, and beef, through many vegetables, the most notable of which are the carrots, yams, and red potatoes.  As noted in the other reviews, the approach to BBQ is different than the better known rub cuisines of Texas, Memphis, North Carolina, etc.  Here the meat is smoked first until it is tender and falling off the bone.  Then it is mixed with a variety of delicious, tangy sauces and allowed to steep until the meat and sauce merge and something completely new is created.  

I have purchased the whole chickens in the past, and they were very good. Perfect for a family dinner with a few of the original side dishes.  These days, I am more lunch oriented, and go for the pulled meat sandwiches and veggies.  The Pulled Pork is excellent, and the Pulled BBQ Ribs are so succulent I hate to swallow and lose the flavor orgy in my mouth.  Beware small bones. 

The lunch special is one of the BBQ meats on a fresh roll and a side dish of your choice.  The prices run from $6 to $8 for the meal. You need to ask for napkins and a fork, as they are not routinely thrown into the bag.  

All in all a great alternative for lunch, not to mention the overall curiosity of walking around the market and being tempted by everything else being offered by the vendors. 

The only complaint is the general lack of cleanliness in the market. I guess that is why Zook's is called a "Barn."

Rosa's is tucked away in a tiny 4 store strip center just off North Campbell, and very easy to miss. But, it is worth finding.  

The family run enterprise is a staple of Tucson, dishing out very good South of the Border plates at reasonable prices.  It is one of those few shops I always return to when in town for the gem show extravaganza in late January/early February.  There is usually a short wait for a table, as the space is small and a tight squeeze.  

The food is decent, if not haute cuisine, and quite tasty and filling. A couple of margaritas or cervesas after a long day looking at hot rocks is the best way to begin the chill down.  The service can be erratic, but they make up for it with attitude and good humor.  

One of the best things they have is a wall full of calendars for purchase with classic Mexican art the prime selling attraction.  I love hanging one on my office wall as a recollection of my time in Tucson, and Rosa's colorful hospitality.

In order to beat the morning traffic last week, I decided to spend the night at The Latham Hotel on 17th Street, and meet with visiting nephew, niece and baby-neph for breakfast the next day.  

Brilliant, if I don't say so myself!

Everything from the online reservations, front desk, room, to valet parking was first rate.  I remembered being here maybe 15 years ago, when the place had slipped into a less than optimal condition, but the new version is just fine.  

I loved my 5th floor corner room.  It was New York small, but clean and very comfortable.  My windows overlooked both 17th Street and the Philadelphia Baptist Church, whose spires filled up one window with an old-Europe sensibility.  I actually moved the HDTV out of the way so I could see it more clearly and take photos.  The bed was firm and I had way too many pillow choices.  Plenty of hot water and pressure in the morning rush times.  

The only issue I had was with the parking.  While the valet is convenient, at $39 per night, it is expensive.  It would be better if upon reserving a room, the hotel provided detailed information on parking options (location, cost, in/out), and allowed the customer the ability to prepare in advance for using self parking down the street.  It might only save a fin or two, but having preferences honored is what good guest services is all about.  

I would certainly stay at The Latham again.  This is a great spot in Center City, just off Rittenhouse Square, with plenty of streetlife for everyone's taste and habits.

Great to have another Greek house in the area! 

Greek Corner moved in about three months ago, and is still getting things settled.  Their menu is for breakfast, lunch and dinner, and offers cuisine from the Agean, as well as curtsies to the American palate with pizza and burgers.  They have not yet installed any spits for the roasting of the lamb-beef mix that goes in the traditional gyro, but grilling it on the griddle seems to do the trick quite nicely in the meantime.  

The place is a former pizza parlor, and the basic elements remain unchanged.  Booths and tables along the walls and down the middle of the floor, counter and table service, and refrigeration units with drinks.  The women working there seem to be part of the family that owns the business.  They are friendly, and happy to see new customers.  They were willing to allow me to taste the Avolemono Soup to see if I liked it, without requiring the purchase of the large bowl.  That gesture won me over.  It was quite good, by the way, although thinner than the thick creamy version found at Mikonos in Ewing.  

My Traditional Gyro Sandwich was a stuffed hot pita, full of nicely browned strips of lamb/beef mix, and a heavy Tzatziki Sauce, whose cool dillness played well with the hot spicy meat.  Shreds of lettuce were also wrapped inside.  The whole thing was delivered, held together tightly with thin paper, and a pile of French Fries finished the plate.  My request for a glass of cold water with lemon was replied to with a large pitcher full of ice and lime wedges.  Nice touch! 

Greek Corner is only minutes from the office.  Very happy to have this lunch option so close at hand.

The County Theater appears to be the only cinema in Bucks to show independent and limited distribution films.  For that it has my appreciation.  I certainly wish the Newtown Theater, the oldest in the country, had the same policy.  The digital projection is a big plus. 

I was there last Sunday for a 4:00 pm show, and it was packed. Not an empty seat in the house! Applause to the members and others who take interest in this institution, as it makes it a  fine community resource. 

If there is any downside (and I hesitate to mention it), it is that when crowded, the seats are a bit cramped, and not as comfortable as the "big house" theaters. Too, sometimes you get some attitude from the regulars who have their favorite seats, and refuse to move over to make room for another couple, forcing them to sit apart. Not much the theater can do about that. 

Over all, a wonderful piece of Bucks cultural heritage alive and well today.

My orientation seems to have opened a portal to the West, and I have found myself driving through and around Wayne, Pa. recently.  Nice area. Last week I decided to slow down and smell the chili.  Found Ping Pong on my trusty Yelp mobile guide, and stopped in with son of mine for dinner. 

First impressions were positive.  Clean, bright, colorful, smiling faces, pleasant aromas. We took a table along the wall and as I looked around I realized we were in a Chinese spice shop where the dishes would be measured in fire alarms.  My favorite cuisine, but not necessarily in my 13 year old's wheelhouse.  He loves Dumplings, so we went with an order of 6 fried.  I suggested we get Dan Dan Noodles so he could begin to appreciate the more gentle side of the firescale.  He was game for the Hunan Spicy Beef; a good, adventurous call.  I picked the Deep Fried Chicken with Dry Pepper, basically a spicy fried chicken dish he could assimilate.  

All were very good to near excellent.  The Dumplings were perhaps the least interesting with a heavy dough shell, but well ground pork, and nice dipping sauce.  He actually left one behind.  The Dan Dan's were a big bowl full of thin noodles and a hearty pork sauce that completely covered the noodles beneath.  I had to add extra Sesame Oil to reach the desired heat, but my son was happy with them as delivered.  All gone!  The Spicy Hunan Beef was the best of the bunch - tender sliced beef in a mid-range Hunan brown sauce, Broccoli, Green and Red Chilis and a few other veggies.  Very good.  The Chicken was slightly hotter and quite tasty, but not the "chicken inferno" I had anticipated from other Szechuanese joints.  Still, just right for the initiat.  

Service was timely and cordial.  The majority of the customers were Chinese, but no one seemed to mind two round eyes in their midst.  Besides, we both knew how to handle the chopsticks with aplomb.  

All in all, an enjoyable repast, and one that I would certainly entertain returning to on one of my increasingly frequent trips west.  

A very nice find, indeed!

For a small regional airport, Trenton-Mercer has a lot going for it.

First, it has contracts with Frontier and Allegiant airlines for service along the east coast and Florida, as well west to Chicago and Detroit. These are discount airlines, so if you fly light the fares will make you smile. 

Second, although parking is no longer free, it is only $8 for 24 hours, in a secure lot right in front of the terminal. Park and walk right through TSA check, across the tarmac, up the stairs onto your plane. Try any of that at an international airport to the north or south. 

Third, Enterprise, National, Avis and Budget have rental facilities here, and the rates are without all the extra airport fees and taxes. I have rented here twice when I needed a larger people mover for a day. Admittedly, I booked through Priceline and didn't have to deal with the rent a car games. 

Fourth, the amenities are minimal, but it is a public place owned by the people of Mercer County. Think of it as a park with landing privileges. They didn't want their taxes used for first class lounges. It is seldom crowded, and the bar/restaurant Sky Lounge offers the basics for three meals and decent drink choice. You can snack and chill watching flights take off and land through the large window overlooking the runway. When was the last time you did that? 

Fifth, flying lessons are available from private instructors with offices around the airport. 

Sixth, living ten minutes from the terminal makes TTN part of the community, and too convenient to pass up.

Seventh, TTN has been in business since 1929, and the enterprises around the airport played an important role in WW II, and it is the home of many Fortune 500 private jets. Amelia Earhart even flew through here. 

So, next time you consider flying from Trenton, maybe give yourself some extra time to explore the area. Several good bars and restos with a few minutes drive to help you on your journey.

I don't remember why Meglio's fell off my "Go To" list a few years ago, but when I drove by it last week I realized I had not been there in quite some time.  Maybe it was the new competition in Newtown that led me to other outlets for my pizza and cheesesteak fix. Maybe it was the sameness of the offerings.  Regardless, it was time for a return visit. 

So, I went back for lunch a few days ago.  The space is about the same, with the wood oven on the left, and the dining room on the right.  The table layout remained the same with mostly deuces and quads around the room.  At 1, the place was buzzing.  A few business lunches, and some post-yoga cool downs.  The menu was all about pizza, cheesesteaks and salads at lunch, although the few dinner entres looked appealing.  The prices were surprisingly reasonable.  It was possible to get out for under $10 @ lunch, perhaps because the shop was in an older strip center and the rent is decent. 

To ease my way back into their kitchen, I ordered a Chicken Cheesesteak with Fried Onions.  It arrived a few minutes later loaded with the prime ingredients.  The roll was soft, but fresh and pliant.  The amount of chicken in the sandy was enormous, and with the cheese and onions was a lot to eat.  The biggest pleasant surprise was how juicy it was.  It had been taken from the grill in time to avoid dryness, and the onions complemented the meat and cheese well.  I mentioned this to my lovely server, and she just smiled and said she had cooked it for me.  No reason to doubt her. 

I won't let another half decade go by without returning for more dishes.  Pizza comes next. 

However that turns out, I am definitely a fan of the Chicken Cheesesteak.

While the price of gasoline in Newtown seems to be higher than anywhere else in the surrounding area, the quality of the mechanics is also higher. 

Steele's Gulf is a very good option should your car need repair.  They are fast, reliable, and have integrity with their work.

Had a thoroughly enjoyable lunch at the Farnsworth House yesterday.  The classic barroom was empty but for my companion and I, and we had the house and service to ourselves.  

My French Onion Soup while in a smallish ceramic pot, was scalding hot, richly beefy stocked, thick with Onions, and sealed with a nutty Gruyere. The Pulled Pork Sandy was soft and mixed in a red BBQ Sauce that glazed the meat in its sticky pungence. There was a lot of it in that fresh roll which I opted to leave behind to shave a few calories off the meal.  Same with the large pile of French Fries that were good, but superfluous given the amply supply of Pork I was addressing.  My lunchmate didn't have any misgivings scooping them up and dipping them in her own excellent sauce covering the Veal A la Genoa she had ordered.  

I tried a few and must admit they could put that combo on the menu as a side. 

Spontaneous Poutine! 

Farnsworth House is an Italian kitchen these days, and a good one at that.  In all the great things that are happening in Bordentown, Mr. Farnsworth still holds his own.  

Even Bonaparte would find satisfaction here.

Nam Phuong was the last Empress of Vietnam.  

Perhaps, it is fitting to name the queen of the Vietnamese houses after her.  She was born too late to enjoy her royalty for very long, and she was denied the privilege of living her life in her native land; dying in relative obscurity in France.  

Her namesake is similar to her in some ways.  The restaurant is large and well run.  Chandeliers suggest a palatial guise, and the servers in black are disciplined, polite and respectful, as you would expect from a royal house. The menu is diverse to appeal to a variety of guests, and the kitchen is skilled in turning out top quality dishes that satisfy those invited to the Emperor's Table. 

Even a solitary traveler such as I was treated with dignified homage. Though a busy night full of families and intriguing couples, I was given a nice table, plenty of time to decide my meal, and graceful delivery, checking on satisfaction, pickup and an offer to desire more before leaving.  I never felt rush by the staff, although the people waiting by the door might have been less patient. 

My Pho with Round Steak and Tripe was excellent, with all fresh trimmings.  The broth was richly complex and a filling bowl at a very reasonable price.  The Summer Rolls were stuffed with fresh Shrimp and Ground Pork, and came with a very good Peanut Dipping Sauce.  As I ate I watched those around me enjoying all the things I wanted to try on my next visit.  

I am not sure that the maxim that a Vietnamese restaurant filled with Vietnamese is a true indication of great food all the time, but it certainly was tonight.  

Nam Phuong, where ever her spirit is now, would be pleased that her name is being so well cared for here in Philadelphia.

I started visiting Charcoal when it was also, "Steaks and Things," about 30 years ago. In those days I lived on the Delaware River in Trenton, and came over to Yardley for an out of the way weekend breakfast/brunch.  It was a great place for a romantic wake up after a long night before.  

Two massive floods and major grief later, a small riverside café has transformed into a full second story restaurant with an eastern wall of glass overlooking the river that when at peace is serenely beautiful, but when raised to anger is as dangerous as an angry rhino.  Sitting here today over a large white cup of java after an absence of more than a decade, I marveled at how light and airy this loft felt.  If you've spent time at the shore in a reverse living stilted home, you know the tree house sensation.

I was here for breakfast, and ordered the Brioche French Toast.  The room was not full, and I shared the space with various knots of people engaged in friendly conversation.  Being alone, I spoke with my server, Mary Anne, who was a natural salesperson for the establishment.  She updated me on ownership and changing cuisine, and even handed me a dinner menu to take with, hoping I would return to try some of the Small, Large, and Pasta Plates.  

Although the environment and dinner menu are 5 Star worthy, the French Toast while good, exhibited a mistake often made by shops attempting the "Thick" approach to this dish.  The Brioche was generously sliced, but not left in the egg mix long enough to allow it to penetrate to the center, leaving the middle a bit dry.  Too, the grill was not hot enough to caramelize the surface nooks and crannies to give it the light crunchiness and moist center that separates the good French Toast from the great.  

Looking around I noted some beautiful omelets and fresh fruit cups that hold promise. I will come back to check them out sometime soon.

What can you say about the complete, in your face, sweet, gooey, dripping down your chin, jelly donut experience? 
Great, right?
If you go for that, and fresh hot glazed burn your tongue goodness, then this is the place for you, and everyone else with a sweet tooth.
Forget the diet.
Go get some!!!

PS.  Personal fave - glazed raspberry jelly filled.
I see the light!

Lucy's Café sits on the first floor of 240 W. State Street, Trenton, NJ, across the street from the State Museum/Library Complex and the Department of Education.  It is nothing fancy, but does have room for a lot of people for sit down breakfasts and lunches.  Furniture is vinyl and steel.  

This morning I stopped in for breakfast for the first time.  There were only a few people there, and I was able to order directly from the cook.  I grabbed a small coffee and a table seat while waiting for the Sausage, Egg & Cheese Sandwich to be done.  When it was, the Korean owner of the shop called for me to pick it up and pay the $5 for everything.  Good price.

The sandwich was well made with a single patty, fried egg and American cheese on a fresh Kaiser roll.  A small side of home fries was included, and were nicely grilled with crisp edges.  A shake of black pepper and a squirt of ketchup and I retreated to my table to consume the beast.  The plate was Styrofoam and the fork, plastic.  Nothing fancy, but it was certainly substantial.  

The taste was very good owing to decent ingredients, and a knowing hand at the grill.  Coffee was that Law brand; not the best, but strong enough to chase the morning fatigue away.  

This stretch of West State Street is quiet in the summer when the legislature is out of session.  There is plenty of street parking available, making for easy in and out.  The parking meters eat quarters in 15 minute increments, so be prepared with enough to cover the time you plan to be inside.

Beautifully converted Lamberville, NJ mansion that offers three squares a day in a quiet, dignified house with plenty of space between the tables for intimate conversation surrounding very good victuals. All very late 19th Century. 

I was there for midweek breakfast and walked in to a mostly empty restaurant.  There is an attractive marble counter with stools, but it was loaded with desserts and didn't seem the place designed to really eat. So, I walked to the next dining room, where there was one other table occupied, but so far across the room that I felt totally alone taking a smaller deuce along the opposite wall facing a window.  

Each table in this room was rough cut from a larger tree trunk and finished with smooth top, but the edges left rough. Beautiful. I'd love one for home. 

The menu is fairly small for the morning meal, and pricing is oriented toward higher end cafes, rather than more reasonable primarily breakfast joints. Still, my turkey sausage, fried egg and cheddar on an unusually attractive and tasty roll, reflected the gourmand focus.  Execution was superlative.  My server incorporated my choice for "lightly runny" eggs with aplomb. That is exactly what I got. Coffee from Counter Culture. Not sure why they don't use java from local roasters better than this North Carolina outfit given the trend toward local sourcing. Still, it was solid Joe, refilled gracefully as needed. 

Nothing run of the mill about Café Galleria. If you're into morning romantic interludes, this is the place.

Hurricane Jack's Bar & Restaurant on New Falls Road, Levittown, PA, is one of many divey sports bars in this end of Bucks County. On a Saturday afternoon it was busy, but not a full house, with primarily men watching the Phillies as they chugged their beer and smoked their cigs between running conversations about the game. Friendly, welcoming crowd (I was wearing my Eagles Super Bowl cap), they allowed me to jump into their party. 

I ordered a Sam Adams Seasonal and their Hurricane Special Burger (onions, hot pepps, provolone), medium. The ale was wet and refreshing; the sandwich large and tasty, despite the slippage into well done territory. Couldn't open my jaws wide enough to bite down on it, so I approached with knife and fork. Still juicy even with freezer time, and we'll worth the $6.95. Hurricane also does homemade potato chips as a side with the burgers. They were really good and well peppered, making the optional fries unnecessary. The surprise star in a supporting role.

I hung out for a while after I was done eating to watch the end of the game, and enjoy the regulars. Even with the multitude of similar inviting taverns around Levittown, Hurricane Jack's is a great low budget watering hole to chill. 

Lots of choices are a good thing.

If a cozy country breakfast/brunch is your thing, then The Fancy Fig on Second Street Pike in Wrightstown, PA., is singing your song. Hidden in The Gathering, a small group of shops and offices in the heart of "downtown" Wrightstown, and cattycorner from Ralphie's Tavern at the intersection with Penn's Park Road, it may take a few minutes to find The Fig, but if you walk into what appears to be the inner courtyard, you will find it waiting there for you. 

Stepping inside the first impression is of a bakery or small deli with kitchen behind the wall, and dining area off to the right. I was greeted by my server, who invited me to sit anywhere.  There was a group of guys (and two priests) sitting at the largest table, so I moved past them and took a small table against the rear window.  Auspicious to have my morning meal blessed by the local clergy. I was brought a small laminated menu and the first cup of their locally roasted coffee.  

The java was joltingly strong and good, and I savored it as the chef put together my favorite breakfast sandwich. It arrived on a ciabatta roll, with egg and sausage links hanging over the edge. Didn't mind at all. They also offered a tiny square dish of fresh fruit, including one gigantic blackberry surrounded by watermelon and cantaloupe. It was all quite good. Fresh, locally sourced, and hot off the iron. Very good sammy!

The manager came over to inquire of my satisfaction. I gave her the right answer, and began a short conversation about the business and sources of their ingredients.  Most interestingly, the coffee beans were roasted in nearby New Jersey by a family member in the Joe business. "Crescent Moon" I think she said.  She suggested that the decaf was even better than the premium blend, so I requested a refill of that genre. She was right.  It had a more interesting flavor profile, but without the kick.  

The view from the window of the interior court area was peaceful on this Indian Summer morn. It made for a perfect setting to start the day.  Open for a year, The Fancy Fig is a cool spot to enjoy your morning over quality coffee and a solid homemade breakfast.

I was thinking "Mykonos" as we drove to Mikonos Restaurant on Scotch Road in Ewing, NJ.  The Aegean island is a place I hung out for a while in an earlier life, drinking Gerovasilliou and Agiorgitiko to excess in the harbor side tabernas by day and surrendering to the liltingly haunting Bouzoukis by night.  I couldn't share my reveries, but I wondered how close to my recollections this Greek house by the same name would come to those wild Hellonic daze. 

 It wasn't fair to even entertain the possibility that there would be any similarity; after all, that was life in a mystic age long gone from this coil.  Still, it did serve to awaken something long dormant, and while this is the age of dark cynicism, the place had enough pictures on the walls and aromas wafting through the room to allow for a moment of silent appreciation. Wine saturated memories are sometimes enough.

The food was pretty good, too.  

Our opening salvo of Avgo Lemono Soup was Star Dog Champion delicious. Creamy, Lemon bite, soft Chicken chunks, and Rice.  Our three spoons fought for each drop.  

The follow up for two of us was the tour de force Liga Apo Ola for 2, a huge platter with ample Moussaka, Spanakopeta, Pastitsio, Dolmades, and maybe something else I have forgotten, served with a metal spatula to aid in distribution.  They were all exceptional, although the Stuffed Grape Leaves had more  dry rice filling than I recall from past experiences.  My guests had never eaten Greek cuisine before, and they were so impressed that they tried to duplicate the Lemon Soup at home the next day.  

Our third member ordered a Chicken Souvlaki Platter.  It looked great (see photo), but my taste of the chicken surprised me with the strange toughness of the meat.  He gamely ate everything, but I could tell he was struggling with it.  A large slab of Moussaka from our plate was the least we could do to help him out. 

But for that last bit of news, this was a 5 Star dinner.  We will return in due course for the Avgo Lemono and further exploration of the menu.  Those Gyros that went by looked amazing!

I finally made it to Felix's Caketeria on Christmas Eve and purchased a dozen of their unique creations to bring to the family celebration.  

Walking in I was first impressed with the warm aromatic shop.  The display case is stocked with an amazing assortment of cupcakes and their bigger siblings that can be baked for weddings and other occasions. Everything was colorful and shining.  The staff was warm and professional and clearly proud of their work, as they should be.  I had no real idea which varieties to select, so I asked the charming woman behind the counter to do it for me, and she obliged.  She even offered to hand write a cheat sheet so I wouldn't forget what I had.   She alerted me that the shop was not "nut free."  Good catch as one of the young nephews has a serious peanut allergy.  The cupcakes were $3/ and $33/doz.  At first I was a bit taken aback by the price, but as I examined the products I realized that I would never do that much detail work for so little compensation.  So, I walked out with two plastic containers especially formed to hold 6 of those sweet babies each.  

Now, I admit to not being a Cupcake kind of guy - if sweets are my undoing, they will be donuts and homemade cookies and pies.  So, while I marveled at the creative names and imagined the richness of the buttercream icing, I did not really know what to expect.  When I arrived in western Pennsylvania 5 hours later with my contribution to the dessert table I was surprised to watch the women in the family stop what they were doing and "kvell" over them.  They actually began to negotiate with each other over which delight they wanted, or were willing to share.  The other fresh-out-of-the-oven pumpkin and pecan pies, plates full of cookies, etc., were momentarily forgotten in their lust for these petite morsels of lathered dough in paper dresses.  Some were even taken aside and hidden in the cupboard; staking an absolute claim.  

After sating ourselves over a great meal in the Allegheny Mountains, we finally reached dessert time.  The Oreo, Gingerbread Cheesecake, Chocolate Dirt, Tiramisu, and Lemon Drop sacrificed themselves first.  But, they were not devoured, but savored with each mini spoonful.  Eyes rolled and gasps of rapture escaped lips.  I selected a Carrot Cake plump tarte.  It was exactly like a great full size carrot cake with the creamiest, yet not overly sweet, icing imaginable.  Yes. I rubbed my fingers over the plate where it sat after ravishing its body to enjoy every molecule.  Mixed with fresh brew kaffe it was the perfect ending to a wonderful afternoon and meal in Westmoreland County.  For a few minutes the talk shifted from hunting to the more refined world of tiny cakes in tight skirts.  

I did hear a few less than sterling comments on one or two of them, but nothing to seriously detract from an otherwise otherworldly experience. 

Merry Christmas to all, especially those I have come to know and appreciate on Yelp.  Have a cupcake and reflect on all that is right in your lives.

Steele's Gulf and Steele Rick Service Station are the same place. Yelp should combine them.

This is an honest repair shop, with a family that has an excellent reputation for reliability and good communication with its customers.

The addiction has not improved, and if anything it has gotten worse. 

Turns out, KK has a fundraising plan that allows the purchase of a larger quantity of their sinfully outrageous donuts to non-profits doing fundraising for their organizations at a nice discount. I guess that helps salve the gluttonous conscience when participating with your church or scout troops, but ordering most of the donuts for yourself.  The thought of someone else eating your donuts is just too much to bear.  

May as well man-up and accept the fact that the crack they put in the donut fillings and glaze is overwhelming you, and that a stint in an in-patient addiction center is the only way to deal with this monster habit.  

A hot cup of coffee to help wash them down is a solid second option.

There are two entries for this establishment for some reason. 

Be sure to check them both to catch all the reviews.

OCI Bar & Grill is off the beaten path along Neshaminy Creek in Hulmeville, PA. I thought I was in the wrong place on a narrow winding road until I saw the actual building in front of me. It feels a little like Middle Earth, yet the joint is cozy and dim with a nice size bar and several TVs showing sports (The Preakness was on while we were there). 

We were there for the "Make Your Own Burgers," and after settling in on a 4 stool hightop, we found the forms to be completed and the little golf pencils, and went to work. The process was to check off choice of meat, cheese, condiments and accompaniments (some free, some not), and the roll desired. Base price is $9.99, but with upgrades the price can jump a few bucks. Fresh cut fries are also available for an extra $2. I went with what I though was a patty melt (onions, spicy mayo and swiss cheese on Jewish rye), while son opted for sautéed shrooms and red peppers on brioche.  

Although we both asked for a medium finish, the pucks were more medium well, without pink centers. Regardless, they were both juicy and delicious, with no sign of freezer life. Really very good. The only downside, and this could be on me for thinking the kitchen knew what the Jewish rye was for, was that what I got rather than a Patty Melt was a burger on plain, ungrilled bread. It just didn't work without a crisp bite to the rye from time on the hot steel.  I kicked the slices to the curb and ate everything else. Next time, I will specify the bread should be grilled. The fries came in a small deep fry stainless basket and were also quite good. 

Despite those issues, OCI is a cool place to hang out. Prices are good, and once the kinks are worked out, the kitchen should turn out quality dishes. They are on the right track.

If you're looking for a large college oriented sports bar with lots of room, loud ambient noise, and a decent menu, Landmark Americana just may be what you are searching for. Right off the campus of The College of New Jersey in the new Campus Town commercial center, this place has room for hundreds in a boisterous barroom with rectangular bar, and slightly less obstreperous dining area.

 I was there for a light bite supper while being entertained by the Saturday late afternoon/evening NFL playoff game.  In this place, the college basketball contest between Kansas and Iowa State was getting a lot more attention. I guess that's to be expected in a campus hangout with its own team. 

I caught the end of the weekend happy hour, and grabbed a pint of Sam Adams Boston Lager for $3. I also ordered a bowl of Baked Onion Soup and their Brussel Sprouts app.  The soupe aux oignons was a small bowl with all the right ingredients, and melted gruyere all around the lip. It was pretty good, and most importantly, hot, on that cool rainy eve.  The choux de Bruxelles were halved, broiled and doused in a tart vinaigrette and bacon bits. There were a lot of them. Very tasty and an excellent choice, if I don't say so myself. 

While my college days are mostly behind me (my son will be a freshman in September), I can still enjoy the high energy exuberance and animal spirits loose in the chamber. With an extended happy hour and better than average sports bar kitchen, this joint has a chance to succeed and see me again.

If mid-20th Century stainless steel railroad car diners are your thing, then Daddypops on York Road in Hatboro, PA, is a "must see" stop on your diner tour.  It sits on the main street in town, all shiny and bright over all these years. The granite counter is split by the kitchen entrance, with a half dozen spinners on each side, and creatively anchored at each elbow by an old barber's chair.  The outer wall is all booths and large windows. The joint oozes Americana charm. 

The menu consists of one sheet, with breakfast on one side, and lunch on the other. Best to plan early meals, as the hours are only from 6:00 AM to 2:00 PM. I sat at the far left counter where I could see the entire dining area.  The two women working the floor were friendly, but respectful - no one called me, "Honey." They were efficient, and ever ready with a hot coffee pour. I sipped my java while awaiting the arrival of my french toast. 

The three bisected thick slices of brioche were served on an oval plate that barely contained its load.  Side dish full of butter cups and Kraft syrup was close at hand for proper doctoring.  I could see that the bread had bathed in the egg/vanilla mix long enough to soak through to the core. The surface was nicely caramelized with enough crispy edges to provide the texture I like.  Allowing time for the butter to melt and run, and the syrup to absorb, I was quickly ready to dive in.  

It was very good.  

No dry spots.  No eggy extrusions. No scorch marks. Nothing fancy at this traditional meal hall. Just perfectly finished egg toast fry that was a pleasure to consume. Old fashioned, just like the house it was made in.

Golden One is a new Chinese American kitchen just behind Neshaminy Mall in the same center as DMV. It is a large room with well spaced tables and a fast takeaway operation. The menu is extensive and they do have a sushi guy slicing and wrapping seaweed. 

My first impression was positive for a simple Egg Foo Young plate with Egg Roll, Wonton Soup and white rice. The base stock for the soup was chicken broth that was not too salty and had decent wonton/dumplings that were not thick skinned, nor with questionable meat filling. The egg roll was even better with adequate roast pork mixed with cabbage and a few greens. The EFY was two pancakes filled with more pork and veggies and a better than average brown sauce that seems to have been prepared just in time. 

Overall, I liked this meal on their Combination menu for dinner. I particularly appreciated the absence of obligatory broccoli florets, which is way overdone by most Chinese restaurants. 

The house being clean with friendly service was also a pleasant positive touch. 

Yes. I grade these places on a curve.

Found in the Fareway Market on Germantown Avenue, Chestnut Hill, Poppy's Cafe is a cubbyhole of a shop dealing in good coffee and a few sweet cookie and sliced pound cake to keep their cash register ringing up sales. 

The multigenerational family running the business is friendly and knowledgeable about their products, and seem to enjoy spreading their information to those customers who ask. 

I chowed on a fresh chunk of vanilla iced pounder, washed down by a medium roast java lightened with milk. Very pleasant combo for the drive home.

Ateethi has nothing to do with mastication, although it may seem that way from its name. Rather, it is a hybrid North and South Indian kitchen in an old commercial strip at the corner of Grant Avenue and Krewstown Road in Northeast Philadelphia, very close by Bustleton. 

It opens at 5:00 pm for dinner most days, so we found ourselves waiting for the flag to go up when we arrived a few minutes early in advance of scheduled foot massage nearby @6. Looking around we saw about twenty basic tables and metal framed chairs in a dimly lit room, with a large mural of the Taj Mahal on the back wall.  The orange tones and low wattage bulbs made for a rather dim perspective. But, our eyes adjusted and the menu became legible and was fairly extensive in its offerings.  Because there were Indo-Chinese dishes, we headed in that direction as it crossed many of our tastebud preferences, and it is not as readily available in most Indian shops. 

Starting with Gobi Manchurian as an app, we received a long rectangular platter of cauliflower florets, onion and peppers in a heavy dark ruby chili sauce.  The veggies had a thin breading and had been fried enough to permit the outer shell to be somewhat crispy, while the heavy sauce held many spicy secrets that made our palettes shout for joy.  As entrees we had Chilli Chicken and their Baingan Bharta (mashed eggplant), and garlic naan to soak up every drop of sauce left on the plates. We discovered that the Manchurian sauce on the cauliflower was basically the same as the Chilli used with the chicken. Both were very good, but no need for both on the same night. Perhaps, they should use the same name to eliminate this confusion. The Bharta was extra hot, and delicious enough to make my nose run. Glad I had that extra napkin!

This was a very good and tasty Indian meal. Prices were good, too. We would definitely return to discover more about their offerings, especially the vegetarian options.  Services was informative and efficient, if not overly friendly.

This place took me by surprise. 

Yeah. The reviews were pretty good, but a bagel joint on the ass-end of Hamilton Avenue?  I just wasn't sure anything amazing was possible.  Still, I found myself heading that way one morning this week, I was hungry, and Yelp Mobile alerted me that Bagel Stop was just ahead.  

I didn't know if I would be able to sit down or the place was strictly take away.  That question was answered quickly when I opened the door and found myself in a tiny shop the size of my walk in closet.  Smelled very good.  Friendly faces all around.  Bagel bins in front of me singing their siren song.  

I ordered my trusty Onion, Butter and Swiss, not toasted.  Four minutes later it was made, bagged and ready for payment.  Bagel and large coffee for under $4?! Surely you jest.  

Sat in my car and opened the bag after taking a swig of java.  The bagel wasn't the biggest rounder I'd ever seen, but it had lots of Onion Flakes and a nice aroma.  First Bite Experience was amazing. The crust was firm, but giving.  The inner texture light and airy, allowing the onion/butter/Swiss mix to play its nutty sweet flavors on my palate.  

This was an exemplary bagel.  Almost at the level of Bagel Train in Yardley.  It was so similar that I wondered if Bagel Train and Bagel Stop had a common ancestry.  

A few more visits and I will know if I have discovered the holy grail of Jersey bagels.

Huong Tram is easy to miss, hiding in plain sight in a small commercial building surrounded by high chain link fences that make it look like a construction zone. Consider yourself fortunate to find it, because this house under new management has a strong Vietnamese kitchen and is large enough to seat a lot of people.  The servers in green shirts are attentive and for the most part bilingual.  They seem to enjoy their jobs, which is a sign that ownership cares about them and the quality of their interactions with customers.  

We stopped in after shopping down Washington Avenue, in need of some sustenance after stocking up on our Asian food supplies for the month.  We were in the mood for both Vietnamese and Chinese food, and found that they really did a good job on both.  

We ordered Wonton Noodle Soup, their Deluxe Fried Rice, and Sweet & Sour Chicken.  A little from column A, and more from column B.  The soup had the excellent flavor of a long simmering beef based pho.  It was rich with mildly spiced undertones, thin sliced steak, and a load of vermicelli noodles and wontons.  The side plate of accessories was put to good use to bring the taste up even more.  It was such a large bowl, that we were given a second smaller one without asking.  It came in handy as I slurped heartily from the secondary pot. Didn't even need any Sriracha. If there was any weakness it was the wontons, that while delicate lacked much filling and thus, taste. This kept it from being nearly perfect.  

The S/S Chicken was better than expected - crispy thin coating, tender white meat that did not have the texture of being frozen, and a thick tangy orange sauce, pineapple chunks and green peppers.  Liked it.  Finally, the House Deluxe Fried Rice was excellently made; moist and full of small caliber meats and veggies.  So good after too many Chinese take out mass produced fried rice sides.  This was the real deal.  

Huong Tram is another superior entry into the Vietnamese world around Washington Avenue.  Will definitely be back to dive into their soup and com (broken rice) offerings. Their smoothies look great, too!

Pho Saigon in the 6800 block of Bustleton Avenue in the Great Northeast of Philadelphia is a very good pho and com house that can save those of us who live farther from Center City than this location many miles of travel down to Washington Avenue, South Philly.  Parking is just about as bad in this developing Chinese/Vietnamese neighborhood, but you are more likely to find a spot on the street with a little patience. 

We took a table along the wall and appreciated the prompt service provided by staff.  Ordering pho tai nam (beef noodle soup with rare steak and flank), vermicelli with BBQ pork and summer rolls, we had more than we could finish for just slightly north of $20.  

The pho had a nice broth base with plenty of thin sliced steak and flank. Plenty of good slurping, but on the way home I began to feel a little off, like there could have been some MSG in the pot to hasten the reduction process. I am mildly allergic to that, and began to feel lightheaded shortly after departing. That is my deal, and many do not have that reaction. Still, the bowl was loaded with noodles. The small bowl was enough, even though the larger vessel was only a buck more.  The pork dish was excellent, however, with the meat a deep dark amber from its time marinating in the BBQ sauce. It was chewy in a good way as it slowly released its smoky sweet flavor with mastication. Again, plenty of dry noodles in the bowl, along with shredded carrot and ground peanuts.  A little fish sauce splashed over the top, and we were in business. The summer rolls were nothing special, but were certainly fresh, with a good peanut dipping sauce. 

I would return to Pho Saigon, but inquire about the MSG situation before ordering. 

This neighborhood has potential.

Vault Brewing Co., as the name suggests, sits in a former bank on Main Street, Yardley, Pa. 
It has been in operation for a while, and it really seems to have its act together when it comes to the art of brewing beer, and making interesting dishes in the kitchen.  It is often crowded at happy hour, but when I arrived for lunch with a friend, we had the entire vault room to ourselves, and the bar was not busy.  Sadly, because this was also a business lunch, we did not indulge in their golden liquids, but did enjoy their house made root beer.  

Service was very good, with knowledgeable and affable dude, who gave us the time needed to chat as we perused their menu.  I ordered the chicken sandwich, although the pizza offerings were tempting. The meal was served on a wood plank with side salad and balsamic dressing. The sourdough bread was lightly toasted/grilled, and the chicken, cheese, aioli and lettuce held together well, and tasted great.  The side salad was mostly green with romaine, escarole, carrot slivers and vinegar. It was okay.  Overall, it was a solid, tasty lunch.  With the root beer and tip it came to $22 per person, which is rich for my blood for a midweek lunch. 

Still, it was worthwhile to get inside Vault and appreciate how attractive it was in a dark wood, cloudy, kind of way. On this rainy afternoon, it exuded a quiet historic tone that was relaxing. It definitely calls for a return call, when there is time to enjoy their brewer's craft, and deconstruct one of their pizzas or other tapas.

Two Slices & Drink Review

Hidden Trenton, the underrated website that highlights the best of New Jersey's capital city, says that Jerry's Pizza has the best pie within the borders of this august urban jungle.  While this narrow focus eliminates all of the former greats that have moved out of town over the past decade, it is interesting to see what is considered today's best by another reputable source.  This website has led me to some excellent discoveries in the past. 

Sitting in the 700 block of South Broad Street, admittedly not the most savory stretch of America even by day, Jerry's lights up the area with plenty of color and pictures of food covering their windows.  Within, the shop is small, with room for only 4 booths, and a narrow shelf and 3 bar stools along the opposite wall.  The pizza ovens sit behind a glass counter, with the kitchen beside it.  Everyone is bilingual here, although the menu is strictly Italian.  

I checked out the pies on display and asked for slices of sausage and plain pizza.  I wanted them "well done," to bring them back to life - cheese bubbling and undercarriage scorched and firm.  That is exactly what I received.  The circumference was a very narrow band of exposed crust, while the rest was tomato sauce, cheese and crumbled pork sausage all around.  Big slices that emitted enough steam to fog my glasses and offer up an intoxicating aroma of garlic, tomato, basil and mozza.  A hearty shake of crushed red peppers and I was ready to chomp.  

The first slice (sausage) held its point pretty well, despite the extra weight topside.  I was able to first bite without aid of a second hand.  The crust was thin and crisp with a mild yeastiness.  The sauce tended to the salty side (especially given the meat), and the overall BCS (bite/chew/swallow) was quite pleasant.  While I prefer a sweeter sauce, this one did not bother me.  The chef knew from tomato gravy. 

The second slice had cooled a bit and needed a point lift to get into my mouth.  Not a real issue given how thin the crust was.  The overall taste and texture were also fine.  

I have no reason to doubt that Jerry's (my namesake) makes the best pizza in Trenton.  It was solid.  Whether it can compete with the Tomato Pie royalty in the greater Trenton area, is a story (and review) for another day.

Jerry's is worth a visit.

Stony Hill Kitchen is an immaculate breakfast lunch space in the Makefield Crossing Executive Center off Township Line Road, Lower Makefield, PA. Although the three buildings appear to have low occupancy these days, the cafeteria-like first floor space appears to be doing all right. 

Ordering is by digital screens and credit/debit card. Food prep is behind the counter or from a large salad bar set up in the middle of the floor. Seems pretty efficient. I was aware of its existence from Yelp, as well as its previous incarnations. After visiting PennMed across the road, I decided to go over and see what was going on. First impressions were positive, so I ordered a Farmers Omelet (veggies, cheddar) home fries, sourdough toast and La Colombe Java. It came to around none bucks, picked up at the service counter and eaten at one of their free tables. 

This was a 2 egger with adequate sauteed onions, mushrooms, roasted red pepper and melted cheese. One slice of buttered toast accompanied the main dish. The potatoes were undercooked, but not so hard as to challenge my molars. The coffee was the strongest entrant to the breakfast sweepstakes, as La Colombe usually is. 

On a cooler day I would have been tempted to sit under the outdoor pergola to enjoy a more leisurely morning, but given the pre-thunderstorm forecast, I opted to remain inside in the sanitary surroundings. Too, given a choice I prefer less single use plastics than provided here. No deduction, but a word to the wise and ecologically sound.

Those of us who fondly remember La Gondola down on the corner of Anderson and Roebling, should sleep better knowing that the historic Italian house has now become Una Casa de Guatemala, Restaurante El Mariachi.   In fact, if you miss the old wall mural of the Venice Canals you can still see it there in all its glory.

I stopped in for lunch the other day on my way back to the office.  I parked a short distance away on Anderson Street, and enjoyed the stroll down memory lane to the side door.  Walking in, you might think this was still in the old hands.  Not that much has changed.  Then, I was approached by a lovely, hustling server doing double duty as the hostess, and rather than listening to a warm Italian accent, I heard the romanticism of Espanol.  It was a pleasant momentary adjustment.  

The menu was full of taco, quesadilla and pupusa options.  Following the recommendations of another Yelper(Mark N.), I went with the Mixtas alternative so I could sample three varieties of the stuffed flat breads.  In addition, the heat of the day being so oppressive, I asked for a Licuado de Papaya con Agua (Papaya Smoothie w/ Water).  For $2, I should have ordered two.  

The Pupusas were about 7 inches in diameter, and came out steaming on a plate also loaded with Pickled Shredded Cabbage/Carrot Combo,and three Salsas.  Each was nicely stuffed with meat, cheese, peppers, onions, and perhaps somethings I did not recognize.  They were well mashed within, and the textures of light pocket pupusa and the individual insides were subtle, but tasty fun.  They were also filling, and I could barely finish them.  The Salsas were Red, Green, and Mixed, each with their own piquancity.  The Licuado was fundamentally whipped Papaya and water.  It was very good and so refreshing on a 90-plus day.  

The house had several table occupied when I was there, and everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves.  Although I was the only one there having to think about what to say in Spanish, the servers and other customers were very cool about the obvious Gringo in their midst.  

The house is clean and bright, and a pleasure to visit.  Chambersburg may not be what it once was, but what it is becoming has promise to be something equally special.

Nadia Thai migrated from Lansdale to Willow Grove and hasn't looked back. Its shop offers solid Siam cuisine, while also being creative and adaptive to local taste.  Payne, owner and master of the front of the house, is enthusiastic and genuinely engaged in making the customer experience unique from greeting to stopping by to assure your satisfaction to salutation and inviting you back again. 

My order of Wild Mushroom Coconut Soup and Hoi Tod (Oyster Pancake) was very enjoyable. The soup was especially sweet, hot and flavorful, although I am not certain all the nightshades listed on the menu were stirring in the bowl. I really liked it.  The Hoi Tod was topped with oysters, tapioca and shallots, the later two fried to a crisp. Nicely done. The sriracha based sauce held it all together with a strong bite. It was a thoughtful interpretation of the seafood pancake found in night markets throughout southeast Asia (admittedly at ten times the price, but who has time to fly over to Chiang Mai for a snack?). 

Until I get there again, Nadia Thai will help keep those memories deliciously alive. 

Oh...and the Yelp Check In bonus fried banana dessert will give your mouth a very happy ending.

Gallo Tropical (Tropical Rooster) is a Dominican/Mexican casa is in the heart of Hatboro,, PA, on York Street right at its intersection with Bayberry Road. Easy to find with metered parking all around (free Sunday). Walking in, it seemed like it wasn't ready for eat in business, but the gracious woman who greeted me advised I could indeed consume my meal on one of the few small tables or counter cleaned and ready for me. Great! I do prefer to eat when the dish is right from the oven. 

I went with  Chicken Empanada as an appetizer, Chicken and Potato Flautas and large Jugo Tamarindo as a delicious health slurpdown. The Empanada was deep fried to a golden hue and loaded with mildly spiced shredded chicken. The outer shell was crispy, while the stuffing was tender and moist. Excellent! There were six fried wheat tortillas rolled up and full of either a chicken/cheese mix or pleasantly mashed potato. This was a first for me, but although I enjoyed the variety provided by the mashed, it wasn't as tasty and compelling as the traditional chicken flute. 

The Tamarind was semisweet and very refreshing. A good offset to the spice of the other dishes. 

There are several very good Dominican kitchens in Trenton, and Gallo Tropical compares well with them. In fact, there is a restaurant by the same name over there.  Wonder if they are related. Regardless, the Hatboro Rooster has a lot to crow about.

Careful as you approach Sophia Bella on Street Road Southbound, as you will drive past their small parking lot curbcut before you know it, and be forced to drive around the block to get back to the entrance of this Italian kitchen in Bensalem, PA. Worse, you might decide to just drive on, and miss a straight up very good meal. 

There are a few small dining areas in the building in addition to a large back kitchen and prepping/cashier zone up front. Attractively utilitarian, all. Room to stand and wait for your order without feeling cramped, as I was doing as my two hot sandwiches were working. 

These were taken to go, so when I opened the brown bag at home, I found neatly packaged long torpedo sammies (Boardwalk Sweet Sausage, Pepper and Onion/Eggplant Parm) in separate recyclable styro containers. Naturally, the enclosed bread absorbed some condensation so they were no longer dry and a crunchy bite, but were still delicious. Quality Italian sausage complemented well with the sweet and savory sauteed veggies. Eggplant breaded lightly and pan fried in extra virgin before placed in the roll with mozza and tomato sauce on top, and baked in the pizza oven until all melted into a savory layered tasty ensemble. 

I bought two to share, and everyone was happy, even the next day when reheated. Service was friendly and casual, and prices reminiscent of pre-pandemic days. 

Pizza looked good, too, but will have to save comments until I return to sample a few.

Wing Wah Chinese Restaurant on New Falls Road, Levittown, PA, is a better than average Chinois Americain house. All takeout in response to Covid protocols, it has a decent kitchen if you are looking for something beyond the ordinary menu. Yet, it is far from perfect, and the actual Yelp score is closer to 3.5 Stars when taking all sampled dishes into consideration. 

I really enjoyed the Beef with Hot Peppers. The meat was tender, the sauce nicely spiced (but, not to Szechuan heat levels), and the onion and carrot thin slices made for a pleasant blend of flavor and texture. The Orange Chicken was abundant, and about average for the genre. It was all white meat with orange peel in the dark brown saucy mix, which was appreciated so much more than some who use cheaper dark meat as a loss leader. Unfortunately, the Wonton Soup destroyed the overall evaluation, because it was hardly worth consuming. It was salty bouillon and thick skinned dumplings, with indescribable meat filling that almost took my appetite away. 

So, avoid the soups that have probably been sitting around too long, and focus on their special dishes not usually found on the universal Chinese American menu.  There you may find a number of choices that demonstration the real skills in the Wing Wah wok.

Nothing Bundt Cakes (Get it?) is a month old pastry shop in the Village of Newtown Shopping Center. It is in fact a franchise that deals in only one product - Bundt Cakes. Risky endeavor to rely on one thing to carry a business to profitability. To succeed, those cakes have got to be great. 

And, they are. 

World class cream cheese icing. Rich, moist cake full of plenty of flavor. A delicious meld in your mouth delight. 

Our lemon cake was kept cool overnight in the fridge, and taken out this morning to sit at room temperature for two hours. It came in a large cake box and wrapped in plastic, which must be removed while still cold to avoid pulling the icing off at warmer temps. A small card with instructions is attached with a mini clothespin. Cute!

So, why not a perfect score? The store experience is a bit overdone. Before the door closes, a voice welcomes you to NBC, and directs you to the free samples. I had to look for the person talking to me who was behind the high counter. She took away my attention while scanning the shop, making me a little uncomfortable. I prefer a moment to orient myself before the friendly sales assault. Too, I did not relate to the scripted welcome. Better to allow the store to speak for itself, grab the imagination, and then offer a more natural approach by staff. 

Also, if you look at the photos from the company, the top of each cake has a icing plug across the normal opening from the Bundt pan. Looks good. Our reality was no such cap over the hole, but just a deep well to the bottom of the cake. It was iced, like a snow covered vent from a volcano. 

No mistake, our lemon Bundt was excellent. These babies are patently addictive.  A few adjustments and the experience could be completely unforgettable.

Andorra Ping Pong is the sibling restaurant to the Ping Pong Restaurant in Wayne, PA. It is similarly Szechuan oriented Chinese cuisine, but in a somewhat smaller footprint in the Andorra Shopping Center just off Henry Avenue very near to Wissakickon Valley Park, and just beyond Roxborough. It is family owned and operated, with husband running the kitchen, and wife, the front of the house. 

We were there for a small celebration, and thoroughly enjoyed our time there. We ordered enough to be able to sample a cross section of their dishes, and had plenty to bring home for our sons. We went with: Deep Fried Chicken, Fish Fillet Dry Pot, Cumin Lamb and Hot Sauce Pig Intestine; all melded together with the help of an excellent Charles Krug cabernet (BYOB). Each entre was a full load. The chicken was crispy, yet still moist within. The fish fillets, tender with plenty of dry Szechuan red peppers, cauliflower, lotus root and cilantro. The cumin lamb was well covered in dry cumin leaf and accessorized with green pepper, onion and good sized long hots pieces, while the intestine skin was dark brown, surrounded by celery, peanuts, scallion and more of those small red heat devils from Chongqing. All tasty morsels. 

If there was anything to talk about, it was the lack of numbing heat in any of the platters. A deep dive into the heart of each failed to discover any black peppercorn, nor star peppers - the two ingredients necessary for the development of numbing sweats.  When asked, we advised that they should bring the heat because we loved the sensation, yet it did not materialize. Spicy, yes. Numbing lips and tongue, no. 

But, aside from that disappointment, the meal was filling, satisfying and most enjoyable. We will still return, and visit the sister ship before too long. Perhaps, we will bring our own extra burn, just in case the kitchen lacks those key ingredients when we arrive next time.

Samarkand is an ancient city in Uzbekistan in western Asia.  It sits astride the Silk Road that Marco Polo travelled on his journeys to the East.  It remains a beautiful and mysterious place with many old walls, narrow streets and amazing markets.  As a centuries old melting pot, it has created its own cultural reality; among the most interesting of which is food.  Taking from cuisine as far away as India, China and the Middle East, their kitchens at once remind you of each of those unique tastes, and at the same time something quite original.  

A visit to Samarkand Restaurant is a much easier way to experience this exotic taste, than to make the overland caravan to this still isolated treasure.  Right in Bucks County the flavor and texture of Uzbeki dishes are available in a house with archways and desert murals that with a little imagination brings you right there. True, this is just the northern outpost of an ever expanding community of Soviet emigres who have settled in Northeast Philly, of which Uzbeks are but a part. Still, some would argue they are the most colorful and delicious. Leave that discussion for others while you take a trip to a terrific meal. 

Our approach was to tapas the appetizers, including mushroom and white corn soup, samsa, cheburek and kutab, followed by lamb and salmon shish kebob.  We shared everything. Service was friendly and attractive in Russian accent. 

Each element was very good to outstanding. Their use of dough to make all the apps was fascinating, as each was different and flavorful, depending on whether baked, deep fried or skillet heated. The lamb and salmon managed to be moist and well grilled at the same time. Excellent hands in the kitchen. 

We finished lunch with their crepe dessert, stuffed with mildly sweet and sour cream, and drizzled with Nutella. It caused a nostalgia wave as sensory images of my grandmother's cheese blintzes danced in my head. Loved them! 

Few of us have broad exposure to Uzbek cuisine, but I intend to spend more time exploring it, as it is quite unusual, fun and delicious.

Seo Rabol, the Korean house on Old 2nd Street in the Olney section of Philadelphia, is one of the more established peninsula restaurants in the area. It is not far from the center of Seoultown on Cheltenham Avenue. They offer a full menu, but their specialty is BBQ grilled on the table. 

We were not hungry enough to deal with the mandatory 2 order minimum (@$20 per), so opted for their rendition of seafood pancake and pork gui - letting them do the grilling in the kitchen and serve it ready to eat. The banchan arrived first in small square plates. The ten or so dishes were all very good and a tour de force of spicy flavors and textures from steamed egg to mackerel. 

The pancake was frittata like, with plenty of shellfish within, and pan fried well enough to be firm, yet still tender. It was one of the better versions I have eaten. The gui was a large bowl full of pork strips grilled just right with an excellent spicy hot/sweet sauce. Much better than I could have done myself at the table, at less than half the cost. It was delicious and almost addictive. We couldn't finish either dish, so the remains were packed up for home consumption. We finished with complementary sweet ginger tea, which cleansed the pallet and was refreshing.

Throughout the meal the large HDTVs were tuned to the Winter Olympics in South Korea. National pride for sure, but no one really seemed to be watching. The table conversation was dominant across the large dining room, as it should be while enjoying a good meal with family and friends. 

Service was efficient and cordial, but it certainly helped to have someone at the table speaking Korean.

State Road in Croydon, PA, is unlike the rest of the Delaware River shoreline in Bucks County. Obviously developed without zoning, it is an alternate universe with mishmosh of industrial, pizza shops, dive bars, and marshes across the gypsy wagon shack landscape. It is strange and unique to this area, and Smokerhead Barbeque fits right in. 

It is the second BBQ joint in this small shed, half kitchen and half dining room. The owners have been doing truck catering for a while and took a chance on bricks and mortar. From the look and smell of things, it was a smart move. They do solid smoked meats in a variety of styles, and love rock & roll. Last night they had a live performer cranking out hits from the 70's thru 90's on his well travelled Gibson and accompanying soundtrack. Decent gravel baritone voice, too. 

My third of a rack ribs were four fat boys done St. Louis way, with sweet tangy flavor and far more than I could eat. There were only two table rockets with North Carolina (mustard base) and Memphis (brown sugar and vinegar) squirts. The meat was smoked dry and the sauces were optional, yet very moist and tender within. Really well done if you prefer control over the finish served up to you rather than having the plate all slathered with basting juices. The pit beans were a mix of grains, tomato base and bacon for seasoning. Good, but a little dry. 

Service was down home and friendly. There was cool comraderie between the chefs and floor staff, and some dancing and harmonizing when a favorite tune struck a fancy.   Beer cans in the cooler, too. 

Thoroughly entertained with ribs to spare last Saturday night.

The Temperance House has been in operation (off and on with a variety of owners) for over a century.  It consists of a restaurant, barroom, bed & breakfast. Since reopening earlier this year under new ownership, I have stopped in a few times for happy hour or later in the evening with friends and associates for after meeting meetings and socializing.  

While I really did not like, "The Temp," before due to its heavy political personality, the new version is much more friendly to all invitees, and offers a few small back rooms for groups to get together with quality bar and kitchen service.  We were there last night for a couple of hours to catch up after last week's national elections (more commiseration, than celebration).  Our server was warm and efficient, and the food and drink were good and reasonably priced.  

From our vantage point behind the barroom, we heard the live band playing in the bar, but not loud enough to interfere with conversation.  Entering and leaving, I spied several people I knew from around town, and we acknowledged each other with nod, smile or wave. They were all having a good time.  

Now that the vibe is more welcoming, a check on their dinner menu is in order.  Hope it, too, is more warm and tasty than the dusty dryness of past party clubbiness.

Don't know New Mama Juana from Old Mama Juana, but what I do know is that this cafeteria style traditional Dominican casa de comidas cooks up a storm of excellent dishes.  Sitting at the corner of County Line and Newtown Roads in Warminster, PA, it has recently expanded into the neighboring storefront to add a utilitarian dining room in addition to the small original corner shop. 

I stopped in when I couldn't find the Mexican place I was searching for, and decided to go in flying blind. Very glad I did, because while really nothing like Mexican food, it did have a strong resemblance to Puerto Rican cuisine with serious pork, chicken and beef options, and white/yellow/brown rice and well simmered beans. While it all looked appealing, I was most attracted to the rotisserie quartered chicken.  

It was excellent. Its skin was dry and taunt, while the meat beneath was moist and pull-from-the-bone tender. The taste was subtle, but well spiced and easy to pull apart and devour. If you said it was like duck comfit, you wouldn't be wrong. The beans were also delicious, but not spicy, and the yellow rice mixed in for a tasty textured combination. Liked the meal a lot. 

Service was friendly and attractive, and although ordered at the cashier, it was delivered to the table with a sonrisa grande by their Guatemaltecan assistant. 

There were many other interesting possibilities that may tempt me to return. I saw tostones, empanadas, and platanos rellenos, that looked great.  I just can't eat that much, and much prefer eating at the source to carry out. 

New Mama Juana is the name. Authentic Latin American island food is the game.

I generally leave New Hope for the New York weekenders and tourists to overpopulate, but sometimes on a Sunday night in the dead of winter the village empties and it is possible to find open tables for a quiet dinner that reminds of this ferrytown's historic beginnings. So it was this weekend past that we ventured into this picturesque river hamlet and found a nearly vacant The Dubliner on the Delaware Irish bar and kitchen on North Main Street. Parking was a breeze almost right in front, and the meter was was only needed until 9. 

We chose a table overlooking the main drag along the front paned glassed wall. The street lights did their best to add a warm glow on a softly raining night. This 18th Century town somehow looked like the perfect set for a movie about the real revolutionary history that happened all along the river when the New Hope Ferry was the only way across the dangerous Delaware's current and icy flow. It was a wilder river then before a reliable bridge could be built. 

Service was friendly, helpful and appropriate. We ordered a Guinness for an Irish brew novice and a Magnate Hard Pear Cider pour moi. Cool, tasty refreshing. From there, we ordered Shepherds Pie, Bangars & Mash, Crab Cake Sandwich and a fresh Cod Fillet with veggie accompaniment. They were all a big hit with the group, especially the first two. This house knows from mashed potatoes and does them quite well. The Shepherds Pie had plenty of ground beef, peas, carrots and brown gravy under the topside frilly  potato cover. Made me wish I had a flock of sheep so I could justify eating this substantial deep dish meal more often. It was fun and delicious. 

The Irish sausage atop the same mashed came with a small dish of gravy, that when all mixed together made for another engaging and nearly addicting mouthful. I was permitted a taste and found it eye openingly exceptional. The Crab Cake was also good with far more crab than bread filler. The Cod was light but could have used a more flavorful finish to give it more spark. 

We all agreed that our meals at The Dubliner were overall better than expected, and that a return visit would be an easy vote of assent. Those burgers looked great, too. 

PS: This is the former Mother's Restaurant location, where I had been a semi regular at an earlier point in my life. I admit to approaching the heavy wood door with thoughts of those days and wondering if memories would haunt. Nope.
