Once inside the new energy of the joint took control and assured that this was a new day for this old haven and the ghosts that be were friendly.

Sedition is conduct that encourages acts of rebellion against the state. If a failure it is a serious crime; if successful, an act of revolutionary heroism. In times like these that try the souls of patriots, when it is difficult to differentiate between the criminals and the righteous, it is understandable that a subterranean public house would choose "Sedition" as its identity. No doubt the dark bricked, grottoed, underground tavern evokes an epoch when such weighty matters were discussed in hushed tones by serious people. 

Chose a side or stand aside, but at least here you can do so with quality drinks and kitchen. We stopped in after visiting Penn Med a few blocks away. The basement felt cool in the dim light of reimagined industrial fixtures. We walked through coved rooms until taking a booth rather far from the bar. Yet, the friendly bartender found us with menus in hand. There were good beer choices, but having to return to see the medical staff after lunch, our libations were strictly water. We ordered the Philbano and Beer Braised Brisket sandwiches, and settled in. 

Both were very good, as were the accompanying fries. The "Philly Cubano" was made up of smoked Berkshire pork butt, provolone, peach BBQ sauce and pickled long hots, all stuffed into a fresh Parker House roll. Simply put, it was a great pulled pork sammy. The combination of ingredients played well together and it was fun to identify the flavors as they announced themselves to the tongue.  First rate. The brisket was not quite as entertaining, but was tender and slathered in horseradish and coleslaw between the semi spheres of a brioche bun. Satisfying. Both were substantial enough to bring half home. 

Whether you intend on sedition or will wait the next act out from the sidelines, be sure to enjoy life and stop in to Sedition for drinks and grub before deciding.

Right in the heart of the National Historic District on Delaware Street sits Jessop's Tavern. Some might say that it is also the true heart of Old New Castle, occupying a colonial building constructed in 1674, and operating as a bar/restaurant for at least the last 75 years. Jessop's is the perfect place to take a load off after exploring town, or as a way station just minutes of Rt. 95 south of Wilmington.  

Reflecting the cultural mix of the early settlers, the offerings are from Sweden, The Netherlands, England, Belgium, and Revolutionary War Americana.  They have a large beer selection, with Belgians their claim to fame.  The kitchen is similarly oriented to traditional fare from those parts of the world.  As they say in their Mission Statement, they "serve history at Jessop's Tavern."  

We stopped in for a late lunch last week after touring Rockwood Mansion, about 12 miles north. It was all dark woods and wenches in period dress.  A long bar along one wall, and tables against the other.  We ordered a dark Barbe ale and pear cider for drinks, and their, "Dutch Pastrami Reuben," and Swedish Meatloaf Sandwich.  Both were large, beautiful to behold, and solid tasty meals.  Every aspect was well designed from breads through sauces, although it was not apparent what the Dutch have to do with pastrami, but, they are entitled to a little poetic license. 

Service was attentive and friendly. When a late afternoon cloudburst trapped us in the tavern just after we finished eating, they had no problem inviting us to stay as long as we liked, and offering us an umbrella to go to the car once the deluge passed.  

Hear tell that they also have excellent ice cream available.  

There will definitely be a next time.

With friends from Changchun in tow, we came to Chinatown to do some shopping at Asia Market in preparation for some good home cooking, Dong Bei Chinese style.  But, realizing it wasn't wise to go food shopping on an empty stomach, we stopped in at M Kee for a late lunch.  This was a first visit for me, and I found the house to be cleaner and friendlier than most.  The menu was packed with rice and noodle dishes, wet and dry, and at prices that were very compatible with the desire to eat light.  

My friends speak little English, but felt right at home chatting up the servers about the menu and how dishes were prepared.  Once satisfied, they went with Chicken Curry over Rice, Roast Pork and Wonton Noodle Soup (See Photos). 

The Chicken arrived in a bright yellow almost creamy curry sauce, and a pleasantly mild flavor that only required a little tweaking with Sriracha to bring up the heat.  Tasty.  The Wonton Noodles Soup was more than I could finish, with a nest of thin noodles beneath the surface of the chicken consume.  The 4 or 5 Wontons were stuffed with ground Pork and Leek (maybe), and had goldfish tails for swimming in the hot broth.  Very nice.  Finally, the Roast Pork was excellent covered in a gleaming tawny finish.  There was a lot of it for under 7 bucks, and it was the star of the show.  

It was easy to see why M Kee is so popular.  The quantity/quality/cost proposition is great here.  The three of us walked out with tip for under $20, totally sated and agreeing this was great down home victuals.  With prices this low, it almost doesn't pay to eat in my own kitchen.

Mamma Mia Trattoria sits in the Oxford Valley Mall campus, right across from Red Robin and in the shadow of Cheeburger x 2. It is part of the Carlucci restaurant empire, the local folks who brought us Mama Rosa's, Carlucci's, Carlucci's Express, this lovely place and a couple of kitchens in the old country. Word is that the old man was in the house just this morning checking on operations. His kids are starting to pick up their involvement as he starts to cut back. Sorry I missed him. 

Of course, I didn't know any of this history until informed by our server after I asked about all the Carlucci photos on the walls. Had I known, I would have checked MMT out long ago. Now that I have, I won't be a stranger. 

The house is casually attractive with two dining areas and a nice cozy feel. The menu is extensive and the kitchen visible along the western wall. We were here for a late lunch that would bypass dinner. We chose a personal size 12" white veggie pie and eggplant parmesan foot long sandwich/grinder to share. 

Both were really good.  The pie was a beauty, with colorful components and a garlicky aroma. The crust was crisp, firm, yet airy. Good cheese veggie balance that did not let the fromage bog down the lightness desired. A sprinkle of crushed red pepper and we got down to business. 

The melanzon was thin sliced, breaded and pan sauteed before being slid into a fresh Italian torpedo roll, top layered with mozza, splashed with chunky tomato gravy, and then placed in the pizza oven to finish it off with a melt and mild scorching of the roll edges. Great soft texture beneath the slight crustiness of the breading. Honest flavorful interplay between the elements. 

If you already know the Carlucci experience at his other shops, MMT will not surprise you with it quality take on traditional Italian cuisine. They are similar, so like one, like all. If new to Carlucci World, this is an excellent place to begin your affair with his kitchens.

When a family has been in the same business at the same location for 40 years, they must be doing something right. 

Pizza Star is a traditional pizza parlor.  They do pizza, steaks and related goodies, and that is all. No pasta. No dinners. Nothing fancy. Just old style pie and sandwiches in a double wide storefront on Woerner Avenue, Levittown, PA.  If you know this commercial strip, you are aware it is not the most attractive bit of design and construction every created. Signage can't be seen from the main roads, and even the street seems more like an alleyway between New Falls Road and Emilie Road. 

But, if you are in the mood for a throwback Italian experience, Pizza Star is the joint for you. Ordering is at the counter, and table service is provided by the kitchen staff. No waitresses here. Just find a table and settle in. The HDTV high on the front wall will keep you informed or entertained. 

I went with their eggplant parmesan sub. There was only one size available - large, but the price was about the same as for a torpedo half the size. Hard to beat. When delivered to my seat, it looked great. Overloaded with melanzone - breaded thin slices, sautéed in olive oil and covered in mozza and their home brewed red sauce.  The roll was first rate, too; brought to highlife with the final bronzing in the oven. 

Taste was very good, although the golden fried discs were perhaps a little too oily from their moment in the hot sun. Not a biggie, but it would have been near excellent had the oil been absorbed off before the sandwich was finished. 

The Star is yet another strong find in this part of Lower Bucks. No doubt I will return to sample the steaks and pizza when I find myself hungry in this sector of the universe.

First visit to this Panera just off the campus of The College of New Jersey. 

Walking in, the place was well kept with plenty of room to dine or simply order and take away. I approached the cashier while checking out their bakery products on the back wall and immediately in front of me behind glass. I went with an Everything Bagel, Chive/ Onion Spread and a thin Brownie that winked at me as I spoke with the cashier. Finally, a light roast java to wash it all down. 

When I spread it all out on my desk, I learned that I would do the spreading. No sweat, knife included. The bagel was fresh, but the soft variety, rather than the crisp chew I prefer. Still, it was acceptable and I enjoyed it. The Brownie was likewise soft, but nicely chocolatey throughout. Half was covered with powdered sugar, giving it a sweet kick without overwhelming the basic premise of these brown squares. Finally, the Joe was hot and tasty from the light roast, which I often like more than the stronger heavier darker roasts. 

Bottom line, this was a decent late morning snack for a busy day, and I won't hesitate to visit again next time I am near The College.

New Hope Star Diner is an old style roadhouse right out of the 1950s. So, it has that going for it. Too, the menu is as big as you could want. There is no shortage of choices. 

When we drove down to Main Street, New Hope on Labor Day it was so crowded with masked and unmasked tourists that there was no social distancing. It wasn't safe to be there, so we drove back to the diner where there were many fewer customers and both indoor and outdoor seating. We wanted to sit outside, but the bees beat us to the shady tables. Rather than deal with those buzzing bandits, we went inside and we're shown to a corner table with lots of space around it. Staff was busy cleaning tables and floor when not serving food. We felt safe eating there.

Our patty melt (w fries, slaw) and Arizona Omelet (w home fries and coffee) were solid plates. My burger was not the medium requested, but it was otherwise tasty and filling. The 3 egger was too much to finish and was taken home. Service was friendly and prompt. 

New Hope Star Diner is a 24/7 operation. It may not be the most popular restaurant in this upscale river town, but on a day when everything on the strip was overrun with people trying to escape the remains of Covid quarantine, it was great to have a place that provided both sustenance and safety from the horde.

An extra star for their community involvement is warranted.

Boy Scout Pancake Breakfast was a fundraising success.

Pho Viet HOA on Welsh Road, Willow Grove, sits in the middle of a modern strip center right next door to an Italian restaurant; one of the beautiful things about the melting pot we live in. Its modern utilitarian decor makes room for a dozen tables along both walls, with enough seating for social distancing in these Days of Covid. Service was prompt and efficient, with a suburban smile. The menu was primarily Vietnamese as would be expected, but also delved into a broader culinary universe found in neighboring Asian kitchens like Chinese and Thai style noodle dishes. 

I ordered Veggie Fried Rolls as an appetizer, Wide Noodles with Veggies "Wet" in a light brown sauce, and two Banh Mi sandwiches, Grilled Beef and Pork (for family take out). I hesitated on their Pho based on the luke warm reviews from respected Yelpers and the price compared to favorite pho houses in the City, which were a few bucks less. 

The four Veggie Rolls and dipping sauce were very good, crisp and full of real chopped veggies, and not just cabbage. The garnish of daikon and carrot were a nice touch. The large plate of fat noodles was supplied with ample broccoli, carrot, onion, mushroom and sprout, but lacking in spice. My mistake for not requesting lemongrass be added, but I squirted on Sriracha from the table rocket to compensate. Not precisely the flavor profile I hoped for, but decent enough to satisfy. I took half of that home. 

The uncompromising winner were the Banh Mi consumed by the family later in the evening. They were both stuffed with excellent roast pork and beef, cucumber, daikon, carrot, cilantro and a tasty mix of hot/sweet sauces, all barely contained in fresh (if not exactly French), rolls. Baguettes would have been near perfection. Compared to what we ate the week before from another Vietnamese/Thai house, this was Blue Ribbon. 

So, go for the Banh Mi for sure, perhaps not for their specials noodle list, while the jury is out on the Pho. I wouldn't hesitate to give it a try as long as the sammies were the primary focus. 

P.S. The Banh Mi were eaten before photos could be secured. Apologies.

This Steve's Prince of Steaks is on Comly Road, just off northbound Roosevelt Boulevard, Somerton, PA, in the far Northeast of the city. If possible, it is even smaller than my regular Steve's on Rt. 1 in Langhorne. There are two windows within. One for ordering your sandwich, for which they have posted a long list of rules to follow to get what you want, and the other only for fries and drinks. Like the rest, the burden is on you to know what you're doing, or face the consternation of the staff and your fellow steak lovers. Not an enviable place to be.

I ordered two "cheesesteaks wit provolone," meaning I wanted two sandwiches with fried onions and provolone cheese. I like the Wiz, too, but preferred the extra mellowness offered by the hard white variation. It set me back $25+. Not unexpected, but I'd be lying if I didn't do a double clutch before paying the dude taking my business. 

Normally, we would eat right along the walls at the Langhorne joint, but this shop was smaller and without short shelves and stools. We took them home to consume. These guys are fast and efficient, and it was fun to watch them work through the greasy glass window that separates kitchen from customers. It would have been a thoroughly enjoyable moment, but for Mr. Priss shouting not to take photos (after the last one). 

Oh, me. Oh, my! Have to protect those state secrets. 

At home, we added our own banana pepper rings to bring up the burn; the pickle bar being removed as a casualty of COVID. It was love at first bite. Great cross section of taste and texture as we incisored through the excellent torpedo roll, cheese and ribeye. My wife and I shared one sandwich, and left the other for her still growing son (6'3"). 

I have no dog in the fight between the chopped vs. solid slice approach to this Philly delicacy. I like them both ways, as long as the beef used is high quality. Steve's is among my faves, but with every pizza shop making their own version, we are really living in Cheesesteak Heaven around here. The worst one in the Philadelphia region is better than anything anywhere else.

One thing for sure - Water's Edge does Covid Protocol right! 

Walking up the stairs to the main entrance you first see a large squirt bottle of hand sanitizer to clean hands before touching the door handle. In the lobby, your temperature is taken and then your driver's license scanned in case they need to notify the county health department to do contact tracing because they learn someone in your party developed Covid symptoms. Then they escort you to a bar stool or table properly distanced from the others. Everyone on staff is masked and gloved. As put to me; "We're dead serious about following protocol. We want to do everything required to keep our restaurant open and keep customers and staff safe." 

Greatly appreciated! 

So, we took a table outside on a chilly evening. Not only did we want fresh air to maximize safety, but we wanted to overlook the wide and muddy Bensalem Creek which the new owners had gone great lengths to accentuate with the tri-level deck between the banks of the creek and all glass back wall of the restaurant. On a warmer night in season, this would be almost idyllic. 

A portable heater was wheeled over to us and sparked on overhead. It took the cold edge off the air, but didn't reach our legs, so we accepted that this would be a somewhat cold experience. Made the night more memorable. 

We ordered the brussel sprout appetizer (smallish sprouts with bacon and parmesan mixed in), Tuscon Salmon (wild rice and asparagus), and the Five Alarm Burger w Fries (candied jalapeno slices, cheese, and an aioli spread on the brioche-style bun). They were all good, if not knock outs, but better than expected from a kitchen attached to what is fundamentally a sports pub with an excellent view. 

Service was very gracious and attentive. I felt a bit guilty forcing the young woman to come outside to help us when she lacked any true winter wear. She didn't complain, nor even show she was frigid. I hoped a larger tip would provide evidence we appreciated her effort. 

Will return with better weather for sure.

The old stable is now populated by diners enjoying the bucolic, high beamed ceiling, stone floors and exposed kitchen.  If outdoor dining in nice weather is your thing, you can be easily accommodated next to the boccie court and outdoor bar. 

It seems I am there most often for special community events, and the layout works well for isolating small groups in places that do not overly interfere with the regular dinner patrons.  The food is family style Italian, meaning if there are more than 3 of you, many of the dishes come piled high and placed centrally on the table where everyone can partake. 

The food has always been solid, both meats, fowl and pasta.  The service is much better than average, with black and whites hustling around to be sure everyone is getting what they expect in a timely and friendly, while professional manner.  The last event buffet consisted of Chicken Francaise, Vodka Rigatoni, Eggplant Rolatini, Grilled Veggies, Italian Bread.  All worth the price of admission.  

Sure glad someone thinks enough of their guests to schedule a social/political event in such pleasant surroundings.

We just purchased a new Toro self-propelled lawn mower from Tanners on Rt. 532 in Newtown.  You may remember the location as the former Yamamoto's. 

I walked in after our tired out mower's metal tube handle snapped from fatigue, and it became impossible to push it further.  The guys at Tanners showed me what they had to offer in a quiet, knowledgeable way.  They appreciated my frustration, and after asking appropriate questions to zero in on my lawn cutting requirements, directed me to a Toro.  There was a small rebate being offered by the manufacturer, to bring the cost in line with the big boxes out on Rt. 1.  I always prefer to buy locally, and keep the businesses in town open.  A small premium for that satisfaction is well worth it. 

Tanners delivered the mower to my home yesterday, fully operational, with a full tank of gas, and road tested.  They took away my old mower, and we agreed that if they could repair it for under a certain amount they should do so, and my 12 year old would have a second machine for his budding lawn cutting business.  If not, they would give me a small trade in offset.  Fair deal. 

When I arrived home my son ran out of the house with a big smile.  He had already cut two lawns with the new mower, and he was in love with his first machine.  We had a sharp cut lawn and a happy boy who had just gone through a right of passage.  

All this and a new Toro ballcap, too. 

Nothing better than that!

Sabrina's Pizza took me by surprise.  I mean, I knew it was there, but I never considered checking it out until very recently.  

Now, I've had lunch there twice in one week, and it could easily become one of my regular stops for tomato pie or other midday meal.  Hamilton has dozens of decent small Italian joints that put out the standard fare, and it takes a lot of tasting to distinguish them from each other. Eventually, the better shops emerge above the rest and the circle of good restaurants finally closes.  If embarrassment of riches makes any sense for pizza parlors, this part of the world has it. That doesn't mean that other cities don't do it as well or maybe better (You know who you are). Still, I have come to appreciate the richness of the pizza/tomato pie tradition around here. 

What about the food, you ask?  The Eggplant Parm Sandwich I had a few days ago was thin sliced, fine ground bread crumb coating and individually olive oil sautéed purple nightshade, placed in a fresh torpedo and topped with plenty of mozza cheese and a chunky tomato gravy.  Totally a knife and fork experience.  With an iced tea, it comes in at just under ten bucks.  

Today's bar pie size Tomato Pie with Italian Sweet Sausage was even better.  It arrived in the hands of the owner/chef on a large ceramic plate, all steamy - a cloud of garlic infused vapors fogging my glasses and attacking my senses.  The crust was firm and crunchy, and even with the extra load of lumpy gravy and ground meat, managed to hold a firm point through most of the meal.  It was excellent and really tasted like it was made in Nonna's kitchen.  

If there is anything to pic a nit about it would be that the pie might have been even better with a little less on top.  The tomato sauce was so chunky that it remained moist on the finished disk and as it cooled and released it water condensate, the remaining slices softened and weakened its ability to hold its load. There was actually a bit of water left over as the pie was consumed, and it lost its crunch.  

Sometimes, less is more.

For fast food franchised joints, Chick-fil-A does a very good breakfast sandwich.  

My Sausage, Egg and Cheese Biscuit was far better than their equivalents at McD's or Burger K.  It is larger, fresher, tastier, and the biscuits themselves flakier and more buttery.  

This was a drive thru order at this newish outlet.  They made a small mistake in my favor by throwing in a box of Taters at the bottom of the bag.  I didn't order them, but neither was I charged.  I wasn't aware of it until I arrived at my destination and saw what was in the bag.  

Nice to come out on the high side of the transaction.  So often, these deals break the other way.

Chencha Y Chole is a very nice Mexican house at the corner of Broad and Cass in Trenton.  It has been open for several months and still has the "Grand Opening" signs hanging on the sides of the newly painted triangular building.  The odd angle of this intersection created an opportunity for the original architect and city planner to design a structure that fits snuggly in this narrow corner, thus adding interesting perspective to the establishment.

Inside is clean and bright and feels like a bit of sunny Mexico right here in River City.  The menu is diverse, and the plates leaving the open kitchen are equally colorful, and more importantly, very tasty.  I asked for my Hawaiian Torta with Grilled Chicken rather than jamon, and was easily accommodated.  The sandwich arrived loaded with bird, avocado, onion, lettuce, queso fresca ,fried pineapple, spicy mayo, and a few other unidentifiables that added to the overall finished product.  The toasted Roll made the entire package very enjoyable.  It came with good Fries. 

Most surprisingly delicious was the homemade Tamarindo drink.  While I thought I was ordering a carbonated bottled of soda, in fact, I was getting something much better.  The Tamarind was cool, mildly sweet and tart, and so very refreshing.  It arrived in a large glass and was a mid-brown shade from the tree pods it was reduced from. Also, very high in antioxidants.  It is great to be so pleasantly overwhelmed.  

Serendipity.  This is one of the best Mexican joints I have tried in the city. 

4 Stars with a Bullet!

This Target is a great example of the old fashioned true department store, with a little of everything you need for daily existence.  Clothing, food, lighting, kitchenware, electronics, sports equipment, music, and automotive - all under one roof.  It may not have everything you want, but it generally has everything you need.  

Heard that it is a good place to work, especially compared to the other Big Brother Big Box stores.  

Not the highest quality, but not the lowest, either.  

Even the snack/coffee area is offered as a convenience to their customers.  

If you remember EJ Korvettes and other last century highway superstores, Target will make you feel a little nostalgic.

I have a memory of being in this place about twenty years ago, and it looking very different back then.  I don't remember if it was McCool's or another name, but for sure it was a much darker and dingier dive in those days.  Today, there are large windows along the back wall letting in some light, and the bar has been moved to the inner wall to permit that to happen.  The place still has that old pub feel, all dark woods and lots of draft beer handles and liquor bottles on the back bar shelves.  

Yes. Plenty of choices, and a decent menu, too.  When I stopped in around 1 for lunch before a meeting a few blocks away, there was only one other guy at the bar, and one table occupied.  Those people were gone before I finished, leaving me to have a good conversation with Heather, the bartender.  This is one of the benefits of late lunches. Miss the happy hour, but befriend the bartenders, and ask lots of questions. 

Very cool that she has been there 13 years, joining the crew shortly after the old place was purchased by the current owners who made all the structure changes seen today.  Turns out the hosts are Greek and do a very good take on the tavern comfort foods coming out of the basement kitchen.  I'm told the new dumbwaiter was installed fairly recently, saving a load of stair climbing to serve customers.  

I had a Summer Love draft and the house Macaroni and Cheese for a light meal.  The former was cool, mildly complex and easy going down, and the later, hot, cheesy and served in the same crockery as the French Onion Soup.  Although an app, it filled me amply, and left room for a coffee stop on my way to the meeting on Market St.  

I was very happy with my short sojourn at McCool's.  In its quiet unassuming way, it is a nice haven from the street hustle, and in a similar vein, a pleasant alternative to the louder vanity stops that abound in Center City.  

The reincarnation has gone very well.

Newtown Farmers' Market is an overcrowded, under-maintained, slightly tarnished version of the Amish markets in the Lancaster area.  They have proliferated to other locales around Bucks, but this was one of the first.  Honestly, it needs a refurbishment, as it gets dingier by the month. 

Yet, there are a few stalls where the food product is original and tasty.  Barbie's Soft Pretzels is one of them.  They don't have a sign anywhere near the shop, but if you know your way around, it is right across from the sushi place near the main entrance.  Lately, I have become slightly addicted to their Jalapeno, Onion and Cheese Pretzel Dog.  They claim it to be a beef hot dog encased within a soft pretzel shell, with the Jalapeno Slices, Sautéed Onion and Melted Cheese all stuffed within the pretzel. The current price is $2.50 per, and it seems a good deal.  The pretzel is the same as you can get as a traditional twist, but the taste and texture are strongly influenced by the contents within.  Each bite comes at you with succeeding sensibilities of slightly salty pretzel, the garlicy dog, with a rush of jalapeno arriba, and finally the subtle cheese to finish each chomp/chew.  Damn enjoyable with each repetition. 

Today, they had a special on Blueberry Shakes (in season), so why not?  I watched the young freulein put in two scoops of vanilla ice cream (they have their own supply right next to the Goodnoe case - they should work out a deal to use the local iconic brand), and then a copious amount of Blueberry mash.  She blended it for at least two minutes.  The taste was superlative with the straw constantly clogging with the sapphire blue berry slurry.  The best moment was when extra suction was applied to my end of the straw and the blockage finally gave way and exploded in my mouth. 
  
In my munchies days, that would have blown my mind. 

So, yes, I am a fan of Barbie's.  Yet, I wish they kept their stall cleaner.  As I stood and looked down into the lemonade machine, the clear sight of mold in the corners gave me pause.  It had not been cleaned well in ages.  Sigh...

I ate my lunch anyway, as I felt the obligation to post this review.

Lola's Café is easy to walk passed without a second glance.  But, if you are fortunate enough to peer through the large storefront glass you will find a small utilitarian banh mi house that turns out a superior Vietnamese sandwich and a very good smoothie, too.  

I walked in for a late lunch before my scheduled haircut around the corner looking for a good baguette based sandy made with skilled hands knowledgeable in the ways of Saigon fare.  I lucked out.  

Lola is the young daughter of the owners of this shop.  The couple running the operation are very friendly and informative about their vision for the business and how they create their dishes.  I had the Roast Pork Banh Mi.  It came complete with in house baked pork roast sliced thin and amply placed in fresh French loaf.  The Daikon radish, Cucumber, Cilantro and Mayo were in there, too.  The bread was slighted warmed, and perhaps spread with a touch of butter or oil to bring up the flavor of the opus.  

I learned that the roast pork starts as a raw ground meat that is mixed with spices and baked in the home oven for several hours before being sliced and used as the foundation for their sandwich.  It is not a "deli meat" at all, but done fresh by the owners as needed.  

It was an excellent banh mi, perhaps the best I have sampled in Chinatown, and on par with those down around Washington in South Philly.  The Pineapple-Banana Smoothie was thick, cool and so refreshing. I walked around with it after lunch and was great on an above average mid October afternoon.  At $4 per BM and Smoothie, the prices were right!

Lola's is worth many return visits to see what else they do in the kitchen.  

4 Stars with a Bullet!

Walking out of Vince's Pizza after a less than stellar couple of slices, I needed something to take the bitter aftertaste of the sauce off my tongue. Imagine my relief to realize there was a bakery right next door. It was like finding an emergency rescue squad right next to a bad auto accident.  

Cairo Cakes is a small shop.  There was a steady flow of customers as I waited, asked questions of the helpful man in white, and made my selections.  The display cases were full of cupcakes, and trays of various brownies and bars.  I jumped at the Lemon Bars, always a favorite.  The Chocolate Peanut Butter and something that tasted like German Chocolate filling with Toasted Coconut Shredded Wheat-like topping, also found their way into my box.  Finally, I picked up a couple of colorful cupcakes for my son to give his mom for a little treat on Mother's Day.  

Everything I tasted was very good, if a little too dense for my palate.  The flavors were all strong and addicting, but they had a cloying stickiness that required a hot drink to clear from the tongue and teeth.  I would have preferred a lighter texture while maintaining the flavors, as can be found in many bakeries.  

Still, this is a nice place to come for sweets in the area, and it certainly saved me from suffering the long term aftereffects of the lousy pizza put out next door.  I will return here when in the area and my sweet tooth needs attention.

First bite at Casa Lupita was a little unusual. 

I walked in for a late lunch and the large banquet/dining area looked like it was between weddings - all white tablecloths with pink bows and ribbons everywhere.  But, to one side near the kitchen a few tables had been left aside for the day/evening crowd to use.  The only other person in the house at 2 was Alicia, the chef, server, manager, and Jacquelina of all trades.  

She was Aces.  She took my order for Sopes de Pollo with Black Beans and Rice on the side, and disappeared into the kitchen to make my lunch.  It was only when I heard the rumbling in the kitchen and she finally emerged with a tray loaded down with my almuertzo and placed it before me that I realized what was going on. She played all the parts of this theatrical production. 

Everything was very good.  The thick corn tortilla used as the base for the Sopes was freshly baked and was strong enough to hold the open face of the Chicken, Beans, Lettuce, Tomato and Grated Cheese that was piled onto each of the three 5 inch diameter disks.  The Mexican spices announced themselves in their splendid red and green, and two small dishes of Salsa waited patiently to be thrown into the flames.  So good.  The Black Beans and Golden Rice were ample, satisfying and filling.  My Mandarin Jarritos reminded my why it was my favorite carbonated drink - the fruit flavors always come through in a way that the Americano alternatives just do not.  

While I consumed this excellent repast, Alicia sat at the next table and chatted with me about the shop and her life since coming here from Cuidad Mexico more than 20 years ago.  She was bright, charming, and had a confident air that was compelling. I thought she was the owner of this hall, but alas, only a very motivated employee.  Impressive, nonetheless.

Casa Lupita is 4 Stars with a bullet.  It may be the best of the Casas Mexicanas I have sampled to date.  

It will be hard to keep me away.

Visiting Skippack Village for the first time to sample the local vineyards fare at Winetober Fest (Thank you for the tix, Yelp Philly), we finally had our fill and needed a place to get off our feet, and eat something. 

After a few hours surrounded by fellow inebriants (have you ever been someplace where the entire ville is drunk?) we found Brasserie 73 in the center of town.  Even before walking in the door we passed a large patio out front. Had it been a warmer evening, that would have been our choice.  However, dining inside was an exceptionally pleasant experience.  The bar/dining room is large, with high ceilings, dark woods, and a definitely continental air. We had a corner table under the front windows where we could watch the winding down of the festival out on the street, while we admired the old world elegance within.  

Service was good with a knowledgeable waiter and bustling staff.  

The meal started off auspiciously with a very seasonal Pumpkin Bisque presented inside a locally grown pumpkin.  It was very nicely done with a creamy base and lots of veggies, sunflower seeds and bacon.  Really tasty!  The Salade du Maison was a spring mix with a light balsamic dressing.  Also decent.  We waited a bit longer than expected for the shared main course, Farfalle with Jumbo Shrimp, Tomato, Sundried and regular, Artichoke, Fennel, and Basil.  This dish was underwhelming given the ingredients, and what came before it.  It felt flat and lifeless. 

I inquired of our wait person about the inconsistency in the quality of the dishes.  He was prepared for it.  He explained that the establishment had gone through 3 ownership changes over the past few years, which accounted for changes in philosophy and ability.  There was a Head Chef change a few weeks ago.  They now had a primo chef from Philadelphia who was still using the old menu, and creating specials to complement it.  The new menu was not yet ready, so we were caught in the middle of the changeover.  The bisque was his baby - creative, rich and savory.  The pasta was off the old menu, and lacked energy.  If you read the other reviews beginning several years ago, you can see the ups and downs of the evolution here. 

The new menu will be installed by November 1, 2013.  I recommend everyone wait until after that date to come for a big meal or a party.  Before that, pay attention to the specials, as ordering off the old sheet will likely prove disappointing. 

Still, a beautiful place to dine. Great wine list. Wonderful space. High prices.

While most of the bakery sweets are heavy, their icing is wonderful.  I have sampled many of their buns, cookies, bars, cakes, and they are all fun to eat.

My favorites are the Apple Cake which reminds me of the densely moist version my Yiddish grandmother made on most holidays, and the Lemon Bars which are equal parts tart and sweet with powdered sugar dusted on top, and a firm crunchy base.  

Both are addicting and require self control to make them last.

Oregon Market appears to be the sibling of Vietnamese market in the Wing Phat Shopping Mall at 11th and Washington, although perhaps a bit cleaner and easier to navigate.  It is connected via the small inner space between stores to the Pho Ha Saigon restaurant, so it is convenient to shop and eat (or vice versa).  

It always amazes me who much more variety of produce these Asian grocers have than the typical American supermarket.  Green leafies from peas, cabbage, lettuce, and every other form of vegetation are washed and bagged for consumption with any one of a score of sauces that go so well with the sautéed end product that is often just discarded in the West.  What's more significant is that it all tastes great fresh from the wok.  

Quite an eye opener.

The fresh fish is ready for inspection and selection.  The boxes of live Blue Claws await their delectable demise. 

If you wonder if there is MSG in your dishes in Chinatown, just walk down the spice aisle and choose from among several large cans and boxes of the white powder.  It is more prevalent than salt.  

If you buy enough, when you go to the cashier you will be offered a free bottle or box of whatever they have in surplus that day.

You can take home a par finished pie from Mom Mom's and finish the job in your oven, but if you prefer to let the real pizza oven handle it, just sit down at one of the deuce hightops and let the chef's hands do it. But, if you're not in the mood for tomato pie, Mom also does excellent homemade soup and fresh salads for the light diet crowd. 

So, I went with a cup of roast chicken and rice soup and small salad with balsamic on the side. Both were very good, with the potage full of shredded bird and small grain white rice. The salad was big for a small, but brightly green and sprite. Eating in the small front of the shop was pleasant, as I was the only customer and could watch and chat with the proprietress as she worked. Although no longer in the store where the M. Night Shamalan movie, Signs, was shot, I still thought of the Mel Gibson scene where he too ate lunch in Mom's restaurant as he was discovering those crop circles in his fields. 

It took me a long time to make it to the new Mom Mom's, but glad I finally did. Now that I have an office down State Street I will make it a point to visit with regularity. 

Next time, the pizza!

Spice C (Noodles) is a solid choice if you feel the need for well drawn or cut handmade pasta from the Middle Kingdom.  They are all about made to order dishes that highlight the taste, texture and quality of freshly made soups that feature noodles as their base.  Dry dishes are also available, and there is the choice of "normal" or "Szechuan" style bowls if part of your zest for slurp includes a high capzasin quotient. 

We opted for the normal large bowl of Beef Soup with Hand Drawn Noodles with Wonton, their version of Szechuan Spicy Chicken, and Chicken, Pork & Shrimp Spring Rolls.  All three dishes were very good.  The soup was robust with well prepared beef broth and a nest of noodles hidden beneath the tranquil surface.  The thin skinned Wontons floated like pale goldfish.  Each aspect contributed fully to the final product.  Wontons were light and chewy.  The noodles required patience to lift and separate into manageable lengths. 

The Chicken plate was generously endowed with thin sliced meat that was cooked just enough to optimal tenderness, and approaching killer spice levels with a black bean chili sauce.  Plenty of veggies in the mix that had completely absorbed their surroundings.  So much pleasurable heat that we ordered another one to take home.  The Spring Rolls were loaded with filling and fried in clean cooking oil that had no leftover taste other than these ingredients.  

Spice C is worth a visit (or two) if you are looking for a soup oriented meal with a Chengdu flair.

Trenton has become a haven for excellent Latin American cuisine. Guatelinda on Clinton Avenue is one such locale where you can find totally authentic dishes that help you forget for a few moments that you are in the heart of Jersey, and feel that you are on the avenidas de Antigua Guatemala while you dine on delicious plates of nearly homemade fare.  

When I walked in around 2 in the afternoon last week, I was not only the only Gringo in the house; I was the only customer.  I asked the guys behind the counter if lunch was still being served.  They spoke not a word of Ingles, so I tried again in my mostly forgotten Espanol.  I was good enough to be understood, and after a few smiles and nods I picked a table and sat facing the front window with a view of the house around me.  The large menu offered Spanish and English descriptions, and even a few photos of the offerings.  The server was very friendly (and cute) and worked with me in her broken English to put together my lunch.  

The platter of Tacos Guatemaltecos arrived loaded with three double tortilla soft folded wheat 'tillas full of well spiced grilled pork, onion, pepper, cilantro, and a few things I could not identify.  On top of the tacos were a half avocado, sliced radish, and a hot ghost pepper.  I doctored each with the accompaniments and went to work.  The combination was wonderful, with each part of the combo playing olfactory harmonics.  Hot, soft, crunchy, chewy, textured, smooth and cool - all in each bite.  It was great and fun to eat. 

The JarritosTamarindo soda helped tamp down the overly hot spots.  Mexican pop is so much more flavorful than its northern counterparts.  It worked so well with its Guatemalan cousins. 

There is a lot more on the menu I want to taste.  I will go back to this, as well as the two or three other very good shops in the area, to satisfy my lust for Central American food.  Don't let the streetscape outside deter you.  Guatelinda is the real deal.

Shady Brook Farm has been an institution in the community for decades.  From a small farmers' market it has grown organically into a multifaceted event driven destination.  The family always comes up with new ideas to entertain on a grand scale. Our favorites are the Autumn Corn Field Maze, Pumpkin picking, and the Christmas Lights Night Drive.  All are done on a scale that let's you know it is not quite professionally polished, but done by the owners'/farmers' own hands.  

Sadly, a large part of the Farm will cease to exist in the next year to become a medical facilities center.  The pumpkin field will be no more.  

Be sure to visit Shady Brook Farm several times over the coming seasons, as the good times and culturally bucolic experiences will soon pass into history.

I hadn't been inside Cross Keys Diner in at least a decade, but walking in it seemed like time stood still.  Everything looked and felt the same.  

This had always been a community center where locals stopped in for a meal along with their neighbors and business associates to enjoy the home cooking and the hominess of the décor.  It still is.  I sat on a spinner directly in front of the kitchen entrance and was immediately serviced by all the workers who were picking up orders or refilling their coffee mugs.  

The menu is diverse, but the real deal is in their breakfast specials.  I opted for the Thunder Cakes, made with a mix of fruit and nuts and a substantial pancake mix that made even the short stack (2 pancakes) more than I could manage.  The melted butter and house syrup absorbed into the coarse texture of the pancakes like water on parched land.  The taste was healthy and filling.  I added more syrup three times during the meal as it continued to disappear.  Yes. It was way sweet enough.  

I couldn't finish the 2 cakes, and wondered how anyone could digest a full stack.  It did sit a little heavy in my stomach for a few hours, but not enough to reach a discomfort level.  I realized later in the day the true meaning of "Thunder."  No need to elaborate.

Cross Keys is still a meeting place that takes its cues from the 1980's, right down to the rock music of the era.  The staff is warm and enthusiastic. Definitely worth another round.

Royal Ashoka sits in a small commercial strip along Philmont Avenue in Northeast Philly.  If you are curious, go to their website for descriptions of their broad menu of north and south Indian delights, plus a nice video on top showing colorful veggies being tossed in a frying pan.  

The house is well appointed with linen and silverware, although the ceiling recessed lighting needs improvement, as it casts shadows at odd angles over the tables. Lower, more subtle sconces would be a big help.  Service is great, and it is apparent management is knee deep in helping out, and takes pride in their efforts.  

Our meal began with Ragada, a chaat variation with Potato Patties, Chickpeas, Yogurt, Mint and Tamarind.  It was delicious and the star of the show.  It was way more than expected, and it was hard to stop eating it to leave room for what was to come.  Gobi Manchurian was a battered and deep fried Cauliflower dish that comes from the mountainous area of North India, near the cultural borders with China.  It was reddish and spicy.  This dish was prepared with a heavy batter that coated the florets like you would find in a General Tso's dish in a Chinese  restaurant.  When I have had this before, there was no such batter, but the veggie was lightly breaded and exposed directly to the chili spice mix, holding a rich burning red and mildly crunchy finish.  The batter approach was not as good as the alternatives elsewhere.

Our last entre was Chicken Amwalla, a Mango Cream sauced Tikka.  This was a first taste of Mango in Indian food for me (other than Mango Lassis), and I liked its creamy fruitiness, and the curry mixed well with it.  The Chili Garlic Naan was great - fresh, hot and jalapeno/garlic richness.  Perfect sponge for sopping up the Amwalla sauce.  

We were really stuffed by this point, and had decided to take the rest home, when our server approached with complimentary Rice Pudding.  Talk about max overload!  I took a small sample.  It was wonderfully creamy sweet.  They were kind enough to understand that we just couldn't finish it and packed it up with the rest of our leftovers.  

Royal Asoka is very good.  Remove the drop ceiling and enhance the mood lighting, and it would be a more romantic destination.

I wandered on to High Street in Mt. Holly one morning earlier this week after getting out of court down the road.  I needed a jolt of Java, and Yelped to find Daily Grind at 48 High.  

It is a small shop, but appointed as most local cafes are with old plush chairs and a few tables around the room.  The bar sits in the back with a wall of chalkboard listing all the creations they are capable of concocting.  About a half dozen regulars lazed in the morning sun pouring through the large storefront windows.  They all knew each other and exchanged small talk. 

To honor the Thanksgiving Spirit, I opted for the special Pumpkin Latte. I hoped for a Cranberry Sauce Capa, but alas, they lacked the ingredients. It was fine; not overpoweringly pumpkined-out. It wasn't cheap at nearly $7, but I was willing to contribute to the success of the local economy in a small way.  There were some good looking muffins under glass on the counter, but I was not in need of the extra carbs. 

High Street looked really good from my corner stool.  I saw two micro breweries on the block, and knew I would be back sometime soon later in the day to check them out.  So nice to see this main street of the county seat of Burlington County, NJ, coming back to life.

People are waking up to the fact that the world of coffee can be as complex as that of beer or wine. The region, altitude, shade, temperature, water, etc., all contribute to your cup of coffee. Small batch roasters are springing up all over the place to sell directly to the public at retail establishments and cafes, and through chains of distribution to local, regional and national outlets. 

This is a business whose time has come.

Evermore Coffee Roasters on E. Union Street, Burlington, NJ has set up shop on the first floor of an old row house, and done a remarkable job renovating the space into an old century feeling comfortable house, with expresso machine up front, and a larger sitting room in back, with their roaster against the far wall.  Colors are soft gray/blue, and the windows let in a filtered light that provide a warm and dated ambiance commensurate with the age of the building.  Like the feeling here. 

My cup of Congo pour over took a short while to brew, but when I picked it up at the counter, it was hot and steaming.  First sip announced a dark, mysterious roasted bean soup with a kick in the head sensibility. It took no prisoners.  Liked it a lot, even with its strong acidity. At $3.75 for a fairly small self-logoed cup, it was a bit cher for the quantity, but worth the experience. The offer of a refill at a reasonable charge (not to mention gratis), would have enhanced the value proposition. The near-lack of bakery goods or other light fare, had me packing up to move on quickly after finishing my drink.  The opportunity to enjoy any of these options would go a long way to establishing Evermore as a destination for the café crowd that often likes a little nosh with their bean wash. 

Still, an interesting and caffeine-oriented stop on the back streets of Burlington is something to savor.  

Street parking. Across from Brickwall Tavern.

You have to really want to get to Mood Indian Restaurant because the approach is a challenge.

 When 95 South was jammed south of Girard, I was able to jump off, zigzag my way to Spring Garden, make a left on N.4th, and start looking for my destination.  There it was, but at first view it seemed to be behind bars.  Fences and security everywhere.  Reminded of prison gates.  Quickly realized all that parking was for residents, and the street meters were the only nearby option.  At 12 minutes for .25 on a Saturday night, I fished out all my quarters and fed the hungry metal mouth. Then located the narrow opening in the fence and the walkway leading to the resto.  I hoped I had all the necessary credentials to get through customs. 

The boss was squeegeeing his front windows as I walked up to the door.  I was impressed that he had not delegated the work, but took pride in his shop's appearance, knowing that first impressions are so important.  Stepping inside after confirming I had arrived with Ali, I was taken by the crispness of the white linen tablecloths and red napkins.  The space had high industrial ceilings, giving an open sensation.  I was shown to the table and sat down to await the arrival of my friends.  I was alone there at 6 pm; thinking that Indians/Pakistanis prefer late dinners.  I liked the vibe as I perused the menu and took in the details.  

After V & M arrived, we ordered several dishes to get a cross section of the kitchen fare.  Samosa Chaat, Chicken Malabar for apps; Salmon Tandoori, Chicken Makhani, Baingan Bharta(Eggplant), a Bread Basket mix, and Basmati Rice as entrees.   Mango Lassi for me, and Sweet Lassi for M.   All were good to excellent. Most memorable were the Chicken Malabar which was grilled and breaded with Coconut, the Samosa Chaat, which had all the ingredients of a Samosa, but reformulated into an open dish full of Potato, Peas, various crunchy chips and spices. Additionally, the Baingan Bharta was very well done with a complementary heat/sweet texture, and the Makhani was tender in a Tomato base curry that was requested hot spiced and delivered fully.  The Salmon Tandoori was the most colorful dish (see photo), but the fish was a tad dry and the veggies and spices so overpoweringly good, that the mild taste of the Salmon was somewhat hidden by its pushy roommates. 

All in all, a very good meal in a pleasant environment.  By the time we left around 8, the room was full, along with our stomachs.  We ended up taking a large portion home with us.  

I will definitely return once they let me out on parole.

Nice country store feel for locally sourced ice cream studio.  Super friendly and informative people. 
When I asked the difference between the Vanillas - Madagascar, Tahitian, and another exotic island label, I was told that the most "vanilla"-flavor was the Madagascar version, while the others were either too light in flavor or more of a marshmallow sentiment.  Went African Isle with a scoop of Blueberry Lemon. 

Creamy texture, full blown taste bud involvement. 

Instant smiles and satisfaction.  

Clearly, a labor of love expressed in imaginative combinations and high quality execution, wrapped up in a easy to miss village ambiance shop.  

The road sign is too small, so unless you know it's there, or have visited Carousel Gardens for other reasons, very easy to miss.  

Worth finding.

NOTE 8.28.2013 - This ice cream just won a 10 Best In USA award from the Huffington Post.  Congratulations!

Okay!

I admit it.  The Home Depot has grown on me.  It still is a big box destroyer of family hardware stores, but now that so many of those mom & pop stores are gone, where are we to go for a choice of power tools, ladders, and expandable screws? 

I found myself there this weekend as part of a home project to install curtains over a French door.  As all such jobs become, it was more than originally bargained for.  Now, that I had the actual drapes in hand, I discovered that my old electric drill was not in great shape after twenty years, and more importantly, that my handy step stool had been lost in divorce.  

First stop - Power Tools.  I felt the rush of adrenaline upon seeing all the sleek steel packaged for a quick date.  Once one of the Home Depot dudes approached to assist, and he explained the difference between NiCad and Lithium batteries, I was the possessor of a new Ryobi power drill/driver, complete with battery pack and charger.  Sexy lime green and black.  

Second stop - Ladders.  I am tall, but for working at over 7 feet to screw in curtain hardware, I needed help, and my old standby step stool had been purloined in a property settlement deal.  So, I checked a few here, and selected a GorillaLadders three step aluminum and rubber folding stepper for a great price, that I had to admit was much better (and safer) than the old one.  

Third step - Get 'er done!  The Ryobi worked like a dream with variable speeds controlled by my trigger finger, and direction reversal with the push of a button.  I climbed up my new stairs and was able to complete the task with relative ease and speed.  

Amazing what the right tools can accomplish in the hands of a rank and clumsy amateur.

Gotta love The Living Room Café on South 5th Street! 

This corner breakfast/brunch nook is comfortable in its simplicity.  Expanded into the storefront next door, the dining area offers wooden tables and chairs along two walls and a little sofa and easy chair ensemble up front.  Big table toward the back for larger groups, or, as on the morning we were there, a place for a teacher to tutor her young student.  Wonderful human relations.  Cool back patio in the space between the two buildings. 

The shop is run by Zack, who triples as host, cashier and chef.  He has everything covered with his engaging personality and obvious passion for his enterprise.  He brews the excellent coffee, takes orders, cooks and serves them with equal aplomb.  The impression after a few minutes settling in, is that you are visiting an old friend or first cousin who has welcomed you into his home.  Can't beat it!  

The menu offers creative takes on American standards, and uses locally sources ingredients to the greatest extent possible.  Too, the names of the dishes pay homage to known personalities in the greater community.  Where to begin?  We opted for the Wake & Bake Burrito and Baked Cinnamon Apple French Toast.  Both were solid choices.  Baked eggs are used rather than fried, making for a drier and healthier meal.  Mixed with house salsa, black beans and sour cream, tightly wrapped and grilled in a tortilla, this breakfast burrito was a tasty substantial morning feast.  

The French Toast used a light, thick cut slice of (apple?) bread, with Chinese flat bottomed spoons full of walnuts and shredded coconut, and a small pitcher of maple syrup, to apply as you see fit.  Very good idea, but for my full enjoyment, the bread itself lacked the coarse texture I prefer, as well as the caramelization that occurs when egg, sugar and hot iron meet on the grill, that crisps up the edges for added flavor and crunch (Perhaps, because frying on the grill is not their thing?). 

Regardless, The Living Room Café is a cozy home to hang out in while eating your early day meal.  Def worth a visit or three.

Tony Luke's on Oregon Avenue close by the Sports Complex is as "Philly" as Philly gets. 

Tucked in under the concrete and steel of elevated Rt. 95, it feels like a Lilliputian railroad car of a restaurant in the uber scale of its environment.  In winter the heavy plastic and aluminum walls are attached to keep the patrons warm.  I had the feeling of being in an ant farm next to the glass wall.  None of which detracted from my first time enjoyment of this iconic cheesesteak emporium. 

Famished after skipping regular dinner to attend a way-to-long business meeting at a local hotel, I would have eaten just about anything.  Lucky for me, my pal suggested Tony Luke's.  We were there in minutes and I drove into the small parking lot next door.  The aroma of fresh (and stale) grease flooded my senses, squeezing my salivary glands, much like a vampire prepared for the first bite knowing it will bring strength and relief.  My mouth involuntarily hung open with jaws ready to clamp down on a great steak sandwich.  Melodies of Rocky Balboa rang in my head.  

I had the Italian Special Steak with Sautéed Spinach.  It reached the take out window about 10 minutes later, tightly rolled up in white paper with Tony Luke's logo emblazoned across it.  We sat at one of the red tables, slit the tape and unwound the packaging.  First glance was of a long Italian torpedo roll, held shut by the former pressure, now free to open and display its steamy contents.  The brown of the steak; the dark green of the olive oil induced heavily garliced Spinach; the melted ooze of the Provolone - all combined to create an exquisite moment of anticipation.  

The first chomp took in as much of the tip of the sandwich as my mouth could hold.  Garghhhh...womp.....grind....chew....swallow....Repeat. The bread was crusty and fresh, belying the following softness of the steak, cheese and spinach.  Texturally perfect! The sequence of the unfolding parts only overtaken by the totality of the whole.  Truly existential. 

It was great, but to be completely honest, the Spinach was over salted with the garlic, and was too dominant a flavor on my palate.  Everything else was awesome, and the Birch Beer a smooth compensation for the sodium chloride load.  

This is a Def place to return.  The overall gestalt is wonderfully and uniquely Philadelphia urban chic, as cool today as it was decades before.

Located in a nicely refurbished shop that previously had been a Chinese restaurant, Yardley Bagel Cafe in the Makefield Shopping Center, is a welcome addition to the area (Yardley is a more toney address, thus the name).  A corner space with windows on two sides, it is a comfortable place to bagel up with decent java and settle into a booth with friends or on a metal stool along a wooden shelf anchored to an exposed brick wall to do your daily reading. They really did a very good job creating a welcoming environment. 

YBC does most everything bagel, with many choices of cream cheese, smoothies and sandwiches to match the multiple choice of well appointed rounders. A look at the bagel bins shows that these folks take pride in their product. They are plump and loaded with toppings so much so that the actual top crust cannot be seen beneath. The generosity is appreciated. The prices are competitive, and perhaps lower than the other bagels outlets in the area. My onion bagel, butter and swiss, with cuppa joe brought me change from my fiver. 

My breakfast looked great with the layers exposed in cross section and little onion bits falling onto the plate with each lift and bite. While I prefer a crustier skin offset by a light and airy center, rather than the mono-textural bread presented here, the onion flakes were like savory poprocks that compensated a bit for that shortcoming. 

Yardley Bagel Cafe won't replace Bagel Train (really in Yardley) for my favorite bagel in the area, but it is a cool place when hanging out is part of the experience. 

Excellent job!

Peter Pan Diner is long gone.  Nottingham Diner lasted for about six weeks. The most recent incarnation at this old kitchen locale opened about a month ago as the White Horse Diner.  After dropping off a client at home apres court I decided to drop in for a late lunch and to see how the old gal looked.  

This is one of the smaller Jersey diners, with a short counter of about six spinners, booths along the front wall, and a small dining room around the side.  Enough parking out back.  It looked like the new owners spent some shekels cleaning up the place.  Everything was spanking bright.  My server, Larissa, was, too.  

There was plenty on the menu, but as a first timer, I went with the "Lunch Specials" list.  All the options were $6.99 with soup/salad, fries and a pickle.  At that price, they were cutting their margins to the bone.  I opted for their California Burger.  

It arrived on a large platter.  The burger was housed in a shiny-topped egg bread roll, and a large slice of tomato, red onion and wad of iceberg under the hood.  The beef seemed fresh and came out hot. A shot of ketchup, and I was in business.  It held together very well under my onslaught.  Little escaped as I clamped down again and again with gizunta bites like a dinosauric carnivore. It all came together smashingly well.  

While I didn't mistake this burger for fine dining, it was solid and enjoyable.  The fries were hot and crisp. The coleslaw, coleslaw. 

That was more than enough to make me a happy fan.

Thinking about bringing the family for Thanksgiving dinner.

First & Ten Sports Pub doesn't look like much driving by this southwestern-looking one story brick house on Hamilton Avenue.  Aside from remembering that this joint has been a bar in many different disguises for years, I would not have bothered to slow down to catch the name on the sign out front.  

But, I did, and looked it up on Yelp to see what the story was.  Reviews were mostly positive, with highlights on their wings and other bar food, while somewhat less than enthusiastic about the beer selection, despite being called a "Pub."  Walls with HDTVs for sports watching were also a clear part of the description.  What the hey?!  It looked worthy of a lunch drop in, so I found myself in their ill-maintained parking lot on a hot sunny sultry Wednesday afternoon.  It was dark inside despite several windows, and it took a few seconds for my eyes to adjust.  

I saw a pretty large "U"-shaped bar, with room for near 20 barstools, two well stations for mixing drinks, and a beer pour stand with at least 10 handles.  From the look of them most were domestic labels, but a few made it across borders north and south.  Lots of HiDef screens up high tuned into the Olympics or local sports.  The walls were rough hewn pine panels, and the ceiling exposed painted beams with beer logos hanging from them.  This was, indeed, a dive bar dressed up for a sports crowd.  Nothing wrong with that at all.  In fact, it was pretty nice in a dingy beer drinking afternoon sort of way.  That was surely the intention of the half dozen other dudes who were trying to keep out of the sun.  Full sized pool table in the back looked like it had a few stories it could tell.  The bartender was working alone and seemed to know everyone, but me.  She approached to inquire, and brought my drink and menu with pace.  

Not in the mood for wings & brew when I knew I had to return to the office, I opted for their Thin Crust Tomato, Mozza and Basil Pie Special @ $6.50.  I do love a good bar pie when the chef knows what she's doing.  It came out about 10 minutes later, and it was a beauty. Cracker thin crust. Slightly sweet sauce with fresh strips of Basil spread around atop the melted Mozza cheese, and sweet Cherry Tomatoes cut in half lengthwise spread strategically across the entire surface.  Very attractive.

How was the pie?  While not at the level of Jo Jo's, Ivy Tavern, nor Pete's, it was still a solid wheel with plenty of flavor and excellent crust.  I would not hesitate to have another along with a basket of Garlic Wings on my next visit.  Sufficient beer choices to keep me happy, although this is not a beer lovers paradise.

PRO TIP - Be careful driving around the building so as not to cause tire or alignment issues.  The back lot needs help.

Definitely time for an upgrade!
I have become a fan. 4 Stars with a bullet.

Surprising good Chinese cuisine at this basement kitchen associated with the Asia Market on North 11th Street, Chinatown, Philadelphia. There may have been change of ownership and this is a first visit, but if the past owners were even better on the wok than these folks, then I missed something pretty special, because I was quite happy with what we ate this night. 

Amazingly convenient if grocery shopping of Chinese ingredients is your reason for being there in the first place. Just go hungry, eat, and then shop.  Worked well for us. It is not too far fetched to think that if the Tasty kitchen runs out of something, they just walk a few feet into the supermarket and pick up what they needed. Symbiotic. 

We ordered the wonton soup, salt baked squid and roast pork on rice. All were very good to excellent, despite the somewhat dank surroundings. The large bowl of soup was loaded with more than a dozen freshly handmade wontons with ground pork filling.  The beef consume was hot with a pleasant flavor.  Made for fun slurping. The squid was cut into fairly large pieces and coated with a light flour, salt and pepper breading.  It was tender and juicy. Especially enjoyed the scallion and sliced jalapenos the dish was mixed with.  The flavor/texture profile became quite animated on the palate. This was the star of the show.  The roast pork had a nice ruddy bark and was lean cut.  Not quite Ting Wong Restaurant level, but close enough. We ended up taking about half of the dry dishes home.  

With all the wonderful alternatives on the street above, there is not that much reason to go subterranean for a solid meal, unless price motivates you highly. The numbers on the menu were very reasonable, and it is easy to imagine that Tasty Place does a large business with students and others on a budget.  

You certainly get more than you paid for here.

Great reuse of a 19th Century firehouse in the heart of Norristown, now a museum and distillery for premium vodka, whiskey, gin, and special batches of other unique blends. Three story open barroom where once horse drawn firewagons were housed, with upper floor sleeping room for those once on duty and a rear space full of stainless steel distilling tanks and vats. Fascinating place I wish I had time to explore with a knowledgeable guide.

Maybe next time, but tonight we were there for a political fundraiser for a local county official seeking reelection. Judging by his choice of party venue, the open bar and the look of everyone present to support him and wish him success, he has a strong chance of re-election. Even the local congressman was there to wish him well.

With speeches and a good buffet (and that open bar) there was opportunity for limited sipping and light dining in the midst of the very loud din of conversation  between the soapboxing. The distillery itself remained background to an excellent soiree. 

Will definitely return for more tasting and a tour.

This fairly new freestanding Dunkin' Donuts in the wilds of Eastampton, NJ, was empty when I arrived for a post court late breakfast and java. In my recent experience, the proliferation of DDs has diluted the quality and consistency of the signature products, so that the coffee is often harsh and undrinkable in some shops, and still quite good in others.  Same thing for donuts. Some have good ones. Some don't.  As everyone is trained the same way, it comes down to water quality and cultural familiarity with sweet rounders.

This joint was pretty good.  There was a small communications problem, but what I ultimately received (breakfast sandwich and joltin' joe) were both hot and tasty.  

No complaints.  And, a nice facility with a large lounge area for those who want to get some work done, or take a comfortable nap - perhaps, both.

Salute Ristorante is another in the new and tasty options in the renaissance of Morrisville, Pa. 
It sits on West Trenton Avenue, where Centre Fruit used to be and next to the venerable dive Morrisville Tavern.  Don't let the neighborhood deter you, because Salute is a very good Italian shop, with dark modern tones, and interesting menu.  I stopped in for lunch today after having it on my Bookmark list for about a year.  

This is not a pizzeria by any stretch, in fact the only way you get a tomato pie is when it is offered as a special.  This place is all about a creative kitchen that spins out fresh and well considered dishes with panache. It is pricey for Morrisville, but the quality of the offerings made me forget that I was still in this struggling river town.  If they can do that, they are indeed, approaching magical.  

Lunch included a small bowl of soup, and I chose the 16 Bean alternative.  It was a solid performer, although I confess to not counting the beans. They were well cooked and soft enough to show they were simmered a long time.  The elbow macaroni in the mix contributed to the interesting textures.  I could easily imagine a soup and salad return visit. 

My eggplant parmesan sandwich became a platter upon request.  Didn't want all that bread, and my table had a large half loaf delivered up front with my water.  I was more than happy with a couple of its large sesame slices and a swipe of cool butter.  The plate was beautifully presented.  The chunky red sauce and white mozzarella covered the unbreaded thin slices of nightshade like an abstract painting framed by the square white ceramic.  Heavy silver toned utensils made short work of the cutting and lifting.  The taste was very nice, with the homemade sauce providing moral support to the veggie and cheese.  It might have been a tad salty, but not enough to detract from the pleasure of eating. 

Salute is a worthy addition to the growing (still nascent) restaurant scene in Morrisville.  I raise a glass of Sangiovese to your good fortune.

Ila Mae's Restaurant sits right off the intersection of Broad and Market in the heart of Trenton. Parking is next to impossible in this neighborhood, so be prepared to walk a few blocks if you want to chow down in a relatively undiscovered gem.  

I stopped in on a cold, icy morning in February.  There were only a few people there and I settled in in the front dining room in front of the large HDTV sitting high on the opposite wall.  The furnishings were Spartan, but the space was clean and inviting. My server, David, handed me the large menu and I decided to have breakfast as it was still being offered.  

I asked about their French Toast and their Breakfast Sandwiches.  David smiled.  He alerted me to the presence of their French Toast Sandwich - Short Stack with 2 Eggs and Beef or Turkey Sausage inside the well grilled bread.  No pork products here.  The meal arrived in about 15 minutes, and I realized that each meal was prepared separately by the chef/owner.  The two people ahead of me were served individually, and then mine was put together.  No problem. I was not in a rush to return to the inclement weather. 

The French Toast was good on its own, but when combined with the spicy Beef Sausage and Scrambled Eggs it took on another identity which was tasty and fun to eat. The extra small pitcher of syrup came in handy to pour over the sausage when I opened the top of the creation.  Its strong flavor was nicely offset by the sweetness.  A sprinkle of black pepper on the eggs completed the effort.  

This was a very good breakfast from atmosphere, through bottomless coffee mug, and everything in between.  Their lunch and dinner menu looks very interesting, and I hope to return to explore it in the near future.

The approach to Concerto Fusion takes you past a 60's era Dairy Queen, over old railroad tracks laid down when Fairless Works smelted steel by the megaton, and if you drive across the Delaware River from Trenton, on the girders of the famous "Trenton Makes" Bridge.  Quite a history lesson. 

Then, you pull into the parking lot for Concerto and behold the façade of the side-facing entrance, all bright orange and red lanterns - like a cross between Miami Beach Ocean Drive and Lantern Festival in Xiamen. Pleasantly disconcerting cultural mix.  And, perhaps, that was the intention of the owners of this Asian fusion establishment, so neatly tucked away in a dark corner of Morrisville.  Get you slightly off-centered as you approach and enter their well appointed den, and prepare you for an experience both gastronomically and architecturally that is also designed to unbalance you.  

The room is spacious with curved walls, flowing koi pond, mirrors and raised dining area.  The small bar sits in the middle of the room, almost invisible, yet with a half dozen stools for those who prefer cold liquid fusion.  Similarly, the sushi area is in a corner behind the entrance and bar wall, where a solitary chef moves silently and efficiently cutting, molding, wrapping and presenting his artistry.  

We sat at a corner table closest to the sushi works and the kitchen, near enough to see what was going on, but not be a distraction.  The ambiance was of quiet confidence and appealing tones.  There was no doubt that a lot of thought had gone into the layout, and that the vision was carried out exceptionally well.  Even several years of operation and breaking in, while noticeable, had not detracted from the effect.   

So, how was the food?  Glad you asked. 

We appetized with the Hawaiian Tropical Roll (Eel, Avocado, Tobiko, Soy Wrap, lightly crusted Tempura and pleasing secret sauce). It arrived slightly warm with a mild crunch, and was a very enjoyable opening gambit.  Wasabi, Ginger and Soy discretely on the side of the plate. I would have preferred the naturally white ginger to the pink colored alternative, but that is a very small minus. 

From there we selected from the Thai offerings: Pad Thai with Chicken and Pineapple Curry Fried Rice with Shrimp.  Both arrived on large round white plates in amounts beyond our capacities to consume.  They were good and satisfying, if not the best of breed that can be found in ethnic restos specializing in this cuisine. Nonetheless, we were happy to bring home the rest for another meal.  Most pleasingly, both had large quantities of nuts; whole cashews for the rice, and ground peanuts for the noodles, and plenty of shrimp and chicken, respectively. 

Service was provided by our waiter who also was bartender this evening.  He kept busy, and was not the most engaging sort.  He seemed a bit ill at ease interacting with us.  No biggie.  Forgivable. 

The only annoyance was the charge for hot tea.  Yes, quality tea is more expensive that the orange pekoe take out variety, but at $2.50 per green tea bag and a pot of hot water, it is off-putting.  That generates more profit than the bar. Makes it worthwhile to plan ahead and bring your own tea. Check. Your move. 

Overall, while not the best sushi and Thai dishes in the world, everything we had was enjoyable.  The design elements within and without made it unusual and had the desired impact of slightly altering perception to be a unique environment much farther away from daily reality than a drive into Morrisville would suggest.

Down to Earth Cafe in the Glenwood Center, Perkesie, Pa., is exactly that - a chillaxing joint where locally sourced creative breakfasts and lunches and excellent coffee induce comfort and good times. 

We were looking for a colorful autumn drive up county on Saturday morning, with a nice destination as the goal. While the Bucks foliage had not peaked, Down to Earth certainly had. We walked in to a large room with heavily eurothaned wood slab tables, mix and match coffee mugs and huge blackboard with the daily specials. The shop wasn't crowded and we found a table across from the cashier, where orders are taken and paid for before pouring the coffee and settling in. 

The first sip of the Speakeasy Roaster House Blend signaled we were in for something great. This Montgomery County company turns out amazing beans. I found myself working it over my tongue to identity it's subtleties like I would a glass of wine.

Superb!  I purchased a bag of ground for home.

My Breakfast Roll (Scrambled Eggs, Bacon, Green Pepper, Provolone and Jalapeño/Tomato Jam on fresh crunchy "Shad" roll ) was a mouthful of interesting flavor and fun. Really liked it. The Pork Roll and Cheese on Kaiser was solid, but nothing exceptional. 

Service is personable, if slow. The delivery of the meals is a bit disorganized. The workers behind the counter seem to lose sight of the seated customers and are unaware of their needs. This is sometimes a problem with semi self serve plans. 

Still, a superior breakfast and top notch java make Down to Earth Cafe a real find.

Antiques, smoothies and coffee mug club add to the feel of wholesome community displayed here.

The spinners at the counter are wobbly, and there is a photo of the marriage of JKF and Jackie O. on the wall, but Kitty's Luncheonette is as real as it gets for traditional breakfasts and lunches in this part of Philadelphia.
