They don't know from brunch, and they close before happy hour; so don't bookmark it for your weekend morning meal, nor try to stop in after work.  This is a 7 to 3:30 corner grill that had a few dozen thick scrapple slices frying to a dark brown while I drank their Ellis Coffee and awaited my first taste of their french toast.  

The house has about a dozen tables in two rooms and eight spinning stools along the counter that overlooks the chef workspace.  It was about half full of neighborhood personalities who seemed to know each other as they were greeted by name.  The server, a lovely young woman who is Kitty's niece, took care of me, and filled me in on the history of the institution, open since 1952! 

Yes. It looks its age, with family photos on the walls, and original floors, walls and stools.  Either you get the deeply rubbed in culture here, or you don't. With its gritty charm and surprisingly good food, it is easy to develop a crush on Kitty, and want to visit her often. She is as authentic as the day is long.  My three slices of thick egged toast were very good.  A little sweet from the vanilla and sugar in the mix, and a little crispy on the edges where the hot steel melted that sugar and left its hardened residue.  They know how to do FT here. $5.50 was a happy price. The java was strong and a little rough (bitter), but nothing to complain about. Again, her Joe is straight up Bunn-O-Matic.  No expresso options with Kitty. 

Kitty's is very close to I-95, and an easy on/off if you want to stop before reaching Center City from the north. Not sure she could handle becoming a hit on the breakfast bookmark circuit, especially on weekends, so if you want to check her out, come on a weekday morning when the regular crowd is thinner.  

But, if you like hard stop traditional breakfast without any frills, give this old girl a go.

Hua Kang Health Center is a first rate Chinese style massage spa sitting unexpectedly in the Marrazzo Shopping Center on Parkway Avenue in Ewing, NJ. It is bigger than most I have visited, with ten private rooms, each well appointed and very clean.  

Their staff is well trained in traditional Chinese technique, plus Swedish and a little Shiatsu.  Lily, my masseuse, asked if I would like her to work deep tissue and walk on my back.  No problem.  She went from my shoulders to the soles of my feet like a dancer.  Very effective. With practically every step I felt/heard a snap, crackle and pop as she stretched me out. 

Hot stones and steam towels alternated where I had the most discomfort, followed by her forearm and elbows probing the facets and pushing apart the disks in my spinal column.  

It was an excellent, relaxing and therapeutic massage. I think I even fell asleep. At a buck a minute, it was a fair price.  After shoveling snow and feeling the sciatic stress, it was great to feel such prompt relief.  

If they had a sauna or two, served fruit and hot tea, it would be just about perfect.

Fraternal Order of Police Lodge # 5 is the labor union for Philadelphia Police and Sheriffs Officers, providing a broad range of bargaining and social support services for officers both working and retired. 

As part of their effort they have a nice size lounge for officers, families and friends at their Caroline Avenue facility.  Additionally, they have a large banquet hall available for rental to outside organizations.  It was in this capacity that I attended the Jefferson Dinner sponsored by the Bucks County Democratic Committee earlier this week.  The hall was spacious with high ceilings and chandeliers.  The food presented in buffet style was better than average for a mass feeding of about 300 people.  We are not talking haute cuisine, but solid Italian American fare with Chicken Francaise, Baked Ham, Roast Beef options, as well as tasty Pasta and nice Caesar Salad.  I ate well after listening to a few too many speeches from candidates in the up coming election. As this is not a political site, no need to discuss who and what was said.  

If I had to organize a large event including dinner, drinks, dancing, and speaking in the Lower Bucks, Philadelphia region, I would certainly consider Lodge 5 as a good locale and forum.  I was very satisfied with the over ambiance of the place, as well as the food. 

 Too, when tired of the windbags, you can slip into the large lounge and take a seat at the long bar for a quick round or two, surrounded by Philly's Finest.  Nice to have a drink feeling secure. 

 Feel free to buy a round for the men and women in blue, and thank them for everything they do for us to keep us safe.

Patel Brothers is a family owned small chain of Indian grocery stores in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.  The operation in Bensalem, PA, on Street Road doesn't look like much on the outside located in a rather forlorn strip center, but once inside the vast array of produce, frozen and dry goods is fairly amazing. 

For a first visit we were pleasantly surprised at the quantity and quality of the fresh produce.  We found it to be better priced than our regular supermarkets and very competitive with our local farmers' market.  We ended up stocking up on some very interesting south Asian veggies, especially hot peppers. Additionally, we picked up a few frozen items (garlic naan, veggie samosas) just to check them out, and some henna for natural hair color applications.  On our way out we marveled at the low cost of the five bags we hauled out of there. 

The aisles were very well stocked, and it was possible to buy rice and flour in bulk.  There were many customers on Sunday morning and it was a bit crowded moving through the store, but this presented the opportunity to talk to some folks about their experience at Patel Brothers, as well as their recommendations for what to purchase.  Very useful.  Staff was ever present and helpful in finding what we sought. 

This was a first visit to Patel Brothers and exposure to all the amazing possibilities present in a good Indian grocery.  Many return visits are likely.

One of the nicer Asian markets in Philly proper, although there are very good H Marts out in the Northeast and Elkins Park.  The place is large, well lit, and stocked with all those things that have never been heard of by the Acmes and Giants of the world.  Need a regional chili sauce from Chongqing?  They have a variety of them.  Want thin noodles from Thailand?  Just ask for it.  Jonezing for sweet pea leaves for that special garlic recipe?  Yup.  It's there.  Need fresh fish for your father-in-law?  The red snapper is right off the boat. 

The prices can be erratic, and sometimes the aisles are so overloaded with goods that two carts can't pass each other, but if that really bothers you, you probably never went to the markets in any town in Asia.  That's just the way it is.  Sell by dates important to you?  It may be better to just close your eyes. 

Staff is very helpful and multilingual.  They even have a small apothecary to save you the trip to the herb shops in Chinatown.  Even had Wood Lock Oil.

Olden Avenue Deli has been sitting across the street from Coleman Kia Subaru for several decades...and it looks it. 

The joint could use a makeover.  A coat of paint hides a multitude of sins. But, if you don't look too closely at the condition of the store, and just focus on the food that comes from behind the counter, you can almost imagine that you are in a cool old joint that really creates some first rate sandwiches for breakfast and lunch.  Management is very friendly and accommodating, and have time to chat and joke while they work.  The four or five tables make eating on site easy. Otherwise, takeout is the name of the game.

My homemade chicken salad sandwich on fresh rye bread was a strong contender for Lunch of the Week.  Moist, mayoed just enough. Piled with shredded lettuce and slices of tomato. My teeth cleaved through it, feeling each layer expose its secrets. Not an ounce of fat nor cartilage to be found. Along with the Calypso Southern Peach Lemonade, it was a very enjoyable and inexpensive lunch. Came in under $8, and I easily could have wrapped up half the Sammy for another snack.  

Olden Avenue Deli also does breakfast.  I will be checking that out soon enough, but as sandwich places go, it should be on your list.  Just don't spend too much time looking behind the counter or at the outside trim, which definitely need work.

The old Post office in Main Street, Yardley, PA, is the size of a large closet. It still has a wall of copper coated post office boxes, and sells stamps and packaging materials. It is really only a substation to the main US Postal Service facility on West Trenton Road in Morrisville. 

It retains it's charm and historical ambience, despite the fact that services are limited and parking can be an issue out front of in back. 

If you find yourself in the Borough of Yardley for a medical visit, breakfast of early happy hour, it is worth a few minutes of your time to stop in to enjoy the atmosphere and pick up a few sheets of forever commemorative stamps. 

It will have you thinking of the way your grandparents saw the world.

Almost everyone appreciates the cause of Mission BBQ,  support of our military and first responders. They are honored daily and even given premium parking right at the front door. But, what about the quality of the meats and sides offered in the kitchen? 

From my point of view the ribs, brisket, sausage, chicken and the savory sides, are all good to very good, but as with most outlets in the northeast, not nearly as excellent as available in the American South and Southwest. We seem to lack the cultural history that creates the awesome smoked meats and heavily flavorful sauces found in every back road smokehouse from Virginia to Florida and Georgia to Texas. Still, Mission is not a bad substitute when time for a road trip is lacking. 

I enjoyed the Baby Backs I sucked off the bone last weekend. The meat was tender, even if lacking crusty bark, smoke rings and thick, luscious sauces that are the true sign of authenticity. The Texas Twang and Tupelo Honey Heat were too thin to hold fast to the ribs, but remained at the bottom of the tray available for repeated dipping. My side choices of BBQ Beans and Cole Slaw were alright and completed the meal nicely. The corn bread was a small thin square, and somewhat dry, but sweet enough to remind me of what the real thing tasted like. 

So, until I have time to visit my sister in Newport News, my former bro-lo in Charlotte or friends in Austin, Mission will have to do. The folks there are friendly enough to make it a positive experience.

Malay Thai Kitchen is still operating with a temporary sign out front, but that doesn't mean they don't know how to run a first class Malaysian and Thai restaurant. That they certainly do very well. 

It begins with the deep Asian décor of the dining room. Although simple, it has Shoji screens on the walls, and black & white photographs spread around that add to the cultural flavor.  It is a calming space, but for the out of place loud contempo western music blasting from the high speakers. How much better it would be with soft flute, strings and bells, to go with the Jasmine tea and delectable menu. 

I ordered Basil Thai Noodles with chicken, at a 3/5 heat level. It arrived looking great on the white ceramic plate. The taste was excellent with plenty of Thai basil, peppers, onion, sprouts and chicken in addition to the broad noodles that offered plenty of surface area to hold the rich sauce. While I learned that the third heat level was more a one to my tongue, that did not detract from the wonderful taste. Really liked it a lot. I am sure they would have provided chili sauce if requested. 

It was great to find another southeast Asian kitchen had arrived in southern Bucks County. It joins the rare few other pioneers who have staked a claim to broadening our cultural and culinary horizons. I will return for much more.  

Congratulations on your recent launch, and great fortune in the future!

Stopped in this Wawa Deluxe to take advantage of their free coffee celebration today. It seemed busy for 3:00 on a Thursday afternoon, perhaps due to this special deal, or maybe they are always so popular. Plenty of nametagged staff working their takeout food operation, and others scurrying to keep everything stocked for customers. 

The Cuban java was quite good, although somehow the Tanzanian African dispenser was empty despite all the attention being paid to this gratis offer. Too, their donut display was loaded and advertising a 6 for $3 bargain (I couldn't resist). 

The store was clean and I was in and out in under 10 minutes. Parking was a breeze and the access through the side streets rather than the main street helped keep traffic moving smoothly and safely. 

These Super Wawas are onto something. Providing a small discount on gasoline and standardized sandwiches, soups, snacks, drinks and solid coffee, in an attractive environment that keeps everyone moving quickly, is a great idea whose time has comes. Taking them off the turnpike and into the community is clearly better than just the convenience stores we have in most places now. The only thing we should worry about is the natural business inclination to demand too much of a good thing, thus creating a glut of copycat roadside service centers in the wrong places that compete for the same dollars. 

I wouldn't mind having one near by, but not right next door.

El Limon - Norristown is another in the locally born chain of solid Mexican restaurants that seem to be expanding almost monthly. It is a smallish shop compared to most of the others, but the quality of the kitchen is just as high. 

I stopped in after an office meeting nearby. I found it decorated with colorful tables and carved back wood chairs depicting the beauty of the traditional town square with church steeples, red tile roofs and flowering bourganvillas. The Muzac was a bit too loud for dining, but surely the staff enjoyed it throughout the day.

My lunch of their tacos dorado (golden fried tacos) was very interesting and tasty. Stuffed within the rolled "flutes" were mashed potatoes, grilled chicken, and cheese. The softness just behind the crunch was fun and unexpected. On top was the mix of lettuce, tomato and fresh crema found on every plate. The red salsa in the table rocket liberally applied brought it all together. Liked it alot. 

It was fairly priced @ $8.50, and filling enough to skip dinner tonight. 

Norristown has many Latin American restaurants to choose from. El Limon (The Lemon) is worthy of consideration for your pesos.

Trenton Farmer's Market is an institution from the time there were actually working (and profitable) farms around Mercer and Bucks Counties.  It has seen better days, but is still a great way to get the basic foodstuffs of life all in one place, at reasonable prices, and avoid the corporatism that is the supermarket industry nowadays.  

If that wasn't enough of a reason to do your consuming here when possible, there are several other good ones - butchers, bakers, veggie mongers, deli delighters, and even candlestick makers who produce first rate digestibles and other things that you would be happy to eat and serve your family and friends.  

Yesterday I stopped in to pick up fruit, veggies, chicken, a little BBQ, and sticky sweets, to tide me over through the coming Nor'easter.  The shops that were open in the afternoon were happy to have a late customer relieve them of some of their stock.  I found some good deals. 

While in the neighborhood you can visit other great places to purchase food or just enjoy a good meal.  Halo Farms, Rozmaryn, and Pho Tan are just a few of the Yelpworthy destinations to consider.

Prince Fried Chicken protrudes from the 500 block of Hamilton Avenue, Trenton, NJ, due to the construction of a second story sunroom in front of the original small store.  While it likely does not satisfy the requirement of the ADA because of the steps needed to enter the shop, those who are able to climb will find the ascent well worthwhile.  

Clearly, these dudes have thought about what people want to buy when they look for American fried chicken.  Boxes and buckets for sure.  Sandwiches, tenders and nuggets more than likely. Hamburgers for the chicken averse. Salads for the health conscious. Sweet desserts for absolutely everyone.  They have all this, and even more. Most importantly, they seem to do all of it quite well in their tiny space.  

This is primarily a take out joint, with only a couple of stools along a shelf on one wall, so I knew that I would be eating at my desk.  That requires consideration of the grease and mess factor with all the paper in my work area. So, I ordered a fried chicken sandwich, rather than a box of chicken and sundries, and a single wing to discover the essence of the operation.  What I found was quite encouraging.  The sandwich contents were a plump, never frozen chicken breast, breaded lightly with a spicy flour coating that turned a golden brown with coaxing from the deep fryer.  A smear of mayo and a leaf of lettuce inside a soft sesame seed topped roll completed this simple creation.  First bite (always so important) reported the juicy freshness of the bird, as well as the interesting mildly hot jacket it was dressed in.  It was very good.  If only the roll had been stronger and able to hold up better, it would been remarkable. Still, I would definitely go back for more.

The wing, bagged expertly in a long narrow wax paper sleeve, was likewise tasty and properly cooked to its optimal moment.  It was easily pulled apart, and the meat removed by teeth and tongue.  Same spicy flavor.  If anything, I liked it more than the sandwich.  

Conclusion: Prince Fried Chicken is really good.  A bucket for the family, along with a sampling of the large cookies, brownies and cheesecake, are in the offing for the near future.  Otherwise, I will just have to clear my desk before bringing in a box for my luncheon pleasure.

The Gardenville Hotel has been standing guard on Durham Road for more than two and a half centuries, protecting travelers between Newtown and Easton from night terrors before, during and after the Revolution. In those days not every battle was in an open field, or behind trees or stone walls, but in the hearts of patriots and loyalists. It was in this very tavern that the debates about liberty and fidelity to the crown were argued, people took sides and made decisions that would effect their lives and the course of history. If you belly up to the bar today you may hear similar talk about status quo and change voiced with the same ferocity. It is good that some things never change much. The issues are as important today in their own way.

If you don't come for the history, be sure to come for the grub. It is very good. The kitchen knows what to do with meat. They have a smoker out back and a grill in house that does a job on brisket, prime rib, babybacks and steak that will satisfy the savage carnivore within. Our prime rib and brisket sandwiches were a load and a half of perfectly smoked and slathered beef, pretending to fit on a Kaiser roll. Each was enough for two meals. My side of baked beans came in a nice size dish that was about the best I'd ever tasted. Zangin' and twangin'! 

You wouldn't think of Gardenville as a custom beer joint or martini bar, but they have enough choice to keep you satisfied. Between an IPA and citrus shandy, we were happy campers. The bar food is mostly fried, but there are plenty of quality options deeper in the menu and specials. Service is a pleasure with black and whites who enjoy their jobs. 

Whether you live nearby or have to drive for a while, Gardenville Hotel is a worthwhile trip back in time.

Things are definitely looking up in Newtown, especially in terms of new eating establishments. Harvest Seasonal Grill & Wine Bar recently opened it's doors in the Village at Newtown.  It is an impressive and attractive house, with lots of stone and wood in a large room. It even has a three sided wall fireplace in the lobby, a large bar on the left, plenty of booths and tables, and al fresco dining under the extended overhang in front. 

I was there for a business lunch this week without a reservation. No problem. At 1:00 pm we had a booth in under ten minutes. Service was bright and friendly, and it was obvious the staff was well school in the details of the menu.  First glance showed that prices were upscale, but so were the dishes described in the large format menu. With a little work it was easy to find a light healthy veggie lunch in the appetizer list and avoid the high end dishes farther in. For around $10 I enjoyed the hummus plate that included grapefruit slices, fresh dark green sweetpeas, scoop slices of carrot and zucchini, and triangles of warm pita. Very good. My associate ordered a quinoa type sandwich and side salad. She said it was also highly satisfying. 

All in all, Harvest Grill is a new level of farm to table cuisine that brings up the standard for quality dishes in the community. There is a price to pay for it, but judging by the crowded midweek dining room, it is a price people are more than happy to absorb. 

Such success does not come without some adjustments to the customary dining outlets in Newtown. They all have to step up their games to stay relevant in the local resto wars, or risk being left behind. On the other hand, the surge in new kitchens appearing in this quarter create serious parking problems that at some point may literally drive customers away as they tire of hunting for a spot to leave their wheels for a chance at a great meal. 

For now, that is a good problem to have.

Please don't get me wrong. I love DeLorenzo's tomato pies, and have been amazed by them since moving to Trenton many years ago and discovering the Italian wonders of the Chambersburg neighborhood. I, like most of those fabulous Roman kitchens, have since left the city for greener lawns in the suburbs, but still returned to Hudson Street, and Robbinsville thereafter, just to continue our love affair with their thin crust tomato pies, that were the best I had ever eaten until that time.

They have since expanded into Bucks County, with their newest venture on Edgewood Road in Lower Makefield, PA. (No, it is not Yardley).  I couldn't wait to have the opportunity to visit their new digs. That finally happened yesterday on a Sunday evening. I had ordered by phone a few hours before to be certain they could handle my request given how busy their joint normally was on weekends. I was assured that my two large pies (one regular and one sausage) could be handled by the designated pick up time of 7:00 PM.  

When I arrived, the smallish parking lot was overflowing, but I lucked into someone pulling out just as I pulled in.  Their store is all new construction alongside the Giant Shopping Center off Stony Hill Road. As expected, the waiting area was jammed with people waiting for tables.  I approached the very busy cashier, and when he had a second to look at me, gave him my name for the takeout order. He checked in the kitchen and relayed that my pies were not yet out of the oven.

Perfect! I would secure them at apex heat and transport them home while still baking inside.  I reflexively began to salivate at the thought of biting into the steaming chunky red gravy, mozzarella and thin cracker crust. Oh, Yeah!

The ten minute wait was fine with me. I used the time to take photos and watch all the happy customers. The aroma was timeless, and threw me into reveries of my earliest experience with DeLo's grand pies. I eventually paid the $35 for the two artisanal works of edible art, and drove home with visions of plum tomatoes and basil dancing in my head. 

The sausage pie was just as amazing as I remembered. Local crumbled meat, fresh melted mozza, and mildly salty thin crust to complement the equally mildly sweet red sauce. The explosion in my mouth was a wonderful party with old friends. Unfortunately, the regular pie was overbaked, with too much crust burn and too little sauce filling the irregularly shaped base. I like some scorching as much as anyone, but this one was beyond that - complete carbon in too many places. This can happen when the kitchen staff is stretched to the max and doesn't watch each pie through the process. Chalk it up to a bad card in an otherwise sound hand. 

DeLorenzo's is still about the best tomato pie in the area, especially on this side of the Delaware River.  Very glad to save the longish drive to Robbinsville, NJ,  although their cousin's shop in Levittown is just as good.

Mexico Lindo Restaurant sits on a rather forlorn strip of South Broad Street in Hamilton, a few blocks before you get to the Trenton line. Don't be deterred by the urban decay visible in the area, because once you walk inside this unassuming storefront you cross the border into Mexico.  Vibrant colors, a hodgepodge of odds and ends tables covered with more colors, a HD TV showing the latest soaps from Ciudad Juarez, and a hand painted mural of the Mexican Eagle grasping a Rattlesnake emblazed on the wall.  I was surprised I was not asked for my passport.

And, the food was very good, as there is an ever growing population of excellent Mexican, Guatemalan, Honduran, Salvadoran and even Puerto Rican shops in the vicinity - making for healthy competition.  My Torta Milanese de Pechuga was a fat boy sandwich on an oversized roll filled with Breaded Chicken Cutlet, Lettuce, Tomato, String Cheese, Mayo and a bit of Chipotle Sauce.  Delicious.  It was really too loaded to just pick up by hand and stuff into mouth.  Knife and fork were needed to get everything into my mouth collectively.  The accompanying Crinkle Cut Fries were also above average.

My most pleasant surprise was ordering the Jugo de Melon drink.  This was the water added version of a milk shake made from Watermelon, and it came served in the aluminum blender container.  It was totally refreshing. 

My Spanish was just adequate for a few short conversations about the restaurant, and to permit me to compliment them on a terrific little joint.  The owner and his family came out to eat while I was there, and I made it clear the food was delicioso, and that I would revuelve pronto.

Very nice set up for this latest addition to the El Limon franchise in Bucks County. Radcliffe Street was already a great riverside lane in Bristol, but is even better with the presence of the small dining room (8 tables/booths) and cool outdoor curbside seating of this Mexican house. Definitely perfect for a still warm late September autumn night. 

Really liked the Tacos Dorados with the combination of shredded chicken, mashed potato and spices, deep fried and topped with lettuce, tomato and queso blanco, and choice of red/green salsa from table rockets. Firm crunch, followed by smooth chew and blended flavors. Yet, @ 3 for $9., it seemed overpriced, as was the tempting and delicious Tres Leches dessert @$5.95. Good taste and texture, but I won't be that indulgent next time. The Horchata drink was cool and refreshing with the taste of vanilla and fresh cinnamon right down to the final suck through plastic straw.

Maybe I need to accept the pandemic inflation of late, but I still have optimism that prices will come down once the supply chain amps up and evens out. For now I appreciate the chance to get out and enjoy a meal beyond my own kitchen.

Four Seasons Diner on Cottman Avenue, Northeast Philadelphia, is a traditional highway roadhouse in the semi-urban jungle that is this part of the great city. It is well maintained, with plenty of parking, classic lunch counter in back, and booths galore all around. They also have a lot of recessed colored lighting in the ceiling, which gives a somewhat funhouse quality to it all. 

I stepped to the rear and was the only customer on a spinner. The menu is enormous for the morning meal, so it took a few minutes to go through it. In the meantime, I received my mugga joe and a side glass of milk, as requested. Ultimately, I went with their french toast and bacon combo for $7.95. Only these old joints that have paid off their construction loans can afford to offer such inexpensive vittles. Wish they also offered real maple syrup rather than the pre-packaged sweeteners. Still, with three large slices of bread and an equal number of well done bacon, I felt satiated without even touching the third slice of toast. 

All the while, I had plenty of attention from the staff, who filled my mug repeatedly, and asked after my satisfaction. Had I been more gregarious, I no doubt would have had strong conversation with the ladies all morning. I preferred to stick to my reading. 

This part of Philly has many diners to chose from. Glad I chose a decent one for today's brekkie. I passed several others on my way to the office, and will check them out in due course.

When another Chinese house was closed on Tuesday in Hatboro, we pulled out the trustee Yelp App and found Wing Lee Cuisine not far away in Horsham on Easton Road.  As the saying goes; "One door closes and another opens."  So it was last evening. We may never know what we were missing, because there is little chance we will return to Hatboro from Newtown for dinner, but we definitely discovered a very good Chinese restaurant about a mile away that is open seven days a week and serves good quality dishes with friendly service from ownership.  

The room was well appointed, clean and attractive with white linen and heavy metal utensils in addition to available chopsticks.  We brought our own libations and were promptly given a table side ice bucket to hold the beer at arms length.  The menu was Chinese in front, and Japanese in back.  There were plenty of options from Cantonese, to Hunanese, to Szechuanese (although this was a light version of the kickin' spiciness we desired; lacking any Szechuan chili peppers or star peppercorns), and a page of fish platters. Regardless of that small disappointment, everything was well made with fresh ingredients, superior sauces, and nice presentations.  

We asked for Hunanese Lamb, which was tender and spiced with black bean sauce.  Very good.  The Szechuan beef and the Szechuan Shrimp were both full plates with plenty of thin sliced beef and veggies, and large shrimp in a thick bright red gravy, but lacking in true Szechuan flavor.  We added some house chili sauce after the fact, which helped a bit, but could not approach the fire quotient of cooking with the authentic flamethrowers.  Finally, the eggplant in garlic sauce was good, although it seemed American rather than Chinese eggplant was used.  

We enjoyed our meal (and birthday celebration).  The candle stuck in the cored/quartered orange and the singing of "Happy Birthday," were very thoughtful touches and appreciated.  

This is one of the better suburban Chinese restaurants in this part of the world.  It makes up for lack of real Chengdu heat by the overall quality and skills apparent in their kitchen.  They would do themselves a favor by having the right spices above the stove for those who know what Szechuan food is supposed to taste like.  If they did, this place could be truly exceptional.

Chinatown Square on Race Street between 10th & 11th, is a nice attempt to bring Asian street food malls to Philly. It is a tiny version of these emporiums found on a grand scale in Flushing, NY, Toronto, and other major Chinese population centers. When done right in a large enough space, there are dozens of mini fast food outlets surrounding a central communal dining area where a group effort is required to scout for seats while the rest line up for the desired treats, and bring everything back to the demarked table. They are wildly successful.

It remains to be seen if Chinatown Square has the critical mass of enough choices balanced with adequate seating to make it. But, my first visit was fun and tasty, and will bring me back for more when in the mood for snacks reminiscent of all those delights experienced in travels through China, Thailand, Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. There, when the sun goes down, the streets fill with bicycle kitchens setting up curbside cafes to grill the delicacies you select from the table spread in front of you, and served on miniature tables and stools on the sidewalk. Such a kick! 

The Cambodian sausage and BBQ beef on a stick from Khmer Grill were both greasily excellent. Tart/sweet marinade, just enough firing to cook everything without drying out, and timely delivery into a styro take out container, made for a delicious bite and chew. 

The other counters serving buns, gyros, Thai ice cream, etc., were all busy with happy folk talking or eyeing their phones. There is even a karaoke bar upstairs. 

Kudos to the developer who put this together. She is on to something that should be popular and lead to copycats all over Chinatown and the surrounding streets. 

This is just the beginning.

More Than Q on Klines Court in Lambertville, NJ, does a good turn for this river city across the mighty Delaware from New Hope, Pa.  It slow roasts ribs, brisket, pork and chicken to soft, pull-off-the-bone tenderness and rubs/bastes with quality dry and wet spices/sauces to produce a quality BBQ.  The house sits on this quiet backstreet, bracketed by Brian's and Di Napoli's, making for a tasty killers' row of excellent cuisine choices.  The interior space is designed for communal dining, so after ordering your food at the order window, look for seats along the long tables or wall counters, to await the call of your number at the pickup window.  

You won't think you've been transported to Memphis or St. Louis, but for eastern Pennsylvania/western Jersey this is damn good. It is every bit as flavorful as the better known Lucy's, Mission, Ben's, Famous Dave's in Bucks, or Smoke-N-Grill and 1911 Smoke House in Jersey, to name just a few. 

Our lunch of brisket and fried chicken sandwiches were loaded and delicious.  The beef was tender with a pleasant mildly spicy lasting taste.  My chicken was corn meal coated and fried just enough to leave the inner bird juicy. The aioli mayo and creamy coleslaw on top contributed nicely to the experience.  Side dishes of cornbread and baked beans were strong complementary textures and tastes - sweet cornbread was freshly baked, and the rich, savory beans were topped with pieces of burnt ends or pulled pork to enhance the chew.  Really got off on them beans! 

Boylan's Soda (Grape) was a sweet washdown with all the tang. 

While More Than Q is a small chain, it does have a local mom & pop feel to it.  

Will def be back for the ribs.

PJ's Pancake House & Tavern is located on Bear Tavern Road in Ewing, NJ. It is north of Rt. 95 in a bucolic part of the township. If you have been around for a while, they renovated the old joint formerly known as The Silo Restaurant. 

The house is western style, with wooden tables, chairs floor and a back room bar big enough for a large party. Gonna have to sell a lot of mimosas to make that work well for morning meal. Still, the place is very attractive, even if I was there just for breakfast. 

I wanted a short stack of french toast, but that was not available. Three slices or tough luck. I ordered it, and waited for my first mugga joe. Service was friendly and there were plenty of servers on hand to handle the light customer presence at 8:30 am. The plate arrived with its cargo of well grilled and caramelized light loaf.  The kitchen did a good job with the egg, sugar, cinnamon and vanilla mix, which saturated the bread to its core. The edges and rises were nicely crunchified, and the application of butter and syrup made everything look terrific. The taste was very good, and even though I had asked for two slices, I found room for all three. The coffee was also strong, hot and kicky. 

This was a superior breakfast. 

I did find the $15 cost for my solitary breakfast to be excessive. Nearly $3 for the java, even if unlimited, caught me off guard. How much could I drink? Two mugs at most. $9 for the FT also felt like an extravagance which I am unlikely to repeat often. They would do well to offer a more affordable choice (short stack) if they want to bring in the masses. 

I know PJ's is expanding rapidly right now, and just opened its fourth store in Kingston, NJ, but unless they want to be the hangout for only the rich and famous, they should find a few smaller/cheaper options.

I've been on a bit of a diner kick of late, and this morning chose Cinnaminson Diner on northbound Rt. 130 in the town of that august name. It is not in a traditional Jersey stainless steel case, but still offers adequate booths and a small 5 stool counter for lone wolves like me. 

After ordering the Country Steak Special (chicken fried steak, 2 eggs, home fries, rye toast & coffee), I settled in to watch the action on a busy Saturday morning. The staff seemed professional and appropriately friendly. They all wore cloth masks, with some carried beneath the nose, and thus useless. Same can be said of the customers waiting to be seated. Oh, well. It is hard to be constantly Covid vigilant.

Really liked my meal, however. The breaded/fried steak was smallish, but crisp and tasty. I asked for the sausage gravy on the side, because I wanted to limit the heavy calorics from that chunky white sauce. They brought out a small bowl of it, when all I needed was one spoonful. It was excellent, but less was more for me. The scrambled eggs were good with a few shakes of Tabasco, and the home fries were plentiful and nicely browned and crunchy. Java was strong and bracing, and I appreciated that my request for milk resulted in a small stainless pitcher of moo juice, rather than mass produced creamers. The joe was included in the cost of the meal; a nice touch too often forgotten in the 21st C. 

This was the best of my recent diner experiences, and helped reaffirm my historic enjoyment of this meal style.

Connecting Bridesburg, Philadelphia with Pennsauken, NJ, the Betsy Ross Bridge was opened to traffic over the mighty Delaware River in 1976. It moves vehicles well from one State to the other, helping commuters avoid heavy loads on Route I-95 during rush hour, or to simply bypass Center City density the rest of the day. I use it to travel from Bucks to Camden for court, and it saves me a bundle of time by circumnavigating the morning confusion at the Benjamin Franklin Bridge. 

But, I admit to mixed emotions about using the Betsy because I know its construction history. The pilings on the Philly side are made up in large part of headstones from the Monument Cemetery that had interred people within it's hallowed grounds since 1839. Like its famous sister, Laurel Hill Cemetery, it was designed to reflect the sentiment of Pere Lachaise in Paris, France,  by being both a resting place for the dearly departed and a public park for the living. But, due to its relatively small size, once the 28,000 caskets were buried and there was no room for more, the maintenance fell off and the board of governors died or otherwise allowed the cemetery to fall into serious disrepair. 

Temple University offered to buy it several times for use as a parking lot, but was rebuffed repeatedly.

 Finally, the school saw its opportunity when the Betsy was being proposed. They again offered to buy it from the City if it would condemn it and seize by eminent domain. Philly agreed, and arranged to make the transfer if Temple would remove the bodies and headstones. This it did by notifying families of the deceased to retrieve the bodies and rebury them elsewhere. Only 8,000 were claimed, and the rest were transported to a mass unmarked grave in Lawnview Cemetery in Northeast. They then sold the granite and limestone markers to the bridge contractor who needed fill for the pilings upon which the upright supports would be anchored. 

Thousands of headstones now lie underwater beneath the steel and can be seen sticking out at low tide. 

So, when I cross dear old Betsy, I say a silent prayer for those whose lives were lived nearby and died only to be unceremoniously separated from their identities and dumped in a lost and unmarked grave, and their stone remembrances buried forever beneath the bridge. 

"... Don't it always seem to go,
that you don't know what you've got 'till it's gone.
They paved paradise
And put up a parking lot."

-Joni Mitchell, Big Yellow Taxi, Ladies of the Canyon, 1970

Pat's Colonial Kitchen is exactly that - a first floor, cramped, cozy, warm, 18th Century breakfast and lunch place that suggests the way life was in 1813 in this community William Penn called his New Town.  If you enjoy living history, this is your place to chow down on pancakes, french toast, coffee, etc., for breakfast; and burgers, sandwiches, and salads for lunch, while imagining your horse and buggy are tied up to the hitching post outside.  

Is it the best food you have ever had?  Some might say so, but that is only half the point of eating here.  Step into Pat's, and you step into real history.  The Revolutionary War was fought right outside on the street!  Geo. Washington really had his war council only one block away before deciding to cross the Delaware River and engage in the Battles of Trenton and Princeton.  

Eat your breakfast and feel just as our forefathers did before we knew we had a country to call our own. 

Judging by the far flung places the other reviewers call home, this is exactly what they came here for.

BurgerIM is bastardized Hebrew for the word, "Burgers", "IM" being the suffix used for the plural. The company began selling franchises in 2008 after a successful launch in Israel a few years earlier. At one point eleven years ago, it was the fastest growing company in the stock market, with amazing earnings.

Unfortunately, the annual reports were determined to be fraudulent. The CEO fled the country ahead of the SEC charging him with security violations and criminal conduct. Confronted by all that, and lack of logistical support, most franchisees lost their investments and closed their doors. Those few shops that remain are survivors struggling to make ends meet. This is true for the BurgerIM in Warrington, PA. 

Glad I made it while it was in business, because their business model is different than most fast casual joints. Their approach is the sale of multiple burgers in designer boxes, with more choice than most. Rather than just beef pucks and chicken fillets, they offer lamb and salmon alternatives, all customizable to taste. Too, they have excellent wings and a few potato choices as well as good onion rings and shakes.

I used GrubHub to score a family box which included 8 burgers (4 Angus standards, 4 Spanish spicy), 6 Sweet/Hot Chili Wings, rings and fries. These are 3 oz burgers, but with trimmings, one sandwich and a couple of wings, were enough for a decent meal. This was about 4-6 meals depending on appetite, and the cost was $49. Kept my family with two still growing young men sated last night, with leftovers. 

The curbside pickup worked well. Didn't get inside to check out the atmosphere. Honestly, I liked the wings more than the burgers, but they were still tasty enough to be satisfying. I imagine everything would be better right from the grill, but with Covid, it's just not worth the risk of hanging around inside. 

Still, the franchise has suffered due to the misdeeds of earlier management, so I hope these folks are around past social distancing and can demonstrate their worthiness thereafter.

A few visits to Dr. Rosenman has satisfied me that he is a good physician with excellent human interactive skills.  Beyond the thorough examination from scalp to toes, he diagnoses quickly and all the while keeps a warm banter going to help keep me at ease.  The provides running commentary on what he is looking at, and while still in the examining room records his office notes on what he has observed and talked with me about, so I can understand more fully what he is thinking, and provide time for questions.  

When he saw something that he was not definite about, he asked me to return in a month to allow him a second look for changes.  As a precautionary measure he took a tiny sample for biopsy.  Nothing to worry about.  

The office itself is clean, if a little dated.  The staff appears to be all women, some busier than others.  Still, I was in and out promptly, and not required to wait more than 10 minutes before he saw me both times.  The payment desk is efficient, and the billings have been reasonable and understandable.  

See you again in a few years, doc.  Thanks a lot.

When it comes to pizza, loyalty to a geographic region's tomato pie comes close to fanaticism. It is completely understandable that raging debates about whether Brooklyn or Pittsburgh or Trenton or Philly or some little shop on the wild streets of South Boston make the best pie.  But, the wise peacemakers among us know the secret - they are all the best if you love them. So much better to put aside parochial claims of superiority and just eat them all! Even the worst is so much better than what those poor souls have to accept as pizza in Colorado or some other state with altitude.
 
Just mange and enjoy. Let your oralgasms carry you away...

Newtown Pizza makes a decent pizza, but it will never be mistaken for an escapee from Napoli nor Roma, let alone Brooklyn Heights nor Chambersburg. Yet, walking by the display counter with all the attractive pies can set your glands a-squeezing, and the Trenton Pie is very aesthetically pleasing to the eye and tongue.  The crust holds the weight of the toppings firmly, perhaps because it is a bit thicker than Romana, and the ingredients are top shelf.  Still, the overall taste sensation is not the transcendent experience of  my favorite pizza shrines. Nonetheless, it is a standup slice worthy of consumption. 

The Eggplant Parm is not always prime, as I have found it to be tough chewing at times.  The same goes for the steak sandwiches.  Mostly a good fill, but occasionally a little under or over grilled.  Just enough to keep you guessing. 

Friendly ownership, staff and crew, and a good citizen in the community.  

As offered at the top, to each his/her own when it comes to pizza. For those of us who love Ntown Pizza, the world is your oyster. Chow down close to home.  For the others of us who have different pizza needs, we know where to go to satisfy them, both near and far.

8.27.13 I just had a couple of great slices of Newtown Pizza's Margarita Pie. Really excellent. I like a slightly charred crust because it tends to be crunchy and supportive of the weight above it.  This one was, with a mildly sweet sauce and fresh mozza, doctored with a light dusting of hot chili pepper flakes. Take a look at the photo.  It was as good as it looks. 

Keep it up fellas and cinco estrellas could be close at hand.

This is a human-free parking garage. 

It puts a premium on following instructions as there is no one around to answer questions most of the time.  Everything is completely automated, from drive in through drive out.  Similar to a car wash, your vehicle is driven onto a moving platform or track and from that point on, everything happens robotically. Your car is pushed left or right to align it with the entrance to the storage area.  It is then lifted off the ground much like a garage lift, and then transported inside the vertical parking structure until you return to pick it up.  

It is critical to take everything you need with you, most importantly your keys.  Turn off the engine.  Use the same credit/debit card to extract your car as used upon entry. Go to the other side of the building for retrieval.  Failure to recall the proper card could result in a long wait until someone arrives to deal with this screw up.  Reading the other reviews it is easy to see how it would be very frustrating to have to wait.  

The evening cost is $14 for the night if in after 5.  Not a bad deal.

Hiding in plain sight within the H Mart in Levittown is a small Korean restaurant, accessible to shoppers to eat in or take out.  They also do catering.  The primary orientation is Korean cuisine, but Chinese offerings are also available.  

The menu takes the form of large format photos above the ordering window.  They are labeled bi-lingually.  The staff is friendly and conscientious.  The food is quite good. 

Today, we ordered Mandoo Kook, a Korean Beef Soup loaded with Veggies, Rice Cake and Egg.  It came with Fried Dumplings and Pickled Relish and Cabbage on the side.  It was richly savory and complex.  Additionally, we had Jeyuk Dupbap.  As we all know, that is Spicy Marinated Pork on top of Steamed Rice, and a small Lettuce Salad.  Very enjoyable and filling.  

While this corner of H Mart would never be mistaken for haute cuisine nor fashionable comfort, it does offer a richly sustainable meal and rock bottom prices.  Definitely worth arriving hungry and eating here before working the aisles for a full shopping experience.

Circle Deli is the nearest food outlet to my office, and we order take out for eating in from there a few times a week. They deliver timely sandwiches, soups, wraps, and a plentitude of snacks neatly packaged and with a smile. 

I prefer to eat later in the day and have stopped off there occasionally to order my own custom lunch.  They are willing to make anything off menu that they have the ingredients for, and do it well.  They are super efficient and friendly as a hard working husband and wife team.  

What is really amazing is how much stuff they can cram into a small space and not seem cluttered and claustrophobic. 

Generally, I am not a deli lunch kind of guy, as I prefer to have a more relaxing meal than sitting at my desk.  But, at crunch time, Circle Deli is a convenient and worthy alternative. 

I am a fan.

The soups and sandwiches are fresh and well made.  
It is fun to watch the crew make a sandwich as they have a discipline/routine to it that is very zen, although they may not know it. 
It is a very local place, and it helps to know Becky or her people to feel at home there. I can understand some of the pejorative reviews from new customers, because they are not known and the young workers are not always people persons. 
Still, the product is good, and the prices reasonable. 
Bottom line - I enjoy the walk from my office for a take out lunch on nice days, knowing I will return with a tasty sandwich along with the stroll through historic Newtown.

PS. Becky's Deli now has 2 outdoor tables on nice days.

Cool Blue.

Overhead river meandering.

Clear Mushroom Soup clarifying. 

Captain Roll (Spicy Crunchy Tuna, Crabmeat, Salmon, Eel & Avocado) drizzled with Chef's Special Sauce), visual, tasty pleasure. 

Hot and grainy Green Tea. 

Great way to reach the end of the day.

It has been a long time since I was in the Gray's Ferry neighborhood, and it was good to be back.  I had heard rumors about a Thai house that was opened at 25th & Christian serving up good and relatively authentic Thai cuisine out of a small storefront.  So, after a great massage @ V&V over at 11th and Washington, I headed west and found Thai Square sitting right on the corner.  

Parking can be an issue in these parts, but I was lucky to find a spot behind the restaurant on one of those super narrow backstreets. Parallel parking requires the front tire to go over the opposite curb to get the right angle for backing. Lucky my city skills had not abandoned me and I slid the chariot right into the space like a pro. So, I was feeling pretty good even before walking in. 

The dining room was small, but clean, with the entire southern wall in glass overlooking a simple but attractive outdoor seating area.  The Madame moved toward us with a warm welcoming smile.  Handing us the menus, she suggested the specials and asked for our drink order.  The Ginger Tea she brought us a few moments later was excellent, with a nice ginger bite and honey background.  Our water was complemented by a small dish of squeezed lime juice and a small spoon.  Another great notion that brought the agua to life.  That was a first for me. Much better infused that a mere wedgely squeeze. 

We were on a roll and the anticipation of what was to come grew.  While the Calamari was a small disappointment in that all the rings were large and coated in a hard jacket rather than a softer finish, the dipping sauce was good enough to demand we finish it with a spoon after the squid was gone. 

Then we received our Tamarind Duck and Shrimp Pad Thai.  

The Duck was nearly perfect.  Crisp skin.  Fully cooked and tender meat.  Tamarind Sauce that was sweetly tart and mild citrus finish, in a sultry dark red amber demi-glaze.  It was so good, I stuck my finger in it to suck it off. This was a treasure too special to waste a drop. 

The Pad Thai was also very good; a full plate complemented with ground Peanut and fresh Sprouts.  It was a strong straight man to the wild machinations of the Duck.  

This was one of those meals that I didn't want to end.  I strung it out as long as possible with rice to absorb all the outrageous moisture on the platter, and another glass of water with lime to carry it all the way down.  

Yes. I took the rest home to savor tonight.

4.5 Stars with a Bullet!

Stella's Pizza has been at this location on Scotch Road for more than 30 years, but this was my first visit.  

The impression is of an old style pizzeria with a side dining area.  When I arrived for a late lunch, Stella herself was sitting there having lunch and chatting with a customer.  I ordered an Eggplant Parm sandwich after seeing another sandwich order come out of the kitchen on a great looking torpedo roll.  It arrived at my table a few minutes later, nicely toasted and so inviting.  The bread comes from Italian Peoples' Bakery, and has that signature crispy crunch that is the beginning of a satisfying meal.  The eggplant was thin sliced, finely breaded and pan fried with minimal oil residue.  The tomato sauce was lightly salty, adding to the very positive overall experience.  All good.

While the facility could use an updating, the quality of the food is very good, and the prices a throwback to about 1990.  $6.50 for a 9" hot hoagie sandwich seems like an incredible deal, especially given the quality of the product.  It is easy to enjoy stepping back in time to an earlier day when a family operated restaurant meant the family was everywhere in the shop; cooking, cleaning, hosting, and just hanging out on breaks to talk with people.  I love the coziness that creates.  

None of this would work if the food was not good, but it is.  So, it will be easy to return to try the other offerings, especially the pizza, and learn more about Stella, her family, and the history of a typical old fashioned family resto.

Man, has Mill Street come back to life!

I had not been down by the Delaware River for several years and was very pleasantly surprised by the return of vibrancy around there.  Kelch House was recommended by a local businessman we were visiting, and he was right on with his suggestion. The five of us had a variety of things on the menu, and all of us were happy with our choices. 

I had the Apple and Feta Salad, consisting of Granny Smith slices, Romaine, Candied Walnuts, and a good amount of fresh Feta Cheese.  The Balsamic was a nice taste to wrap it all together. A good meal @ $9.  Looking at my mates I observed various stages of gluttony displayed over a Cheesesteak and French Onion Soup.  Someone mentioned the Fries were excellent.   

The facility is dressed in colonial attire, with large windows bringing in wonderful light. The view of the river from our table was great on this autumn day. 

Definitely worth a special visit to return to both Kelch House and Bristol. 

Well done, City!

Stopped in recently about a half hour before closing on a weeknight.  Although not at all crowded, the warm brick/old wood ambiance mixed well with the several customers hanging on into the night.  The exposed brick and long bar anchored the room, while the wooden tables and chairs offered the sense of an Old City establishment that could have existed at any time since the late 18th Century.  In fact, the foundation was that old.  Walking in from cobblestone streets completed the impression that Prime Stache doubled as a time machine. 

I sat briefly at the bar waiting for my companion to arrive for a late business discussion.  No pressure to order a drink after explaining my purpose, and the bartendress was friendly and attractive.  I had a chance to settle in and look around.  I liked everything I saw.  The bar menu looked appealing, and as a former barkeep I appreciated the fresh fruit and infusion jars resting around the work area.  I was tempted, but knew I needed a clear head.  Still, I have a strong desire to try something creative next time I come.  

My contraparty arrived and we moved to a table.  She was hungry and ordered Turkey Sliders.  An app of Sweet Sautéed Carrots arrived first.  They were small and thin and obviously a local produce.  Nice snappy sweetness.  We discussed our businesses while awaiting the main course, and switched to questions that we could answer for each other while she enjoyed the mini burgers.  Really wish I was more hungry, but observing her face as she ate was a clear indication of high enjoyment.  I continued to sip away as our comfort level with the space and each other grew into a more detailed and tangential discussion.  

We ended up closing the place.  All the other chairs were up on their tables when we finally walked out.  

Prime Stache is known as an American Bistro.  The quality of the environment, drinks, and the food, makes it something more than that. While the word, "Stache," suggests both a Golden Age of American history, as well as a slightly out of date image for a modern resto, it successfully sets itself apart by a consistency of atmos, service, and product that liberate from the constraints of time and place, and bring you into a timelessness that is compelling.  

I am excited about returning here again, and that makes me a fan.

This is one of the new versions of the old theme that is Dunkin Donuts.  The space is larger, brighter, cleaner than most of its siblings, with one end of the shop furnished with easy chairs and small tables to encourage hanging out.  

The coffee is average DD brew. The staff is efficient. The baked goods looked all shiny and glazed, but I did not try one this visit.  

Maybe next time.

Only in America!

Here we have a "New York Bagel" shop run by Arabic speaking guys, who seem to know how to "make the donuts..." 

I was impressed.  

The crew of Ewing's Finest who were there ahead of me seemed to know a good morning stop.  I felt incredibly safe.

But, the parking lot was like a DMZ.

If you don't have time to make the trip to Istanbul, Damascus, Beirut, Amman, Jerusalem, or any other Middle Eastern city, the next best thing could be a stop at Tulip Hookah Café in Langhorne, Pa.  Once inside, you are transported from Bucks County to a much more exotic locale.

  Have imagination. Will travel. 

Find a comfortable spot to sit or recline and order a variety of Shisha (Flavored Tobacco) from the servers.  They will return with a beautiful glass water pipe (Hookah) and your smoking preferences.  Sit, smoke and talk as long as you wish.  This is a old custom in that part of the world.  Pass the pipe's mouthpiece tipped hose around, and taste the flavors of Turkey, or many other Arab/Muslim-centric countries.  

Tulip also offers snacks and non-alcoholic beverages, and live music entertainment several nights a week (check website or call ahead).  The $10. cover charge gives you license to stay all night.  

When I resided in that part of the world I would often find a soft carpet and pillows to relax on the floor and watch the hookah's smoke drift and dance toward the ceiling. Sometimes there was music and song.  I would ask for a small cup of the local thick coffee, pour in a ton of sugar, and sip the caffeine alternating with a long draw on the pipe.  The visions were astounding. When feeling flush, I asked for flavored brandy to replace the water in the pipe, so I could completely experience the transition from hookah/coffee house to Bedouin's tent in a secret desert oasis.

Visions of Scheherazade, Princess of Persia and storyteller of the 1001 Tales of the Arabian Nights, await...

Tonight I went in for a light meal while waiting for my son to finish a Magic tournament at Oxford Valley Mall. I just couldn't bring myself to go to its food court, so I drove down Oxford Valley Road and remembered Jahan Kabob. 

While the craft beer retail outlet dominates, this time, I was able to order a Falafel Pita and Rice, and sit with my excellent meal and ignore the rest.  The food was wonderful. The Falafel was fresh and moist even after deep frying.  The Pita was warm and pliant.  The Lettuce, Onions and Tahini Sauce was all perfect complements.  The Long Grain Basmati-like Rice was prepared with a rich spiciness that was very soft and tasty.  I usually don't enjoy rice as anything more than a sponge to sop up sauce.  This rice was exceptionally moist and flavorful.  It was a great side.

Clearly, this place has knock out cuisine inside a rather incongruous setting of a craft beer store.  If it was in its own space, it would pack in the diners.  

While it is not the place to bring a date, and is primarily a take out joint, the food taken out of this context is first rate, and really an amazing opportunity to sample Afghani kitchen craft.  The owner/chef is also a first class host and salesman for his food. 

A bump to 4 Stars is the right move.

Francisco has opened a third restaurant in Bucks, and his second in Newtown (Florentinos on State Street is the other).  His "Little Mama" is Salvadoran and Mexican cuisine done with a flourish.  This is no Chipotle fast food experience, although the ingredients are equally fresh, but more creative and satisfying on the palate. 

I was there for lunch, and limited myself to a few dishes, one Apperitivo (Guacamole Mamita), and Empanadas (hand made corn turnovers stuffed with chicken, spices and beans).  The Guac was excellent.  Smooth, cool, and so easy in the mouth.  The Empanada was crusty and flaky with just enough heat to keep the tongue on guard.  The chicken filling was chunky and soft. Really well done. 

Bottom Line - a totally satisfying, if somewhat cher, Almuerzo. 

A good place to go for a business lunch to impress your clients with your international panache. 

Next time, the Hamburguesa Mexicana comes off the board and onto my plate. A burger with jalapenos, onions and hot pepper cheese with a side of yucca fries has got to be incredible.

10.01.2013  -  Returned today for lunch.  Had the Hamburguesa Mexicana as promised. It came out loaded with cheese, jalapenos, lettuce, tomato, and avocado and a perfect medium rare.  The bun appeared to be toasted baguette-style loaf and a good fit for the innards.  Liked it a lot.  Only downside were the Yucca Fries, which were too dry and bland.  Asked for ketchup to give it some life. 

Still a 4 Star attraction, as everything was enjoyable, especially the Mexican environment, and wild colors.  Definitely got that right.

As the nearest pizza joint to my office, I really have not taken advantage of its prime location. After trying Jeppy's Brooklyn Pie that oversight will soon be corrected. 

Today I dealt with the man himself. Affable to the nines. He recommended slices of the 'Brooklyn' sitting in display.  Agreeing, he hand selected the best two available and put them in the oven to reheat.  The mozza was homemade, and tasted it. Mildly salty and soft. The crust, airy and cracker firm and crisp. Really superior work. 

This shop is in the first floor of a converted residence with apartment above. The restroom is back in the kitchen, requiring an escort. The WC itself is unusual, in that it shows its previous adaption for family living with full shower. 

Given the surprising quality of this pizza, it is definitely deserving of an upgrade to 4 Stars. That they forgot my drink keeps it from attaining top rank.

International House of Pancakes (or burgers if you follow their latest campaign) is nothing if not consistent with their primary menu. The pancakes are good wherever you find the IHOP sign, the coffee always hot and served with a pitcher for refills. Breakfast is breakfast across their wide spread enterprise. 

We stopped in after an appointment to grab a morning bite. The store was large and divided into sections. We were seated in the back room and approached by our server in less than a minute. 

Coffee, please. And, that spicy omelet with avocado on top, while you're at it. Extra plate for sharing, too. Easily done. It arrived with second plate in a few minutes. Surprisingly good, especially the unexpected BBQ brisket sticking out both ends that added a savory chew to the otherwise soft melty dish. The three pancake side was more than enough to split after spreading on butter and a combination of table syrups. Glad we had only one platter, because we were challenged finishing it. 

IHOP is an easy choice if a decent American breakfast is what you want. The jury is still out on the burgers.

What was once Patrick's Pizza and BelItalia Pizza, is now 7 Brothers Pizza.  Let's hope the third time is a charm!

This tiny shop in the 1300 block of South Broad Street, Trenton, NJ, has been washed and painted, and provided new furniture (all 3 tables), in the attempt to attract and keep customers who need Italian takeout in this south Trenton neighborhood.  The owner is from Ecuador.  He is expanding his restaurant business from his "2 Brothers" location in Ewing near the College of New Jersey.  He is friendly and loquacious, and readily engaged in conversation about his new enterprise (open only 3 weeks).  He explained that this part of the capital city was already loaded with good Latin American restaurants, but was light in the pizza/cheesesteak category.  He was hopeful of filling this void. 

If my Chicken Cheesesteak was any example, he has a good chance to succeed.  Their lunch special of sandwich, fries and cold drink for $6.50 was certainly priced to please.  Served on a ceramic plate, rather than paper, the sandwich also contained sautéed Spinach and the Fried Onions he suggested.  It was nicely presented for in house consumption, which I appreciated given that often times the meal is in take away form regardless of intention to eat right there.  That's treating the customer right.

As with every place I've been this past week, the air conditioning was overwhelmed by the heat of the day, not to mention the ovens, so I ate with a light sweat beading on my brow and dampening my shirt.  That did not deter me from enjoying lunch, as sometimes it is nice to roll with the elements, just like in the good old days before universal AC.  

The food was good and tasty.  The only suggestion would be to improve the quality of the rolls to have a crustier bite.  There are many bakeries around Trenton that make great bread.  It may be more expensive than the regional soft roll providers, but I would gladly pay a little extra for a Wonder Roll from Italian Peoples down on Butler Street.

Wissahickon Brewing Co. is a low key suds emporium on Schoolhouse Lane in East Falls just above Ridge Road. Beer is all they do, and they do it well. Their minimalist decor is open and comfortable enough for a young family with their infant to hang out easily. The brew room is large and open right behind the bar. They also have seating in the loading dock, and more tables outside if fresh air with your pilsner is your thing.

We ordered a flight of four, mixing their Raisin d'Etra, Whit and Koho IPAs and Belgian Kelpius Kove. They were all very good. I preferred the the two bookends, while DT relished the hoppier IPAs. There is no kitchen here so if you're wanting solids with fluids you have to order out from a local pizzeria. 

The staff was friendly and happy to educate about their products. Ordering at the bar was required, but the room was clean and uncluttered with everyone, both customers and workers, helping out. 

As we were leaving we were introduced to the Wissahickon brewmeister who was working on Saturday night. He invited us to a quick tour of his domain, which we graciously declined due to time constraints. We asked for a raincheck, which he graciously extended.

Until next time.

Over the years, this basement emporium has become my last resort for ingredients that just can't be found anywhere else in the City.  That special vinegar for dumplings, the fried chili in oil with black beans, and the narrow gauge rolling pin for making dumpling skins from scratch, all reside in Asia Supermarket.  But, you might need help finding all of them from the amazing employees who have the entire layout memorized.  

Speaking Mandarin or Cantonese helps, but with a smile and small kowtow, they switch to English and will even guide you to where these treasures are found.

The restaurant scene in Doylestown, PA is always changing, mostly for the better. I have eaten three times in the space now occupied by Sesame China Bistro, and with each change of hands has come an improvement in the dining experience. This Asian fusion house offers primarily Chinois/American dishes found in every takeout shop across the western world, yet they do it with a fresh approach that brings some modernity and better techniques to the wok style.  

Yes, they do offer a Thai dish or two, and even a glimpse at ramen soup, but it would be a mistake to think that Chinese cuisine is not what they understand best. I was there for late lunch and was at the cashier to order General's Chicken, Hot & Sour Soup and hot tea.  My meal arrived about ten minutes later on a large white ceramic bowl for the General, and small dish with flat bottom spoon for the soup.  A small mound of white rice was provided as accompaniment. 

The Hot & Sour was full of tofu, mushrooms, carrot slivers, sprouts and a little pork.  No MSG in sight (thank goodness).  They used a vinegar that I was not familiar with, changing the flavor just a bit to the sweeter side.  I liked it, but the traditional vinegar would have probably enhanced the enjoyment for me. The chicken was not heavily breaded before deep frying, a definite plus.  The deep tamarind-colored goop was perhaps also sweeter than expected, but then again, I did not request that it be spicy.  There were some small pieces of chili pepper in the mix, but not enough to reach the balance of sweet and spice that the General is known for. Still, I liked it, and saw that preparation was well presented. 

I would return to Sesame Chinese Bistro if the opportunity presented itself, but don't consider it more than a pretty good Chinese/American house, where I would visit for lunch, but not for a dinner when a more authentic MIddle Kingdom and Szechuanese hot and numbing meal is my preference.

I get the excitement everyone has about Comfort Food and Kitchenette.  It is an amazing place for Morrisville, Pa., and if it is a sign of things to come, this town is in for a renaissance.  The space is open and light.  Exposed industrial ceilings.  Brightly colored walls. Open kitchen.  Lots of interesting chachkas. Friendly service.  Locally sourced and health oriented menu (where possible). 

The Pickle Brined Fried Chicken Sandwich with homemade Potato Chips came on strong, with a large breast of chicken, dipped in heavy batter, and fried to a golden brown.  The bird was still juicy under its new skin, and the tomato, lettuce, mayo accompaniment was harmonic.  Too big for handling, I resorted to knife and fork to demolish it.  Crunchy and tasty.  If there is a criticism, it is in how the breading/batter used to coat the chicken turned into a hard shell, rather than attaching itself to the chicken.  Although it tasted good, it cracked with each cut and was eaten separately from the bird.  Admittedly, this was a deboned breast, and not designed for hand to hand combat.  Still, I prefer when the breading and meat hang together and allow them to be eaten simultaneously, without an outer jacket falling away from the chicken beneath.  It was tasty, nonetheless.  The Chips, while flavorful, were too fry-centric alongside the chicken for one plate.  Cut fruit would have been better for me.  

Live and learn. 

Will return for at least one more round from this kitchen.  There were a lot of happy faces and kvelling sounds all around, suggesting that I may have simply made the wrong choice in selecting fried chicken in such an avant garde coolio joint.

Genius.

A Dim Sum Sports Bar in Chinatown!

Who'd a thunk that a hybrid Asian oriented kitchen with a beer dominated sports bar would work?  I hadn't, but I am sure glad the guiding hands behind Bar-ly did.  This is a fun and original spot, and likely a theme that will be duplicated around the country. 

A greatly enhanced environment after the former tenants, a 60 label beer menu, and enough wide screens to allow everyone their own view.  The food is decent, with choices from spring rolls to kimchee cheesesteaks, with Japanese, Korean Chinese, Vietnamese and American influences throughout the offerings.  I had the boiled dumplings and a burger. Both were good, but not best in breed. Checking on the other plates exiting the kitchen, everything looked attractive, and the patrons seemed to enjoy the victuals. 

If I was strictly interested in a good meal, I might chose a different restaurant that was more sedate and allowed for whispered conversation.  However, if the idea is a fun and fluid afternoon of football with above average bar food, or a Thursday night of Flyers, Sixers, or Phillies, with friends and compatriots, this place is definitely on the short list of cool places to hang out and get loud.  

Kudos to Bar-ly. They have created a unique environment that acknowledges and celebrates the cross fertilization of two amazing cultures.  Go for a visit and take it in. 

Good times for all.

Chiangmai is an attractive Thai house on Fayette Street in the heart of Conshohocken, PA.  It is part of a three restaurant local chain that have a good reputation for authentic Thai cuisine in a nice atmosphere.  My experience at lunch confirms that opinion. 

I entered about 1:00 PM and was seated at a deuce at the front window. Cool view of a bustling Fayette Street.  The menu was presented by an attractive server who directed me to the specials page offering a prix fixe of soup, salad/app and entrée for $9.95.  Sounded good, but I knew I couldn't eat that much, so ordered the Vegetarian Drunken Noodles. 

While waiting, I took in the décor of the dining room. It was simple, yet beautifully appointed with wall and ceiling hangings from home. Lots of color and texture. The staff was likewise adorned in native dress.  It wasn't difficult to remember my days relaxing in Chaingmai after business in Bangkok. Brought a secret smile to my face. 

The large platter arrived quickly - a massive load of broad noodles, chopped broccoli, carrots, onions, sprouts and cubes of tofu in a moderately spicy sauce. Really flavorful and good mix of textures, shapes and colors. As beautiful as the sarong on the woman serving me. 

Very much enjoyed my lunch, and would not hesitate to return here, or to the other restaurants in their portfolio.

MEETING ROOM SERVICES ONLY

We held a fundraiser in the Pheasant Room last night for about 70 people.  We provided all the food and drink, but the hotel management provided set up/clean up, ice and ice containers, and a "Can Do" attitude for all our requests. They were helpful, friendly and made sound suggestions.  They also assisted with creating the sound stage for our musical entertainment. 

All for a very reasonable price. 

As a result, the event was a smashing success.  Everyone was happy and well fed, even when during speech time when all the local pols made their pitches to Get Out the Vote. No one left early, and many remained to listen to our local musicians make merriment. 

Homewood Suites is definitely a place to consider for your next meeting or event. The only downside is that it lacks a kitchen for serious catering, but once there you can have fun and even spend the night.

There is no doubt that the Tanner Brothers Store that sits at the intersection of Almshouse and Hatboro Roads in Warminster, Pa., could use an extreme makeover to improve the shopping cart traffic patterns, and modernize the check out, but if that were done it would likely sacrifice all that it has been and continues to be.  What's that?  Only a well used, still functional, farm stand for the farm run by the family of that name for generations.  There wasn't a fraction of the population nor vehicular traffic in those days.  It was about the only game in town for fresh produce, dairy and other kitchen necessities before the Acmes, Clemens, and other grocery chains started pushing north into Bucks County.  Seen it this light, it is actually an anthropology museum with daily changing interactive exhibits. 

Compared to those modern markers, Tanner Bros does suffer in the amenities department, but makes up for it with generally fresher produce, cheaper eggs, and excellent handmade ice cream.  Sure, as a convenience and secondary marketing attraction, it offers national brands on its shelves, and those things are not as competitively priced.  But, when we plan well, we hit Tanner's first, and then make a run to Giant or its ilk for everything else.  Makes us feel good to shop locally, and spend a little time in the past.  

It's great to have large bins full of yams, corn, melons, leeks, etc., to touch and choose.  And, after lugging it all back to the car, to take a few more minutes to appreciate (and slowly consume) a great Butter Pecan Sugar Cone while watching the cows that manufactured the milk for it, lazily chewing their cud in preparation for the next milking.

Valentino's is a small pizza joint in the strip center that included JC Teriyaki on Pennington Road in Ewing, NJ. It has four or five booths, but business is obviously primarily take out. I stopped in for lunch this week and found the place bright and friendly, if a tad disheveled. However, their pies on display looked very appealing, and I opted for two king size slices reheated to well done, and a Snapple.  At $6 and change, it was a good deal. 

The slices were very thin, yet firm enough to hold their points high and proud, without a quiver nor bended knee.  It was crisp, hot, and tasty and had splashes of chunky sauce throughout that reminded of tomato pie, but was in fact still a pizza with plenty of cheese visible beneath the red blotches. A heavy shake of crushed red pepper, and the slices came to life.  They were very good, with little drip or drop. 

In fact, this lunch was far better than anticipated, and was one of the better pizza surprises of the past year. I would certainly return for a fresh pie and to sample their cheesesteaks.  

If they found time to clean up the house, and put away all the unfinished boxes and cases of soda sitting in the back, Valentino's could find itself a nice romantic table for two hole in the wall for those wanting a private conversation over cracker crisp crusty pizza.

Ten of us showed up at Ocean Harbor late Saturday morning for dim sum.
