Perhaps because it was mid-August, street parking was available on Race Street, so we only had to walk a block to reach this large, bright yellow painted, high ceilinged, dining hall. Had this been a wedding, we would have been the guests of honor, because we were seated up on the stage at the rear of the room. 

Wish I knew the names of everything we sampled, but it came at us so fast and furious, with multiple carts constantly dropping off dishes, that I barely had time to photograph them before they were snapped up by our crew's chopsticks. Regardless, everything was surprisingly good. 

No problem with service, either. The size of our group provided all the incentive necessary to get us plenty of attention.  That most of our party spoke Mandarin probably didn't hurt. 

All we ate and drank came to $100. Great deal for the quantity and quality of food consumed. 

We agreed that coming back again was very likely.

On the hottest day of the summer it was nice to slip inside Triumph Brewing Company and enjoy the dim lights and heavy air conditioning. A few brave souls sat outside, but after standing in the humid 90 degree heat at The Garden of Reflection to commemorate 9.11, there was no way I wanted more of it.  Today, the sun won. 

My first visit here in New Hope, and the facility was spacious with big bar on one side, and dining room on the other.  We sat is a dark corner to discuss business although part of my mind and all my heart was elsewhere.  Triumph is proud that it locally sources its provisions and is serious about sustainable agriculture.  Way cool!  

I had a half sized Watermelon Salad consisting of red and yellow sweet melon with Watercress and a light dressing.  It was exactly right for today - cool, pleasantly refreshing.  I read on Yelp that the Calamari was good, so when the wait person suggested that or Grilled Chicken, Beef, or Shrimp on the salad, I jumped at the squid.  It was not on top of the salad, but in a separate plate because there was so much of it.  Tasted like good Calamari should - crisp without oiliness, nicely spiced to offset the innate mildness of the crustacean. I took most of it home.  

Sorry to say, it was too early to try any of the beer, and the heat would have turned the day into an Albert Camus novel. So, will return again to explore that end of the menu.

A very nice place, adequate parking (metered), and better than average healthy food. Very satisfied, and plan on going back soon.

Good business meeting, too.

It is great to see a new food hospitality business open its doors in Trenton, NJ. 

Studio B Bakery & Bistro operates in the space of prior galleries and restos that were not able to survive the vicissitudes of street life in Jersey's capital city.  Yet, this one feels like it has a chance to make it.  The space is utilitarian and simple, but comfortable.  They sell attractive bakery goods and offer breakfast and lunch that is traditional, yet creative in the use of ingredients and awareness of contemporary dietary concerns.  The staff dresses in black Ts, and is certainly friendly.  

I walked in just after 1 in the afternoon, looking for lunch and a good review.  The menu was high on the wall behind the counter.  The Pecan Chicken Salad caught my attention, and when I inquired about the availability of sandwich or panini, was told that the only option was a brioche roll.  No problem. I like brioche.  It came (eventually) with a side of sweet potato fries. I requested hot green tea on a chilled rainy day.  

What was not mentioned was that although the front of the house was not busy, the kitchen was slammed with a large project (never explained), and that I would likely have to wait more than 30 minutes to be served.  Luckily, I wasn't in a rush, and I spent the time productively reading.  

When the plate was bought to me, it was quite attractive.  The chicken salad was curried, with a load of pecans, lettuce, red onion, on a standard looking hamburger roll (not brioche).  Again, no explanation for the change, nor apology.  Still, I liked the meal.  The chicken was tasty with a pleasant lasting flavor on the tongue.  The sweet potato fries were plentiful, crisp and a nice change of pace.  

At the end, the owner came over and apologized for the delay. He seemed a decent, high energy and sincere guy.  A little better communication up front would have been appreciated along with a check in during the meal to see if I needed anything.  Not biggies, but just enough to warrant less than full throated endorsements, and a wait and see attitude for what I hope will be a major success on South Broad Street, within walking distance of my office.

UPDATE: MARCH 1, 2017 - I went in for breakfast this morning after court.  There were only a few other patrons around the house.  I sat at the counter and was promptly assisted by one of the two servers in black T's.  I ordered the Orleans Scamble, a three egger with sausage, onion, parsley, crisped shredded potato and cheese, and their chicory enhanced java.  The white plate arrived a few minutes later looking great with a dusting of parsley around the edges and the meal piled up in a line mid-plate.  A few shakes of Crystal Louisiana Hot Sauce and I was good to mange.  It was very good and quite filling. I appreciated the mix of flavors and textures, although a minute less on the grill for wetter eggs would have been my preference.  The coffee was hot and the chicory was a refreshing reminder of how joe is done in The Big Easy. Would have been even better if a refill had been offered.  

Solid and enjoyable. Still a 4 Star experience, until those small niceties are mastered.

Still a fine place for lunch, particularly on an early Spring day when a walk from the office is a perfect respite from the workload of the moment. 

On such days, and many others, Becky's is a fine destination for a fresh and tasty meal.

Philadelphia is a cool town.  

It honors its own, even when they are mythological personalities like Rocky Balboa, the Hollywood heavyweight champion of the world back in the day. 

Much like the movie character himself, his statue did not always have a permanent home.  He bounced between the top of the Art Museum steps, the old Spectrum, the Wells Fargo Center, and finally a cozy corner at the Art Museum, somewhat hidden by the grand stairway and tall trees.  The city couldn't decide if Rocky was just a local sports icon, or a full blown cultural and historic personality deserving of so much attention, so he was on the move depending on who was pulling the strings in City Hall.  Finally, the people of this great city spoke.  We didn't care if he was just a movie hero who never really lifted a finger in anger or self defense.  For decades Rocky and his alter ego, Sly Stallone, were the best things that happened to this burg since Ben Franklin flew his kite. 

In so many ways Rocky Balboa is Philadelphia. Hardscrabble.  Historic. Italian Market narrow street kid, Independence Hall.  The Constitution.  Belmont Plateau. All images of greatness and deep cultural roots.  Rocky takes his place among the must-see attractions in the City of Brotherly Love. 

It represents the everyman we all aspire to be.

Zebra-Striped Whale, named after the children's book of the same name and authored by the owner of this pleasant ice cream café, is an Alice in Wonderland place to disconnect from the outside world and kick back for a while. Sitting on State Street in Newtown Borough, it is a center of activity most warm evenings.  It is necessary to make reservations for the bench out front - it is that popular. 

The ice cream is very good, and the coffee is too.  The back of shop seating area is comfortable and eclectic; a great place for a small meeting like I had this afternoon.  It is quiet on a weekday afternoon, and no one comes back to ask if you need anything else. Walk up to the front counter if you want a refill or another scoop.  

While ZSW is not my favorite ice cream emporium in Newtown's creamy rich population of chill zones, it does possess the best options if you like to mix your SCREAM on cold marble with Reece Cups or Mason Mints.  To my tongue, Goodnoe's and OwWowCow taste better, but our Zebra is a whale of a place for the kids after dinner or weekends, and for us business folk during the day.  

Glad they are here and successful.

The 6800 block neighborhood of Bustleton Avenue, Northeast Philly, has been reborn as a satellite Asian center now that both Chinatown and Washington Avenue have maxed out with markets, restaurants, sundry shops and boutiques that are very popular and have little room for growth, and almost nothing for more parking.  

This community has two dim sum houses.  We decided to try Jade Harbor first, and were able to park right behind the kitchen in the alley (please don't tell anyone else).  This Guangdong emporium has a few dining rooms on the first and second floors.  The tables in each are packed tight to squeeze in as many customers as possible, and the narrow trail from the rear kitchen to the front of the house is often clogged with people moving around to get to their seats or restrooms.  Actually, that is something of a good thing, as it forces the carts to navigate slowly or at full stop next to your table to allow a close inspection of the goodies, and to ask the women handling them for more information.  

We were seated behind the entry door to one of the dining rooms.  Three chairs, but really room for only two.  At least we did not have to wait.  Hot tea arrived quickly, followed by the first of many cart visits.  We asked questions and snagged seven dishes from Shrimp Shumai and Beef Meatballs to Watercress Dumplings and Sticky Rice Balls with Lotus for dessert.  Everything was good to nearly best of breed.  Special mention for the Sticky Rice Pork Dumplings that were sweet on the outside and savory within.  They were a first for me.  

As Bustleton is closer to home than a trip downtown, we will no doubt find our way back here with some regularity when the dim sum bug hits us.  That I was the only "foreigner" in a house full of Chinese families suggests that this place may actually be as authentic as the banquet halls on Race Street. Jade Harbor certainly seemed that way to me and my beautiful Chinese companion. 

Will explore the other dim sum shop down the street and get back to you.

State Representative Candidate Forum

The Bucks County Free Library system has mixed reviews from library users, but last night they did the community a solid by providing a meeting room for the League of Women Voters State Representative Candidates Forum.  More chairs and a larger room would have been helpful, but the organization cannot be blamed for the substantial turnout to hear the two gentlemen answer questions submitted by the audience.  

This is the way democracy is supposed to work.  If someone wants your vote and thinks they have the qualities needed to make an exceptional public servant, they must stand before us and let us see them with all their strengths and weaknesses.  Transparency in past experience and future policy positions are essential to intelligent decisions by the electorate.  

What was most remarkable was how similar their answers were to most questions.  They both seemed so amenable to listening to each other, and working together whenever possible.  

Oh, that this was really so!

Yet, this was all somewhat less than honest due to what was not addressed at all.  Each party they represent operates collectively.  The track record of the party in majority or minority is just as important as what an individual candidate believes.  After all, politicians don't work in a vacuum.  They take their positions according to what their leadership dictates.  The influence of a rookie representative (both would be new), is less than minimal, especially if plum committee assignments, reelection and promotion are desired.  Unfortunately, they were not questioned about the position of their party on the important issues, nor how they would deal with disagreements they had with leadership.  Without that information, it was too easy to say whatever they believed, without any grounding in reality. 

Opportunity lost.  

Still, in my view, one was clearly superior to the other in terms of intelligence, thoughtfulness, compassion and experience.  I know who has my vote.

The Groveland Grill on RT. 611 in Pipersville ,PA, is a small roadside kitchen specializing in breakfast and lunch. It sits in a small commercial strip and is easy to miss if driving at normal speeds. I actually had to turn around and go back to it as I went north and didn't spy it until I was passed the driveway into their parking lot. 

The house is clean, with about ten tables and a counter with seven stools. The folks working there are very friendly, and welcomed this first timer with warm greetings. I took a seat at the counter across from the Bunn O Matic where Ellis coffee was being brewed. There was a dark blue ceramic mug with side stainless of milk in front of me in seconds, and a two page breakfast menu placed before me before I reached the counter. These people were on their game. 

There was a list of omelettes, benedicts, pancakes/French toast, and combo platters, but I decided on a standard breakfast sandwich of sausage, egg and cheese on kaiser. The side of home fries with grilled pepper and onion bits was also too tempting to pass up. 

The sammy was doubled up, making for a fat and filling meal in its own right. The taters were alright, but despite the flavor from the sauteed onion/pepper, the tubers themselves were a bit dry like they had been sitting on the corner of the grill too long. Maybe my arrival at 10:00 had some to do with that, but a word to the wise...

Loved the Ellis java, which was refilled as often as I desired. 

Groveland Grill is definitely worth your breakfast attention.

Thanks to all you Yelpers who pointed the way to House of Thai Cuisine on Cottman Avenue in the Mayfair section of Northeast Philly.  It really is a great find!

But, it did not seem that way when we first arrived on the scene.  Saturday night was the early celebration for St. Patrick's Day.  The streets were a sea of green -  drunken green. We had to weave our way around the crowded sidewalks, police corners, and pools of liquid whatever making for an obstacle course.  The block is not particularly attractive, and given the weirdness of the evening, I wondered how comfortable we would be once we entered the restaurant.  Would it be full of green curry? 

Amazingly, once we opened the door and went inside the world became quiet.  We were the only ones in the house.  The space was beautiful - classy wood floor, linen tablecloths and nice lighting. We were greeted by the owner/manager, who was gracious and seemed oblivious to the crashing roar outside.  In his domain, he was in control.  

The food was very good, too.  The Spicy Seafood Soup was loaded and tartly spiced.  My Vegetable Soup was full up with veg chunkies and Tofu, but could have been a bit hotter.  The Massaman Curry with Tofu and Sweet Potato was delicious, but surprisingly sweet.  My Drunken Noodles with Beef was simply great - a mountain of wide flat noodles, a ton of thin sliced beef, and a wonderful sauce.  I inhaled it. I did not even connect the fact that the roaring throng might be drawn to my inebriated pasta. 

The room slowly filled up, and even a few carousers in emerald beads and hats came in to chill over a Thai meal.  The atmosphere was calming and their welcome by the boss directed their energies well.  No problems. 

I really liked House of Thai Cuisine and put it in the class of my local favorite, Aroi Thai in Southampton.  When I want the distinctive urban charm of Mayfair, I will find myself there again.

Steve and Lisa Landolfi opened this café/deli only a few weeks ago in Yardleyville, the shopping niche on Afton Avenue in Yardley, Pa., For those of you who are not familiar with that name, it is where the Pink Daisy is located.  

The space is nicely decorated in a modern sensibility, yet having red checkered tablecloths even for breakfast.  Like that touch.  Too, there is a fun black and white of a very young Frank Sinatra in a supposed mug shot pose for the Bergen County (NJ) Sheriffs Department.  The criminal charge - Seduction.   

And seduction is what you get at Landolfi's.  Everything is clean and neat.  The coffee brew is very good, and Steve goes back into the kitchen to cook my breakfast, disappearing for several minutes while the smells and sounds of grilling Scrambled Eggs, Sausage and Home Fries emanate, and slowly prepare me for a home cooked morning meal.  Lisa delivers the large plate, piled high with Rye Toast and the other staples, placing it down in front of me with confidence.  There was no doubt in her mind that I would enjoy my breakfast. Hmmm...

She was right.  The Eggs were light and fluffy, while the 5 link sausages browned enough to provide a crunchy bite, yet soft enough inside to protect its soft mellow - spiced heart.  Best of all were the Home Fries.  Thin sliced and olive oil fried to a wonderful taste.  Still soft and full of flavor.  The Rye Toast handled the butter and played well with the rest of the plate.  A little Tabasco on the Eggs and I was in business.  

Seduction by small bites. 

There oughtta be a law...

One door closes and another door opens. 

We were visiting the New Castle National Historic District when the choking heat and humidity finally crashed down on town in a major thunderstorm. We hung out in the local tavern as long as we could, but still hoped to catch a look at the beautiful courthouse in the center of the old city. We were late, as it closed at 4:30, but we did walk around the perimeter and grounds for a while. 

Heading across Delaware Street, I noticed a sign pointing to a coffee house in a cobblestone alley. Trader's Cove's entrance was deep in that alley, and it also had "Secret Garden" behind the building that held the cafe. We went in to load up on caffeine before heading home.  Their expresso area was tiny with small display for pastry and miniscule kitchen behind that. We ordered chai latte and a cappuccino, with two small pastries (apple fritter and slice of apple walnut coffee cake). Once prepared we sat it the back room to drink and nosh. 
Turned out that there was musical entertainment waiting for us. Two guys with acoustic guitars played and sang for us. Called themselves The Grantwriters, because they both had worked for non-profits and that was what they did. Their style was 50s - 70s soft rock, a la The Everly Brothers sound. Very pleasant. 
An unexpected interlude, but appreciated. We listened for a while as the room filled with a group of elders who seemed to be having a meeting there. They needed more seats, so we exited, walked through the Magic Garden, and took our leave of New Castle. 

In fact, from beginning to end the whole Delaware Day had been so magical.

PS. The java and cakes were good, too. Local roaster and baker. Nice find we might have missed if the courthouse was still open.

Robin Hood, the robbing hoodlum of Sherwood Forest, was known for taking from the rich and redistribution to the less fortunate. In many ways this diner-esque restaurant in Southampton, PA, is true to that calling. They turn out large, very good meals at excellent prices for their loyal customers. Open 24/7, it is an anchor of the community. 

We stopped in for a Presidents' Day breakfast to relax on a Monday morning without work. The house was a bit more than half full and we we're quickly taken to a small table along the windowed wall. Coffee arrived with the requested milk, and we gave our order for a short stack of french toast, side of hash, and a standard scrambled, bacon, potatoes and whole wheat. It was all quite good.

The frenchies were constructed of large slices of texas toast with caramelized edges and pleasant vanilla flavor. Two slices were more than enough. The corned beef hash was likewise crispy with mellow savoriness. The packaged syrup took it down a notch, where real maple would have made it exceptional. The eggs were the right consistency - just north of soft, and the taters plentiful. We both commented on our enjoyment of the meals, and compared them to other recent experiences that we're not as good at more expensive locations. 

Robin Hood was definitely one to remember.

PRO TIP - We were disappointed upon getting the bill and finding an extra charge for bacon when the menu indicated it was part of a breakfast special. Either we missed the fine print, or there wasn't any, that the special was not available on holidays like Presidents' Day. Not that it would have made a difference, but it would have been nice to be told this before settling on our order. Our server said she didn't know about it, and she was advised to add the charge by management. Foolish move. Now they have to see this addendum to an otherwise positive review.

Maybe they thought I could afford it, and they were the ones in need, so a little extra pinch was merely income redistribution. No. It was just bad business.

East Front Café is the dream of two locals to have their own business, and at least one of them was able to walk away from the trials and tribulations of working for someone other than themselves.  In this, at least Sandy, the spirited face and personality of this breakfast/lunch house, has succeeded.  Layoffs come and go, but they were willing to take their assets and start something new.  Sandy may have been a nurse in a past life, but she is a full frontal restauranteur now.  She excels in her house personality role, and has no trouble picking up where ever needed.  Her husband, still on the force at Trenton PD, lives his dream through her.  

Six years are long enough to settle in and dig deep roots in this downtown neighborhood.  They have a good thing going.  The dining area is small, but their takeaways are strong.  To keep things streamlined and efficient, customers order at the cashier in front of the kitchen from the many wallboards describing the menu.  Breakfast is a short list, but lunch has a lot to offer.  From salads to sandwiches; wraps to paninis, the ingredients are fresh each day, and the product well stuffed with food and love.  Take a seat or stand aside, and your meal will be delivered unto you. 

Sandy recommended the Baja Wrap on Wrap Wednesday.  I accepted her challenge on spinach tortilla.  It arrived full of black beans, onion, pepper, lettuce, chicken and a mild chipotle sauce.  The package included soft drink and cookie or granola bar.  It was tasty and filled me completely.  Atmosphere was active and noisy, full of table conversation from engaged folk.  

East Front Café is a keeper, with awesome personality and legit plates to satisfy the hungry beast within.

One of the reasons healthcare has become more expensive than ever is the way hospitals have become medical centers, and medical centers a place with hotel-like accommodations and amenities to comfort not only the patient, but their families and visitors, as well. Capital Health - Hopewell is but one beautiful example of the new breed in institutional medicine. 

On a recent visit to a client I was overwhelmed by two things. First, the crowded parking lot that left drivers hunting for space both front and back of the buildings. Finally found a few near the emergency room entrance, but still far from the circular drive. Second, given this, how empty the actual hospital was. There were very few people in the lobby, gift shop, cafeteria and halls on this midweek morning. Maybe everyone was is surgery or the gym taking Zumba classes. 

But, it was obvious that little expense was spared in the building materials, with wood and stone everywhere. The private room I saw was hard to differentiate from a three or four star hotel, with the exception of the absence of bathroom Jacuzzi. My friend was very comfortable, indeed. The staff seemed to be a full complement, with doctors, nurses, technicians, therapists, and orderlies scurrying to and from assignments. 

This is what they mean by, "...progressive, quality patient care with significant investments in our exceptional physicians, nurses and staff, as well as advanced technology." It includes a Level II regional trauma center, stroke center, perinatal, Level III NICU and emergency mental health screening facilities, and the region's first Pediatric Emergency Department (including, autism-friendly pediatric E.R.). And, what would a state of the art medical center be without a neuroscience institute, comprehensive breast care and digestive health centers, Cancer Center, Heart & Vascular Institute, and orthopedic joint replacement "Center of Excellence?" There are numerous awards associated with these efforts, and to be sure, they all cost exorbitant amounts of money. 

No doubt, we will all be glad everything is there in Hopewell if we need it some day.

Admittedly, being objective about funeral homes is a bridge too far.  

When a good friend departed this mortal coil a few days ago at an age too young, it was just a matter of hours before his family arranged for his "launch" to take place here.  One door closes. Another opens. The soft breeze in the trees is the soul waving goodbye. 

The chapel was no different than any contemporary synagogue.  It was quietly dignified and naturally had us reflecting on the passing of one life to the next dimension, and our own frail mortality.  

Lots of oak. Family reading poems. Rabbinic eulogy spoken personally from the memories of family and friends.  

The Mourner's Kaddish. A prayer for the living. Of the greatness of the knowing Breath. For Peace. That despite profound loss, the One is to be praised. 

"... and the world will carry on..."

What used to be Dragon Restaurant, has been under new ownership for several years, and been renamed, "Dragon of Newtown."
The new team has done a good job improving quality and consistency.  
I have been a regular lunch customer since the changeover.  The combo meals as with most Chinese places offer a cup of soup, egg roll and entree with choice of rice and the ubiquitous broccoli sprigs in a price range from $6.95 to $7.95, including hot tea, hard noodles and duck sauce.  Service is prompt and courteous.  The owner is usually present to oversee operations, and she makes a point of checking with the diners. 
This is typical Chinese-American cuisine, tending to the sweet Cantonese style most liked by western palates.  If you go for this kind of Chinese food, this is a good place.  If you are more adventurous, or know and like the dishes served in China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, or our bigger cities' Chinese communities, then this may not float your boat. 
If you like the spicy Szechuan style, you will have to hunt further in my reviews to find one.
My usual lunch: Hot and sour soup, egg roll, orange beef and rice.  Satisfying. 

2.20.13 - After further review, and multiple lunches, an upgrade to 4 stars is warranted. I must be a fan to continue to return here for lunch on an almost weekly basis.

6.10.18 - The Dragon relocated to the old Meglio's site about a year ago. Smaller space, but same kitchen skills. Prices for lunch specials are now up to $8.50, likely reflecting moving, renovation and rental costs. Worth the increase for the far above average Chinese/ American house that is as prepared for you to grab a table as for picking up the well packaged take out. 

Philamena continues to run a solid, tasty operation.

Bravo Pho has replaced the earlier Vietnamese restaurant at this location, and all I can say is, "Hallelujah!" 

There is no comparison between the two enterprises. Bravo is the real deal, not just a reasonable facsimile for folks who don't know from authentic Viet cuisine. The menu is extensive, and the noodle soup (pho) and rice dishes (com) are excellent. The owners and chef are legit from Hanoi, and know their way around a Vietnamese kitchen. No excuses necessary!

I was in the mood for their version of wonton soup, which was basically pho broth with a large number of dumplings rather than noodles in the hot bath.  Same accoutrements (Thai basil, sprouts, jalapeno slices, lime wedge), and same great taste, but with beef/pork stuffed wontons. I thought it was a very good version of the classic. 

Why not five star? Well, because I am spoiled by visiting Vietnam and eating incredible food in both the north and south of the country. The small houses in Philly and Ocean Grove, California are often excellent, and this one may yet transport me to the Mekong River as those do. When that happens there will be five stars shining above its door. 

Bravo to Bravo for being as slurpin' good as it is!

Schenk's Family Bakery on Veree Avenue in the Fox Chase neighborhood of Philadelphia, has been in the flour, water and yeast business since the early twentieth century when their first generation started baking in Germany before immigrating to Germantown  and opening their shop in 1938. Both the family and the bakery have moved around, but always remained Philly centric. Their recipes travelled well.

Today, their storefront is small and lined with glass display cases and shelved walls, all full of their classic cookies, doughnuts, cupcakes, custom iced cakes and amazing pound cake. My small sample of half dozen doughnuts (glazed, vanilla iced, cinnamon sugar and powdered sugar) were all fresh, lightly yeasty and full of sweet flavor. They were perfect for accompaniment with hot coffee. 

The vanilla pound cake was dense, moist and was solidly superior to any commercial effort I have eaten. Better even than Starbucks, which has been on my pedestal for a long while. It would have been great heated with a scoop of ice cream, but stood unapologetically on its own. Why they loaded it up on three sides with copious amounts of white icing is a mystery. It was truly an amazing sugar coating, but unnecessary given the quality of what it covered. Diabetic overkill. 

That shelf of large Eagles playoff cakes looked great and gave comfort that they would be the hit of any party or cold afternoon tailgate at the Linc. Unfortunately, the sweetness would not be enough to change the outcome of the game to come.

We had a very good dinner here last week while in town for haircut and walkabout. 

The floor plan is spacious, with bamboo and other strong Asian cues.  The staff was friendly and able to answer a few of my more technical questions about the dishes.  The insights provided led me to try the Hue Style Noodle Soup.

Turns out, this potage uses Egg Noodles rather than rice, and has a red cast due to the ground up Spicy Red Peppers and Hoisin mixed into the Beef Broth.  Otherwise, the same Sprouts, Thai Basil, Jalapeno Slices, and Lime Wedges were available as desired. The taste slides up the heat scale and adds another dimension to the otherwise wonderful flavors of the traditional Pho.  A lot of sliced Steak in there, too.  Very satisfying. 

The Shrimp & Pork Roll app was fresh and delish with a sweet peanut sauce for dipping. 

Will definitely return to try more of the menu.

Very enjoyable experience at Vietnam Palace.

Met up with a friend the other night at Hot On D Spot, a Trinidadian Restaurant at the western end of Nottingham Way in Hamilton, tres close to Trenton.  Don't know about you, but I had never tried Trini cuisine before; and in fact while I knew that Trinidad was an island in the Caribbean, I knew little of its history and culture.  My loss. 

Trinidad was settled by a mix of folks who really did not want to be there - African slaves and Indian indentured servants (almost slaves).  They mixed together into a very interesting and spicy society.  The food evolved into something that did not look or taste like either's home cooking.  It was sort of like Indian with similar breads and curry orientation, but with meat on the bone dishes that were of a different continent.  

Regardless, the food was great. We had some Doubles - basically Chickpea and Potato mash with Curry in small round Naan-like soft breads.  Very tasty and definitely a cousin of Samosa.  Next I ordered Roti with Boneless Chicken, while my companion went with Roti and Goat.  Both had a side of the same mix of Chickpea and Potato found in the Double.  I thought the Chicken outshined the Goat.  It was tender and in small pieces long cooked in a spice pot.  The Goat was still on the bone.  It required more work to eat it, and to my palate, was darker and more gamey than I like.  

The accompanying Roti was superb.  It was large and folded up on the plate, but as it was taken out and ripped apart to be used to pick up the meats and veggies, it had elasticity and a ground Chickpea and spice dusting on the inside that added taste and a curiously fine grit to the experience.  I could not finish it.  

I hope to learn how to eat with one hand without using utensils and just pinching the food with the Roti.  It is much harder than it looks, especially if you try not to get your hand dirty.  

The owners and staff were very friendly.  We engaged in a running conversation about the food and life in Trinidad.  Fascinating.  The house only has four tables and a fridge with cold drinks.  I stopped beforehand to pick up a six pack of Red Stripe to add to the festivities. 

This one is a definite keeper.

Ironically, our plan was to walk over to 3rd & Chestnut after taking care of a few things in Chinatown.  The original destination was Han Dynasty in Old City so we could sample what was reputed to be among the best Szechuanese in Philly.  

But, as John Lennon so cuttingly observed, "Life's what happens while you're busy making other plans..."  On our way down Arch we saw the sign for Szechuan Dim Sum Restaurant.  We had been looking forward to a brisk after rain walk, but on seeing this convenient alternative, we wordlessly took each other's hand, made a hard right and jaywalked directly to their front door. Not much traffic on this Saturday afternoon, or we might have been less impulsive. 

We walked in to an almost empty house, with seven wood top tables and a mirrored wall.  There were two servers, also acting as hosts.  The young woman shepherded us to a table mid-shop, and dropped off two menus.  She asked what we wished to drink, and brought a nice aromatic hot black tea moments later.  The set up of fork, spoon and sticks was wrapped in a heavy paper nap with a rose printed on the right spot for the package to appear perfectly placed for casual elegance.  Nice touch. 

The menu was bilingual so my companion had an easy time with descriptions and photo captions. She went quickly to the Spicy Crisp Intestine, and left the rest of the ordering to me.  Up for the challenge, I opted for the Szechuan Style Spicy Chicken (basically, salt/pepper dry pot chicken), and Spicy Eggplant in Garlic Sauce.  Wasn't in the mood for DanDan, Wonton, nor Mapo.  

They arrived in that sequence, with about 5 minutes between each delivery.  All were very good to excellent.  The Intestine was thin cut, lightly fried, and loaded with Red Chili, Scallions, Celery and Peanuts.  Good heat, but not a conflagration, as I did not see any Szechuan Black Peppercorns in the mix; thus no anesthetic effect.  It took you to the edge of the fire, burned your eyelashes, but did not throw you in.  

The Chicken dish was a variation of Salt/Pepper Dry Pot Style Chicken morsels, well dusted in a spicy ensemble, and flash fried twice so there was little oily residue.  Tender meat with more Red Chili, Peanuts, Scallions, and a sprinkling of Sesame Seed on top.  The heat quotient was perhaps a few degrees higher than the Intestines, with more spice during and after cooking.  Very tasty, but perhaps the weakest link in our dinner chain.  

The biggest and best surprise was the Eggplant.  It was sliced into lengths of a four/five inches, skinned, and somehow wok-ked to give a mild crispiness.  How did they do that? It was a neat trick, and it was piled high on a deep dish that created an island surrounded by red, shining, heat vapored, sauce.  The heart of the nightshade remained soft and contained a hint of sweetness.  This combo tag team between the Red Chili flame and unexpected sugar underneath was delicious and fun.  

We thoroughly enjoyed this repast.  If asked to compare with other hot houses in Ctown, it would fall somewhere just below Emei (across the street), on the same plane as Four Rivers and Spice C, and above Traditional Szechuan.  It really reminded me of the old Chili Szechuan on Baltimore Avenue, before it moved to larger digs and lost its edge.  

Gotta say that this block of Arch Street has it going on!

Han Dynasty will just have to wait.

I have been fortunate not to know anyone inpatient at St. Mary Medical Center for many years, but I continue to come here periodically as part of my effort to maintain my health.  Their radiology department is still the nearest source of X-rays, CT Scans, MRI's, etc.  

I was there again last week for a couple of scans requested by my family doctor.  The hospital itself has undergone a facelift over the past few years, and it shows.  The lobby is larger with more seating area, while the registration area is now out of sight.  The hall to radiology passes both a serenity garden with a glass wall for viewing, and the original cafeteria, which has always been a decent place for a bite.  

I was in and out of the building in under an hour.  The check in was fast and courteous, and the lab technicians working with me were relaxed, yet professional.  They made the ordeal of passing through the CT Scanner as easy as possible, when required to remain still and hold your breath with arms overhead six times as the mobile bed slides through the huge spinning magnets. 

Still; no harm, no foul.  I walked out into the waning spring day feeling better about taking care of myself.  

St. Mary seems on top of its game for my purposes.

When Café Ole, right down the street from Downtown Deli had a sign on the window saying that it was closed and for sale, I looked up Warren Street and saw that the Deli was open for business this overly warm November morning.  I asked the folks working out front whether they were serving breakfast, and received an affirmative reply.  

Say no more. Just point me to the coffee.  

I settled into a table on the raised balcony/dining area and in short order a friendly woman approached to ask what I wanted to eat.  I didn't need a menu and I asked for a Sausage, Egg and Cheese Sandwich on a Kaiser Roll.  She nodded and said that particular item was, "...one of my specialties."  

Well, all right!

And, she was right.  Her creation arrived a few minutes later.  The Eggs were Scrambled, rather than Fried, and I found that I liked the overall texture and taste better that way.  The Sausage Patty was slightly crunchy on the edges, which was unusual.  I couldn't tell if it was done purposely or not, but it was another surprising plus.  The Roll was fresh and chewy with a light yeastiness.  Nice. 

The Coffee was some unknown brand to me, but went down hot and smooth. 

Prices were lower than in the burgs, likely reflecting the lower rent paid in the core of this capitol city.  I made a mental note to keep Downtown Deli on the circuit for breakfast before court, and potentially, lunch, afterwards.

Croyden has its full share of divey bars and used-to-be-great taverns where a working person could belly up and grab a few mugs of frosty before heading home, or before bed.  Dog & Bull was one of those places in yesteryear, but is not THAT place any more.  That it is a way cool micro bar on the tracks next to the train station, is true, but what the owners have done with it brings it to another level of coziness and good grubbiness. 

It is now a favorite watering hole for anyone looking for a cool place for a few drinks or a better than good lunch or dinner.  It is tiny.  But, they have a great number of crafts on draft, plus a menu that keeps you entertained.  So, even though I walked in thinking we would have a drink and conversation, we ended up sitting at a high top over dinner. The place is intriguing. 

We both drank the hard Cherry Cider, a first for me, but likely not the last.  It was cool, mildly sweet, and oh, so, refreshing.  My Fried Chicken was done well with Mashed and lightly steamed String Beans.  It satisfied my recent addiction and it was interesting to see how different this dish could be from the standard KFC.  I did not taste my partners Salmon Wrap, but it was large and she stopped talking after she bit off the first chew.  Must have been good. 

Before leaving, the live music began.  An acoustic set by a local artist whose first cover of a Neil Young classic was decent.  He was game, but playing at the back end of the barroom is not the best way to grab everyone's attention.  While his guitar and voice were amped, it was not so loud as to disturb anyone who wanted to continue conversing.  Nice touch.

I really like what they've done to the place, and will return for more of the cool atmosphere, good drinks, and well produced bar/comfort food.

Santangelo's Cafe is a down to earth example of creative adaptive reuse of old urban factories, this one in Norristown, PA. It is a tiny place with entry around the back of the large red brick structure, requiring attention to signs on the street directing where it is hidden. Plenty of parking back there. 

This family run breakfast, brunch & lunch joint has been going for 15 years, and the siblings certainly know how to work together. They are friendly and justly proud of what they do in the community. I sat at the six stool counter overlooking the small kitchen. Although a curtain separates customer view from flying spatula, the sounds of breakfast making are easily heard and entertaining. 

Coffee was decent, and my ask for milk over Mini Moos, graciously met. Unfortunately, it took too long to get a refill, as the curtain blocked the staff view of customers, and the floor person was obliviously attached to her phone. Yet, the short stack french toast was very good. Nice egg, vanilla and cinnamon mix for dipping, and good caramelization. 

Overall, Santangelo's is a strong find on the post industrial streets of Norristown. A little polish on customer service would elevate this earnest cafe to a higher level to match the quality of its menu.

Ting Wong on 10th Street in Chinatown is one of the old school houses specializing in Guangdong cuisine. The abundant evidence hangs in the front window where ruby roasted pork and duck are displayed on hooks as savory invitations to come inside with strong appetite. 

The dining room looks nicer than I recall from my last visit sometime in the last decade. Newer furniture now graces the house, and maybe even renovated floors and lighting. The place is still packed on weekends with people young and old eating their fill of the excellent meat kitchen up front and/or the soup and noodle possibilities in back. 

We had a bit of both. We ordered congee with ancient egg and beef chow fun from the latter and a plate of roast pork and duck over rice from the former. Everything was good to great. The congee was thick and loaded with black hard boiled egg, morsels of pork and chive on top. So much better tasting than it sounds! The pork and duck dish was almost all meat, perfectly roasted to a dark ruby bark and only the slightest fat for extra flavor.
The chow fun was the weakest entre, as it seemed a touch overcooked without sufficient brown sauce to compensate. Still, the taste was there, it just needed more lubrication. 

We liked our meal so much that we ordered half a duck and equal quantity of pork to take home. It was just as good tonight, two days later. 

Ting Wong is a wonderful tradition in Philly Chinatown, with mostly great southeast China cuisine, great prices and a strong following. It is totally old fashioned. You would not want it any other way.

This was my first visit to any Dollar Tree and I was surprised they could fill a supermarket sized store with so much cheap merchandise. I was sent there to pick up helium balloons for my son's Eagle badge court of honor the next day. Wasn't sure if 21 of those shiny boys would lift me off the ground or fit into my car, but I was going to find out. 

Turned out that this Family Dollar was Balloon Central HQ. Right above the cash register were a few hundred already inflated stars and flags in a multitude of colors, with drawers along the back wall with dozens of additional choices. A large tank of helium with special nozzle to fit the mouth of the balloon stood at the ready. 

The shop wasn't crowded and the young cashier had time to pull out the red, silver and blue ones already floating above her, and then retrieve the Stars and Stripes from inventory and fill them from the tank. They were truly a buck each, despite the amount of work required to prepare them for me. She was efficient and friendly throughout. 

I managed to stuff all in my trunk and back seat without a loss, although that was all I saw in the rearview. 

They looked great around the reception area after the ceremony today. Family Dollar made this piece of our day a pleasure to make happen, and would certainly use them again in a helium high voiced New York minute.

They've done a really nice renovation of the old Toll House, turning it into something useful and attractive again after decades of neglect. It will no doubt become a keystone of the new Village @ Newtown that Brixmor is developing. 

We should hope that Nina understands Newtown history and its deep roots directly from William Penn's founding of his New Town in Bucks County, through its 88 years as the county seat, our central role during the Revolutionary War, and even the significant impact of anti-independence sentiment that tore the populis apart before final victory. In Newtown, it is ever more than selling ice cream. It is also about helping people see our story all around them. Nina's is in the unique position to do so with every lick. 

So, yes. Their fresh, hot waffles taste great, and their proprietary ice cream recipes are sweet creamy delights, that measure well against the other milk churn outfits in town. Still, beyond the novelty, it will be known by how it contributes to the overall Newtown experience. 

With so many new food outlets coming on line in their immediate vicinity, we can only hope that Nina has enough parking, that it survives the competition by taking full advantage of its special home, and that it calls on surrounding history as a big part of why it deserves our dollars.

Eddington House down on Hulmeville Road south of Street Road, Bensalem, PA, is a local bar with a decent kitchen and strong following. It is rustic with knotty pine barroom and dining area, and plenty of TVs for the sports contingent. Service is shared among all the floor people, who are collectively friendly and seem always on top of their game. 

We ordered their signature Reuben on Rye and a Pepperjack Burger from their new large format menu. Sam Adams Winter draft and Coor's Light wet are whistles. $2.50 domestic drafts were greatly appreciated. We watched the Sixers take on the Hornets and end their losing streak by 8. (They really have to work on those turnovers!) 

Both sammies were very good. The corned beef was sufficiently fatty to have plenty of taste, especially in the mix with melted swiss and Russian dressing pressed into toasted rye. The half pound slider had not been frozen and was served the requested medium finish, with Pepperjack adding some zing and straw onions a pleasant crunch. They had no problem subbing cole slaw for fries, although I sampled them on my beautiful companion's plate and they were crisp and nubby. 

The only knock on the joint was the loudness of the bar, which circulated throughout due to poor acoustics. Made for challenging conversation at times. Aside from that Eddington House is a nice hangout for brew and bite in this part of Bucks County. 

Quality, pricing and service are all right.

Pho & More 2 is a pleasant facility, nicely appointed to give it a clean open aire. The row of windows up front let in a lot of light for a bright, colorful sense that helps accent the casual semi-tropical feel of the place.  The service is equally light and friendly.  

Having read here that the pho was not the strongest aspect of the house, we went in another direction.  We ordered Goi Cuon (Summer Rolls) as an app, with Pad Thai Shrimp and Com Thit Nuong (Broken Rice w/ BBQ Pork).  All were quite good. The Rolls were cool and crisp with a smooth Peanut Dipping Sauce.  The Pad Thai, while not the best ever, was a solid contributor with a good number of midsized shrimp and a mildly tangy sauce.  The Com dish offered a load of tasty Pork strips, Rice, and Pickled Veggies.  Each table had large bottles of Sriracha and Hoisin to use as needed to reach the desired personal taste of spice and heat. 

We lingered after dinner to chat with our server about business and our time in Vietnam.  He was from HCMC and had been here only a year.  We were able to compare our experiences, and came away feeling very comfortable in his work home.
Whatever may have been lacking in attaining haute cuisine status was compensated by the relaxed coziness of the shop and friendly interaction with the staff.  

It is a place I can return for an easy meal when in the area to shop the Asian markets.

The first review did not take into account the real centrum of Isaac's - its beer. 

As my awareness and taste for craft brews evolve I am developing a richer appreciation for Isaac's Bar and Newton's Natural Laws.  I have returned often enough to realize I have become a fan.  

The choices are extensive and the additions well conceived.  

4 Stars for what there is.  5 Stars for what it could become.

UPDATE: December 23, 3016 -
Full House this Friday night before Christmas. 30 minute wait for a table not unreasonable. Nice booth for 6 upstairs. Service good given the crowd. Mad Elf in the house. 
But, my Pickleback Burger arrived feeling neglected in the kitchen. More well done than the requested medium, and the deep fried Jamison pickles very dark brown and really burnt beyond enjoyable. Burger crumbled when forked, rather than holding firm as a never frozen puck would do. Disappointing effort by the no doubt busy grillmaster.

Adams Avenue in Northeast Philadelphia is a center for the Vietnamese community. The neighborhood is full of pho and com (noodle & rice) houses that are about as authentic as you can find on the East Coast. No, it is not yet as diverse as Garden Grove, CA, with little differentiation between southern and northern style cuisine, but what they do have, they do well by and large. 

Pho Ha Saigon benefits from being a fairly new structure; well designed and spacious enough (in a post industrial sort of way) to attract and hold your attention, with a respectable and capable kitchen. The service staff is generally bilingual and large enough to stay on top of their work. Their HVAC is strong enough to suck the front doors closed and create a semi-vacuum between them, making prying them open to enter or exit a chore. Hopefully, that also means there is sufficient circulation to be sucking out any Covid suspended in the air. 

I went with a smaller bowl of Pho Ga (Chicken Noodle Soup), Spring Rolls, and takeout for the family of Grilled Beef w Vermicelli, and Roast Pork/Beef Banh Mi). The bowl was still large enough for a few goldfish to swim comfortably. The chicken broth had very good flavor profile and there were plenty of accessories (Thai basil, sprouts, jalapeno slices, & lime wedge) to adapt to my tastebuds. The sliced breast meat was downright generous, and the under the surface nest of thin rice noodles, more than adequate. 

While the Spring Rolls were generic, with standard sweet dipping sauce, the pho was a pleasure to slurp with flat spoon in one hand and chopsticks in the other. It filled me completely. I suppose the broth could have been somewhat deeper in secondary seasoning and simmer time, because I found myself suffering a mild case of MSG poisoning on the way home. I am allergic to it, and I should have warned them when ordering. Still, MSG really shouldn't even be in their kitchen. Chalk it up to my oversight. I won't remove a star, but reserve the right to let people know in case they are also sensitive to it. 

That evening my family went after the Banh Mi and Vermicelli dish with gusto. The sandwiches were stuffed and had great taste with strong roll contributions. The Grilled Beef was succulent and in small thin sliced pieces. Delicious. 

But for my bout with the food additive, I totally enjoyed my meal at Pho Ha Saigon, and will not hesitate to return with memo to self about inquiring about MSG.

This local Verizon Wireless shop recently opened, and it is likely they are still working out many kinks associated with any new operation.  Still, I found their willingness to fully engage the customer on the issues important to the phone/service buyer, ie., selecting a new phone, changing the SIM card from a foreign phone for use in the USA, selecting the right plan when five phones are involved, and working through all the set up requirements on the equipment (even in Chinese), was quite amazing. Props to Derek who went above and beyond the call in spending at least 90 minutes with us as we worked through these issues.  He never lost his cool, and remained open and inventive as one roadblock after another was deciphered and overcome.  

This wireless phone business is not easy for most of us, and we all know that it has become increasing expensive with every passing year.  It is almost as if the next step in this industry is for private consultants to begin to offer analysis of need and service availability across the spectrum of alternatives and point us in the right direction, if not complete the transactions for us, and get paid by the phone companies for bringing customers to them.  

Until that day arrives, it is fortunate we now have a local shop with knowledgeable and willing service folk who can at least provide that kind of insight for their own company's line of product and services.  We definitely felt that Derek was doing his best to listen to us, and respond with suitable alternatives.  

These circumstances are never "Wahoo" moments.  But, I am certainly a true fan of the effort I saw today.

Capital Health's new medical center in Hopewell, NJ, follows the trend in modern healthcare to merge the concepts of hospitals and hotels into a one stop shop for all medical needs, with a level of comfort and service that blurs the line between the two industries. Thinking of it as a hotel providing for health needs is probably accurate. 

This is both good and bad. No one complains when a facility is clean, well staffed and meets the needs of everyone walking through the front door. The menu of services is extensive, with well trained professionals all around. Yet, the cost associated with these offerings can be excessive, and even with some insurance, beyond the financial means of most people. Those insurers have become more severe in their rejection of most invoices, realizing they are being asked to pay for a level of comfort for patients and visitors previously unavailable. What do you do when the hospital provides only private rooms and your carrier contracted with you to pay only a percentage of the semi-private rate? You hope you aren't admitted. 

The level of specialization in each sub-discipline means a higher trained doctor is at your call, but while that is critical for some conditions, it is not for others. Still, the expense of over treatment is spread among all the patients without notice, nor consultation. 

Part of this built in excess is due to how medical centers are developed, and the amazing tax advantages a health facility developer has over regular commercial work. The developer makes its money as the construction is done, while the management arm of the business can only expect pay as you go. Medicare, Medicaid and private insurers continually cut their portion of the bills to be paid, while the price tag on the service constantly goes higher. No wonder even the wealthy fear unanticipated medical expenses. 

So, you have to hope the best medicine is available when needed, but also understand the cost of readiness and proximity may break your budget.

On a gentle rise over Peace Valley Park & Reservoir, Peace Valley Lavender Farm provides a splash of rich blue from its plantings on the slope. While the shop is closed due to Covid-19, it is possible to buy their wares from a price board listing all their lavender based products. More than just sachet, you can find lavender infused honey, lavender butter cookies, and lavender scone mixes for the DIY crowd. 

Our purpose for being there was to check out the plants available for our garden. We are looking to add to our landscaping along our back fence, and a row of bushy sweet scented blue lavender would look and smell great for both us and our neighbors. There wasn't much to consider due to Coronavirus. But, at least we got an idea of how beautiful the dark blue variety would look in the ground or dried and hung around the house and offices. 

It seemed that if we were patient, we could purchase the right seeds, dig the beds, plant, mulch and care for them from sprouting to crazy full mounds of wild in the wind sweet lavender. 

And, Peace Valley Lavender Farm had everything we needed to get started.

Riverview Restaurant & Bar is the successor to Café Gallery on the river end of High Street, Burlington, NJ.  A lot of money and attention to detail went in to the makeover of the bar, although the dining rooms with the large windows facing the Delaware appear about the same. It remains a well appointed house designed for higher end dining and drinking in this historic river city. 

I stopped in for an early breakfast last weekend.  Sitting at the bar, I appreciated the comfortable opulence of the thick dark stone bar top and the mirrored back bar holding a multitude of bottles of whiskey, tequila, brandy, and other libations. There was one other customer there waiting for a takeout order, and only a few tables occupied in the other room. 8:30 am was the perfect time to settle in and find out what the kitchen could do. The clipboard menu looked good, and I opted for their version of a croissant filled with sausage, egg and cheese, with the complementary side of home fried taters. Excellent strong java came first to further open my eyes to the coming day. 

Service came directly from management, with an assist from an English-accented young woman, both of whom were friendly and willing to provide information about the operation opened less than one year. The meal was very good - everything fresh and cooked just for me. Thoroughly enjoyed it.  Special mention to the home fries, which were large chunks, well seasoned with taste and texture that had me devouring more than I should. The java seemed likewise freshly roasted, with a pleasant aftertaste that is often lost when the grounds age for a few days. 

I will return for a romantic dinner sometime soon, to see how everything holds up after dark. But, as far as breakfasts go, Riverview really knows what it is doing.

Lahaska, Pa has a reputation for being overly touristy, especially in warmer weather. The label is earned by gitchy shops and bad traffic.  Yet, if you are able to rise early and cruise the rolling hills and farmers' fields of Bucks County and reach Chive Cafe before 9, there is a good chance of finding a table, or even an empty sun drenched front porch, and settle in for a excellent country breakfast.

Such was our good fortune on this picture perfect Saturday morning. Blue skies. White clouds. 75 degrees. Windows down. Windblown hair. Bob Seger tunes. We parked in back and walked in through the kitchen door, found our way to the front porch facing Rt. 202, and chose a deuce against the inner wall. 

La Colombe joe arrived in large colorful mugs.  The small breakfast menu led us directly to their sandwiches. One based in lamb sausage for me, and in grilled ham for my beautiful companion. Fried egg. Melted cheese. Cut fruit and home fries (extra) completed the plates. 

The "#3" sandwich stuffed into a toasted & buttered brioche-style roll; Lamb Sausage, Feta Cheese, Roasted Tomato, Grilled Onion and Fried Egg.  The meat appeared to be thinly sliced to provide more savory flavor.  All the parts played well together, but the Feta and Lamb were major elements, while the Egg, Onion and Tomato were minor scale.  Very tasty, especially when "animalizing" it by throwing the Home Fries into the fray and pressing down. 

"#2" exchanged Country Ham, American Cheese and Herb Mayo for the strong parts of the above, and put them into a traditional Kaiser Roll.  Its statement was more reserved, but a solid chew and swallow.  The taters added some greasy zest. 

There is more to the offerings at lunch and dinner.  Local sourcing is a priority.  The La Colombe coffee was strong and flowing freely.  If country atmosphere is part of your delight, Chive Café provides it is copious quantities.  Definitely worth another look later in the day.

I haven't updated this review since Dragon of Newtown moved to Swamp Road a few years ago.

The menu hasn't changed much, but the size of the restaurant has shrunk to fit in an appropriately smaller space retained from the years as Meglio's. It appears better organized and more tidy than before. Service remains friendly and attentive, and Philomena is still the empress overseeing the operation. 

Although I am occasional there for dinner, lunch is my regular beat. Their combination specials are a few bucks higher than other Chinese houses, but by comparison the quality is higher than most. The wonton soup has a pleasant consomme base stock and the wontons are thin skinned and stuffed with a good ground pork filling. I normally request Orange Beef (fried rice, broccoli, comes with). The sauce is tart with slivers of orange peel, and appears to be made to order, rather than the time stamped heavy gloop offered elsewhere. Decent tea flows freely. 

For a local dine in/take out, Dragon is a way better than average option among Chinese American kitchens. They are really making an effort to appeal to the pallette as well as the wallet.

DJ Kitchen offers Szechuan cuisine on City Line Avenue, Philadelphia. 

Well, sort of. 

It has the red Szechuan peppers down in large quantities, and many other hot spices that bring the willing cognizant diner to the brink of tongue burning ecstasy. Yet, like most other Chengdu facsimiles around town, it stops short of the authentic 'flavor of numb' brought on by only the traditional black peppercorns and star peppers that grow in the hot humidity of the ancient Du plains in the plateau region of the central and western parts of the province. 

Without the Numb, it just isn't true Szechuan. It is still quite good, with quality ingredients and plenty of meat, veggies, spices and sesame oils, but it isn't the Full Monty. The portions are substantial with leftovers for the boys at home. 

We thoroughly enjoyed the Cumin Lamb and Long Hots with Beef. They were colorful with powerful aromas. The meat was tender while the peppers and onions, crisp. The red onion was particularly sweet in contradistinction to the growling bark of the green long hots. Both damn good. The only shortcoming beside the absence of numbing essence, was the saltiness of the Dry Pepper Crispy Chicken. It was an unnecessary distraction to an otherwise entertaining platter. 

We enjoyed chatting with Ming, one of the owner/managers, who took time to explain some of the history of the restaurant. He and his partners have created an interesting haven for those seeking an alternative to the regular Chinese American grub, and although it doesn't travel all the way to to the numbing mountaintops, it does take us a long way up that winding spicy road.

Carlos Garcia seems to have a thriving pizzeria business with the recent opening of his fourth parlor in Morrisville, PA. They are all enumerated after his daughter, Camila. I haven't met her, but it is obvious her father takes great pride in her and the success of the enterprise. 

The location is in a small strip center, replacing an earlier pizza/pasta joint that succumbed in the midst of COVID-19 last year (RIP). It is apparent that they have worked hard to freshen up the space with colorful wall murals and end to end cleaning. The people there are friendly and have skills, although the older dude folding boxes in front of the counter couldn't manage to make eye contact. Maybe a language problem. 

So, I ordered by phone rather than GrubHub, to keep the money in their register rather than sharing with a third party. I went with a large pie, half sausage and penne aglio olio with spinach (which came with side salad and small loaf of oven fresh bread). 

The pizza was good, with firm crust and scorch marks across the bottom. The slices held their point when lifted and folded for eating. As they cooled that rigidity waned and dog eared. The crumbled sweet sausage was plentiful, but a bit salty. The other half of the pie was plain, and probably would have been better with a tad less cheese, so the flavor of the tomato sauce and basil could shine through. 

The pasta was not listed on the menu, and I suspected they didn't regularly indulge such preferences. Still, there was plenty of garlic and good taste. Having had the same dish at a different place last week that was over the top with whole fresh spinach leaves sauteed perfectly, this version was light on the finely chopped greens. I won't downgrade as the chef was doing me a favor and may not have had exactly what he needed for the optimal dish. I appreciated the effort. 

Overall, quite decent for a neighborhood Casa Italiana Mexicana. 

3.5 STARS

I always feel a bit out of my element when invited to a good steakhouse like Capital Grille in King of Prussia. Not a steak lover, I can appreciate the clubby atmosphere, the dark wood tones, and white jacketed servers always where they should be, attentively taking care of their beef obsessed customers. I even love the aroma of grilled sirloin and the menacing glitter of oversized serrated knives slicing through medium rare filet mignon. For me, the odor is the best part. 

So, I ready my excuses for not joining in the carnivorial feast, yet always manage to find plenty of good things to enjoy on the menu outside of the main attraction. Nobody really minds that I am the guy who goes with calamari, wedge or Caesar salad and a tapas approach to the many veggie sides available. Give me interesting brussel sprouts, cauliflower or roast/mashed potato, and I go to town. 

Capital Grille does everything well, and the servers are always on their game. The New England Clam Chowder, Wedge Salad and large plate of calamari (tentacles included) were all tasty and left me full even without the heavier meat load. 

I mused as I worked through my choices, watching my office compadres cut bloody paths through their perfectly finished steaks and chops. I knew we were appreciated by the powers that be to be treated so well.

It's great to see the effort being made to attract new ventures to the shopping centers on Trenton Road in Morrisville, PA. For too long this area has been struggling to attract customers. The best way to make a commercial zone less sketchy is to provide activities that can be enjoyed with the family. Good and entertaining food is part of the equation. Poke Ocean while not a home run, it a solid contributor with its sushi/poke/udon/teriyaki orientation. Three other food outlets are under construction as I write. 

The floorplan looks alot like the previous BBQ joint that ran out of steam last year. It is just cleaned up a bit. Service is cordial and efficient with the right Asian flair. Lunch is served from 11 to 3, although there does not appear to be a poke list discounted for lunch, making the other parts of the afternoon offerings the more appealing. I asked for the salmon teriyaki lunch which included miso soup, iceberg ginger goop salad, white rice and a nice salmon filet over sauteed onion and carrot slivers. The amber sauce was quite good. Additionally, I received a complimentary fried veggie roll, which I liked. 

The lunch was good, although I really don't get the attachment to the iceberg salad, found in every sushitorium in the country. It is all water with that thick orange ginger dressing. Without nutritional value, I would prefer a different option with a more interesting taste/texture profile. How about edamame? 

3.5 STARS

I remember when Antonio's was just a good pizza joint on Trenton Avenue in Morrisville, Pa., just over the Calhoun Street Bridge from Trenton.  My fondest memory was eating there while waiting for oral argument in the New Jersey Supreme Court.  We won that case, so I always associate this restaurant with success.  Now, it is an "Italian Bistro," and has become an upscale stop for folks who like good Italian food but don't want to travel far to get it.  

I sat in the base of the tower last Sunday night.  I had been jonezing for a good aglio olio, and the Café delivered.  My Cavatelli Siciliani came nicely plated in a deep soup bowl, complete with Sweet Italian Sausage, Broccoli Rabe, lots of browned Garlic and topped with Romano Cheese.  Although there was a fair amount of olive oil in water at the bottom of the dish, it did not diminish the full flavor of the ingredients.  I enjoyed it.  

It came with a full loaf of in house baked bread, and a Green Salad with Balsamic.  The bread tasted like pizza dough (which it was), and was unnecessary calories.  The Salad was a fair mix of Lettuces, Tomato, Red Onion, Carrot.  Nothing creative, but a solid veggie accompaniment.  

Service was fine with several servers in black stopping by regularly to refill my water glass and be sure I was satisfied.  Aside from it being a bit too cool for me in a T shirt, the experience was very good. 

Coming at $15.99, the price was about right, but it would have been a true deal had it been a buck or two less.  

Parking was not an issue Sunday night, but it is a small lot, which is likely trouble for a busy lunch hour or prime time dinner reservation. 

Café Antonio is all grown up!

Cosmos on Trenton Road in Fairless Hills is a fairly big place, equally divided between restaurant and bar.  My time was spent in the watering hole, which has a large rectangular bar with a few dozen stools, and is surrounded by HDTVs high on the walls for a good view of whatever sportage is being shown.  The bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable, and very accustomed to people eating while they imbibe.  

As it was my first visit, I opted for their Fire Apple beverage and a bowl of French Onion Soup.  Both were scalding in their own way.  The drink was a combination of Angry Orchard Hard Apple Cider and Fireball Whiskey.  Fireball is a cinnamon-based fermentation, and its flavor goes very well with the hard apple.  It was challenging to just sip it in its large beer glass, as the natural inclination was to take large gulps as I would for straight brew.  Alas, that was not a wise move, as the whiskey's bite clawed at my throat on first swallow, nearly causing me to cough.  A quick learner, I adjusted and thoroughly enjoyed the cool apple crispness with cinnamon kick the rest of the way.  And, yes, I was able to walk away when done.  

Perhaps, the balance came from the very good bowl of L'Oignon Gratinee.  The beef broth was completely sealed by the melted Gruyere, and when opened with spoon, the steam rushed out like a volcanic vent.  Probing, I encountered a load of translucent onions, chunks of thick bread, and slightly oily-sheened beef broth.  It was tasty and savory, and played very well with the cool cinnamon appleness of the Fire Apple.  I had stumbled on a good combination of flavors, textures and temperatures.  

The "cocktail" came in at $8.50, and the potage at about five bucks.  Definitely a nice place to hang out on a midweek evening while exploring both the bar and kitchen menus. 

See ya soon!

A party of seven can be a challenge for a popular and busy restaurant, especially when six of the guests have never eaten Italian food before.  Confusion, questions, blank stares.  But, when lucky enough to be handed off to a seasoned professional wait person, what might have been an eye-rolling chore, becomes an interesting and entertaining part of the evening.  

So it was at Carlucci's Grill in the Lower Makefield shopping center that is anchored by Kohl's Department Store at the corner of Oxford Valley and Big Oak Roads.  I was given the responsibility of ordering for everyone, so after studying the menu I decided to stick with the classics, so everyone would discover what Italiano was all about for the most people.  Parmigianas for everyone, except for the more adventurous who opted for Carlucci's "Princess" finish to chicken and shrimp.  Standard sides of pasta with red sauce, except for the aglio olio linguini I preferred.  

Gotta give kudos to our main man in black & white, and the kitchen.  The feast began with a puff bread with an olive oil garlic drip.  Never had that before, and it was very good fun to rip apart and devour.  The accompanying salads all had balsamic dressing, and were solid, if not exceptional.  We finally arrived at the entrees.  Large plates of veal, chicken and shrimp or eggplant, covered in red gravy and melted mozza or cream sauce (Princess), and sharing space with an ample load of al dente linguini, were placed before us.  

We all fell silent as we dove in.  The veal was fine, thin sliced and sautéed before dosing in ample thick and chunky gravy, with just enough cheese cover to allow the dueling colors to swirl without sealing the meat within.  Nice chew, better swallow. The eggplant could have been more tender, probably due to the thickness of the slices and not enough time in the fry pan to really soften the large circumference of the purple beast.  Still, a credible job.  The pasta sides were average. 

Carlucci's is BYOB, so we consumed Pinot Grigio and Corona in sufficient quantities to keep everyone lose and engaged.  Most importantly, we gave our guests something to talk about after returning to Asia.  

This is what Marco Polo had in mind as he returned to Venice on the Silk Road with his first shipment of rice and noodles.  He could not have fully realized what he was starting.  The Carlucci's have certainly carried the traditions that evolved from the Court of the Great Kublai Khan to us in competent hands.

Another of the growing cadre of very good Mexican restaurants in and around Trenton.  This one, El Potrillo (The Colt) has taken over Marsilio's Kitchen on Roebling Avenue in the Burg.  It is amazing how Mexican rugs thrown over tables change the look and mood of one of the classic Italian houses.  One can only hope they can do something that is the Mexican equivalent of the great Chicken Cacciatore that its predecessor was known for. 

The space is casual, but also clean and well organized.  The bar is no longer servicing alcohol, but in its place are fresh squeezed fruit/vegetable juices.  My large snifter of Carrot Juice was sweet and coolly refreshing.  The menu is diverse and provides just enough English to hint at what you will get.  

My Torta Carnitas (slow cooked pork) was huge and enough for 2 meals.  The Roll was thin and nicely crunchy.  There was plenty of meat at the bottom and it was the base for the Lettuce, Avocado, Onion, Jalapeno, Fresh Cheese, Tomato and Spicy Mayo that all came wrapped neatly in paper.  I needed knife and fork to work my way through the half torta, taking the other piece home for another lunch.  

The combination of fresh veggie juice ($4) and the torta ($8), may seem steep for this type of shop, but when you realize they are preparing two meals for you, the value proposition becomes outstanding.  

El Portrillo asks if "You have tried the best Mexican food around?" 

They are certainly entitled to their hyperbole, because it is among the best I have sampled in Trenton.

Frey's Deli & Pizza sits in a small strip center on northbound Lincoln Highway (Rt.1) in Penndel, PA. It is an unassuming place with a few tables, a big front window, and prep area in the back for pizza and takeout. There isn't much in the way of provisions in the refrigerated display case, but what they do have is either made inhouse or Dietz & Watson. 

I asked about their tuna salad, and was advised it was prepared fresh that morning and a popular seller. Good enough for me, I went with a whole hoagie with lettuce, plus sweet/hot peppers. 

Opened it back at the office. It was heavy in the wrap paper, and substantial upon opening. Not only was the tuna as good as advertised, but the roll had a nice crust and texture that was a pleasure to bite through. Quality sandwich all the way. Tasty, and not the least bit fishy. Just enough mayo to hold everything together and blend perfectly with all the ingredients. One of the better deli sammies of recent memory. Prices were good, too. 

Only downside - there wasn't much to chose from in the drink department. Definitely would benefit from more selection for washdown. But, other than that, Frey's was a very pleasant surprise nosh.

Finally made it to Yardley Ice House, the back parking lot converted shed that puts out some excellent Italian Ices.  

It sits behind Mil-Lee's Luv - In Diner off Main Street, Yardley, Pa.  You have to drive down the adjoining driveway to find it.  First impression upon parking, Oy. what a dismal place for an ice cream parlor.  That is soon forgotten upon walking inside.  The space is cute, in a claustrophobic way, but the folks are friendly and patient describing their options.  

The Bordeaux Cherry/Vanilla Custard Gelato I had was quite good.  The ice was Black Cherry red with plenty of cherry chunks mixed in.  The taste was cold and true.  The Custard was even better.  Stand up curl.  Great creamy texture. Just the right vanilla flavor.  Very close in substance to Kohr's at the shore.  Nothing wrong with that.  

The regular ice cream was not sampled, but I was very satisfied with this Gelato.  The question of the hour seems to be whether it compares favorably with Rita's?  
To my buds, they are very close.  You can't go wrong with either selection, so it comes down to secondary preferences.  Do you mind consuming from franchises over stand alone family businesses?  Do plastic cups rank over paper containers?  Does your loyalty flow toward Pennsbury or Council Rock or Morrisville? 

All important inquiries in the decision to choose your cool desserts.  But, I'll let you decide.  

I'll take you anywhere you want to go.

The Borough Pub on Farragut Avenue, Bristol, PA, is a pleasant joint to stop for a beer or two, and a light bite if hungry. Although it is located on a fairly forlorn stretch of old Bristol Borough, the inside is a cozy knotty pine paneled long room with rectangular bar up front, and dining room/kitchen farther back. Prices are appropriate for the neighborhood, and there is a decent brewlist for those who enjoy a long draught of pilsner.
