They currently have a Yelp check in bonus of a domestic draft (not a crafty). I had a light beer with my meal. 

Son and I stopped in for dinner recently for the first time, and were impressed. The space was well maintained, the staff friendly, chatty and accommodating; and the kitchen better than expected. I went with a small bowl of French Onion Soup and their "Pubrogies," a version of the popular Polish dough pockets stuffed with mashed potatoes, and covered in a nice mix of sautéed onions, green peppers and jalapeno, with a large dollop of sour cream on top of it all. Son with younger and larger appetite, ordered the Cheesesteak Spring Rolls and Honey Chipotle Pulled Pork (Chipotle sauced shredded pork with melted pepper jack, on a jalapeno cheddar brioche bun). 

Everything was good to nearly great. The soup, perhaps the weakest link, had the right savoriness, but lacked the crusty bread and load of wine soaked onions of the original recipe from Les Halles. The "rogies," were tasty with a nice kick from the hot pepper, and balanced well against the inner mashed. The spring rolls were larger than anticipated, crisp and crammed with beef, cheese, onions and peppers. A kicky ketchup came along for the ride for dipping. The pulled pork was devoured by son (didn't offer me a bite) - always an indication that he was enthralled and unwilling to share. Glad he liked it so much. 

Our server, Dawn, had a great attitude. Around just enough to keep everything refilled and moving, with a sense of humor and bonhomie. 

Borough Pub is a place to relax, sip and chew in an atmosphere that is both family and sporty. It doesn't take itself too seriously, and as a result, it is a cool place to kick back and catch some sports and conversation with people you enjoy.

Hot Oatmeal with Brown Sugar and Walnuts......5 Stars

Toasted Everything Bagel  ................................ 5 Stars

Hot Coffee ......................................................... 2 Stars

Intangibles (Facility, staff, atmosphere) ............ 4 Stars

Cumulative Score .............................................. 4 Stars

I liked Garden of Eatin, had a favorable first impression, and certainly would not hesitate to return when in the area.

Hawkeye's Country Tavern is a modern roadhouse on Route 113, Perkasie, PA. It has a decent, but limited beer list, and talented hands in the kitchen. The menu is primarily American classics, with a large sandwich page and multi component entrees for those desiring a bigger meal. 

I sat in the step down barroom that felt like a basement with low ceiling and large rectangular bar. I didn't see the dining room. My server was prompt and friendly, bringing the draft Stella Artois to me in seconds. My plan was to have an early solo dinner while the family worked into the evening, and to bring home food for them so they had something interesting to eat when they arrived.

The chips & salsa table nosh was a nice touch. 

I liked the homemade meatloaf dinner that came with mashed potatoes and fresh steamed zucchini. It was def a step up from a burger, with texture and flavor coming in part from the dark brown gravy on top. Washed it all down with the cold Stella. 

I ordered the Brisket and Cuban Sandwiches and their Original Burger (grass fed locally w cheese, grilled onions and avocado) as takeout for the fam. Later that night I tasted the brisket on brioche and it was quite tender with a nice almost sweet BBQ bite. The Cuban disappeared without an offer from the stepson, while the burger was devoured by son after the rest of us went to bed. Told me he liked it, with special mention of the creamy avo adding interest when I saw him in the morning. 

Overall, although labeled as a roadhouse tavern, Hawkeye's felt like a family restaurant (although I didn't see any kids). It did a very good job with the cuisine standards, and with a better curated brewery component and deeper whiskey shelf, it could attract a more rousing crowd and rock out.

As many reviews of Parkview Cafe explain, this place is difficult to find in the back of an industrial park off Horsham Road, and without a sign to let you know you are close. But, if you follow the GPS into the park, you will eventually see a green awning that lets you know you have arrived. Park the car, and walk along the walkway until you reach the front door. 

Inside, you find a traditional looking luncheonette dining room with tables along a wall of windows, and a smaller room separated by a half wall from the main space. Everything is a simple comfort. The menu is limited to breakfast and lunch, and the morning I was there, one server for the operation, unless someone came out of the kitchen to assist with ordertaking and delivery. So, best to sit back and adjust to a slower pace. 

I made my own omelet of three eggs, onion, pepper, tomato, feta cheese, and asked for it "country style," with the homefries inside the egg case. Twenty minutes and half a mug of coffee later, it was placed before me, with straight edges and two stacks of half moon rye toast alongside. The Valentina Mexican Hot Sauce splashed on top added a desirable bite. 

Aside from being a tad bit dry in spots from overcooking on the hot steel, it was a good dish and quite filling. The buttered toast offset the spice, and the java washdown was satisfyingly bracing. A solid breakfast, but if I had been in a hurry, I would have found it almost unbearably slow. Because I wasn't, I can mention it without heavy markdown, and hope that a word to the wise is sufficient. 

The only "Parkview" seen from the cafe is the vista of surrounding aluminum warehouses and light industrial structures with minimalist shrubery. Once I figured out that someone here had a deep sense of irony, I enjoyed the insight with a smile and tip of my cap to the desert dry humor.

The only Irish Sports Pub in Newtown, The Green Parrot, named for a 19th Century saloon of the same name that thrived at the other end of Sycamore Street and had a less savory reputation, has become the anchor of the new Goodnoe Corner commercial center that is the heart of Newtown Township.  If you want to catch World Cup action, this is the only local place to belly up to the bar and see it live at 6 in the morning.  It is also the centerpiece of all the street action fairs, shows and other events that occur in this fair burg. 

If you enjoy loud bars with a couple of dozen HDTVs on the walls and winsome bartenders pouring your crafties, this be your place.  It has a rotating beer list that is bound to have something that appeals.  The kitchen is strong in the apps department, and grills up good burgers (starting at $10), but the dinners can be spotty, so for the price I tend to look elsewhere to sup. 

Still, I am a fan for what The Green Parrot does well, and for its active role in the life of our community.  Plenty of parking behind the house, and on the street.  Entrances front and rear. Nice covered porch which works well for private parties.

After gorging @ Mood Café and wishing it had a lounge to push away from the table and offer time to digest, I realized the only alternative was a strong dose of caffeine if I was to make it home alert enough to dodge all the gaping potholes between West Philly and Bucks County. 

 Perhaps it was Devine Intervention, but as I turned the corner onto 47th Street, I saw the bright red neon of the Vietnam Café.  The image of a big glass of Vietnamese Coffee filled my head, giving me an immediate jolt of anticipation.  My parking angel was also accommodating; providing a space almost right in front of its door.  I uplifted a smile in gratitude. 

Walking in, it was apparent that design and expense were put into the space.  It was very pleasant with many windows, attractive lighting, cozy tables, and a nice bar.  That was where I headed after advising the host/manager/owner that I was only interested in coffee.  The place was not crowded for a Saturday night, and there were a few empties at the bar.  The gracious gentleman did not skip a beat, and welcomed me to take a seat and he would see to the coffee.  Moments later, he was behind the bar, depositing my personal drip stainless steel press in front of me.  It sat on top of a thick cocktail glass with a half inch of Condensed Milk at the bottom.  I watched the dense brown colloid infuse the Milk, drip by drip.  I had time to take out my phone and check with Yelp about the place.  I learned that I had been in its sister ship, Vietnam on 11th 
Street, in the past.  This made sense, given the attention to detail not often found in VN joints.  I also perused the menu, wishing I was hungry enough for a Banh Mi and a Com dish.  

The coffee hit the spot and I decided to indulge with a Spring Roll to be a good sport.  It arrived precut and with a rich sweet/spicy sauce.  It was fried, a small surprise, but quite good.  I was in and out in about 45, deciding that I would definitely return for a full repast to show my appreciation for the graciousness extended, and the karmic smile bestowed.

With an hour to wait before I was due back in court, I drove down High Street looking for a place to hang out over coffee.  

I found that place with YelpHelp at the Mugshot Diner.  This is a corner establishment in the heart of downtown Mt. Holly.  It does not look like a traditional diner until you go inside.  Once the door closes behind you, all the cues are visible.  The counter with a half dozen high back stools; the booths along the walls, and the very friendly server slinging hash, Joe, and worldly wisdom to all who listen.  Of course, the mug shots are there, too.  Everyone from Frank Sinatra to Elvis hangs from the wall.  The multitude of bail bondsmen on the street close on the county courthouse explain why this name was chosen.  

I ordered a Corn Muffin and Java and had time to talk with the waitperson, who happened to also be the owner of the business.  She was energetic and took pride explaining how she and her spouse had brought this business back to life after the original owner of the property had "bailed" on food here and taken the concept to Philly and other locales.  The café that had been here for a couple of years ultimately failed, and these good folk approached him about reincarnating the Mugshot.  The rest is current events.

My Corn Muffin was much better than average, remaining moist and mildly sweet even after grilling.  It was also larger than what I had sampled in other similar food outlets.  The coffee was strong and there was no hesitation when I asked to swap out the half and half for regular milk.  

There are a few very good breakfast/lunch houses sprouting up in Mt. Holly lately, and Mugshot Diner is one of them.  I will be visiting again when I find myself with time on my hands in historic Mt. Holly.

When I came into Nifty Fifty's for the first time today my first impression was that the joint was almost empty at 2:30, and a far cry from the description of bedlam read in some reviews. Okay. That was a good thing, although I noticed the sign out front said something about being a "Family Fun Restaurant," with mini golf and an arcade. I hoped that that the victuals would still be as good as Yelped. 

Clearly, NF's is more about the shakes and hand made soda concoctions than the burgers.  After all, you get a choice of more than 100 shake flavors, while the burgers menu is really rather small. Single, double or triple, with/without cheese, shrooms, onions, lettuce, mayo, etc.  Not even a jalapeno option.  The fries and onion rings sounded more exciting than the slider selections. 

All this evidence became manifest shortly after I ordered the black cherry shake first, and then the single burger with, and mushrooms and fried (not sauteed) onions, and the onion rings.  The burger and rings came out in separate red plastic baskets, while the shake was overflowing its large aluminum container in which it was spun in the blender.  I looked at the feast before me.  Shake, rings, burger in that order of visual stimulation.  I grabbed a few extra napkins as the shake began to run down the sides of the container, leaving a path through the condensation. 

The shake was just incredible.  Intense black cherry flavored, thick, sweet, creamy. I started to fade back to about 1954 (Yes. I was a kid then) and relived the wonder sensation of a DQ Blizzard.  A pleasure zone in my cortex was triggered and I silently convulsed with joy.  It was way to much for me, and I took half of it home.  The onion rings were extra large, and breaded with a mix of spices and bread crumbs that made the crunchy bites delicious.  The burger became an afterthought.  It was decent with adequate grease, diaphanous onions and canned shrooms, to satisfy my basic burger lust, but not up to the standards of 5 Guys, Jake's Wayback, nor In N Out. The single seemed smallish. The bun undistinguished, and the ketchup shot from an overused red plastic counter rocket. The bun collapsed under the oily weight of the topping and I had to retreat to a knife and fork.

Sure. I will go again.  The overall experience was fun and the meal had some major positives (the shake and rings), that overcame the rather lethargic effort at a good burger.  I obviously picked the right time to go, as I sat alone at the counter and had the friendly waitress to myself.  I enjoyed the meal in peace.

How many people love their jobs so much that they willingly pose for a Yelp photo without being asked twice?  Not so many.  But, at this Philly Soft Pretzel Factory, not only are the pretzels bagged while hot, but the workers there genuinely smile and have fun taking care of you.  

We picked up 10 standard sized bowties, although we had the choice of minis, and singular chubby nubs.  During our interaction, they described how to use them as sandwich ends by slicing and even grilling before loading with our favorite contents.  Never thought to use them at home that way, but liked the idea.  

I never believed a one item business would be successful in the long run, but these folks have been ongoing for more than ten years.  That is a hell of a lot of pretzels.

Now that my office is in the area I have the opportunity to find and try a whole new world of food outlets.  One of my weekly staples is good pizza, and being so close to Trenton, tomato pie is practically on every corner.  

Divine Pizza attracted me to its name as it was different than all the standard Tony's, DeLo's and other family named shops that abound.  Could be the name was Divino in the old world, but my first reaction was that they were trying to make a statement about their product being heavenly, or at least aspiring to be.  It's located in a mini strip commercial structure on Arena Drive with a Dairy Queen as the anchor tenant.  That was a good sign.  Built in dessert.  

Walking in I noticed that this was a side by side orientation, with the dining room next to the kitchen/take out area, rather than front and back.  The dining area was not too big, and the tables had a nice black and wood top surface.  The menu was presented in a small bound book that covered everything for lunch and dinner.  Again, slightly different than most joints.  The radio was playing quiet rock; another pleasant distinction.  

I went with the regular double slice of pie.  When it arrived a few minutes later I observed that the shape was almost equilateral, with narrow circumference  crust.  Picking up one it was quite firm, and held its point high without the hint of bowing.  First bite discovered a very firm undercarriage that demanded a purposeful clenching of the jaw to break through.  Very nice.  A peek under the hood showed the scorching of dough from a very hot oven.  The black streaks were just enough to demonstrate no fear of under baking, nor reheating.  It stood up to the challenge.  

Finally, the chew and taste were purposeful and a little complex.  It was both salty and sweet, with the sweetness coming from the tomato and the saltiness from the crusty bottom.  They played very well together.  

I liked this pizza much more than anticipated, and realized that there were many elements of the experience from the first moment that foreshadowed a good tomato pie.  Divine Pizza may not extend to the heavens, but it turned out a very enjoyable slice.  Given this introduction, I will certainly find my way back to see what else they can do that is better than expected.  

Divine Pizza may yet be Dante's best work.

Xi'an Sizzling Woks does its namesake food very well.  As others have commented, stick to their Chef Recommendation and House Special menu and you will have a unique and enjoyable meal.  The farther you wander from Xi'an, the more the cuisine slides toward the norm, and becomes like most other shops in the area.  Best to stay on the Silk Road from beginning to end. 

My experience last week proves the point.  We ordered Dumpling in Chili Sauce (Szechuan), Xi'an Liang Pi (Cold Mild Spice Noodles), Biang Biang Noodles w/ Ginger Scallion Sauce (Rave), and Spicy Pot Flavor Fish Fillet (Surprise Star of the Show). 

The Dumplings were the weak link in our meal.  The skin was thicker than in a true Szechuan house, and the ground pork while plentiful, did not exhibit much flavor.  The Chili Sauce was not nearly hot enough.  We were sorry we wasted stomach space on something so mediocre.  

The Xi'an Liang Pi was a fettuccini width cold noodle bathed in a semi-hot sauce with Tofu, Shoots, and a few things I could not identify.  It was good and renewed our faith that the rest of the meal would be deliciously distinct.  

We moved on to the Biang Biang Noodles in Ginger Scallion Sauce.  As you have already read everywhere on this page, these Biang Biang are Bangin!  Our server stirred the bowl for us to be sure the sauce coated as much of the pasta as possible.  These hand cut bad boys were longer than a foot, and required high end dexterity to lift them high enough to clear the pile in the dish, maneuver them over to the small plate and then work the chop sticks to your lips well enough to take hold of the noodle and suck it into your mouth. Slurpy mess, but well worth the effort, as these were terrific due to the play of ginger, scallion and cumin (I think) on the tongue.  Subtle heat that grew slowly, but never approach the scalding of a Szechuan chili dish.  The noodles were firm and chewy and filling. 

We would have called the night a great success if we had stopped there, but the urge to try something more brought us to the Spicy Pot Fish Fillets.  These tender morsels of fluke were crisp on the raised texture of each fillet, and included veggies and mushrooms is a wonderful red/orange sauce that also packed a punch, but more gently than, say, Emai across the street.  I loved this dish, and will try the other variations with beef, chicken, lamb and pork intestine in the future. 

Xi'an Sizzling Woks is a smallish shop with no more than a dozen tables.  Best to get there early or late to avoid a wait.  It represents the style and cooking of this very old city that was once the capital of a Chinese Dynasty, and is now an industrial and university town, exceedingly well. It is certainly worth a visit (both city and restaurant).  It could easily become a regular stop on my Chinatown cruise.

If I am here often enough to be a Duke, I must be a fan!

Too, this morning I had the Raspberry Stuffed French Toast blackboard special.  Two slices of well dipped bread sandwiching homemade creamy Cream Cheese stuffing, and topped with in house Raspberry reduction topping.  

Sweeeet & Tarrrt!  Filling enough for two meals. 

Best thing I've eaten at Squirrels Nest.

Sub Maria's scores points just for its nameplay.  

This now Korean deli is packed into a small corner storefront with floor to ceiling shelves and refrigeration that provide almost everything imaginable for a good Jersey lunch.  Superior loaves of fresh bread are the heart of any worthy sandwich, and Maria's uses an excellent bakery.  Light, mildly springy, just the right yeast aftertaste.  When loaded with well made Chicken Salad, Lettuce, Tomato and Sweet Pickled Peppers, it is a pleasure to indulge. 

The back glass walled drink cases are full of the favorites, except for some of the more exotic international brands, like Jarritos.  But, you can't expect a joint this small to have everything.  

The aisles inventory snacks and pre-packaged sweets to complete the meal.  

Now, if they figured out a place to make fresh fruit smoothies, bubble teas, and real brownies, they would be a candidate for the Jersey Deli Hall of Fame.  

As it is, Sub Maria's knows how to create an awesome Submaria...ine. 

A little hard to find at the ass end of Nottingham Way, it is worth pulling out the GPS to enter this special emporium.  

Parking lot out back.

First visit to Stadium Bar & Grill last Wednesday night while waiting for night class to let out.  I do remember this being Kris Krois, a deep blue seafood joint that I enjoyed a couple of times.  Times change.  Now we have a nice large rectangular bar with back dining room that pours national and local suds and an abbreviated short order menu for those so inclined.  Specials every night of the week.  

This is a neighborhood bar looking for neighbors on this forlorn stretch of Rt. 1 in Fairless.  Only 5 people here when I walked in around 7:30 pm.  The friendly barkeep approached with a smile, and when I said this was my first time, she promptly gave me the quick tour of drinkables, and handed off their menus to examine.  My Sam Adams Winter Lager was perfect for a cold night, and had I been hungry, a few of the snacks looks appealing and very well priced.  

The HDTVs were channeling plenty of sports, and the other guys were engaged in conversation about industrial cooking.  Apparently, they worked at different assisted living facilities, and had tales to tell.  I eavesdropped now and then, as one of the homes was in my town.  Good to know the inside poop.  

My 45 minutes went fast. I paid and promised to return on a Monday for their wing night.  No one seemed to hear me, except the nice bartender, who said she would be waiting.  

Cool!

I am a Bristol fan. 

When I see something worth applauding on Mill Street I want a review with a marching band.  So, when Café Bombay came to my attention I had to visit ASAP.  Last night was the night. I drove down with two mystery munchers and entered just after 7 per our reservation.  We were the only patrons, which was a bit disconcerting, but we grabbed the table in front to have the best view of the world going by, and be farthest from the kitchen.  The turmeric in the air was so palpable that we all were sneezing within minutes.  At least we knew the Masala Sauce would be dynamic. 

For apps, we order 1.5 orders of Veggie Samosa.  We were pleased that half orders (1 samosa) were viable, as we only were three, and wanted to save space for later. The Sams were excellent with soft potato and hard peas.  NIce.  Our entrees consisted of Kerala Chicken Curry, traditional dish; Chicken Xacutti, Roasted Coconut was the most noticeable spice;  and Navarathan Korma, veggies, cheese, nuts & herbs.  All the gravies were creamy and packed a punch.  Given that we had to find a common denominator of heat, the range chosen was between 6 and 8, and all tasted, "just right."  Additionally, we had Bombay Naan, a sweet version of the classic Indian Oven baked bread, with Almonds, Raisins, Ginger and Coconut; a perfect balance to the spicy heat coming from the main courses.  All these were first class.

The Mango Lassi while good, was undersized for the price of $3.50.  We were suggested to try a slice of Coconut Ice Cream Pie for dessert.  A first for me, it was pleasing like a cold Key Lime Pie, but a questionable purchase at $4.99.  

Café Bombay is definitely worth another visit as the menu hides other treasures.  Still, in an attempt to learn the lesson here, I would skip the lassi and dessert, and stay with the variety of main courses and regional specialties listed on the menu.  

One other oddity is that the online website menu does not list prices to permit changing market conditions.  That is a situation that should be easily remedied with a host changing the prices as necessary.

Seventh Heaven!

If they say it, it must be true.

Back in the Day downtown Trenton was a hotbed of cuisinery delights. So, it comes as a somewhat pathetic reality to acknowledge that there is at least one such institution there now.  Where once you could choose among very good Italian, Greek, Diner, Seafood, Soul Food, and even the hidden blues/jazz club within shouting distance of City Hall, today there are a plethora of dumps along the sad streets of T-town; and there is Settimo Cielo. 

Born out of the ruins of an older restaurant, Settimo Cielo came into the world with the vision that this once proud city still held the potential for a classy well appointed joint that could kitchen up high quality Italian dishes.  Surrounded by State office buildings and concrete pill box garages, this oasis has been around long enough to prove the truth of that dream.  

If they cook it right, they will come.

Went there for a business lunch the other day with two other attorneys who work in town.  They are semi-regulars, and were excited to bring me there for a sit down.  It was great to be able to walk there from their office near the County Courthouse.  Upon entry, the drab street was promptly left behind, and we entered a cool umber dining room complete with art and mirrors, tablecloths and shining silver.  The menu was presented, water poured, and specials announced within minutes.  Everyone had a Spanish accent, and that added to the intrigue of what was going on in the kitchen.  

I have learned to eat light for a business lunch, so as to impress my companions with my lean approach to work.  No room for extra calories when preparing for battle.  The image seems to work.  My mates, not concerned with what I thought of them, went heavy with Pasta and a Creamy Vodka Sauce.  I heard there was a Spinach Salad Special complete with Pears and Apples, and went for that. 

The Bread Basket offered decent baked dough, but perhaps not what exited the ovens of Italian Peoples or the belated Colonial.  Still, the crunch was satisfying.  My friends seemingly inhaled their thin pasta, while I navigated through an excellent fresh green Spinach Salad that included a touch of Blue Cheese and Walnuts.  It wasn't big, but it was tasty, and served the purpose of demonstrating my cross-pollinated Spartan/Epicurean style.  

It was a satisfying lunch on several levels, not the least of which was the positive experience surrounding the food. 

Settimo Cielo is certainly worth a return evening visit.

Bonjour Creperie Café is on the first floor of an office building at 790 Township Line Road in Lower Makefield, Pa. It seems to have been open a very short time as it is still bright and shiny.  Even the crepe cooker looks brand new.  

Jean Pierre is the owner and crepemaster in this maison.  He dresses the part well, with black striped pants and white chef's jacket.  Even his very authentic French accent adds to the genuineness of the experience.  He greeted me with, "Bonjour," and seemed happy to have a short exchange in Francaise.  

My breakfast Crepe of Bacon and Gruyere, topped with a smoky Vinaigrette drizzle was very good, and the accompanying Java was also a superior blend.  There is much more on the lunch and dessert menus, but they must wait for another time, when I don't have to run off to the office.  

I hope Bonjour Creperie Café does well at this location.  This office complex does not offer any alternatives, and it is nice to have a quality vendor close at hand for the folks who work here. There is also an outdoor area for good weather dining.

With Philly off limits for the arrival of Pope Francis, I took the opportunity to explore a different part of the Universe and drove out to Telford for a taste of the Vietnam Café & Restaurant.  As the saying goes, "One door closes, and another opens..." And, so it was on Saturday night.  

This family owned and operated Viet house has been at this location over ten years.  Upon approach it looks to be small and designed for take out, but on entry the large size of the dining area comes into view.  Plenty of room for dozens of people with tables off to the right.  Orders and most table service are provided by one gentleman who appears to be at least a manager of the shop, if not an owner.  His torn jeans approach to his job suggests the later.  

We opted for Summer Rolls, Grilled Pork Banh Mi, and Chicken Fried Rice.  They were all very good.  The Rolls were stuffed with large Shrimp and ground Pork.  The Peanut Dipping Sauce was pretty much standard, but was the expected complement to this appetizer.  The Banh Mi was very good with fresh French Baguette, well-grilled and BBQed Pork, and ample sliced Cucumber, Carrots and Cilantro.  A squirt or two of Sriracha and the crunchy supple sandwich came to life.  Loved the bread.  The Fried Rice was really unnecessary, but it was a huge mound of freshly made White Rice full of Chicken and Veggies.  I would pass on this in the future. 

The patrons here looked like the remains of the hippie literati with some curious couples thrown in the mix.  We fit right in!

Now that the Pope has departed, I will more likely return to Philly for my Vietnamese fix, but Vietnam Café & Restaurant was certainly as good as most of those I have tried around Washington Avenue.  Good to know it is there should the city fathers over react again to the coming of an international superstar.  With the Democratic Convention coming next summer, Telford could get another look.

PRO TIP - The Banh Mi is not on the menu.  They are found on the walls of the joint, and are available for the asking. 

PRO TIP 2 - Pay your check at the register.

Great first impressions!

The floor is well laid out with plenty of room in the front and back dining areas.  The space is tastefully decorated with Asian influences.

The takeout menu fits on one page, front and back, so it is not too complicated, even for a first time customer.  Appetizers run from spring rolls to fried egg rolls, dumplings and sugarcane wrapped ground shrimp.  We were there for the Pho, and had Pho Ga (chicken in steaming chicken broth with a heap of rice noodles).  The garnish of sprouts, basil leaves, jalapeno slices and lime, was fresh and added great textural flavors.  The Pho comes in two sizes, kids and regular.  The regular bowl is large enough for your pet goldfish (to swim in comfortably). Next time we intend to branch out into the sandwiches and grilled entrees, as they looked real good on the next table. 

I have loved Vietnamese coffee since visiting Ho Chi Minh City, and it was exactly the same with condensed milk and personal size french press coffee drip at the table. 
The fresh fruit smoothies looked tasty, too. Next time.

Bottom line - Maybe not quite the experience of a Pho cafe in Da Nang, or our bigger cities, but still authentic, flavorful and worth the trip. 
Highly recommended.

2.20.13 - I have been back a few times and tried the Tea (personal teapot and wonderful teas), Sandwiches (BBQ Pork on authentic French Demi Baguette very tasty), and Mango Smoothie (creamy, fruity and so good going down).

We had a great fundraiser here at Rose Bank last night. 

The tasting barn is a wonderful indoor venue for a party of 100 people or more. The high ceilings and exposed beams still smell of cedar, and the stone floor and windows help create a perfect ambiance for a fun evening. 

Luckily for us, several of the best restaurants in Newtown pitched in with contributions of their popular dishes - La Stalla, Vecchia Osteria, Piccolo Trattoria, State Street Kitchen, Slack's Hoagie Shack, and Starbucks gave us more than enough food to keep us sated throughout the night. Kate Sotillie and Chuck Ball performed perfect accompanying music (she can really sing, and Chuck plays acoustic guitar with flash and style).  Kings of Leon! Fleetwood Mac! Adele! Come on people!!!

Yes, we did have a few obligatory comments offered by our County Commissioner, State Representative, and the "Two Tough Mother" candidates for Supervisor, but we did not allow the pols to take the air out of the huge room.  

Every table had a bottle of red, blush and white to enjoy, and about a dozen more for given away as door prizes. What I tasted was pretty good, although I had to limit myself because I was the MC for the fete, and I did not want to embarrass myself.

Pho 75 on the 11th block of Washington Avenue in South Philly has about the best pho broth I have tasted around here.  It is rich and complex with subtle anise undertones that seem to shift in intensity from top to bottom of the bowl.  It is really quite amazing.

I ordered the Rib Eye Steak in a regular (small) bowl and had it steaming my glasses in under 5 minutes.  The side accoutrement of Thai Basil, Jalapeno slices, Lime wedge, and Spouts were all fresh and plentiful.  After using all I wanted, there was plenty remaining on the plate.  I pushed them aside to make room for the Sriracha and Hoisin Sauces into which l dip the beef for eating.  

Maybe I am just a barbarian, but with broth this good it does not make a difference to me what meat goes into the bath, aside from its contribution to the flavor of the soup.  The wonder of the pho is all about the taste of the broth.  The most important thing is to be sure to finish every last drop in your bowl to reach and savor all of it.  Don't worry if you want to pick up the bowl and pour the contents down your gullet.  

That's what everyone else is doing anyway! 

CASH ONLY - Minus 1 star for lack of convenience.

Bella Café is a new edition to the scene at the eastern end of New Falls Road in Levittown, Pa.  It remains an Italian house under new ownership and name.  They have an extensive breakfast menu for the early crowd, which I was there to take advantage of.  The place was clean and attractive in an old school way, and service was warm and efficient.  

I was looking for French Toast, and Bela had a couple of choices.  Short or Tall Stack of Texas Toast styled egg fry, or the same in "Stuffed" versions with sweet cream cheese and fruit of choice toppings. Tempted, but I ask for the regular shorty.  A few minutes later, a large white round plate arrived with a nicely powdered sugar dusting of well grilled Pan Grille Francaise. 

The egg had been mixed with vanilla, sugar and cinnamon long enough to absorb a lot of flavor, and left on the iron sufficiently to allow the edges and ridges in the bread to be caramelized.  The chef knew his stuff.  The thick toast looked great, especially after a melting of butter, and pour over of packaged Smucker's syrup.  The taste and texture were fine, and a nice reward for waking up early enough to indulge this morning. 

I was the only customer today, which is unfortunate for all the folks who are missing a good wake up.  Even the coffee was fresh and strong.  

If there was anything that kept Bella from ringing a fifth bell, it was the use of packaged corn syrup sweetener, rather than having a maple syrup option.  I would have gladly paid an extra sum for the chance to turn this French Toast into something magical with the addition of real maple grade B dark, to complement an otherwise excellent presentation.   

Nice going!

This Chicken Holiday has a few things going for it.  

First, it turns out top of the line Fried Chicken, BBQ Ribs and Buffalo Wings.  Each order is individually prepared when it comes in, so nothing is sitting around waiting for an unfortunate to consume a less than prime meal.  I found the chicken to be moist with nicely spiced breaded and fried coating.  The Ribs were large, dark brown from the basting sauces, and nearly "fall of the bone" tender.  The BBQ taste was both sweet and tangy, just as it should be.  The Wings are larger than found in most outlets, but the hotness covers every nook and cranny.  

I can't say that these items were the best I ever had, nor that they were as good as it gets.  Yet, given what is available in the area, they are all on the high end of taste and enjoyment, and for me, there is no need to look further afield to satisfy my Fried Chicken Addiction. 

And, if you come on a Sunday afternoon you can enjoy an impromptu car show in the parking lot.  Folks are there from all over opening their hoods and hooking up their stereos to external speakers so everyone can check out their wheels to Deep Purple.

East Lincoln Highway, Langhorne, PA, is primarily noted as the location of the Reedman-Toll automobile dealership, the largest car outlet in the country. In its shadow are many smaller businesses, including this Friendly's restaurant. Obviously, it is well known, as when I arrived around 7 pm on a Sunday night, it was more than half full of customers chowing down on the traditional American cuisine and ice cream desserts for which this chain is known. 

I was guided to a booth along the front wall by the hostess, and handed the laminated multi-paged menu. Their Sriracha Burger sounded interesting, and I went with it, medium. I was assured by my server that I would receive a pink finish from their never frozen ground beef.  She was right. Unlike many burger joints that promise the desired degree of grilling, but inevitably deliver only a well done puck, this kitchen did keep its word. I was given a medium burger that was lightly pink throughout. Gratitude. 

The rest of the accompaniment - pepper jack cheese, bacon, onion straws, lettuce, tomato, sriracha mayo, on brioche bun - were all present and accounted for, although the "crispy" onion was soggy. The overall taste satisfied my burger craving for the week. At ten bucks it was priced beyond its actual value, but it was good to know that Friendly's was keeping up with the burger wars, where every food emporium had to offer a decent six ouncer to stay competitive. 

It is safe to say that Friendly's keeps up with the other franchise Joneses in this universe. You can come here for a burger or other of their beef and chicken offerings, and leave sated. And, if in the mood, their ice cream makes for a very convenient and creamy end of meal. 

Looks like Friendly's will be around for a while longer. 

3.5 STARS

Lou Lou Burgers is a new house on Main Street, New Hope, PA. The inside dining room is small, but there are plenty of red umbrella-covered tables in the front yard to help out. It is run by college students, which keeps the energy level high to offset the laid back atmosphere in the woody dining room. It also means less than consistent service as sometimes they are more engaged with themselves than customers. No big deal, but you don't want to be that guy who gets impatient waiting for the bill with empty plates on the table. 

My Firecracker Burger was a fresh ground half pound of round steak and brisket, finished to the requested medium on a decent bun. The taste was excellent, with a never frozen texture and true beef flavor. Liked it alot. The side of fries were likewise taters just moments before the drop into boiling oil. Crisp, lightly salted, with plenty of those little nibs to crunch. 

Prices are reasonable @ between $6.50-7.50 per, but everything else costs, so it is hard to get out at less the ten bucks a person. 

This is New Hope (No Hope), after all.

This Burger King sits in the neighborhood of Sesame Place and Oxford Valley Mall.  As such, it is in a premier location to attract families and shoppers for a fast bite.  Anticipating this, BKHQ designed this shop with extra space, large kiddie room, and a multitude of dining areas with different looks and feels. They even put in a fireplace lounge for those in a romantic mood. It may be the nicest Burger King I have ever seen. Almost date-worthy.

My Whopper was as good as a Whopper can be, and still fell short of much of the competition. It was hot, but the large slices of onion were not. Mayo and lettuce caused slippage, and my fingers bore witness to the consequence. Fries were decent and there were plenty of carbonated beverages, while not the excessive choice of the new fangled sodie machines. 

Service was amazingly efficient for a fast food operation, with servers walking my tray over to me beyond the counter. The space was very clean. 

If BK figured out how to make a first rate burger, a joint like this would be a revelation.

Although Ginger Wok in the shopping center anchored by McCaffrey's Supermarket in Lower Makefield, PA, is oddly named given its decor and menu, it is an attractive modern Asian house with a dual identity. Operated by Chinese folk, it offers Japanese sushi and Chinese American standards in a room that feels much more oriented toward raw fish. A lot of money was spent on dark slate floors, white wavy walls, nautical wallpaper, and subtle lighting. No denying the place is beautiful. I was pleasantly surprised by how good it looked. 

I was there to try their Chinese lunch menu, and was not disappointed. For $6.50, all the usual suspects were available with soup or eggroll and fried/white rice. While most deliver such deals in takeout packaging or cheapo plates, my meal arrived on a strong white sculpted platter and metal flatware. The black tea (+$1.50) came in a ceramic mug and with strong flavor. 

The General's Chicken was well prepared (although a lighter coating would make it better), with a legit semi-hot amber sauce complete with small Szechuan chilies. The fried rice was copious, but could have been warmer. The wonton soup had a good light broth, with average wontons. Service was friendly and timely. 

I walked out $10 lighter, but quite satisfied with my Friday afternoon meal. 

PRO TIP - Walk to the back of the house to see the sushi bar and fish tanks, the second of which has a few Gar in the crystal tank. Exquisite fish.

It's not the largest beer distributor in Newtown. It's the ONLY beer distributor in Newtown. As such, it is a convenient place to pick up a few cases of Boddington, Flying Fish, or the King of Beers, for your next shindig or to get you through the week. 

Yes. It still feels like a cool, damp warehouse, mainly because it is.  Floor to ceiling cardboard encasing a cool twenty-four is bound to make everything moist. 

Don't forget to go next door to the State Store, a/k/a Ten Centre Wine and Spirits, to pick up your other alcohol requirements.  This one, two punch makes for convenience.  The big parking lot out front makes it hassle-free. 

Drink responsibly. Party like a maniac.

When another Chinese restaurant was closed one night this week due to broken air conditioning, we turned again to my trusty Yelp app to find another Middle Kingdom kitchen in the vicinity. Henry's China Inn was right down Krewstown Road about a quarter mile, so we decided to give it a go.  

Turns out that Henry no longer owns this house, but at 90 he can be forgiven for retiring and living the good life.  The current owners have been at it for several years, with husband chef working the wok, and wife hostess and service provider doing her social thing in the front of the house, along with a few other employees, who all seem to be content in their positions. 

The menu is pretty much traditional Chinese-American fare, with lots of pork, chicken, shrimp and beef for combination with rice or noodles.  There is also a page of specials that allow the wokmaster to show off his talent.  We ordered three dishes, intending to bring home the remains for stepson who chose not to join us.  Salt & Pepper Shrimp, Orange Beef, and Eggplant in Garlic Sauce were our selections.  All were actually better than expected in terms of both quality and quantity.  

There were about ten large shrimp very lightly breaded with enough salt and pepper to make it a fairly spicy dish.  It was cooked just enough to allow max taste, while leaving the crustacean juicy and fun to chew.  They were laid atop a mix of chopped green pepper and onion that supported the dominant flavor of the shrimp well.  Solid!  The orange beef was a full load, flash fried to a nice crunch, and drowned in a dark brown orange based semi-thick sauce.  We had requested it to be very spicy as the menu suggested was an option, but it arrived sweeter than we wished, and returned it to the kitchen for more chili to be blended in.  Second time was improved, but we still asked for a side dish of hot oil which we poured on top. That was the ticket. It would never be mistaken for Szechuan style, but it least it provided a pleasant burn on top of the Guandong sweetness.  Finally, the eggplant was very good and plentiful, and a nice counterbalance in both taste and texture. 

We had a good conversation with Madame owner, and enjoyed the overall experience of our visit to Henry's.  We realized that it was difficult for a non-Szechuan kitchen to create the numbing flavor we were asking for, so we decided that going forward we would pack a jar of our favorite crispy chili in oil sauce when we went out for Chinese dinners, just in case we wanted to feel the burn, so we could doctor the dish to our specifications.  

Henry's is a utilitarian space, designed for eating in without flourishes of heavy Chinese décor. Still, it was comfortable and clean.  We left very satisfied. 

BYOB.

I've been conducting an informal tour of all the Mexican, Guatemalan, Salvadoran, Puerto Rican and other Central American restaurants that have sprung up in the Trenton-Hamilton area over the past few years, and generally replaced the Italian houses that came before them.  The transformation has been amazing, and after sampling lunch in more than half a dozen shops, I am impressed.  City populations evolve over their lifetime as one ethnic group after another emigrate from somewhere else to a future in a new place. 

So it is here, where the shift from southern Europe to South America has been steady and irreversible.  Of course, all this change is much easier to take whether you are part of the migration, or merely observing it from the comfort of your barstool or table for four, when the culture and cuisine are generally neutral to positive (no worse than what came before to the open mind and unbiased palate). 

While I love Italian food (and even married into the tribe), I find myself thoroughly enjoying what has replaced it.  Las Casas Mexicanas are by and large, excelente.  This is very true of Taqueria El Mariachi on South Olden Avenue in Trenton, just west of Greenwood Avenue.  

It was a rainy afternoon when I approached for lunch and found the adequate parking lot behind the row of buildings that house TEM. I was able to pull up directly behind their place and enter immediately through the back door. Barely a drop reached me, and the sketchiness of the street scene was minimized drastically by this direct access.  Walking by the kitchen, the staff smiled and directed me to the dining room, where they promptly followed me to my chosen table with menu and water glass.  The attractive waitperson spoke little English, but between my broken Spanish and her charming Spanglish, we got through introductions and my order of Flautas de Pollo (literally, Chicken Flutes).  

When my plate arrived, it was covered over with Lettuce, Tomato, Onion, Avocado, Beans and Cheese.  The Flautas were buried beneath, almost invisible.  Cutting through the salad I uncovered four rolled corn tortillas stuffed and overflowing with a Chicken Cheese and Spice mix.  It was very well done. Delicious and fun to eat. Also, quite filling.  I ended up eating the stuffing out of two Flautas and leaving the flutes behind.  I also had a drink called, "Jamaica," which was a sweet fruity juice that I took to be Jicama and/or Pomegranate. All this, plus change for my $10.  

The house has the same casual and divey atmosphere of most of the other Mexi and Guat spots I have tried so far.  The majority of the costumers were eating in their work clothes and were comfortable as if at home. I like this laid back setting.

I will continue my tour, but can easily recommend Taqueria El Mariachi for a good, filling and cheap Mexican meal.  

PS.  This place is definitely Mexican.  It says so on the menu, and I asked my server (en Espanol) the nationality of the cuisine.

Shree Fusion Grill sits on Bridge Street, Morrisville, PA, in the only new building in that part of town.  It has a small dining room with about ten tables, as well as an outdoor seating area in good weather.  It is open for lunch between 11:30 - 3:30, and opens again for dinner at 5:30 until 9:30.  

From reading the few reviews, it seemed that lunch specials were available at reasonable cost, but I learned upon asking that that deal is only for take out service. Disappointed, I inquired about smaller dishes on the menu for lunch.  The server informed me that they also made thalis, the famous Indian samplers that offer 8 to 10 different dishes in small stainless steel bowls, served on a tray with basmati rice, naan and papadam. At $10.99 it sounded interesting, so I went with the chicken thali.  

It arrived about 15 minutes later, with a samosa, lentil soup, chicken tikka masala, eggplant (baingan bharta), potato and pea (aloo matar), chickpea and potato masala, plain yogurt, and honey rosewater gulab jamun, basmati rice, etc. It all looked good, and the heat level was enough to bring sweat and runny nose. Liked all of it, although it was a bit more than I could finish in one seating. The pitcher of lemon water came in handy. 

Shree Fusion Grill is not haute Indian cuisine, but it is a solid kitchen in a casual setting. The menu tips its hat to "Manchurian" style Indo-Chinese plates, and also has French onion soup, wraps and burgers. Clearly trying to appeal to the broadest cross section of the community possible. It isn't Indian Garden, nor Guru, but they know their way around Indian spices and provides a very good meal for those looking for an alternative to the regular daily choices in the neighborhood. 

PRO TIP - Plenty of parking in back, if you drive around the corner and follow the signs to Renaissance Center.

The Market at Styer Orchard is several things. First, it is a pretty good deli, making breakfast and lunch for people lucky enough to realize they have a kitchen and small dining area in the house. Second, it is a bakery producing excellent fruit pies, apple cider and other donuts, and a variety of other pastries and cookies.  Third, it is a gift shop with shiny Christmas objects, and all year round seasonal do-dads. A little too gitchy for me. But, if you come for the top two possibilities, the likelihood is you will leave happy.  

I finally stopped in for breakfast earlier this week. At first, I could not find anyone who worked in the deli/kitchen part of the building.  I saw the deli case full of smoked meats and fresh salads, but no one to give my order to.  I saw women in the bakery taking pies in/out of their ovens, but they looked busy.  So, I briefly came around the deli counter and stepped into the back kitchen. Someone was back there, and when I called to her, she promptly came to me to apologize, and take my french toast order. Three slices of wheat bread and coffee, please. 

I went to pour my java while waiting for the grillwork. There was limited selection, and it was clear that caffeine was not the priority around there. When I finally got a fresh cup and added milk it was really rather ordinary.  For $1.40 for the larger size, I really won't complain, other than to say a better bean would lead to happier customers. The Market was def not a café (But, it sure could be!). 

My grilled egged bread was very good, however. Large slices of wheat loaf, dipped in a superior mix of egg, sugar and vanilla extract, that when kissing hot iron really caramelized the surface of the bread.  It had that light sweet crispness that I love in french toast. They fell short by only offering Smucker's syrup, rather than pure maple, but that would be expecting too much. 

Given what's happening elsewhere in the vicinity with coffee and pleasant coffee houses, the potential at the Market @ Styer Orchard is tremendous.  They already have a superior bakery and deli, so they are way ahead of the game. Just bring in a coffee maven barista with the right equipment, redesign the floorplan a bit to make it more attractive and comfortable, and this joint would be jumping! I'm not talking slick, because you still want the current regulars to come in for their apple cider donuts and chicken salad sandwiches; but toned up enough to get the after workout and business breakfast crowd interested enough to make it a primary pit stop. Check out Be Well Bakery & Cafe in Huntington Valley to see what is possible.

This place is an undiscovered vein of gold waiting to be found by someone with a little imagination, capital, a touch of design skill and love of coffee.

Wish that person was me.

I've returned to Mil-Lee's a couple of times over the past year.  Have to say that the breakfasts have been consistently very good with overflowing plate and excellent friendly service. 

The coffee has a nice bite.  The Sausage, Onion, Pepper Omelet I had today was tasty and filling. The accompanying Home Fries were too much to finish.  

It is time to add the Luv-Inn to my short list of breakfast favorites on my way to court in Trenton.  

I should have bounced to 4 Stars before this.

Unfortunately, Washington Crossing Coffee has departed the scene here at Capital Health. The area where it once resided is now just a seating area on the second floor of the medical center, with several high tops still in place where customers once sat. I was surprised how few people I saw inside the large building, especially considering how crowded the parking lots are all around the institution. Understandable how a small business couldn't survive in the absence of many people as potential customers and a cheap cafeteria on the lower level. 

But, fear not. 

Starbucks now has a micro stand inside Lori's Gift Shop on the first floor near the front door. It may not be as good as WCC, but give the youngster credit, it may ultimately succeed where the local mom and pop operation could not. 

Time will tell.

I don't often feel the need for a pedicure, but I admit that when my feet are beat and toe nails ragged, some TLC to the tootsies can be a true pleasure. So, after a particularly horrific week of office moving and presidential election poll working, I wandered through Morrisville one evening this week and found M & M Nail Bar Spa in the shopping plaza just off Trenton Road.  

Even though it was 15 minutes to closing, and the front door was locked, the woman running the shop was happy to let me in and give me the full foot deal for $23.  Very much appreciated.  Hot soak, salts, scrub, clip, dig, sand, and massage, accompanied by my choice of alcoholic beverage, juice, tea or coffee.  Very cool way to mellow out.  

Thirty minutes later my wheels felt like Fred Astaire's feet - Happy, light and content.  The glass of red wine may have had something to do with that. 

Next time, how about a few apps?

The original Jake's is here on Bustleton Pike in Richboro, PA. in a small strip center. The dining room/lunch counter is smaller than their house in Newtown, but with the addition of the extended barroom next door, the place feels more interesting. Also MaiTai brunches are always a strong addition. 

I sat on a spinner and enjoyed the repartee with the ladies in black working the room. Time to chat and work on this rainy Columbus Day. They took turns serving menu, coffee and breakfast. Good teamwork. The java was from a Bunn-O-Matic; hot and strong. 

The short stack french toast was good, with plenty of egg, vanilla and touch of sugar in the mix saturating to the center of each slice. Caramelized edges always please me, and I was not disappointed. Real maple syrup would have made this an almost perfect plate, but it is hard to offer that liquid amber elixir at these prices. 

I sat in for a second mug of Joe to postpone walking out into the storm. I didn't mind extending my visit a little longer this wet day.

Royal Tavern on Passyunk Avenue, Bella Vista, Philadelphia, is a small dark gastropub made to look and feel turn of the 20th Century. It is shoehorned into a rowhouse footprint, with beautiful dark wood backbar, small dining area against the opposite wall and a step up space in back on the way to the restrooms. Kitchen in the basement. 

"Dark," is the operative adjective here, because the lighting is so dim aside from a string of Christmas lights that even reading the menu, let alone eyeballing the meal, was a challenge. That's not necessarily a bad thing when the cocktails, beer and food are all first rate, and visuals only serve to support the party going on in your mouth. So it was @ Royal.

We started with a draft of Free Flow IPA, which had a refreshing grapefruit subtext, and a Fat Tire under glass. As Royal rookies, I went for their famous Angus burger (Gouda and whole Longhot Pepper being the most notable elements), and the special spicy shrimp tacos. Both were excellent, with the burger a perfect medium finish and hot to trot on the tongue, and the three tacos barely rollable with shrimp, lettuce, salsa and avocado loaded within. Damn good fries, too. 

Of particular convenience to Washington Avenue and the Asian markets there that we came to stock up for upcoming Spring Festival. We just put all that stuff in the trunk and walked over to Royal. Made parking a non-issue. 

Gotta do this more often!

The name says it all. 
Uncle Mike's Homemade Ice Cream. 
Tucked away in a small strip center on York Road, just off Street in Warminster, PA, with small blue sign above the store, it is a little hard to find as you drive by. But, I caught sight of a roadside flag as I approached, and was able to pull into the parking lot without problem. 

The shop is bright white, with limited indoor and outdoor seating. Mike carries about 12 - 15 flavors at any given time. Only hard ice cream. No soft serve.  There are a combination of young and older kids working there who are friendly and efficient. 

I ordered the two scoop medium size cup of butter pecan and peanut butter cookies & cream. They were large scoops and plenty for this lonesome traveler. It became obvious that Unca Mike really did mix his own flavors. Originally, the peanut butter cookies and cream had been two distinct flavors, but he must have been running low on the ingredients for both, and just threw them together to use them up. Necessity being the mother of invention, the result was the best of both worlds. Excellent peanut butter swirl and cookies and cream playing off each other like old friends who don't visit too often. So, in fact, I received 3 flavors within the two scoops. 

No complaints. 

They all were richly creamy and bursting with taste. Very good ice cream all around. At $4.50, it was a excellent deal. 

This Uncle Mike knows from ice cream.
The Moo Truck is temporarily closed. Be sure to call before coming.

Divine Pizza has become a semi-regular lunch stop over the past year and a half.  Their pizza remains solid, but I have been impressed with the quality of their hot sandwiches.  

From Eggplant Parm, to Italian Sweet Sausage, to Peppers and Onions, to Italian Hot Dogs, their plates are substantial, hearty and very tasty.  Their torpedo rolls are first rate, and are locally baked to produce crunchy skin and soft insides.  

Definitely have become a strong fan.

There is a small table in the front of Belly Busters, but take out and delivery is really the only way to go for breakfast and lunch at this tiny roadside shack of a South American kitchen on old Rt. 13 (Bristol Pike) in Eddington, PA. We didn't know that until after we ordered, having cozied into the few chairs around that mesa and sipped their excellent coffee. I guess they took pity on us and allowed us to stay and eat our breakfasts. Or, maybe it was me taking pictures, asking questions and letting it slip that I would write a Yelp review about the experience, that changed their minds. Thank you.

We went with a breakfast special of doubled sausage, egg and cheese sammy and morning burrito. El senor worked the grill, while la senora was barista, cashier and hostess. Couldn't tell if the young guy making deliveries was family or not. Our grub was great and a good value. The biggest surprise was the new wing of the shop dedicated to java. It was a full blown Expresso operation born from the dozen years working at Starbucks before opening their own business, complete with bottled syrups for flavored lattes and capps. 

We were fortunate to be able to hang out over breakfast and watch/listen to customers and staff interact. It was apparent that the family was proud of their success and showed appreciation to everyone who came in. Admittedly, Belly Busters is a bit of a dive, but only in the best way. The corners may be dusty, but the love and effort are tangible.

Newest design for DD. Not surprised as it had to do something extraordinary to get into Upper Makefield. This shop has an inside lobby with doors on 2 sides to allow for circulation of customers. Too, it has a pleasant sitting area to one side complete with a lounge by the large front window. 

The coffee is standard for a DD. Service is friendly and efficient. 

Nice to have a morning hangout in the Crossing.

Very decent Vietnamese house in Mt. Laurel, NJ.

Man! This part of the world is all shopping centers and highways.  What happened to rural Moorestown and Mt. Laurel?  Well, at least they had the good sense to permit Pho Xinh to open their southeast Asian restaurant. It's not just Viet cuisine, as it also has offerings from Thailand.  

My lunch was the Jasmin Grill, consisting of 2 very thin pork chops, grilled and barbequed, cuke and tomato side salad/garnish, and a cup of broken rice.  For another buck I also received a small fried spring roll.  Very good service, with everyone pitching in.  

Taste was fine, especially after I mixed the Hoisin and Chili Sauces together for dipping the meat, and poured the thin spring roll sauce over the rice to add more flavor.  

If I find myself in the area again, I will sit down for a bowl of Pho. 

Not quite Washington Avenue, Philly, but strong for this neck of the woods.

Nonno's Italian Coffee Parlor is what a true café should be.

  It is attractive to visit with its old wooden fixtures and furniture; it is truly artisanal in how it produces its signature drinks, both hot and cold; and offers creamy, colorful Gelato and bakery sweets to complete a wonderful experience.  It is no wonder that the place is packed from morning to night.  People know a great thing when they sit and taste it. 

It really is that good!

But, there is a downside to success.  If you just want to stop in/take out a latte or capp, or even a small lemon gelato slurp, you may end up waiting as long as those people choosing to sip/dine in.  The service is often slow, making a quick business stop on the way to the office or a meeting, problematic.  They really need to figure out how to handle the crowds that love their stuff. The snaking line doesn't work when feeling rushed.  The other issue is the no credit card policy.  What's up with that?! Normally, that suggests a few financial problems that obstruct the acceptance practices of the offering banks.  The success of this venture suggests otherwise.  Cash flow does not appear to be the problem.

Offering an ATM in the back hall by the bathrooms is not really the image a Eurostyle café should be demonstrating.  This situation detracts from the customer service expected in quality establishments, and should be rectified.  

But, man, the drinks are good. Makes the annoying sloth-like pace and cash only deal tolerable as long as I am not in a hurry. 

To make 5 Star rank these things need to be fixed.

I have returned three times since the review, and sampled their food each time. 

Their burgers are very good.  Large patty cooked to the requested finish with loads of toppings and a steak knife piercing the sandwich like a dagger through the heart. Also ordered the cheesesteak sliders, which were basically cheesesteak encapsulated within a thin dough deep fried before presentation.  Also, good, but not the grabber that the burger was. 

Beer selection is excellent for a neighborhood bar & grill, and the service remains friendly and courteous. 

Work being done in the back to bring up the comfort of the dining area.  Too, the men's room is nice enough to be in someone's home.  Well done!

Right down 17th Street from The Latham Hotel, I strolled down to Little Pete's one morning last week for an early breakfast while waiting for the rest of the family to get up and ready for the day.  

A diner or luncheonette may be debated, but the atmosphere is mid-20th Century, and the tone is one of a dive.  That can be a very good thing if you like time travel with your eggs and coffee. I sat at the oblong counter and was promptly given a glass of water and a menu.  The coffee was poured a moment later.  My toasted Corn Muffin slid in front of me before turning the front page of the Inquirer.  Service in black with a sly smile seemed appropriate and I enjoyed the wonderment of my server's daily grind.  

Before leaving, I looked around the counter at all the individuals sitting in their own worlds on their Ipads and smartphones.  I missed the banter than used to take place between waitperson and customer, and felt the loss of human interaction.  I put down my own technology and journal and exchanged a few pleasantries with the woman who had been refilling cups of Joe for decades.  She just needed a few interested ears to tell her tale.  

So, next time you find yourself at Little Pete's try to be fully present and interact with this artifact of American history before it becomes extinct.

Cafe Lift on North 13th Street just south of Spring Garden, occupies the first floor of an old factory in this almost up and coming neighborhood south of core Center City. It's decor is all early 20th Century post industrial.  This has it's charm with high ceilings and exposed pipes and ducts, and large photos of the local buildings in black and white that are strong suggestions of it's history. 

On Saturday morning it was packed with a 20 something crowd enjoying Rival Bros Coffee and a short, but tasty breakfast/lunch menu. Hard walls make for poor acoustics, and the din was several decibels above comfortable. But, everyone was friendly and dealing with the racket. Even the queue to the single restroom had cool people who understood the situation and willingly chatted with their line mates.

Our table wait was about 25 minutes, but we made it to a small deuce in the middle of the room, with people on either side. It was tight, but the ambient noise allowed for privacy. The menu was divided into brekkie and lunch on either side of the document. I went with the chicken salad wrap, and DT opted for their burger. Both we're good. The burger seemed hand packed which gave it a softer texture and more retained juices. I prefer a more chunky chicken salad, but had no negs about theirs. We were drinking the house java, which was hot and kicky, but served in small white cups that needed refilling after a couple of gulps. Larger joe vessels would have been more efficient for the staff and felt more generous to the customers. 

Cafe Lift is a very interesting place to hang out. The room is really humming and the staff works hard to please. The harshness of the sound makes the experience not completely ideal, but that is overcome by the quality of the people and the kitchen, not to mention the enjoyment of just being in an old urban factory that has been so well repurposed.

Bobby O's Deli on Rozel Avenue just off 2nd Street Pike in Southampton, PA, is hard to find until you realize it is on this side street in a small strip center, without signage other than above the door. But, if you appreciate family owned and operated businesses that do things as they have for the past thirty years, it is well worth slowing down to find it. 

We stopped in after taking the PennDot driving test nearby, in need of breakfast and coffee. Their all day breakfast sandwich sign in the window was most welcoming. No tables in the tiny shop, but a short wall shelf with four stools was all we needed. We each ordered a sandwich with variations of bacon, sausage and pork roll, egg and cheese on hard rolls. At $4.50 per, the price was right. 

Daughter took our order at the cashier post, while Mom worked the grill and dad brought in new inventory. All their Sammies were very good, with special mention to the rolls which were fresh and excellent. Choice of cheese helped, too. Liked them alot. 

If there was any shortfall, it was that the sausages seemed to be those precooked frozen jobs just reheated, rather than a fresh patty brought to life on hot steel. It would have been even better with the higher quality ingredient. Still, that is a minor nit in an otherwise high value morning meal. 

May they have another 30 years!

The United States Postal Service as embodied by the Post Office at 20 Terry Drive in Newtown has provided me and my business with a post office box address, mail and shipping services for several years.  I like having a face behind these services as it reassures that someone is taking personal and professional responsibility for making sure everything I send out gets to its destination, and that I receive everything that is sent to me.

Yes, FedEx and the others can do a lot of the same things, but there is something very American about having these guys and facilities in the community.  

Let's hope they figure out a way to stay open and active as part of the American landscape.

The aptly named, "Moo," is a small burger shop on the south end of Main Street, New Hope, PA. What makes it unique is the use of locally sourced ingredients where possible in the construction of their sandwiches.  The beef, milk, ice cream (soft serve) are from the surrounding area, and they list their providers on a board next to the pick up window.  It is also staffed by locally sourced young folk, making for a very at home sensibility. There are three or four tables inside, with more counter space and stools along one wall.  More seating out front on the elevated patio overlooking the street. 

We stopped in Sunday evening for a bite to satisfy our moderate hunger. Not looking for a big meal.  We ordered two Moo Burgers, one order of fries and a salted caramel shake.  That list cost us $22., which seemed a little on the high side, but perhaps not for New Hope. The dining room was more than half empty, so we took a table toward the rear, and waited to hear my name called.  

The food was served on an aluminum tray.  The burgers were wrapped in paper with access on one end, and the fries were in a small cardboard barge. The shake was 7 ounces with a wide straw for better suction. The puck was medium to medium well, with lettuce, tomato, cheese and a "special" sauce.  Martin's Potato Rolls held the opus together.  They were very good, with a never frozen texture and fresh grilled flavor.  The rolls were strong enough to remain intact to the last bite. Always appreciated. The fries were also right out of the earth, with a short stop for washing and slicing. They were excellently crisp, with plenty of nubs for extra crunch. Finally, the shake was creamy, cool and sweet. Delicious, but perhaps an indulgence at $6 for a smallish plastic cup.  

Overall, we liked Moo a lot, and would not hesitate to visit again when in a burger mood. Far superior to the casual fast food burgers proliferating around the nation.

Very nice to have a bakery café open in Chinatown late on a Saturday night. 

The Vietnamese Coffee was very good.  The Dulces were varietal and fresh. And the service unhurried in a "have a long conversation" way.  

Pleased to find a place to hang out for a while without high decibels, nor strutting nighthawks.  

Table in the back. Stay as long as you like.

The last stop of my Farmers' Best, Kobawoo and H Mart Asian shopping day, H Mart falls somewhere in between the larger, well inventoried, but dirty FBM, and the smaller, well thought out aisles and cleanliness of KM. 

 This successful chain has expanded since 1982, and continues to offer well stocked fresh produce and a wide variety of Asian packaged frozen foods and groceries.  If I were to choose only one stop shopping, H Mart would be the best compromise.  Their prices are reasonable and you can find most of what you want for your exotic food requirements.  I have visited their locations in Levittown and Edison, and again, this one stands in between those two in terms of size, customer service and aisle access/comfort.  

The most unique aspect of this shop is the space it shares with a decent food court for a sit down or take out dining experience, and the Paris Baguette bakery in the basement which provides a pleasant café experience pre or après purchasing your consumables.  

Have you ever wondered how "H Mart" got its name?  I did, and went on its website to see if I could find out.  The "H" is the first letter of the phrase, "Han Ah Reum," meaning, "Arm full of groceries."  I leave it to the Korean readers to know if that is accurate. 

But, the image works for me.

Market at the Fareway is the successor to the Chestnut Hill Farmers Market on Germantown Avenue, Philadelphia. It is owned/operated by the folks who brought you the Chestnut Hill Hotel, next door. It incorporates historic charm with contemporary cuisine alternatives, including the Chestnut Hill Brewing Company, for a fun and flavorful cultural experience in the heart of one of the most attractive neighborhoods in greater Philadephia (I hesitate to use the word, "quaint"). 
It still possesses the charm of the old farmers market, with butcher, baker and green grocer in house. But, in addition you can enjoy the pleasures of street food like Korean fried chicken, local microbrew beer, sweets straight out of the oven, pizza, and sushi, and more. There is a common dining area for those who prefer to eat while the food is at its apex taste. 
Although there is a free parking lot behind the structure, it is often full, requiring a search of the streets surrounding the market. No doubt, the residential neighbors nearby find that annoying, to say the least. In fact, there is litigation going on between the owners of the market and the closest neighbors about the expansion of the operations to include an outdoor beer garden. An agreement between the previous owners and the concerned citizens was thought to deny this growth. The outcome remains to be seen at this time. 
Certainly hope all sides can find a workable solution for this issue, as angry neighbors are never good for business, and overreaching businesses are seldom good for long term peace and prosperity in the neighborhood. 
It would be a shame to lose the benefit of the new Market at the Fareway, for the sake of an effort to squeeze additional profits from an already successful venture. Why not allow for a certain number of outdoor days for the beer garden every year, and keep it closed the rest of the time? There is enough room inside for those who want to drink on site. And you can always buy some to take home. A special permit would be required from the ABC or State Police to allow for special events, but that seems manageable compared to fighting about this, and leaving it to a judge. 
Should I return, I promise to eat and drink inside until this is resolved.

Hometown Deli in the Anchor Crossing Center doesn't look like much walking in. Small eating area to the left, a few rows of snacks and drinks coolers in the middle, and deli department to the left rear. It all seems a little worn. But, ordering a sandwich and taking possession of it quicky changed those first impressions. 

My chicken salad on rye toast was delivered to my table by the deli chef. It was bigger than expected, and first bite opened my eyes in pleasant surprise. The chicken salad was chunky, creamy and had very fresh taste. Combined with a thick red tomato slice and dark green lettuce, inside real rye toast, it was very good and enjoyable. It was almost too much to finish. 

Apparently, they do breakfast sandwiches just as good. 

See you again soon, Hometown Deli.

Visited my first Playa Bowls the other day. This new tropical tan Jersey Shore original shop recently opened in the Village @ Newtown Shopping Center, and the "Grand Opening" banner was still strung up over the front door. No question that if you like fresh fruit, smoothies, yogurt and granola, you have come to your little spot of heaven. 

The large wall board menu is a bit daunting to read, but once I adjusted to the sound bombardment from the loudspeakers kicking out rock music several decibels above my comfort level, I settled on a Gogi Bowl consisting of sliced pineapple, banana, gogi berry, granola on a chill base of bright purple dragonfruit sorbet. I took a stool at a high plank table to await my name being called. The place was packed at 3:00 p.m., and it took about 10 minutes to hear my name shouted out above the crashing din. 

I retrieved the midsized plastic bowl and spoon and returned to my seat. It looked great. The taste was of very fresh fruit, crunchy granola and cold, almost crystalized dragonfruit creamie. It was refreshing and fun. 

All the while I took in the scene around me. Everyone was high school age. 90% female, and there was no doubt that I was the only one over 30. It was good that so many people my teenage son's age were hanging out healthy. 

I just wish I didn't have to overcome the sound barrier, and I hope they recycle.

You would be forgiven if you approached the corner where Sabor Latino Bar & Restaurant is located, and decided not to park, nor go inside.  It is a particularly dreary intersection in the depths of Trenton, with a few boarded up houses, and war torn streets.  Yet, it you summoned the courage to open the door and walk in, you would thank yourself for bravery being well rewarded.  

Sabor Latino (Latin Flavor) is a Dominican house with a kitchen familiar with the cuisine of Puerto Rico, Guatemala and Costa Rica.  The bar room also serves as the dining area, and the staff is friendly and attractively bilingual.  The broad menu offers lunch and dinner with prices below $10 and $16, respectively.  A few HDTVs on the walls broadcasting futbol en espanol, and gentlemen at the bar and high tops conducting business.  

My server recommended the Pernil special, and I accepted her suggestion.  A few minutes later I was presented with a large plate of Roasted Pork, White Rice, Salad and a cup of Red Beans.  There was also a table rocket filled with a mix of spice and mayo for use on the greens.  The Pork was soft, juice and tender with a nice taste of mild BBQ sauce.  The skin took the fire well and it was crunchy to chew with a stronger flavor from the basting and flames.  The Rice and Beans were solid accompaniments.  The Salad was just some Iceberg and Tomato; not bad, but more of a garnish than a side dish.  

I was checked on several times by my waitperson.  She clearly was concerned that I be satisfied with my meal and overall experience, and was pleasant in her relief that I enjoyed my lunch.
