Sabor Latino is yet another of the strong effort coming from the Central American community in Trenton.  It may not yet have the well earned reputation that was Chambersburg for Italian joints in the last century, but this and the other casas are definitely on their way toward that recognition.

I wasn't sure what to expect when I found Tuscany Ristorante on Yelp. It was located on Rhawn Street in far Northeast Philadelphia, just off the Boulevard, an area not known for haute cuisine. But, we were not that far away and in the mood for an Italian dinner. My uncertainty mounted as I found the last parking spot right in front of the corner liquor store, and rolled up over the curb and sidewalk to park. The dudes out front gave me a glance, like, "What the F *** do you think your doing...?" I pulled my Eagles hat lower over my brow as I got out of the car and gave them a wink. Sometimes being 6'4" is enough for street corner respect or at least a pass. Or, maybe it was just the hat. They had less risky things to do on a Sunday night. 

Anyway, we found our way inside the restaurant and were immediately taken by the white linen, heavy flatware, and polished marble floors. Okay. This wasn't a local pizza joint. These folks were serious about creating an atmosphere of opulence in the middle of this urban jungle. For the most part, they succeeded. 

What was even more pronounced was the fine quality of the food coming from the kitchen. We ordered calamari, roast chicken and rice soup, chicken marsala, chicken francais, a side Caesar salad and house veggies - roasted potatoes and broccoli. One thing was better than the next. 

The squid was nicely deep fried with excellent dipper. They were all rings, without tentacles, which gave the impression they were received that way from the purveyor rather than being sliced in house. Liked them, but would have been better if handled completely by the chef. The soup was excellent - creamy, flavorful with lots of chicken and rice. The Caesar and veggies came with dinner. Both were more than adequate, but small in size and just a solid complement to the stars of the show. 

Tuscany knows from sauces. They did a masterful job on the marsala and francais reductions. The marsala had plenty of chunky fresh mushrooms in a dark marsala wine base. Very nice. The francais was heavy into lemon and white wine with light egg batter coating, in which the thin chicken fillets had been pan sautéed in extra virgin, amply caramelized and set afloat. One of the best things I have put in my mouth this year. Wowee! 

Service was very good. Friendly and casual. Plenty of time between courses, and many stops to inquire of our satisfaction. Dessert looked tempting, but enough was enough. Most surprising was the pricing; reminiscent of the turn of the century. 

Aside from the poor acoustics caused by all the hard surfaces, Tuscany Ristorante was a total win. We will definitely be back.

The Bristol Amish Market sits just off Route 13 at Green Lane, in Bristol, PA.  It is one of several such markets around Bucks County, and one of the newest and cleanest.  

If you enjoy visiting Lancaster, PA, and the world of the Amish and Mennonites in Central Pennsylvania, you can have a small dose of that here, but without the traffic problems caused by the interaction of horse & buggy and combustion engines.  The people working here come by their dress honestly, from women's bonnets, to men's black hats and beards.  Everyone is friendly and somewhat shy.  Delightful!

The small shops within run the gamut from butcher to baker, and green grocer to donut maker.  Everything looks fresh and appealing.  Prices are not on the low end, however.  Compared to their sister market in Newtown, the Bristol Market is larger, cleaner, brighter, and easier to use.  If you go Thursday morning when they are just opening for the weekend, the space is lightly travelled, and it is easy to get in and out without lines.  

As with most other Yelp reviewers, the highlight here is Mary's Gourmet Donut Shoppe, at the back of the warehouse.  She bakes up excellent fried dough; dipped in an assortment of ultra sweet and smooth topping and icing.  My poor blood sugar!  It sells both cake and light donuts, that spoil you away from Dunkin and the boys. Even the coffee is very good.  Unlike the other purveyors here, Mary's is not really Amish, and employs locals to run the shop.  They are willing to engage in conversation about their wares in much more detail than the Amish butcher baker ladies who only converse with customers beyond the business basics if faced with a determined interlocutor. 

Just bought a dozen to bring to the office.  So hard not to rip open the box and dive in.  But, I was good, and allowed the staff to slice the tape sealing the box and savor the sticky moment.  Man, those Peanut Butter & Jellies were tempting!

 They were gone before I could pour my coffee.

Chicco's Pizza on the corner of Brownsville Road and Philadelphia Avenue in Trevose, PA., is an attractive Italian house focused primarily on providing a solid lunch and dinner to the surrounding neighborhoods in the part of Bucks County.  It has a clean and bright dining room separated from the walkup/takeout part of the store. Their luncheon menu includes a plenty of torpedo based sandwiches made from quality ingredients that come to about $10 with tip. They also do pizza, but I did not try any this day. 

My "South Philly Special," consisted of breaded/fried chicken breast, broccoli rabe and a ton of melted mozza on top of an oven toasted roll. There was also a heavy load of sautéed garlic in the mix, giving its dominating flavor to the greens. It was a large unfinishable sandwich, but tasty and made to order for me. In fact, the chef came out to tell me that it would take longer than usual to secure my meal because she was cooking up a fresh batch of rabe for me. It tasted it! 

While this part of Bucks is not a regular haunt for me, I was in the area on business. So, if things go right, I could find myself back here to sample more of their menu, especially the tomato pies.

Tower Hill Brewery is a nano beer maker located in the Chalfont Village Shopping Center. Their equipment is easy to miss even though it is in the front of the shop by the door. Production is clearly limited to their own in house use unless they have other facilities elsewhere. 

My pint of Himmel Hefeweizen was good, with smooth finish and mild banana flavor. I sat at the bar under two HDTVs, watching the Penn State - Iowa football game sipping, while the kitchen prepared the Loaded Pierogies I ordered. 

Dinner arrived in a long handled white oven ready ceramic pan with four homemade potato and cheese perogies, topped with bacon bits and chopped scallion. A small cup of sour cream completed the presentation. The first bite was extremely hot and I needed my beer to extinguish the fire. Thereafter, with more caution, I worked my way through what was really more appetizer than an entree. The dough pockets were excellent. Creamy mashed and cheese with lightly onion flavor that went well with the bacon/scallion topping. These guys make great "rogies." 

At $14 for four of these babies, I was paying a premium price for their quality. As good as they were, the value proposition was not right, and I left with the impression that they really were not worth having more than once. Still, Tower Hill Brewery does good suds and grub and is certainly a place to visit with thirst and appetite.

In the middle of a cold Saturday afternoon in Glenside Village just a few blocks from the famous Keswick Theater, Daryl's Pastries sits in a small aging storefront in the center of this attractive historic district. The shop was crammed with chest high display cases full of colorful cakes, cookies, pastries and my reason for being there - donuts. Perhaps six people could fit in front, and a half dozen more in the tiny cafe sitting area to the right side. 

Service was friendly, if necessarily rushed due to lack of room. By my arrival, some choices were depleted, but I was able to score a box of traditional doughboys (glazed, chocolate glazed and apple crisp) and a cup of coffee for the drive back to Bucks to share with the family. Sadly, the old fashioned brownies I craved were not available.

I found all the samples to be enjoyably sweet and well textured. The skin was slightly crisp and the heart soft and tender as they should be. They went down smoothly with their coffee chaser. The family happily agreed. 

Given the current popularity of customized donut shops offering multiple varieties made 'just in time' for the consumer, these badboys were somehow dated, but a pleasant reminder of how good rounders can be. Not every bakery needs to be Factory Donuts or other assembly line ultra expensive variant in order to create superlative timeless addictive floury confections.

Daryl knows from donuts.

Decent beer distributor in Richboro, PA. 

Plenty of choice. Domestic, European, Mexican and some hard cider. I needed a case for an upcoming Spring Festival (Chinese New Year) dinner. In the absence of Tsingdao or other Asian brew, I opted for Modelo Especial, a very good Mexican lager with strong, yet balanced flavor. 

The 24 count case cost $33 and change including tax. No bad, but not as reasonable as at my favorite alcohol warehouse in Jersey. Still, considering time and transportation, it was well worth it. 

Happy New Year, Everybody!

Hulmeville Inn was a dive bar before the term gained currency in the 21st Century.  

It sits at the crossroads of time, at the intersection of a stage depot between Trenton and Philadelphia in the 19th Century, and a cool and courageous crafty beer pour in the present day.  

Sometimes it feels like they are shooting an episode of Duck Dynasty at the pool tables with all the beards on display.  Still, even a clean shaven face is welcome in this throwback bar.  

The suds are amazing in their diversity from local to international, although the kitchen always seems a step behind in offerings and quality.  It is a fun place to go just to hang out and watch sports, or chalk up the old cue.  The prices can't be beat, and this is one of those places where they can sniff out pretension, so best to just be at your ease.  

I don't get down to Hulmeville often, but when I do the Inn by that name is a worthy place to visit. 

Walk in. Belly up. Buy a round. Shoot the sh*t.  Rack 'em up.  Break 'em. Set up shots for nightcaps. Head on home.

UPDATE. FEBRUARY 3, 2017 

Came in tonight for dinner and beer. Here, we normally order food and drink at the bar, and bring the glass back to the hightops in the barroom to await the cook delivery of the plates. Their brew list comes on sheets of paper and a wall screen. There were at least 40 choices from around the world and as close as Bucks. 

For drink we ordered Devils Double, a dark IPA, and Merry Monks. I guess we were feeling a little naughty and monastic at the same time. Both were strong mood setters. For nosh, we opted for a medium Firehouse Burger and their Boardwalk Cheesesteak.  We waited for our grub as the bar filled with Friday nighters. Nice, friendly crowd. Dates, friends, co-workers, fams. Bar Lady knew everyone's name and where they sat. 

My burger was a half pound delight on a ciabatta roll, loaded with red onion, romaine and a perfect medium finish. Needed utensils to consume because my mouth just wasn't big enough (I know. Hard to believe.). The Boardwalk steakwich was HUGE, with finely chopped onions, peppers and roasted reds and a layer or American. The roll was great for holding the massive beefy pile and it's drippings, so if you desired less grease you only ate the top of the loaf. But, if you craved full force cardiac compromising taste, you chomped all of it. Freedom of Choice! 

Hulmeville Inn has been tapping kegs for patriots for 200 years. You can feel it all around you, like a friendly ghost's embrace. 

Hoist a few together.

White Dotte Dairy Bar & Grill is an old school roadside attraction at the intersection of Rts. 38 & 206 in Vincentown, NJ. It produces good soft serve ice cream and an assortment of burgers, cheesesteaks and other  fast food that take your mind off the drive through pancake flat Burlington County. 

I stopped by for breakfast earlier this week to find out what they were doing to be in business for 70 years. It is a small custom made railroad car like wooden structure with small counter and a few tables. Clearly their success relies on take out. Yet, I enjoyed my time on one of their stools at the green paisley lunch counter. The menu is All Americana standards. I asked about the french toast, and when the friendly server said she really liked it, I went with it.  I sipped their generic coffee while waiting for it to come off the grill in back. 

The walls had pictures of the farmstead and family since inception. Curious about what "Dotte" meant, I asked whether it stood for someone named, "Dotty," or something else. I was surprised to learn that it had nothing to do with a person, but that "White Dotte" was the name of the chicken breed raised there. I googled that and found that the actual breed was Wynedotte,  an American egg layer developed in the 1880's to produce brown eggs. Beautiful bird, too. Very cool.

And, the french toast was very good. The mix had excellent proportions of vanilla, sugar and cinnamon, that completely saturated the three slices of their bread, and caramelized the edges. Surprisingly tasty. 

White Dotte turned out to be much more than expected. Historic enterprise from one family. Cozy building. Esoteric name that added to the positive impression. Decent grub that made this a stop well worth repeating. 

A chance to learn something unexpected and captivating.

Utsav ("Festival" in Sanscrit) is the latest Indian house at this location on Philmont Avenue near the border between Huntington Valley and Northeast Philadelphia. It serves Kerala style cuisine, and does a particularly good job with vegetarian dishes. The room is bright yellow, matching that shade of curry. We dined alone this Sunday evening, which hopefully is not a sign of their opportunity for success, because we were quite impressed with the quality of the food overall. 

We ordered the Calamari Cochin appetizer, Chicken Amwalla, Vegetable Salan and Chili Garlin Naan. Pappadam was offered as a table nosh. Enjoyment scaled from decent for the squid, to excellent for the Veggie Salan, with the Amwalla falling in between. An explanation is required.

The calamari was the weakest link, and not the best way to start our exploration. It was dusted with a grainy flour similar to corn meal, which didn't really work texturally nor flavorably with the crustacean's own qualities. The onion, green pepper and garlic were sauteed in a heavy oil, which actually became the dominate taste. Just not pleasant when the squid should have been allowed to shine. Yet, the chunky, tender Amwalla was very pleasant with its mango mild curry mix. It was an indication of the playful possibilities in the kitchen. Likewise, the veggie salan was a surprising dish based in freshly cracked and poured coconut milk and yogurt sauce. The highlight of our dinner. The chili garlic naan was well baked and very tasty in its own right and as a handy scoop to capture the great sauces. 

Service was friendly and informative. Prices reasonable and in a range that encouraged some experimentation. 

Utsav takes it place among the very good Indian restaurants in the area. Be festive!

This was my first taste from an El Limon restaurant, and I have to say it was very good from atmosphere through loud post almuerzo belching. 

We were the only patrons in the shop when we arrived on Friday afternoon around 2.  There were three women in the store, two sitting at a table in front who quickly stood and took us to a table and distributed menus. The third was in the open kitchen toward the back with a very large ladle stirring something is a mega-gallon pot on the stove. 

The room is decorated a la Mexicana, with bright paint everywhere. Otherwise, the tables/chairs were utilitarian.  The two page menu offered lunch and dinner, with a little space for desert. I appreciated that there were sopas and tortas along with the standard burritos and tacos. 

The refrigeration unit was full of Mexican sodas and homemade huaracha.  We stuck with water and lime, and ordered torta al pastor and tacos pescados. Somewhat surprising that there were no chips and salsa offered gratis for the table, but required a $4 charge. Never saw that in the many other shops I have dined in around the USA, nor even in the homeland. I guess that works for them.

Anyway, the meals were quite good. The tacos were full of lightly fried tilapia, onion, cilantro slung in hot tortillas.  Three were more than enough with sharing, especially with the accompanying rice and beans. The torta was even more engorged with pit fired strips of pork, tomato, cilantro and their own spicy mayonnaise, on a fresh large soft roll.  Delicioso! 

El Limon does a nice balancing act between authentic Mexican fast food and the American palate. They understand their customers are from both worlds. 

If they found a way to provide the chips and salsa in the traditional way, rather than to enhance their bottom line, this local chain would make my short list of favorite casas Mexicanas.

Pulaski's Meat Products is a Polish butcher shop located in the Trenton Farmers Market on Spruce Street. It was drawing quite a crowd when we walked over to their high refrigerated display cases. No surprise when the huge selection of sausage was sighted. They had dozens of choices from pork, beef, lamb and combinations stuffed tightly into skins. There were kielbasi of every rank and order, even a cherry wood smoked variety that captured my attention.

Service was prompt, courteous and friendly from the folks in those long white aprons. We opted for a few grillers for the backyard, and one of the smaller cherry woods. Too, the sign said they carried "Homemade Pierogi," so I inquired about them, and was told to go over around the side of the displays to the wall units in the side hall leading to an exit. Found them. Selected the potato/onion stuffed dough. Grabbed two packages. Noticed that they were not homemade, unless they lived in Brooklyn. It all came to about $35. 

Just a bit tony for the bad part of the capital city. 

We noshed on the kielbasa on the drive home. Both varieties were very well made and had firm outer skin and tender filling. Sure they will be even better grilled or fried. That night we cooked up the Polish dumplings with a mix of fresh sauteed red onion, mushroom and red & yellow pepper as a topper. Very good after the boil/fry preparation, although I would have loved them more had the mashed potato been somewhat less dense. Enjoyed the combo, but it could have been spectacular with more attention to that detail. 

The Trenton Farmers Market is still in operation after all these decades, and still attracting enough consumers with quality vendors willing to lend their credibility to make it all work.

Fitzwater Cafe on the South Philadelphia street by the same name appears to be a continental bistro style breakfast/ lunch maison with a creole flavor. In earlier incarnation it looks to have been an auto repair shop. It is a lot more gentrified today, with French, Louis XV paneled ceiling, long bar with mirrored back bar, and beautiful Provencal ceramic tile floor. The space is bright and airy with glass wall southern exposure. It is a beautiful setting for breakfast or brunch. 

We stopped in after an early morning of medical attention and on our way down to Washington Avenue for grocery shopping. We ordered their breakfast burrito and morning andouille sausage, 3 egg and swiss Sammy on torpedo roll. Coffee (hot and strong) all around. 

Both plates were enough for two meals apiece. The burrito had a great blend of meat, cheese and savory veggies. The Sammy was almost as good, but the hollowed out roll didn't have enough crunchy body to offset the oiliness of the andouille. Really needed a French rather than Italian case. 

With everything premium priced to lead to a $30 breakfast with java, it was very good, but not the perfection implied by the cost. Still, Fitzwater Cafe is a winner for this corner of the City.

This is the same Ploy Siam that was in Robbinsville, NJ for several years. It relocated to reduce overhead from their former large restaurant. Same folks. Same kitchen. Same quality Thai cuisine. Just a much smaller storefront down in Burlington County. 

I was there for a late lunch/early dinner last weekend. I recognized the 'mama san' from the original spot, and she confirmed the above information. We chatted briefly before she too my order for Tom Kha Soup and their Crazy Noodles (aka Drunken Noodles). The place is very basic with utilitarian tables and chairs and minimalist decorations. With three rows of tables in a narrow shop there was little room for Buddhas and elephants. 

My meal was as good as I remembered. The Tom Kha was a deep bowl filled with veggies and medium spiced lemongrass and coconut milk broth. Delectible! It was hot enough to warm the gullet, but not so hot as to pucker the lips. Among the best of breed in recent memory. The noodles were Thai Spicy and loaded with more greens, onions, sliced chicken and a few shrimp. It did more fire damage than the soup, but by the time I was a quarter into it, I had adjusted to the flames and was having fun. Excellent brown sauce. Chewy broad rice noodles. The only momentary disappointment was the dearth of shrimp I had apparently paid extra for (without proper notice). Somehow a buck per was not what I anticipated. Yet, it was all tasty enough to be in a forgiving mood. 

It was the Bhuddhist thing to do. 

I was punished for my indulgence. Lesson learned.

Friends B & G is one of the better places to hang out if beer, sports and decent (not great) food are your priorities. When we arrived Friday around 9, the place was packed, but the good people at the bar were more than willing to move down and make room for us.  Love that kind of courtesy.

We had drinks and eventually a booth cleared and we were able to sit around and have a couple of apps that were ample for the 8 of us.  The Nachos Supreme were what you would expect - piled high with chips, cheese, chopped onions and peppers; and the Hot Wings pretty good when considering there were about 20 of them.  Good prices, too.

Our group often meets there after big events (like elections), and we always find space to celebrate.  We are hoping for a good reason to party next Tuesday night.  

You are all invited.  See you there.

Same great big fat donuts as the other Yum Yum shops around.  Same good coffee.  Same very reasonable prices.  Same friendly service and pride in the baker's craft. 

This one lacks a public restroom, meaning if that is one of the reasons for your stop here, you should consider visiting the Wawa Service Station across the street before you go. 

Easier to indulge that way!

Bagelissimo is an Italian deli of a bagel shop, showing that cross cultural alternatives can work well. The shop in a fairly new strip center on Rt. 206 North, has a decent layout for eating in or taking out. They offer a fair variety of bagels, muffins and sandwiches, although the rounders are a bit denser than I prefer. 

My onion bagel, butter and swiss had good flavor, plenty of dry onion flakes, and a lot of chewability. A few air pockets here and there would have brought it completely home for me. 

Service was prompt and friendly. Prices about the best I have encountered recently. My sammy went for $2. I am sure the manager saw my double take. I dropped a buck in the tip basket out of appreciation for my wallet.

Nifty Fifty's is an authentic throwback burger and shake joint that epitomizes the Philly scene in the middle of the last century.  Loud, garish, neon-blitzed lighting, the whole 9.  It is diner-like with booths and counter service, and dedicated to the proposition that a great greasy burger, fries and sweet creamy shake are timeless icons that people never tire of.  

They are quite right!

Our visit last Saturday night was met with a 30 minute queue for a booth.  The line moved along fast enough to hold our interest, and the aroma of hot grease was so overwhelming that we could not have walked out if we wanted to.  It is instantly addictive.  My companion for the evening was a new arrival to America, and this was her first exposure to old fashioned burger mania.  

We were escorted to our table/booth and handed their bible (menu).  Rather than attempt to explain what this cultural event was all about, I just ordered the ever-popular Bacon Cheeseburger for her, and the Double Cheeseburger with Fried Onions & Mayo for me, along with a basket of traditional fries and a Black Raspberry Shake to share.  

When everything arrived on the arms of our incredible server Destiny, I watched as my companions eyes widened as she took her first bite, munch and sip.  They said it all.  She was excited, happy and totally into the experience.  I was a half step behind her as I doctored my burger and the fries with ketchup.  The shake was creamy and cold in its aluminum mixing vessel.  It so nicely offset the crunchy saltiness of the ample fries, and the deeply satisfying juicy chewiness of the burger.  

Nifty has perfected the formula for grease to such an extent that you crave it despite knowing it is not so good for you.  The soft bun absorbs much of what is not directly ingested, yet no thought is given to leaving it on the plate.  The fries have a similar subtle attribute that makes them very tasty, especially when there are small nubs in the bottom of the basket.  Love those babies.  

Five Guys approaches Nifty's burgers for taste and texture, but lacks the overall ambiance of this iconic burger emporium.  

I know there are other good things on the menu, but I have never made it passed the sliders.

Francisco's Pizzeria is having a soft opening this week, and by the looks of things they know how to launch. They took over the former Cosi on Pheasant Run in the Newtown Business Commons, and have done a nice makeover with exposed brick wall, partially dropped ceiling for lighting and HVAC, and new pizza ovens in the open kitchen. The place looks good and the dining area is comfortable. The staff looks polished in their black T's. 

We stopped in for a late lunch on Friday after finishing a list of chores. The menu offered most of the usual suspects found in Italo-American houses, with everything from salads to pizza to calzones to full dinner. We tried their buffalo chicken cheesesteak, fried chicken wrap and eggplant parmesan sandwich. All were good, although the steak Sammy and eggplant scored higher than the wrap. The torpedo rolls had good texture and taste, especially after being toasted in the oven to finish the job. 

This is the closest restaurant to home, so it will get a strong workout from us, particularly if their pizza is top of the chart. Who knows? Perhaps my son who currently works at another Italian joint in town, will look into getting a job just 5 minutes away.

Is it possible to be a fan or Wahoo for a shoe repair shop? 

Existential inquiry, but one worth considering as long as your soul and sole relate well with each other. Mine always have.  The longer I walk, the deeper within I delve. Same for you?  Then, be sure to treat your feet well through well crafted footwear maintenance. 

Newtown Shoe Repair sits in the middle of downtown Newtown Borough, in an undersized storefront shop, with walk up steps to the wood and glass doors.  Careful, if you open the door without the magic words, you are stepping into a time machine than has only one destination date - 1955. 

The old machines, the smell of leather and wax, the shelves full of shoes and boots...
Worth a visit, but of course the business owners would love you to take off your shoes and let them put on new heals and a shine. 

It is a bit expensive for basic service - now $25. for almost any repair.
So, as the other reviewer suggests, drop off your shoes and walk around Newtown for a great afternoon.  But, you might want to bring an extra pair of shoes...

Authentic Polish/East European smoked meat emporium situated in the Trenton Farmers Market, with the touch and feel of butcher/deli of my childhood. The center of attention is the Kielbasi collection where you can order any combination of long red sausage you desire for slicing, grilling or mixing in a casserole. Also do their own stuffed cabbage quite well. 

Not impressed with the pierogi which are no longer homemade, but trucked down from Brooklyn, and are thick skinned with too dry potato mash. 

And, as with most of the outfits here, the prices are premium leaving little to the imagination. Definitely paying for the privilege of participating in a cultural event.

DiCarlo does itself a disservice by letting itself be called only a pizza joint. The "restaurant" is really the more important piece of the action at this small Italian kitchen in the Mallard Creek Shopping Center, Richboro. There is an extensive menu with some interesting dishes that cry for attention. 

Very glad we went that way, rather than limiting ourselves to a couple of pies as suggested by the restricted name. 

We ordered Chicken Francaise with Linguini, Veal Bruschetta with Broccoli, Carlos Junior with Linguini and a Chicken Parmigiana Sandwich. They were all huge portions, well designed and surprisingly tasty. The francaise was three large breast medallions in a decent butter, lemon, white wine sauce. It could have been more tender and penne would have worked better than the messy linguini. Still it was good, if not best of breed.

On the other hand, the veal was lightly breaded and pan fried before being topped with fresh chopped tomato bruschetta. It was delicious even if the broccoli had long tough stalks. The Junior was basically an Italian Sausage and Penne dish with a garlicky sauce. Good, but its name was the most creative part. Finally, the Chicken Parm sandwich was immense and very good. 

Each dish was enough for at least two meals, so in combination with the reasonable prices, made for an economical family feast to celebrate surviving another week of Covid. 

Because of the lack of attention to detail on a few of our choices, the actual score is 3.5 Stars, rounded up. Refine the francaise sauce a bit, pare down the broccoli to remove more tough stalk, use real Italian loaf for garlic bread, offer choice of pasta on phone orders; and this simple house could approach a five star takeout experience.

Gabby's Banh Mi is a Vietnamese sandwich shop on Main Street, Ambler, PA. It is on the first floor of an older building, giving it a subdued, dated, yet peaceful quality. It is run by a young family with infant in tow, which helps set the tone. 

Their main offerings are the demi baguette sandwich with choice of protein and fixings, and pho with choice of meat in large bowl. I knew I couldn't consume both in one visit, so I opted for the Banh Mi with roast pork and all the accoutrement. A home brewed peach ice tea came along to assist with wash down. 

The bread is the most important part of any sandwich, and this was no different. It was fresh, soft, mildly crusty, with sourdough flavor. I squirted extra hoisin into its matrix to enhance the sweet BBQ nature of the pork, and to complement the daikon, spicy mayo and cilantro. It was very good, leaving tiny crumbs behind on the table with each bite. The tea was likewise peachy keen, but could have been bigger than a 6 ounce glass for the price ($4.50).  In fact the nine bucks for the sammy seemed trop cher as well. I guess commercial rents in Ambler are on the way up. But, as South Philly is closer to me than Ambler, except when I have business in Norristown, I will most often continue to take such pleasures in the city when the mood strikes. 

Otherwise, the bowl of ribeye pho on the next table looked damned inviting.

We waltzed into the Blue Danube just before 7 on a Saturday night during Christmas Week, and were immediately seated without rez at a very cozy table for two along a back wall that felt very private.  The layout of the restaurant reminds of many other old Chambersburg establishments that set up a kitchen in an old row house. While not in that part of Trenton, it is close enough to offer the same sensation. It was do doubt done in the 60's or 70's, and has all the charm you would expect from a deeply urban environment at a time when Trenton was still an All American City.  Sadly, those days are history. 

The staff is friendly and helpful, and quickly understood that we were first-timers who needed a brief guided tour through the menu. Although my grandparents came from this part of the Old World, our being kosher kept us from sampling most of the better offerings from a Budapest or Viennese kitchen.  We ordered the Danube Sampler, consisting a Pierogies, Stuffed Cabbage, Sausage, and curly Noodles, all in their appropriate sauces.  As an appetizer it was a good introduction to several tastes we would not otherwise reach in one meal.  The star of the plate was the Stuffed Cabbage; tender cabbage and soft ground beef and pork mix with rice, with a mild sweetness that was most enjoyable.  The Pierogies were also soft with a potato/cheese filling and nice Sautéed Onion topping.  The special sausage was a very small piece, but that was just as well as the flavor was a bit odd to my tongue and would take some getting used to.  

Our entrée was a shared Pork Schnitzel and Brown Sauce with a side of the same noodles.  It was quite good, but not particularly unique in any way.  The Brown Sauce was ladled on a bit heavy, perhaps diluting the taste of the breading and pork. 

There was some confusion about our order, but our server handled it well, and we ended up with a free glass of wine to make up for it.  That was reasonable.  

Bottom Line - We really enjoyed the atmosphere of Blue Danube, and the wait staff.  The food was good, but not great.  The standout was the Stuffed Cabbage, with the Pierogies a close second.  I would not rush back to try more things on the menu, but if someone suggested a good East European dinner, I would not hesitate to recommend a return visit.

With a sign under the peak of the roof reading, "Circa 1734," you get the feeling that the Newportville Inn is pretty old. Approaching it as it sits on Lower Road running along Neshaminy Creek, it is easy to imagine it looked more or less the same 250 years ago when it was a pre-Revolutionary War weigh station between Philadelphia and Trenton. Historic lore mentions the likes of George Washington, John Adams, Alexander Hamilton and even Thomas Jefferson in the vicinity as they sought safe places to meet to plot the course of independence while the British Army occupied New York and threatened Philadelphia. This historic structure was there to offer room and board to the wayward revolutionists. 

Aside from newer additions and the outdoor beer garden, the building is basically unchanged since back in the day. Sitting at the old bar in a small chamber with low beamed ceilings and deep well windows, time can seem to stand still. Yes, it could stand some renovation and deep cleaning, but not at the expense of lost charm and legendary significance. I enjoy such time warps on occasion. 

Besides, the German menu and beer choices are hard to duplicate in the area. My Wartmeister Pilsner was cold, smooth and refreshing. The footlong wiener house special with potato salad and sauerkraut, a delectable authentic meal. Dining at the bar with Johnny Bartender working his magic, and the 76ers on the tube, was a very satisfying interlude. The hot potato salad was great, and the sliced apple in the sauerkraut a terrific idea, adding a touch of sweetness to the briney sourness. 

While not a lover of all German cuisine, wurst and schnitzel I like, and Newportville specializes in them. Given how friendly everyone was to this stranger, I can see returning as the mood for a brat or breaded/fried chicken or pork schnitzel moves me.

Kabobeesh is a Pakistani semi-fast casual house that serves very good South Asian cuisine on a budget. The atmosphere is utlilitarian, the service minimal, but the food excellent. 

Following the sage guidance of Yelp friend Vinny B., we ordered the Resham Chicken Kabob, Lahori Chargha and the Chickpeas.  They were prepared in the kitchen and brought to us about 20 minutes later on styro plates, with a huge basket of naan.  All were very good to excellent.  The Resham was the ground chicken variety, heavily spiced and grilled over open file kabob-style. It came as a dinner, on a bed of basmati rice, small salad, and the order of chickpeas in a deep brown sauce.  The flavor was rich and rewarding. Wrapped in a torn piece of naan, or eaten straight up, it was a treat.  The chickpeas were likewise tender and richly tasteful as they mixed with the chicken in an adventurous combination.  The rice was pleasantly aromatic, although the salad was lost in the party of other dominant tastes.  

The Chargha is a Pakistani version of roast chicken, well dosed in wonderful spices and in the oven long enough for the meat to easily pull off the bone. The strong flavor was unusual and captivating, requiring two hands to work the cut up parts to access all the chicken between the bones.  Luckily, we found the napkin stash and grabbed a few extras to keep the mess under control.  Really loved this dish. 

The weakness of the experience was the general take out orientation of the business despite the many eat-in customers.  Styro plates and cups, plastic forks and knives, made for a less than fully enjoyable experience.  From both environmental, and personal comfort perspectives, the dinner could have been a complete home run with the availability of reusable dishes and flatware.  It might cost a little more, but respect for the planet and customers, would turn Kabobeesh into a full throated five-star evening.  

It is still a very good place to go to get your Paki on.

There he was. The famous Steve Stein came out from behind the long refrigerated display counter to greet me and apologize for having his staff request my photo ID and vaccination card before allowing me to enter the dining room to have breakfast. 

I didn't mind. This was a new legal requirement for entry enforced by the City of Philadelphia by a fine of $2,000. Actually, I had no issue with the public safety needed to protect from Omicrom, but also saw how it could become rather draconian, while also damaging businesses forced to have customers move through a checkpoint in order to be served. It reminded me of military checkpoints I had to endure while traveling in the Middle East, but without guns and uniforms (at least for now?). Still, far from a pleasant prospect, and one I hoped wouldn't be necessary for long. 

The facility is a classic Kosher style Jewish deli/restaurant, with 75% dedicated to smoked meat, fish, and a large variety of salads, knishes, bakery and many premade meals. There was also a large green grocery with beautiful veggies stacked high. 

I ordered the Fried Matzo with extra Sautéed Onions mixed in. It arrived at my table the size of a large dinner plate. While not as crisp as my mother cooked in smaller patties, it was hot, steaming and delicious. A good shake of black pepper upped the spice level to where I liked it, along with the enhanced onion flavor requested at a $.50 up charge. I would certainly get that again. 

I also brought home a few Onion Bagels (semi-dense and excellent when toasted), and a couple of Potato Knishes for later consumption. They were traditional and very similar to my childhood memories - light wrap that baked well and held their contents to the end. Loved them. 

Not sure how often I'll go out to eat with these Covid regulations in place. They make the risk of exposure impossible to ignore. 

We are, indeed, living in difficult and memorable times.

PS. The complimentary slice of Apple Cake was very good and greatly appreciated.

Housed in a former convenience store, Piazza's Bakery does all its work in their large workspace and ovens in the back room. A large tray of yeast glazed pretzel twist donuts was coming out, and I immediately pointed to it, saying, "I want some of those!" 

Great choice, because they were terrific - light, airy, mildly yeasty and, oh, so, perfectly glazed. Very reminiscent of Crispy Kremes classics, but bigger. The brownies were just as impressive with a layer of chocolate icing above dense chewy choco base. Their croissants were also good, but not as flaky as a French boulangerie would create. 

Their were plenty of cookies, fruit pies and customized celebratory cakes that looked great, but were beyond the limits of my sweet tooth. Didn't see much in the way of bread or rolls while there, but that could have been a question of timing.

Piazza's is worth another visit.

Quite busy in the middle of Sunday, this Golden Dawn Diner in Burlington, NJ, is an institution in this part of South Central Jersey. It has been slinging hash for more than 50 years, specializing in breakfast, brunch and lunch, but with plenty of choices for dinner, too. Prices have gone higher with inflation pressure, but it is still on the lower end of cost as everything rises under the same economic realities. 

I was there for a morning meal, and quickly ordered their Veggie Lover's Omelette, Hash Browns, Rye Toast and Coffee. The three egger was loaded with onion, green pepper, broccoli, snow pea, mushroom and tomato, with my ask for added feta cheese accepted with a smile from my amazingly attentive server. It was very good, with more variety of ingredients than usual. The potatoes were also a large score, with enough crisply browned surfaces to make me happy. The rye was buttered, yet remained crunchified to the end. The Java was was institutional Bunnomatic, but refilled so often I almost felt compelled to drink more just to keep my server feeling appreciated. She was very good, dropping off fresh napkins with each visit and making sure the requested glass of milk for the coffee was also replenished. 

To my knowledge, there are three Golden Dawns in this region; in Hamilton, NJ and Levittown, PA, as well as this one. They are all good, and this may be the oldest in the clan, while Hamilton, the newest. Can't go wrong with any of them, especially if you enjoy diner desserts, which are baked in house, large portioned and generally delicious and inevitably fattening.

FD Subs has been at this location in Ewing Plaza Shopping Strip for a few decades with different owners and levels of satisfaction. When I stopped in this week for late lunch of a turkey/swiss sub, the wall menu looked like it had been hung in the last century. Still, it was extensive and provided succor for the famished. It wasn't open for in house dining yet, but the husband wife team were well versed in their menu and demonstrated prodigious production skills. 

Their strong suit was that everything for the sandwich contents was cut on demand, and thus as fresh as possible; and decent torpedo rolls (really the most important element of the creation) were pulled from a bag only as needed. My Honey Turkey and Swiss hoagie with shredded lettuce, mayo and hot/sweet peppers wasn't zoftig, but ample enough to warm and fill the belly of the beast. I enjoyed it. 

I have been on a deli kick of late, and FD was about as rewarding as the other local family run shops in the region. Good to help keep all of them in business by chosing mom & pop businesses open and thriving, rather than those factory like places that offer gasoline as a side dish.

On a unusually balmy early November afternoon Café Alessio's outdoor patio is a great place to have lunch, enjoy the breeze and blue sky, and watch Doylestown go by.  

The three of us stopped in after taking care of business in the courthouse.  The al fresco dining area was not crowded at 2:00 pm, and we settled in to review the lunch menu.  Our waitress was very helpful in pointing out the specials as well as those items she liked the most.  We ended up with two California Burgers (medium) and a Milano Sandwich.  

The Burgers were half pounders and hand molded.  They arrived appropriately pink inside, one with Fries, the other, Chips.  The Lettuce, Tomato, Onion, Avocado and Cheese were loaded on top and encased in a brioche-style bun that held up well.  I was given a few bites and thought it was quite good - fresh tasting and nicely grilled.  

My Milano Chicken Sandwich was served on the same bun and had interesting tomato based paste smeared on the bread, and more lettuce, garlic and sautéed spinach.  I liked it, but not quite as much as the burger.  

The menu included salads, pizza and pasta dishes that all looked attractive as served to other patrons. Prices were reasonable for D'town and the price/quality value proposition made Alessio's a true deal, especially with all the autumn light glowing around us.  

Definitely satisfying.

Another state of the art burger emporium from Five Guys. 

If you like your sliders fresh, hot and greasy, this is your place.  For $10. you get the standard double with or without cheese and all the toppings you can imagine, on a crushed bun, and a cuppa hot fries that spills into the bag and is easily enough for three. Another few bucks for the bottomless drinks.

When the 13 year old we were with suggested McDonald's for lunch, I Yelped for an alternative and found this 5 Dudes even closer than the golden arches.  It was his first try and though he didn't say much, he ate the whole sandwich, plenty of fries, and washed everything down with Sprite.  

Win-win for all of us.

I have been back regularly since my review.

Having overcome my hesitance about the quirky advertising with cows asking humans to eat more chickens (that's another dissertation about social morality), and eaten a few other things beyond the Sausage, Egg and Cheese Biscuit (5 Stars), I achieved the realization that I was too harsh in my evaluation before. 

The sandwiches are good, the shakes superior, and the playroom for kids, unique.  I don't have to agree with corporate politics to appreciate the grub. 

Okay. I am a fan. I am willing to admit it.

When the Viking Stovetop's downdraft exhaust fan went on the fritz, visions of very expensive repairs danced in my head. First, very few repair dudes handled Viking equipment, and those few who did wanted my first born as collateral before agreeing to come to the house to check it out.  

I finally called Dave's Appliance Repair in Horsham after the local boys struck out. A real person answered the phone, listened to the symptoms, and seemed confident they could handle it.  Their only demand was that the first visit be paid for in advance. At $90, I knew why. My doctor visit costs less. Still, I paid it, and one of their service techs came for a visit within a few days.  He was a pleasant chap with an amiable sidekick.  

He started taking apart the exhaust venting system to get to the root of the problem - the burned out motor. He had to dissemble the cabinet in front of it, remove the rear cabinet wall, and return to his truck several times to grab the right tools for this ever more difficult surgery.  He finally removed the dead metal, but didn't have the right one to replace it.  So began a series of visits (three and counting), as he ordered first one part, and then another, until the right one was obtained and installed.  I had to pay for the anticipated parts and labor before Dave would order them. At first, it annoyed me that a deposit wouldn't do, but I ultimately realized that this $900 one time bite was saving money, because of all the wrong parts and then extra pieces and effort necessary to get the job done.  

Our kitchen contractor had installed this stove so tightly to the rear wall, that there was little space to maneuver to get the work done.  Each visit took longer than anticipated.  Our technician (who's name will go unmentioned out of respect for his impressive skills), had to freelance most of the way, because nothing seemed to fit as expected.  Ultimately, he succeeded in finishing the job, much to the relief of all of us.  The exhaust is literally up and sucking. 

At this moment, we await replacement filters.  This has proved yet another saga, as the model number deemed appropriate does not fit in the frame. Dave is having the right size filters fabricated now.  

Yes. The multiple visits have been frustrating, but Dave and his people have seen it through, and promise to make good on the entire operation.  I believe it. Not every job is a piece of cake, as this one turned out to be a real challenge.  Still, every step of the way, they have been honest with me about it, and attempted to create a workable solution.  They have been on time, and always courteous and even funny.  The stove and exhaust are working well for the first time in a few years, and once the filters are replaced (rather than just cleaned), everything will be good to go for many more.

Leave it to my 15 year old son to tell me he needs a haircut at 5:30 pm of the evening before he leaves on a trip with his church group. Arghhh!!!

Luckily, we knew of a couple of franchise hair shops that take walk ins and are open late.  We drove over to Hair Cuttery in the Village of Newtown Shopping Center, and found the "Open" sign lit, and people inside being served.  

I sent him in ahead to get started while I parked the car, and then followed him inside.  He was already getting his hair washed when I came in.  I sat at the front window to watch and wait.  He has longish hair and only wanted a trim to help out with the heat that was coming while he was camping.  The conversation was animated, with him touching the back of his head and around his ears, and his stylist listening and asking questions.  

Twenty minutes later, he was finished with a short blow dry and comb. He looked great, and seemed very satisfied with the result.  At $18 for the men's haircut (prices are higher than listed on Yelp), and a $5. gratuity, the price was still right, especially given the circumstances of our visit.  Son said he would go back there again.  

That's a relief. Just give me more notice next time.

Although designed primarily for take out, there are two tables in the front of the house for eating in.  Be forewarned that in cooler weather, the space is not heated, but for a small space heater that can be turned on near the tables.  

Aside from that bit of discomfort, the fare from this Chinese/American shop is better than average.  My Orange Chicken, Fried Rice and Hot & Sour Soup were all superior to most of the other alternative takeaways in the Morrisville/Trenton region (except for the more authentically Chinese restos that don't fit in this category).  The chicken did not seem to have been frozen and the sauce was pleasantly thinner than the goop found in most places.  Too, it was a nice customer service to offer to make the Orange Chicken for a lunch special when it was not on the menu.  

The Soup was loaded with tofu, sprouts and mushrooms, while not dosed heavily with MSG. The Fried Rice was dyed with the bouillon beef stock, but was otherwise full of veggies and chunks of pork.  

The friendly, accommodating service made for an enjoyable, if chilly, meal.

Needing to paint the wood trim around my home the same color as the original, I took a chip of paint to The Paint Store in Newtown to see if they could match it.  They were able to match it as a Benjamin Moore paint called, "Steamed Spinach."  Who'd a thunk it would be that easy? 

So, they mixed me a quart of it, low gloss, and I walked out a happy homeowner.  The experience was pleasant and completely no sweat.  The shop has all the material necessary for such jobs.  The prices are not as cheap as the highway box stores, but the convenience of being 5 minutes from home, and keeping our community businesses successful, is worth the small premium to me.  

Now, all I need is a way to get 30 feet up to the gable to paint.

Bailey's sits in a small strip center on Emelie Road in Levittown, Pa, just off Five Points. It is a neighborhood bar and grill with a decent beer list and menu into wings, burgers, soups and salads. Prices are quite reasonable. Nothing fancy, but solid grub and suds. Family place. Loud music. Friendly staff, all of whom stopped by our table to see how we were doing. 

We weren't feeling adventurous. Our thirst and hunger led us to a local brew IPA and Strongbow Cider, followed by roast beef panini and patty melt. Chips came as accompaniment, or for $1.50 more, a pile of fries. 

The sandwiches were large and quite good. We brought half the panini home. We thought we were ready to go when our server asked if we had interest in dessert. 

"Maybe. What ya got?"

Simple question. Profound answer. 

The chef has a special gift for desserts. That day he had created a mango glazed cheesecake. The rest is history. We were given a big slice of this creamy orgasmic heartsweet forklicking beauty. It was a cool, dense, tastebud exploding chunk of the most extraordinary cheesecake I had ever experienced - better the Junior's, the Cheesecake Factory, and even your Aunt Betty. 

Not even Bailey's knows what they have going on in their kitchen. This guy is the King of Cheesecake. 

Check it out. Start with dessert.

I was a regular breakfast patron at the Radcliffe Café for several years after discovering it was only a little off my route from Newtown to Mt. Holly on mornings I needed to be in court down there.  It is named for the street it is on, which runs along the Delaware River until reaching downtown Bristol.  It is easy to imagine how nice it was 100 years ago when the area more open and the river carried the commerce from Trenton to Philadelphia and all points in between.

The Café is a great spot for a hearty breakfast - traditional style. Eggs of all varieties, pancakes, sandwiches and bottomless cups of Joe predominate.  There are the regulars who are there daily, the semi-regulars who come routinely, but do not call the lunch counter seats their own, and the tourists who stop in because they stumbled onto it, or heard a good rumor about it (on Yelp?).  Dog eared copies of the Trentonian were available for reading accompaniment. 

The staff is out of central casting for diner molls. You can't get out without being called, "Hon," or "Sugar," at least once.  You gotta like that cultural affect to be captivated by its charm.  When I was a semi-reg, there was a server who I wanted to call me that and more.  I always sat on the right hand of the counter to enjoy her intriguing smile and black jeans.  My choice was either a big breakfast sandwich, which always came with the Sunnyside Ups leaking out, or the French Toast.  Both tasty. Both completely satisfying.  

Sadly, I could never linger for a long chat with her, as court beckoned.  Still, my imagination often ran wild with the possibilities. 

 Stop in and start your own daydreams.

Newtown Jewelers is a family run jewelry store on State Street, Newtown Borough.  It is a small shop, but it has a nice selection of affordable pieces, including watches, gold and silver rings, bracelets and necklaces, as well as a few nice gemstone articles. They are well connected and can find almost anything you want, and they enjoy the challenge. 

I routinely bring my watches there for repair and batteries, and find the interaction with Cheryl and Bill to be warm and often entertaining. 

This is certainly a shop locally winner!

I was looking for a place to hang out while a family member was in night class at Morrisville High School (English as a Second Language).  Yelp offered a few suggestions nearby, and I choose to discover the Morrisville Tavern on West Trenton Avenue, at the edge of the Big Oak Shopping Center.  

It wasn't very busy at 7 pm when I walked in; just folks who looked to be regulars and family/friends of the attractive bartender.  No one bothered to look up, which is a good thing on a first visit.  I sat facing a multitude of HDTVs, and I was quickly approached by the lovely alchemist working the patrons.  She gave me a rundown of the beer on tap, and when I asked about hard cider she offered Angry Orchard Apple.  She also changed the channel on a few of the screens to bring up the Sixers basketball game (not that they would provide any real entertainment).  

The Angry was cold with a sweet/tart bite.  Very good.  I took a look at the menu and specials board, and wished that I had not already had dinner.  The variety looked appealing, and the platters being served at the bar looked appetizing.  Will definitely make a point to come hungry in the future.  

This is a nice dive bar.  The natives are friendly and seem to have a comfort with each other.  Personal conversations all around.  I could do without the smoking, but given the scarcity of tobacco-accepting taverns these days, I understand why those in the habit appreciate having a place to call their own.  I can deal with it now and then.  

I will be back soon, perhaps, next time without my work suit, so I can join in the camaraderie with more enthusiasm.

Emei Shan is a holy Buddhist mountain in Szechuan Province, China. It is a difficult climb up steep trails and even steeper stairs. On the way, monkeys drop out of the trees seeking donations from the faithful, sometimes quite aggressively.  Still, once reaching the summit, you stand above the clouds and look out at a timeless world of sky and mountaintops.  Breathtaking.

E Mei Restaurant takes its name from this mountain.  

When I made my first visit over the past weekend, I was impressed with the effort made to upgrade the floor with quality tables and chairs, as well as table clothes and an overall sense of wanting to treat the customer well.  It worked. The cuisine is slightly different than the better know superheat of most Szechuan style dishes.  The owner is from Chongqing, a major city in China, that was formerly part of Szechuan Province, but is now an Autonomous Zone, carved out of its former province.  Their food is spicy and often hot, but more subtle than the blast furnace approach found in better known Chengdu-ese molten flavors. 

My companion and I started with apps of Dan Dan Noodles and Eggplant with Pepper. Both were well done, and only mildly hot.  The beef sauce on the noodles was plentiful. The eggplant more shredded than sliced, yet even with the ample peppers, did not raise a fire alarm.  Both were quite enjoyable. 

Our main courses consisted of Fish Fillet in Hot Spicy Sauce, Diced Rabbit with Peanuts in Chili Sauce, and Saute Squash.  Here's were the thermometer began to rise.  The fish came in a deep dish with a ton of fillets.  The sheen from the chili oil in which the fish swam was very noticeable, and its red color contrasted nicely with the pale yellow of the odd shaped fish.  This dish was about 4 alarm, meaning my tongue instantly reacted to touching the sauce and began to numb a bit. Just the way I like it! 

Rabbit is not my fave, but having had it in Chongqing I wanted to celebrate the opportunity.  The meat was on the bone, and cut into small pieces.  The peanuts were a strong presence, helping to control the overflowing chili and star peppers attempt at an insurrection. It was 5 alarm even with the peanuts holding the worst elements at bay.  For me, rabbit is a lot of work because of all the bones and small morsels of meat attained.  Still, it tasted very good, and all of it was gone by the time we called it quits on more eating.  The small green squash was a pleasantly sweet counterbalance to the rabbit's "hare" raising. 

All in all a very enjoyable and authentic meal.  Definitely worth a return visit.  For those of us who love Szechuan heat, this place is worthy, even if not at the apex of the volcanic chili scale.

Climb E Mei and taste the view from the top.

All this for under $50. plus tip.

This Guatemalan house at the corner of Dayton and South Clinton Ave. in Trenton, NJ, is another of the fine casas Latinas in and around the capital city.  What used to be an Italian neighborhood with bars/restaurants on every block, have now become a league of nations of Central and South American culture and cuisine.  

Stepping into the barroom the first impression is of a darkly lit, yet surprisingly clean and inviting space.  Nice back bar with lots of tequila and rum, an attractive friendly bar keeper who smoothly shifted between Spanish and English, and a pool table under bright lights for the real players.  There is a larger dining room in the back, but I was all about sitting on a spinner and grabbing lunch.  

Symone was attentive and engaging; more than happy to provide some history for this place, while prepping for the evening crowd.  She's the daughter in law of the owner, and has been part of the scene for six years.  The menu offers traditional comidas Guatemalteca, which is similar to Mexican, but with a couple of pleasantly different flourishes.  The tortillas are thicker and chewier, and most side dishes offer more than rice and beans.  I ordered the Carne Adobada with Black Beans and Potato Salad.  The meat was well grilled and spiced with their secret recipe (I asked for it, but she claimed it was a secret even to her).  The Black Beans were rich and creamy, and the salad unlike any potato conglomerate I had ever tasted before.  Cool, chunky, slightly sweet, and mayo-ed with something else I couldn't define, that made it very good.  My Horchata drink was perfectly chilled for the heat of the afternoon.  Loved it.  

All the while, Symore returned to be sure I was satisfied, and tell me more about the operation.  She even allowed a photo when I suggested it would be a boon to business.  

Take a look.  You can see why.

Mercer Café at the corner of East Westmoreland and Mercer Streets in Port Richmond, Philadelphia, PA, is a classic neighborhood restaurant that helps give this section of the City of Brotherly Love its distinct character. It has a cozy, clubby atmosphere and a strong kitchen for classic and neo-classic menus focused on the morning and afternoon meal.  There is a small counter and a couple of dozen tables in the front of the house facing Westmoreland, and many more along the wall to the back of the house.. It is a very nice place to hang out with excellent La Colombe Coffee, and your favorite breakfast or lunch repast. 

Our basic egg, hash browns and wheat toast, and Greek-style omelet (I edited the ingredients), were both solid meals, yet not the knockouts they could have been. We found the potatoes to lack crispness and be overly salted. Too, there are unusual upcharges on any bread accompaniment other than plain Jane white.  Their whole wheat option costs a few dimes more, looked good, but lacked any identifying flavor. It was just a good sponge for the runny over easy yolks. Similarly, my omelet which contained onions, spinach, tomato, feta and those taters, was pretty good (especially with a large dose of Cholula), but the premium rye toast was smallish and far from the freshest bread I have eaten for an additional half buck.

There must be a business reason for costing out the meals with add-ons for bread choice, but it is idiosyncratic to say the least, especially when the quality of the loaves denies that they could have cost so much more than the white. 

Still, putting that aside, Mercer Café is a strong city breakfast and lunch nook, with superior Java, that can easily become a favorite stop on the Philadelphia breakfast train.

I stop in on occasion when in the area and feeling the "burger lust" hit me. 
Red Robin offers a cool semi-roadhouse environment and sliders on the high side of the scale.  My preference was the Onion Burger with sauteed onions, red onion and onion roll for the bun.  Not sure it is still on the menu, but the First Bite Experience was so very pleasurable. Endless French Fries are also a plus for the hungry. 

I know there are other things on the menu, but I have never gotten beyond the ground beef disks, fries or rings. 

It compares well with Cheeburger Cheeburger, although it may lack a little something side by side with a 5 Guys.  As Grease Palaces go, Red Robin is a solid alternative, and scores well on the comfort scale and as a family activity destination.

08.12.13 - Returned after a movie at Neshaminy AMC. Same roadhouse atmosphere and friendly service. The special Berzerker Burger was nicely spicy and medium pink. Son was way happy with his basic Bacon Cheeseburger.  His thing is to put the fries inside the bun, and he relishes that first bite confirming his sound judgment. We split a Van Shake. It was pretty good, but not at the level of Nifty Fifty, or Chick Fil A. 

Still a 4 Star experience. Very pleasant place for a above average burger.

Bigger than it looks from the outside, Mario & Frank have a good thing going at the tail end of Nottingham Way in Trenton/Hamilton, NJ.  Apparently, there are at least three other shops, as this one says it is number IV. I can understand why they have expanded.  Their food is very good as far as old school pizza parlors go.  Short menu with the usual suspects, but what they do, they do well.  This is a family operation, and during the course of my lunch, I received service from at least three of them.  All friendly, efficient, and happy to have one more customer in the house.  

I ordered the Eggplant Parm Sandwich.  It arrived about 10 minutes later on a white oval plate (no paper here).  It was neatly transected amidship, with three layers of lightly breaded, twice sautéed eggplant, just enough mozza (not drowning in it), and dollops of homemade chunky tomato sauce with the right amount of garlic and pepper for a great aroma.  

It is my habit lately, due to trying to reduce carbs, to eat almost every sandwich open face, to reduce the bread intake.  Thus, I was able to eat each layer of eggplant top to bottom, and enjoy each bite.  It was very good.  I couldn't resist a few bites of the roll.  The top was shiny and the bottom nicely showing flour and yeast remnants.  It was also enjoyable, and left me wanting to abandon my dietary resolution for another day.   

The plan now is to find and try the other Mario & Franks locations and see how they measure up. If as good as #4, the discovery will be a great tasty adventure.

I am not sure I would have located a super Wawa in the center of Richboro, PA, but it is there, and takes its place as the crown jewel of this landlocked hamlet, gas islands and all. 

The store itself is a good example of the new breed of roadside services that modernizes the convenience store with enlargement, attractive environment, and decent food and drink alternatives. And for the coffee crowd they have figured out that procuring better beans is a cheap way to grab the loyalty and favor of the java drinking public. Selling any size for a buck is a loss leader that everyone can appreciate, and leaves some jingle for something sweet to eat. 

The gas prices are generally below the competition, and as it is self service in the Commonwealth, the efficiency pumping your own saves time and treasure. 

The evolution of the reststop service oasis has come a long way in a short time. With plenty of choice in a reasonably clean cool space, there is something for almost everyone. Add a few tables for the sit and chat folks and it could become Richboro City Hall.

The Liberty Bell Diner on Frankford Avenue, Northeast Philly, is an urban diner.  It lacks the stretch stainless and glass look of the Jersey version of pure Americana roadside "stuff and go" restos.  Rather, it is more compact and hunkered down in what is now the parking lot of a strip commercial center that has seen better days.  The location certainly makes for easy parking, but I am sure the green field that was here first, was more attractive.  

That doesn't stop it was being a very good representative of the genre.  The counter sits to one side just outside the kitchen. The dining room is a nice size with about two dozen tables, white and blue painted walls, dark carpet, and a couple of HDTVs up high.  Service is provided by young women and men in black, who are well trained and friendly, with the right amount of tats exposed on their arms.  Coffee arrives quickly, and they are patient with newbies scanning their menu and asking questions.   

Our Blueberry Pancake short stack was fine, if not outstanding.  Fresh fruit in the mix was generous.  A noticeable shortcoming was the use of Kraft Syrup for the gooey sweetener, rather than something healthier and engaging. It is hard to get passed the heavy dose of corn syrup as its main ingredient.  I would gladly pay extra for a small pour of pure maple dark B grade. 

The Sausage, Egg & Cheese on Kaiser was a crowd pleaser and customizable.  It was easy to swap out of a plain breakfast patty, and into a sliced/grilled Hot Italian Porker.  It made all the difference in creating an excellent sandwich designed for my taste.  The roll was also pleasantly fresh and strong enough to hold its contents to the last bite.  The Hash Browns were forgettable. 

The staff seems to really enjoy the regulars.  There was a knot of ladies in black laughing and commenting on the photos one of the customers was sharing with them.  Even the owner allowed himself to enjoy the moment.  Very cool. 

Overall, a superior breakfast stop.

If you were blindfolded before walking into Julio's Famous Pizzeria, and saw it for the first time from inside, you would think you were in a 1950's burger and soda fountain emporium, with period photos of greats like James Dean and Marilyn Monroe, as well as the hot rods of that era plastered on the walls. Lots of paisley formica, too. Definitely not the expected décor for a pizza parlor. Yet, it is fun and it works as part of the entertainment offered in this unusual joint. 

Their thing is the sandwich pouch. Looking like a half pita, but much thicker, it is an alternative to the standard torpedo roll. It is offered for all sandwiches. It does appear to hold greater volume than a hoagie roll, but the trade off is that it lacks flavor, density or any crustiness. It is basically plain white bread shaped like a sack. I chose to try this with the Italian sweet sausage, pepper and onion grinder I ordered. I also had them throw in a load of banana peppers to add some heat to the project. Service was personal and informative. The dude actually sat across from me to discuss my options in detail when he learned I was a first timer at Julio's.  Cool!

I quickly discovered that the ingredients in the sammich were great, with high quality sausage, and plenty of pepper, onion and red sauce. However, the pouch was tasteless and did little to add to the experience. It wasn't worth the empty calories, so I ended up leaving most of it in the basket. 

My word to the wise is to stick with a regular long roll with a crust and a little sour dough flavor. It might not hold all the contents without overflow, but that is why forks were invented.

Chicken To Go has been around a long time on the point of South Broad and Chambers in the Trentony  part of Hamilton, NJ. It was Cluck - U Chicken before that.  So, this place knows from fried chicken, wings, and sammich, not to mention, ribs, burgers and milk shakes. Although painted yellow inside and out, the overall locale might be considered seedy.  Lunch is the time for a reasonably secure check out. 

Inside, the order/waiting area was surprisingly clean; much nicer than the exterior.  The people working there were friendly, and more than happy to explain the facts of life to a newbie.  I decided on The Original Chicken Sandwich on fresh Kaiser Roll Special, with lettuce, tomato and mayo.  A side of  Wedge Fries came along for the ride, as well as a drink. 

While waiting, I looked around and was curious to see a new patio area for al fresco dining on the side of the building.  Although 94 F was a bit warm for sitting under a large umbrella, it did seem a nice idea for a cooler day.  

When I opened my lunch bag at my desk, I beheld a large chicken breast, pounded and stretched, and well breaded for frying.  It stuck out of the tasty roll on all sides, with the lettuce and tomato making it slick, but still manageable.  This was no ordinary fast food chicken sandwich.  The chicken had not been frozen, and retained its proper texture and moisture. It was excellent, far better than Chik Fil A, or Mickey D's.  It was a filling meal by itself, and I ended up giving away most of the wedge fries to an officemate. 

Next time (and there will definitely be a next time), I will try some fried chicken and/or BBQ charcoal ribs.  And, for those dessert extremists out there, they offer sweets from milkshakes to hot apple pie, and fried Oreos, Twix and Reese's Peanut Butter Cups.  Haven't had those since my son was camping with the Boy Scouts, and I was providing adult supervision. 

(Yeah. Right!)

Maggio's is down on 2nd Street Pike in the deep corner of a shopping center. From the outside it looks like just another Italian resto in Southampton, PA, where so many others exist. But, looks can be deceiving. Walk in and you find a large space with a high ceilinged dining room with glass roof, separate barroom and lots of tables and booths for a big crowd. Check out the two menus (one for breakfast and another for lunch and dinner), and you realize that Maggio's is more a universal American diner with just about something for everyone, but with Italian style. 

We stopped in for lunch after a nearby endorsement meeting. Escorted to a table and promptly handed both menus, our server patiently waited as we dove into their long list of offerings. Eight pages take a few minutes to work through, but we chose an American burger and Italian sausage, onions, peppers and provolone sandwich. Both came with fries and slaw. Prices were on the high end of reasonable, and I would have been disappointed had the meal not met expectations set by the cost. 

Luckily, our lunch was very good. The sausage was housemade - a mix of sweet and hot - at the bottom of a good torpedo roll, overloaded with sauteed onions, green frying and jalapeno peppers and blanketed in melted provolone. Half was enough for me, and I wish that choice had been suggested in the menu. Still, it was excellent. The textural and flavor profile was extremely entertaining. It was one of the best versions of this classic I have eaten in quite a while. The fries were good, but I wasn't there for extra carbs. The coleslaw was minimal, but a subtle sweet undertone to the spicy onslaught of the sandwich. My buddy enjoyed every last morsel of his burger. 

Maggio's is a worthwhile stop for folks in the area. I will stick to the earlier meals, as the prices associated with dinner are a bit daunting. If they are able to serve half sandwiches or soup/sandwich/salad combos, the house could be even more popular.

Cold Spring has moved uptown from its original digs in an blown out old industrial building in Yardley, to this modern warehouse just south of 5 Points on Rt. 413, Wrightstown, Pa.  While the 19th Century look of the old place was cool, having an air conditioned space large enough to hold and display a vast variety of American and international suds, is an improvement.  They even have room for the mid-sized shopping carts that can hold a couple of cases while you shop and make way to the cashier.  

We were in a Mexican fiesta mood, so picked up a 12 bottle case of Corona, and another of Dos Equis (XX) Sampler.  Bought a supply of Lime at Tanner Bros. 

True, the price of cerveza goes up all the time, especially for the imports, but there is something to be said for comfort and convenience in brew buying. 

Cold Spring opens at 9 during the week, giving it a leg up on other local distributors who open later in the morning.

Never too early for fiesta!

Enid C. has it right. 

Pork Soy Sauce Noodle, Shaved. 

It was textured to the bite, lots of surface area to pick up and hold the wonderful sauce; a large bowled experience with Ground Pork, mild Chili Flavor, Cilantro cooked into the mix, and enough liquid to cover every nano of the free form Noodles. 

Did it change my life as suggested by Enid?  The jury is still out, but the fact that they are taking so long to decide is definitely a good thing.  

I am hooked!  Just added 5 or 6 spoons of Sesame/Chili Oil from the table container, and the taste exploded in my mouth. 

When a joint has over 800 reviews there is little left to distinguish one from the rest.  Short and sweet (In this case more spicy) is the way to go.

If you like Polish food, beer, and atmosphere, Larry's Corner Tavern is your kind of place.  

Sitting at the corner of New York Avenue and Mulberry Street in the bowels of Trenton, Larry's is a cool oasis where Polish is the primary language, and English is used only when absolutely necessary. Even the Blackboard Specials are in the mother tongue, and require translation by Daria, the amazing bartender and hostess of the dark barroom and back lounge that is called a "Euro" Bar.  

Although I was there for Pierogies and a drink, I had the misfortune of coming on a day when there were no Potato and Cheese Pierogies, but only the Meat version.  No, thanks.  Still, the menu had other options and I had their Burger that was dressed with Onions, Peppers, Cheese and a side of Hot Sauce.  (Sorry. Can't remember its name.)  

It was very good, along with fairly standard French Fries.  The best part of the experience was my exchange with Daria.  She is a natural friendly, warm and even flirty woman, who keeps the totally male customers in line with funny bilingual quips, and a sharp repartee.  All the guys watch her with active imaginations, and she plays her part well.  Quite entertaining. 

I will return to Larry's some time soon, but call first for the pierogies I remember as being superlative with sautéed onions and cool sour cream.  Maybe, I'll consider their kielbasa or blood sausage if my yearning for my grandmother's cooking becomes very strong. 

Parking in the rear, and an outdoor area with picnic tables also available.

Mission BBQ on Roosevelt Boulevard in Northeast Philadephia, does pretty good BBQ ribs and chicken, especially for a joint north of the Mason-Dixon Line.  The house looks the part, with lots of dark wood, picnic-like tables and photos of first responders on the walls. 

We ordered the equivalent of half racks of baby backs and regular spare ribs, and a half chicken.  All had sides of some sort, but aside from the fries and corn bread, those were not memorable. The ribs on the other hand were very good.  Pull off the bone smoked, with tender meat and nice rub and bark.  Each table had 6 bottle rockets with various sauces to be squirted on to moisten and flavor the chew.  None of them really stood out, and for the most part, the "as is" ribs were fine without anything more.  

Prices were reasonable. Service was all at the order counter with no table service. 

The consensus was that this was a legit BBQ joint that we would return to when the mood for pork ribs or pulled meat overcame us again.
