Approaching Rozmaryn (Rosemary) Restaurant on a rainy January night takes a bit of courage.  The store front is a rowhouse with a neon "Open" sign in the window and an old unlit sign beneath it.  The front door is open and all you see is a long hallway with dim yellow lighting.  Sketchy characters on the sidewalk make you involuntarily prepare your fight/flight responses.  Be ready for anything...

But, first walk across Olden Avenue to the liquor store to pick up authentic Polish beer to make the experience complete.  In the back of the store is the Polish section.  More sketchy guys standing around - these 'packin' employees watch your every move.  But, the Xywiec Beer is back there in bottles or cans. I pulled out a six pack of glass and brought it to the counter. $10. minimum for credit cards, so I had to pull out my wallet (I really didn't want to do it).  Done. Walked back across the street and up the front steps of 925.  On the first door to the left was the restaurant sign bidding we enter.  What was behind the door? 

I went in first.  I was greeted by an apartment converted into a small eatery.  Yellow walls, stained wood trim. Wall sconces, but little other adornment.  No one else in the main dining area.  We stood a moment and waited to see if someone would come out to seat us.  A few long seconds later a woman appeared from the rear with a warm smile and firm voice welcoming us to her shop.  She was the owner, hostess, and chef.  Very big persona.  Lovely, and I immediately relaxed.  At 6:30 we expected other patrons, but we were the first and only folks there all night.  She sat us at a central table for 4, allowing us to spread out.  NFL Playoffs had depleted her clientele, but we were quite happy to have all her attention.  

After getting the lay of the land from the gracious Madame, we ordered off the rather small menu, which is in both English and Polish.  The Polish Plate to share as our appetizer.  It consisted of Meat Pierogies, Potato Pancakes, Kielbasa in Yellow Mustard, and Apple Sauce.  The Pierogies were the least enjoyable part of the dish. While the dough was lightly fried and was a good consistency, the meat was too dense and organ-tasting for me. The Potato Pancakes were large and thin, not very oily, and a good mix of potato and flour (to hold them together).  They were crispy on the edges and tasty with a dollop of Apple Sauce to mix a little sweetness with the mild saltiness of the latke. The Kielbasa was excellent.  Scored before grilling to help the heat penetrate and to avoid splitting, the outer skin was just firm enough to hold the link together, but when bitten, it gave way nicely to allow the very tender innards to meet the tongue, disclosing its softness and interesting spice.  It was the surprise star of the plate.  The mustard kicked up the flavor, but did not overwhelm the essence of the sausage.  

We had the Stuffed Cabbage and Breaded Chicken Cutlet as our entries.  The Cabbage dish came with Mashed Potato and Cucumber Salad.  The Cabbage was tender and the mix of beef and something else was good, but perhaps a little bland.  It needed something to sweeten it, or at least that was how my Polish-Jewish grandmother prepared them. The potatoes were not hot enough, and seemed to have been plated before visiting the oven. Mild disappointment.  The Cucumber Salad was a cream base and decent.  

My Chicken dish was excellent.  The breast was large, with a pleasantly hand dipped breading coating it.  I opted for Mushrooms rather than Tomato Sauce, and was very pleased with the freshness and amount piled on the chicken.  Very tasty and definitely something I would order again.  The mashed were again cool and I left most of them alone.  The Red Beet Salad finished the plate.  Served appropriately cold, it was a nice fit, bringing mild sweetness to the mix of flavors in the breading, chicken, and shrooms.  I was happy.

To complete the repast, we ordered the Blintzes stuffed with Farmer's Cheese, and dusted with Powdered Sugar.  These babies were wonderful.  Perfect crepe wrap, and a whipped sweet cheesy filling.  Light, and a perfect end to the meal with freshly brewed coffee.  

This is a one of a kind richly local ethnic urban place that is easy to love.  The entire experience from the sidewalk scene, to the liquor store, to the special charm of the owner/chef, make Rozmaryn worth a visit or two.  When a meal becomes the food for a short story you have found something remarkable. 

This was definitely that, and more.

59 Almshouse is the address of an attractive roadhouse in Richboro, PA. It is all light wood and stone, with a cathedral ceilinged barroom that echoes with the sound of a full house at happy hour and a more sedate rear dining room for families and more intimate conversation. 

We stopped in for dinner on a Friday evening, just in time to catch the last five minutes of HH. My watermelon-tini and the bourbon barrel aged ale were both nice to get our appetites revved for what was to come. Blackened fish tacos and Southwest burger got top billing. We found both fairly well constructed and tasty, although my try at creativity, asking that the side of fries be poutine-ized was somewhat less than hoped. 

The cod in the tacos was fresh and well blackened in a frypan. The semi-authentic Mexican fixings (avocado, lettuce, aoili crema) we're on target. An enjoyable dish for sharing, although the tiny cup of black beans was cool and not flavorful. The burger was delivered partially medium (as requested), but partially rare, making for a hand packed patty that was partially quite good, and also half less than hot enough. Must have been grilled on the outskirts of the steel. Still, it was okay. The brown gravy that covered the fries was flavorful, but too heavy for the potatoes and turned them soggy, sacrificing texture and crispiness for something closed to chunky mashed. Didn't work for me, but it was my idea so I don't put that on the kitchen. Won't do it again.

We sat at a small booth in the barroom. Tight fit. The house was full of happy timers of mixed age, all having fun. It was obvious that '59' was a well known local hangout where everyone was welcome. We enjoyed the atmosphere. 

Nice place. 

3.5 Stars, rounded up.

The word, "Mega," normally suggests something very large, but in the case of Mega Quality Pizza it can't be related to the size of their shop, as it is quite small, with only four booths shoehorned into a tiny storefront in the 9800 block of Bustleton Avenue, Northeast Philly. So, maybe they are talking about the immense quality of their pies. Some people seem to like them a lot, but they have never been nominated as among the best pizza in this city. After grabbing a quick dinner there last week of their Steak Royal sandwich, Caesar Salad and Quesadilla at very reasonable prices, I can only conclude that the value offered by the quantity and quality vectors from the kitchen makes dining there a pretty big deal if your fortunate enough to find an empty table. 

My Steak Royal was enough for two people with ordinary appetites, with a load of chopped ribeye, onions, sweet & hot peppers and a splash of red sauce. Of course, the bread makes the sandwich, and their bakery provider has taken good care of them with a premium crunchy torpedo that really came back to life with a few moments in the oven to turn the package into a crispy grinder. It was very good. The cheese Quesadilla was decent, too, but the need for simplicity kept it from being a standout. There is only so much you can do with a single ingredient grilled cheese, even when found in a hot tortilla. Such is the effect of dietary restrictions. The Caesar was mega large in a big bowl, but little more than romaine, tomato, feta, red onion shavings, a sprinkle of parmesan and a plastic cup of Caesar dressing. It wasn't so much that we couldn't finish it, but more that we not motivated to do so. It was fresh, but fairly generic.

With a third mouth to fill, we would have ordered a small pizza, too, but we did not need it for the two of us. That will have to wait for another visit. As Mega is right down the street from my favorite Chinese foot massage center, that may not be very long. 

Is Mega Quality Pizza deserving of that name? Check it out and let us know.

Salerno's III on Lower Ferry Road, Ewing, NJ, recently changed hands, but has not lost its verve.  

I stopped in for lunch earlier this week thinking I would have two slices of pie and be on my way. Those plans quickly evaporated when I was handed their lunch menu by the friendly server wearing a wonderful Italian accent.  Available were many downsized dinner dishes at very attractive sub-$10. Okay. I gave it a try. 

I ordered cavatelli aglio olio.  It came with a nice side salad, and a basket of garlic knots/rollups. It was a substantial meal that would easily last through dinner.  The salad was romaine based, with sliced tomato, cucumber and red onion, with a standard balsamic dressing. The bread was right out of the oven and very tasty, especially as sops for the garlic/oil bath of the pasta bowl.  The cavatelli was cooked well, with amply browned garlic throughout.  There may have been a bit too much broth on the bottom of the bowl, but it was easy to adjust to avoid drippage.  

This was a very pleasing and substantial lunch.  It was certainly bigger than I have encountered in other Italian houses in the area, and the taste was very good.  Certainly, dinner would have been enough for two.  

I came for pizza, but ended up with something much better - a complete meal that was as pleasurable as it was surprising.

First thing - You gotta know what you are dealing with here. 

JC Fish Market & Soul Food is a Chinese house that does a very good fried fish.  I walked in expecting something else entirely.  But, with the proprietress shouting into the phone in Cantonese, and the two male workers answering her similarly, it was plain the soul food had a very eastern orientation.  

There is only one 4 seat table in the joint, so this is fundamentally a take out shop - something these folks do very well. The menu is set up primarily for sandwiches, platters, fried chicken and dessert.  Prices are downright cheap, with the range for sandwiches between $3.75 - $6.95; regular platters (fries & cole slaw), $4.65 - $10.65; and the dinners (two sides, corn bread), $6.60 - $12.75.  The quantities are large, easily enough for 2.  

Still, to make it work, you need to understand how the deal is constructed.  As a newbie, I ordered the Whiting Sandwich.  I watched as the three fish fillets were taken from the fridge, hand dipped in the breading, and placed into the deep fryer.  Five minutes later they were removed from the hot oil with tongs, and placed into a styro take away, with holes in the top.  A pile of pre-packaged plastic wrapped 2 slices of bread were placed on top of the container, and everything placed in a plastic bag.  Plastic forks and napkins were to the side for the taking.  I picked up a square of corn bread to taste @ .85.  The price was under six bucks. 

Returning to my office, I opened the package and prepared to eat.  I took out the bread, slapped 2 of the 3 fillets on the first slice and closed the preparation with the top slice.  The bread was soft and fresh.  The Whiting Fillets were great! The breading was light with a pleasant spice mix.  The fish itself was thin and tasted as if it had never been frozen. The cooking oil was clean and added nothing to the flavor of the meal.  The corn bread was likewise fresh and mildly sweet.  No complaints. Impressive. 

Knowing what I know now, I would probably head for the platters in the future, to grab a little greenery for my diet.  Too, if the fish was this good, I can imagine what they might do with the chicken.  

If there is a downside to all this, it is that the meal certainly smelled like fish.  Now, my car smells of it, and my office smells of it, too.  People walking by my door were loudly sniffing and asking;

 "Fish?"

Walking into Pete's Steakhouse on North Olden Avenue, Ewing, NJ., is like falling down the rabbit hole in Alice in Wonderland.  From the outside, the place is nothing special, but on the inside, the joint is as bright and shiny as a new penny. Clearly, these folks put a lot of effort into polishing the place to a loud red and silver hue. That, and the old bicycle hanging from the ceiling, and the James Dean, "Devil Without a Cause," poster, tell you what is going on.  

Welcome back to the 1950's! 

I was there for breakfast this week, although a lot of the menu deals in burgers, cheesesteaks and other grilled dishes.  Still, the breakfast possibilities were not a short list, and I was able to chose from pancakes, omelets, and morning sandwiches.  I opted for the french toast, which was a full plate (6 half slices) of vanilla and sugared egg dipped decent bread.  Melted butter and a nice pour of syrup (not maple), and it was ready to eat.  

It was a decent version of one of my favorite breakfasts.  Caramelized enough to enjoy the light crunch along the edges, and thick enough to absorb a lot of the egg and the follow on butter and syrup.  It wasn't the best of breed, but I was not complaining. Tasty and filling. The mugga joe was hot and strong, just as I like it.  At $10 and change for the meal, it was about what I expected from the outlets in the area. 

But, the atmosphere was what really sets the place apart from other diners and cafes.  It is different enough to be refreshing.  Will return for the burgers and revisit the rating, but for now, three and a half stars is about right. Round up to 4.

NOTE: The name, "steakhouse," is a misnomer, as the only steaks available here come on a long role with cheese and onions.

My second visit to Bristol in one week after a few years absence. Mill Street is coming back to life, and the area close to the Delaware River seems to be spearheading the revival. It is great to see a renaissance in this old river city.  It has suffered hard times through some neglectful governments and perhaps not so fatherly town elders. Yet, it is hard to keep a good old ville down when it has natural beauty and a real purpose over the centuries.

So it is with the King George II Inn. Originally built to be close to the ferry to Burlington, New Jersey, the only way across this water course for more that 250 years AFTER the ferry was started, the KGII evolved into a restaurant and subsequently an inn. Sitting in the oldest part of the building, the tavern, it is easy to imagine what it was like to be living and traveling in colonial America.  The various farmers, businessmen, hucksters, cons, grifters, and cutthroats gathered here to do their business, and wait for the ferry to take them to the colony of West Jersey. 

Even today, that historic atmosphere permeates the Inn. Certainly there are ghosts stories aplenty.

I stopped into the Tavern for late lunch, sitting at a small table at the window overlooking the bottom of Mill Street, and the river just beyond.  The server (who was as gracious as an owner) greeted me warmly, took my order, and left me to my mental wandering.  The Pierogies appeared on a long thin white dish, covered in sautéed onions and fresh chives. A dollop of sour cream occupied one corner.  They were lightly fried, potato and cheese. They were pretty good at 6 for $9. I knew I was paying for the privilege of location.  No complaints.

The Tavern itself was excellently preserved and rehabbed to feel very original. All dark woods, heavy oak tables, and mirrored bar.  A perfect place to reenact debates between Patriots and Tories over lagers and locally distilled whiskey.  

It is certainly worth a visit and a meal if you are into American history.  It is not quite Williamsburg, Va., where the entire community is a historic park and everyone is in costume.  Still, with a little imagination it is capable of taking you on quite a trip.

In my search for the best bagel in the Trenton/Hamilton matrix, I stumbled upon Tina's Bagel Factory.  It is attached to Tina's Italian resto; and they no doubt share their pizza oven.  

While I did not expect much, it turned out to be the best bagel I have tried so far in the area.  Not too dense as most of the other purveyors are; Tina does not over knead the dough, leaving air pockets throughout to keep the heart of the bagel light and the skin crunchy. Kudos!

I will be back as time allows to see if I just got lucky or she really knows what she is doing. But, for now, Tina goes to the head of the bagel class.  

Nosh on!

Pho Ha is a utilitarian furnished soup shop in the heart of Philly's Little Ho Chi Minh City on Washington.  The tables and chairs are built for speed, not comfort, but given how fast they turn out a large bowl of Pho and Bun Bo Hue (weekends only), it is understandable that you will not be there very long. 

We came in around six on a Saturday evening, and the place was nearly empty.  We were warmly greeted, directed to a table, and asked for drink preferences within 60 seconds.  After ordering Pho Tai and Bun Bo Hue, we barely had time to start a conversation before the steamy aromatic pots of soup were placed before us.  Don't ask why I went with the large option because I couldn't finish even half of it.  Even the small bowl was big enough to be a goldfish pond. 

The soup was loaded with a variety of meats, veggies and noodles, floating in a richly spiced broth that tasted of secret recipe. Even my protégé, a restaurant owner in her own right, could not identify all the subtle flavors overlapping and melding with each other.  While she might attempt to concoct the Pho, she was at a loss with the Bun. Guess I'll have to return to Pho Ha if I want to be blown away by that mystical brew again, although rumor has it that it can be found in other hidden springs in the area.  

I enjoyed Pho Ha both for it authenticity and its location in the midst of the Asian community that is growing in South Philly.  It is convenient to shop, eat and even massage within a small walking area and dream that I am back in HCMC enjoying the exotic culture that is Vietnam.

Cash only. ATM in house.

GuatePan Latin American Bakery is a local chain of three bakeries serving the greater Guatemalan and Latin American community of Trenton, NJ.  This particular location is the original shop, and it is large enough to have tables for breakfast and lunch.  The long display cases are a visual treat with colorful cakes, cookies, rolls and pastries under bright lights that make each come alive with sweets temptation. 

My Desayuno Tipico Guatepan was a large plate with double fried eggs over tortilla, black beans, platanos, sausage, queso fresa, and salty goat cheese.  A choice of toast or tortilla completed the deal.  Everything was fresh and tasty, with the combination of flavors and textures competing for attention.  It was a fun solid meal to start the day.  Too, the coffee was strong and came in a large insulated carafe that never seemed to empty.  

I left quite full, and unable to consider picking up a few of the beauties behind the counter (speaking of the pastries).  The house was full of families enjoying themselves, as well as regular walk in customers picking up their daily dough.  

It is no wonder that GuatePan has been so successful.  They have a large constituency that appreciates the quality of the products the backroom bakery turns out, as well as the clean and friendly atmosphere created for their families to enjoy a repast together. 

Too bad its sibling stores don't have room for dining, because there is no doubt they would draw like iron to magnets.

If this is the "Old Neshaminy Inn," I really want to see the new one! 

This local tavern is new and modern, with large barroom, long bar, multiple HDTVs, and a better than average menu that will keep people coming back for an inexpensive pint and decent grub. It was refreshing to be able to pay a reasonable price for Angry Orchard apple cider, a personal size Old Trenton square tomato pie, chicken parmesan dinner, bowl of chili, and 10 blazing buffalo wings, and get change for my $50. That doesn't happen every day.

The atmosphere is noisy with high ceiling in the main room that amplifies sound. Upside, you know your conversation is private; downside, you can't always hear what your table mates are saying. The music is a mix of 70's through contemporary rock, which fits my groove well. Service is fine with women who seem to like people and have a sense of humor. Always appreciated. 

The food? Solid bar offerings that can surprise you with it's taste and quality, but may not be consistently so. Big pluses on the chili, tomato pie, and hot wings; a little off on the chicken parmesan dinner. To be clear, the pizza was very good with crunchy crusty edges, tart marzano tomatoes and decent cheese. Not what you get at the new DeLorenzos', but a pleasant alternative. Chili was mildly sweet beneath the heat, and the wings brought tears to my eyes just sitting on the table. The dinner parmesan needed more flavorful sauce, especially with the load of penne it came with. Even dry pepper flakes could not compensate for the lack of spice in the pot. At $20, that was disappointing. 

Next time, we will stick with the sandwiches, pizza and burgers - more traditional barfood - rather than treating Old Neshaminy Inn as an Italian restaurant, which it really isn't (yet?). 

3.5 Stars

This was my first visit to Bonefish Grill. I guess I was always put off by their logo of a fish skeleton. Kinda spooky. But, we were nearby, and it was lunchtime, so for a moment I wasn't drawn to thinking about death when I saw the restaurant on Oxford Valley Road just near the mall. 

The atmosphere and decor was quite nice, with lots of dark wood, large bar and servers wearing white chef coats. We were taken to a booth in the barroom. It was comfortable, with last century rock & roll playing on their sound system. We were brought menus that included both light lunch options and more substantial dinner choices. We went with Fish Tacos (Blackened Cod) and Fish & Chips. 

Both were good, especially the tacos which included mango pieces for sweet juiciness to interact with the spicy salsa. Two were enough. The F&C was also good, but I wished that the outer breaded shell was less oily, as it didn't work as well with the lightness of the fish within. Still tasty, but the inconsistency was palpable. Service was excellent with our friendly white coat attentive and suggestive. 

We agreed that we would certainly give Bonefish another try when the mood for seafood struck us.

Sometimes first impressions are deceiving. So it was with Non Solo Pasta. 

Returning to the Italian shop after a few years, this time for lunch, I had a completely different experience. This time rather than order a pasta bowl that was off menu, I went with their standard melanzon parmesan, which came with choice of soup or salad.  

It was excellent. 

First, the large bowl of escarole soup was steamy and full of flavor, with white beans simmered to softness for added texture and subtle flavor.  Very glad I went with that over a side salad. The eggplant was thin sliced and sautéed in extra virgin olive oil, without breading, and then ladled full of red gravy over the top.  It was tender, light and delicious.  So much better than the breaded/fried variety that adds more calories than taste. Easily cut with a fork.  The side of spaghetti was generous, but truly unnecessary in light of the quality of the star attraction. I left most of that behind. 

My companion selected the caprese salad and the Caesar. The red and yellow tomatoes were ripe and mildly tart to offset the fresh buffalo mozzarella, which was soft and semi-sweet. Very well done and about the best I've sampled of this simple dish. 

Everything was well presented and a delight to indulge. After my earlier visit, the quality of this meal took me by very pleasant surprise.  I will return sooner next time. 

Only downside is the lack of WiFi in the house, given how poor reception is in this part of Morrisville. Made it impossible to check in or put photos directly through Yelp. Still, managed to deal with that upon returning to the office.

Located in a tightly designed old commercial strip on Bustleton Avenue in the far Northeast, Philadelphia, Little Istanbul is a small Turkish restaurant with pleasant atmosphere, good service, and a fairly broad menu of Mediterranean and Ottoman style cuisine. With about a dozen tables, it pays to know what you want to order coming in because the room turns over quickly. This part of the city has a strong East European, Silk Road community, and this place fits right in.

We ordered Red Lentil Soup, Sauced Eggplant, Ground Beef/Lamb Pide and the Baked Salmon dinner. Based on our experience we would stick with the gyros and appetizers next visit, and shy away from the more elaborate dinners and Pide. Here's why:

The soup and eggplant were excellent, with fresh flavor, plenty of spice and wonderful bread and pita to help it down the gullet. The lentil soup was creamy and steaming hot, and more yellow than red. Apparently, it had a chicken broth base, which surprised my companion. The eggplant came in a tomato and olive oil base, and was served cold. Loved it. 

However, the salmon, while a thick steak, was delivered past its peak from the oven. It was a little dry and the sauce it came in was not able to revive it. Otherwise, the taste was okay, but it could have been so much more. The Pide is very similar to a dish found in Georgian bakeries. The shape of a boat, it is basically thin dough with cheese and ground beef and lamb spread thinly across parts of the dish, much like pizza in taste, but with more interesting crust. It would have been great with more meat topping, but as it was it was a simple pleasure. 

The lamb and chicken gyros we saw served nearby looked like absolute winners, and we would definitely try them next time. 

Too, enjoyed sitting across the dining room from the large photo mural of the Bosporus waterway that transects the city of Istanbul (not Constantinople), and separates eastern Europe from western Asia. A fantastic old fortress city now part of a modern Turkey.

3.5 STARS

This IHOP on Roosevelt Blvd in the Great Northeast, is an older version of this historic franchise. There are only two narrow rows of double and quad booths with open kitchen in the middle where the crash and drum of the cooks and server shouted orders offer a momentary throwback to an earlier time when a family trip to the local pancake house was a very special occasion. 

I guess those memories led me there this morning, when I suddenly saw it in front of me as I drove south down the Boulevard. The parking lot is likewise a small footprint, but I found the last available in the row. The greeter sat me at a quad and brought me menu and thermos pitcher of Java. Thanks for the extra leg room, my dear. Your tip just rose a few bucks. 

I ordered the Original French Toast Combo (2 slices w powdered sugar, 2 Scrambled Eggs, Home Fries and 2 Sausage Links). No. I didn't finish all of it, but I was pleasantly surprised how good each element was; especially the eggs, potatoes and coffee. The Frenchie was okay, but really need a touch of vanilla and cinnamon to bring up the flavor profile. Caramelization of the edges would have brought a nice crisp to the texture. 

Still, all in all, it was a very satisfying meal that allowed a short dalliance in my childhood along with room to stretch my legs.

This may be the largest Starbucks I have seen east of Ohio! 

At least 5,000 square feet, it feels like a small theater, more than a cafe. Plenty a seating with tables, chairs and more relaxed furniture in the corner. Easily 15 foot ceiling which does impact the acoustics, but almost feels like being outside. A 50 foot wall long black and white panel that pulls the room together. 

Yet, when I was there at 4:30 on a recent afternoon, the operation was being run by only 3 baristas, including drive through service. Impressive that they managed to sweep and clean up the place during their shifts. 

Menu was standard for the Green Mermaid, although the display case was somewhat depleted given the time of day. I snared the final slice of lemon pound cake - my endulgance for the week. It was as tart and sweet as always. 

While still not a true fan of Starbucks, this place isn't bad.

We stopped by Nina's Waffles & Ice Cream as we cruised Doylestown after the March for Science. It was a first visit, and the instant impression was one of an old time, wood floor, bright walled, musical, ice cream parlor.  A small space for a popular destination, the room had less than a half dozen tables to sit and enjoy their interesting take on hot waffles and cold creams. The high glass refrigeration unit held about a dozen and a half flavors, with the industrial waffle iron right next to it.  As we took it all in, one of the women behind the counter let us know we could sample any of their creamies with tiny spoons.  We demurred, and went directly to ordering a waffle with two scoops of their offerings, Berry Berry and Banana Walnut.  

It was served in a heavy weight paper boat (like for fried chicken and fries), with plastic utensils, including a knife for cutting the underlying thick waffle.  The cost of $10+ for what seemed to be two large scoops of ice cream and a thick waffle, took me aback for a second, but I decided to consume this dessert before deciding if it was overpriced.  

Nina makes her own ice cream in her store in New Hope, Pa.  It is high quality, creamy, and invested in local sourced ingredients (where available), and subtle flavors that demand your attention for full enjoyment.  The Berry Berry was very good, and the Banana Walnut was a pleasant surprise in not having that unpleasant banana extract taste, but a gentle real ripe Chiquita lick.  Big chunky walnuts, too.  Nina knows from ice cream.  

The waffle did require knife to cut into bite size pieces, and possessed a heavy texture that held up well to the melting above.  Yet, in the overall scheme of things, the ice cream was far superior to the doughy base.  The interplay between the solid and the liquid was pleasing for a moment, with the waffle offering a slight saltiness that magnified the sweetness topside. Still, if pressed to save a few calories, I would opt for all ice cream, and take a pass on the iron cakes. 

A few more tables within, and some benches without, would help make Nina's into a true ice cream hangout, particularly on cooler or rainy days, when walking around town with an ice cream cone is not the funnest thing to do.  Hard to lick and hold an umbrella. 

Still, if ice cream is your thing, Nina's has something waiting for you that will definitely make you smile. Maybe a tad overpriced the way I ordered it, but next time I would skip the waffle and go straight to the cool delicious prize.

Ristorante Denicola has been around for more than a decade, but I just found out about it last week. Two Yelp friends introduced me to this fine Italian house when we met for dinner a few nights ago, and but for their detailing its location in the Mallard Creek Shopping Center I would never have seen it.  Intentionally or not, it is a well kept (hidden) secret.  

The front door is inconspicuous, like a secondary entrance near green/white awnings that feel like the porch in the back of a home.  Walking in, it is surprisingly large with rough hewn wood horizontal panels, dark tones, carpet, and nicely spaced tables. We sat is the corner in an otherwise empty dining room.  

Our server was well known to my friends, and she took very good care of us all night.  This family business' signature style is to deliver much more than expected in the form of non-ordered extra dishes that are a surprising addition to the meal.  For us, they dropped off Grilled Veggie Antipasto, Tomato Bisque, Homemade Sausage Pizza, Chicken Breast Joey (a piccata/marsala feel)  and Cannoli, on top of our main courses.  All this was a meal unto itself.  When they then deliver a large plate of Penne A'glio Olio with Sautéed heavily Garliced Spinach, the result was taking most of it home.  I'm not complaining, but it again brought to the forefront my discomfort with intentional excess in a world full of hunger.  

Here's the ironic part of the experience - my pasta was very good; al dente with well browned Garlic Chips mixed into the Spinach and Red Pepper dusted Penne.  It was the best of my samplings, but the one I ate the least of because I was already full from everything that came surrounding it.  The gratis accompaniments were also good, but a step down from the main course.  The Antipasto had fresh cut tomato, onion and cilantro on top of the Grilled Zucchini and Eggplant.  The "bruschetta" was cold while the nicely grill-ribbed large veggies were warm.  It was an inconsistency that detracted from the cohesion of the dish.  The Homemade Sausage was excellent and plentiful, but the tomato sauce was thin and runny.  The Tomato Bisque had a pleasant creamy texture and taste, but was a little lumpy. The Chicken Joey was fine, but I was beginning to feel overwhelmed and mildly compelled to take a share. The Cannoli were perfect. 

The overall effect was that each additional offering both added and detracted from the meal.  I don't think that was the intention in the kitchen, but that was how it felt.  The generosity of the house also opened the door to mild disappointment.  

After this review my friends may regret inviting me, and I am sorry for that.  I will definitely return and ask for a more limited approach to my next meal.  I would rather be totally impressed with the food I desire, and have fewer filling distractions. 

Less is More.

The sign on the front door points to the left where the entry of its sibling House of Pho is located. That tip alone alerts you to the fact that Taiko Bistro and its neighbor are closely related.  In fact, they are family; owned by the same people, and put in place after the success of House of Pho led to expansion to cover the bubble tea explosion around the country. They share a kitchen, while House handles traditional Vietnamese fare and Taiko addresses the taste for Asian snacks and tapioca ball drinks. 

Following directions, I walked into the elder to order Roast Pork Banh Mi, Ribeye Pho and a Mango Smoothie "to go." I returned to my car for the suggested 20 minute wait, as the business wasn't really set up for in house dining. 

Ten minutes later, the manager/owner/cashier was coming over to my vehicle with a nearly wrapped package. I opened my door to accept the bag and thank her for going the extra mile to find me when everything was ready, rather than waiting for me to re-enter ten minutes later. 

That kind of courtesy is memorable. 

The Banh Mi was excellent. Tasty load of thin sliced roast pork with pleasant hoisin flavor, daikon, carrot, cilantro in a fresh demi baguette. Liked it a lot. I assembled the Pho in a large bowl while it was still warm, but with the large next of noodles, generous beef and desire to add copious sprouts and Thai basil, I chose to microwave the broth to better cook everything else and bring the dish back to optimum. It was still good; the taste was there, but there was no doubt it had lost something in transportation. 

The Mango Smoothie was more a slurpie, with too much freeze and little smooth. It was clearly made from a mix without a hint of fruit pulp. Disappointing. Maybe bubble tea was the way to go. 

Lesson learned. Banh Mi travels well, and Pho can be resurrected by focuses reheating at home, but a poorly conceived smoothie is impossible to revive. 

3.5 STARS

This is a new drive thru Starbucks on RT. 541 (Burlington-Mt. Holly Road), is one of their smaller designs, yet with ample comfortable seating for those who prefer to sip in or work, and a tight bar area with two cashiers and snack offerings. The staff is skilled and friendly, and keep the joint humming and clean. 

I stopped in after court in Mt. Holly, in need of a caffeine jolt to keep me sharp through the rest of a dreary Thursday. My grande low fat latte did the trick as I watched the laptops burying their noses in daily labor. 

Wish I liked nitro cold brew, because that was very popular with the peeps there. There must be something to it, but I just don't like the bitterness. 

Regardless, in the land of Dunkin it is nice to have an upgrade available.

I don't know who John Lucas is, nor how he learned to cook Italian food, but his small casa Italiana has it going on in the cheffing department. Bailey's Center now has a bona fide first rate pizza joint on the premises.

We visited for the first time Friday night. The dining room is small (3 booths, 6 tables), so the reservation made sense. Our booth had been set aside and prepped for our arrival. The house is cozy, and feels a lot more comfortable than it appeared from the outside. The menu is lengthy, with choices from pizza to full dinners and everything in between. 

We began with bowls of pasta fagiole soup that arrived just after a basket of hot bread knots.  Both were excellent. The soup was full of short pasta tubes and white beans in a smooth veggie stock. The bread was out of the oven reheat, yet crisp on the outside and tender soft within. It was mildly salty with great texture. Perfect for dipping in the soup and the platter sauces that followed when unwound and pulled apart. Entrees were chicken francaise and veal marsala, both over penne aglio olio. 

The francaise was wonderful. Egg dipped, pan sauteed in lemon and white wine. Delicious!  Three medallions turned golden brown and tender enough to be 
cut by my fork. The penne beneath was also very good with the melding of the juices. Lemon and garlic are a great combo. The only disappointment was the veal. It was too thickly cut, not tenderized, and a little tough to chew. Too, the marsala sauce was off, more like the wine was turning to vinegar, making for a sourness that was not appealing. 

Service was friendly and accommodating. 

Overall, we were very satisfied with our experience at John Lucas. Far better than expected. Still, it wasn't perfect because of the marsala issue. Definitely worth a try. 

4 Stars.

I must have gotten lucky judging by all the naysayers' reviews of this Mickey D's on Cottman Avenue at Roosevelt Blvd., in N.E. Philly. But, rather than being disappointed by its performance, we were actually pleasantly surprised by how good their food and service were. 

We were in a rush to return home after a large shopping excursion to the Asian supermarket nearby, and opted for rapid food from the only drive through in sight. We ordered a quarter pounder w cheese, chicken nuggets, fries and drink, took possession within minutes, and continued our drive home to Bucks County. 

We immediately noticed the heat coming off the fries In the open top paper sack. First sampling was of perfectly done Frenchies - hot, crisp and addicting. The burger was also just off the steel and settling nicely onto the bun. It reached my mouth in optimal condition, with even the onions soft and translucent and the pickle stuck to the cheese so it couldn't fall out. It was like the dream burger from the adverts, except this baby was for real. 

Once in a lifetime! 

Naturally, it wasn't all ideal, as the nuggets had a processed food texture. I knew I was awake. Still, this was as close to amazing as McDonalds ever gets, and the moment required recognition. 

Now that we know it can be done, why should anyone settle for any less?

Last Christmas Eve when General Washington crossed the Delaware River and marched on Trenton overnight to surprise the Hessian mercenaries in their barracks, he stopped in Patriot's Crossing for a cold one with his officers after the successful encounter. A very cold night, he chose to stay inside at the bar after the long ride on horseback. 

While there he was greeted by fellow rebels and militiamen celebrating their victory.  Service was exceptional at the bar, with ample choices on tap or bottles. He particularly liked the Victory Summer Ale brewed down in Philadelphia, although the Dogfish Head dark was the favorite of most of his officers. Hungry, he ordered a southwest cheeseburger, loaded with onion, jalapeno chips and spicy aioli mayo smeared on the textured bun.  His charge de camp ordered the mushroom swiss burger. Both came with fries or onion rings. The General always demanded "Liberty Fries," as the French had not yet done enough as allies to warrant naming rights to those potatoes. 

Their burgers were quite good. The beef recently slaughtered and ground by a local farmer, with no opportunity for freezing unless left out in the cold. Although camped along the Pennsylvania side of the river, this Jersey tavern had been off limits to all but the long boatmen who traversed the treacherous currents to trade in farm goods and military rumors. George Washington knew this, and counted on intelligence from these patriots to keep him informed about what they heard about enemy movement. This watering hole was an excellent place to carefully exchange information because although there were few Red Coats brave enough to be out of their encampments at night, there were still loyalists like Abraham Doan around and about, who would happily steal your horse and sell it to the British or trade in military secrets. In other words, it was a den of thieves and spies who bargained in hidden code and dastardly deeds for the right price. Perfect for the surreptitious exchange of information when the fate of the war remained unknown.

The crowd has not changed much since the day the General stopped in to have a round with his men.  The easy success in Trenton gave him the idea and the courage to attack again near Princeton the next day, to keep the Reds off balance and in retreat. 

Little did anyone know that they were witnessing an important turning point of the Revolution, when the dream of freedom became the possibility of true independence. 

Legend has it that General George stops in every Christmas Eve to carry on the tradition. The tavern owner keeps his barstool empty awaiting his arrival. A pewter pint of brown ale sits on the bar near that spot waiting for the anniversary party to begin.

Well, not exactly like Trenton Tomato Pie, but close enough to use the sacred name of the best pizzas in the Universe (Pardon me, Brooklyn). 

These guys make excellent chunky red sauce for their red over white creations. Truth is, they may pour it on a bit on the heavy side, so that the thicker crust becomes moist from the tomato slurry. Makes for a base that can't support the topside, unlike the Trenton pie that uses both thinner crust and less nightshade, yet manages to hold its point beginning to end. Despite this engineering, the taste was superlative. The added mushrooms provided subtle flavor and more texture. So, I am not complaining at all; just pointing out the cultural difference. Both ways work, it just depends which you prefer. 

The chicken parmesan sandwich was also quite good, with enough chicken tenders, great sauce and melted mozzarella for a pleasing full mouth bite. The weak link was the torpedo roll, which lacked crispness and sourdough flavor to enhance the finished mix. 

There was kitchen artistry in both pie and sub, and a better baker would make the difference in reaching my fifth star.

Note to Alex - Thanks for the excellent comment to the review. I still have family on Anderson Street, and totally appreciate what Trenton brings to the (pizza) table. While all the Italian kitchens may have moved to the burbs, the heart remains in Chambersburg (perhaps at Italian People's Bakery on Butler).

Quintessential working person's dive bar, with a laid back atmosphere, decent kitchen, and friendly barkeeps.  

Fair beer selection on tap, but not a craft beer haven. A great place for a Burger or Cheesesteak, especially on the days that they are a special low price. Open for breakfast for the early birds.  See their website for updates and events.  

The outdoor patio is a great addition.  Enough TV screens to satisfy the most diverse taste in entertainment.  Last night, World Cup, Yankees, and Mexican soap opera played their unique games.  If you prefer live entertainment, it is available certain nights with local bands, or a customer acting out his comedic fantasy.  I enjoyed a guy in a Rod Stewart wig hitting on the lovely bartender with one pick up line after another, until we were all listening and shouting suggestions.  It was a kick! The dude was funny. 

Puss N Boots. Definitely a great place for a hot plate, a cold brew, and a hearty laugh; all at great prices.

Sputino's has a great location in The Marketplace in Doylestown, but it is divided between it's kitchen up front and the dining room further back in this attractive indoor mall. There are a few stools right at the entrance to watch the maestros at work on their 90 second Napolitan pizzas, but a lot more room in back. 

After standing in the misting rain during the March for Science at the old courthouse, we had quite an appetite, and wanted to give our business to a local shop in appreciation for the town being so inviting to our people. We weren't the only ones with this idea. 

We ordered a pepperoni pie and two Sanpelligrinos - Limonata and Blood Orange to quench our thirsts.  The pie came out in about 7 minutes, looking hot and steaming. These Nappis are always small, and just enough for a snack for two. The edges were scorched with burnt dough and the thin 'ronis sweating out their oil.  

The thing about this type of tomato pie is that because it is super thin and baked so fast, it also cools quickly causing condensation and a damp crust with minutes. It is imperative to eat it quickly to maximize the enjoyment. Few of us like damp, limp pizza, which these become by the time you get it home. So, eat it while it burns your palate to get the most flavor.  Too, unlike the traditional pizza, these Nappis are all about the crusty dough, not the toppings.  The quality of the undercarriage is what matters most.  So, a great pie maker will use the freshest flour and water, and add the right spices to make the crust taste dramatically superior to the other forms of this art.  The toppings are there to influence the taste of the dough, but not dominate it. 

Sputino understands this concept and produces a very good crusty dough that hardens and blisters in 90 seconds in the wood burning hive oven.  It is not the best I have ever tried, but it is very solidly delicious.  If you are curious about other versions of these pies, come to Newtown and visit Acqua e Farina, another Napolitan house. There, for about twice the price you will experience a bit more taste in a new Italian stone and stucco villa. The Vault in Bordentown, NJ, also turns out a nice pie in a converted bank. 

After trying these and more, I find them a nice alternative to my first love, Jersey Tomato Pie. Always good to have a change of pace comfort food close at hand.

This is a tough spot to survive for a pizza shop due to its awkward location at the intersection of Buck and Holland Roads. Too many odd angles to negotiate unless your heading south on Holland. Still, it is worth your patience and driving skills to go to Giovanni's if you want a hot lunch or dinner to bring home. 

I picked up a Sweet Italian Sausage Sandwich with sauteed onions and green peppers (sauce on the side) today. I called ahead and when I arrived 15 minutes later it was being kept hot on top of the pizza oven, wrapped and ready. It was a jumbo sammy, jammed with enough for at least two people, it's contents cut into bite size pieces of sausage and smaller virginized pepper & onion. The roll was a little soft due to being housed in one sided aluminum paper which trapped all the moisture inside, but even so it was an enjoyable lunch experience. 

I managed to consume half before my warning lights alerted me to reaching overfull capacity. Repackaged the rest for home delivery. 

Overall, a very good submarine @ just under $10 for a zoftig belly buster.

Fairless Hills is a little beyond my normal range for breakfast, but the reviews for Café Ferraro raised my curiosity, and on this morning without a 9 o'clock call I decided to check it out. 

Good move, Mr. S.!

The Café is in another of those endless aging shopping strips that line Oxford Valley Road, but Ferraro's stood out from the rest of the concrete with a bright hand lettered sign on their front window artfully proclaiming its presence.  I walked in and saw the counter to the right with about 9 spinners, and several tables to the left.  The space seemed well occupied for 8:00 am, but what was obvious was the amount of conversation going on.  Everyone was engaged, not just with their own table, but with the rest of the house.  This was a very friendly joint.  

I sat at an empty stood next to a woman who I had never met.  My coffee arrived before I could ask for it. The server took my order of French Toast and Country Sausage and immediately suggested the morning special which included two Eggs and Coffee for less than I would pay for my spoken desires.  I always appreciate getting more and paying less.  I was hooked.  

Turned out that the French Toast was excellent, with a touch of Vanilla in the mix and nicely caramelized edges. The Sausage Patty was exceptionally fresh and tasty without being greasy.  The Scrambled needed a touch of Louisiana Hot Sauce to make it sing, but the well used bottle was quickly brought to me when I asked if it was available.  

I had a long chat with my stoolmate and learned about her family, work, and plans for life.  She told me: "This place is like family.  Everyone knows your stuff and wants to help, if needed."  There is even a doctor who shows up almost daily and hangs his shingle while eating breakfast.  That's amazing!  No extra charge for a diagnosis with your pancakes. 

Café Ferraro is a great little place.  If it was closer to home, it would quickly join my breakfast rotation, but given geographic realities, it will remain a treat for those rare mornings when I don't have to be standing in front of a judge at 9.

FresCafe Food Company is a new Lahaska breakfast/brunch/lunch cottage in the Earl's Restaurant complex. It is in Nancy's old place, but with fresh coat of paint to bring out the country shine. It is a little hard to find, but if you use Earl's as a guide you will find it by parking there and walking into the courtyard. First you will see the blue umbrella outdoor seating, with the main doors to FresCafe just beyond. 

Like most of Lahaska, it is an attractive countrified touristy house made to appear 18th Century village, with plenty of large trees, exposed beams, period artistry and wagonloads of charm. It is well done, and somewhat representative of the history of the area. Big windows and low ceilings with views of brick and aged board contributing to the comfortable atmosphere. Coming midweek avoids the crowds and allows for a leisurely morning cuppa joe and traditional repast. Service was attentive and friendly, but left me alone except to ask if I wanted more coffee or needed anything. Just the way I wanted it.

The Brioche French Toast was fine, topped with sliced straw and blueberries. A bit more vanilla extract in the egg mix would have enhanced the flavor, and an option for real maple syrup would have taken the dish to another level altogether. For a farm to table kind of place that would have been a strong move. Still, the coffee was decent and the overall experience quite positive. 

There is a premium paid at all Lahaska establishments and FresCafe is no different. Still, the quality/price proposition is not out of line with the rest of town, and if you like these type of destinations, you will be pleased with this one.

Those who know and love tomato pie are aware that Trenton, NJ, has some of the best around. So, when a tiny take out shop in Penndel, PA, calls itself, "Trenton Tomato Pies" it has a lot to live up to. It has to be damn good to justify its name. Yet, because the pie can't be immediately consumed, it has an inherent disadvantage to those restaurants that allow you to eat it right out of the oven when the molten disk is nearest perfection and at its most dangerous. 

So, I knew it was a challenge for these folks to succeed. I admired their courage and willingness to make the effort. I decided to stop in without advanced ordering to avoid any possibility the pie and sandwiches would be sitting around any longer than necessary for me to grab everything and get home as quickly as possible. 

I ordered a small Tomato Pie, Cheesesteak w Hot Peppers and Hot/Sweet Sausage, Pepper & Onion, w Hot Pickled Pepper sandwiches. I waited in my car about 25 minutes until everything was done, and drove the 15 minutes home. In the car I opened the pizza box to let steam escape to preserve crispness, and partially unwrapped the  cheesesteak for the same reason. The aroma was terrific and set off my glands' anticipatory reaction. 

Squirt...!!!

How was everything?  Glad you asked. 

Well, despite my best effort to protect the crunch, the pie had lost some of its bite and much of its heat. It was still good, but I had to use my imagination as to how much better it would have been if eaten sooner. The thin crust had good flavor, the under layer of mozzarella was light and not overpowering, and the crushed tomato top spread across its body was mildly sweet and acidic. These guys knew the secret recipe, just too bad they didn't have an adjoining dining room. 

The Cheesesteak was decent, but not upper echelon, and the Mixed Sausage Pepper & Onion was actually pretty good, and more tasty than the steak. They seemed to be made from different rolls, with the later superior to the former in texture and taste. Can't explain that. 

Bottom line - Trenton Tomato Pies is a very good choice for your Italian menu, depending in large part on the travel distance until consumption, or your ability to reheat in your oven prior to first chomp. I suspect they are waiting for the vape shop next door to close so they can expand and have the dining space they so sorely need to jump up in rank and play with the tomato pie big boys.

When friends called unexpectedly and told me they were at Karla's for dinner and drinks, and invited me to join them, it was very easy to drop what I was doing and make the 20 minute drive from Newtown to New Hope.  I hadn't seen one of my old friends for some time, and Karla's has been a very nice institution in New Hope for more than a decade. 

Parking is always an issue in this river town, but in winter it becomes possible to find a spot off Main Street and a reasonable (and healthy) walk to whatever destination you have in mind.  It was a cold Friday night, and while the streets were empty of most pedestrians, Karla's was packed with customers in each of their historic and well appointed rooms on its multi-leveled layout.  I found my friends sitting in a far corner at a deuce, and the staff was kind enough to find an extra chair, fit me in, and provide me with a menu, although my friends were far along in their meals.  Even the neighboring diners were accommodating to my squeezing in next to them, and we all were able to enjoy the post-Christmas spirits.  

I ordered a Lemon Drop Martini and the Mahi Mahi Sliders - a light repast. Five minutes later the drink arrived, properly mixed and very refreshing.  Normally, I would take a pre-sip photo for Yelp, but on this night I didn't feel like waiting for the phone cam.  I took a long sip, and then another. Very nice.  

The sliders arrived about 10 minutes later.  Three mini-burger bun sized sandwiches, with a nice chunk of Mahi, Lettuce, Red Onion shavings, and slightly spiced orange sauce, each complemented with a mini pickle lanced by a long wooden pick.  They were delicious.  Each component added subtly to the others.  The fish was fresh, and everything hung together and did not fall apart even after picking each up and holding it as I ate due to my distance from the table.  Thoroughly enjoyed them. My friends took bites and agreed.  

Karla's is a place where the architecture, history, and ambiance of the space invites you to spend a long time savoring the experience.  Looking around it was obvious that everyone was having a good time with mostly larger groups of diners, and no one really wanted to leave.  Best of all, no one felt rushed.  

Just a wonderful winter night.

Needed a fast bite between afternoon and evening meetings and decided to hit up the McDonald's on Horizon Boulevard, Bensalem, PA. I seem to prefer Mickey D's recently when in this "no time to sit and eat" mode. Starting with their surprisingly tasty crisp fries, to their less compelling, but still decent Quarter Pounders, this oldest of national burger franchises has really upped its game in the last few years.

I enjoyed my repast, even while slumming in the car as I drove to the next destination. Hot taters, oniony beef pucks, soft bun and cold chill drink, we're just about what I wanted and needed. 

Not that I want this to become a habit (bad one), but I have to admit I felt a childlike sense of happy abandon in chowing down on this almost forbidden micro pleasure.

Yummy Asian (no relation to Yummy Sushi) is a surprisingly decent Chinese restaurant.  Their menu has a large Japanese Roll offering, but little actual sushi, nor Thai cuisine.  If you stick with the Chinese dishes, you should be quite satisfied.  

We came in for a Friday dinner.  The house was nicely appointed.  The service was attentive.  We ordered the Walnut Shrimp, Beef & Chicken Hunan and a Dragon Roll.  The shrimp dish consisted of 8 or 9 Jumbos, Tempura breaded, with a sweet mayo sauce covering the entire pile of crustaceans.  It wasn't the best I ever had, but was still quite enjoyable.  

The Hunan style beef and chicken was also well done.  This approach uses less straight ahead red chilis, and substitutes a mix of chili and black beans. It retains a lot of heat, but not the fire breathing kind.  The meat was tender and did not seem to have been frozen.  

The Dragon Roll was only okay.  The small amount of fish within the construct of rice, avo, seaweed, etc., was not the freshest.  The ginger was colored orange, rather than the natural white, and the wasabi was likewise artificially dyed green.  Clearly, the sushi guy had gone to Sushi College and finished the basic course in slicing and rolling, but was not working with top ingredients.  

My friends enjoyed the chance to speak with management in Mandarin, and that seemed reciprocal.  Probably don't get many organically grown Chinese stopping in.

The Vault is housed inside an old bank building that has been renovated except for the remaining 'vault' complete with heavy duty safe door.  The high ceilings and windows easily remind of the days when banks testified to their success by using their depositors money to build grand edifices to their capitalist acumen.  These days our financial institutions are more often viewed with distain and mistrust, resulting in a more modest approach to their architecture, in which they all fundamentally look like fast food restaurants without the large menus in the drive thru.

Fortunately, the pizza created inside this now comfortable house is anything but what you find in most pie shops in the area.  This is a different animal.  Neapolitan style, meaning the focus is on wood burning ovens that reach over 900 degrees Fahrenheit, that completely bake and sear the dough inside of 90 seconds.  I stood and watched my Pie being made and then placed in the oven.  The crust turned brown and then scorched before my eyes.  

The upside of this is incredibly fresh crust that becomes an accompaniment to the toppings (Margharita), rather than the firm platform for them to rest upon.  The experience is more like eating a hot pita dipped in spicy tomato sauce, mozza cheese, and basil leaf.  It sort of turns the meal on its head, but once I understood what was going on, I really enjoyed this variant approach to pizza.  

The downside (such as it is) is only that if you have a firm belief that pizza should only be made one way-with a firm tasty crust upon which are placed fine ingredients to be eaten as one entity-you may be disappointed that The Vault's ingenuity takes tomato pie in a different direction.  You can actually tear off part of the crust and dip it into the toppings on the pie as you would salsa & chips. 

I'm not suggesting that Napolitan Pie can replace that better known approach to pizza making.  It just that when you feel like something just as good but a little different, The Vault is waiting for you.

"....with a name like Smucker's...

Couldn't resist, but the slogan does hold true.  If their food isn't good, they will hear about it in a bad way.  

Fortunately, most of the salads and side dishes found in the display are very good.  The service is friendly and prompt, and you can even taste a sample of anything that interests you.  My favorites are the Baked Lima Beans, Chicken Salad, and Rice Pudding; all of which I can eat in one meal either in the tiny sitdown areas, or as take home.  Also, the jarred goods on the right hand side of the shop are worth a look for some esoteric Pennsylvania Dutch/Amish treats.  Their Corn Relish is great! 

Still only open Thursday through Saturday, it is best to get there early for the freshest selection.  Eat it quickly to enjoy its peak flavors.

When I leased a storage unit at this Public Storage about 9 years ago, it was with the intention that I would only have it for a short time, and then be done with it.  Such are the empty intentions of this good man. 

I finally ended my relationship with these folks yesterday.  What had been a reasonable $80 dollar a month rental had become more than $230 a month, and was taking a bite out of my budget.  No one to blame but me, yet there is a lesson to be learned about procrastination and the cost of delay.  I learned it! 

The office people were always great to deal with.  They even suggested ways to reduce costs.  In fact, it was their positive attitude that finally woke me up to the need to be done with their services. 

This operation demonstrates that there is a business available for any need.  Not so in every country, but in the USA, if you need a place to hold a generation of furniture you will likely never use, but to which you have an emotional attachment, free enterprise will provide you with the means to accomplish that end.  

All we need now is another business to wake us up and remind us to be rid of useless junk.  Oh, wait...That business already exists, too.  1.800. GOT JUNK. 

God bless America!

King Market is a traditional green grocer, the same as can be found on almost every street in every city and village in China and around the rest of Asia. Everything is fresh, well presented, and out on the sidewalk where the natural light lets you see exactly what you are buying.  It is also a great marketing tool to make you walk past the display on 10th Street.  It is impossible not to slow down or stop the take a closer look at some unusual veggies and fruit not seen routinely in the larger supermarkets outside of Asian neighborhoods.

Be it baby bok choy or the more exotic Fire Dragon Fruit, you are going to find something you are curious about and want to try.  Those lucky enough to have a long term experience with such wonderful healthy choices still appreciate the ability to secure their cultural comfort foods in such an authentic locale.   

Inside are found what doesn't fit on the sidewalk, as well as packaged goods, food staples, and refrigeration units with things that require it.  The two aisles are narrow, with boxes under the display shelves and in the corners, making passage a bit of a challenge, but that is part of the fun. 

If you are coming to Chinatown for a meal consider a stop at King Market for fresh produce, rice, home brewed soy sauce, vinegar, and a few sweets that you will not find at your local Giant or Super Fresh. 

You will be glad you thought of it.

I work about half a mile from Ivy Tavern on South Broad Street in Hamilton.  It has been anchoring this area for a very long time. I remember hanging out here in the 80's when I was bartending downtown and had a night off.  They always had live bands, cheap drinks, and hot skirted bar mistresses.  Unbeatable combination. 

Then, I moved on and didn't return until last week.  30-odd years and it still looked exactly the same!  Still pumping the standard label suds, and baking a very good bar pie.  The crowd seemed older than I remembered, but then again, so was I.  Those guys cemented to the barstools were likely the same as had been the young dudes the last time I was there. Funny how we find our place in the world. 

Anyway, I was catching a late lunch and had less than an hour to shut the growl in the pit of my stomach, and get back for the next interview.  The servers were still muy attractiva, so I took a spinner at the end of the bar, ordered a pie and Redd's, while chatting up my collegial barkeep.  The pie arrived about 10 minutes later, cheese a bubbling, and the aroma of ripe tomato, garlic and sausage steaming into my face.  Tears came to my eyes.  Some things are just timeless.   

The Bar Pie is an interesting creation.  Larger than the "personal size pizza," often found in the Nuevo-rias of the world, but smaller than the usual "small pie."  This is a "tweener,"- big enough for two for a late night comfort food raid, but also small enough for a hungry person to consume solo.  It is about 3 regular slices from a large pie.  This one was very good.  Scorched bottom from the superhot oven, and almost molten topping when it arrived.  It cooled slowly, and while the first sliced required fork and knife to handle, the last couple of slices could be handled manually without insulated gloves.  It was crunchy, feisty, and delicious.  Plenty of Sweet Italian Sausage to sate the savage beast.  

While perhaps, a step down from its brothers at JoJo's Tavern, Ivy still bakes a very good bar pie. Well worth the trip from a wider radius.  Knowing that it is so close at hand, and offering good grub, good prices, and good reveries, makes it a priceless and prized stop on the Trenton Pizza Train.

A certain political party in Bucks County had its annual Jefferson Dinner at Pen Ryn Mansion last week.  

The entire locale is incredibly pretty for Bensalem, Pa., but the Delaware River still has its charm, and the building and landscaping there are very nice.  There is plenty of parking and if you have time you can stroll down to the banks of the river and watch the dusk settle in and the lights of Burlington, NJ come up across the river.    

The dining facility is ornate with heavy curtains and chandeliers, but although dated, it does give off an air of historical pretense.  If there is an issue it is with the HVAC.  On this relatively warm October night, the bar area was downright hot, and the large banquet room only a little more comfortable.  Of course, all the hot air from the podium may have had something to do with that.  

Pen Ryn would be a nice place for a traditional wedding or other large format celebration.  This is my third of fourth visit, and it is always an attractive, if not completely comfortable place to spend the evening with a few hundred of my closest friends.

The South Street Bridge literally connects two parts of my life - my law school days in West Philly, and my early professional life living at 26th and Delancy. The distance from 48th and Baltimore and my first home purchase may have been less than a mile distance, but the existential shift was immeasurable.  Regardless of on which side of the river I resided, the South Street Bridge stood as the connection between past and present, student and worker, freebird and taxpayer,  dreamer and doer. 

So, when I return to the area for any reason, I feel compelled to reflect upon the passages in my life.  I drive by the old townhouse in Center City and consider my great fortune in being able to buy a home across the street from a warehouse and brownfield that soon became a beautiful park.  I cruise into West Philly to see what's new on campus on my way to the outer reaches of Balto Ave., and see how much better everything is now.  Even the Bridge itself has been renovated, and is no longer the rusty derelict I walked across so many times.  Like many things in life, its better days are now.  Hopefully, that is an indication of what lies ahead for all of us.  

There are times when the span may have saved my life after leaving a great concert at Irvine Auditorium, and running into some folks who did not take kindly to the company I kept.  There were other times that it offered warm greetings to a returning prodigal son after too long away from the cozy confines of my piece of West Philly. And, yes, there were times it felt like a prison gate or pirate ship plank I had to walk while suffering the anxieties of final exams, or broken hearts. 

I have said elsewhere that bridges hold a special significance for me. The South Street Bridge is one of the inner sanctum of spans between one life and another that enables me to feel life intensely as a continual passage on the roads (and bridges) of life.

Strong first impression of East Sushi.  

Located in the shopping center at the corner of Scotch Road and Parkway in Ewing, that also houses Five Guys, and immediately next to Villa Rosa, East Sushi was a surprise find for me.  I had driven down this way many times and never seen it.  Very glad I finally did with Yelp help.   

The space is attractive with hushed lighting, dark tones, the sushi bar to the left rear, and booths and tables along both walls.  A half wall divides the shop and provides a modicum of privacy.  This is a "fusion" house in the best sense of the word.  They really do succeed at being equally adept at fish sculpting/rice molding, and Chinese cuisine.  Although I was alone and ordered a Cantonese dish (Beef Chow Fun), I could see and hear my neighbors enjoying their sushi rolls and sashimi.  

Not that I wanted to eavesdrop, but although it was lightly attended when I arrived around 8 pm, they sat the three tables of customers right next to each other, making it impossible to ignore my neighbors.  It would be a plus should management recognize that spacing out the customers when possible would enhance to overall experience of the diners.

My meal was very good.  The broad Rice Noodles, thin strips of Beef, abundant Vegetables and quality Brown Sauce, made for a quite enjoyable repast.  I could only finish half of the large plate in house, and took the rest home for a second round.  The Green Tea served singly in a ceramic mug was also tasty and promptly refilled without charge.  

Service was professional. 

I'll be back to check out the Japanese side of the operation and trust it to be as good as my neighbors made it seem.  There is also a short Thai menu for those who favor those flavors.

At least once or twice while in town for the gem shows in late January, the family demands a dinner more in line with what we consider comfort food.  I may prefer to gorge on Indian, Mexican and Vietnamese cuisine, and my family goes along willingly. Still, I know with me working most of the day and leaving them at the hotel to play, they need something that is fun to eat.  BJ's Restaurant & Brewhouse fills the bill.

The place is large and bustling.  Mixed group of people at dinner time, with the happy hour folks mingling around the bar, and those of us in for a meal scattered around either along the bright windows, or deeper inside where it feels cool and dark.  While fairly typical of the latest variant of the modern roadhouse, it does it very well.  I get to drink a few interesting local craft beers, and my son gets his favorite drink of all time - root beer.  Once he tasted it he was mellow the rest of the night.  I took a sip. Smooth, light, sweet, and chill.  It was okay that he had nearly a pitcher of it.  He would remember it for a lifetime.

BJ's seemed to be about pizza and beer, and we saw no reason to stray far from their wheelhouse on the first visit.  2010 was our first sit down, and I still remember the deep dish pies as overwhelmingly thick and overloaded with terrific flavor and texture.  The BBQ Chicken Pizza was enough for 6 people, and the Flatbread Roasted Veggie and Goat Cheese a crispy, glorious treat.  We ordered both of these for the 3 of us, and ended up taking most of it back to the hotel for the next day. The following visit, we had a simpler design; one Flatbread Pizza, One Crispy Jalapeno Burger, Wedge Salad and Gourmet Mac & Cheese for the young man.  All very good, and less to take back with us.  We were a happy clan, especially after trying a Pizookie, their signature dessert.  If you love cookie dough, this is for you - baked cookie dough topped with Vanilla Bean Ice Cream and a square of Dark Chocolate.  It is one delicious hot mess.  

Sitting back here on the East Coast as I write this, I can still recall the total satisfaction from the experiences at BJ's.  It makes me dream of returning next year for more of the same pleasures.

Coming here directly from Farmers' Best Supermarket on Adams is probably not fair to Farmers'.  But, we needed a few things in the way of kitchenware that Kobawoo had in large amounts.  It was impossible not to notice how clean and organized this place was compared to where we had just been.  Better lighting.  Broader aisles.  Smaller space, yet nicely laid out.  

Strong display of serving vessels and cooking utensils for both the home and professional kitchen.  Only thing it lacked was plastic chopsticks for restaurant use, so bamboo would not have to be wasted on a single use.  

Overall, a good place for Asian cooking needs, and one to which I would gladly return.

This is where the deliciously creamy Goodnoe Ice Cream is made. 
You have to go to the Goodnoe Ice Cream shop on Sycamore Street to actually buy it. 
Very worth the trip.

Still a great place for lunch or dinner in Newtown. 

My son loves the Buffalo Chicken Cheese Steak and it is one of the first things he wants when he returns for a visit. 

I had Penne Aglio Olio with Spinach tonight, and it was very good.  The side salad needs a little work to bring it up to par, but that is a small nit in an otherwise enjoyable dinner.

First rate gelati with an abundance of fruity flavors to mix with the heavy creaminess of the custard. Darkest Cherry, or Green Apple, or Mango Tango, or something like that are all treats. 

Word on the street is that this Rita's is the most successful in their national franchise. For a little barn that is closed between Thanksgiving and May Day that is quite a feat. 

Come to Newtown for ice cream and other sweet creamies. So many choices in a small area, and a great town to walk around while ice creams drips from your chin.

At the intersection of Stoopville Road and Washington Crossing Road in Lower Makefield, Village Market has been dishing out good breakfast and lunch sandwiches for decades.  Their recent upgrade adds to its luster, and the newly engineered intersection makes it easier to get in and out with risk of bodily harm.  It is easy to miss the deli section in the white building next to the Exxon station, but try to stop in.

VM has a deserved reputation among locals for hearty breakfast sandys and over-stuffed burritos, way above average lunch options (especially Cheesesteaks and Chicken Salad subs and wraps, and even decent fresh coffee. It is primarily a take out joint, and the parking is adequate.  The staff moves efficiently and knows what the regulars want.  

There is a bit of confusion as to who has jurisdiction over Village Market.  Although much closer to the center of Newtown, it is actually in Lower Make.  Don't let that squabble deter you from sampling their homemade menu.  But, if you have the misfortune of being pulled over for speeding on Rt. 513, the police who will be stopping you and issuing the summons are from Lower Makefield, so don't blame Newtown.

A dozen or so visits to Bagel Train has led me to the opinion that it deserves an upgrade to four stars. 
Perhaps, my taste bud memories have waned, allowing me to create new images of my childhood in the City.  Maybe, I am feeling more at home standing in line and interacting with the good folks working there.  Too, it could be the realization that BT's "baagels" are less expensive than the recently departed Bagel Junction (of blessed memory). 
Regardless, I now look forward to the first bite of these creations, and that deserves recognition via promotion.

When my son's bike went down, and he suddenly needed it for a scout trip in 2 days, I stuffed his wheels into the back of my car and drove over to Harry at the Newtown Bicycle Shop. As usual, Harry Betz was elbow deep in some repair and had to disengage before coming out to greet us and find out what we needed. His triage took about 10 seconds and he diagnosed both the obvious and hidden problems clearly to us.  Could he do the repair? Sans doubt.  Could he do it before tomorrow night, as son was leaving crack of dawn for New York State?  Oh, ye of little faith... Mais bien sur. 

My son and I were relieved, and were out of the shop within 5 minutes ready for a stop at Rita's for a guilt free stress release celebration.  

Returned the following evening before closing, and the bike was good as new, and much cleaner than when it entered.  

I hear what the others are saying about "service with a smile." That may not always come with the expert repairs and knowledge that a local biz is watching our backs in a crunch. Still, I am a fan of having a confident expectation of getting the job done right and on time. Besides, Harry is  way cool when you spend any time with him.

If I need to hit an Asian grocery, butcher, fish monger, rice shop, or soy distributor, and can't get out of town to a H Mart, Hung Vuong Super Market in the Wing Phat Center will have to do.  It has all I need in so many varieties that I start to lose perspective and wonder if there really is one special soy sauce for the specific dish I want to prepare, rather than one of many that would do quite nicely.  Of course, I then search for a store employee to ask this question and he/she inevitably walks me down the aisle like a curator in a museum and pulls out a bottle and hands it to me with a look between bemusement and contempt that I didn't know what I was looking for.  Mea culpa!

Having spent a long time in Asia I know that this and other "super" markets exist there in much better condition and organization than Hung Vuong and the other big stores in the city.  There, they don't smell, they are kept clean, offer better packaging and more refrigeration, and actually sell a wide variety of western products you don't find here. I generally avoid those modern conveniences and shop the outdoor markets to find the specific item I want at the vendors who specialize in those things.  After all, I am a foreign traveler because I like the traditional ways of doing business.
