Those outdoor or night markets are not to be found regularly around here, so I accept that Hung Vuong and its siblings down the street and in Chinatown, are as good as it gets.  Luckily, I enjoy the experience enough to make it all worthwhile. 

These days I am working my way through all the bottled chili sauces to find the few I like best.  I should complete my research sometime around 2018.

The third generation of Goodnoes are now in the ice cream business, carrying on the rich and creamy family tradition. While no longer occupying the history corner restaurant (great loss), they have the same ice cream that made the name synonymous with excellent ice cream, sundaes, malts, etc.  The dairy still turns out the same delicious flavors that your grandparents loved and waited for on Saturday nights.

Newtown has an embarrassment of ice cream riches.  Sweet Pea, Owowcow, Zebra Striped Whale and Goodnoes.  All are good in different ways. But, for my ice cream dollar, Goodnoes is still first in my heart and stomach. 

It is worth a visit to Newtown to try all four places and decide for yourself.

I was lucky enough to stumble into the Grand Opening of Café 128 one morning earlier this week.  The new coffee house is located at the prime location directly across from the State House on West State Street, and situated in a walk down basement space that has been very nicely renovated into a subterranean cozy space. Plenty of exposed brick, wood and granite all around.  
It was obvious they were still getting set up when I walked down the steps, but I was greeted warmly and welcomed to their new enterprise.  They do breakfast and lunch and appear to have state of the art equipment, including point of service payment system that allows the customer to use the latest technology to cover expenses without the staff touching a credit card.  
My order was a simple Everything Bagel with Butter and Swiss.  While I did not ask for it toasted, it came out that way.  No problem, as it appeared to have been pressed by a Panini iron that flattened the bagel, but also slightly melted the cheese and butter, but not enough to create a leakage issue.  It tasted very good as I drove back to the office.  The coffee was from the Small World Coffee people, and was a satisfying brew. The bagel was a good bite.  
 
If this house can manage the flow of lunch customers in that small space, they have a great opportunity to do very well there.  This stretch of West State Street in Trenton is very attractive these days, inviting people to walk and take their pleasures as they stroll.  

The proprietors are accomplished in the food trade, with other shops in Pennington and the sushi bar at Trenton Social.  They know "...Renton." 

Best of luck!

As an attorney who has appeared here on behalf of clients seeking to become United States citizens, I have witnessed both the good and bad of this important service of the US government. 

The entire process takes too long from application to final examination and Citizenship ceremony, but that is not the fault of the good people who work here (except when furloughed because of a government shutdown). Most do their best to make the experience as positive as possible given that there are too few employees to cover the number of applicants.  The wait is generally under an hour to get into an interview or exam, and the actual face time with an examiner is under 30 minutes.  The questions are reasonable if the applicant has studied a little in advance, and the examiners tend to be patient and understanding of language and cultural differences. 

The most important thing is to be prepared.  Be sure you have all your official documents in your possession, and have responded to all correspondence seeking more information.  You may need updated tax returns, or employment letters, etc., and be sure you have them.  Otherwise, there may be a need for a return visit. Review the information brochures provided for the form and content of questions.  It is very helpful to talk with those who have successfully completed the process because often the same questions are asked.  There is no shortcut to knowing basic American history and government structure.  Just memorize as much as possible, and be able to talk a little about some of the topics. 

Most examiners are sympathetic to your goals, and want your to succeed.  A few may be having a bad day, and when that happens you have no choice but to roll with the punches. 

Being represented by counsel is not required, but is often a good idea as it helps greatly with preparation of documents and reviewing possible questions, and can provide a sense of security while waiting in the large waiting room, as well as when with the examiners.

Jay's Steak & Hoagie Joint on Highland Avenue, Parkland, PA, turns out very good cheesesteaks and related grub and fair prices. Their style is heavy on chopped steak, with plenty of whatever you want on it. They do not skimp. 

I walked in yesterday to discover a small building, recently renovated into the 21st Century, with a small order counter, one table, and a back kitchen behind a half wall that bisects the room. Easy to hear the banging and clanging on the grill as the beef is torn asunder and plied with cheese, onions, peppers and hot sauce for constructing a Jay's Special. The roll was decent and able to hold most of the overload as long as it is wrapped tight and held on the horizontal until you get to where you intend to consume it. 

That was my kitchen table. There was a little leakage on one end, but it did not escape past the outer white paper. The taste was strong, spicy and very satisfying. I could only eat half. 

Jay's is definitely a strong choice if you know you want steaks, wings, wraps or hoagies. A pizza parlor it is not. They do a great job in the quantity/quality department, and offer prices that do not offend. It is a bit hard to locate in an older residential neighborhood, that clearly lacked zoning when it was built. Winding streets are fun to navigate, and when you arrive there is a special sense of accomplishment.

 Don't miss their food truck in the side yard, nor the outdoor seating on the rear patio.

The Saloon is housed in one of the most historic buildings in Newtown Township, although the interior has been so well redesigned that you would never know it once you get passed the old buggy out on the side porch.  Rest assured that you are dining where travelers and locals have chowed down for more than 200 years.  Yes. The food is much fresher than that. 

I stop in occasionally for lunch or a late evening refresher with friends.  The bar is where I accomplish both.  As a former tender, I enjoy the tight confines of the long narrow room and excellent old bar.  Yesterday, I came in for a late lunch and sat at a high top along the wall.  A couple of old dudes sat at the bar chatting up the bartendress, so I basically had the room to myself.  I ordered their 10 oz. Saloon Burger with American, Red Onion, Lettuce on a Roll; Medium please.  It came out slightly beyond the midpoint, but still quite good.  The grill marks were pronounced, as was the taste of the hot steel.  The accompanying Fries were crisp, with a mix of those small overdone pieces that I love to crunch.  My attempt to reduce calories has me eating only half the roll, so the larger than usual burger was more than enough for a satisfying lunch.  

The price points on most dishes offered in the afternoon are between $8 and $12, with their burger coming in at $9.  

Really a nice spot for a quiet lunch, and a good night spot for a drink and conversation. In good weather, the deck outside awaits.

Still @ 4 Stars.

Returned to try a little Sushi in the form of Salmon Skin Roll.  It was well presented, tightly wrapped, and tasty.  Very happy for the low salt soy sauce option on the table.  

Also ordered Chicken Pad Thai, and while amply plated with plenty of fresh ingredients, the taste was not what I expected from this Thai dish.  Wrong spice mix to my palate. 

And, my pet peeve again presented itself.  Although there were only 3 tables occupied in the house, we were all seated on top of each other, disturbing the tranquility of the well crafted environment.  I just don't want to eavesdrop on what the next booth has ordered before as they show off for their guest, nor how many sushi roll orders should be eaten in vs. taken home to the kids. 

Give us all a little space and we can enjoy our East Sushi in peace.

Sirtaky is the Greek restaurant on High Street in the middle of Mt. Holly, NJ, that replaced the Mugshot Diner.  It looks about the same as before, but the menu is now far more oriented toward the Aegean than the previous occupant. They are open for three squares a day, but I was there just for breakfast (Opens @ 8).  There is a nice counter with about half a dozen spinners, and three booths and a couple of tables.  The joint is pretty cozy. 

I sat at the counter and ordered corned beef hash, two over easy eggs and rye toast. It came with a truckload of homefries, which I could not finish. It was a solid and tasty brekkie. Their java is strong and hot. 

I had the pleasure of chatting with Paul, the chef (and owner?) of the house.  He was charming and very interested in what I thought of his cooking. It was not difficult to tell him what he already knew - that he knows his way around a Greek kitchen.  We ate breakfast together while we talked. That doesn't happen every day! 

Sirtaky is a great addition to the scene in Mt. Holly. Now there are breweries, cafes and a few real good places for the morning repast within blocks of each other.  If Mt. Holly isn't careful, it could become a legit destination for foodies and crafties in the region. 

That would be a good thing.

This corner banh mi shop is not much to look at.  Maybe 150 square feet with only 2 tables for eating in, and the rest of the space totally utilitarian for the production of Vietnamese fast food.  There is a wall menu with photos of their offerings and a cooler full of fruit for their various smoothies.  The ladies of the house are pleasant, courteous and very deferential.  I love that they bowed when they delivered my food. 

My Spring Roll arrived after the Banh Mi, but that was of no concern.  They were 5 lightly fried, tightly wrapped, logs full of ground shrimp and pork with veggie filler.  The dipping sauce was clear with a sweet vinegar taste. Very nice.  

The Banh Mi was loaded with BBQed Pork, Cucumber, Carrot, Cilantro and a good Peanut Dipping Sauce.  The Roll was not quite a crusty baguette, but was fresh and complementarily soft and chewy as the palette on which the other flavors were painted.  Quite good. 

Banh Mi Cali is primarily a take out joint for those wanting a good sandwich or one of their many handspun smoothies or bubble teas.  Still, as a solo traveler this night, it suited me perfectly as the place to relax with a good light meal in a small corner of Vietnam.

The coolest thing about Sloc's Bar & Grille is that it is attached to Slocum's Bowl-O-Drome, on Pennington Road, Ewing, N.J. If old school bowling is your thing, then this is a wonderful place to indulge yourself. The lanes are old, but full of families and leagues throwing strikes and spares, while the small tavern down the hall, pours suds from mostly well known national brands, and uses the kitchen in back for better than your average bear's bar grub. The dining area was full of groups playing cards on St. Patrick's Day, with most folks garbed in green. 
I sipped on my Coor's draft, watching the NBA as I waited for my order of pierogi to be served. The friendly barkeeper was more than happy to change the channel to the game, as nobody else seemed to be interested in the NASCAR race showing on all the screens. Not even the grumpy dude sitting next to me at the bar seemed to mind. I guess there was enough green in my Eagles Super Bowl LII hat to satisfy him. 
And, those pierogi were as good as advertised. Moderately chewy doughy dumplings stuffed with mashed potatoes and topped with a motherload of sautéed onions. They appeared to have been boiled and then fried in a pan, as the surface was browned and crisp on the surface, and tender within. The plate was heavy on the crude oil, but that added to the overall homestyle flavor. Delicious. 

Best of all, the prices were reasonable. 8 ounce draft plus decent snack for just over $10., is quite the deal. 

Although rather old, there did not appear to be any access issues, as everything was on the ground floor with sufficient space for assisted walking or even the private medical chariot.

I am new to Maryanne's Homestyle Cooking, although I know they had another location in the past.  I am glad I finally made it, and that it is now closer to home.  

This is a modern version of the old style small town luncheonette that was prevalent across the USA in the early and middle part of the last century.  It is more than a simple place to have a good meal, but also the unofficial town center, where people meet to discuss their lives, community and nation.  It has a warm and comfortable Americana feel to it.  I enjoyed my first visit sitting in a booth behind two senior gentlemen who were doing movie reviews and political analysis at a fairly sophisticated level.  At least 75 each, they gave nothing away to younger minds.  

The service was solid with timely walk bys asking if I wanted more coffee.  My French Toast was above average, but not among the best I have had.  The java was hot and tasty.  

If there is a weak link in Maryanne's armor it might be the way they approach providing the accompaniments to the dishes served.  Their syrup came in a small plastic cup.  It seemed to be watered down to be just maple sweetwater, rather than anything close to authentic commercial grade maple syrup.  It was completely soaked up by the bread because it lacked the viscosity to sit atop the short stack long enough to allow for cutting and consumption.  It made for soggy French Toast half way through the meal.  I would gladly pay extra for the choice of syrups.  The butter was likewise very thin and airy and had little buttery taste.  

Maryanne's could be a real HOME run if they decided to provided an upgrade to these items, or at least the choice to patrons.  Their prices are very reasonable for the clientele, but even folks on Social Security enjoy a little pampering now and then.

Walking into Ted's Montana Grill in Warrington, Pa., (its only location in the Commonwealth), reminded me of my first visit to the Short Branch Saloon in Steamboat Springs, Colorado. A very long bar backed by mirrors and multi-leveled bottles of liquor, tiled barroom floor, small dining areas spaced around the rest of the building.  Tight booths for couples and foursomes with high back benches to maximize privacy. Cowboy and Rocky Mountain accents. Wood beams, floors and paneling everywhere. The only thing missing were the spittoons on the floor at the ends of the bar. With fond memories of those western days, I immediately felt nostalgic, while my expectations rose quickly. 

We were seated toward the rear of the house, in a booth out of sight of the bar.  We were about the first to dinner. The table top was covered with a paper map of the Bitterroot Mountains.  It was an early rendition and suitable for framing. We were in the mood for burgers and sandwiches.  We realized that we were in luck because Ted's specialized in beef and bison burgers, along with a few interesting chicken options.  Steak was also on the menu, but this was more an exploration of the lower ridges without the urge to climb to Trapper Peak.  

We went with a Naked Bison Burger, Red Rock Chicken Sandwich, and The Z Bar Chicken Sandy.  All in the $13-14 range.  When the platters arrived our eyes widened at the sight of three well stacked dishes housed in interesting Rolls, Cheese, Onions, Shoestrings, and a sideload of French Fries.  The set up contained steak knives - a reasonable concession to the reality that there was no way to put these big brazen Buffalos in our mouths full bite.

 All three meals were really good; the Bison being the most anticipated and enjoyable.  I knew that buffalo meat was more tender, leaner and sweeter than its bovine cousin, and this held true for this humdinger. It was large, loud, juicy and delicious. The Red Rock and The Z were also solid cluckwichs and very enjoyable, but much more in line with past experiences.  No knock on them, but Billy Bison stole the show, naked and proud. 

Warrington isn't in our hood, but we do get to Doylestown with infrequent regularity.  Ted's Montana Grill will go on the short list of worthy stops on the way down from the mountains.

This is a new listing for Original's Italian Pizzeria, a/k/a, Original's Pizza, in the Morrisville Shopping Center.  I returned for lunch last week and found a packed house full of luncheon moms and summer break kids enjoying their freedom sharing a pie without adult supervision. Good for them!

I found an empty booth under the "roof," and ordered an eggplant parm sandwich.  It arrived about ten minutes later, steaming hot.  My approach with scalding sandwiches is to attack with knife and fork, rather than attempt to pick it up and take a dangerous bite. 

The eggplant was nicely breaded and sautéed in olive oil prior to being loaded into the Italian loaf and finished in the oven to melt the cheese and toast the outer edges.  There was enough tomato sauce on top to keep everything moist and tasty.  The gravy was a little salty, but that was not a big deal. The eggplant was soft and tender and mixed well with the sauce and cheese.  Saving the bread for last, it was very good - crunchy and tasting of all the elements that had been within. The surprise of the show! 

I can see why people enjoy Originals and keep it jumping. The atmosphere is communal and neighborly.  My lunch was far better than average. Fair prices. Good service.  Great for kids to ride to on their bikes.  

A keeper.

Duck Sauce pioneered Asian Fusion (Chinese foundation) in the Newtown area.  The facility is dark and comfortable, and the staff is friendly and attentive without being overbearing.  Management is stellar, with the proprietress, Amy, warmly greeting everyone with a warm smile and sparkling eyes. 

The food is a few notches above standard Chinese fare, while also providing a taste of Thai cuisine for the more adventurous.  The dishes are nicely plated and presented individually to satisfy both your visual and aromatic sensibilities.  The tastes are unique and you always feel the extra thought put into the creation of your meal.  

Lunch comes in at about $10 per, while dinner moves up to about $15.  Not bad for the quality and ambiance of the overall experience.  

Everyone's taste buds are different, but I just had the Beef with Chinese Eggplant in a Basil Soy Sauce that was very good.  The Wonton Soup came with thin skinny wontons as well as spinach leaves, making for a mildly sweet sensation. White, brown or fresh made fried rice are all available with every meal.  

Funny, I just returned from China and this was my first Chinese meal at home.  I found myself wondering why I was given a glass of ice water and western utensils when my Chinese eating companion had no water nor fork and knife.  I had to ask for chop sticks. This is only a small peeve, but perhaps it would be better to ask the patron if they want ice water or hot water and chop sticks or knife and fork rather than assuming from appearance what those answers will be, especially when the other diner is automatically given the Asian settings.

The Courthouse Cafe is the closest restaurant to my new office, directly across the street from the red brick Church of the Redeemer and catercorner from both the new & old Mercer County courthouses. I have stopped in for a quick meal now and then when going to/departing these halls of justice over many years. Although the name used to be Gus's, it still looks and feels the same.

It is old school. It slings traditional breakfasts and lunches for the courthouse and state worker crowds, and keeps quality, creativity and price in balance for the limited time and budget restraints of their market. It does this well, as can be seen by the full house at lunch and the empty seats after about 1:30.

My Chicken Salad on Rye Toast was a decent sandwich. Fresh ingredients. Good bread. The side of fries was okay and the thimble cup of sweet slaw pretty tasty. At around $8 with tax, it was a fair deal.

The Turkey & Swiss was likewise a solid lunch, as was the Chicken Salad & Bacon Melt I had last week. 

Ownership is in the house and involved in everything. They keep the house friendly and  check in with customers.  

It's good to have a reasonable and reliable luncheonette as a neighbor.

Just returned to Duck Sauce after an absence of more than a year.  It remains the dark wooded small dining room with booths around the walls. The teapots are still heavy metal with better than standard tea.  The menu does not appear to have changed at all, and that was a small disappointment.  

However, the Pan Seared Pork Dumplings were well made, held together, and were very tasty.  I asked for a side of Hot Sesame Oil to bring up the burn, and poured it directly into the Soy/Vinegar Mix they dispense with this dish.  With that, it was very enjoyable.  Too, the Teriyaki Salmon was a nice size steak and was grilled just enough to leave it thick and juicy with a glowing glaze.  The golden yellow Mango surrounding the salmon was both ripe and sweet and a great color combination.  I was happy with both dishes.

Duck Sauce is still a solid "Fusion" house, and the best Newtown currently has to offer.  It does feel a bit stuck in the 90s, and could use a makeover in terms of ambiance and offerings.  It will not satisfy the more sophisticated pallets accustomed to authentic Chinese, Japanese or Thai cuisine, but it does turn out tasty plates that are enjoyable for what they are.  

I know where to go when I desire serious Asian food.  But, when I am not in the mood for a longer ride, and the comfort of home is appealing, Duck Sauce still provides the mood and flavor that keeps me satisfied.

Whether you're a fan or not of Golden Nugget Antique Flea Market depends on your feelings about junque, you know, that stuff packed away in your basement, attic or garage that you can't find a use for, but can't let go of.  Well, Golden Nugget is where you go if you want to be rid of it, or to get more of it.  Either way, this outdoor market along River Road south of Lambertville, NJ., is a cultural trip down memory lanes and forgotten trails.   

When I stopped in this week it was after heavy rain and the gravel  trading area was pretty muddy.  Still, I was able to drive in and park behind the market and take the steps down to the action.  At 8:30 am, the place was busy with the gypsies, mountain men, pickers, and collectors who are addicted to finding obscure gems in a mountain of trashy throwaways.  It must work for most regulars, because many are there three times a week to search, bargain and barter for those old tools, keys, buttons, knick-knacks and the most esoteric tchotchkes that are precious baubles to them. Why was I there?  My hunt involves old pocket knives.  They don't need to be sharp, but they do need to open and close, and have all their blades.  I found several around, but only purchased one that was fairly valued after friendly haggling.  The others were nice, but too dearly priced for my blood.  Amazing what excellent handicraft attaches to American steel.  Secondly, I look for beautiful beads to use in making jewelry that has been a small business for many years. Strung with pearls and other natural stone stringable pieces, make for interesting and attractive neck or wrist ware.  

I'm not in love with Golden Nugget, nor the other similar flea markets in the area, but every now and then I have an urge to explore these backwaters of the American economy to see what I can find on the worn out tables in the park.  

Who knows?  Maybe I'll get lucky again.

Marcos Pizzeria has reopened!
The fire that closed Marcos and its neighbor put a serious dent in my pizza diet, and I can imagine others felt similarly. 
It is located in the Village of Newtown Shopping Center, just behind the Wendy's. Once a week I go for a couple of slices (tomato pie and traditional eggplant), and never fail to run into someone I knew in the same frame of mind needing a pizza to brighten our day. The few times I was there for dinner, I had a parmigiana or aglio olio pasta dish. Satisfying.
The downside has been that the shop is small and not comfortable enough for extended dining.  Too, in winter when the door opens, everyone is greeted with a cold blast, which chills both the patron and the food.
There are other pizza options in Newtown, and I frequent most of them.  They are all decent, if not attaining the Trenton nor Brooklyn pizza pantheon. But, who can travel to those places every time you crave a T.pie?  Right now, Marcos offers me the most positive "Pizzaxperience" in town.

Jersey hyper market comes to Bucks and shows up the local talent Acmes and Giants with huge selection and cutthroat pricing.  It has everything those other guys have, and so much more in a shelf by shelf comparison.

 More labels.  More variety.  More choice.  

It may not have been the wisest thing to make a first visit on a Saturday afternoon when the place was full of Sunday pushcart drivers, as the number of near misses with the granny class kept me on edge and hoping my auto insurance comprehensive would cover any property damage.  Too, the cost of things was not always clear on their price cards below the items, especially the discounted products.  A bit more clarity would be a big help.  

Other than those nits, Shop Rite - Yardley is a great place to stock up.  We came in needing a few things, and walked out with a large cart full of everything else we would use in the months ahead. 

 Next time, a weekday evening will be explored to see if the overall experience will feel less risky.

Although Metro Diner doesn't originate around here, it fits right in with all the other dinners that have been in Bucks County for decades. It doesn't mimic the stainless facsades of yesteryear, but has its own style and comfort. More brick and glass with paint on glass stenciled sign windows proclaiming their most popular items (Chicken & Waffles, Chicken Pot Pie, Fish & Chips, etc.), and only a short counter with fewer than ten stools, the booths and tables are where most eating takes place. 

On this weekend I was in the mood for something different for me, and asked for their chicken pot pie. I sat at the counter overlooking the kitchen and enjoyed the small talk among the cooks and servers. 

I watched as my dinner was removed from the oven, put on a large plate, passed from the kitchen to the dining room though a window with shelves to facilitate transfer from one to the other. The wait person placed before me a huge biscuit crust covered oval dish, browned on top and steaming at its edges. How attack this enormous package? 

I cracked open an end with my fork, lifted the corner of the crust and folded it back on itself. The aroma of the creamy thick sauce, full of vegetables and chunks of chicken wafted up to greet me. Seductive. I tasted a bit of crust. It was a fresh biscuit flavor, not too flaky, with a slight saltiness. The veggies were firm, the chicken, tender. It was all together terrific. Not that I am a pot pie maven, but this was the best I've had. In another house without the name "diner" attached, and with a good bottle of Pinot, this meal would be a star of the show and cost much more than the $10 it demands here.

The fried chicken looked appetizing, too. If as engaging as its potted cousin, Metro could become a habit.

First time visiting the Gloucester Premium Outlets in Blackwood, NJ, but it likely won't be the last. I am usually averse to "outlet world" experiences, as being over the top gross commercialism, that no longer reflects the factory overrun and slightly defective merchandise where the concept began; but is now part of the corporate master plan to produce specifically for sale in this setting. Too, so often there is no real saving going on, but only the false perception of discount. 

Certainly, I saw some of that in the Michael Kors Armani universe. But, surprisingly, other shops provided some true value. Calvin Klein had many casual shirts available at good prices, as did Banana Republic with their slightly eccentric styles. My biggest score was in Columbia Outdoors, where their outerwear was discounted up to 60% from the real online catalogue prices I had seen the day before. Picked up a really nice water resistant green vest and some camping gear. 

The quasi-village look of the the center was attractive. Plenty of surrounding parking, wide walkways throughout, enough directories to keep from getting lost, and a few food outlets for when shopping no longer overcame hunger. 

Yelp-wise, not every store was listed separately, making check ins and reviews impossible for we addicts who need to record our every move. That will hopefully take care of itself eventually. 

Nonetheless, Gloucester Premium Outlets proved worth the drive and a pleasant consumption experience.

Tropical Family Restaurant at the western end of Lalor Street, Trenton, is one of the many converted corner bars that in their heyday were packed with the people who toiled the heavy industries of Trenton's steelworks and watered their weary souls here.  Those folks are mostly gone now; replaced by the next wave of immigrants who prefer their corners to provide spicy sustenance along with the cervesa. Tropical Family fills that need for the Puerto Rican pallet. 

I stopped here for lunch last week.  I was pleasantly surprised by several things. First, they have a nice size parking lot surrounding the premises. So much easier than searching for street space.  Second, the house is very well renovated with brilliant color and murals and new buffet table, making it one of the nicer Latin places in the city.  Third, the service was first rate and came with sincere smiles from the bilingual staff.  Finally, the lunch menu while small, offers enough comida authentica to still the savage beast.  

My Pernil Sandwich was loaded with Pork, Lettuce, Red Onion, and Mayo on a fresh roll.  The meat was tender and everything together was a fun munch.  I did find it a little lacking in the heat department, but the table Tabasco took care of that.  I also ordered a Refresco Mango - a blended ripe Mango with water and ice.  It was very good, but next time I would go without the ice to avoid the brain chill the came along with it.  

Tropical Family seems like a solid choice for dinner, too.  And, as the name implies, it is a family joint where spouse and chachos would be comfortable and have plenty of great options for a meal.

Blooming Grove Inn occupies the space of what was Lieggi's on Upper Ferry Road in Ewing, NJ. It is a pleasant converted mansion on the slopes of the eastern side of the Delaware River Basin.  My visits have always been at the bar for after work meetings and light socializing.  The crowd is forty and fifty-somethings; all well behaved.  The bartenders are excellent.  Noah remembered my face, if not my name, after an absence of at least six months.  Impressive.  

Last night, my margarita had the right touch of Padron and Cointreau, and my friend and fellow court gladiator enjoyed his aged malt whiskey.  Behind us at the end of the bar, a mellow guitar vocalist played gently and sang from a decent list of soft rock standards. It was just enough to fill the gaps in our conversation, but seemed to disappear when we spoke again.  

We decided to have a bite at the bar, rather than score a table.  I asked for the Meatballs I had seen brought out earlier, and Sam went for the Tapas plate. My dish was excellent.  Tender, airy meatballs in a tart, garlic tomato sauce, sprinkled with dry Italian grated cheese.  I only skewered a few pieces of cheese, greens, mushrooms off his plate, but thought everything was fine, if not enthralling. 

So, why four stars?  It has nothing to do with the quality of the house, the kitchen, nor the bar.  They were all fine.  Blooming Grove just isn't my cup of tequila.  I prefer a less well kempt, more outside the box, more diverse, kind of place.  It felt too tame.  More a place to take your aunt and uncle, or business associates, when you don't want them to know who you really are.

Joe's Mill Hill Saloon has been holding up the southeast corner of Broad & Market Streets in Trenton, NJ for decades, and aside from some refurbishing it continues to be an attractive barroom and dining venue as authentic as the day is long.  Large rectangular dark mahogany bar with stools for more than twenty. High tin type ceiling that show its age. Large beveled mirror with the Joe's logo etched in. On a late winter afternoon with the western sun blindingly pouring through the windows, the setting is good enough to be part of a Raymond Chandler novel. 

I took a seat on a stool facing the Christmas adorned mirror. The barkeep must have been behind the well for twenty years; older but none the worse for wear. The menu still offered soups, salads, sandwiches, burgers and cheesesteaks, but the beer selection was way better than I remembered. Old Brown Dog Smutty Nose Draft. Yeah! Why not? It went down cold and biting, just as its name suggested. 

The house Build Your Own Burger was constructed with American, fried onions & mushrooms, and sliced jalapeño. Medium rare, and delicious.  Fresh cut fries slightly undercooked, but still thickly good. 

Very glad it's right down the street from my new office for the next time I'm feeling like Dashiell Hammett.

This is a newer Chick-fil-A in the footprint of the dearly departed Krispy Kreme.  They have done a nice job renovating the shop, and setting up dual take out drive up lanes.  The actual restaurant is also well laid out, and has very well trained staff running the place.  

I ordered a late lunch there earlier this week, and was surprised by the level of friendliness and care coming from behind the counter.  They even brought my meal to the table so I did not have to wait off to the side while it was being prepared.  That was only the second time a fast food joint had risen to that level of service, and the other occurred right down the road.  Must be something good in the water. 

My Spicy Chicken Sandwich was good.  The breast was soft and tender as if never frozen.  Somehow, CFA chicken is always the most flavorful and chewable of all fast food cluckers. The waffle fries were crisp and plentiful.  Their dipping sauces are pretty unique, and my sriracha packets were a mix of that well known chili heat and a subtle Thai-like sweetness.  Tasted great on both the chicken and the taters. Of course, the hand spun shake was as cool and creamy as always. Went the way of plain vanilla, as the cookies and cream option would have clogged the straw.  

Generally, I like the breakfast sandwiches offered by Chick-fil-A more than their chicken, but I have to say the improved service here and the high quality of their menu is slowly making me a believer that they have something special going on.

I understand why so many people enjoy dining at Café Michaelangelo on Bustleton Avenue in the Far Northeast, Philadelphia. While most customers are local to the area, we were coming down from Bucks County, and this Italian haven was just a few miles over the county line. 

It doesn't look like much on the outside. A narrow parking lot separating the building from heavily trafficked Bustleton. The façade a worn brown wood with narrow doors and confusing signs.  Still, we found our way in through the side entrance and walked into a small lobby, followed by a large glass-walled dining room with high exposed beam ceiling and vistas overlooking a back yard that was treed and green - more like a tree house feel, than a structure anchored to the ground. Although aging, it was very attractive. Positive first impressions. 

We were seated at the first table in the dining room.  Although closest to the door, there was a half wall with trellis protecting us, and we soon forgot we were sitting on the edge. The menus were brought out quickly and we settled in to scour it for that evening's delights. While reading, we ordered a Stone IPA and River Horse Raspberry Tripel Horse Belgian-Style Ale. (You're wrong! I had the fruity beer, and my beautiful companion the very stout IPA.) We decided to go light. Fried calamari as a shared appetizer, and roast pork and Italian sausage sandwiches as our mains. Alina was our excellent server. She took very good care of us first timers. 

Although the calamari was almost exclusively cut into bands, with only one set of tentacles, it was quite good; especially the dipping red sauce which was spicily chunky and required a second helping. While I might not get it again, it was a fine vehicle for sauce delivery. 

The sandwiches were both first rate. They were served on decent Italian rolls which supported their passengers from plate to mouth without hesitation or flopping. The meat was tender and flavorful, with dipping sauce to enhance the experience. The sausage was cut into smaller slices for ease of ripping off chunks of the sandwich, and had ample onions and green frying peppers mixed throughout and more of that wonderful red sauce.  Really liked both plates. And, there was a plentitude of stuffing in each - so much so that we could only eat half of each sandwich and brought the rest home for stepson to enjoy.  We had planned to order something separately for him, but we had so much that it wasn't necessary. Alina brought us the takeout containers and bags with an easy smile, despite the loss of the extra sale to the house. No doubt, she had seen this happen before. 

We thoroughly and zestfully partook of our Café Michelangelo meal, and commented as we ate how good it was. In warmer weather, eating on the back patio would be a worthy addition to the program. 

An exceptional find on the wild streets of Bustleton. And, the prices didn't hurt either.

Elmwood Park Zoo is a 16 acre community zoological garden on the outskirts of Norristown, PA. As small zoos go, this one is pretty cool. It has maximized its diminutive size with a 24 hour a day schedule and state of the arts events that can make everyone from 3 to 93 entertained, at least for a while. 

From zip line through the treetops, to daily face to face animal feedings, to overnight camping with informative guide, Elmwood has it going on!  The late morning I was there to wait for my next meeting nearby, there were dozens of families with young kids walking around, interacting with the animals, and taking tours through this attractive, hilly landscape. Whether greeting Noah the Bald Eagle, or Stella the Horned Owl, the children were enthralled, and their parents happy to provide the family with an extraordinary experience. 

The zoo is available for private parties, including weddings. Educational programs abound addressing conservation projects and endangered species. Cub Scouts to seniors have something to events geared to their age and ability to learn and engage. 

Founded in 1924 when the private owner donated the original land to the Borough of Norristown, and managed by the government until it became too expensive to maintain on taxpayer funds, and was reorganized as a non-profit in 1977 known as the Norristown Zoological Society. Through the 21st Century it continued to expand its size and services, including a master plan that built several pavilions  and large scale permanent exhibits, including the Kimmel Conservation Kingdom in 2001, its interactive playground where human and other species met to learn from each other. 

More than 500,000 visitors come annually, most of them families participating in all the activities. It may be small in stature compared to the more famous Philadelphia Zoo, but pound for pound it provides more alternative activities than its older, Ben Franklin founded, sibling.

Definitely worth a visit or two.

Back in the day when I lived in the Fairmount neighborhood at 26th and Brown Streets, shops as good as Rybread didn't yet exist, and we walked to the local corner taverns for suds and a meal.  Now, this neighborhood has experienced a modest renaissance and has a good variety of kitchen alternatives within a few blocks radius.  Makes me think about what it would be like to live here again in the shadow of the Museum of Art and take advantage of all the improvements.  

We were showing out of town guests the beauty and grace of Philadelphia from the steps of the museum (so nice that on the weekend we could stop for a while right in front of the PMA and let our friends run up the stairs and enjoy the view without hassle).  When we agreed we were hungry, I searched Yelp for local restaurants, and saw Rybread in my bookmarks.  We drove there in about 3 minutes. Plenty of street parking. 

There were no other customers when we arrived and we settled into the three small tables in the front of the shop.  One of the friendly servers explained that we should order at the cashier and we would be called when our lunches were ready.  Simple enough. There were five of us, and we wanted to sample everything that was selected.  They agreed to cut the sandwiches in quarters to accommodate.  

There were good looking scones in the display, and we impulsively asked for a blueberry and cranberry. Baked in house, both were excellent; slightly moist and mildly sweet.  Nothing wrong with starting with dessert.  We then went with the Savannah (turkey, brie, cranberry sauce and mayo on multi-grain bread), Lake Tahoe (tuna salad, cheddar, tomato on ciabatta-panini style), Napa (fresh mozza, roma tomatoes, pesto, balsamic glaze on grilled baguette), and Tucson (oven roasted turkey, swiss, red onion, chipotle mayo and tomato; ciabatta panini style).  A large size soup of the day (sweet potato, chicken) was thrown in for good measure. 

Each of the sandwiches was very good to excellent.  The bread fresh and brought to life through the panini press or just out of the bag.  The ingredients were fresh and ample.  No skimping on these works of art.  The soup was wholesome, hot and tasty.  We congratulated ourselves on our wise choices, and the good fortune of finding this charming, yet cramped, restaurant converted out of this block of row houses.  
 
People came and went as we sat and ate.  Some came in, saw the indoor tables were occupied and walked out again. On this rainy day, the outdoor seating both front and rear was not a real option.  Still others, got their meals to go.  

The bill for the indulgent five of us was less than $50, with a few shared Joe's Iced Teas.  At that cost, the priceless chalkboard atmosphere was free.  

Would love to return for breakfast, which is available before noon.

Viet Tokyo Cuisine is a new restaurant on Haines Road, Bristol, PA.  Its doors have been open about ten days, offering Pho (Noodle Soups) and Com (Rice Dishes) from the southern part of Vietnam as well as Sushi.  It is owned and operated by a lovely Vietnamese woman and gentleman who are anxious to please customers with authentic beef broth noodle soups with a variety of thin sliced beef,  meatballs, or chicken.  The environment is utilitarian with about six booths and a few tables around the single dining room.  Decorations are sparse, but the house is clean and the service is solid.  

I ordered a bowl of their Pho Bo Tai (Round Steak).  For $8.95 I was served in a large square bowl of a decent beef stock, nest of noodles, and 8 - 10 thin slices of the rare steak that I separated with my chopsticks to allow each to finish cooking in the heat of the soup.  I added Thai basil, sprouts, jalapeno slices and lime juice to taste, and set out to work my lunch.  The noodles needed to be pulled apart, but that was easily done. The beef was very good, especially when dipped in a mix of sriracha and hoisin sauces. I could not finish the pho. 

Finding a pho shop in this part of Bucks County was a pleasant surprise.  While there are a few others around, they remain few and far between.  I found that the broth, while good, needed more time in the pot to simmer and reduce to a more complex spicy finish.  This is normally at least a 24 hour process, and this one was not quite mature. Still, I enjoyed it, as well as the labor of working the noodles, beef and consommé.  That is one of the best parts of slurping pho. It can be such a hands-on experience. 

I will likely check Viet Tokyo out again to sample the rice options. It would be great if they also made Banh Mi sandwiches, but they were not on the menu.  Still, maybe they could do them as a special once in a while. If good it would guarantee my faithfulness. 

3.5 Stars. 

Can't speak to the sushi.

I enjoy the occasional lunch at the Broad Street Diner because in addition to being close to the office, they put together specials for the midday meal that are solid and filling.  

Yesterday's Chicken Salad Sandwich on Rye was a fatty, and I had the option of several sides rather than fries.  Opted for Apple Sauce on a hot day, and the cup of Split Pea Soup that was placed before me was a complementary part of the deal.  

At under $8, I felt well cared for.

Hit another Farnsworth Avenue hotspot yesterday with a late lunch in Under The Moon.  Have to say that Bordentown is turning into Lambertville.  That is a very good thing. Bonaparte would feel right at home.

Under The Moon dresses up like an old antique store that specializes in kitchen furniture and tableware.  It is wall to wall tubular steel tables and chairs and trundle tables.  The glassware and coffee mugs are a mix of various decades. The painted wood panel ceiling was attractive and interesting.  It was all so very charming and cozy. 

I was alone when I entered around 2:30 looking for a late lunch.  Kim greeted me with a big smile and told me to sit anywhere.  I picked a double mid-shop to have equal views forward and aft.  A run through the menu had me narrow my selection to an appetizer ($9), as the prices were above my self imposed lunchtime limit.  The Corn Souffle with Leaks sounded about right.  

It came with a few slices of home baked Garlic Bread, which itself had a small amount of Garlic Butter at the ready.  The Souffle was not large, but it was filling.  The consistency was appropriately like whipped egg, and the Fried Leek topping looked like gray straw left by a miniature farmer.  The taste was remarkable for the sweetness of the corn and the crispy onion salute of the Leeks.  I liked this ensemble very much.  The price no longer felt so cher.  All the while, Kim returned periodically to check on me and keep me company.  

When done I was asked if dessert was a consideration.  I saw the options in the display near my table.  Everything looked over the top!  Still, sweets would have to await another visit as I had plans at night.  

The owners obviously take great pride in their establishment, and they have made an exceptional effort to stylize their house.  The food seemed to have a continental and mildly Spanish orientation.  No problem there.  The empanadas tapas were on my short list.  They were made in house by the mamacita or abuela. 

Under The Moon is a great date.

Murphy's is a local bar down on Bristol Emilie Road, Levittown, PA. For a small dive bar it has some really good things going for it. Along with an interesting clientele who seem to all know each other, it possesses a beautiful classic wood shuffleboard along one wall, similarly well appointed bar runners whose friendly manner and fun loving personalities make them entertainers as much as mixologists, as they dance to the jukebox 'zak. 

Although the kitchen was slammed when I ordered a cheeseburger off their limited menu and I had a bit of a wait until it reached me, it was well worth the delay. Served by the cook himself taking a walk from the grill to clear his head, it was the best half pounder I've had for quite a while. It was a perfect medium finish as requested. With lettuce, fat tomato slice and thin fresh red onion ringlets, the juicy flavor/texture was a masticating joy. Quality brioche roll, too. Crisp fries showed the small details were not taken for granted. 

But for the fact that smoking is allowed, Murphy's was five star all the way. Have to add the expense of laundering the smell out of my clothes to the otherwise top drawer experience.

Maybe, "Beef & Ale" really means it!

Ruben's Pizza sits in a tiny strip of stores that is easy to drive passed without even noticing. If not for the fact that I was on Spruce Street in Ewing for other reasons, I would never have stopped to settle my later afternoon hunger. But, there it was, with new sign out front just in the right place to catch my eye and safely pull into the miniscule parking area in front of their building. 

They have both personal sized and small pies selling for $5 and $7.50 for 12" and 15" diameter wheels, which seemed perfectly designed for my pleasure - the equivalent of the bar pies famous throughout Trenton, but without the bar. Sized and priced right to move. So, I ordered the small 15"er with Sweet Italian Sausage. 

The shop is too tiny for tables, and I planned to take it home, knowing that it would be past its prime by the time I opened the box. To my surprise, although no longer hot enough to burn my tongue, it retained its point when lifted, and folded nicely between my lips and into my mouth. Nice char on the undercarriage, too. 

The taste was good with slightly salty tomato slurry top, hint of basil and correct amount of melted mozza proportional to the sauce. It left a very good first impression. 

Def worth remembering the next time I'm in the Trenton Farmers Market zone.

I guess it means something that it took four years for a return visit to Duck Sauce, despite the fact that it is the closest restaurant to my Newtown office, and I love Chinese food. 

The reasons are what you'd expect. It just isn't the exceptional Asian fusion it once was, and the competition in that niche has grown in the interim. It seems there has been a change in ownership, with the old kitchen creativity having lost its edge. While it remains better than average as a Chinese/American house, it really doesn't overtly compete in that space. Rather, it's claim to fame has always been that it is a different kind of Asian place - a fusion experience that suggests traditional dishes, but does them in a unique way to make their menu special. 

While the menu looks the same for the most part, the separation from standard offerings elsewhere is now less distinct; the distance between Duck Sauce and the average Chinois, smaller. 

The Wonton Soup is still very good, but the wonton skin a bit thicker. The Calamari appetizer had a coarse breading that detracted from the softness and flavor of the tender crustacean beneath, while the dipping sauce was fine. The Orange Beef was soft rather than crispy, and the dark amber semi sweet sauce, thick and more gloopy than remembered. Yet, there were the potato sticks sprinkled on top, still a nice touch. The Shrimp and Cashew platter was very good, but not dissimilar to what you can find almost everywhere. 

I finished my lunch satisfied, but not in love with the meal, as I once was. It is still a good place for quality ingredients and presentations, but I left with no urge to return within the next four years. 

3.5 STARS

The Warrington town fathers & mothers showed their vision of the future when they approved The Shops at Valley Square commercial development on Route 611.  They did not see the big shopping malls of the 20th Century as enhancing the land values that surround them, but were open to the concept in modern urban planning that recognizes that people prefer to have consumer experiences on a more human scale.  

Capture the essentials of small town America in an attractive village-like setting, and they will come to spend money.  They got that right. 

The Shops at Valley Square found the sweet spot for commercial enterprise for this era.  Buildings designed to look like a country town, with sidewalks, narrow streets, street parking,  buildings no taller than three stories, and attractive shops and restaurants that are as inviting on the outside, as they are within.  Include the brands that people want and the eateries that beckon their hunger for relief, and success is almost assured.  

The facility is very attractive and inviting.  We were there for dinner, and the choices were pretty good; Panera, Ted's Montana Grill, P.F. Chang's, Chipotle, and even a Wegman's if we wanted to take home.  It was easy to park near our destination, and fun to walk a few blocks to see what was going on.  

Not every municipality shows the foresight to bring in such a sparkling center that has become a destination for the surrounding communities, and beyond.  

Have a visit and enjoy the future.

I just needed a light bite for the drive back from UDel to Bucks, and this McDonald's flashed on the Route 2 horizon. This was to be a drive through encounter, so I never saw the interior of the small footprint burger emporium. 

It has been a long while since my last McBurger, and I faltered at the order stand, not remembering what the latest deals were. I asked for a quarter pounder, and was immediately asked by the speaker voice if I wanted a second one for a dollar. 
Sure. Why not? Did I also want a value meal? I didn't want fries, but a bottle of water made sense. The voice was patient with me. I knew most customers were more familiar with Mickey's menu than me, although I was aware they were test marketing a new fried chicken sandwich at the behest of their franchisees, who were trying to compete with Popeyes and Chick-fil-A. 

The burger tasted fresh, with nice flavor addition from thin red onion ringlets and pickles. The beef was a little salty for me, but not overly so. The bun held together well. 

I was satisfied as I munched on the way north, and reminisced on my summer working at McDonald's in River Edge, NJ, the year I graduated from high school and prepared for college. I imagine it is still a great job for a teenager.

Rosario's is that turquoise colored 1940's tiny food shack that sits on Rt. 130 South, just past the 206 split in Bordentown, NJ. It has been spinning pizza for a couple of generations.  Grandpop still runs the show, but son is deeply involved. 

Surprisingly ample parking lot for the 7 or 8 tables within, but with takeout and delivery options, the shop can get busy.  The afternoon I stopped in, there were four kids not yet in their teens who had ridden there on bikes, enjoying summer with slices and fries.  Perfect place for nostalgia. It was so easy to remember doing the same with my buds as we celebrated our nascent independence. 

My two slices and a coke contributed to the reveries.  Yet, on their own, the pizza was solid, with good tasting mozza and fresh tomato sauce.  The crust could have been firmer, but I was in a forgiving mood.  At slightly more than $5 for lunch, this was a worthy pizza stop.  Too, Rosario's did not make a dozen pizzas in advance for display.  Their old style approach was appreciated, as I knew that whatever pie I was eating had not been made long before.  Just in time production works best for fresh food.  Those houses that leave pizza around all day for people to see and chose could learn from Rosario.  Stale warmed over pizza is never prime. 

Next time I want a quick lunch with a dose of childhood, I will be back.  Probably sooner than later.

One of those old fashioned stainless steel and glass diners from the 1950's, that is still pumping out excellent breakfast fare for road warriors. Pulled in driving my late model Zipmobile, and when I returned, it had transformed into a 1958 Packard.  Just what I always wanted!

The staff was perfect for this stage.  Friendly, gregarious, and full of "Honey."  

The French Toast was very good, too.  Enough egg, soaked through and through, and a caramelized texture where the super hot range had cauterized the surface of the bread.  If they had used real maple syrup rather than the mass produced prepackaged variety, it would have attained all star (5 Star) status.  Also needed a Cecilware coffee urn, rather than the newer Bunn for the best coffee. 

I don't mind cutting corners to make ends meet, but in my fantasy the syrup comes straight from a Vermont Sugar Maple to my plate.

Metro Grill in the Glen Roc Shopping Center is another very good Italian restaurant with a clubby feel and full house for dinner nearly every weekend. The space is small, adding to the sense that its bar and dining room are popular in the hood. Service is in the traditional black and white mode - all first rate. Our reservation options were for either 5:30 (too early due to work) or 7:45. We grabbed that table for three. 

The menu had everything expected from apps to dessert. We opted to share the calamari frita with a Thai chili dipping sauce, followed by chicken franchais, chicken marsala and their pork chop plate. All were very good to excellent. The squid had a strong crunchy breading that was enhanced by the Asian style sweet/hot spice. It was a legit alternative to the red sauce that normally accompanies this dish. The two chicken platters were tender fillets with with custom made sauces. The mushrooms in marsala wine and the artichoke in lemon and white wine renditions were a joy. The pasta sides were a nice counterbalance in red dress to the subtleties of the mains. The pork chop was at least a two inch cut with demiglaze, string beans and mashed. That heavy serrated blade came in very handy. If there was any weakness at all, it was the chop was a bit tougher than it should have been. Still, the juicy taste was there, it just required more mastication than desired. 

We had no room for sweets at the end. 

Metro Grill is an excellent representation of the Trenton Italian cuisinary tradition. It is proof that you can take the restaurant out of the Burg, while maintaining the Burg within the heart of the restaurant.

Jersey Bagel Cafe & Pizza on Rt. 130 Northbound, Willingboro, NJ, is a little hard to find, even when standing at their front door. It sits far off the highway in a multi building commercial center that is currently undergoing construction in their drives, and with retail shops all around each pod. 

I was at the right place, but it took a few minutes due to poor signage to find the only open door to the premises on the side. The main doors were locked and a hand made arrow pointed to the second door, which was also bolted closed. I was too near to just give up, especially when I saw someone inside who didn't respond to my knocking on the glass. So, I walked around the corner, and lo and behold, there was another single door entrance inviting me in. 

Very glad I hadn't given up, because despite the rough introduction to JBC&P, the bagels within were really very good. Service was friendly and Covid appropriate. For pennies over a 5 spot, I enjoyed a fairly large Onion Bagel smeared with a liberal amount of Veggie Cream Cheese spread, and large self-serve java. 

The baker had the right touch and had left the bagel with a crisp skin, yet light inner texture. Just the way I prefer them, with nice mild sourdough flavor under the soft innards and crunchy dark brown toasted onion flakes (perhaps a bit burnt, but still quite good). The Joe was hot and strong. 

While there I saw a tray of homemade baklava under display glass. Made it tempting to return sometime soon for their Italian offerings, and get a taste of that delicious looking honey drenched pistachio pastry.

Lemon Grass Thai Restaurant on Huntingdon Pike is a legit Thai kitchen that doesn't pretend to be what it is not. This is no erstaz fusion joint putting out sushi, Chinese and a little Bangkok cuisine. No. It is strictly what it claims to be - all Thai all the time. And, that's the way I like it. 

The dining room is dark and small with a bamboo grove potted by the door and soft wood and cool orange tints throughout. Management is Siamese and the chef was likely raised there, too. So, it is as authentic as it can be, while making understandable concessions to American taste buds. I was very pleased with lunch the other day, as it all seemed deliciously consistently Phuket. 

The lunch deal consisted of an appetizer, soup/salad and entree, for $9.95. I was attracted to the Buddha Dumplings (veggie), Coconut Soup (veggie) and Drunken Noodles (chicken and hot). It was a combination that came at me in waves. First, the fried dumplings were full of ground veggies and a good dipping sauce. Pleasantly chewy with mild flavor. The soup was steaming and loaded with thin sliced carrots, string beans, mushrooms, tofu, with a slightly stronger spice bite than the B. Balls. Finally, the drunk pasta, while not the jumbo noodles expected, was still strong enough to use it surface to hold on to the heavy brown sauce tenaciously. It had a larger quotient of hot chili powder, and thus the strongest taste and plenty more veggie and sliced chicken. It was perfectly sized at less than a dinner portion, but more than enough to fill me up after all that came before. 

Service was attractive, friendly and invisible except when delivering the dishes to the table. 

It was great to be back in an authentic Thai house after recent exposure to "fusion" huts that couldn't deliver on the promise of real Pattayan cuisine. If their duck is up to the standards of the rest of the menu, 5 stars won't be far behind.

Pho Ben City (clever ref to Franklin City), sits on Rt 611 in Abington, Pa. It is a nicely reused former fast food outpost, that is now a well designed, modern Vietnamese house with a full menu from pho to com to full plate dinners.  Service is friendly and prompt. Prices are competitive with other local pho shops, but higher than found in cities north and south by a couple of bucks.  Higher rents in the burbs lead to higher prices.

My Phone Tai was good. The broth was clear and could have simmered longer before serving to bring out the flavor. The accompanying Thai basil, sprouts, jalapeno and lime were freshly bright green. Plenty of lean beef and needles lurking beneath the calm surface. 

The roast pork Banh Mi was tasty, with nice crusty baguette holding it together. Spring Rolls were average for content and taste, while the dipping sauce was a little thin. 

Complimentary scoops of ice cream was a nice closer.

 Pho Ben City is quite good, but it does give away some of the strongest elements of Viet cuisine, perhaps due to location and clientele. I have no problem with that, but admit to liking the style used where most visitors to Saigon houses seek the full Monty of taste.  To my tongue, it is superior to Pho & Beyond (less MSG), and about on par with Pho Palace, if a little behind House of Pho in overall richness of experience.

Covid Takeout Review

Did a GrubHub takeout from Shagun Palace yesterday, and was very satisfied with the result. The restaurant is in the rear of a shopping center on Street Road, Bensalem, where there is a significant cluster of South Asian kitchens. Competition being severe, the quality is higher than in many more isolated Indian houses. 

Our order: Veggie Samosa for an appetizer; Chicken Korma, Chili Chicken - Dry, as entrees; and Baingan Bartha (curry eggplant), for a veggie side; and Garlic Naan to soak up the sauces. The foods were all very good to excellent, with kudos to the korma and dry chili chicken, which displayed spice skill with the sauces. The bird was perfectly cooked, and not at all dried out. 

If there was a weakness, it was the Naan, which appeared premade and merely heated in the oven before wrapping in foil. It was thicker and drier than normal, and not the least bit flakey, nor with expected air pockets. There was practically no garlic flavor. Next time, skip the naan. 

There are talented hands at Shagun Palace where they are allowed to perform their magic. They are masters of curry cream reductions, but make a mistake in not carrying the expertise through to their breads. If they lack a tandoor for BBQ and Indian oven breads, they really should invest in one. It would make Shagun a more complete 5 Star experience.

Santorini is one of the most beautiful Greek islands in the Agean Sea. Shaped like a crescent, it is the geologic remains of an extinct volcano, creating a large harbor where the central vents were before collapsing beneath the sea. Houses are all whitewashed in the towns that cling to the cliffs above the sunken caldera. These days it is best known for its blue domed churches, and excellent cuisine. 

So, naming a gyro house after Santorini makes sense, as it suggests a rugged land with equally tough people capable of great artistry in the kitchen. This new small Greek place is well appointed to feel like you are sitting in a café in Kamari or Oia, the two main villages there. They have a limited menu, but their focus is on the traditional fare - gyros (the derivation of Heros), or sandwiches made with hot pita stuffed with well spiced meat, or veggies, i.e., falafel. 

The shop has three vertical roasters for pork, lamb and chicken. A large electric shaver is used to slice off the meat from the central spit, before being loaded into the pita with tahini sauce, yogurt, onion, tomato, fries and paprika. The whole pita is then rolled snuggly around these contents, and wrapped in paper and again in aluminum foil, so it is served like a cornucopia on a plate. 

The result - a delicious sandwich, requiring help from a fork to consume, because it is so filled to overflowing that each bite has some of it falling out onto the plate. Not that I'm complaining. 

The gyro with a bottle of water was about $10 plus tax. The lamb is another buck or so. 

Very worth a stop if you like Greek street food in an attractive setting overlooking Santorini Bay.

If you don't mind paying $23 for a four pack of local suds, Newtown Brewery is a worthwhile destination for the yeast heads in the crowd. The facility is very attractive with plenty of wood and stone, and the beer is excellent for the most part. 

We stopped in last weekend and the room was hopping. Tables full of folks escaping Covid captivity. But, we weren't ready for a space packed with over a hundred people without masks, nor social separation, so we bought our "I lost My Marbles" Belgian Tripel four can and headed home. Just didn't feel safe (and thus the one star deduction for lack of public awareness by management).  Under better circumstances, Newtown Brewing would be a big hit in these parts, and in fact, it appears it already is. 

The beer was quite strong at 11% alcohol content, but the taste was great, and the color a robust rusty slurry. Liked it a lot. I'm no expert, but these guys seem to have the right recipes. 

They do have a food truck in the parking lot most weekends, and we were fortunate to approach the window of Stuff'd Bunns and grab two sliders to partake with the ale at home. They were great and a perfect partner to the cold fermentation. More on them in a separate review coming soon to these Yelp pages. 

I hate to have to take out a loan to support my occasional beer addiction, but aside from that, and the insensitivity to the CDC guidelines, Newtown Brewery really enhances the neighborhood. Just hope no one gets exposed to the virus. That is a price far to high to pay for a momentary pleasure.

Bowman's Hill Tower sits in Washington Crossing Historic Park at a high point along the Delaware River where a most important part of the American Revolution was played out.  Construction was part of the Civilian Conservation Corp that put Americans to work during the Depression, and was completed in 1931. 

The view from the deck 320 feet above river level is awesome.  Especially on a clear fall day, it is possible to see more than 12 miles up and down river, as far as Trenton to the south. The flowing river and changing foliage make for a strong memory. Certainly, Washington would have appreciated having such a tower to use to observe British activities approaching this location.   

But, it was not just patriots occupying these fields after the Continental Army was defeated by the British in New York, and Washington beat a hasty retreat through New Jersey into Bucks County to save his remaining troops.  Not everyone believed in the cause, and many of the locals actually supported England and did its bidding, including spying and behind the lines mayhem.  The infamous Moses Doan was in this vicinity as the plan for the Christmas raid on Trenton was put into operation.  He is believed to have crossed the Delaware just ahead of his hunters, and rode to Trenton to warn the Hessians of the coming attack.  But, for the fact that the German commander Rahl did not bother to listen to Doan, we might still be speaking with British accents. 

So, Bowman's Tower is worth a visit, and while you are at it, spend a few hours searching the old homes and cemeteries in the Park.  From New Hope to Morrisville there is plenty of history to be seen.  

The ride along Rt. 32 is worth the price of admission alone.

I was last here when it was known as the Old Neshaminy Tavern about a year ago. Since then it has adopted the "Brewery" tag, and taken advantage of the Pennsylvania law that allows local breweries to manufacture their own suds, and sell the products of other Pennsylvania breweries (only) with special dispensation in taxing and licensing. Smart move, as the name is attractive, the kitchen remains solid, and they now have many beers, ales, IPAs, and other interesting fermentations for your drinking pleasure. 

There is a large chalk board on one wall with a listing by number of what is available. Those numbers correlate to taps behind the bar with numbers above each. Call out what you want by name or number, and the gracious bartender will pour it for you. About half come from their own stainless vats, while the remainder are what management thinks is noteworthy from around the Commonwealth. Of course, if you want a national brand, some of those are available in bottles or other taps. I chose the Neshaminy Creek Churchville Lager, a well made semi-dark pilsner from right down the road in Penndel. Loved its dark amber color, and the corresponding flavors of black coffee and chocolate. 

I also ordered their Trenton Pie and side of Brussel Sprouts. They were both very good. The pizza was true to its name, with thin crust, Marazano tomato chunks on top and mozzarella underneath. The Brussels were plentiful, and would have been better with a tossing of vinaigrette in addition to the bacon pieces to give them more bite. Took most of both home after sampling some at the bar as I enjoyed my lager. 

Langhorne isn't known for its local attractions, but it does have a few interesting points to visit. Langhorne Brewing Company adds to that list of worthwhile destinations in this part of Bucks County.

The Perk has successfully turned their parking lot into an outdoor dining garden complete with beautiful Japanese bonsai specimens from Bucks Bonsai landscapers. With large umbrellas and heating towers, it is a pleasant place to have a late lunch on a chill Saturday afternoon with the sun casting it's golden hue. 
This is a great place to enjoy the Borough of Perkasie, a tight community in northwest Bucks. 

I sat with the sun at my back and ordered a Blue Moon draft, French Onion Soup and Sauteed Pierogi from their appetizer menu. I also asked for takeout of Crab Cake and Chicken Parm sandwiches for my working family. 

The beer was served in a soft plastic glass with orange slice split over the rim. Cool and refreshing. The beef broth and translucent onions were very good once I pierced the thick layer of melted provolone that sealed the steaming contents of the of the potage d'oignon gratinee. Liked it alot. The pierogi arrived in a styro container. There were four homemade potato pasta pockets that had been sauteed in butter and thin sliced browned onions. These were excellent, and I would have loved if there were one or two more in the box. Still, it was an appetizer, not an entree, so I understood they were designed more as a delicious tease than main course. 

Last night, my wife and stepson came home to the crab cake and chicken parm. After a short reheat I sampled both and found them to be superior sandwiches. The crab cake was fresh, sweet and housed in a brioche roll. The parmigiana was a thick chicken breast, well breaded, with a decent red gravy and melted cheese. Very good. Both came with house deep fried potato chips. Nicely done. 

The Perk is an anchor establishment in Perkasie, and well worth the travel from home to stop in now and then. If we lived closer, I would no doubt be a regular.

As federal agencies go, USCIS sets the standard for how to treat people right. 

The new facility on North 41st Street in West Philly is a vast improvement over Callowhill Avenue. Not only is the space well renovated for more comfort during the inevitable security screening and wait for your appointment, but the guards and staff are trained to treat people with respect and assistance. They patiently repeat instructions and never lose their cool. 

The meetings are conducted across a counter and thick glass wall, but the interaction remains low key and humane. They intend to answer questions fully, and will make formal inquiry when they do not have a reasonable answer on their computer screen. Don't forget that most visa files are not in Philadelphia, and they cannot see everything in them.

Street parking, metered or not, is usually available if you are driving, and the subway is not far away. Too, this part of town, just beyond the universities and at the edge of Powelton Village, offers many tasty distractions before or after conducting your business.

This Puerto Rican bakery is a tiny shop on Brownsville Road, Trevose, PA. Primarily takeout, it has a few tables for those of us who prefer to sit, sip and eat while the iron is hot. The business opens at 8:00 AM, not the 10:00 reflected on its Yelp page. As we were there for breakfast, the earlier time is important to know. 

We ordered two egg platter breakfasts. Both had two fried eggs (ordered over easy, but delivered sunnyside up), five slices of small loaf toasted sweet bread, and bacon/sausage.  In addition, we had excellent coffee and shared a marble donut made for us after ordering. Service was friendly, informative and nicely paced. 

Turned out that the egg/meat/toast part of the meal was pretty ordinary, with the only remarkable piece the pleasant taste of the bread. Much more interesting and rewarding was the strong java brewed through an expresso machine, and the donut.  Expresso coffee was used, which made for a rich, aromatic joe. The donut was still warm from the oven and covered in a thick icing of vanilla and chocolate. Delicious, but not too sweet. A super pleasant chew. 

I would return to enjoy more baked goods and coffee, and likely pass on the breakfast offerings. Lo Le Lai has the feel of a café, and would be a great one just based on the quality of its flour products.  

Definitely, a treasure to explore.

We just enjoyed a very satisfying Good Friday breakfast at Jake's in Newtown. Plenty to eat, tasty and quite fairly priced. 

It seems time to revisit the old review and adjust the ranking to 4 stars. I've eaten here often enough to become a fan.

This is just a great place to have a terrific burger that satisfies your Burger Lust for at least a few days.

With the evolution of Burger Culture throughout the planet, it is only a matter of time that the first wave of fast food meat patty institutions, like Mikey D's, BK, and Wendy's either adapt to the second wave epitomized by 5 Guys, Red Robin, Cheeburger, Jake's Wayburger, etc., by upgrading both the menu and the facilities, or go the way of the Doo Doo Bird, and face extinction. 
 
This new breed of puck slingers is simply too good not to supplant their predecessors. Once the new Burger Meisters figure out how to drop their price points into the range of the old joints, their fate will be sealed, and as with the dinosaurs, they will become a distant memory, a story grandparents tell their grand kids about when they were young and went to a place with golden arches to get their burger needs met. As with all such tall tales, the kids won't believe anyone ever had to settle for something so ordinary. 

Luckily, we don't have to.  The future is here and hiding is a grease-streaked brown paper bag.  Go get it!

General Deck, Bar & Grill on Street Road, Southampton, PA, is a deceptively attractive sports bar with decent kitchen and large outdoor rear deck for nicer weather. The barroom in front contains a rectangular bar, recently refurbished along with the rest of the house, with TVs everywhere you look. Behind the bar are two smallish dining rooms, redone to look rustic with stone and rough hewn wood. The deck comes last, and is approachable directly from the parking lot. 

I stopped in to catch the 76ers game against the Lakers, and was lucky enough to watch the locals demolish the LeBrons by 23 points! The menu was sitting on the bar, and I heard their California Burger calling my name. Got it finished medium, with a side order of Brussel Sprouts fit onto the large plate right next door. Service was friendly, and young enough to need to show their IDs. 

The burger was very good - done as requested, with fresh avo, lettuce, sliced sweet red onion, tomato and ranch dressing, on an above average bun that held together to the very end despite significant drippage from the puck and its playmates. The Brussels were excellently soft and savory with bacon, feta and a tart balsamic glaze overcoat.  

NOTE: The only recognizable defect in the entire show was the steep staircase to the second floor restrooms, which were inaccessible to anyone with a disability. I know that rehabilitated old buildings present challenges to compliance with ADA requirements, but given the amount of work done on the structure, and the addition of the large deck, a unisex handicap outfitted restroom should have been designed into the first floor, and a ramp installed for wheelchairs and walkers for entry into The General.

My first time visiting HG Bucks Bagels in Warminster, PA. It was recently remodeled, and it looks quite nice and clean, with room for both a bagel and pizza operations. When it comes to dual production, you have to hope that they maintain adequate separation of ingredients and recipes, so the pizza doesn't start tasting like bagel, nor the bagel too much like tomato pie, particularly in the crust and toppings departments. 

Luckily, that doesn't seem to be an issue, as, while I only tried an onion bagel (w Veggie Spread), it did not remind me of a slice O' pie. 

Yet, perhaps there was some leakage in style. I found my bagel to be large, freshly baked and loaded with hard toasted onion bits, but the shell lacking in crispness to differentiate it from the inner bread. I much prefer a harder skin from boiling with lye for about 40 seconds.
