When that doesn't happen, the outer coat is more like ordinary loaf bread, and not the tougher exterior that epitomizes the true rounder. So, while I liked the chomp, it would have been so much better if it had required a stronger, sharper bite from my incisors. 

It wasn't a bad bagel, but done right, it could have been a real contender. 

3.5 STARS.

Copa on South Street was my mainstay for several years after tai chi classes at The Painted Bride.  Those days are only for reminiscing now, but the taste and zest of Copabanana remains a trigger to my salivary glands. I have returned on occasion, and still loved the dirty ambiance, lusty margaritas, incredible Copaburgers (extra jalapenos, please), and the earthshaking Spanish flies...er...fries.  My son, now 12, has gone with me, so another generation is preparing to take its place where Friday night legends are made (and oft forgotten by Saturday morning).  
What others Yelpers say about the conditions in the joint is true, but the best Tex-Mex food is always found in the dingiest hole-in-the-wall places.  Am I right? At least you know there are no cleaning agent molecules in the air to settle on your food. 
These days I try to stop in before or after a 76'er game.  Copa still possesses that "in your face" attitude that I have loved, lo these many years.
May it always be so.
Amen!

With the advent of coffee houses on every block around this piece of the Delaware Valley, there are now plenty of very good java outlets where you can order locally roasted bean drinks, settle in, and have a pleasant caffeinated interlude. Rojo Roasters is one of the early movers, and found a great old industrial site on far North Union Street in Lambertville, NJ, to set up shop. The place is cozy with strong Joe, laid back jazzy sound, and a reputation for well respected coffees. Half the shop is given to java mavens, and the other to making the beans morph from green to dark brown. The aroma can be overpowering. The regular customers seem well entrenched.

Yet, this inherent strength can also be a hidden weakness. A bit of sampling from the nearby competition leads to the realization that Rojo is strong in some areas, but weak in others. Because they are limited to their sources, equipment and process, there is a sameness to their products. When in the mood for powerful coffee, it is top of the mountain. All their beans and drinks are on the harsh side and lack subtlety. Reminds of Starbucks, and that is not necessarily a good thing. 

The other houses offer Rojo and other local, regional and national companies. It allows them to select the best of breed from across a broad spectrum of styles and technical processes. Thus, when you want something milder, or perhaps, nuttier or fruitier, you can get it alongside the stronger Rojo label. 

Yet, Rojo does what it does very well, and has a large following. Too, their bakery goods are first class. Loved the blueberry lemon pound cake this morning. Moist, dense, dark blue delicious. 

We are in a buyers' coffee world these days. It pays to sip around and discover what you like most on any day of the week. Chances are you will find it close at hand.

On the second visit I opted to eat breakfast in house, and found it enjoyable with the smell of the baking bagels in the air, and the bucolic ambiance.  The Onion Bagel was as the first one - not quite crunchy enough.  Still, it was fresh and tasty, and at a great price of under $4. for the bagel and decent Jamaican Blue Mountain style java.  

Easy to become a fan of this comfy chill.

Donuts Plus (exactly what the "Plus" is, is a secret), in the 4300 block of Chestnut Street, West Philly, sits in a rather inappropriately placed strip center in the middle of a heavy urbanscape. To look at it passing by you wouldn't think that this tiny shop cold possibly compete with the better known fry-dough emporiums around town.  But, the truth is that although it doesn't "cock-a-doodle-doo," its own rooster, it has the magic recipe for excellently addictive donuts.  We stopped four people along the way to ask directions, because the walking GPS seemed confused. Everyone thought we wanted a Dunkin, and hadn't heard of this joint, until we encountered a security guard who knew exactly where we were looking to go, and provided solid directions.

The space was tiny upfront where you place your order through heavy plexiglass and small defensive windows, but the folks behind the barrier possessed winning smiles, and the assurance of knowing they were very good at what they do.  

We walked in after a meeting at USCIS nearby, looking for some sweet cheer and caffeine.  The cast of characters hanging around inside was loud and maybe even slightly bizarre, but they stepped away from the window and allowed us to do our business.  We ordered an apple fritter, a couple of old fashioned honey dipped donuts and two javas. A small handwritten sign said, "Donuts $.95 each." We paid cash and returned outside to enjoy the beautiful spring day in February, and stroll back to the car a few blocks away.

The dough boys were simple and delectable. Firm outside. Soft inside. Sweet layer of skin. These were yeasties, not the cake d-nuts found elsewhere.  The fritter was huge, but too oily for complete enjoyment.  The other two were simply a pleasure. The coffee was a mild brew, and easy going down.

Now that I know how close Donuts Plus is to USCIS, it will be a regular stop before or after immigration proceedings.

Steven Robbins has been providing my glasses (progressives and sunglasses) for over 15 years.  He has been in business in Newtown for three decades. His current location is next to Jake's Eatery and Domino Pizza, but don't let that deter you.  The shop is first class, and he and his staff make you feel comfortable right from jump.

Most important, he has a large collection of designer frames, at reasonable prices.  His turn around time is at the longest a few days.  

Take a look around by yourself, or get the relaxed guided tour from Steve.  Kuerig Coffee Maker available with snacks while your stroll around the shop.

Definitely, worth a look before or after you have exhausted the alternatives.  Steven Robbins Eyewear is a winner.

This was my standard 2 slice lunch at a new place for me, Palermo's on Rt. 206 South in Bordentown, NJ. 

The joint has been at this location for a few decades it seems, and it shows its wear and tear both inside and out.  The booth I sat in was in need of new padding to compensate for the sag in the bench.  

On the other hand, service was attractive, lively and prompt. Ingrid was an excellent salesperson for the menu and seemed passionate about the Tomato Pie.  I ordered two slices well done, and Iced Tea.  When the slices arrived on their aluminum tray they were darkly brooding and steaming.  The chunky crushed tomato sauce was mildly sweet, while the cheese carried the slight overtone of salt.  The crust was thin, but not as micro as other shops, yet was definitely bending under the weight of the topside when lifted from the outer crust.  It didn't collapse and fold, but I did have to lift the point from its downward trajectory to get it into my mouth.  On the other hand, these were big slices. 

This is a very good Tomato Pie, and I was glad Ingrid double checked with me between the TP and the Pizza.  She encouraged me to get a fresh small pie for optimal results, but I knew I wouldn't eat that much at lunch today.  Management has put a lot of effort into the right ingredients, and for the most part they have succeeded with a superior Trenton style Pie.  

Everyone is a pizza expert, and I am, too.  While I will try the fresh out of the oven pie before a final judgment, my preliminary observations were positive, with the exception of thinking there might actually be too much cheese on these babies causing the weight and serious bending going on at lift off. 

Still with really superior taste and a strong biting crunch, Palermo's is worth another look or three.

SEPTEMBER 9, 2015 - UPDATE: Returned today and sampled an Italian Sweet Sausage Sandwich with Sautéed Onions, Peppers and Potatoes.  The sausage was butterflied and grilled thoroughly, and then placed at the bottom of a decent soft Italian long roll and overloaded with olive oil grilled peppers, onions and crispy cubed potato.  Very enjoyable.

Sakura Mandarin has become a regular stop when in Philly for any reason (do have an office there, but prefer to be in Princeton or Newtown).  Working through the menu I have discovered my favorites and tend to repeat them on most visits.

The Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai Steamed Pork Soup Dumplings or Juicy Buns) are the Best of Breed to my taste in Philly.  Six steaming top knot dumplings that require skill and care to eat without squirting the soup onto your date.  The waitresses love to offer a lesson in proper technique.  Be sure to pour some of the vinegar with ginger into the dumpling after it is opened to enhance the flavor of the soup and pork ball inside. 

The Shanghai Pan Fried Pork Dumplings are also very good for those who prefer that preparation.  While not quite the experience of  XLB, they are quite good with a vinegar chili sauce mix accompaniment.  

All the Vegetable and Tofu dishes are also good; the spicier the better. The Americanized dishes are okay, but clearly not as inspired, nor hot, as the more traditional Chinese styles.  When I go with my young son who is not acclimated to serious HEAT, he prefers the General Tso's Chicken, Orange Chicken, and Dan Dan Noodles.  They are all pleasing to him, but I find them a bit too sweet and thickly sauced, although the Dan Dan's are not bad at all when more Chili is mixed in. 

The staff is very courteous and helpful.  No problem with attentiveness which can be an issue in some places.  

Can't speak to the Japanese side of the menu, other than the take out menu is much prettier than the Chinese side.  Wonder what that means???

A regular stop when in Tucson for the gem show, India Oven on North Campbell has always provided me with enough fresh, authentic cuisine of the sub continent to keep me happy and coming back for more.  The curry sauces are creamy and well spiced, with fresh chicken and veggies.  It is the place my then young son first tasted and began to appreciate Indian food.  He loved the Mango Lassis and Naans, and slowly tasted his way into a broader enjoyment of all the flavors, textures, and colors created in the kitchen.

Sometimes it is a bit hectic during the dinner rush, and the service while always friendly, can be spotty bordering on uncomfortable, but never having had a bad meal here over the many years of visiting, it has become a favorite while in town.  

Many other gem show vendors come here after closing shop for the day.  On one occasion I sat next to a diamond merchant and his wife from India.  We started a conversation about business, and we ended up showing each other some of the stones we had with us right there on the tables, and finished a transaction the next day that resulted in some very happy gem folk buying/selling/trading stones that may never have transpired but for a common love of Indian food. Now, these good people are friends, and we plan to catch a meal together when in town.  

 Glad the resto didn't ask for a commission or finder's fee! 

India Oven gives a whole new meaning to the concept of, "hidden gem."

When I was a kid, my father would take me with him when he went to the car wash. In those days, we could sit in the car as it went through the line of sprays, spinning brushes, waxing and drying.  It was like being eaten by a dragon, going through the entire digestive tract, and exiting the other end.  For a kid that was about as much fun as I could have without going on a family vacation. 

Car washes have evolved over time, and the drive through variety has been mostly replaced with the "brushless" system that removes the passengers from the car, and pulls the vehicle through the wash on a conveyor chain. We are left to watch from the windows of the hall alongside the washing system.  

I still enjoy watching the process, and can't help imagining being inside the car. 

The Broad Street Car Wash has been around for a long while, although I never used it before.  It is the same mechanism as in my hometown, but this one seems better run, is definitely cheaper, and comes across with a better finished product.  At under $12 for the "Silver" Inside and Out service, it is a great deal.  There is even a $2 Off coupon for the Diamond Service, which provides foot massage while you wait (NOT - but wouldn't that be great!).

That it is less than 10 minutes from my office, making it a lunch date.
A worthy successor to the Clemons Supermarket that was here for many years. Bigger store. Better prices. Good people.

Towne & Country Cleaners sits right behind The Brick Hotel and next door to Grapevine Natural Foods on North State Street.  It is one of those places I never noticed until I asked around for a place that could repair the lining of my winter coat that had separated at its seam and needed to be reattached.  I was told that "Lucy" was very talented and could take care of it.  

Walking in for the first time, the place is a bit dark and dreary; needing better lighting and a fresh coat of paint to really make it appear more appealing.  There is a small changing area in the front of the shop, and a large mirror where the recommended alternations are pinned.  

Lucy greeted me with a warm smile and listened and observed as I opened the old coat to show her the problem.  She took a close look and realized that the wool and silk had separated and could be replaced or repaired.  She gave me the cost differential, and I went for the repair @ $25.  Two weeks later I picked up the finished job, and have been happily wearing the coat since.  After that, I have returned to T & C every time I need tailoring or repair.  I have always been happy with the work.  

While the work is first in class, the shop environment needs the same TLC that Lucy puts into the clothes she touches.  Some lights, brighter colors, living plants, a nice area rug, would go a long way to making T & C an even better place to get this excellent work done.

What a difference new ownership makes!

Last time I was in this shop it was a different pizzeria that touted its alleged New York City ties. In fact, the pizza had no resemblance to something from the Big Apple.  One visit was more than enough.  That place is now history. 

What replaced it is another animal all together!  Jersey's Tomato Pies (and Bistro) actually knows what it is doing.  It turns out a very reasonable facsimile of authentic Trenton Tomato Pie, complete with super thin crust, quality Mozza base and chunky/sweet Tomato Sauce.  It was quite good, and my newly arrived foreign guests were treated to their first pizza that required no apologies.  They were very impressed and devoured our Sweet Italian Sausage Pie without much comment beyond satisfying grunts and big amazement eyes.  

Thank you, JTP&B for a cultural experience my Chinese guests will remember for a lifetime.  

Now, to reach the 5 star apex achievement, only a little tweeking is needed.  The center of the pie was a little damp, making the lifting of a slice problematic as the cheese/tomato/sausage mix could not be picked up by the crust, but needed to be slid onto our plates and folded back onto the drier part of each wedge.  Removing more of the water from the tomato and slightly longer time in the oven to harden the doughy center, might solve this.  

Small nit is true, but when you come so close to perfection why not work to move the needle as far as it can go?

The Weekday Café sits in the rear of the first floor of the Doylestown Commerce Center. There is no road sign to alert you to its presence, and even if you use Yelp directions you find yourself driving past the modern office complex without a clue the resto is in there someplace. It was only by driving around the parking lot to the rear of the building on the left that I spied the outdoor seating, parked and went inside to recon. 

It was worth the effort. 

The café is run by a lovely woman.  She was busy with a catering order when I arrived, but still greeted me warmly and took the time to explain the layout and breakfast menu.  Ordering a Bacon, Egg and Cheddar on Croissant, I found the coffee shelf and poured some excellent brew.  

The sandwich was fresh and tasty and I took a few extra minutes to have a second cup while reading the morning news. People working in the building came in and out, and all had a pleasant repartee with the owner.  

At under $5 for the breakfast, I knew The Weekday Café would become one of my stops when heading for D'town.

If you want an evening of All American Fun in the Central Jersey, Bucks County, Pa. area you can't do much better than catching a Trenton Thunder Minor League Baseball game at the newly renamed, Arm & Hammer Park on the riverfront in the state capital.  Although it is now 20 years old, the park still packs in the fans with a ton of concessions, decent and fairly priced food (I caught a $2 beer night), and a party festive atmosphere. Where it can easily cost a family of four a couple of hundred bucks to attend a Yankee or Phillie game to the north or south, here you can easily get away with less than a couple of Franklins. 

Last Thursday night my son, his buddy, and I attended the park but faced a prolonged rain delay of over two hours.  We were in and out of our seats and into the shelter of the main concession area a few times.  No one complained as they were having too much fun, and the ball club was absolutely raking in the dough as people loaded up on food and drink while we waited.  

I definitely had the impression that management loved these rain delays for the increased profits from the captured audience.  Pretty smart move.   They did not want to spoil the party by declaring a Rain Out too soon. They let us stay so we could all sate ourselves and continue to hope the game would get underway.  It never did as the mid-June storm soaked the outfield and puddled up on the infield tarp. 

No harm done.  The ticket stubs will be honored at a future game.

Newtown Chocolatier is a venerable and sweet institution in Newtown.  They recently moved from their old digs on State Street to Newtown Richboro Road (Swamp Road). 
The new location is very well designed with plenty of display area to drool over.  
The chocolate remains among the best home made sweets I have ever tasted.  The prices are higher than I like for a chocoholic, but I never complain about the quality.  Their arrangement with Whole Foods testifies to their dedication to their craft. 

I am crazy for their peanut butter cups (Reeces), as well as their turtles and creams. But, to save a few bucks I usually go to the half price baskets to see what they are letting go at a discount. Yesterday, it was chocolate covered pretzels, cashew in milk chocolate, and solid milks, as well as a mix of darks.  Walked out with a bag at almost $10, that will satisfy my sweet tooth for a week or so.  

Newtown Chocolatier is not a place I can frequent, but every now and then when I need a lift, it becomes my oasis.

Just discovered this place down State Street from my office.
Full menu of massage alternatives. Chinese owner/practitioner. 
First deep tissue massage was excellent for a long enduring herniated disk.  
Prices higher than the cities, but the convenience and absence of driving, tolls, and gasoline costs, make this quite reasonable.
Very comfortable environment and dedicated owner.
Will definitely go again.

8.27.13 I have been back twice since the first visit/review.  Jinrong, the Master Massage Therapist, knows where the problem lies, and her hands find the pressure and trigger points to work.  An hour of a little discomfort when she digs in, but weeks of relief when she is finished opened the facet joints and calming the nerve roots.

Happy Hour Tavern is in a small commercial strip on Veteran's Highway, and quite easy to miss. Effort should be made to find it if a friendly working man's bar is what you like.  

They have a fairly broad beer list, both tap and glass. The kitchen isn't exciting, but it does a decent job with the basics.  The important aspect is the atmosphere.  It is a cozy, unassuming place, where you can sit at the bar over a good crafty, shoot the breeze with some great storytellers, and walk out with change.  

Most significantly, they have one of the rare shuffle board games - complete with sawdust needed to keep the oak surface slick.  Love that game. It ought to be an Olympic sport. Way more exciting than curling.  

No. I wouldn't bring a date here, but when I want a hidden place to sit, think, smooze, and feel the cool weight of shuffle disks in my hand, Happy Hour Tavern does the trick.

It was a quiet Sunday night at Basil Leaf, the Vietnam/Asian Fusion restaurant in the Village of Newtown Shopping Center.  I had the place all to myself.  Looking around, I had the sense of being in the antechamber of an Asian palace. Dark tones, bamboo, the sound of a flowing stream.  Very comforting.  But, why was the place empty but for me?

Honestly, I don't know after eating some very good Southeast Asian cuisine tonight.  Vegetable Soup (Chicken Broth, but Veggie broth available) was piping hot and very tasty with lots of snow pea pods, broccoli and carrots.  Spicy Lemongrass with Chicken (nicely presented wok-fried dish with a really good tangy hot sauce and plenty of tender pieces of thin cut white meat), and Jasmine White Rice (softer than regular white rice); Ginseng Tea for a healthy chaser.  

I know they were closed for lunch for a while, but I was advised lunch resumes this week.  Still closed on Tuesdays. 

Bottom Line - I was totally satisfied, and will return. The cost of the meal as described, $20.  Maybe, the tea ($4) should be gratis in a nice place like this.  That would bring the cost down to a very reasonable dinner expense.

I don't want to forget to mention the service was friendly, knowledgeable and timely. Thanks, Jackie.

Brothers Pizza has been a cornerstone in Langhorne for years, and the new shop in the converted Shell/Texaco station at the corner of Pine and Maple makes it into an institution.  

The restaurant is well designed with ample booths with high backs providing much more privacy than the old place.  There is a nice dining room that is separated by wood and glass doors from the take out/cashier area.  There is a level of comfort now that was missing in the earlier iteration.  

The pizza and tomato pie are good, but not exceptional.  The crust is firm and crunchy and holds the weight of the toppings securely. The sauce and cheese are above average, but are not homemade with chunky tomatoes, nor likely shredded in house.  The Eggplant Parm Grinder is one of the best in the area, with fresh Italian loaf, nicely pan fried Eggplant and the same pizza sauce and cheese as on the pizza.  The sandwich is returned to the oven before serving, toasting the top edge of the meal, melting the cheese, and exciting the entire mix to a higher level that tastes great with wonderful texture when eaten.  I really like it.  

Service is attentive.  I recognize one waitress as being with Brothers for many years.  She and her compatriots do a good job.  The prices are reasonable, and cheaper than the same meal down the hill in Newtown.  

The joint is busy at lunch and dinner. The new space is barely adequate for the crowd.  Glad that their business has responded well to their new digs.

There are two listings for this supermarket, with this one containing the store number.
Be sure to look for both to find all reviews.

Gluten is not a problem for me, but I am always happy to find a new bakery in town. Whether cupcakes, breads, donuts or other pastries, I am game to give them a try. 

The Happy Mixer in the Summit Square Shopping Center pays a steep rent to bake and sell their sweet delights. Hope they can appeal to enough people to make them successful, although a shop as limited as they are in this area is going to be challenged. Still, I stopped in to sample a few donuts and mini cakes to see what the hubbub was all about. 

I took a few bites of their apple cider donut with maple glaze frosting, the coconut crunchy donut, and the mini lemon pound cake.  My impression was that they did a very good job on the cake part of each of them, but that the icing was still a work in progress. The base of each had a good moist texture that tasted as fresh as today.  Liked it a lot.

 The glazing on each was stronger in flavor than expected, so much so that I found it was distracting from the overall enjoyment of each piece. It was thick, and easily flaked away from the underlying cake. The maple and lemon in particular felt like they were not really part of the donut or loaf, and the intensity of the flavors felt somewhat contrived to dominate the creation, rather than integrate with it. The lemon was very unusual and did not taste natural. Perhaps, too much extract was used. In any event, two bites were enough of that. Hopefully, a more mellow version will become available. 

The shop is small and cute, with young assistants to take your order and ring it up. $13 and change for six pieces.  Everyone wants local business to succeed, and hopefully The Happy Mixer will find its niche in the community, with high quality baked goods that are far superior to the well known chains.

Basil Leaf appears to be closed or out of business. 
The blinds are drawn closed, and there is poster board covering the glass door. A business card from the Health Department attached to the door asked for a phone call. 
Hopefully, this is a temporary situation.
Will keep Yelp advised...

Although hard to find sitting on the second floor of the mostly Vietnamese shopping center at 11th and Washington, if you are into strong handed traditional Chinese massage, this place is worth the hunt.  

After an exceptional meal nearby, we retreated to V & V for a foot massage.  This normally includes a brief full body massage while your feet soak in very hot herbed water to soften them up, while reclining comfortably in a large adjustable easy chair.  It has taken me several years to be able to put my sensitive feet into the near-scalding soup, but I finally can do it and actually enjoy it.  

The first squeeze of my trapezius let me know my masseuse meant business.  Ouch! She knew the pressure points, meridians, and even a few pleasure points along the way.  Her English was just good enough to say, "relax."  Easy for her to say...

The foot portion of the hour was equally intense.  She triggered the deep sole points as she attempted to explain her concept of reflexology.  She would show me a place on my foot, and then say the body part of correspondence.  All the while her skilled and amazing strong hands prodded and dug, releasing the pain and tension I live with most days 

It was an excellent massage. 

At $50 for the hour, the price was decent, but no where near the $25 paid in New York's Chinatown or Flushing for the same work.  Still, there is a lot to be said for saving time, tolls and gas, so the cost was probably a savings, even with the expected $20 per first hour tip.

The Cake Box on Farnsworth Avenue in historic Bordentown, NJ, is a mellow country town cupcake house that also offers great La Colombe coffee, and a chill place to stop for dessert and java after a good meal down the street. The cuppies are small, with the head of buttercream frosting at least as high as it cake base. So, you have room for one after dinner. 

I stopped by after court in Mt. Holly on my way to the Trenton office. The room has aged well, with white tile and old wood all around. The glass display is big enough to show the dozen or so alternatives cupcakes available that day. I was more interested in coffee renewal, but still wanted to sample one these beauties. The blueberry lemon sounded good. I took a seat at a small table up front to enjoy the streetview on a perfect autumn day. 

The icing was a sugary blonde bouffant hairdo. It wasn't overly sweet, which allowed it's creaminess to shine through. The cake bottom was moist and firm like a solid white cake. I liked it, but a little bigger biteage would have pleased me more. The coffee was excellent, and the La Colombe beans were available for purchase.

$2.75 per cupcake. A great addition to the awakening that is happening in the Town 
Borden.

A fun and challenging course, especially for a public facility. Reminds of the wild rough and smallish greens of the British Open courses like St. Andrews in Scotland.  

Apres golf in the cozy clubhouse is also a pleasure with a small bar and room for a small dinner party. 

Also can't complain that it is the club nearest home.

Lexi Lu's Café is a strange setup.  

Up front it is a well designed, attractive take out shop.  Walk past their kitchen and it is Amoroso's Flower Shop, where you can still buy a bouquet of roses for your anniversary.  Love the adaptive reuse of this old storefront on S. Broad Street, Trenton; right across from the very old courthouse.  It is hard to find driving by, and there are seldom parking spaces within the surrounding area.  But, if you work or live in the neighborhood, or go to the new civil or criminal courts, you can walk over and pick up soup, sandwich, breakfast muffin, etc., on your way to the office.  It closes at 2:00 pm.  

Service is exemplary given how small the space is.  The two friendlies who helped me out were attractive and efficient.  One made up my grilled chicken chipotle wrap, while the other provided the history of the business and worked the register.  Both were happy to pose for photos when I pulled out my Yelp screen after ordering.  You can see the results.  

The lunch was very good.  Fresh, quality ingredients and TLC.  Plenty of stuffing for a large wrap.  It was enough for two meals.  @ $8.50, it was a spectacular deal.  

Too bad there is no place to sit, because the room is comfy in a cramped way, and it would be nice to absorb more atmosphere from the winsome workers.

After a pleasant exchange of messages with the owner of Langhorne Coffee House, I learned that the eggs are bathed in Italian Sparkling Water to create the light texture I described in my earlier review. Apparently, a family secret from the Old Country (the best kind of cooking secrets).  

Knowing the truth of the matter, my impression has changed for the better.  An extra star is warranted, not only for the discovery of how the meal was made, but also for the wonderful extra step that continues a family tradition to be shared with the world.

Every once and a while you enter a world so unusual that the experience is just as much anthropological as a chance to eat unexpectedly connected cuisines. This happened last night when we ventured into Asian Mix Restaurant just off Haldeman Avenue in far Northeast Philadelphia. This little piece of urban heaven has a fair share of Chinese, Korean, Russian Georgian and Uzbek kitchens, but this was my first time sitting down for a dinner of Korean/Uzbek/Ukrainian dishes springing naturally from the life of one family. 

Imagine leaving Korea as a child with parents and siblings for a new home in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, on the western fringe of Asia along the ancient Silk Road. Assimilating what you could in that crossroads city, and then moving further east to Kiev, Ukraine, and ultimately a generation after first departure, arriving in the City of Brotherly Love. More adaptation. More Integration. 

Your grown children don't speak Korean, but are fluent in Uzbek, Russian and English. They open a restaurant offering what they learned to cook along the way; a menu equal shares spicy kimchee, soups, salads stuffed pastas and exotically prepared meats, chicken and fish. From these offerings, we selected potato Pierogi, kimchee, Ukrainian borscht and schnitzel made from ground chicken, turkey and beef ("A Family Feast") with a tomato/cabbage side salad with excellent balsamic vinaigrette. 

It was all a little strange, but also very good. The pierogi looked like Chinese dumplings, with thin skin and a bit too watery mashed potatoes filling. Still very enjoyable. A dollop of sour cream implied eastern European sensibilities. Similarly, the borscht was a rich deep red served hot with mushrooms, beans and chunks of meat for flavoring. Very different than my grandmother's interpretation from Galacia that served this cold with a simple hot boiled potato and sour cream. Liked it alot. The kimchee was excellent and very spicy, the way it is done in the northern peninsula. The schnitzel had a nice walnut cream sauce, but was really more sliced meatloaf lightly fried, than a breaded fillet. Very good, but perhaps misnamed. The accompanying salad was a strong contributor to the plate. 

As we ate, we saw that part of the owner's family was sitting in back with young children. They looked to be Korean, but as I walked by they were speaking Russian and English. I had the urge to sit with them and ask about their lives and long immigration story. 

I knew it was the stuff of family legend.

Out of town friends chose to stay at the Radisson Hotel Philadelphia Northeast for a few nights while visiting the area.  I tried to tell them in advance that the hotel was not really in Philadelphia at all, but just beyond the city limits in Bucks County.  I also described the neighborhood as groaty old Route 1, auto dealers, by the hour motels, and garish liquor stores. They didn't care. The price was right, and they wanted to shop in the surrounding malls.  

I went to see them there a couple of times. Parking was easy with a big lot.  The building looked a bit dated, but still highly functional.  Nice atrium in the lobby.  Cool black and whites of historic buildings in Philly.  A decent bar and free breakfast.  Clean, comfortable rooms.  Small bathrooms. 

They managed to eat at several interesting places within a short distance (Steve's Prince of Steaks, Andy's Diner, Mission BBQ, Starbucks, to name a few).  They had nothing but good things to say about the place, other than they wished they had stayed in Center City, and could just put their horses in the stable and walk around town.  

Maybe next time.

When Macy's does an after-sale sale, and the prices are up to 80% off the original, I can find useful, quality merchandise in the Men's Department.  The area is clean, organized and fairly relaxed for finding a style and quality I like.  

At those discounts the value is greatly enhanced and it can compete with the deep dive price warehouses like TJ Maxx and Target. 

Just picked up a couple of very nice sweaters at very attractive prices.  You don't even need to bring all those coupons that arrive in the mail or online.  The cashier will willingly give every discount available as you check out.

When it's 96 in the shade, it is okay to give yourself permission to cool down and chill out with some quality ice cream.  Finding myself in the northern wilds of Bucks County on a visit to Ockanickon Boy Scout Reservation on an unforgiving day under the broiling sun, I  wove my way down twisting two lanes into the oasis town of Plumsteadville. The blacktop mirage rippled its shimmer view, making the buildings appear to float.  

I spied the Plumsteadville Inn, and right next to it, Chubby's.  Normally, I don't like ice cream before 5, and prefer not to eat it alone. But, this was an exception.  I needed to lower my body temp before I started to act on my hallucinations.  I walked in, and the AC hit me hard.  Two angels came to my aid, offering to provide me with cool scoops of any flavor I could imagine.  Because it was my first time in heaven they handled me a Golden Ruler as a gift (see photo).  They said it would help me stay "measured." 

It was up to me to design the proper elixir to counteract the heat.  Intuition led me to Salted Caramel and Black Cherry. It was lovingly served me in a styro cup, for under $5.  The angelic smiles as I tossed the change into their prayer jar will not be forgotten.  

By the time I walked the short distance to my car the ice cream was already melting.  I tasted both before I would be required to drink from the cup.  Sheer excellence.  Cool, creamy, sweet, salty, chunky, chewy - Ambrosia of the Gods.  What else do angels serve on a sweltering day?

ArcAngel Chubby does not make his own ice cream.  It is Nelson's Ice Cream, made in Royersford, Pa.  It may not be the bestest ice cream I have ever tasted, but on a day like today when shoes stick to pavement, it came straight from Valhalla.

This Popeye's Chicken shack sits in a long commercial strip on Trenton Road, Morrisville, Pa.  It is a standard franchise for the company.  The space is clean and attractive, with a well hidden drive thru component around to the back.  

I went in the other evening for a light dinner and to help nourish my life long Southern Fried Chicken addiction. I just can't seem to get enough.  Love the crunch and the hot oil burning my fingers. Love the spicy coat.  Love the way it pulls away from the bone with a little coaxing. 

These days, fried chicken is offered on the more sophisticated menus, and even for breakfast with waffles for those who just want max carb load.  (I'm not there yet.)  But, just because someone with a chef's hat and culinary school degree puts a batch together doesn't mean it is any better than the cheaper, faster, mass produced variety.  In fact, there is a school of thought that fried chicken is like singing the blues.  You know; "You have to suffer if you want to sing the blues..." Those hands playing six string acoustic or even Lucille, bring something to the experience that can be felt deep in the soul.  

Chicken be that way, too.  The true fried chicken artists, like the best Delta or Hills Blues guitarists and singers, are rooted in a culture and existential angst that generates the creative instinct leading to emotionally charged performances.  Those same forces are at work with fried chicken.  In the hands of a master, the chicken becomes an extension of his life, the same way a great song emerges from that primordial place deep in the heart.

This 2 piece box o' chicken may not have been epic, but it was solid and even inspired this review.  So, even though we weren't sitting in Muscle Shoals, Alabama in a roadside chicken house, there was enough there to let the imagination run wild.

Just wish they actually played that music at Popeye's, rather than the current soundtrack.

I realize that I sometimes live in a fantasy world, but there are times when reality presents itself as phantasm. 

So it was when I opened the old wooden door and entered The Hob Tavern.  Yes. They say the letters stand for "Heart of Bordentown," but there is another deeper meaning.  Bordentown has a rich if mysterious history of being the place where Napoleon Bonaparte was spirited away from Elba by French royalists who wanted to protect him from the republican elements at work in France, and hide him until the time was right for the 3rd Empire.  What better place than a tiny hamlet in the New World where his family owned a vacation home on a rise overlooking a wild Delaware River? Who would notice a small man speaking French walking around the village?  

Too, it is easy to imagine entering Middle Earth and sitting in a Hobbit home while here. It is dark and glowing with friendly inhabitants that are inviting and have an open kitchen for all who visit.  So, if you give yourself time to consider the possibilities, and settle in, you could have quite an adventure. 

The HOB is a dive in the best sense of the word.  It is a locals bar one block off of the main Farnsworth Avenue.  The streets back there are narrow, and the homes are small.  There is plenty of beer, and the kitchen remains "grill on" until 1:00 am on weekends.  Prices are ridiculously low.  The homemade soups are great.  The menu options for sandwiches, burgers, salads, etc., remarkably diverse.  The quality is several steps above bar food.  

Try to go on an off hour to enjoy the environment before the crowd hides that from you.  Weekday lunch until 5 is a good window.  

Let us know what you think.

Lion Dog in the Campus Town commercial zone on the campus of The College of New Jersey, is a take out only hot dog shop. It offers an extensive menu of frankfurters and sausage varieties, fries and soft drinks for the "dog" lovers in your world. Being one of them, I looked forward to stopping by to taste their merchandise. Took care of business today.

It took a circling of the block to spy Lion Dog, and around again to locate parking. Walking in I realized I would not be dining there as there were no tables, nor counters. Okay, I'll bring something home. I ordered the Italian Hot Dog with Sabrett Kosher beef woofer, and watched as the owner prepared the sandwich at the grill. I saw pieces of green pepper, potato wedges and the frank grilling up and packed into a torpedo sized roll, followed by a long squiggled squirt of brown mustard. I asked for Lenny's World Famous Pepper Hash on the side for application at home. 

Turned out the hash was a nice addition with a vinegar sweetness and carrot chips, onion and maybe a little celery. I also added some ketchup for extra zing. 

It was a good rendition of the Trenton originated hot dog creation, the Casino Dog. The Sabrett kept it's strong garlicy character, and allowed the rest of the pieces to harmonize with each jaw clenching bite. It would have been even better had there been double dogs and green frying peppers within a fresher roll from Italian People's Bakery, as the original did. 

Bring that to life and Lion Dog would have a true special. 

PRO QUESTION - What is the name of The College of New Jersey mascot? 

ANSWER - Roscoe the Lion.

Grab-N-Go Bagel & Deli sits in the same commercial strip as Le Soleil Bakery and China Boys Restaurant. It is a neighborhood convenience store with a strong deli and grill department for good breakfasts and lunches.  Their inventory includes fresh bagels, muffins, and the right breads for making a superior Boar's Head sandwich.  They also offer Eight O'clock Coffee, the old A&P brand.  I have never seen it brewed for sale before.  

My simple Onion Bagel, Butter and Swiss was prepared smartly, wrapped in foil and bagged in a minute.  With medium coffee, the $3.50 price was a true bargain.  Even better, the bagel was plump and freshly crisp on the outside and softly chewy within.  Can't be sure, but they may have gotten these babies from Bagel Stop over on Hamilton Ave.  I enjoyed the sandwich and the coffee cup sits on my desk as I write this review.  Still tastes good. 

While this is not primarily a bagel shop, they can be forgiven because the rounders they do have are good, and the rest of their products are first rate, as long as you like Boar's Head. 

Fast, friendly service.  Management on site.

Oh, Yeah....they also sell hookahs!

It is best to be a bit contrary to enjoy The Franklin Fountain.

Long and narrow shop with authentic antique early Americana, and the oldest working soda fountain in the USA, the place is worth a visit or two for that alone.  Servers in costume make it feel a bit touristy, but considering the entire facility is OLD, I can excuse the attempt at the Williamsburg effect.  

But, in ice cream season the place is packed, often with lines onto the sidewalk.  So, if you don't mind eating ice cream in somewhat cooler weather, go anytime between October and April, or later in the evening, and the lines are gone.  

The overall gestalt is very pleasant and it is obvious why TFF is a known destination. The ice cream is good, but not among the pantheon of ice cream greats.  The prices are high and not related to the quality nor quantity of the prime product. Too, it is CASH ONLY, something that is rather annoying given the expense of the product and the obvious fact that they can afford the extra bank card fees.  

Bottom Line - Worth a visit for the experience and extra time in this oldest section of Philadelphia. But, they do themselves a disservice by not having credit card access, and failing to have air conditioning.

This tiny Spanish pizza joint is tucked in between a vape shop and an organic dry cleaner, and is very easy to miss, but AJ's is worth finding.  It is a family run business with the kids doing their homework at the back booth while mom and dad cook up a very good facsimile of authentic Italian food.  

I stopped in last evening to see what it was all about and to satisfy my hunger.  Warmly greeted, I perused the menu and ordered the Eggplant Parm Sandwich and a drink.  While waiting, I observed the daughter working on a book report, while her infant brother was being entertained by an older sibling.  Mom worked as the chief chef and cashier, while a couple of other guys helped out, all the while keeping up a lively conversation en Espanol.  

The food arrived with the mozza melted over the top of the eggplant and filing the valley made by the open torpedo roll.  First bite, very hot, but tender nightshade nicely contrasted by the well toasted and crunchy roll.  Surprisingly, the thin slices of eggplant were not breaded, but were allowed to stand for themselves.  Gratitude for the calorie saving.  The overall consumption was a pleasure, with even the olive oil adding to the experience.  

AJ Pizza could use some elbow grease in the corners to avoid being a dive, but the dining was fine.  I will return to explore further.  And, at $6.50 for the big sandy, they well matched the local gentry and the jingle in my pocket.

UPDATE : APRIL 4, 2018

Stopped in this afternoon for a late lunch, and in a pasta aglio olio mood. The menu offered it with broccoli, but chef was happy to make it with spinach. For $7.95 it came with a small side salad and three of their garlic knots.  

I should have further asked for penne, because what arrived on a large square plate was spaghetti with plenty of sauteed spinach and thin sliced garlic. Not a biggie, but I laughed at myself for missing that detail. Laughed again when I had to ask for a soup spoon in order to be able to spin it onto the fork for neat consumption. Details. 

When I finally got down to it, the taste was very good and enjoyable. The biggest surprise on the upside was  the garlic knots that were hand delivered wrapped in aluminum foil a few minutes later. They were amazingly excellent! Great texture, perfectly baked and brought to life by the oven flame. Spiced and crunchy with strong garlicy flavor, and designed to sponge all the aglio olio swimming in the bottom of the platter. Best of breed. 

AJ's doesn't look like much, and could use some TLC, but if you can look beyond that, you can find some decent grub and even some awesome details.

Manny Brown's is in the Summit Square Shopping Center, down the strip from Giant Supermarket, and close by Moishe & Itzy's Deli.  

How much more interesting both places would be if they knocked down the wall and served each other's customers.  Pastrami and beer, and 13 TVs would be a boon to both.  Maybe, this will start them talking.  I know they are not directly next to each other, but why should that stop the integration of interests?

Manny's is a friendly place with a game plan of serving a good mix of draft crafty beer, and a decent bar menu.  It does not have the room to offer the alternatives of Isaac Newton's, nor the diveyness of The Clubhouse to be a buffalo wing sports bar, but falls somewhere between the two.  Neither is the clientele the same as those mentioned.  It is not as yuppified as Isaac's, nor as dank and noisy as Clubhouse.  It servers those who are somewhere in the middle on the day they choose to go there.  It provides a reasonable alcohol component, satisfying grub and sports with the sound turned down.  A good compromise on the right occasion. 

I was there on a Saturday afternoon during the World Cup.  The bar was mostly empty except for a few couples as tables awaiting lunch.  I was looking for a quick bite as I selected which TV monitor to watch.  I went with their Burger and Fries - a juicy half pounder with Sautéed Onions, Melted Swiss, and a large pile of Fries, and the Columbia v. Greece match.  I relaxed with a Domestic Draft awaiting service of my lunch, and chatted with the bartender trainee and her manager.  They were friendly, and clearly into their jobs.  

The Burger was quite satisfying and would qualify as comfort food on those nights when necessary.  The price at under $10. for the meal was an excellent deal.  

I wondered why I did not go there more often, and resolved to remedy that oversight in the near future.

Not sure how this one got passed the filters, but Broad St Car Wash and Broad Street Car Wash are one in the same.  

They both do a very good job cleaning my vehicle of all the ashiness that covers the sheet metal (polymer) after snow and salt get finished turning the wheels into a ghost. 

If I had to choose between one or the other, I would probably choose Street, as St implies sainthood, and I doubt that this "Shine On Line" operation is on the short list for canonization. 

Although, there are times I thank the Almighty for creating this automated wonder of the world.

Great to spend the morning in Fishtown having breakfast at the Milkcrate Cafe at the corner of E. Columbia and Girard. Interesting enviro with a huge record collection spanning music of the late 20th/early 21st Centuries. I didn't make it down to the vinyl shop in the basement (just read about it in their Yelp page), but as a holder of old wax, I wish I had. Next time. 

Still, the cafe is part of the gentrification of this part of Philly and is in the perfect location to take advantage of it. It is a bit dusty around the edges, but with La Colombe coffee holding court and a good kitchen, it offers a mellow sitdown and strong java flow, with comfort food designed for the pioneering spirit of the surrounding neighborhood. Easy to spend hours there sipping joe and doing light sledding on your screen. 

Loved the caffeine and found the well stuffed "Flying Breakfast Burrito Brother" a large tasty bite and chew. It was hot and moist and almost more than I could eat; but I managed to slay that dragon, and spend a few extra minutes watching the street life on Girard Avenue on a cold sunny morn. 

It would be great to have a home on one of the narrow streets of this old revivalist corner of P.delph, but until that day arrives, Milkcrate will just have to be that place I can feel at home.

Great Valley Diner on Route 30 in Malvern, PA, sits in a former fast food structure, but aside from the general boxy nature of the space, it has escaped its past, and now looks something like what it is - a kitchen for three squares a day. It has a small counter with three or four spinners, and a dining room with a dozen or so booths and tables. The menu has all the usual suspects, especially breakfast, with a full list of egg/omelet, pancake/french toast possibilities and decent coffee served in red mugs. 

I went with their Italian Omelet, but subbed feta cheese for their regular provolone.  No sweat.  It was served less than ten minutes later and was quite good, with crispy home fries and rye toast.  There were plenty of sweet sausage, onion and pepper in addition to the fresh feta.  Service was provided by a family member, who was pleasant and attentive.  My red mug was refilled twice without request. 

Adequate parking. Exiting from the connecting shopping plaza onto Route 30, a bit confusing. 

3.5 STARS

Cheesecake Factory may be the quintessential modern American diner. Huge diverse menu and awesome desserts. Yeah, it doesn't exactly look like a stainless roadside palace; designed to appear more like a massive adobe warehouse on the outside and something out of the fantasiful Arabian Nights, within. While not a regular visitor, sometimes it is exactly what I am looking for, especially when the answer to every existential question is, "cheesecake!"

It certainly filled that bill last night. We weren't sure what we wanted for dinner, but knew what we didn't. Tired of checking off all the ethnic styles available within driving distance and eliminating most of them, we came to Cheesecake Factory. It had dishes from all continents, a bar, and those awesome creamy sweet cool desserts. Perfect cure for indecisiveness. We drove to Willow Grove in about 30. The expansive hall was busy but not full. We were seated immediately near the bar.

We caught the final minutes of happy hour and celebrated with half price glasses of an excellent cabernet. We selected the Crispy Brussel Sprouts for an appetizer (wonderfully done with bacon and maple syrup), and their Southwest Chicken Sandwich (strong contender in a crunchy baguette and spicy aioli), and Shepherd's Pie (savory ground beef and veggies in mushroom gravy topped with a load of mashed potatoes and melted cheese). Toasting our way through the meal, we completed with a flourish of a thick slice of shared almond cheesecake (they bake them right). 

This was a full and fun dinner that permitted us to chose cravings that we didn't know we had. We couldn't finish any of it, and brought enough home for another meal. Cheesecake Factory may not see us again for a while, but it's good to know it's there when we need the modern American diner to help us decide what to eat.

El Changarro ( "small shop") in Mexican Spanish slang,  is exactly that - a small grocery/variety store with a Mexican Guatamaltecan kitchen and dining room in the rear. Like most of the other Latina cocinas in and around Bucks County, it caters to the growing population from south of that border so much in the news lately. (Have to say from observation that there are many more good cooks and entrepreneurs entering the USA, than undesirables. I guess the wall is to limit the number of Mexican restaurants setting up businesses around the country.) Please excuse the editorial. 

So, I was there for a weekend dinner recently having learned about the joint on Yelp. As directed, I walked through the store to the dining area in back. It was pretty big. About a dozen tables nicely spaced,  colorful mural on the walls and wood carved people with amusing faces and traditional costume all around. The gestalt back there was definitely a little reality altering. It almost became a Mexican town square. 

Food was ordered at the kitchen window and delivered to the table. My order was taken by a bilingual young guy. It was prepared by three women who were not. The menu had most of the usual suspects and house made bebidas and liquidas frescas. I went with an al pastor quesadilla rather than three tacos, to increase the contents and reduce the amount of tortilla. It was served about 10 minutes later. It was plump from all the spicy roast pork, beans, lettuce, tomato, pineapple and queso. It required knife and fork to avoid spillage. 

Liked it a lot. Plenty of flavor and texture. Moist, too. I spread red salsa on top to ensure adequate burn. Filled me completely and left a pleasant belch at the finish. Ahh. 

Right down Street Road from Parx Casino, in a shopping center with plenty of parking. Worth a trip.

All the usual suspects on the breakfast and lunch menu at Hatboro TNT Diner, and surprisingly good prices, too. That explains the dominance of the social security crowd. They know a good deal when they see one. 

True, this is formerly a Wendy's burger house, and the outlines of the old small version franchise from the 1980s shows. Still, it is clean, well run and has a friendly serving staff capable of keeping you coffee cup full and quality small talk. This is an adaptive reuse that still works in the 21st. 

My french toast was a well made two slice platter which was enough for me, decent sausage patties and a bottomless cup of java. I've had worse at twice the price. 

What it lacks in local color, it makes up for in solid deliverables and stirling repartee with staff.

 Thanks, Debbie.

Generally speaking, the Chinese restaurants in the far Northeast Philadelphia have been disappointing. Most seem to have settled into a "good enough" attitude when it comes to their kitchens, with little effort for excellence, nor originality. It is regrettable that the locals have few decent choices until they are prepared to travel farther down Bustleton, or all the way to Chinatown for a good meal.  

One of the few exceptions to such poor performances is Taste Queen on Krewstown Road, just off Grant Avenue.  We settled in there for dinner late last week, and found it to be refreshingly concerned about quality cooking and satisfied knowledgeable customers. While it is accurate to called the "Queen" a study in pink as others mention, that eye-irritant is soon forgotten when dinner is brought to the table.  We were able to request a higher heat quotient than normal from our Hunan Chicken and Orange Beef, and actually have it prepared as we wished.  Both were large platters, with extra spicy black bean sauce on the chicken, and real Szechuan peppers mixed in with the tender beef.  They were so satisfying that we did not need to ask for more sesame oil or chili sauce. Very good job!

What was even more surprising was their rendition of Pumpkin Soup, on their Specials Board.  It was rich, creamy and very fresh.  Someone in the kitchen knows a thing or two about non-Chinese cuisine. 

Service was friendly and prompt, and the server didn't mind me practicing my baby Chinese.  She was quite amused. 

Finally an above average Chinois joint within range of home that meets our expectations for good Middle Kingdom dishes.  

Return guaranteed.

This may now be La Parrilla Steakhouse, but for me it will always also be DeLorenzo's on Hamilton Avenue, Trenton, NJ.  I was there too many times eating excellent pizza to be able to forget what came before. 

Ho Hum.

But, that is not to say that this new Guatemaltecan meat house is not a very worthy successor.  It certainly is.  Where most Latino restaurants in and around the capital city are geared to feeding the neighborhood in a very down-country homey and comfortable dive (in a good way), La Parrilla has higher aspirations.  It is a degree or two fancier than most other casas, and the focus is primarily on meat in all forms, as opposed to handling the desires of the larger populous.  It offers 3 squares a day, like many others do, but does it in a somewhat more upscale environment.  The HDTVs and air conditioning were all working well, so there was no need to feel like I was living in Central America in order to enjoy their cuisine (although, I admit to liking that authenticity by necessity, too).

Although I really enjoy Central American kitchens, something on their menu caught my eye - the Guayo Burger.  I decided to check out this crossover dish to see how they would interpret this North American standard.  In addition to the expected Chips & Salsa (good), the large plate arrived with a 1/3 pound burger, done to my requested medium, with Lettuce, Onion, Spicy Mayo and broken Potato Chips inside.  Along side was a massive pile of French Fries, nice and crisp.  The roll had sesame seeds and reminded of a Whopper.  The real stand out was the mixture of taste and texture with each chomp.  It was very good, but not so foreign as to lose sight of its origination.  If they had stuffed some of the fries inside the sandwich, it would have been a dead ringer for an Animalized In N Out Burger.  A few grilled Jalapenos would have been totally over the top.  Still, it was very satisfying just as it was.  

The homemade Horchata was excellently made; the rice and cinnamon blended drink, cold and so refreshing.  The whole meal came to under $12. 

Def want to come back to try some of their BBQ grilled meats.  

PRO TIP - Street parking only, so try to come early or late as parking around there on Hamilton Avenue can be challenging.  Side streets offer more opportunities.

This was my first visit to Chili Szechuan since its relocation from Baltimore Avenue in West Philly.  It is certainly larger than before, and its booths and dark tones, more cozy than before. It has always offered authentic Szechuan spicy cuisine from Chongqing, China, but now it even adds the reality of many restaurants especially in the northern climes, of being chilly temperature-wise in winter.  We appreciated the cultural use of cold weather and wore our coats during the meal in honor of the reminiscent freeze in the house. Brrrr....

The food was as good as before. Spicy Lamb Chops, Szechuan Chili Sauce Fish Fillets, Eggplant in Garlic Sauce and Crispy Shrimp - Sweet & Sour, were our choices. They were all good to great, although our waiter admitted that even on the non-Americanized menu, they cut the heat for a western customer. So, even though we were mostly Chinese at the table, we all suffered through reduced burn and numbness. Next time, we will insist on the full monty fire treatment. We can all handle it!

The dishes arrived as prepared by the kitchen, and not all at once. Thus, the spicy lamb chops made the first impression of the night. They were excellent; with enough cumin and pepper to heat the tongue and gums, but not anesthetize them. Fun finger food.  Next came the eggplant in garlic sauce.  It, too, was a strong contender, with plenty of Chinese nightshade and a thick, rich dark amber coat. It could have been hotter, as the innate sweetness of the veggie dominated the other flavors, and needed more competition from Szechuan chilies. The shrimp was delivered next.  It was good, with 10 jumbos in an orange glaze. However, it was far more sweet than sour, and suffered most from Americanization syndrome. It really needed a blast from the smelter to bring out its hidden attributes. Finally, the Szechuan chili sauce fish fillets arrived in a deep dish to accommodate the soupy red hot bath it cooked in.  This dish was excellent and packed the most punch.  Tender pieces of boneless flounder is a beautiful orange/red conglomerated hot liquid.  Finally, a little numbness!

We passed on their dessert options, as they were not Chinese, and all came from an outside vendor.  The hot tea was from a non-descript bag, rather than loose pack.  Not so good. 

Overall, Chili Szechuan was a worthwhile trip on a cold winter night, yet it would do itself a favor by fixing the heating equipment, not making assumptions about "round eyes," and upgrading their tea choices. While these are mostly secondary considerations, they do detract from the experience.  As such, it really can't compare holistically to Han Dynasty or the other Hot Houses in Philly, where those details mean something.

Very good Cantonese house on Race Street near 9th, with front of the house glassed in roasting kitchen and regular food preparation room in back for the rest of the menu. Our server advised that the chef was Fuzhounese. Regardless of his beginnings, he knew his way around a South Chinese chopchop. 

The dining room was small, even by Ctown standards. Maybe 7 tables altogether. The food list was extensive, and we settled on Hong Kong Wonton Vegetable Soup (very good), Salt & Pepper Spare Ribs (excellent) and Beef Chow Fun (excellent). All dishes were substantial and we had plenty more than the two of us could handle, and a large amount to take home. On top of that, before leaving we picked up a pound of sliced roast pork because it looked so good hanging in the window. It was delicious and we worked through it for the next week. It was lean with thin layer of fat under the crispy brown dermis. 

Lau Kee reminded of Ting Wong, a worthy place for a solid meal across the traditional food groups of Cantonese cuisine, with a comfort level that was inviting to regular visits for families or octogenarians on a date. Prices quite reasonable, too.

The Five Four Bar & Grill takes its moniker from the local zip code for this part of Levittown, Pa.  It is a fairly new house with large rooms for the bar, dining and even two pool tables for those so inclined.  Friday and Saturday nights starting around 9:30 local bands rock the casbah. The crowd is a mix of ages and interests, but have found a neighborhood spot where everyone is welcome, the drinks are not expensive, and the kitchen turns out reasonable good bar food and a few higher end dinner specials.  It is a non-smoking establishment. 

We sat in a booth near the green felt tables, a little distance from the bar, but close by the stage.  We didn't mind when the pool cues invaded our space. We just moved the beer bottles and pint glasses to the other side.  Sharing is caring.  The Labatt Blue Draft was cold and refreshing, and the Coney Island Orange Vanilla Cider tasted like Brooklyn summer on the beach.  The prices from the multi-paged beer list were surprisingly low, especially after patronizing some other bars up county.  

Dinner consisted of a Burger, Chicken Tender Wrap and Chicken Parm Sandwich.  All came with crisped French Fries.  They were all good, if not outstanding.  The Plain Burger with Cheese, Lettuce, Onion and Tomato was on a decent fresh roll, and came out slightly beyond the Medium requested.  Still good, but not memorable.  The Wrap disappeared quietly without complaint, and my Parmesan was also tasty on another good roll and enough red gravy.  None of these dishes were large, but given the price range, were more than enough for a light bite. Service was very friendly and prompt.  We were satisfied, but did not understand why silverware was not provided for the meals without request.  No biggie, but seemed odd.   

Unfortunately, we had to depart before the band came on, but Five Four is worth a return visit later on a weekend evening to catch the show.

You would not be surprised by the total "shackiness" of Smoke 'n Dudes if their cabin was surrounded by forest rather than parking lot.  Outside was a large trailered-up grill/smoker ready to be hitched and taken on the road.  Step inside, and the knotty pine paneling and wood plank tables with red checkered cloths put you in a mind of a backcountry store where BBQ and moonshine are a way of life up there in the Smokey Mountains outside Ashville or Gatlinburg.

The menu is small reflecting the size of the joint.  In for lunch, the friendly server showed me the specials menu, and I opted for the Pulled Pork Sandwich with Cheddar and Sautéed Onions on a fresh oversized smooth topped Roll.  It came with chips, but for a buck extra, fries could be subbed in.  While I waited I sipped on my Lemonade and listened to the banter between the employees.  This might be Bensalem, but the accents and topics of conversation were straight from the southern Appalachians. I was right there with 'em. 

The sandwich arrive full-plate, and I opened it up to have a look-see, and taste a small sample.  First impression was of a fully smoked meaty lean pork; good texture, but perhaps cooked with a milder marinade and BBQ sauce that left the meat juicy, yet not as flavorful as I like.  The Dudes were ready for that as the table had 3 bottle rockets of sauce ready for squirting.  Spicy, Hickory and Apple were the flavors.  I tasted each and found the Apple to be the most intriguing and tasty.  It had a nice fruity sweetness that was distinct from the other undertones of vinegar, molasses and brown sugar.  A long squirt dousing the pile of pork quickly resolved that issue.  

From that point on the entire experience was pleasurable and satisfying.  I liked the Apple BBQ Sauce so much I added some to the chips, and if I had ordered the fries, would have used it rather than ketchup.  These sauces are for sale at the counter.  

While great BBQ is hard to come by in this neck of the woods, Smoke 'n Dudes provides something very close to what I love - fall off the bone, spicy, tangy well grilled and smoked meat that assault the salivary glands and squeeze them dry.  
What I would have given for the right beer and shot of Dickel at that moment! Alas, this was lunchtime in Bensalem, and that fantasy would have to await another time or place.

  BYOB for dinner???

Curiosity finally got the best of me after going by Sophie's Kitchen several times to and from our monthly visit to First Oriental Supermarket to stock up on Asian groceries. The earlier Viet cafe at that corner was not all that good, so it was with a pleasant sense of change that this new operation caught my attention. 

We walked over after shopping and found our way up to the second floor dining room. It looked basically the same as before with modern simple decor and large windowed walls overlooking Washington Avenue. There was a family at the middle table, so we grabbed one against the inner wall where we all could maintain some privacy. The guy overseeing things came over with menus, took our drink order (water) and placed white curved plates and flatware wrapped in black cloth napkins at the head of the table. Classy for lunch. 

We ordered beef skewers and mee katang, a fat noodle dish with veggies. Both arrived with color and energy glistening from them. The beef was a thin sliced, well marinaded BBQ, and grilled just enough to be tender, moist, lightly crisp and delicious. Really good. The flat noods had a wonderful sauce, subtly savory and sweet with plenty of greens mixed in. A little sriracha on the edge of the plate for dipping and we had an excellent dish. Loved it. 

While the menu was somewhat limited, we thoroughly enjoyed the food and bright atmosphere on an overcast day. Prices were reasonable ($24 w tip). Given it's convenience to the market next door, we could become regulars of this appetizing Cambodian house.

This old diner located at the intersection of Limekiln Pike and Mt. Carmel Avenue in Glenside, PA, is a miniature of today's full monte diner experience. The counter has only 6 spinners, and the main dining rooms together, less than a dozen tables. But, size does not tell the story of Moonlight Diner. This place has been running since the middle of the last century feeding this neighborhood with solid victuals and homemade desserts. That I was the only customer by the time I finished breakfast does not reflect on the quality of the experience.

I sat on the last stool on the right overlooking the refrigerator full of juice and milk and the kitchen door. The friendly server approached with a menu and inquiry about drinks. Coffee with a small glass of milk arrived in front of me two minutes later. I order their Farmers Omelet (onion, tomato, mushroom, bacon, feta cheese extra with home fries folded in) and rye toast, and took a phone call as I waited. The platter was placed before me before the call ended. 

First bite alerted me to the need for a shake of black pepper and squirt of Frank's Hot Sauce, which I promptly applied. Those adjustments did the trick and it was smooth sailing from there. The taste and texture were excellent and it was a completely filling breakfast. Everything blended well together and seemed in perfect harmony. Coffee mug refills were forthcoming when required. Service was timely and cordial. They treated this stranger well. 

Much appreciated.

As a first timer, I was pleasantly surprised by Steam, the railroad car-looking restaurant/pub on 2nd Street Pike in Southampton, Pa.  

The Friday night crowd was loud, but friendly.  The bar was long and packed.  The dining tables seemed to turn over quickly enough without a reservation.  We waited about 20 minutes for a deuce hightop mid-floor.  The service dudes were all "can do!" 

My burger was very good and required knife and fork as I could never open my jaws wide enough to capture it in a bite.  My companion's sliders were also tasty.  The French Onion Soup was decent, but not the strongest entry of the evening.  

Steam (suggestive of the locomotive steam engine), appears to have a successful formula.  Space, fairly priced drinks($5 margaritas, beer specials), a long happy hour, and an above average bar menu.  Live music, too.  

I will likely be back.

I've had a light addiction for tuna hoagies of late, and this Friday afternoon I found myself thinking about satisfying it again. Yelp alerted me to a Jersey Mike's down on Street Road in the Giant shopping center in Feasterville, about seven miles away. I found their app and ordered a standard sized sub with sesame seed roll, and added tomato, mayo, black pepper, lettuce, banana hot and sweet peppers. I drove down and arrived as the staff was finishing my order. It was right on time.

Back at the office I opened the twisted end wrapper and beheld a beautiful sandwich, if shorter than expected. First bite disclosed that the roll was superlative with bakery freshness, great texture and ideal flavor. On the other hand, the tuna tasted "thin," and lacking substance - not really all that good. The banana peppers and sweets were no where to be found. The actual eating experience was satisfactory despite these drawbacks, but could have been so much better had there been more quality control on the tuna salad and double checking the desired ingredients. 

Overall, Jersey Mike's is somewhere in the middle of the pack of chain sub shop tuna hoagies available locally. Generally, mom and pop delis do them better, but there is wider diversity in how the tuna is prepared and more inquiry is needed to be sure each recipe has what you want in your sandwich. 

3.5 STARS

Bukhara Restaurant & Tandoori Grill sits on southbound Route 130 in Burlington City, NJ, in a worn out mini strip center at the intersection with Wood Street. From the outside you might decide not to go in, but that would be a case of judging a good book by it's rummy cover. 

Within is a small and attractive dining room with white clothed tables and large buffet along the wall. For lunch the buffet provides eight hot curry-oriented choices, a few sweet desserts, basmati rice, with naan coming from the kitchen oven, for $9.99. I tend to avoid buffets due to incentive to over indulge, but the only other dishes available on the menu seemed to be a personal portion of one of the entrees on the buffet table, @ $7.99, plus naan. So, the cost was the same whether I ate too much or just enough. Alas, the cost of principled consumption. 

No matter, my buttered chicken was quite good in its mild yellow creamy sauce. The bird was a little dry, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. The naan arrived at the table hot, steaming and absorbtive. In the absence of rice it did excellent work as the spongy spoon lifting the extra curry to my mouth so as to leave nothing but crumbs behind. My lunch mate had nothing but praise for the buffet, and all the rice and naan desired. 

There are better Indian kitchens, but none in the immediate vicinity. So, when the urge tugs this is not a bad option for scratching your itch. 

3.5 Big Ones!

Waterside Cafe & Diner sits in the street front building of the Waterside apartment complex in Bensalem, PA. There are only 5 parking spaces for customers who aren't disabled, so they must expect that most people eating there will live in that small neighborhood. The quality of their food suggests that they will soon outgrow their restrictive environment and need to expand their parking facilities to accommodate their anticipated success.

The dining room offers about a dozen tables and a counter with six stools. I sat on one of them as a sole diner, facing the work area. A server walked over with menu and inquiry about something to drink. At that time of morning, coffee was the only thing on my mind. It was strong and bracing. The breakfast choices were extensive, and I selected the Veggie Omelet & Home Fries with Rye Toast. 

It was all quite good, with a load of fresh greens and melted cheddar. Including the half plate of potatoes and two slices of buttered bread, it was too much for me to consume, but a strong tasty breakfast all the way down. Service was first rate. 

While this stretch of Bensalem is off my beaten path, I look forward to the occasion that leads me back there so I can sample more morning suggestions @ Waterfront.

Sitting in the long shadow of Bowman's Tower, the Conservation Corps public works project in the 1930s putting people back to work during the Depression, the tavern on beautiful River Road approaching New Hope, PA, is a well executed colonial style pub. It has a dark paneled dining room, and revolutionary edged barroom that capture what it may have been like to be part of the independence effort in the 18th Century around here. It really feels good to be part of that, even if just for lunch. 

I was there for the first time in at least a decade, and the new ownership can be proud of what it has maintained, and created in terms of atmosphere and ethos. Their menu is wholesome with wide choice of apps, sandwiches, soup, salad, burgers, and trop cher entrees. When I spied a brussel sprouts side dish and potato bisque, I knew where I was going. Two of my favorite ingredients in any dish - cream based potato soup and kale/brussels side salad were too special to pass up. Even better, my lunchmate went with the scallops main course and slid a couple onto my plate for the tasting. Yes!

Everything was very good to amazing. The bisque seemed to have mushroom puree mixed with the pomme de terre, making for a savory rendition. Delicious. The balance between the slightly bitter kale, and the more subtle brussel sprouts was a bit off to my taste. It needed more petit choux and less kale to really make me happy (in fact, the kale was not in the a la carte sides description, but was definitely in the dish). The seared scallops was true to their word, and just mildly grilled, with sweet potato puree, caramelized apples, pancetta, almonds and cider brown butter drizzle. It was a real treat, but a heavy lift for lunch @ $27. 

Bowman's Tavern is deep with atmosphere, and successfully carries out its promise of colonial charm, local produce where possible, and skilled hands in the kitchen. It is easy to imagine the General and his officers discussing plans for the next battles around the bar, or at the dinner table in the back room.

Fill A Bagel & Bread is a locally owned/operated bagel shop on Pennsylvania Avenue, Oreland, PA. It is their second store, and they have been a success baking and selling their goods to the surrounding communities for decades now. I was in the area after an appointment and hungry enough for breakfast as I drove back to my Bucks County office. A cuppa hot java and an onion bagel smeared with veggie cream cheese punched my ticket. 

What about the bagel? 

Well, it wasn't the best I've had, but far from the worst. Although fresh, I found its texture too dense, like perhaps the dough was kneaded too long before boiling/baking. The circumference of the rolled and twisted dough was smaller than ideal, and lacking air pockets that help lighten the bite and chew and allow the veggie cream cheese to afford more balance with the slightly sourdough flavor. The taste was alright, but the texture was not what I prefer. Plenty of roasted onion flakes all around. Service, friendly and efficient.

I agree with the comments that the cost/benefit is somewhat askew for the nature of the business, location and overall quality. I have paid less for better bagels and coffee in bigger towns and cities.
