Yet, I don't know their running costs, and no doubt the shop reflects its financial need to pay the bills and make a reasonable profit. 

So, I find myself at the borderline between three and four stars attempt to find the right equipoise. I land at 
3.5 Stars, and allow the app to round it up to 4. 

I would certainly return given the opportunity.

Chinatown Café is an refugee from Race Street, Philadelphia.  Owner Cary is a Bucks County pioneer, coming to this frontier lacking in quality Chinese cuisine, and opening his shop several years ago because he saw an opportunity to be one of the first quality chefs to start a business. He knew there was a great need, and the socio/economic means to support it.  

He has succeeded.  Chinatown Café stand above most of the rest of the Chinese restos in Central Bucks, if not the entire domain.  The quality, taste, and overall gestalt of his shop are exceptional.  From soup through fortune cookie, the dining experience feels wholesome and well suited to the Chinese/American palate.  Cary knows what people like, and provides it at a high level.  When inside his world, you feel you will be exiting onto 11th Street.  

This week I went in for lunch.  Although there is a lunch special menu, after my recent experience with an awful lunch at another place, I did not want to go that way.  So, I ordered off the main menu - Duck Fried Rice.  I knew that Cary was a duck wizard.  Out came a huge steaming platter loaded with well seasoned rice and big pieces of roast duck.  It was enough for 6 people.  It was moist, flavorful, and exactly what I wanted.  Just Ducky! 

Cary and I chatted a bit about our businesses, and when he realized I spent time in China, he brought out a bowl of Wonton Soup for me to sample.  Very nice of him to do so.  The broth was rich, golden and as good as my Jewish grandmother made. Swimming easily in the bowl were several fancy goldfish wontons, with nearly translucent skin, and silky tails.  Stirring the mix gave the impression that the wontons were alive and enjoying themselves peacefully in a koi pond.  I think this style wonton is actually called, "Butterfly Wonton," but they look like goldfish to me. 

The last remains of the Duck Fried Rice sits in my refrigerator awaiting consumption.  I have enjoyed it daily since the visit.  I have to finish it before I can go back for more. 

Four Stars with a Bullet.  I have to see what Chinatown Café does not the spicy end of the spectrum to be completely in love.

We stopped for Saturday lunch after car hunting nearby.  Mirim Japanese and Korean Restaurant was the most interesting choice in the area, so we drove over to their location in a small commercial strip that also housed fried chicken, pizza and Chinese massage parlors for future exploration. 

We quickly discovered that lunch menu was not available on weekends, so we ordered two dishes at dinner prices.  We went with Dolsot Bulgogi and Pork Katsu, which came with the traditional Banshan small dishes that accompany most Korean meals.  They were all well spiced pickled veggies, cabbage and sprouts that went well alone and with the spicy boiling beef bulgogi and the nicely breaded and pan fried katsu.  Everything was done well, and service was adequate, if lacking personality. 

The room was divided into three areas; front dining room with booths, rear dining room with tables and a sushi bar.  Mirim had been there for a long time, and the water stained ceiling and the floor had seen better days.  Still, the kitchen knew what it was doing, and we were satisfied with our meals.  We took home what we couldn't finish, and enjoyed it with dinner. 

I had visited Mirim many years ago and remember it as being in better shape than it was yesterday.  In the interim many more purely Korean houses have opened between there and Center City Philadelphia.  These newer places have the advantage of youth and the growing appreciation for Korean cuisine - especially their awesome fried chicken.  Mirim could get its groove back if it took a look at what was going on around them, made some needed upgrades in facility and menu choices, and considered being a purely Korean shop.

Iron Hill Brewery & Restaurant is a new entree among the many eating establishments in the expanded Village @ Newtown Shopping Center, focusing on mostly traditional tavern fare to go with their house brews from the stainless works in the rear of their premises. As a local outfit headquartered in Wilmington, Delaware, it is good to see how attractive their plant is and how successful their business model has been. 

We used Yelp to get on their wait-list on a Sunday evening, and when we arrived they had us on the screen and we were seated immediately at a high top quad against a wall. The building was beautifully appointed with lots of wood and leather, high ceiling, and huge glass wall in the back to show off the brewery operation. The space was well thought out for the comfort and interest of the customer. Our server was friendly and knowledgeable, and aimed to please.

Son & I were thinking burgers and sandwiches, but I was also tempted by the seasonal Butternut Apple Soup on the appetizer menu. So, the young one went for a Grilled Chicken Sandwich w Fries, and the old man jumped at the Pub Burger w Fries (medium). First, the soup was really good with a cream base. The flavors of the squash and apple both came through. So nice! The burger was as requested - juicy, with gouda and jack cheese, bacon and aioli smear on the brioche style roll. Delicious, even if the bottom of the roll gave up the ghost halfway through the meal due to the dampness of the load. I had to finish with knife & fork. Son 'O Mine was happy with his meal, but didn't think it was exceptional. Fries were hot and crisp. 

I sampled their Little Red Wagon suds. Maybe it was a kid's drink, but I liked the subtle strawberry rhubarb sour taste. Good complement to the rest of my meal. 

Iron Hill is a big improvement to the restaurant scene in Newtown, along with several other eateries in the Village @ Newtown. It contributes to establishing our community as a legitimate destination for the hungry and parched. So many quality choices now available to us. 

Check it out.

This sports bar in Richboro, PA, is a fun place to watch Eagles football. It is a large space with a long U-shaped bar, surrounded by HDTVs high on the walls. The bartenders are so busy they don't have a moment to follow the action, but they are friendly and don't lose their cool. 

Prices are reasonable for a bar that makes it bones primarily around sporting events. Most bar food (burgers, quesadillas, soups, salads, sandwiches) can be had for $10 or less. Beer selection is not focused on crafties, but there are a few in the house, while most of the usual suspects are on tap.  My pint of Miller Lite was $3 and change. 

The house erupted each time the Eagles made a play, and went berserk when they pulled out the win of the Rams. There was a collective groan when Carson Wentz was injured. Of course, there were a couple of people in too deep with drink, who were obnoxious, but they were led outside by the firm arm of house security. 

My chicken quesadilla was pretty good. Loaded with chicken and cheese, it was a solid app to get me through the game. It was exactly what I expected from the neighborhood sports bar.  I was particularly pleased that the lovely barkeeps made no attempt to refill my beer glass after I let them know I only wanted one. They were cool with someone who did not want more to drink, but only was there to enjoy the game with fellow fans.

I tipped them accordingly.

Gino runs his shop, Mamma Rosa's Restaurant, like he was inviting each customer into his home for a meal.  The space is a converted/expanded residence from a time before zoning made such mixed uses impossible in most places.  It is cozy, warm, and bright, sort of like a old summer home in Ortley Beach or Lavalette. 

I sat at a kitchen table and ordered what Gino suggested was one of the better things on the menu, a Chicken Parm Sandwich.  It arrived about 10 minutes later; a fat breast, butterflied, with rich tomato gravy, grated cheese, on a very good oven toasted half torpedo.  It was excellent and required knife and fork to be eaten without losing the back end.  

Gino introduced himself and we chatted about his bio and how he came to be a restauranteur. The entire experience was very personal, and it was easy to slip and stay in the embrace of your Italian grandfather's kitchen.

Time to upgrade Ms. Philly Grill after a return breakfast visit this week. 

The place looks about the same as when last here several years ago. Still clean and full of red and white leatherette booths with chrome around the trim. This time staff was more attentive, bringing orders from the kitchen promptly and offering to refill the coffee mug as they passed around the dining room. 

My Hercules Omelet was a three egger variant of a Greek, but with Gyro meat (beef/lamb) in place of sausage, and spinach, onion, tomato and feta. Large half plate of home fries alongside. I liked it a lot, especially with a squirt of hot sauce all around. Coffee was strong, too, with the requested milk rather than creamers. 

It is quite possible that the same regulars I saw last time where still hanging out. My server looked like the woman who helped me before. She seemed to take a proprietary interest in the operation. 

Glad I returned and was able to write a more positive review. It also provides me with another good joint to eat when in the vicinity.
